[[J─лvana-dharma-yoga: Introduction Source: prekshaa]]

рд╡рд┐рд╕реНрддрд╛рд░рдГ (рджреНрд░рд╖реНрдЯреБрдВ рдиреЛрджреНрдпрдореН)

[On the occasion of D V GundappaтАЩs forty-fifth death anniversary, Prekshaa is delighted to publish the first episode of a new series тАУ a modern English translation of DVGтАЩs Kendra Sahitya Akademi Award-winning work, Bhagavad-g─лt─Б-t─Бtparya or J─лvana-dharma-yoga. Translated from the original Kannada treatise by Sri. Raghavendra Hebbalalu and Smt. Sreelalitha Rupanagudi. тАФEditor]

Invocation

рдЬрдЧрджреНрд░рдгрд╛рдЩреНрдЧрдгреЗ рдпрд╕реНрдп
рд╕реНрдорд░рдгрдВ рдЬрдпрдХрд╛рд░рдгрдВред

рд╢реНрд░реАрдХреГрд╖реНрдгрдмреНрд░рд╣реНрдордгреЗ рдирдордГрее

To him whose remembrance in
the world-battlefield is the cause of victory,
to that charioteer of P─Бrtha,
salutations to Brahman known as ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa!

INTRODUCTION

реР рддрддреНрд╕рддреНрдкрджрд╕реВрдЪреНрдпрд╛рдп рд╡рд┐рд╖реНрдгрд╡реЗ рдкрд░рдорд╛рддреНрдордиреЗред
рдЬрдЧрдЬреНрдЬреАрд╡реЗрд╢рддрддреНрддреНрд╡рд╛рдп рд╢реНрд░реАрдХреГрд╖реНрдгрдмреНрд░рд╣реНрдордгреЗ рдирдордГрее 1

To him indicated by the syllables Om Tat Sat,
to the all-pervading Viс╣гс╣Зu, to the Supreme Self,
to the Essence of jagat (universe), j─лva (individual), and, ─л┼Ыa (god)
salutations to Brahman known as ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa!

рдорд░реНрддреНрдпрд╛рддрд┐рдорд░реНрддреНрдпрд▓реАрд▓рд╛рдп рдкреГрдердЧреНрдЬреАрд╡рд╕реНрд╡рдмрдВрдзрд╡реЗред
рдзрд░реНрдорд╛рдзрд┐рдзрд░реНрдордЧреБрд░рд╡реЗ рд╢реНрд░реАрдХреГрд╖реНрдгрдмреНрд░рд╣реНрдордгреЗ рдирдордГрее 2

To him whose l─лla is both human and superhuman,
to the own friend of every j─лva,
to the guru who teaches dharma and adhi-dharma (that which transcends dharma),
salutations to Brahman known as ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa!

рдПрдХреЛ рдмрд╣реВрдирд╛рдВ рдпрдГ рдХрд╛рдорд╛рдиреН рджрджрд╛рддрд┐ рдмрд╣реБрд░реВрдкрддрдГред
рд░рд╛рд╕рд┐рдХреНрдпрдореВрд░реНрддрдпреЗ рддрд╕реНрдореИ рд╢реНрд░реАрдХреГрд╖реНрдгрдмреНрд░рд╣реНрдордгреЗ рдирдордГрее 3

He who satisfies the desires of many in myriad ways,
to the embodiment of aesthetic enjoyment,
salutations to Brahman known as ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa!

рдирд╛рдирд╛рдордиреБрд╖реНрдпрд╣реГрджрдпрд╕реНрдкрдиреНрджрд╕реВрдХреНрд╖реНрдорд╛рдиреБрдХрдореНрдкрд┐рдиреЗред
рддрддреНрддрджреНрдзрд┐рддреЛрдкрд╛рдпрд╡рд┐рджреЗ рд╢реНрд░реАрдХреГрд╖реНрдгрдмреНрд░рд╣реНрдордгреЗ рдирдордГрее 4

To him who resonates with the subtle heart-throbs of billions of beings,
to the knower of the way to each oneтАЩs welfare,
salutations to Brahman known as ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa!

рдкреНрд░рддрд┐рдЬреАрд╡рдкреГрдердЧреНрд╡реНрдпрд╛рдзрд┐рдирд┐рджрд╛рдиреИрдХрдЪрд┐рдХрд┐рддреНрд╕рд┐рдиреЗред
рд╕рд░реНрд╡рд░реЛрдЧреИрдХрд╡реИрджреНрдпрд╛рдп рд╢реНрд░реАрдХреГрд╖реНрдгрдмреНрд░рд╣реНрдордгреЗ рдирдордГрее 5

To him who heals by diagnosing the unique disease of each j─лva,
to the one physician to myriad maladies,
salutations to Brahman known as ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa!

рдЬрдЧрджреНрд░рдгрд╛рдВрдЧрдгреЗ рдпрд╕реНрдп рд╕реНрдорд░рдгрдВ рдЬрдпрдХрд╛рд░рдгрдВред
рдкрд╛рд░реНрдерд╕рд╛рд░рдердпреЗ рддрд╕реНрдореИ рд╢реНрд░реАрдХреГрд╖реНрдгрдмреНрд░рд╣реНрдордгреЗ рдирдордГрее 6

To him, whose remembrance in
the world-battlefield is the cause of victory,
to that charioteer of P─Бrtha,
salutations to Brahman known as ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa!

рддрджреНрдЧреАрддрд╛рд░реНрдерд╛рдиреБрд╡рд╛рджрд╛рдп рдпрддреНрдпрддреЗ рддрддреНрдкреНрд░рд╕рд╛рджрддрдГред
рд╕рд╛рдорд╛рдиреНрдпрдЬрдирдореБрджреНрджрд┐рд╢реНрдп рдордпрд╛ рдХрд░реНрдгрд╛рдЯ рднрд╛рд╖рдпрд╛рее 7

By his grace, I venture to translate
his G─лt─Б into the Kannaс╕Нa tongue
for the benefit of common folk

рд╡реНрдпрд╛рдЦреНрдпрд╛рддрд╛ рдмрд╣реБрднрд┐рд░реНрдЧреАрддрд╛ рдирд╛рдирд╛рдорддрд╡рд┐рднреЗрджрддрдГред
рд╡рд┐рддрд░реНрдХрд╛рдВрд╕реНрддреБ рд╡рд┐рд╣рд╛рдпрд╛рддреНрд░ рдЛрдЬреНрд╡рд░реНрдерд╢реНрдЪрд┐рдиреНрддреНрдпрддреЗ рдордпрд╛рее 8

Commented upon by many, has the G─лt─Б been,
by those of various schools of thought
Abandoning convoluted logic,
I reflect upon its straight meaning in this work.

рдЬреАрд╡рдирд╡реНрдпрд╡рд╣рд╛рд░реЗрд╖реБ рд╕рд░реНрд╡реЗрд╖реНрд╡рдкрд┐ рдЪ рд╕рд░реНрд╡рджрд╛ред
рддрддреНрддрд╛рддреНрдкрд░реНрдпрд╛рдиреНрд╡рдпрд╛рджреЗрд╡ рдЧреАрддрд╛рдкрд╛рдардлрд▓реЛрджрдпрдГрее 9

In matters of life, in all of them,
through the constant application of its purport,
dawns the result of G─лt─Б-study

рддрд╕реНрдорд╛рджрд╕реНрдорд┐рдиреН рдкреНрд░рд╡реГрддреНрддреЛрд╣рдордиреБрд╖реНрдард╛рдирдкреНрд░рдпреЛрдЧрджреГрдХреНред
рд╕рдиреНрдорд╛рд░реНрдЧрджреГрд╖реНрдЯрд┐рд╢реБрджреНрдзрд┐рдореН рд╡реЛ рджрджреНрдпрд╛рджрдВрддрд░реНрдЧреБрд░реБрд░реНрд╣рд░рд┐рдГрее 10

Therefore, have I embarked upon this,
having seen the benefit of the G─лt─Б in practice
May the inner guru, ┼Ъr─лhari, give
all of you the clarity to see the right path

рдмреНрд░рд╣реНрдордкрддреНрддрдирд╡реАрдереАрд╖реБ рдЪрд░рддрд╛ рдЬреАрд╡рд╕рдореНрднреНрд░рдорд╛рдиреНред
рдкрд╢реНрдпрддрд╛ рд╣рд┐рддрдирд┐рд╢реНрд╢реНрд░реЗрдгреАрдорд┐рдЪреНрдЫрддрд╛ рд╢рд┐рд╡рднрд┐рдХреНрд╖реБрдгрд╛рее 11
рдХреГрддрдВ рд╕реНрд╡рдЪрд┐рддреНрддрд╢реБрджреНрдзреНрдпрд░реНрдердВ рди рдЬреНрдЮрдВрдордиреНрдпрддрдпрд╛рддреНрд╡рд┐рджрдВред
рдХреНрд╖рдореНрдпрддрд╛рдВ рд╕рд╛рд╣рд╕рдВ рд╕рджреНрднрд┐рдГ рдХреГрдкрдпрд╛ рдЪрд╛рд╡рд▓реЛрдХреНрдпрддрд╛рдореНрее 12

By ┼Ъiva-bhikс╣гu, who while wandering
in the streets of BrahmanтАЩs city
witnessed the agitations of the j─лvas
and being then desirous of bettering their welfare,
has this work been created тАУ to clarify his own mind
and surely not due to any pretence of knowledge
May those learned forgive this audacity
and kindly deign to see this work!

~

р▓Ур▓Вр▓др▓др│Нр▓╕р▓др│Нр▓кр▓жр▓Ър▓┐р▓Вр▓др│Нр▓пр▓и-
р▓ир▓Вр▓др▓В р▓╡р▓┐р▓╢р│Нр▓╡р▓кр│Нр▓░р▓кр▓Вр▓Ър▓▓р│Ар▓▓р│Лр▓жр▓Вр▓др▓Вред
р▓Хр▓╛р▓Вр▓др▓В р▓Ър▓┐р▓др│Нр▓кр│Нр▓░р▓нр│Жр▓пр▓┐р▓В р▓Ьр▓Ч-
р▓Хр▓Вр▓др▓░р│Нр▓пр▓╛р▓ор▓┐ р▓кр│Нр▓░р▓нр│Б р▓кр│Нр▓░р▓╕р▓ир│Нр▓ир▓В р▓Хр│Гр▓╖р│Нр▓гр▓Врее 1

The joyous ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa is meditated upon with the words Om Tat Sat
He is the infinite, who pervades the l─лl─Б of the universe.
He is attractive by the light of consciousness.
He is the lord and the inner controller of the world.

р▓ор▓░р│Нр▓др│Нр▓пр▓╛р▓др▓┐р▓ор▓░р│Нр▓др│Нр▓пр▓▓р│Ар▓▓р▓В
р▓ир▓┐р▓др│Нр▓пр▓В р▓зр▓░р│Нр▓ор▓╛р▓зр▓┐р▓зр▓░р│Нр▓ор▓др▓др│Нр▓др│Нр▓╡р▓╛р▓зр▓╛р▓░р▓Вред
р▓кр│Нр▓░р▓др│Нр▓пр▓Хр│Нр▓╖р▓кр▓░р▓ор▓жр│Ир▓╡р▓В
р▓╕р▓др│Нр▓пр▓жр▓┐ р▓ир▓бр│Жр▓пр▓┐р▓╕р│Бр▓Чр│Ж р▓ир▓ор│Нр▓ор▓ир▓░р│Нр▓Ьр│Бр▓ир▓╕р│Вр▓др▓Врее 2

His l─лl─Бs are both human and superhuman.
He is the eternal one and the support of
principles of dharma and adhi-dharma.
He is the manifestation of the Supreme divinity
May that charioteer of Arjuna lead us to Truth!

р▓Пр▓Хр│Л р▓╡р▓┐р▓жр▓зр▓╛р▓др▓┐ р▓мр▓╣р│В-
р▓ир▓╛р▓В р▓Хр▓╛р▓ор▓╛р▓ир│Н р▓Ор▓Вр▓м р▓╡р│Зр▓жр▓╡р▓Ър▓ир▓В р▓кр│Нр▓░р▓др│Нр▓п-ред
р▓Хр│Нр▓╖р│Ар▓Хр▓░р▓┐р▓╕р▓┐р▓ж р▓мр▓╣р│Бр▓░р│Вр▓кр▓В
р▓╢р│Нр▓░р│Ар▓Хр│Гр▓╖р│Нр▓гр▓В р▓др│Лр▓░р│Бр▓Чр│Жр▓ор▓Чр│Ж р▓ор▓Вр▓Чр▓▓р▓Чр▓др▓┐р▓пр▓Врее 3

He epitomises the Vedic statement тАУ
тАЬEko vidadh─Бti bah┼лn─Бс╣Б k─Бm─БnтАЭ
[The one establishes the desires of many]
May he of many forms, ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa,
show us the path to the auspicious!

р▓Чр│Лр▓кр│Ар▓ор▓зр│Нр▓пр▓жр▓┐ р▓░р▓╕р▓┐р▓Хр▓В
р▓др▓╛р▓кр▓╕р▓░р│Кр▓│р│Н р▓др▓кр▓╕р▓┐ р▓░р▓╛р▓Ьр▓др▓Вр▓др│Нр▓░р▓жр▓┐ р▓╢р│Бр▓Хр│Нр▓░р▓Вред
р▓╕р│Вр▓кр▓╛р▓пр▓В р▓░р▓гр▓░р▓Вр▓Чр▓жр│К-
р▓│р▓╛р▓кр▓др│Нр▓╕р▓Цр▓ир▓╛р▓╢р│Нр▓░р▓┐р▓др▓░р│Нр▓Чр│Ж р▓╕р▓░р│Нр▓╡р▓В р▓Хр│Гр▓╖р│Нр▓гр▓Врее 4

The enjoyer amidst the gopik─Бs,
the ascetic among ascetics, ┼Ъukr─Бc─Бrya in polity,
Expedience in the battlefield,
a friend indeed to those in need тАУ
┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa is all!

р▓кр│Бр▓░р│Бр▓╖р▓╛р▓░р│Нр▓ер▓Ър▓др│Бр▓╖р│Нр▓Хр▓╡ р▓ир▓┐р▓Ь-
р▓Ър▓░р▓┐р▓др│Жр▓Чр▓│р│Кр▓│р│Н р▓Хр▓гр│Нр▓Чр│Ж р▓др│Лр▓░р│Нр▓ж р▓ир▓╛р▓ир▓╛ р▓Ьр│Ар▓╡р│Лред
р▓жр│Нр▓зр▓░р▓гр│Лр▓кр▓╛р▓пр▓╕р▓ор▓░р│Нр▓ер▓В
р▓Чр│Бр▓░р│Б р▓Хр│Гр▓╖р│Нр▓гр▓В р▓ир│Жр▓▓р▓╕р▓┐ р▓ир▓▓р▓┐р▓Чр│Ж р▓ор▓ир│Нр▓ор▓╛р▓ир▓╕р▓жр│Кр▓│р│Нрее 4

He demonstrated the fourfold ideal of life in his own life
The One capable of elevating all the j─лvas
May that guru ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa reside and rejoice in my mind!

р▓╣р▓░р▓┐р▓пр▓╡р▓др▓╛р▓░р▓Чр▓│р│Кр▓│р│Н р▓пр▓жр│Б-
р▓╡р▓░р▓ир▓╡р│Лр▓▓р▓╛р▓░р│Н р▓ор▓ир│Бр▓Ьр▓╣р│Гр▓жр▓пр▓ор▓░р│Нр▓ор▓╡р▓ир▓░р▓┐р▓др▓ир│Нред
р▓Чр│Бр▓░р│Бр▓╡р│Жр▓ор▓Чр▓жр▓░р▓┐р▓В р▓Хр│Гр▓╖р│Нр▓гр▓В
р▓зр▓░р▓гр▓┐р▓п р▓Чр│Бр▓гр▓╡р▓░р▓┐р▓пр▓жр▓╡р▓и р▓Хр│Гр▓╖р▓┐р▓пр▓┐р▓Вр▓жр▓╣р│Бр▓жр│Зр▓Врее 6

Among the avat─Бras of ┼Ъr─лhari,
who other than the best among the Yadus could fathom
the mystery of the human mind?
Thence is ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa our guru
What can come of agriculture to him
who knows not the quality of the earth?

р▓ор▓╛р▓ир▓╡р▓╣р│Гр▓ир│Нр▓ор▓░р│Нр▓ор▓ж р▓╡р▓┐-
р▓Ьр│Нр▓Юр▓╛р▓ир▓┐ р▓╢р│Нр▓░р│Ар▓Хр│Гр▓╖р│Нр▓гр▓ир▓╡р▓ир│Ж р▓нр▓╡р▓Чр▓жр▓нр▓┐р▓╖р▓Ьр▓Вред
р▓ор▓╛р▓ир▓╕р▓Хр▓╛р▓пр▓Хр▓░р│Лр▓Чр▓ир▓┐-
р▓жр▓╛р▓ир▓╡ р▓Хр▓╛р▓гр▓жр▓и р▓╡р│Ир▓жр│Нр▓пр▓╡р│Жр▓Вр▓др│Бр▓кр▓Хр▓░р▓┐р▓Хр│Бр▓Врее 7

The scientist who divines the secret of manтАЩs heart,
nay, the healer of the malady of mundane existence!
How can a doctor who cannot diagnose the disease
of the workings of the mind be of any use?

р▓кр│Нр▓░р▓др│Нр▓пр▓Хр│Нр▓╖р▓зр▓░р│Нр▓ор▓ир│Н р▓Ер▓Вр▓др│Жр▓пр│Ж
р▓ор│Вр▓░р│Нр▓др▓┐р▓ор▓жр▓зр▓┐р▓зр▓░р│Нр▓ор▓ир│Н р▓Ер▓Цр▓┐р▓▓р▓╕р│Бр▓▓р▓нр│Лр▓кр▓╛р▓╕р│Нр▓пр▓Вред
р▓кр▓╛р▓░р│Нр▓ер▓Чр│Бр▓░р│Б р▓кр▓░р▓ор▓др│Зр▓Ьр▓В
р▓ир▓┐р▓др│Нр▓пр▓В р▓др▓ир│Нр▓ир▓бр▓┐р▓Чр│Ж р▓ир▓ор▓Чр│Ж р▓др│Лр▓░р│Бр▓Чр│Ж р▓кр▓ер▓ор▓Врее 8

He, the epitome of dharma, who embodies adhi-dharma,
is easily worshipped by all

Does not every human being have the natural desire to live well or be able to lead a good life? What is тАШgoodтАЩ in our life? What is beautiful? What is valuable? What is the meaning of good? How do we establish the value of a thing? How can life be made good? Those desirous of finding answers to these questions can benefit immensely by an ardent study of this work тАУ the Bhagavad-g─лt─Б. Who or what is a j─лva? What is the relationship between a j─лva and the world? What is Divine? What is the relation between j─лva and the Divine? These are some of the questions for which answers can be found in the G─лt─Б.

Our ancestors have referred to the Bhagavad-g─лt─Б as a mokс╣гa-┼Ы─Бstra (a treatise on liberation). The G─лt─Б is indeed a mokс╣гa-┼Ы─Бstra; but it is a j─лvana-┼Ы─Бstra (treatise on living) as well. A temple comprises the garbha-gс╣Ыha housing the m┼лrti, the mukha-maс╣Зс╕Нapa (front porch of the temple), the pradakс╣гiс╣Зa-patha, and the gopura. While there may be one who can scale the tall gopura and touch its golden kala┼Ыa at the top, the other nine hundred and ninety nine will be content with doing the pradakс╣гiс╣Зa, getting a dar┼Ыana of the m┼лrti, and partaking of the pras─Бda. Similarly, while there may be one person benefiting from the instruction on mokс╣гa, nine hundred and ninety nine people will derive benefit from the instruction on dharma. Essential lessons on improving oneтАЩs life graduallyтАФbe it for a scholar or a layman; be it for those well-settled or those who are struggling with difficulty, be it for men or for womenтАФcan be found in the Bhagavad-g─лt─Б. A healthy respect for oneтАЩs life, enthusiasm to do oneтАЩs own duty, courage in the face of adversity, faith that brings solace during moments of doubt тАУ are some of the treasures that we can glean from the G─лt─Б.

The translators wish to express their thanks to ┼Ъat─Бvadh─Бni R Ganesh for his valuable feedback and to Hari Ravikumar for his astute edits.

[[The Structure of the G─лt─Б Source: prekshaa]]

Prerequisites to the Study of the G─лt─Б

A word of caution before we begin. All parts of the G─лt─Б cannot be understood at the same level of clarity by everyone. ShouldnтАЩt instruction befit the aspirantтАЩs qualification? The amount of benefit we derive from the G─лt─Б is directly proportional to our levels of faith, moral readiness, and intellectual ability. Anything beyond our capability might not be understood by us. So it would simply be our loss if we discarded the G─лt─Б just because we could not understand a sentence or section of the treatise during our first or second reading, or because something did not seem right to our mind. Taking what we can grasp at the moment and reflecting upon it enables us to subsequently understand higher levels of meaning. If our study has to be fruitful, we must be equipped with the prerequisites of patience and faith. Mah─Бtm─Б Gandhi has referred to the G─лt─Б as his mother. The kind of unquestioned faith a child has in her motherтАЩs words, the kind of unquestioned trust a child has in her motherтАЩs cooking are the kinds of faith and trust we need, without which a great workтАЩs essence may go unattained.

The subject of the G─лt─Б is profound, subtle, and knotty. To understand it, we need a flight of stairs-like arrangement. WeтАФcommon human beingsтАФmay be unable to explain the essence completely in one sentence or ascend in one step. The essence of life can be likened to a mountain. Those desirous of climbing it must be ready to do so step by step, resting wherever necessary, breathing in and understanding the rarefied airs as they ascend to the summit level by level. Here, it will not do to be hasty. Haste might cause misunderstanding. Manas-sam─Бdh─Бna (calmness of mind) and s─Бvadh─Бna (patience, caution) are two primary qualities that a votary of the G─лt─Б must possess.

Different Schools of Philosophy

Another word of caution тАУ about dvaita, advaita, vi┼Ыiс╣гt─Бdvaita, ┼Ыuddh─Бdvaita, bhed─Бbheda, and other schools of philosophy that have differed in their exposition of the Supreme Truth. These differing schools are about the zenith of experience; about the relation between j─лva and Brahman; about the final goal of mokс╣гa. Suppose that a person is at the foot of a hill and desires to climb to its summit. In that case, isnтАЩt a discussion about what is in the temple at the hillтАЩs peak a waste of time? IsnтАЩt there a cave behind the temple? IsnтАЩt it dark? Is it a snake or a rat thatтАЩs inside the cave? Is the rat in the womb of the snake or has the snake been pierced in its eye by the rat? Or are both the rat and snake in yoga-nidr─Б*? Or have the snake and rat lost their natural enmity owing to their penance?* This is something that a person who has entered the cave and come out can tell us. It seems that such people have not been available to us.

One could ask, тАЬWonтАЩt the bh─Бс╣гyas (commentaries) authored by the ─Бc─Бryas of various schools suffice?тАЭ The answer is that there is no unanimity of opinion in those works. Who then do we believe in? The commentators excel in expounding upon the meanings of subtle scriptural passages. Using tarka (logic) and vy─Бkaraс╣Зa (grammar), it could be argued that advaita is dvaita or that dvaita is nothing other than advaita. The greatest instrument of knowledge in this lofty subject is the personal experience of the knower. That which is agreeable to oneтАЩs experience becomes his or her subjective truth. If one were to ask if Truth had parts in it or if Truth was a тАЬwholeтАЭ entity, the answer would be that though Truth is indeed whole and unbroken, the mind perceives it piecemeal. IsnтАЩt the eye on only one side of the head? The eye can see only one side of an object from one place.

The Truth is one; its appearances are manifold. If this is kept in mind, it can be shown that not only dvaita and advaita schools of Hindu philosophy but even non-Vedic religions such as Jainism, Buddhism, Islam, and Christianity can accept the G─лt─Б.* Our goal though in this discourse is to study the meaning of the G─лt─Б in such a way as to not oppose any traditional commentator. There is always freedom to choose whenever interpretations differ. Our focus is not on the parts where the interpretation differs but on those aspects acceptable to all. (Readers are encouraged to look at the appendix on the harmony of the three schools).

The Form of the Treatise

The Bhagavad-g─лt─Б is an account of a dialogue; a dialogue between Arjuna and ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa. Both of them are in the battlefield of Kurukс╣гetra where the P─Бс╣Зс╕Нavas and the Kauravas with their armies are standing in opposition to each other. Arjuna is the the third among the five P─Бс╣Зс╕Нavas, ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣ЗaтАЩs bosom friend. Arjuna, who is enthusiastic to fight until the start of the war, sees the multitude of people around him and begins to express his doubts and concerns thus тАУ тАЬAh! That I should kill them! Can I kill them? Is it proper to do this for selfish benefit? Is that not a grave sin?тАЭ ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa begins to clarify those questions. Questions and doubts arise again and again with those clarifications. ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa answers all of them. Thus expands the work. Those sorrows, doubts, and fears felt then by Arjuna are not his alone; or only of that time. The same dilemmas, uncertainties, confusions, and anxieties affect us every single day. Such fundamental questions of life have always bothered the human animal in all eras, all eons, and at all places in one form or another. The humanness of the human is in dealing with these questions and answering them. Such solutions find a solid basis in the veritable mine of the Bhagavad-g─лt─Б. The G─лt─Б is thus a scripture of life germane to all times and places.

In our study, the G─лt─Б has been viewed from the perspective of the everymanтАЩs need. Nuances of the ┼Ы─Бstra and the duels of logic are not important to us here. This is an exposition created by a common man discussing with another of his kind тАУ much like classmates talking to one another.

Is the G─лt─Б a ┼Ъ─Бstra or a K─Бvya?

This work is termed тАШG─лt─Б-┼Ы─БstraтАЩ as well. The words тАШg─лt─БтАЩ and тАШ┼Ы─БstraтАЩ convey widely different ideas in their meanings. G─лt─Б refers to a song. Its main function is entertainment тАУ delighting oneтАЩs feelings. That does not address the intellect. However, ┼Ы─Бstra addresses the intellect. Here, a predominance of feeling is unwelcome. Thus g─лt─Б and ┼Ы─Бstra appear mutually exclusive from a superficial view. However, in ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣ЗaтАЩs dialogue with Arjuna, thought and feeling have come together in a single narrative. For instance, the first chapter of is full of ArjunaтАЩs despondency and expressions of karuс╣Зa (pity, compassion), which show mental agitation more than intellectual cogitation. The eleventh chapter of the vision of the vi┼Ыvar┼лpa (Universal form) is full of adbhuta rasa (wondrous sentiment). The other chapters exude feelings of devotion and Bliss. Juxtaposed with these are a study of S─Бс╣Бkhya, dhy─Бna-yoga (the method of meditation), and the teaching of the Yaj├▒a principle тАУ all of which need significant application of thought. Therefore, it seems to be apt to term this work a тАШ┼Ы─Бstra-k─БvyaтАЩ or a scriptural poem.

That the realms of mind and intellect are different, even distant, does not hold in their elevated states. In that elevated station, both of them coalesce into one тАУ like an ideal husband and wife. The mind prods the intellect, which in turn indulges the mind. The light of the intellect and clarity of mind combine to yield an internal bliss akin to the joy of experiencing the radiance of moonlight. Like the happiness experienced while the eye conveys the beauty of form with the simultaneous sweetness of music conveyed by the ear. It is impossible as well as improper to separate such a blessed union of mind and intellect. The Bhagavad-g─лt─Б is a тАШ┼Ы─Бstra-k─БvyaтАЩ encompassing this dual. This will be discussed further in the appendix.

The present series is a modern English translation of DVGтАЩs Kendra Sahitya Akademi Award-winning work, Bhagavad-g─лt─Б-t─Бtparya or J─лvana-dharma-yoga. The translators wish to express their thanks to ┼Ъat─Бvadh─Бni R Ganesh for his valuable feedback and to Hari Ravikumar for his astute edits.

*Translators’ Note: Even Prof. M. Hiriyanna famously said that the G─лt─Б can become the Bible of any creed. While this might be true of ‘Pagan’ faiths similar to san─Бtana-dharma, it appears unlikely in the case of Semitic religions, which are not merely dualistic but also predatory in nature. Like Aurobindo Ghosh said, тАЬ[Hinduism] is in the first place a non-dogmatic inclusive religion and would have taken even Islam and Christianity into itself, if they had tolerated the process.тАЭ (The Foundations of Indian Culture, Sri Aurobindo Birth Centenary Library. Volume 14, pp. 73тАУ75)

[[What to Expect from the G─лt─Б? Source: prekshaa]]

What do we get from the G─лt─Б?

What can we expect from the Bhagavad-g─лt─Б?

We normally expect something special from any book we choose. If it is a story, we expect interesting accounts of human character; in a play тАУ a range of passions and emotions; in a song or a poem тАУ an echo of our caprices and anxieties; in a historical account тАУ narratives about different countries and nations; in a manual of astronomy тАУ a description of stellar and planetary behaviour. Similarly we look forward to increase our understanding of the subject in treatises on Physics, Chemistry, and Mathematics.

What is our interest in the G─лt─Б? By тАШour,тАЩ I refer to common people. What do we reckon as a benefit from a study of the G─лt─Б? If we make this clear to our minds, there will be no reason to complain later that this study was a waste of our time.

LetтАЩs accept that the popularity of the G─лt─Б has attracted us. Several scholars and luminaries of our country have worshipped the G─лt─Б over many millennia. Our preceptors have used the G─лt─Б as a scriptural authority. Many philosophers of Europe have respected it. Our own leaders such as Bal Gangadhar Tilak, Mahatma Gandhi, Aurobindo, and other greats have accepted the G─лt─Б as a fount of inspiration to their own lives. It is but natural, therefore, for us to presume that such a famous work must have something special in it.

Our ancestors considered the G─лt─Б as a mokс╣гa-┼Ы─Бstra (a scripture of liberation). For those who lived a hundred or two hundred years ago, the difficulty of everyday life was not as big a matter as for us. The main means of sustenance then was agriculture.There was nothing to worry about as long as the rains and crops happened on time. There was no contact or distraction from other cultures. The people lived according to the ancient tradition. Traditional rituals, customs, and systems were enough for them. Living peacefully like their fathers and grandfathers was all the pleasure they wanted from life. Hence, with everyday life not bothering them as much and becoming somewhat bearable, their minds sought more after the way beyond. It was thus that mokс╣гa became something close to them.

Our burden nowadays is of life in the world. 1 Earning oneтАЩs food and clothes, job opportunities, hopes and desires, loans and taxes, relentless toil, rest-less movings about, distress in practicing our customs, friction with other faiths, admixture of varс╣Зas, and an infinitude of other worries form our fate. How then can we pay attention to mokс╣гa? Our daily burdens of life are more than enough for us. Can the G─лt─Б help us amidst all of this? If so, it might be of value to us.

This is the favour we are eager for. Our minds are in turmoil; we need some fortitude. Our beliefs are shaking and infirm; the mind needs a secure resting place. The future is stuck in doubt; we need a comforting assurance. If the Bhagavad-g─лt─Б were to show us such viveka, such ┼Ыraddh─Б, and such sam─Бdh─Бna, we would desire to read that work.

The G─лt─Б makes it clear in its own words that it can indeed bestow this benefit upon us. Though our ancient commentators gave importance to mokс╣гa, they have stated that the G─лt─Б is equally applicable to everyone in terms of worldly life.

Dharma is the holistic and sustainable method to enrich worldly [personal and public] life. Dharma and mokс╣гa cannot exist without one another. The prerequisite to mokс╣гa is dharma and the perfection of dharma is mokс╣гa. Hence what was a treatise on mokс╣гa to our ancestors is to us a treatise on dharma.

The Declaration of the Work

Any new work on the G─лt─Б would have to encounter a fair question: тАЬWhatтАЩs so special about this?тАЭ

There is no dearth of treatises on the G─лt─Б. ─Аc─Бryas ┼Ъaс╣Еkara, R─Бm─Бnuja, and Madhva, who were the chief propounders of their respective schools of philosophy have all written commentaries on the G─лt─Б. There have been sub-commentaries and glosses written upon those works. There are collections of other compendia and exegeses built around these glosses. There are innumerable translations with explanations of the G─лt─Б not just in all Indian languages but also in English and other foreign languages. Why a new work then?

The author of the current work has to say this in response тАУ

  1. The G─лt─Б is a mokс╣гa-┼Ы─Бstra according to ancient commentators. In this work, it is chiefly a j─лvana-┼Ы─Бstra (scripture of life). While the ancient ones held vair─Бgya in greater importance, we have to live in this world, finding practical solutions to the problems of life. Applying the teaching of the G─лt─Б to worldly life is our goal. 2. Our ─Бc─Бryas have given greater significance to schools of Ved─Бnta тАУ dvaita, advaita, and vi┼Ыiс╣гс╣н─Бdvaita. In this work, it is considered that it is possible for these sub-schools to not just co-exist without opposition but exist in harmony like brothers. 2 3. Is karma more important in the worship of the Supreme? Or is bhakti more important? Or j├▒─Бna? Our ancients speculated on this issue. In our view, all these three, along with aс╣гс╣н─Бс╣Зga-yoga, are not harmful when practised together but could actually help one another. It is possible for these four practices to co-exist. The proportion of each practice could be set according to the seekerтАЩs ability and opportunity. But there is no fear of danger even if the proportion is slightly off the mark. 4. Our ancestors held the authority of ┼Ыruti and smс╣Ыti to be paramount. Here, an attempt has been made to harmonize the mode of inquiry employed in the modern scientific method with ┼Ыruti and smс╣Ыti and satisfy rationalism. 5. Ancient commentators were well-versed in traditional ┼Ы─Бstras. They wrote for those who understood the language of the ┼Ы─Бstras. They were able scholars in tarka, vy─Бkaraс╣Зa, and other branches of traditional wisdom. Here, emphasis is placed upon the straightforward meaning of the verses of the G─лt─Б. The G─лt─Б has several paradoxical passages (e.g. тАЬI am not in them; neither are they in me!тАЭ 3) as well as utterances that are epigrams (e.g. тАЬThe one who enjoys is verify a thief!тАЭ 4) The meanings of such passages can be stretched in any direction. In such cases, it is but consistent to interpret those passages according to the meanings of unambiguous passages of the G─лt─Б, the Vedas, and Upaniс╣гads. 5 A simple and straight path is thus sought after here. 6. Followers of the Veda and those who donтАЩt follow the Veda are both addressed here. 7. The discourse here attempts to follow the method of a non-scholar, a common man, who could discuss deeply with his friends subjects such as the Divine, j─лva, destiny and dharma.

It is in light of these reasons that this teaching of the G─лt─Б is termed j─лvana-dharma-yoga (the Yoga of the Right Conduct of Life) in this exposition.

[[The Nature of the G─лt─Б Source: prekshaa]]

The Nature of the Work

The G─лt─Б is simultaneously a simple-difficult work or a difficult-simple work. What does it mean? Words may be simple to understand but the meaning of the sentence is difficult. The part that teaches n─лti is simple; the part that establishes philosophy is not. It is thus easy to fall in the trap of thinking that one has understood the G─лt─Б. However, it is hard to realise its essence in oneтАЩs mind.

Though the language style is not that complicated and the figures of speech are clear, the word association is complex in a few places. Though similes and other figures of speech have been used to clarify the purport in a few verses, paradoxes and epigrams have also been employed to impress the seekerтАЩs mind and stay rooted there as well. Such paradoxical and epigrammatic verses need more considered reflection.

Any work or treatise cannot overcome the time and place of its composition. Though we may accept that the Veda is apauruс╣гeya (not of human origin), there are several marks of human influence in that great body of literature. The memory of the Kuru and P─Б├▒c─Бla regions, for instance or the names of kings such as Janaka and J─Бnu┼Ыruti mark out time and space. Hundreds of с╣Ыс╣гis are mentioned. The description of the movements of stars and planets are an aid in estimating the time of the manifestation of the Veda. Lokam─Бnya Bal Gangadhar Tilak has used the position of the mс╣Ыga┼Ыir─Б (Orion) and other asterisms to estimate the antiquity of a certain с╣Ыk that mentions this. It is thus evident that a few geographical and astronomical markers of a certain age can make their way into a work. The author is subject to his era and geography and has not overcome them.

In addition to the physical environment, his social milieu considerably influences an author. The beliefs of his people, their legends and stories, their aspirations, opinions, tastes, and attitudes are things that an author cannot possibly escape from. They would have had some or the other influence upon him. The best of the poets and philosophers cannot completely be immune to the effects of their age, region or social conditions.

A poet, however, has to rise beyond his condition. The more one is beyond time and geography, the greater his importance. We do not want a report of our world around from him. We have that even without his help. The question is of extracting ourselves from our condition and rise beyond it. This is where we need his favour.

But there is a limit to it. If the poet soars greatly beyond his condition, we may not be able fly with him. If there is not even a modicum of relationship between the world of the poetтАЩs imagination and the world that we know, we will be unable to even understand his words. His tongue might be foreign to us; his world might be from a different planet. There might be no medium for us to comprehend him. If we are to benefit from a poet, we must adhere to a couple of rules тАУ

  1. There must be at least an iota of similarity between his worldтАЩs characters and their conversations with our world and our behaviour. 2. There must be some novelty in the dispositions and circumstances of the characters and in the expressions of their feelings that give fresh stimulation to our minds.

We should be able to relate to the theme of the work; but within a limit. If the limit is exceeded, we might not enjoy it or even grasp it.

The goal of the preceding is to impress upon the reader that there is an unavoidable association between a work and its authorтАЩs time, age and circumstances.

The above definition of a literary work holds for the R─Бm─Бyaс╣Зa and the Mah─Бbh─Бrata as well. That the works of V─Бlm─лki and Vy─Бsa hold for all ages and regions is our thesis as well. Their main storylines, the expressions of feeling, the discussions on n─лti, and expositions that establish philosophy will apply to all of humankind at all times. However, even those illustrious works mention the social conditions of the eras of V─Бlm─лki and Vy─Бsa. Included in them are their legends, common idioms and proverbs, their ancient traditions, histories, their beliefs and faith. These ancillary aspects may not be accepted by those of this age. Even if we disregard some parts of the story or some sub-plots, there will be no loss to the comprehension of the main narrative. There might be a loss of uniqueness of narrative here and there. Consider this, тАЬThe earth is flat. Eight elephants bear it. Those elephants stand on the back of a turtle, which is on the hood of the serpent, Adi┼Ыeс╣гa.тАЭ If such descriptions are left unaccepted, a little bit of the storyтАЩs flavour might be found lacking. But there will not be any inadequacy in understanding the storyтАЩs principle.

Such aspects can be found in the G─лt─Б. The faith that rains and crops stem from the yaj├▒a is as old as the Vedas. There is no harm to the main thesis of the G─лt─Б whether we accept this belief or not. Another such matter is that of the devay─Бna (the way of the deities) and the pitс╣Ыy─Бna (the way of the ancestors). This is another item of Vedic faith. Believing in it is optional. This causes no loss to the main teaching of the G─лt─Б whose thesis is independent of the inquiry behind the yaj├▒a and the different ways of ayana (departure).

The Two Stages of Instruction

The G─лt─Бc─Бrya instructs us in two stages. One is for a normal aspirant, or one of worldly practice. The other is for an exceptional aspirant, or one relating to the Absolute. If Arjuna is a normal aspirant, let him come to the way of sva-dharma through desires for kingdom, fame and heaven. The path of

рдкрддреНрд░рдВ рдкреБрд╖реНрдкрдВ рдлрд▓рдВ рддреЛрдпрдВ

could be followed. Let him perform yaj├▒as, let him depart by the way of the moon. If on the other hand he is an exceptional aspirant, let him transcend the three guс╣Зas (sattva, rajas, tamas), be established in the Supreme dharma and work for the welfare of the world from the perspective of the Universal Spirit. Thus the paths differ based on the stature of the aspirants. Differences in path, however, do not matter from the destinationтАЩs view. This is a rule to keep in mind throughout the study of the G─лt─Б. The G─лt─Бc─Бrya accepts both the worldly and the Absolute.

[[The Conversation of the G─лt─Б Source: prekshaa]]

The Style of a Conversation between Friends

The sequence of the G─лt─Б appears jumbled at times. The G─лt─Б is referred to as a ┼Ы─Бstra. Its theme does make it one. But in the G─лt─БтАЩs method of instruction, we do not see a systematic division and order in its topics as in a school textbook. There is a chapter-wise division for sure. But the matter apposite to a specific chapter-topic shows up admixed in a different one. Another chapterтАЩs issue shows up in the current one. There is a reason for this. This work was not authored as a textbook. Neither Arjuna nor Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa set out to write one. The turn of events got them to converse and that flowed as a dialogue between friends.

R─Бma saw his old friend Bh─лma in the market. Both of them remembered their childhood friend ┼Ъ─Бma. Then they talked about the story of SomaтАЩs daughterтАЩs alliance with ┼Ъ─БmaтАЩs son K─Бma. ┼Ъ─лna, TimmaтАЩs lawyer had won the lawsuit. When the lawsuitтАЩs description ended, the matter of K─Бma came up again followed by Soma and Bh─лma once again. Then about the latterтАЩs brother-in-law Boma. A dialogue between friends typically rambles among different topics like this; much like what Bhavabh┼лti has said тАУ

тАжin the meandering manner of gossipers. 6

The same happens when friends talk about philosophical topics. From the present topic to a Pur─Бс╣Зic story; from the pur─Бс╣Зa to the condition of the world, from the world to the Absolute, and from that to the current issue тАУ the conversation swings back and forth. This can be found in PlatoтАЩs Dialogues wherein the debates between Socrates and others are described.

It can be seen from everybodyтАЩs experience that the subject of a discussion between friends can go hither and thither. This characteristic of a friendly chat has entered the G─лt─Б quite naturally. So we have to observe the links of an actual conversation here. Consider a person enquiring his friend тАУ тАЬWhen did he come? What happened there?тАЭ Both of them know what is being referred to by тАШheтАЩ and тАШthere.тАЩ Their opinions can be inferred from their tone of voice and facial expressions. When we read their dialogues without seeing them, their mental states have to be surmised from their backgrounds. In the same manner, the link between one verse and the next and the flow from one idea to the next can be understood through a consideration of the antecedent and precedent verses. This is where traditional bh─Бс╣гyas help us. Seemingly mysterious links between verses are clarified by these bh─Бс╣гyas. Once these links are inferred, we can see that the work is indeed logically well connected.

Was there Enough Time for a Dialogue?

Some people ask тАУ тАЬCan such an inquiring and deep conversation happen on the battlefield? Is it even possible to have a lengthy dialogue amidst two enemy armies baying for battle?тАЭ Another common suspicion is whether these words really came out of the mouths of Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa and Arjuna. And whether they really spoke in verse. My answer is that such doubts are irrelevant.

Before doubting if there was time for dialogue when everyone around clamoured for war, we should remember the rules of battle conduct of that age. Conflict in that era did not mean anyone killing anyone else in any manner or place. There were rules pertaining to the place of battle, its time and of worthy and unworthy conduct. War in that age was an occasion for dharma; especially of the kс╣гatriyas. Its rules were accepted equally by both opposing parties. Fighting would not begin upon sighting either side. There was no fear of harm till both sides decided that it was opportune to fight. There was ample time even after Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣ЗaтАЩs and ArjunaтАЩs dialogue.

It was then that Dharmar─Бja alighted from his chariot and approached Bh─лс╣гma and his preceptors. His brothers, without knowing his bent of mind, presumed that he was surrendering out of fear and tried to stop him. Dharmar─Бja did not pay heed to them and without uttering a word went to Bh─лс╣гma, prostrated at his feet and sought his blessings and permission for war. He did the same with Droс╣Зa, Kс╣Ыpa, and ┼Ъalya. ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa again tried to bring over Karс╣Зa to the P─Бс╣Зс╕Нava side. Finally Dharmar─Бja stood in the middle of the battlefield and called out for anyone intending to come over to his side. Yuyutsu, Dhс╣Ыtar─Бс╣гс╣нraтАЩs son from a servant girl, came over to the P─Бс╣Зс╕Нava side.

It is only after all this the war began. Nobody had the fear that anyone would rush into it. Everything took place in a relaxed, sequential manner. Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa and Arjuna had sufficient time [for a discussion.]

The Authorship of the Work

Now to the authorship of the work. Nobody will opine that all the words of the G─лt─Б, including тАШca,тАЩ тАШtu,тАЩ and other filler words, have been uttered by Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa and Arjuna. Sanskrit was natural to them. So it is likely that most of the words in the G─лt─Б, which were in vogue those days, were spoken by them. How could it be said that the intent of those verses did not belong to them? All the doubts, clarifications, statements of opinion, and logical inferences definitely belonged to Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa and Arjuna. Such discussions were common in that age. The Mah─Бbh─Бrata has numerous such instances. Viewed thus, it can be established that most of the language used and all of the sentiment belong to Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa and Arjuna and the only the metrical structure came from Vy─Бsa. Mahaс╣Ыс╣гi Vy─Бsa has reported a verse form of the dialogue through Sa├▒jaya for us.

Anubandha-Catuс╣гс╣нaya тАУ The Fourfold Connection

It is an ancient and traditional practice to define the four connections during an introduction to a work of ┼Ы─Бstra.

Adhik─Бr─л, Viс╣гaya, Sambandha, and PrayojanaтАФthe four anubandhasтАФ

[are essential] for the pursuit of a ┼Ы─Бstra to bear fruit 7

The four anubandhas or connections are тАУ

1. Adhik─Бr─л тАУ the qualified student

2. Viс╣гaya тАУ the subject matter of the treatise

3. Prayojana тАУ the benefit of studying the work

4. Sambandha тАУ the relationship between the viс╣гaya, the adhik─Бr─л, and the prayojana.

1. Who is the adhik─Бr─л or one qualified for a study of the G─лt─Б?

The one who has experienced difficulties, dilemmas, and crises in the world; who is able to control desires for sense-pleasures; who is endowed with empathy towards all people; and is passionately curious about knowing how to lead a life to ensure it is meaningful тАУ qualifies to study the G─лt─Б. Controlled desire, self-control, and a desire to know the Truth are the internal qualifications for a student of the G─лt─Б.

2. The Viс╣гaya or the theme of the G─лt─Б is the Universal Principle.

тАЬWhat is the nature of the j─лva? What is the principle of ─к┼Ыvara? What is the character of the world? What is the relationship between the j─лva and the world? What is the supreme way for the j─лva? What is the position of ─к┼Ыvara in the triad of jagat, j─лva and ─к┼Ыvara?тАЭ - are the questions that the G─лt─Б can answer. Its subject is the Vision of Universal Life.

3. Sambandha is of three kinds:

a. The relation between the teacher and the taught. The seeker is the taught and the G─лt─Б is the teacher.

b. The relation between harmony and the harmoniser. The G─лt─Б is to be studied in conjunction with the Vedas, Pur─Бс╣Зas, and Itih─Бsas with the assistance of tarka and vy─Бkaraс╣Зa while refined by worldly experience, reasoning, and evidence. All of the ┼Ы─Бstras and experiences are needed for that.

c. The relation between the purifier and the purified. The instruction of the G─лt─Б has to pervade all spheres of human life and make excellent all actions by purifying them. Life has to be refined through an implementation of its teaching and become capable of greater ends.

4. Finally the topic of prayojana or benefit.

A repeated study of the G─лt─Б makes light of the soulтАЩs burden of life. Through philosophical discernment, the mind understands the true value of various worldly things and a forms a value hierarchy. That marks the cessation of delusional error. Questions such as What is the meaning of life? What is the Absolute? What is to be done? What should not be done? are answered and a pure path of dh─Бrmic life becomes visible. Then comes clarity of mind followed by the solution to lifeтАЩs trials and tribulations. This results in tranquility. That [clarity and serenity] is the fruit of the study of the G─лt─Б.

Though a cursory examination of the fourfold connections has been made, there are a couple of items that need further thought. The first one is of the adhik─Бr─л. The G─лt─Бc─Бrya has several kinds of adhik─Бr─лs in mind.

Four kinds of fortunate people worship me, O Arjuna тАУ
the distressed,
the one wants to know,
the one desirous of wealth, and
the wise one 8

All of these [bhaktas] are excellentтАж 9

Individuals are at various levels in intellect and tastes, in knowledge, in richness of personal qualities, and in the extent of dispassion according to the karma done in their previous lives. These differences in ability and taste are innate. Therefore instruction and modes of practice differ accordingly. Even though the defining markers of adhik─Бr─лs appear to be the same, they vary in degree from person to person. Thus all forms of life that remember the Supreme have separate paths towards welfare depending on their capabilities.

The above explanation of the connections is of a common type and coarse. There are several points to be pondered upon here. The above explanation might be incomplete if it those points are not examined.

[[Instruction on the Viс╣гaya is According to the Adhik─Бr─л Source: prekshaa]]

Let us first look at the theme of the work and the qualification to study it. Each of these decides the other. The story of puс╣Зyakoс╣нi befits a six year old. A study of the Raghu-vaс╣Б┼Ыa, however, is for a student aged sixteen or more.

Thus each one decides the other. The one who is capable of dealing with the viс╣гayaтАФsubject of the workтАФis the adhik─Бr─л. The instruction has to be tailored to the education and capacity of the seeker. Both of these are thus relative to each other.

The viс╣гaya of the G─лt─Б is not of a single kind, when subjected to subtle examination; rather, it is of many kinds. While there is the devotion of common folk on one side, there are logical conundrums that can cause headaches to great pundits. Pravс╣Ыtti-dharma (the mode of action) and nivс╣Ыtti-dharma (the mode of renunciation), at─лta-sthiti (the exalted state), bhakti-yoga (the path of devotion), karma-yoga (the path of selfless work), dhy─Бna-sam─Бdhi-yoga (the path of meditative concentration), and j├▒─Бna-yoga (the path of wisdom) тАУ is the stepped path of the G─лt─Б. The intended seekers are correspondingly of different levels. There are several levels of seekers that fall in the purview of the G─лt─Б тАУ from the ignorant to the illuminated and from family men to ascetic mendicants. Because of the variety in adhik─Бr─лs, the instruction is also varied. From тАЬOffering a leaf, flower, fruit, or waterтАЭ 10 to тАЬBe devoid of the three guс╣Зas, O Arjuna!тАЭ 11 there are several paths of instruction. The destination is one; but the paths are eight. It wonтАЩt be wise to argue that only one of these eight is right and the rest are not. If the maxim of тАШAs the student, so the instructionтАЩ is remembered, it can be seen that the controversies of religious doctrine fade away.

The goal of medicine is one; a state of a healthy body is another. But the causes of sickness are many; the forms of diseases are many. Therefore modes of diet and treatment are many. Ginger and pepper do not treat an eye disease; alum cannot treat indigestion. Medicine is prescribed according to the weakness of the body. Instruction is given according to the debility of the j─лva.

This now is the most important matter. That the G─лt─Б is applicable to all varс╣Зas, all classes, and to all those in any circumstance or stage, to all women and men, has been clearly stated by the G─лt─Бc─Бrya. However, all instructions are not for everyone. Every student has to understand his or her own capability and choose the appropriate teaching after a thorough examination. This has been clarified by the G─лt─Бc─Бrya himself тАУ

Whatever is the utility of a small reservoir of water
when there is a floor and water is flowing everywhere тАУ
that is kind of utility of all the Vedas
for a person who has realised the Brahman! 12

Even if all ponds, streams, wells, and tanks are full of water, a man can use only whatever is necessary for his uses such as his ablution and drinking. Similarly, even if there are a hundred instructions in the Vedas, the judicious man chooses and uses whatever fits him. The same holds for the G─лt─Б. A palace befitting a queen holds hundreds of attendants in as many quarters. It is only appropriate for each occupant to reside in the appointed quarters. All floors and all rooms are not for everybody.

Questions such as, тАЬWill not there be discrimination then? Is it proper?тАЭ might arise. The answer lies in the highs and lows of human behaviour. K├▓bbari-miс╣нh─Бyi (a sweet dish made with grated copra) is certainly desired by many. Would it then be proper to feed a bagful of that to a two-year-old, citing equality of treatment? What would happen to the childтАЩs health? Just as there are limits on the food taken in by the body, there must be limits on food for the mind. This limit indicates a healthy respect for the nature of anything. тАШRealityтАЩ is understanding the nature of a thing as it is. Tattva is the same thing. A thingтАЩs thing-ness is tat-tva. That Tattva, Reality, or Truth is the foundation of dharma. Since, in reality, each j─лva differs from one another in innate disposition, it becomes necessary to prescribe different instruction and practice for each. Thence the multifaceted teaching of the G─лt─Б. There is no question of inferior or superior here. Is an injection a superior form of medicine or is a mixture inferior? Is a tablet better than medicinal powder? Our disease is one of ignorance. The G─лt─Бch─Бrya is the healer. ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣ЗaтАЩs answer to ArjunaтАЩs question about the race between superior and inferiorтАФin the A┼Ыvamedhika-parva of the Mah─Бbh─БrataтАФsubsequent to the war can be considered here тАУ

All are superior in their own domains
They all help one anotherтАЩs domains too! 13

In society, each one is best in his own appointed duty. Just as a br─Бhmaс╣Зa is the best when it comes to the Veda, a kс╣гatriya when it comes to protecting the kingdom, a vai┼Ыya when it comes to wealth, a gс╣Ыhastha in service of the world, and a saс╣Гny─Бsi in tapas, everyone has to help others while being the best in oneтАЩs own duty. In the same vein, the instruction most suitable for the spiritual progress and refinement of every j─лva is the best for him or her. The same is declared in the G─лt─Б thus тАУ

Performing oneтАЩs own dharma, even if imperfect,
is greater than performing anotherтАЩs dharma well 14

The reason I emphasise this so much is the inordinate impetuosity shown by people in the matter of mokс╣гa. The G─лt─Б has received much fame as a mokс╣гa-┼Ы─Бstra. People therefore want to unravel the secret as soon as possible and rush towards liberation. Such haste is not just a waste but dangerous as well. Nobody avers that the G─лt─Б is not a mokс╣гa-┼Ы─Бstra; no one says that the thought of mokс╣гa is wrong. But the G─лt─Б is as much a dharma-┼Ы─Бstra as it is a mokс╣гa-┼Ы─Бstra. While the thought of liberation is good, it is good to to reflect upon dharma as a prerequisite. People have to first understand that there is no mokс╣гa without dharma. Upon consideration, it is seen that there is no reason to hanker after mokс╣гa separately. Mokс╣гa follows dharma by itself. A person who earns his livelihood in the day according to his ability and follows a healthy lifestyle does not have to take pills for a good nightтАЩs sleep. He whose food is well-digested falls asleep as soon as he hits the sack. Mokс╣гa is set for the discerning one who performs dharma diligently. Let us therefore follow the G─лta with a focus on the matter of dharma.

The viс╣гaya and the adhik─Бr─л are not completely separate from the view of our study of the G─лt─Б; but are symbiotic. We have seen that dharma is indeed the theme of the G─лt─Б if the student is interested in dharma. We have discussed the prayojana of the G─лt─Б study cursorily. There is one thing left to be stated about the sambandha (relationship among adhik─Бr─л, viс╣гaya, and prayojana). This is about our attitude. It has been mentioned that the relationship is one between the teacher and taught тАУ the G─лt─Б is the teacher and we are the taught. Is this not clear? Should it be explicitly stated? The answer is yes. The relationship could be one of a refuter and the refuted. IsnтАЩt it quite possible that Buddhists, Muslims, and Christians could study the G─лt─Б in order to refute it? Our explicit statement is to clarify that there should be mutual faith and respect between the work and the student.

┼Ъraddh─Б is trust that is not blind. It is the trust with which a child eats what its mother gives it; that with which a patient takes his medicine from the doctor. If the child does not relish the food given by the mother, it throws it away and demands something else. If the ailment does not get cured, the patient complains to the doctor who prescribes another medicine. Both the child and the patient have from their experience a freedom to examine the mother and healer respectively. Similarly, the ┼Ыraddh─Б we have in the statements of the ┼Ы─Бstras and the gurus is not opposed to independent thought but subject to reason and experience. The way of the world is to examine first and trust later. However, ─Бtm─Б, j─лva, and dharma are supranormal subjects. Therefore it is trust that is followed by examination in these matters. The G─лt─Бc─Бrya himself specifies that what is needed is reflection and not a lack of thought through the following statements тАУ

Understand thatтАж from inquiry 15

тАжhaving analyzed all of thisтАж 16

and so forth.

There is yet another thing that has to be said here. That is related to the difference between the nature of worldly or physical sciences and this subject [i.e., the G─лt─Б]. Mathematics, Physics, and Chemistry can be grasped only via the intellect. Physical objects can be grasped by the senses. Therefore, they are available through the pram─Бс╣Зas (means of knowing) of pratyakс╣гa (direct perception) and anum─Бna (inference). The ─Бtman is suprasensory. It cannot be grasped by our hands or measurements. To obtain it therefore, we have to rely upon the Veda-┼Ы─Бstra, which is the testimony of ─Бptav─Бkya (trusted source). If we donтАЩt place our trust in it, there is no way out.

The other preparation we need in addition to ─Бptav─Бkya is the purification of our inner being or a clean disposition of mind. Those in hasty pursuit of mokс╣гa tend to forget this.

It is an error, a dangerous one, to think it possible to unravel the secrets of Ved─Бnta through a sleight of mind. It is possible to win at a game of cards through a trick. A machine can be operated through a shortcut. A math problem can be solved through a stratagem. It is also possible to shut up an opponent with wit. We think it possible to storm the city of mokс╣гa using an easy manoeuvre. But Brahman is not something attainable merely through intellectual artifice.

[[S─Бdhana-catuс╣гс╣нaya - The Four Prerequisites Source: prekshaa]]

It is indicated above that the buddhi is a power that works with the manas. The buddhi is under the influence of the manas. Therefore, to purify the buddhi, it is imperative to purify the manas. Buddhi is an implement that enables reflection. Manas experiences the product of the buddhi. In Ved─Бnta, j├▒─Бna (wisdom) is the same as anubhava (experience). Knowledge of Brahman is the experience of Brahman. Mind is the arena of experience. Unless the mind is ready, there can be no true experience of reality. Hence a purified mind is inevitable for the study of the G─лt─Б-┼Ы─Бstra. The method of purification of the mind is termed s─Бdhana-catuс╣гс╣нaya (the fourfold attainment) comprising the following тАУ

1. Nity─Бnitya-viveka (Discernment between the real and the unreal)

What things of the world exist at all times? What are those that live for a short duration? The mind must repeatedly reflect upon and practise discrimination between the great and the trivial, the fixed and the unsteady, and the eternal and the transient.

2. Ih─Бmutr─Бrtha-phala-bhoga-vir─Бga (Renouncing the desire for enjoyment in this world and beyond)

Gradually renouncing the desire for bodily pleasures in this world or in other heavenly abodes; being unruffled by sense pleasures.

3. ┼Ъam─Бdi-с╣гaс╣нka-sampatti (The sixfold wealth of quietude &c.)

a. ┼Ъama is the absence of other thoughts while in control of inner senses; keeping the mind established in itself.

b. Dama is the control of external senses.

c. Uparati is the withdrawal of the mind from external happenings and being established in itself.

d. Titikс╣гh─Б is forbearance; to be equanimous while being unruffled by the duals of profit and loss, joy and sorrow, love and hate, or hot and cold.

e. ┼Ъraddh─Б is implicit faith in the words of the ┼Ы─Бstras and the learned.

f. Sam─Бdh─Бna is establishing the mind in its object while not allowing it to wander.

4. Mumukс╣гutva (The intense desire to be liberated)

Curiosity about mokс╣гa. Mokс╣гa is the experience of Bliss devoid of any trace of sorrow, beyond duality, that is a result of release from bondage.

To summarise, the student of the G─лt─Б, having seen the limitations of earthly wealth and pleasures and controlling Desire, Anger, and Envy, realises the existence of the ─Бtman beyond bodily existence and considers that Supreme Essence to be the best amidst all transactional reality. This is the foremost prerequisite for the student of the G─лt─Б.

A Couple of Precautions

It is important to understand how the essence of an important work should be comprehended. A couple of precautions are pertinent here тАУ

1. To temporarily let go of oneтАЩs skepticism in the narrative (тАЬтАжwilling suspension of disbelief for the momentтАжтАЭ тАУ Coleridge)

2. To focus on the purport of the work in its narrative.

1. Willing suspension of disbelief.

To suspend questions about characters and events that arise during a story for resolution at a later time. тАЬDid R─Бvaс╣Зa of the R─Бm─Бyaс╣Зa really have ten heads? Was he able to assume a form at will? How did M─Бr─лca become a golden deer?тАЭ тАУ such are the items of doubt. тАЬWas the potency of the mantras the reason for the birth of the P─Бс╣Зс╕Нavas? Was the number of damsels that ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa brought from Narak─БsuraтАЩs town exactly sixteen thousand? Were they all of the same age or were there old women among them?тАЭ тАУ Such questions are irrelevant from the perspective of the storyтАЩs essence. These incredible incidents are essential for the poet-worldтАЩs reality. These are the bricks of the poetic monument. We need to believe in the solidity of these bricks if we want the tale. We need to be able to believe in the story and nod our heads with a, тАЬHmm,тАЭ much like children who do so. Instead if we were to ask questions at every stage of the story, the poetic edifice falls apart and we derive no use from it. This is a rule relevant only to the story aspect of a work.

2. Focus on the purport of the work amidst the flow of words.

By purport we refer to that meaning which resonates with the intent of the work or the sentence. For example, if during a meal a person is asked to bring saindhava, one should infer it to be тАШrock saltтАЩ rather than тАШa horse.тАЩ Meaning stems from context. In the sentence, тАШCome over to my house while visiting the temple,тАЩ the phrase тАШcome overтАЩ does not mean тАШarrive on top of,тАЩ but тАШto casually visit.тАЩ In ┼Ы─Бstra, this is referred to as lakс╣гaс╣З─Б-vс╣Ыtti (using the secondary sense of meaning when the primary word meaning is not apt). It should be remembered that the intent of the speaker is more important than the word.

If intent is more important, should not only those words appropriate to the intent be chosen? Why the superfluity? This raises a question on the innate capability of a language or the lack of it. That is an area to ponder. Can language exactly convey the intent of the mind and intellect? In several works is seen the inability of language to precisely express the authorтАЩs intent. To make up for that, we must resort to several figures of speech such as upam─Бna-upameya (simile), utprekс╣г─Б (hyperbole), and punarukti (repetition). Our daily language is filled with such figures of speech as well. тАЬI polished off ten dosas,тАЭ тАЬI gave a couple to the mischief monger,тАЭ тАЬThat baby is like a flower,тАЭ etc. are examples for that. Words are not enough to convey our emotional states or our experiences. We say that тАЬHe was fuming with rageтАЭ or тАЬEverything has cooled down.тАЭ We exclaim, тАЬIt was like seeing God,тАЭ or тАЬIt was like drinking amс╣Ыta,тАЭ or тАЬI remembered K─Бmadhenu!тАЭ Thus, even common folk cannot converse without figures of speech even for a moment. Seeing that normal words do not completely convey delight or pain in those sentences, uncommon or special words or comparisons are employed. Those comparisons fill in the gap left by words. That indeed is тАШalaс╣ГтАЩ (enough) тАШk─БraтАЩ (make) тАУalaс╣Еk─Бra = making it enough; filling any gaps or shortcomings. Alaс╣Еk─Бra is used to fill in those gaps created by normal word usage. It is a kind of lakс╣гaс╣З─Б-vс╣Ыtti. The same consideration is used in all art forms. What does a young lady do when she does тАШalaс╣Еk─БraтАЩ (make up) to herself? She does two things. The first is to amplify or accentuate the beauty of her own bodily features. A small dark dot on her beautiful golden cheeks brings out the attraction in the cheeks. A single white jasmine flower on her dark tresses renders the entire hairdo gorgeous. How? The seer is able to appreciate beauty of the same thing faster and with more vividity. This is a kind of alaс╣Еk─Бra or decoration. The other kind of alaс╣Еkaraс╣Зa is to make any deficiency or ugliness invisible. Applying face powder to a faded face, filling gaps between teeth with gold, using wax to smoothen out any pockmarks тАУ are all examples for this. Even here, alaс╣Еkaraс╣Зa or decoration is used to resolve any gaps in beauty and project the product as real. This is indeed artificial. When something artificial is used for good i.e., when its effect is pleasurable, we call it alaс╣Еk─Бra.

More words are thus used in a language for either clarifying the meaning or amplifying it. The sentiment conveyed by the statement тАШR─Бma is goodтАЩ is also conveyed by тАШR─Бma is exemplaryтАЩ but the sentiment is amplified in the latter.

[[Repetitions and Reiterations in the G─лt─Б Source: prekshaa]]

Let us get back to the Bhagavad-g─лt─Б. There are so many punaruktis (repetitions); upam─Бna-upameyas (comparisons in a simile) and paradoxes. Our attention should be on their purport. When prosaic speech does not suffice and figurative expressions are resorted to even while describing commonplace incidents and worldly experiences, how else could the mind of the philosopher expressing thoughts about the supernatural reveal itself to us without figurative language? Consequently, there is quite a bit of symbolism in the Veda especially in the matter of the ─Аtman (Self).

The puruс╣гa-s┼лkta is a large allegory. When such language is encountered, the mind must not focus on the literal meaning but on the purport. In the statement

sahasra┼Ы─лrс╣г─Б puruс╣гaс╕е

does not mean that the vir─Бс╣н-puruс╣гa (the Cosmic Being) has one head more than 999 or one head less than 1001. тАШSahasraтАЩ just signifies innumerable. That is the substance.

The Bhagavad-g─лt─Б has the same words repeated. The same matter is conveyed in different words.

nityaс╕е sarvagataс╕е sth─Бс╣Зuс╕е acaloтАЩyaс╣Г san─Бtanaс╕е ред
He is Eternal, Omnipresent, Fixed, Motionless and Everlasting

Here both sth─Бс╣Зu and acala mean the same. What does nitya and san─Бtana mean? Both mean the same. Is it not a fault when the text is repetitive to express the same thing in three different words? It is not so here. It is rather advantageous here and much needed from our perspective. For, when the instruction does not come in a flood of words but in subtle and terse letters, it might not catch the mind of a dull or a careless learner. If, however, it is repeated in many words, the fear of such a loss is lessened. The effectiveness of a sentence is not only gained from its inner strength but also from its external size. Experienced teachers know that in a school, children are taught the same concepts тАУ even easy ones тАУ by revising it multiple times. While dealing with an extremely subtle and deep topic, the instruction might not be understood or even misunderstood if terse language is used. Therefore a little repetition is not a defect but a blessing. Names of trees occur as if in a catalogue during descriptions of forests in the R─Бm─Бyaс╣Зa and the Mah─Бbh─Бrata. The names of a hundred persons are encountered when an ─Б┼Ыrama is being described. Are we botanists or anthropologists that we need these catalogues? The answer is that this description of a multitude has an impact on our mind. It is required for increased impact in the depiction of the object.

Descriptions of such collections are encountered in the tenth and eleventh chapters of the Bhagavad-g─лt─Б. We have to comprehend the meaning of the flow there. A significant opinion or instruction flows out in multiple streams. In the vibh┼лti-yoga, for instance.

An economical word arrangement in which no word required to elucidate its meaning is left out, no superfluous word is added, and in which any movement or transposition of letters results in a greater, lesser or completely different meaning is known as a s┼лtra. Let us look at an example from the Brahma-s┼лtra тАУ

The above s┼лtra has four words:

asya = of this world
janma = origin

yataс╕е = from which proceed

Brahman has to be supplied to complete this s┼лtra, i.e., тАЬ(Brahman is that) from which proceed the origin &c. (preservation and dissolution) of this world.тАЭ

The above s┼лtra is explained in the Upaniс╣гad thus тАУ

(Taittir─лya-upaniс╣гad)

The Brahma-s┼лtra conveys in four words what the Upaniс╣гad takes fifteen words to do. The presence of the conjunction тАШcaтАЩ conveys a special meaning in the s┼лtra; the absence of it conveys yet another meaning; similarly with тАШtu.тАЩ The style of the s┼лtra befits experienced scholars; and gives an opportunity for their logic and arguments. The author of the G─лt─Б did not follow the rule of aphorism. His style is one of poetry. His admirable goal is to explain uncommon subjects with common words. Therefore we do not have to sift through every letter of the G─лt─Б. The holistic vision is appropriate here. Our goal is not the word to word meaning of an instruction but the essence of the flow of thoughts тАУ the general drift or tenor of the words used. This, if remembered, will bring several controversies about the teaching of the G─лt─Б to rest.

The story aspect of the G─лt─Б is in a poetic form. Poetry attempts to convey the subject matter in a way that is impactful to the mind. That kind of an attempt makes imperative several figures of speech such as the hyperbole. This is something even we are aware of. During the education of children, we use exclamations like тАЬBravo!тАЭ whenever a child solves a problem correctly. When it is two тАУ we use expressions like тАЬAwesome!тАЭ If there are a couple of children there, we begin to think on how it would be possible to convey a unique phrase of encouragement. For one, we may use тАЬSmooth!тАЭ and for the other, we may use тАЬIncredible!тАЭ We might use тАЬUnbelievable!тАЭ for the third one. We do not use the literal meanings of these words when we convey our appreciation. We do not weigh the implications of the usage of such words. Such an examination of exact word meaning is unnecessary for our use and may even be detrimental. Encouraging students is our only goal. If we weigh our words carefully much like an apothecary weighing his medicines, and try to state the exact intended meaning, the effect on the students might be more discouraging than encouraging. Therefore it is proper to grasp the meaning of GodтАЩs words after considering His intent.

Arjuna was crestfallen. He was out of his wits. The intent of the Lord was to infuse enthusiasm and confidence in him and make him surge forward.

The poet uses a few extra words to ensure that the meaning sticks to the mind. This is a literary device that is seen employed even in the Veda.

The VedaтАЩs chief goal is one of vidhi (injunction); to decide dharma. Are then all those Vedic passages injunctions? No. Should not the propitiated deity be invoked during the yaj├▒a? There are mantras for those known as st─Бvakas (hymns of praise). These praise Deities thus тАУ тАЬYou are the greatest among the great! You created all of us! You are the one who existed before us!тАЭ тАУ in a variety of ways. It is but natural to use many words when praising anybody. We see that even in the world. Can a minister be praised with the words, тАЬYou have an LLB degree! You have two ears!тАЭ and so forth? Does that even count as praise? If, however, the minister is praised with words like: тАЬYou are the avat─Бra of Bс╣Ыhaspati!тАЭ &c., there is a good chance of getting our work done. When it is so in the mundane world, can Yaj├▒e┼Ыvara (Lord Agni) be propitiated with тАЬYou burn!тАЭ, тАЬIf you are controlled, you give us happiness. Please restrict yourself!тАЭ and so forth? Will Agni give us what we desire? Therefore a plethora of st─Бvakas are necessary. The pragmatic view is that this is a device to get the favour of the deity. The Absolute or philosophical perspective is that since Para-brahman is the final destination, we arrogate all its qualities on all the devat─Бs.

There is another class of Vedic passages known as arthav─Бda. The arthav─Бda informs us that one would get certain fruits on the completion of certain rites. In everyday language, this could be termed an advertisement.

There are several such Vedic passages included to stimulate (prarocana). The stimulation is for the performance of certain rites and subsequently achieve interest in them and prosperity.

annav─Бnann─Бdo bhavatiред mah─Бn bhavati
prajay─Б pa┼Ыubhirbrahmavarcasenaред
mah─Бn k─лrty─Брее

The above is the praise of food. Food has to be acquired in plenty. The one with food eats abundantly. He becomes great. He begets progeny, bovine wealth, Br─Бhmic effulgence, and extensive fame. What is the intent behind such praise? For man to work and earn his living. To work for a living is not something debased but the best among duties. It is needed even to realise Brahman. By stating all this, the maharс╣гis desire to infuse a sense of importance with faith and enthusiasm even during common everyday tasks. When the Veda says, тАЬMah─Бn bhavati,тАЭ the intent is not to convey that the one eating will put on weight and become a wrestler but to insist that such a person would become great in quality and influence.

Similarly in the G─лt─Б, one finds enough passages of upade┼Ыa (instruction) as well as for clarification. There are even more passages to generate interest. So, it would be instructive for the reader to observe how certain passages convey the overall meaning of the G─лt─Б and in what way. When this is done, the harmony among various parts of the text becomes evident.

[[Importance of Realizing the Meaning Source: prekshaa]]

The Importance of Contemplation

The G─лt─Б has two intertwined streams of instruction. One is theoretical whereas the other is practical. The theoretical part is especially intellectual with an ascertaining of the truth using an analytical mindset. The practical aspect or s─Бdhana pertains to the emotional mind. The mind when active is known as the citta тАУ тАШAnusandh─Бn─Бtmaka-vс╣Ыttimad-antaс╕еkaraс╣Зam cittamтАЩ (тАШThe citta is the contemplative mind.тАЩ) The buddhi has to be followed by citta. But the citta is slower than the buddhi. Hence there is always a difference between the buddhi and the citta.

It is seen that in the world, there is always a gap between words and deeds. It is not that only dishonesty is the reason for this. Spoken words might not match what is in oneтАЩs mind on half the occasions. But during the other instances, the reason is impossibility and not dishonesty. The citta is not ready to follow what the buddhi deems appropriate. The citta is not as careful as the buddhi. The more difficult the buddhiтАЩs instruction gets, the more unprepared the citta is for it.

ManтАЩs mind is like a sheet of paper. It remains flat and smooth when not folded layer by layer or rolled into a tube. Once folded, however, it is a struggle to make it smooth. The same goes for a bar of metal. Once bent in a certain way, it is not easy to make it straight. The same happens with a cane stick. The citta too, similarly, yields to habit. To let go of an old habit and take on a new habit takes time, patience, and firmness. This is its nature.

Thence is Bhagav─БnтАЩs statement.

asaс╣Г┼Ыayaс╣Г mah─Бbaho mano durnigrahaс╣Г calamред
abhy─Бsena tu kaunteya vair─Бgyena ca gс╣Ыhyateрее (6.35)

abhy─Бsa-yoga-yuktenaред (8.8)

abhy─Бsa-yogena tato m─Бm-icch─Бptuс╣Г dhana├▒jayaред (12.9)

Deep is the gap between the citta and the buddhi.

This is why the practical aspect of the G─лt─Б is harder than the philosophical aspect. Practice of the g─лt─Б requires a long-standing firmness of the mind and constant effort. It should not be thought that mere hearing of the instruction is attaining the goal. Even if the principles are well-understood intellectually, it is not the same as attaining the final fruit. The g─лt─Б-┼Ы─Бstra was not created for argumentation but for practice.

Experience is Knowledge

We can go a step further and state that one who lacks practice will be found lacking in the realization of the truth, for j├▒─Бna is not a mere comprehension of an idea but a method of work. In other words, j├▒─Бna is not akin to a point but to a line. There are several stages in j├▒─Бna. The peak, however, is experience. The one who has scaled a mountain peak can claim to have seen the entire mountain. The one who has experienced the truth completely knows what it is. The j├▒─Бna of an inexperienced person is insufficient and hence not trustworthy. It is as dangerous as confusion. Therefore those are honest students of the G─лt─Б who take the effort to practice and consequently realise it in their experience.

Experience is becoming that which we contemplate upon тАУ through an effort of the mind. The mind is like lac or beeswax, capable of assuming any form. It has to be melted, cast in the shape of the contemplated object, and then hardened. That is experience тАУ becoming the object. The gopik─Бs meditating constantly upon ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa had their minds passionately absorbed in him, consequently attained his form, and experienced Bliss. That is experience.

Such an experience of the Supreme can happen only through significant effort and prolonged practice. Therefore people like us who have read the words of the G─лt─Б and have slightly understood its literal meaning have not attained much. Our efforts and practice are important. For this, we need to understand by ourselves the modes of instruction and practice that match our ability and competence. Theoretical philosophy is not unimportant. But its importance is for intellectual inquiry. That inquiry bears fruit during actual experience. Practice is imperative for experience. And experience is not something that happens intellectually. Along with the buddhi (intellect), the manas (psyche), the citta (the unconscious storehouse of all impressions), smс╣Ыti (memory), comprehension, inference, and intuition as well as other powers of the internal organs should converge. If all of lifeтАЩs energies were to be engaged, the fruition of that effort and its ripening is the experience of the Supreme.

Let us therefore focus on applying the teaching of the G─лt─Б.

Mere Reading is Insufficient

Several students of the G─лt─Б religiously read the work even if they do not understand it, in the ardent belief that the act yields religious merit. That is a good thing, no doubt. But there is a danger in that. They might get the false assurance that just uttering the letters of the G─лt─Б can destroy all their p─Бpas. Repetition and remembrance of Bhagav─БnтАЩs holy names have been greatly extolled in our tradition. However, remembrance of the name and reading the work are but the means. Towards what? Means to ensure that our minds are focused on the Divine. Utterance of the names of the Divine with the mind elsewhere is fruitless. It is a mistake to think that repeating the letters of the G─лt─Б will remove p─Бpa accruing from performing bad deeds. The benefit of repeating the G─лt─Б text is in memorizing it. Once memorized, it becomes easy to recall the text again and again. With repetition, the meaning of the text becomes clear to the mind. Reflection on the meaning of the text becomes easier with the meaning clarified. Reflection on the essence of the text enables contemplation. Hence the p─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa or ritual reading of the text is sequentially beneficial rather than as a complete solution by itself. For the complete benefit of the G─лt─Б, the focus must be on its meaning. The practice of parroting the text has increased of late. The desire of proclaiming to the world that they have read the G─лt─Б has spread a lot. What of mere reading? What of understanding the meanings of sentences? Only after harmonizing the meaning across different parts of the G─лt─Б, seeing its meaning holistically and an extended practice might the essence of the G─лt─Б flash in the mind. The same is said about the Vedas as well.

sth─Бс╣Зur-ayaс╣Г bh─Бrah─Бraс╕е kil─БтАЩbh┼лtbr>adh─лtya vedaс╣Г na vij─Бn─Бti yoтАЩrtham

The study of the G─лt─Б should not be like the burden of the washermanтАЩs vehicle.

yath─Б khara┼Ы-candana-bh─Бrav─Бh─л
bh─Бrasya vett─Б na tu candanasya

What if a donkey bears the weight of sandalwood logs on his back? It experiences only the burden and not the fragrance of the sandal.

Therefore, the p─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa bears fruit only through contemplation on the workтАЩs meaning.

The path of contemplation has been divided into three stages by our ancients тАУ

┼Ыrotavyo mantavyo nididhy─Бsitavyaс╕еред
tarati ┼Ыokam-─Бtmavitред

The three stages are ┼Ыravaс╣Зa, manana, and nididhy─Бsana.

┼Ъravaс╣Зa is listening, which means reading or performing a ritual study.

Manana is thinking about the meaning. Manana is the reflection on the meaning of the work by the union of the refined manas and the well-trained buddhi.

Nididhy─Бsana is the constant considered observance in oneтАЩs own deeds of the principle understood through manana.

Of these three, the first one is not hard. The other two are achievable through great difficulty. If manana has proceeded well, nididhy─Бsana should not be difficult.

Thus manana is the most crucial part of contemplation.
