[[Contemplation and Reasoning Source: prekshaa]]

Manana

There is an element of truth that escapes words and can be discerned only through inner experience. That is the secret. Contemplation via considered reflection is the only way to unravel the secret of Brahman. If the study has to be beneficial, it must follow the path of reflection.

There is an anecdote in the Bс╣Ыhad─Бraс╣Зyaka-upaniс╣гad. In the court of King Janaka, G─Бrg─л asks the с╣Ыс╣гi Y─Бj├▒avalkya about the structure of the earth and the structure of its warp and woof. Y─Бj├▒avalkya, in turn, describes the structure of the worlds from here to Brahma-loka stage by stage. At that time, G─Бrg─л questions him about the structure of Brahma-loka, who then cautions her with:

M─Бtipr─Бkс╣г─лс╕ерее
тАЬDo not over question!тАЭ

Questions and answers are fine until a point, after which they become meaningless. This is because what exists beyond a certain point is beyond words as well. Experience is the only way out after that. Thence the path through reflection and meditation.

Reflection is primarily an intellectual activity. One could call it the maturation of ┼Ыraddh─Б or faith. Faith in instruction has been ordained for the disciple. Faith is belief. If belief already exists, the question arises as to what the need for the intellect would be. The rule of manana shows that a need for the intellect co-exists with the presence of ┼Ыraddh─Б. Manana clarifies the word-meaning of the instruction, analyses its purport, validates the message, and firms up our conviction. What we have in the beginning is incomplete knowledge or j├▒─Бn─Бbh─Бsa тАУ a semblance of knowledge. This apparent meaning is refined through manana to get the accurate import. Thus the role of the intellect is critical in the study of the scriptures. ┼Ъravaс╣ЗaтАФlistening or readingтАФis the first stage in knowledge acquisition. Nididhy─БsanaтАФmeditationтАФis the last. The bridge between the two stages is mananaтАФreflectionтАФwhich requires a meticulous use of the intellect.

The Nature of Dharma

Constantly paying attention to the principle and adhering to it during various activities of life is the application or practice of dharma. The four main indicators of dharma are as follows тАУ

  1. The remembrance of the greatness of the Divine. 2. Renouncing oneтАЩs ego. 3. Reducing the feeling of тАШmeтАЩ and тАШmine.тАЩ 4. Applying oneтАЩs own capabilities for the benefit of others.

Such a dharma takes multiple forms such as kuс╣нumba-dharma (dharma towards oneтАЩs family), kula-dharma, (dharma towards oneтАЩs clan), janapada-dharma (dharma towards oneтАЩs nation), and others. Only if the practice of the G─лt─Б-principles occurs across these dharmas can a faraway glimpse of the Divine be achieved. That is experience. The three main methods of dharma has been delineated by the G─лt─Бc─Бrya himself.

tad-ity-abhisandh─Бya
phalaс╣Г yaj├▒a tapaс╕е-kriy─Бс╕еред
d─Бna-kriy─Б┼Ы-ca vividh─Бс╕е
kriyante mokс╣гa-k─Бс╣Еkс╣гibhiс╕ерее
Yaj├▒a, d─Бna, and tapas are the three paths to attain Divine experience. Yaj├▒a is worship of the Divine. D─Бna is service to society. Tapas is educating or refining oneself. These three form the path to elevate oneтАЩs life.

The Bhagavad-g─лt─Б expounds upon dharma as much as it instructs about mokс╣гa.

┼Ъr─л ┼Ъaс╣Еkar─Бc─Бrya clarifies this in his introduction to the G─лt─Б.

dvi-vidho hi vedokto dharmaс╕е, pravс╣Ыtti-lakс╣гaс╣Зo nivс╣Ыtti-lakс╣гaс╣Зa┼Ы-ca, jagataс╕е sthiti-k─Бraс╣Зamред pr─Бс╣Зin─Бс╣Г s─Бkс╣г─Бd-abhyudaya-niс╕е┼Ыreyasa-hetur-yaс╕е sa dharmo br─Бhmaс╣З─Бdyair-varс╣Зibhir-─Б┼Ыramibhi┼Ы-ca ┼Ыreyorthibhiс╕е anuс╣гс╣нh─лyam─Бnaс╕еред тАж
Vedic dharma is two-fold тАУ one of activity (pravс╣Ыtti) and the other of renunciation (nivс╣Ыtti) тАУ and is responsible for the maintenance of order in the world. This dharma, which gives both worldly welfare as well as mokс╣гa, has been practised by the br─Бhmaс╣Зas and other varс╣Зas who are desirous of welfare.

abhyuday─БrthoтАЩpi yaс╕е pravс╣Ыtti-lakс╣гaс╣Зo dharmo varс╣З─Бn-─Б┼Ыram─Бс╣Г┼Ы-coddi┼Ыya vihitaс╕е, sa dev─Бdi-sth─Бna-pr─Бpti-hetur-api san, ─л┼Ыvar─Бrpaс╣Зa-buddhy─Б anuс╣гс╣нh─лyam─Бnaс╕е sattva-┼Ыuddhaye bhavati phal─Бbhisandhi-varjitaс╕еред тАж
Although this dharma of action is a means to worldly prosperity and is prescribed for different varс╣Зas, and is capable of achieving the regions of the devas, if practised with submission to the Supreme with no regard towards the results of the work, it is conducive to the purification of the mind.

The opinions of R─Бm─Бnuj─Бc─Бrya and Madhv─Бc─Бrya are not different in this matter. All the three ─Бc─Бryas say the same.

No Distinction of Religious Doctrine in Dharma

The difference of opinion amongst the ─Бc─Бryas is not with respect to the dharma portion of the work but with the aspects pertaining to philosophy or tattva тАУ the nature of reality. The reason is that the philosophical aspects deal with the final questions about the nature of mokс╣гa. The ─Бc─Бryas greatly developed the topic of philosophical inquiry and extensively discussed the exalted condition or state of the j─лva. This resulted in the G─лt─Б being thought of as mainly dealing with mokс╣гa and that the question of dharma was subsidiary to it. That is not quite correct. For common people, practice or the application of dharma is primary.

There is yet another reason. ┼Ъruti (Vedas), Smс╣Ыti, Pur─Бс╣Зas, and Itih─Бsas as well as long-standing traditions have the same opinion about dharma. Dharma is principally an external practice. Therefore, authority or testimony, conclusion, what is right and what is not тАУ are all topics available to most people. It is easier to achieve unanimity in this regard. Because it is clearly observable in the world, there is not much dissent in the matter. Mokс╣гa, however, is an internal state wherein external testimony is insufficient. While the opinions of the world have achieved near unanimity vis-├а-vis dharma, the same has not been achievable when it comes to j─лv─Бtman and param─Бtman. It is not possible either. There is scope for debate and analysis in this regard. It is possible for one to analyse or critique anotherтАЩs theory. With the growth of polemical works, the focus has been more on tattva and mokс╣гa, which has distracted people from the practice of dharma.

The Position of Tarka (Logical Reasoning)

There are hundreds of commentaries and glosses on the Bhagavad-G─лt─Б. As far as we know, it is the commentary of ┼Ъr─л ┼Ъaс╣Еkar─Бc─Бrya that is the oldest. He gave more attention to tattva and so his adversaries had to follow suit. We need to understand why ┼Ъr─л ┼Ъaс╣Еkar─Бc─Бrya gave more importance to the philosophical portion.

┼Ъr─л ┼Ъaс╣Еkar─Бc─Бrya set forth to establish pristine Ved─Бnta by showing the defects in the philosophical schools of his day. The three main rival schools were тАУ 1. Buddhism, 2. The Doctrine of Karma, and 3. S─Бс╣Еkhya.

Buddhism was non-Vedic and had four sub-schools. We donтАЩt need to delve into their details now. Suffice it to say that they did not accept the Divine principle.

The Doctrine of Karma, propounded by Kum─Бrila and others of the P┼лrva-m─лm─Бс╣Гs─Б school, holds that the karma portion of the Vedas is the primary one and that yaj├▒as and other Vedic rituals comprised dharma, which resulted in the final human goal. The third groupтАФS─Бс╣ЕkhyaтАФis also a Vedic philosophy. They held that there were numerous fundamental constituents of the universe and the relation between cause and effect is established via two principles known as prakс╣Ыti and puruс╣гa.

These three schools of philosophy were in vogue during ┼Ъr─л ┼Ъaс╣ЕkaraтАЩs time. All the three were philosophical in nature. It was then the duty of ┼Ъr─л ┼Ъaс╣Еkara to refute these three schools and establish his own school of philosophy of the One Self through testimony and reasoning. Therefore we find analyses of philosophy and examinations and refutations of reasoning in his works. As a result, those that came after him had to further develop dialectical approaches in their works. Due to historical factors and development of various philosophical schools, commentaries on the G─лt─Б have concentrated more on tarka while the aspect of dharma was sidelined. I feel that an abundance of tarka is unnecessary in our times and that the benefit from hashing out the same issues repeatedly is probably less than looking at the work from a contemporary perspective. I do not deny the commentaries of our ancient teachers. Those commentaries show us the way. We need them. Without them, we might lose our way. But we need a present-day viewpoint as well. There will not be any contradiction to existing schools of thought. Our thought has to be harmonised with that of our ancients. That is the way of progress. The history of man has to flow unimpeded and unbroken like the flow of the Gaс╣Еg─Б and other great rivers. Our new thoughts and interpretations have to similarly continue from that of our predecessors.

[[The Puruс╣г─Бrthas and the Self Source: prekshaa]]

Puruс╣г─Бrtha

Man is a bag of desires. His life is a river of ceaseless likes and dislikes. Whatever he desires and whatever goals he attempts to attain have all together been termed by our ancestors as puruс╣г─Бrthas.

There are four puruс╣г─Бrthas тАУ

1. Dharma (good works, virtue, sustenance, global ethic)

2. Artha (wealth, means to fulfill desires)

3. K─Бma (desire, enjoyment)

4. Mokс╣гa (liberation).

K─Бma and Artha are first desired by all. Both of these are born of an impulse from Nature. Dharma, however, is achievable through the individualтАЩs discernment.

The uses of artha are twofold тАУ 1. Dharma and 2. K─Бma. Wealth has to be earned without violating dharma and has to be used for giving to the deserving and to help society. Artha then becomes a means to attain dharma.

Dharma has to partially follow Nature as well as oppose it. But mokс╣гa has to be achieved by completely transcending Nature. One end of human life is k─Бma that is completely subservient to Nature. The other end is mokс╣гa that is beyond Nature. Dharma then is the human endeavour to ascend from the bottom to the top. Dharma is special in that it is good work that yields double results. One is the fruit of pleasure the other is that of well-being. Dharma can pull us out of the web of Nature for a moment, bring down our selfishness and ego, turn our minds towards the Supreme, and prepare us for the world. This refinement of the j─лva is the fruit of well-being. While dharma can take us on the path to progress, it could cause regress as well. Yaj├▒a, d─Бna, tapas, and others are ways of worshipping the devas. Pleased with us, the devat─Бs give us what we desire. That is the fruit of pleasure. There is intoxication in the wine of this fruit. Just as tasty food eaten without considerations of limit can cause indigestion and thereby disease, the boons we desire can delude us and pull us down to error. Is this not the story of R─Бvaс╣Зa and other r─Бkс╣гasas? They obtained boons from their tapas and misused them. It is not easy to find one who, by means of thought, knows what befits him, what benefits his nature. When we attain desired pleasures, we forget ourselves in the intoxication of their enjoyment. That can make us negligent. We begin to hanker after another pleasure when what we have is not enough. It could motivate us to do wrong. When that pleasure ends, we covet after yet another. It could lead us astray. Thus, the fruit of pleasure from the practice of dharma could be enjoyable at first but end in sorrow; which means that dharma, by its giving of fruit, could enable its rival puruс╣г─Бrtha through a flourish of k─Бma and coveting after artha.

The Composition of Human Nature

An important consideration here is the composition of human nature. The three guс╣Зas of sattva, rajas, and tamas are found mixed in unequal proportions. The results of dharma are dependent upon the doerтАЩs proportion of these guс╣Зas. For what goal does man perform dharma? To what specific dharma among the numerous forms of dharma is he attracted? The fruit of dharma depends on the answers to these questions.

ManтАЩs inclination towards artha or k─Бma stems from different proportions of these three guс╣Зas. From those inclinations arise dharma and its opposite, adharma. From dharma and adharma emerge the fruits of the activity or otherwise. From the fruits again arise avarice and delusion, which result in the increase or decrease of the guс╣Зa-proportions. A shift in *guс╣Зa-*proportions further causes a change in human nature, dharma, adharma, and the succession of results and the cycle continues. This is saс╣Гs─Бra or worldly existence.

The Means to Attain the Supreme Self

Mokс╣гa is beyond this causal chain of transformation. It is the transcendence of activity by being rid of desire. The activity of the liberated one is known as adhi-dharma, which is beyond the fruits of dharma and adharma. Saс╣Гs─Бra is not a burden to the liberated but rather a l─лl─Б, an effortless pastime, which implies that saс╣Гs─Бra becomes light, as if it does not exist.

When the practice of dharma becomes easy, when dharma happens without exertion, and when it occurs as naturally and involuntarily as breathing тАУ thence begins the conduct of adhi-dharma. That is the liberated state. Therefore all our effort has to be in the performance of dharma. The riddle of life is completely embedded in the question of dharma.

kiс╣Г karma kim-akarmeti kavayoтАЩpy-atra mohit─Бс╕еред (BG 4.16)

тАЬEven the most intelligent become foolish when it comes to what is to be done and what is not to be done,тАЭ declares ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa himself. Dharma has to nourish the attachment to desire and wealth as well as restrain it. When should the nourishment stop? When should the restraint begin? Our difficulty is in determining this boundary.

Nature stands behind attachment to desire and wealth as support. She excites the sense organs, causes a preponderance of selfish desire, and erases discernment. There is yet another power of confusion that joins her тАУ our past karma. There is no guarantee of a result regardless of how bravely we fight without losing our sense of discrimination, no guarantee of absolute freedom from danger either. Waves of accidents hit so many lives. Obstacles and dangers occur unexpectedly like typhoons and earthquakes. Just as pre-ordained favourable karma envelops us with the fuzzy lustre of delusion, ill-luck covers us with a shroud of darkness. How can we glimpse dharma when our eyes are hazy with sorrows and crises?

Just as there is no limit to the creative faculty of Nature, there is no limit to human misfortune either. She conjures up dainty delicacies and new games. But man is tortured by ever new hungers and pains. On one side are fresh desires while on the other side are old deeds. Enmeshed between the two, the j─лva finds it necessary to concentrate on an entirely different means towards well-being. Dharma has to nourish fresh desires, educate, stand up human effort and uplift the j─лva. By stating

gahan─Б karmaс╣Зo gatiс╕е рее (BG 4.17)

Bhagav─Бn illustrates the knotty nature of the dharma-riddle. The duty of dharma is to reconcile a j─лvaтАЩs ancient residue of karma with its current desires and future well-being. Among these three, the one that must gain the upper hand is future well-being, which is the way of attaining the Divine.

[[The Great Instruction of the G─лt─Б Source: prekshaa]]

The Yoga of Life

The Bhagavad-g─лt─Б establishes and illustrates these three problems of life on a philosophical foundation. There is a place for k─Бma, a place for artha, a place for dharma, and a place for mokс╣гa. How is it possible to establish the suitability of attaining one of these four? What are the rules for each of the four puruс╣г─Бrthas? How are those four courses to be adjusted to ensure that they do not hamper one another? Indicating the answers to these questions through an elucidation of the nature of worldly life and core principles is the scripture of the G─лt─Б. It shows the path for men and women to elevate their lives according to their mental preparations, their intellectual capabilities, and their circumstances. Therefore it is but apt to call the G─лt─Б a тАШSamyag-j─лvana-┼Ы─БstraтАЩ (тАШScripture of a Good LifeтАЩ) or тАШJ─лvana-yoga-┼Ы─БstraтАЩ (тАШScripture of Life-YogaтАЩ).

The Great Instruction

The great teaching of the G─лt─Б is Respect for Life. Life is a play of Brahman, the Supreme Consciousness. Be it any animal, its inner state has an element of the power of the Supreme Brahman. It is our duty to realize this and perform our lifeтАЩs work with faith and efficiency. We should not belittle Life by deeming it insignificant. Life is an opportunity to obtain the best. It is a great duty and therefore worthy of our worship and service. One should engage in oneтАЩs own dharma with a pure mind and a faith for the Absolute. A life well-led is a life spent in the worship of the Divine.

The Yoga of the Full Life

It is an article of belief of our ancestors that the Bhagavad-g─лt─Б is the essence of all the Vedas and Ved─Бnta. That the G─лt─Б too is an Upaniс╣гad is an object of faith and tradition.

тАЬ┼Ъr─лmad-bhagavad-g─лt─Бsu upaniс╣гatsu…тАЭ goes the description.

тАЬSarvopaniс╣гado g─Бvaс╕е… dugdhaс╣Г g─лt─Бmс╣Ыtam mahat…тАЭ is another description that states that the G─лt─Б is an Upaniс╣гad.

It seems proper to say that the Vedas and the Upaniс╣гads (known as Ved─Бnta) have found reconcilement in the Bhagavad-g─лt─Б. The non-Upaniс╣гad portions of the Vedas тАУ i.e., the Saс╣Гhit─Б and the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa portions deal especially with the worship of devat─Бs. The Upaniс╣гads focus on the principle of ─Бtman or the Self. The G─лt─Б integrates the path of worship of the Vedic karma portion with the philosophical inquiry that is found in the j├▒─Бna portions of the Veda. The Good Life is not a тАШpointтАЩ-like concept; it is like a тАШlineтАЩ that comprises a multitude of points. It is not of a тАШpoint in timeтАЩ or a single moment but of a тАШperiod of timeтАЩ comprising innumerable moments. There is scope in it for worship of devat─Бs through yaj├▒a, d─Бna, and tapas. There is opportunity for worldly duty in the form of personal as well as societal works. There is room for philosophical contemplation via meditation on the Self.

The Bhagavad-g─лt─Б demonstrates that each of the following three тАУ 1. Worship of devat─Бs, 2. Life in the world, and 3. Meditation on the nature of the Self тАУ are connected to one another, and that each of them have a definite position in the Good Life and that they have to be comprehended in an integrated, holistic form.

Thus a great benefit for us from the Bhagavad-g─лt─Б is the vision of an Integrated Good Life for all of humankind except perhaps the pure atheist. The vision of the G─лt─Б is such that it is acceptable to not just those Hindus who believe in the testimony of ┼Ыruti and smс╣Ыti but also to those Parsis, Muslims, Christians, and those of other faiths without religious contradiction. 17 Its teaching is not against rationality in any portion. There is no religious dogmatism or heterodoxy or intolerance towards other opinions in the G─лt─Б.

tad-viddhi… paripra┼ЫnenaтАжрее (BG 4.34)
[Learn that… by sincere questioning and enquiry…]

vimс╣Ы┼Ыyaitad-a┼Ыeс╣гeс╣Зa…рее (BG 18.63)
[Having reflected upon this without leaving anything unexamined…]

Thus the G─лt─Б does require reasoning. It is reliant upon the Veda only when it comes to supra-sensory reality. For the Truth that is not available via direct perception or the Truth that although experienced as oneтАЩs own Self is inconceivable, there is no other resort for us than the Veda. In such an unavoidable situation, though the G─лt─Б quotes from the Veda, it could still be considered a hypothesis that needs further reasoning.

Logic or reasoning is about something known. There is no ground for logic in a void that is bereft of any experienced object. A statement about something that provides matter for logical reasoning is a тАШhypothesis.тАЩ It could be a positive or negative statement but should convey a definite opinion. When we encounter such a hypothesis, we consider it from different perspectives and ask different questions. We discuss it with our experience and reasoning. If that statement stands scrutiny of all these examinations, it becomes a principle. The G─лt─БтАЩs statements about Reality stand unshaken even after many such analyses. That is why the G─лt─Б is considered an authority. All those questions that are born either of the intellect or out of experience can be answered by the G─лt─Б.

The statement of the scholar Theodore Goldstucker that Hinduism is like an ocean can be applied to the G─лt─Б as well. Young children feel happy when they look at the ocean. They play with the sand on its beaches. They dance with joy when they see the variegated conches and shells. They are amazed by the ceaseless play of the waves. Adults experience pleasure by splashing waves on one another. They expand their sight to the horizon and become contemplative. They desire to voyage on it in boats and ships. They stretch their bodies to take in the ocean breeze. This is about common people. Brave seafarers immerse in the mass of water and bring up pearls, jade, and jewels. San─Бtana-dharma is also like that. From the devotees of village deities such as M─Бramma and Gaс╣Еgamma, from those that sacrifice chicken and male buffaloes to those savants who realize the Impersonal and Formless Truth, people of all classes, all kinds, and all levels of capabilities are providedтАФby the Bhagavad-g─лt─БтАФthe satisfaction of bettering their self according to their mental and intellectual capabilities.

The G─лt─Б offers a meaningful and holistic vision of life. It has considered every aspect of human life without ignoring anything. It has analysed every facet of human nature without overlooking it. It has addressed the welfare of human beings of all possible levels of worth without giving up on them. It is an all-round, all-capable set of principles. It is harmonious in its essence without any inconsistency. None should feel disheartened if he could not find an answer to his question. He should reflect upon the statements of the G─лt─Б again and again. This becomes possible when the entire text is in his memory. The problem that arises in one part of the text finds a solution in another part. Any deficiency seen is not in the work but in oneтАЩs study of it. He must reflect upon it repeatedly. Reflection with patience and mindfulness is required. As he discusses the work within himself, and resolves every issue that arises, facets that were not apparent from the beginning become manifest and solve his doubts. Such constant contemplation is possible only for someone endowed with ┼Ыraddh─Б.

┼Ыraddh─Бv─Бn labhate j├▒─Бnamрее (BG 4.39)
[The sincere one endowed with dedication attains wisdom]

yo yacchraddhaс╕е sa eva saс╕ерее (BG 17.3)
[A man is what his ┼Ыraddh─Б is]

┼Ыraddh─Б hi param─Б gatiс╕ерее
[DedicationтАФ┼Ыraddh─БтАФis the highest state]

The one without ┼Ыraddh─Б cannot escape mental delusion. The G─лt─Б is an elucidation of the philosophy of jagat, j─лva, and ─л┼Ыvara that is complete, consistent, and harmonious all over. Venturing near the G─лt─Б without ┼Ыraddh─Б is like entering a temple when unclean тАУ it is an effort in vain.

If the essence of the G─лt─Б has to be conveyed to a person of faith, it could be done so through this proclamation of the ─к┼Ыopaniс╣гad тАУ

kurvann-eveha karm─Бс╣Зi jij─лviс╣гecchatagс╣Г sam─Бс╕ерее
[Doing your karma here, desire to live for a hundred years!]

Which means that life is not evil. One should not wish to abandon it but face the difficulties in it and fight them bravely. This is the teaching of the G─лt─Б.

tasm─Бd-yudhyasva bh─Бrataрее (BG 2.18)
[Therefore, fight, O descendent of Bharata!]

yudhyasva vigata-jvaraс╕ерее (BG 3.30)
[Engage in war, having abandoned your mental fever!]

yudhyasva jet─Бsi raс╣Зeрее (BG 11.34)
[Fight the war! You will be victorious on the battlefield!]

[[Chapter 1. Yoga of Inconsiderate Compassion (Part 1) Source: prekshaa]]

Gist

р▓нр▓░р▓др▓Хр│Бр▓▓р▓жр│Бр▓нр▓пр▓╡р▓╛р▓╣р▓┐р▓ир▓┐

р▓ир▓░р▓ир│Бр▓др│Нр▓╕р▓╣р▓┐р▓╕р▓жр│Ж р▓Хр│Гр▓╖р│Нр▓гр▓В
р▓Чр│Кр▓░р│Жр▓жр▓В р▓др▓ир▓Чр▓╛р▓ж р▓зр▓░р│Нр▓ор▓╕р▓Вр▓Хр▓Яр▓нр▓пр▓ор▓ор│Н рее

When the two armies of BharataтАЩs descendants
met at Kurukс╣гetra, and the war-conch sounded,
Arjuna, having lost his will
told Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa of his fear and doubt about his dharma

Substance

When the armies of the Kauravas and P─Бс╣Зс╕Нavas gathered at Kurukс╣гetra, known as dharma-kс╣гetraтАФthe abode of dharmaтАФArjuna beheld his elders and relatives in front of him and was overcome with pity. He said that he did not want to enjoy the kingdom that he would obtain by killing his near and dear ones. Thus he became тАШ┼Ыoka-saс╣Гvigna-m─Бnasaс╕етАЩ тАУ i.e., his mind was agitated by sorrow. He threw his bow and quiver down and told Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa that he would not fight.

Chapter One

Arjuna-viс╣г─Бda-yoga (The Yoga of Arjuna’s Distress)

or Pr─Бkс╣Ыta-k─Бruс╣Зya-yoga (The Yoga of Inconsiderate Compassion)

The first chapter of the Bhagavad-g─лt─Б is a story, not instruction. This story relates the reason for the G─лtopade┼Ыa. Since the purport of this work can be easily discerned from its commencement, even though this chapter does not have any teaching, it is portentous of the nature of the instruction that follows. This story is in two parts тАУ

1. The description of the preparation for war and

2. ArjunaтАЩs aversion for fighting.

1. Preparation for War

Dhс╣Ыtar─Бс╣гс╣нra, the king of Hastin─Бpura*,* asks Sa├▒jaya what his childrenтАФthe KauravasтАФand his brotherтАЩs childrenтАФthe P─Бс╣Зс╕НavasтАФdid.

Replying to that*,* Sa├▒jaya said, тАЬO king, your son Duryodhana saw the preparation of the army of the P─Бс╣Зс╕Нavas. He came to Droс╣З─Бc─Бrya and requested him thus тАУ тАШVenerable Sir, there are many mighty heroes on both sides. Still, the force under Bh─лс╣гmaтАЩs command is not enough; the army of the enemy led by Bh─лma is adequate. Therefore, you and the heroes on our side may please protect Bh─лс╣гma from all sides.тАЩтАЭ

apary─Бptaс╣Г tad-asm─Бkaс╣Г balaс╣Г bh─лс╣гm─Бbhirakс╣гitaс╣Гред
pary─Бptaс╣Г tv-idam-eteс╣г─Бс╣Г balaс╣Г bh─лm─Бbhirakс╣гitaс╣Грее (BG 1.10)

…bh─лс╣гmam-ev─Бbhirakс╣гantu bhavantaс╕е sarva eva hiрее (BG 1.11)

HadnтАЩt Duryodhana, in the beginning, designated Bh─лс╣гma as the commander of the army? Why did he go to Droс╣Зa instead of Bh─лс╣гma? From his words, it appears that Duryodhana had some doubt in his mind. (1) Did he believe that Bh─лс╣гma was partial towards the P─Бс╣Зс╕Нavas, and therefore he might not fight with his full might in the battle? (2) Did he think that Bh─лс╣гma was old and lacked physical strength? (3) Did he consider Bh─лma to be more competent, even though Bh─лс╣гma was a mighty warrior? (4) Or, if the above three were not the reasons, did he think that Droс╣Зa was beleaguered by jealousy or anger that he was not chosen to be the commander-in-chief of the army, and try to allay that by flattery? (5) Alternatively, did he deem it profitable to have Droс╣З─Бc─БryaтАЩs pride stirred up by indicating that deep inside, his own respect and reliance were more in him, even though he had designated Bh─лс╣гma as the commander-in-chief as a mere formality? Thus, we can think of five or six reasons for this supplication of Droс╣З─Б by Duryodhana. Let the reasons be as they may, it is clear that Duryodhana was not without doubt. His mind was wandering because of fear and apprehension. This conjecture becomes established later, in the 19^(th) verse.

sa ghoс╣гo dh─Бrtar─Бс╣гс╣нr─Бс╣З─Бс╣Г hс╣Ыday─Бni vyad─Бrayatред (BG 1.19)

The sound from the conches of the P─Бс╣Зс╕Нavas tore the hearts of the Kauravas.

As if he guessed at the misgivings in DuryodhanaтАЩs mind, Bh─лс╣гma blew his conch loudly with a mighty roar like that of a lion. That was a sign that they were ready for battle. In reply to that, all the commanders sounded their conches.

…┼Ыaс╣Еkh─Бn dadhmuс╕е pс╣Ыthak pс╣Ыthakрее (BG 1.18)

This invitation to battle is the first stage of the story.

2. ArjunaтАЩs Reluctance to Fight

When the time to use his weapons had finally arrived, Arjuna requested Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa тАУ

senayor-ubhayor-madhye rathaс╣Г sth─Бpaya meтАЩcyutaрее (BG 1.21)

тАЬO Imperishable One! Please park my chariot between the two armies. With my own eyes, let me see whom I have to fight with тАУ those who are backing the vile Duryodhana!тАЭ Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa parked the chariot as requested and asked Arjuna to look at the Kaurava army. When Arjuna did so, he saw that all the warriors on the Kaurava side were his near and dear ones. Men whom he regarded as he did his own father, his preceptors, uncles, brothers, nephews, grandchildren, friends and relatives; they were all his own people. As soon as he saw them, Arjuna felt the gush of affection and attachment specially reserved for oneтАЩs own relatives. As soon as the realization that they were worthy of his respect, love, and affection dawned on him, ArjunaтАЩs heart melted. He became limp and broke down; his face fell, his bow slipped from his unsteady hands and his willpower gave way.

et─Бn-na hantum-icch─Бmi ghnatoтАЩpi madhus┼лdanaред (BG 1.35)

тАЬO slayer of Madhu, let them kill me if they want to, I do not want to slay them!тАЭ тАУ thus decided Arjuna.

This conduct of Arjuna was unexpected. Arjuna was no fledgling in battle; that was certainly not the first time he saw huge armies. He was a renowned warrior and had won hundreds of wars. He was familiar with the brutality and horrors of battle. Secondly, he also knew that his opponents were his own people. He had not forgotten that elders such as ┼Ъalya were deserving of respect and that Duryodhana, Du┼Ы┼Ы─Бsana, and others were his cousins. The pity that had not surfaced in him until then arose in him at that very moment. How did that happen?

We must ponder upon this. Our mental speculations about a far-off object, based only on our imagination and hearsay, will all undergo an abrupt sea-change when it comes nearer. We may hear and consider the bereavement of a friend and may think that we have understood its nature; but when we experience the same thing, we think of it as a new calamity and suffer. This is the power of direct experience. The mind is more agitated and frenzied with direct experience, rather than hearing in detail about the same thing. Thus, ArjunaтАЩs experience in the battlefield of Kurukс╣гetra is an unfamiliar experience for him, in a way.

…hatv─Б sva-janam-─Бhaveрее (BG 1.31)

The feeling of тАШsvaтАЩ in тАШsva-janaтАЩ (1.28, 31, 37, and 45) became intense when Arjuna saw his elders and relatives. That is the extreme result of his cognizance of the fact that he, himself was now about to fight them. The grim spectacle of his kindred geared up for battle at Kurukс╣гetra excited the passionate proprietorship of Arjuna.

[[Chapter 1. Yoga of Inconsiderate Compassion (Part 2) Source: prekshaa]]

At this point, as an example of the severity of the result of oneтАЩs own experience, we can recollect the episode of the blind king Dhс╣Ыtar─Бс╣гс╣нra. Vy─Бsa offered to give him the capability to witness the scenes in the battlefield.

yadi tv-icchasi saс╣Еgr─Бme draс╣гс╣нum-enaс╣Г vi┼Ы─Бmpateред
cakс╣гur-dad─Бni te hanta yuddham-etan-ni┼Ыamayaрее
(Bh─лс╣гma-parva 2.6)

Dhс╣Ыtar─Бс╣гс╣нra replied тАУ

na rocaye j├▒─Бti-vadhaс╣Г draс╣гс╣нuс╣Г brahmarс╣гi-sattamaред
yuddham-etat-tv-a┼Ыeс╣гeс╣Зa ┼Ыс╣Ыс╣Зuy─Бс╣Г tava tejas─Брее
(Bh─лс╣гma-parva 2.7)

I do not want to watch the massacre of kinsmen with my own eyes but I am interested in the war. Therefore, grace me so that I can hear about the occurrences in the war. Acceding to this request, Vy─Бsa bestowed upon Sa├▒jaya the capability to view the battle from afar and arranged for him to narrate it to Dhс╣Ыtar─Бс╣гс╣нra.

Dhс╣Ыtar─Бс╣гс╣нra was ArjunaтАЩs senior. He was older and more experienced. Therefore, he did not want to witness the horrors of the battle with his own eyes. The effect of sight on the mind is more acute than that of hearing. The eyes cannot bear as much as the ears do.

The reasons that Arjuna gave to justify his aversion for war are required to be pondered upon by all those who are desirous of knowing about dharma тАУ

  1. It is not good to kill oneтАЩs own relatives. 2. тАЬNa k─Бс╣Еkс╣гe vijayamтАЭ тАУ I do not desire to win. 3. тАЬKiс╣Г no r─Бjyena kiс╣Г bhogaiс╕етАЭ тАУ What is the use of kingdom and enjoyment? 4. тАЬKiс╣Г j─лvitenaтАЭ тАУ What is the use of living? 5. тАЬP─Бpam-ev─Б┼Ыrayedasm─БnтАЭ тАУ We will only accrue sin by this battle. 6. тАЬLobhopahata-cetasaс╕етАЭ тАУ Should we become afflicted by avarice? 7. тАЬKula-kс╣гaya-kс╣Ыtaс╣Г do┼Ыaс╣ГтАЭ тАУ Corruption that causes the annihilation of the entire clan. 8. тАЬMitra-drohe ca p─БtakamтАЭ тАУ The p─Бpa of betraying friends. 9. тАЬKula-dharm─Бс╕е praс╣Зa┼ЫyantiтАЭ тАУ The dharma of the entire race will be destroyed. 10. тАЬDharme naс╣гс╣нe adharmoтАЩbhibhavatiтАЭ тАУ When dharma is destroyed, adharma will dominate. 11. тАЬPraduс╣гyanti kula-striyaс╕етАЭ тАУ Virtuous women will also debase themselves. 12. тАЬJ─Бyate varс╣Зa-saс╣Еkaraс╕етАЭ тАУ Different varс╣Зas will mix together. 13. тАЬSaс╣Еkaro narak─БyaivaтАЭ тАУ This inter-mingling will pave the way to naraka. 14. тАЬPatanti pitaraс╕етАЭ тАУ The pitс╣Ыs will be dragged down. 15. тАЬUts─Бdyante j─Бti-dharm─Бс╕е kula-dharm─Б┼Ы-caтАЭ тАУ The individual dharmas of different j─Бtis and clans will be ruined.

And so on and so forth.

In this list of the evils of war, there is no mention of mokс╣гa; there is no thirst to know oneself; nor is there a dialogue about human nature. This is what we have to always keep in mind because the G─лt─Б discusses these three key points. Why did they appear in Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣ЗaтАЩs answer although they were not present in ArjunaтАЩs question? To know this, we have to completely understand the fundamental parts of ArjunaтАЩs question. The feelings hidden in the above list of Arjuna’s arguments may be divided into four groups тАУ

  1. The necessity of pity 2. Being scared of p─Бpa 3. Being detached from worldly enjoyment 4. Being rooted in dharma, having deep ┼Ыraddh─Б in it

Which of these four can we reject? HavenтАЩt we always been taught that we should practise the above four qualities? What is the deficiency in Arjuna’s argument then? Why did Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa not agree to it?

The first chapter of the G─лt─Б has always been called the тАШYoga of ArjunaтАЩs despondency.тАЩ True, there is despondency here. But is it the sole subject this chapter deals with? There is a reason behind ArjunaтАЩs despair. There is also a direction to it. We should understand both.

The outcome of ArjunaтАЩs excessive pity was his reluctance to fight. By killing, he would not only lose his loved ones but also invite p─Бpa. Arjuna also wanted to escape from this p─Бpa. Is this endorsed by dharma? In a righteous war, is killing adharma? Is there any situation where killing a living being becomes dharma? This has to be deliberated upon. Had Arjuna understood the nature of dharma? Were the doubts he had about the duties of a kс╣гatriya correct? What is dharma? It becomes necessary to contemplate upon this.

Distress can be caused by anything. It can be caused by the feeling of inadequacy of strength, or by a hesitation that the gods may not be pleased; or by the hopelessness that he may not be a partner to profit in future; or the fear that he himself may be injured or even die. None of these were the reasons for ArjunaтАЩs despair; it was caused by excessive love. Sa├▒jaya describes him thus тАУ

taс╣Г tath─Б kс╣Ыpay─Бviс╣гс╣нam… (BG 2.1)

Arjuna is completely controlled by his love and pity. Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa’s answer is that his pity is unfounded there. There is no doubt that mercy is a fine quality. But it is acceptable if it is exercised upon a worthy object in a worthy manner, not otherwise.

Pity is a kind of mental alteration. It has to be born, by itself, within us. It does not need outside force or even any influence. As Bhavabh┼лti said,

vyatiс╣гajati pad─Бrth─Бn-─Бntaraс╕е koтАЩpi hetur-
na khalu bahir-up─Бdh─лn pr─лtayaс╕е saс╣Г┼Ыrayanteред
(Uttara-r─Бma-carita 6.12)

The thread that binds people together is something that is within their hearts. Love is not based on outward support. That inward object is brought into being by Nature. Just because it is natural, it cannot be concluded that such pity is acceptable or beneficial. Whether something is beneficial or hurtful should be decided only after due contemplation. Arjuna’s pity, in that sense, is not brought about by deliberation. It was an impulse of the moment. Impulse is hasty and is not enough to cultivate belief. Proper consideration and reflection should eliminate the improprieties of the emotion. Emotion thus justified by discrimination becomes acceptable.

Probably with this in mind, ┼Ъr─л Y─Бmun─Бc─Бrya calls ArjunaтАЩs pity тАШasth─Бna-k─Бruс╣ЗyaтАЩ тАУ compassion at a wrong time and wrong place. ArjunaтАЩs intemperate and inconsiderate pity can be classified as a sentiment. Sentiment is emotion, or even excessive emotion. The heart when it does not submit itself to being examined by the head becomes agitated, it is sentimental. Bhagav─Бn calls this тАШhс╣Ыdaya-daurbalyaтАЩ тАУ weakness of the heart. The softer the heart, the shallower it is, the weaker it becomes. We can call it the quagmire of tears. It may be said that this kind of flaccidity and unsteadiness is characteristic of our times.

[[Chapter 1. Yoga of Inconsiderate Compassion (Part 3) Source: prekshaa]]

It is claimed often that ours is an Age of Science, an era of intellectual superiority. On the one hand, the intellect is mighty but on the other hand, the mind is fragile. Our times despise difficulties. Let nothing be difficult, may everything be easy тАУ a piece of cake тАУ this is todayтАЩs mindset.

This starts in our schools. Indian languages have the letters cha, bha, kс╣гa, hra тАУ who needs these letters? They weary the children.

Let us not chastise students for anything. They have to be reformed by bribes of candy and sweets. Let us spare the rod even if it spoils the child.

Skin exposed to the sun and wind will become rough. Let us keep it covered always.

It is perturbing to be asked to brush oneтАЩs teeth before breakfast. Let people eat whenever they want, brush their teeth whenever they want.

Thus flows the river of pity in spate!

Why should one obtain forty out of a hundred marks to pass? It is enough if she manages ten!

There should be a manure shop right next to a shop that sells fine musk. That is equality.

Let the man who has never had a bath in his life rub the body of a man who bathes daily. IsnтАЩt that brotherhood?

If the daughter says that she does not want to marry someone who is not a billionaire, can we ask her to marry a millionaire? If we do force her, what will become of individual freedom?

If there is an unjust conflict between countries, let us prattle about peace and non-violence and not even raise the subject of war. Let our weapons rust even if our hearts simmer.

Why does the Creator give legs to humans? It is because of legs that we have to walk and strain ourselves. Instead of that, let us design a machine in a car that will lift people and seat them within.

Why should the Supreme create horses? Horse-riding is dangerous and fatiguing. Let men fly without the least exertion.

Why do we need snacks like chakli or puс╕╗с╕╗aс╣Еg─Бyi? They exhaust the teeth. Can we not suck tasty candy instead?

If a debtor does not repay his loans, do not demand that from him! Let him not fear about being jailed. Scaring is torturing. Let us take pity on him and loan him more money.

Let murderers not be afraid of execution. Let us give them asylum with tasty food and warm shelter so that he does not feel any grief.

The police should not incarcerate dacoits and cause them undue hardship. They should beg them to become good citizens.

Workers should forget that they are working and behave as though they are masters. Let the company run into losses, it does not matter. The happiness of the comrades is paramount.

The stone-hearted R─Бma sent S─лt─Б to the forest in a cruel manner. Why should we worship him?

The river of pity flows further. This is the weakness of the soul, the fragility of the mind. It is not manliness.

If a human soul has to become strong, it should be ready to face difficulties.

n─Бyam-─Бtm─Б bala-h─лnena labhyaс╕е…
(Muс╣Зс╕Нakopaniс╣гad 3.2.4)

A coward cannot grasp dharma. It needs courage and intelligence. The bones of a lazy man are soft; he is not capable of taking on challenges or fighting in wars. He cannot protect dharma.

Only the t─Бmasika and r─Бjasika qualities of humans cause war, not s─Бttvika. When sattva is prominent, there is no conflict. Even if there is one, it is resolved quickly. Rajas and tamas do not end like that. They understand the language of the stick, not that of guidance. The predominant trait of Duryodhana and Du┼Ы┼Ы─Бsana is t─Бmasika, not s─Бttvika. For such rulers guided by their baser instincts, any medicine other than war would be useless. Therefore, there was no means to correct them except stringent punishment.

A great man said, тАЬWhat is dharma without mercy?тАЭ A philosopher said, тАЬWhat sort of mercy is it, without dharma?тАЭ Thus, to aid in the goal of establishing dharma, just as there is a place for mercy, there is also a place for punishment. Courage is the first quality needed in a person who wants to protect dharma. A man who flees without fighting on seeing injustice and adharma is not merciful but is actually encouraging adharma.

This, then, is the mental state of Arjuna. His is not compassion bestowed on people worthy of it but pity shown towards people who are entirely undeserving of it. Bhagav─Бn himself proclaims that one should exercise due discretion whether the recipient is worthy of pity.

de┼Ыe k─Бle ca p─Бtre ca tad-d─Бnaс╣Г s─Бttvikaс╣Г smс╣Ыtamрее (BG 17.20)

This philosophy had been forgotten by Arjuna.

ArjunaтАЩs thought was that of pity but the circumstances were not right. P─Бyasam is good to eat and digest, not to smear on the body. This discrimination тАУ of finding the right place to do the right thing is the basis of dharma.

That ArjunaтАЩs dejection transformed into pity and detachment shows that his understanding was superior. His dispassion is not that of a coward or a weak person. The dejection of some people transforms itself into rage. In some others, it brings hopelessness and rigidity. Arjuna did not become depressed or angry. His words тАШKiс╣Г bhogair-j─лvitena v─БтАЩ do not have any philosophical curiosity. His mind is uncertain about dharma. That had to be remedied. The reason for the uncertainty was the pity that arose in him.

Like anger, pity is also a mental change. In normal human circumstances, it may be a good sentiment. There is no dharma without mercy, but mercy should not be unrefined. The pity that animals and birds show to their young ones is artless and unrefined. Mother Nature has placed this unthinking inclination in all living organisms. In lower organisms, the purpose of this natural inclination is to nurture the offspring. In humans, if this natural inclination works independently of discrimination it can cause confusion and have adverse consequences. Compassion not tempered by discrimination is unbridled infatuation and delusion тАУ that is partiality; that is the confused view; that is the thorn in the way of justice. Therefore, Bhagav─Бn felt that the juice of compassion that swelled in Arjuna out of his natural inclination had to be filtered by viveka. Mental alterations have to be purified by philosophy тАУ that is the subject of the next chapter.

[[Chapter 1. Yoga of Inconsiderate Compassion (Part 4) Source: prekshaa]]

The fault of ArjunaтАЩs compassion is not just that it was indiscriminate and unexamined. It was mixed with ego. The self-delusion that he was responsible for deciding the nature of his dharma, that the others were fit for compassion, that the decision to fight the war was out of his own free will (see BG 18.58тАУ59) was included in it.

Among the various forms of human relationship, compassion is indeed great. There are very few people in the world worthy of compassion but dharma applies to the whole world. Therefore, the appropriateness or inappropriateness of compassion has to be examined with due consideration given to dharma. Dharma is a conglomeration of many principles of which compassion is only one. A dh─Бrmic person should consider other relevant principles during his course of action.

Compassion is natural whereas dharma is established by right judgment. The basis of compassion is nature whereas the basis of dharma is philosophical deliberation. Compassion that negates dharma can be disastrous. Therefore, when compassion manifests itself, it is necessary to examine and purify it in the light of philosophy. Thus, a study of the nature of dharma becomes pertinent.

Summary

р▓зр▓ир│Бр▓╡р▓В р▓зр▓░р▓┐р▓╕р│Жр▓ир│Жр▓ир│Бр▓др│Нр▓дред

War is the root cause of p─Бpa, causes elders and loved ones
To be killed, destroys the dharma of the world, therefore
I will not bear my bow, said Arjuna
To the Lord тАУ thus finishes the first chapter.

Appendix: Dharma is Multifaceted

Many people think that dharma is a feast of l─Бс╕Нus and c─лroс╣нis. They do not feel that pepper chutney and ginger pickle are dharma. Arjuna is like them.

He is a good man. His virtues are something we generally praise but we do not know if viveka is part of it. Goodness unaccompanied by viveka cannot yield the intended result. In the feast of a man of discernment, there is a place for pepper rasam, just as there is a place for p─Бyasam. In the conduct of dharma, just like there is a place for compassion, there is a place for stone-heartedness.

vajr─Бd-api kaс╣нhor─Бс╣Зi mс╣Ыd┼лni kusum─Бd-apiред
(Uttara-r─Бma-carita 2.7)

Arjuna had forgotten this. Just as nurturing life is dharma, there can be circumstances where killing also becomes dharma. Just as friendship is dharma, there are also circumstances where war becomes dharma. In the case of Sugr─лva and Vibh─лс╣гaс╣Зa, friendship became dharma for ┼Ъr─лr─Бma. In the case of V─Бl─л and R─Бvaс╣Зa, killing became his dharma.

The essence of dharma is the elevation of the soul. By following dharma, the soul should get trained and should elevate itself to at least a little higher state. The souls of Sugr─лva and Vibh─лс╣гaс╣Зa were in a slightly more elevated state than those of Vali and Ravana. The training that they had to undergo had to be done through friendship. V─Бl─л and R─Бvaс╣Зa lacked the qualifications to be trained through friendship in their current birth, so it was necessary for them to be reborn to acquire them. Some dirty clothes can be washed and cleaned. Some other dirty clothes cannot even be touched by water тАУ fire is their refuge. The same can be said about bodies. This is the essence of the art and dharma of war.

After Hiraс╣Зyaka┼Ыipu was killed, his son Prahl─Бda beseeched Narasiс╣Гha to grant him salvation. The Supreme One replied тАУ

triс╕е-saptabhiс╕е pit─Б p┼лtaс╕е pitс╣Ыbhiс╕е saha teтАЩnaghaред (Bh─Бgavata-pur─Бс╣Зa 7.10.18)

…pituс╕е p┼лtasya sarva┼Ыaс╕еред
madaс╣Еga-spar┼Ыanen─Бс╣Еga-lok─Бn y─Бsyati supraj─Бс╕ерее (Bh─Бgavata-pur─Бс╣Зa 7.10.22)

The touch of the SupremeтАЩs limbs is the panacea that cures the p─Бp─л. Therefore, Bhagav─БnтАЩs avat─Бra kills the p─Бp─л, thereby freeing the soul from the prison of vice. This sort of killing, even though it looks cruel at the superficial level, it is not cruelty but compassion when examined subtly. It is the compassion of a wise man тАУ like that of a surgeon.

Dharma has to occasionally take fierce forms тАУ just as the hands of the father who feeds sweets might also have to give a slap. Just as a spank from the father is affection, just as the bitter medicine from the physician is compassion, so also is the war that is waged for the sake of dharma.

Dharma is not just the sound of festive bells, it is also the sound of lionsтАЩ roar. The call of dharma is not just for feminine affection but also for masculine brave-hearts. Our people should understand this well. After pepper has finished its job, black gram can take its place. After war has finished its work, compassion and affection can find their places. After the stick of the teacher has worked its magic, the disciple will win prizes. Bhagav─Бn himself has indicated this тАУ

yat-tad-agre viс╣гam-iva pariс╣З─БmeтАЩmс╣Ыtopamamред (BG 18.37)

Neem always comes before jaggery.

duс╕еkham-ity-eva yat-karma k─Бya-kle┼Ыa-bhay─Бt tyajetред (BG 18.8)

na dveс╣гс╣нy-aku┼Ыalaс╣Г karma ku┼Ыale n─Бnuс╣гajvateред (BG 18.10)

We should not give up a job because it is tedious. It should not be avoided just because it is difficult for the body. An activity should not be shunned because it is difficult or disagreeable; neither should it be adhered to because it is delightful.

It is enough if a job is dharma. Whatever it is, it has to be finished тАУ that is the purport of this chapter. It is not right to eye the results, whether they are good or bad, attained or not attained.

Like the Pit─Бmaha Brahm─Б, dharma can also be visualized as having four faces. It is said that Brahm─Б recites the four Vedas through his four mouths. Dharma, with its four mouths, will teach these four duties тАУ (1) nurturing of the ─Бtm─Б, (2) purification of the ─Бtm─Б, (3) understanding the true nature of Self, and (4) benevolence towards the world. Among the above, purification of the ─Бtm─Б is tapas. It cannot be achieved by short-cuts. Like ┼Ъiva, it has a terrific form; it performs the fearsome t─Бс╣Зс╕Нava dance; it drinks the h─Бl─Бhala. ArjunaтАЩs eyes beheld this fierce form of dharma in front of him at Kurukс╣гetra. It needed a courageous heart not feminine yearning. It needed virility. That is why Bhagav─БnтАЩs advice was replete with instructions to be valorous and heroic.

Soft as a flower now, hard as a rock then, rigid at another time
Flowing continuously like a river now, meandering then, and then hidden
Sweet as honey now, pungent as ginger then, behold thus, dharma takes
A hundred forms in this world, suited for various souls.

р▓ор▓ир│Бр▓Ьр▓╛р▓ир│Бр▓нр▓╡р▓кр│Нр▓░р▓╛р▓Ьр│Нр▓Юр▓ир▓ир│Бр▓Хр▓Вр▓кр▓╛р▓░р│Нр▓жр│Нр▓░р▓▓р│Лр▓Ър▓ир▓В
р▓Шр▓ир▓╢р│Нр▓пр▓╛р▓ор▓В р▓Хр│Нр▓╖р▓ор▓╛р▓зр▓╛р▓ор▓В р▓╢р▓░р▓гр│Нр▓пр▓В р▓Хр│Гр▓╖р│Нр▓гр▓ир▓╛р▓╡р▓Чр▓В рее

One who is cognizant of human experiences, his eyes moist with sympathy
Dark as a cloud, the abode of mercy тАУ he, Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa, is our refuge always.

Thus Concludes Chapter 1.

[[Ch. 2 Yoga of Discernment of Reality (Part 1) Source: prekshaa]]

Elucidating the nature of reality
from s─Бс╣Еkhya and other ancient sciences,

the eternal and omnipresent Self in detail and

Substance

Arjuna was unaware of exceptional circumstances wherein violence became imperative and compassion became inappropriate. He did not realize that a limited personal perspective or common public opinion was insufficient to arrive at the right conclusion. He was ignorant of the idea that the determination of oneтАЩs dharma required discernment between the Real and the Unreal.

Karma (action) depends upon the performer whereas the fruit of action is dependent on Providence. Excellence or kau┼Ыala (skill) is that by which one does not accumulate detriment while performing oneтАЩs dharma.

Chapter Two

S─Бс╣Еkhya-yoga (The Yoga of Knowledge)

or Tattva-viveka-yoga (The Yoga of Discernment of Reality)

Terminology

There are several words of ┼Ы─Бstric terminology in the G─лt─Б such as ─Бtm─Б, brahman, and prakс╣Ыti, which have not been defined or explained. Such words had been in common parlance for ages prior to the G─лt─Б. These terms have come to us from the Vedas and Upaniс╣гads that are thousands of years older than the G─лt─Б. Therefore, it might not have been necessary for either Vy─Бsa, Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa, or Arjuna to explain these terms. However, an understanding of these terms is a necessary prerequisite for our study. Let us now comprehend, albeit in brief, some of the most important terms.

1. Adhi-dharma тАУ This word is not found in the G─лt─Б. I do not know if this term has been used in any ancient work. As I deem it to be a necessary term, it has been used in this work.

Dharma can be deliberated upon through six different perspectives:

A. Dharma is the body of obligatory worksтАФboth worldly and VedicтАФcomprising ritual practices, conduct, and restrictions that enables oneтАЩs own welfare as well as that of the others.

B. Svadharma is dharma based upon a personтАЩs circumstances, clan, and society. In other words, it is oneтАЩs own dharma.

C. Adharma тАУ (i) Something that is not dharma or (ii) Something that is against dharma.

D. Vidharma тАУ (i) Something that is not oneтАЩs own dharma or (ii) The dharma of the others.

E. Ubhaya-t─Бс╣нasthya (indifference to both) тАУ Being indifferent to both dharma and adharma.

F. Adhi-dharma is one who, though beyond dharma and adharma, follows dh─Бrmic behaviour in society. As he sees his own Self everywhere, he has no friends or foes; or likes and dislikes; and hence free from the touch of p─Бpa and puс╣Зya. Therefore the adhi-dharma has no need for rules and prohibitions. However, he acts as if he is subject to societal rules and norms and performs worldly activities while free from the fruitful or unfruitful rewards of those actions.

tyaja dharmam-adharmaс╣Г ca рее
(Renounce both dharma and adharma)
yena tyajasi tat-tyaja рее
(Renounce that by which you renounce)
Saс╣Гny─Бsopaniс╣гad 2.17

2. Avidy─Б тАУ This word is not found in the G─лt─Б but is found in ┼Ы─Бstra. Avidy─Б is the deficiency in human knowledge, not the absence of it. The illumination of the Self is obstructed by the impurities from previous lives. Therefore one is unable to see an illusion as an illusion. This lack of knowledge and its insufficiency is avidy─Б.

3. ─Аtm─Б тАУ This word has several meanings. Let us note a few of them here:

(i) Consciousness accompanying the body тАУ The entity being alluded to when man refers to the word тАЬIтАЭ in his mind. This ─Бtm─Б, referring to itself as тАЬIтАЭ (тАЬahamтАЭ), тАЬIтАЭ, separates itself from the world. This can be referred to as deh─Бtm─Б or embodied self. The body or deha includes sensory and motor organs, mind, intellect and the vital airs.

(ii) Manas тАУ ─Аtm─Б also refers to the mind that is distinct from the body. тАЬMah─Бtm─БтАЭ (great soul), тАЬduс╣гс╣н─Бtm─БтАЭ (evil soul) and тАЬp─Бp─Бtm─БтАЭ (sinful soul) refer to this definition of the ─Бtm─Б.

(iii) J─лv─Бtm─Б тАУ The entity that, while different from the body and mind, illumines and enlivens both. This is referred to as the j─лv─Бtm─Б. The word тАЬj─лvaтАЭ refers to pure consciousness coupled with the body and a few other elements.

(iv) Antar─Бtm─Б тАУ Pure consciousness without any up─Бdhis (adjuncts). This is also referred to as the k┼лс╣н─Бtm─Б or s┼лtr─Бtm─Б. The name s┼лtr─Бtm─Б denotes the consciousness that is like the string in a necklace of pearls that is unseen and untouched. It is the inner essence of all beings.

The previous definitions pertained to the individual being.

(v) Param─Бtm─Б тАУ Collective existence of the individual consciousness found in all beings. This pervades all creation and gives energy to every being. This is an aspect of para-brahman.

4. ─к┼Ыvara тАУ State of brahman related to creation, preservation, destruction, and other activities pertaining to the created universe.

5. с╣Ъta тАУ Natural order in the world. This is seen in the movements of the earth, the planets, the sun, the moon, and other celestial objects as well as in the change of seasons and in the production of offspring. The special distinguishing quality seen in each individual substance is с╣Ыta. Seen this way, с╣Ыta is the seed of dharma. с╣Ъta is Truth contemplated upon internally, or Reality. It is also the power that makes available the appropriate fruit for karma.

6. Karma or transmigratory karma is of three kinds:

(i) Sa├▒cita тАУ This is the collective set of merits and demerits produced by actions performed across several lives. These are waiting to yield results.

(ii) ─Аg─Бmi тАУ Karma that has not yet yielded fruit and will yield fruit later.

(iii) Pr─Бrabdha тАУ is a part of the sa├▒cita karma that has begun to yield fruit. In a pile of grain, a few grains would have begun to sprout; pr─Бrabdha is such. This pr─Бrabdha can be exhausted only by experiencing and enduring it.

Has not the beginningless j─лva lived across so many births? The mass of karma that remains after experiencing its fruits is akin to todayтАЩs leftover food that came from yesterdayтАЩs cooking. This is of three kindsтАФsa├▒cita, ─Бg─Бmi, pr─БrabdhaтАФas explained before.

When grains of ragi (or any cereal) are moistened, a few of those grains sprout sooner. Other grains sprout in time. The sprouted ones constitute pr─Бrabdha. There are other distinctions in pr─Бrabdha тАУ but those are not relevant here.

Terminology

[Continued]

7. K─Бla-De┼Ыa тАУ See De┼Ыa-K─Бla.

8. De┼Ыa-K─Бla (Space-time) тАУ The ideas of size and duration that emerge in our minds through the experience of various objects and actions. Both de┼Ыa and k─Бla are expressions of the existence of the world. The world is an aggregate of things and actions. The word de┼Ыa (or dik - direction) indicates the shape and size of objects in the world and their mutual relationships. The word k─Бla denotes the actions of the world, the extent of their influence, and the intervals between them. The feeling of de┼Ыa-k─Бla exists wherever the world exists. Where there is no world, de┼Ыa-k─Бla does not exist or it is beyond the Universe. That is Infinite Existence; that is pure existence. De┼Ыa and k─Бla are but markers of the experience of existence. This topic is extended in the Appendix.

9. Daiva-vidhi (Fate/Destiny) тАУ The Divine order that controls the experience of a j─лva. That is the law of с╣Ыta. This is the yarn woven from two threads. One of those threads is the existing individual karma of the j─лva. The other is the Universal law for ensuring order in collective existence. These two threads come together to form daiva.

10. Dharma тАУ What sustains i.e., saves and protects, is dharma. The set of activities, worldly actions, and rules that nourishes and exalts life is dharma.

The above ten aspects belong to this world. The mode of living by which a human j─лva gives up its adjuncts of body and bodily organs, subsequently attains Divine experience, and goes beyond the world is known as dharma. The system of the world that ensures deliverance for the j─лva is dharma, which is applicable to the j─лva as long as it is in contact with the three kinds of bodies. Once beyond the j─лva state, there is no bond of dharma. (See adhi-dharma)

11. Prakс╣Ыti тАУ The power of brahman and is its expressed state, i.e., its external form.

12. Brahman тАУ The root meaning of brahman is big. In the ┼Ы─Бstras, it means limitless. That is Infinity. The bounds of time or space do not limit brahman. That is of the form of consciousness. It is impossible to define it completely with words because words belong to the material world. Brahman-consciousness is not just omnipresent in the Universe but is also beyond it. It is even beyond human imagination. This brahman is parabrahman (Supreme brahman). It is also known in human conversation as Param─Бtm─Б and ─к┼Ыvara. (Look at the earlier definition of the word тАШ─Бtm─БтАЩ). The source of the Universe is brahman and when expressed in the world, it is known as ┼Ыabala-brahman (brahman endowed with variety) or k─Бrya-brahman (brahman as effect). The manifest brahman is also known as parame┼Ыvara (Supreme Lord) because in this state as ─к┼Ыvara, brahman causes creation, sustenance, and dissolution of the universe. When beyond the world, brahman is referred to as ┼Ыuddha-brahman (pure brahman), k─Бraс╣Зa-brahman (cause brahman) or Para-brahman (Supreme brahman).

These explanations are of a coarse nature. The subtleties in meaning will become clearer as we proceed.

13. M─Бy─Б тАУ The thing that, as a result of the incessant interaction amongst the components of the world, rises as a cloud-like layer between the seer [one who is seeing] and the seen [that which is being seen by the seer]. It makes existent objects appear as non-existent and vice-versa. That which masks an existing object is known as ─Бvaraс╣Зa. Making a non-existent thing appear is known as vikс╣гepa.

The word m─Бy─Б with its various shades of meaning will be seen in this work.

14. M┼лrta-Am┼лrta (with form-without form) тАУ Of the five primordial elements (Earth, Air, Water, Ether and Light), Earth, Water, and Light are considered to be with form and hence m┼лrta. Air and Ether do not have a form and are hence am┼лrta.

M┼лrta and am┼лrta are also used in the sense of sa-deha (with body) and a-deha (without body).

15. Vyakta-Avyakta (manifest-unmanifest) тАУ Vyakta refers to the state in which a thingтАЩs inner qualities are expressed or manifested externally. The world is a manifestation of brahmanтАЩs power. Avyakta is the state wherein a thingтАЩs qualities lie unexpressed like a sprout latent within a seed. This is the state of prakс╣Ыti before creation.

16. Vyaс╣гс╣нi-Samaс╣гс╣нi (individual-collective) тАУ Vyaс╣гс╣нi refers to the individual level; and is something that can be counted one by one or separately.

When we say тАШrupeeтАЩ, its hundred different paisas are counted together. The paisas individually count as vyaс╣гс╣нi. Samaс╣гс╣нi is the integration of different things together. A collection of all vyaс╣гс╣нi is known as samaс╣гс╣нi. Putting together a hundred different paise to form one rupee is samaс╣гс╣нi.

17. Vy─Бkс╣Ыta-Avy─Бkс╣Ыta (divided-undivided) тАУ Vy─Бkс╣Ыta is the state when different parts are seen in a single mass of objects. The state when something is divided or classified into genera (plural of genus) and classes is vy─Бkс╣Ыta. Vy─Бkaraс╣Зa (Grammar) means the same. Classifying a whole language into nouns, adjectives, verbs, indeclinables, suffixes, and prefixes and defining the relationships amongst them is vy─Бkaraс╣Зa.

Avy─Бkс╣Ыta is the state when a mass remains undifferentiated or undivided.

M┼лrta-Am┼лrta, Vyakta-Avyakta and Vy─Бkс╣Ыta-Avy─Бkс╣Ыta are three sets of terms used for explaining the process of creation.

18. Sat-Asat (real-unreal) тАУ These words have two or three meanings.

The first meaning.

Sat тАУ Existent, what is created, Truth.

Asat тАУ Non-existent, one without a тАЬrealтАЭ existence, falsehood.

In this sense of meaning, asat also means mere appearance. Whatever does not exist in reality, i.e., cannot exist by itself and is dependent on something else to be perceived by the eyes, ears, and other organs, however fleetingly, is asat.

A tree is sat; its shadow is asat. Man is sat; his reflection in the mirror is asat. Similarly, brahman is sat, the world is asat. Mithy─Б (error) is asat. Sat is Truth, reality.

Asat or mithy─Б (error) does not refer to a void; or complete non-existence; or something imaginary like the horns of a hare. It means that it is an appearance, dream-like.

The second meaning.

Sat тАУ Something that is perceivable. What we know as existent is sat.

Asat тАУ Something that is not perceivable. Whatever is not available to us, even if it exists.

asadv─Б idamagra ─Бs─лt
Aitareyopaniс╣гad 2.7
(WasnтАЩt it asat that existed before?)

Asat is imperceptible. In this meaning, asat is also avyakta (unmanifest).

The third meaning.

Sat тАУ What is good; beneficial.

Asat тАУ Not good; bad.

[[Ch. 2 Yoga of Discernment of Reality (Part 3) Source: prekshaa]]

The Beginning of the Instruction

The second chapter of the G─лt─Б has four main aspects.

  1. The remainder of the first chapterтАЩs topic, i.e. ArjunaтАЩs words of abandoning battle. 2. Propounding the eternal nature of the Self (─Бtm─Б) 3. The necessity of performing oneтАЩs own dharma 4. The nature of the knower of reality

Let us look at this one by one.

ArjunaтАЩs Wish to Give Up

The story of ArjunaтАЩs depression continues in the first nine verses. When Arjuna dropped his bow and arrows and sat immersed in sorrow, ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa objected. He said, тАЬArjuna, how did this mental impurity come upon you? This does not befit an ─Бrya. This is not conducive to attain higher realms. This causes infamy. Discard this cowardice. Cast off this lowly weakness of the heart and rise for battle!тАЭ

Arjuna replied, тАЬO Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa, how can I bring myself shoot the worshipful Bh─лс╣гma and Droс╣Зa with my arrows? If we, by not killing preceptors, have to subsist on alms, even then, such food obtained from begging is far better than food mixed with their blood. Should we win over our enemies or be won over by them? Which path is better for us? Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa, who are our enemies? Those upon killing whom we do not wish to live! My nature has been overcome by the taint of selfish pity that is the nature of compassion for тАЬme and mineтАЭ (k─Бrpaс╣Зya-d┼Нс╣г┼Нpahata-svabh─Бvaс╕е). I have become confused about what dharma is owing to this self-love. What of a kingdom on earth or the position of Indra in svarga? I do not see anything that can cure me of my sorrow that is drying up all my senses.тАЭ He then said,

na yotsye! (BG 2.9)
тАЬI will not fight!тАЭ

and sat silently. The first part of the second chapter ends here.

Now, Bhagav─Бn again set forth to give instruction.

a┼Ы┼Нcy─Бn-anva┼Ы┼Нcas-tvam (BG 2.11)
тАЬYou grieve for those who should not be grieved for!тАЭ

What does this mean? Should one not grieve for his preceptors and relatives? Should one become stony-hearted?

It is natural for the heart to melt with compassion. However, in some instances, one should harden his heart. The battle for dharma is such an instance.

War is an occasion that involves several groups of people. Floods, fire accidents, earthquakes, and epidemics are disasters that the Divine imposes to punish groups of people. A single personтАЩs action also affects people other than the doer when it yields results.

kaс╣Ыt─Б k─Бrayit─Б caiva preraka┼Ы-c─Бnumodakaс╕е
(Nitya-n─лti 30)
The performer of the action,
one who causes the action to be performer,
the one who urges it, and
the one who approves of it,
[all share equal responsibility
in good and bad deeds]

Individual karma (actions) bear individual fruit; group actions yield group results. Though Duryodhana and his brothers were the main actors in the war, Bh─лс╣гma, Droс╣Зa, Karс╣Зa, ┼Ъalya, and others joined forces with them regardless of whether they liked it. The same happened in their rival camp. While a few joined for the cause of dharma, there were others who joined either side for revenge, glory, or other reasons. Death was perilously close to both sides. In this episode of dharma, who were the ┼Ыocyas (ones to grieve for)? Who were the a┼Ыocyas (those who should not be grieved for)? Who? None were to be grieved for. Those who died there were not to be grieved for. Why? Death comes for a few as deliverance from their demerits. For others death results in a better path. Duryodhana, Du┼Ы┼Ы─Бsana and others would have continued to commit sinful actions as long as they lived. The seed of impurity had existed in them across lives. They had to be divested of their armour (body) to help them get rid of their p─Бpa. Death became a means for this. Death in battle was the only way for them to redeem themselves from this situation of p─Бpa.

Thus death redeems the evil from the clutches of evilness. Therefore it is not necessary to grieve for it.

Even for those who are virtuous, death is helpful. Bh─лс╣гma and Droс╣Зa were great souls and deserved higher worlds. But they had to inhabit earth due to a residue of their karma of previous lives. Once they had exhausted their karma, they would once again become eligible for those higher worlds. Hence for those righteous, death obtained in a war of dharma helps attain heaven and better worlds. Hence sorrow is not proper even in this situation.

When is grieving appropriate, when is it proper? The answer is: Never. It is of course another matter that it cannot be avoided. It cannot be argued that all things that are natural are correct as well. There are so many bodily actions that are natural but undesirable. It is the same with mental actions too. All things natural cannot be accepted. Sorrow upon bereavement is natural. But it is wise to mitigate oneтАЩs sorrow after considering the progression of a j─лva and the law of nature. Bhagav─Бn now teaches this wisdom through a description of the ─Бtm─Б that is the essence of the j─лva.

The Eternality of the ─Аtm─Б

The instruction now begins. Arjuna asks four important questions:

  1. IsnтАЩt violence or killing beings a misdeed? 2. IsnтАЩt compassion our dharma? 3. ShouldnтАЩt selfish desires be discarded? 4. IsnтАЩt dharma the biggest value?

┼Ъr─л-kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa had to answer these questions.

Arjuna had all the following mental qualities: fear of doing evil, compassion towards beings, selflessness, and faith in dharma, which are accepted by all to be the best of qualities. Did such a man, endowed with such admirable qualities, need instruction? Yes. Because Arjuna possessed those qualities not as results of his own deliberations but because he was impelled by his own natural condition and also by imitating others. All of us are mostly like that. There are a few naturally friendly tendencies within us. We normally refer to that as a тАЬtug at oneтАЩs heartstrings.тАЭ While that behaviour is devoid of any pretense, we should not consider that feeling to be completely pure. There is quite likely an iota of selfishness or a particle of pride or a piece of egotism that is non-obvious and latent in such behaviour. Friendship becomes pure and wholesome only after this aspect of self-interest is removed after a thorough examination. We learn several behaviours from those around us. We form our opinions through others. Any action or habit or opinion or belief should not be construed as pure or as being conducive to welfare just because it follows popular convention. We should have independently analysed it and understood its good aspects. Thus our behaviours and opinions must be a result of a proper examination.

[[Ch. 2 Yoga of Discernment of Reality (Part 4) Source: prekshaa]]

It may be apt to recall the maxim of the English philosopher John Stuart Mill. It is not enough if one person forms an opinion or follows a certain set of actions because of faith in the words of othersтАЩ words. One should yearn to understand the exact reasons why a certain thing is good through oneтАЩs own analysis. Then the thing becomes truly beneficial. A belief that arises from blind faith may not be as fruitful.

The same words are stated by the Vedas that are thousands of years old тАУ

yad-eva vidyay─Б karotiтАж
tad-eva v─лryavattaraс╣Г bhavatiрее
Ch─Бndogyopaniс╣гat 1.1.10
(Whatever one does with knowledge, that becomes efficacious)

vij├▒─Бnaс╣Г yaj├▒aс╣Г tanuteрее
Taittir─лyopaniс╣гat 2.5
(Knowledge from analysis accomplishes an activity)

Vidy─Б refers to knowledge тАУ the knowledge of a thing, knowledge that rises from deliberation on cause and effect. The knowledge that is produced from analysis is vij├▒─Бna. Action becomes meaningful only when accompanied by knowledge borne out of reasoning and discernment. Arjuna did not possess that clarity of thought. His fear of p─Бpa was not the result of his own analysis. It was based on what others said. His compassion was because of unrefined mental impressions and it lacked the refinement of analysis. It belonged to the feeling heart, not to the thinking mind. His dispassion similarly lacked consideration. It came from momentary distress and not as a result of discernment between the eternal and the ephemeral. The householder, encountering some disorderly conduct or arrogant behavior in his house, laments, тАЬI will exit all of this and go elsewhere,тАЭ or bawls, тАЬWho cares if something happens to me? I canтАЩt deal with all this!тАЭ In the next moment, he tries to fix the problem. ArjunaтАЩs feeling of renunciation was like that тАУ a renunciation that was not hardened by discretion but one assumed in a hurry. His tendency towards virtue was of the same kind тАУ one that came from worldly convention and not from a fundamental knowledge of dharma. He agreed that he did not comprehend the true nature of dharma.

pс╣Ыcch─Бmi tv─Бс╣Г dharma-samm┼лс╕Нha-cet─Бс╕ерее (BG 2.7)
(With a mind confused about dharma, I ask you)

When Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa began answering ArjunaтАЩs questions it is evident from the following words that the latter was ridiculed тАУ тАШprahasannivaтАЩ (as if laughing), тАШpraj├▒─Бv─Бd─Бс╣Г┼Ыca bh─Бс╣гaseтАЩ (you seem to speak words of wisdom). ArjunaтАЩs knowledge was born out of confusion and not true wisdom. He uttered weighty words of wisdom such as p─Бpa, puс╣Зya, vair─Бgya, dharma тАУ like a scholar. He did not understand anything about the origin of these wise words or their inner meaning or the depth of its meaning. That was what was derided by Bhagav─Бn as тАШseeming words of wisdom.тАЩ Bhagav─БnтАЩs duty, then, was to disabuse Arjuna of this confusion.

тАЬArjuna, you are endowed with a keen faith towards dharma. Saying тАШuts─Бdyante j─Бti-dharm─Бс╕е kula-dharm─Б┼Ы-ca ┼Ы─Б┼Ыvat─Бс╕етАЩ (transgressed are the age-old ways of the clans and j─Бtis) тАУ you expressed anxiety and sorrow. Do you, however, know what the duty of your class is? Recall it! Is parroting тАШDharma, dharmaтАЩ the same as knowing its true nature?тАЭ

The crux of all of ArjunaтАЩs questions was the matter of the ─Бtm─Б (the Self). The relationship with the world, compassion, puс╣Зya, p─Бpa, and dharma тАУ are all matters pertaining to the j─лva. As the j─лva is a manifestation of the Self, the answers to all other questions become evident only after having known the true nature of the Self. Thus it is imperative to know what the Self is.

Dharma and adharma cannot be determined merely by our natural impulses or by worldly convention. The compassion in ArjunaтАЩs mind was a transformation of the mind that happened naturally rather than arising out of an examined consideration. The opinions he had of puс╣Зya and p─Бpa were created by what people spoke of and lacked any solid proof or testimony. dharma has to be decided based upon the nature of reality. The nature of reality has to be determined from ┼Ы─Бstra (scriptural exposition). The nature of reality is something beyond the empirical and unavailable to the senses. Hence it has to be determined only by the Vedas and other scriptural testimony. Therefore, Bhagav─Бn has declared in the sixteenth chapter тАУ

tasm─Бcc─Бstraс╣Г pram─Бс╣Зaс╣Г teрее (BG 16.24)
(Therefore, ┼Ы─Бstra is your means to knowledge.)

Dharma can be determined only by understanding the nature of reality, which in turn is determined from the ┼Ы─Бstras.

Nity─Бnityaviveka тАУ Discernment between Eternal and Non-eternal

We see two kinds of objects in our experiential world.

A few objects constantly change and undergo growth, decline, and other modifications. These are non-eternal. This constitutes the majority of the experienced world. But doesnтАЩt the experienced world exist at least for a little while? From where does its ephemeral existence arise? DoesnтАЩt this experienced world act even in its limited condition? From where does its power of animation arise? Who gave it its form? Who changes it? The root of this power of the world is eternal тАУ Brahman. The sentience that acts behind and inside all objects is Brahman. Thus the experienced universe comprises two substances тАУ the impermanent world and the eternal Brahman.

The world is asat тАУ i.e., lacks an independent existence. Brahman has existence and it is this existence that is the basis of this world.

Now, Bhagav─Бn expounds on the relationship between these two substances because the answer to ArjunaтАЩs question had to originate from this bifurcation of the world into the eternal and the non-eternal. The act of war is related to the non-eternal.

From these words,

n─Бsato vidyate bh─Бvo n─Бbh─Бvo vidyate satah╠г ред
ubhayor-api dr╠гs╠гt╠гoтАЩntas-tv-anayos-tattva-dar┼Ыibhih╠г рее (BG 2.16)
тАЬSat (existence) is not born from Asat (non-existence). What does not exist is not born from what exists. (i.e., the non-existent is never born and the existent never dies). They are the wise who have realized the essence of the existent and the non-existent.тАЭ

Did not ArjunaтАЩs doubt arise from his concern over killing sentient beings? Killing is that which makes something non-existent. What is тАШbeingтАЩ or тАШnon-beingтАЩ? Let us first understand their nature тАУ says Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa. What things are apt to be denoted as тАШexistentтАЩ or by the verb тАШisтАЩ? Whatever cannot be destroyed and whatever remains unchanged is aptly denoted by the words тАУ тАШsat,тАЩ тАШsatt─Б,тАЩ or тАШsatya.тАЩ Such an unchanged and undestroyed thing is Brahman.

avin─Б┼Ыi tu tad-viddhi yena sarvam-idaс╣Г tatam ред
vin─Б┼Ыam-avyayasy─Бsya na ka┼Ыcit kartum-arhati рее (BG 2.17)
тАЬWhatever permeates all of this тАУ understand that to be indestructible. None can destroy this, which has no decline.тАЭ
antavanta ime deh─Бh╠г nityasyokt─Бh╠г ┼Ыar─лrin╠гah╠г ред
an─Б┼ЫinoтАЩprameyasya tasm─Бd-yudhyasva bh─Бrata рее (BG 2.18)
тАЬThese bodies you see are perishable; however the Principle that nourishes them is eternal; imperishable; and beyond all measure. Arjuna, your arrow and sword cannot harm It. Therefore, arise and fight!тАЭ

When the reality is thus, if anyone said that you were a killer and another is killed, that person would be ignorant of reality. There is none killed here and no one is the killer. The Self has no birth or death. It does not have any divisions of time such as the past, present or the future. That is forever immutable.

ajo nityaс╕е ┼Ы─Б┼ЫvatoтАЩyaс╣Г pur─Бс╣Зo
na hanyate hanyam─Бne ┼Ыar─лreрее (BG 2.20)
Birthless, Eternal, the Ancient One is not killed even if the body is killed.

nityaс╕е sarvagataс╕е sth─Бс╣Зur-acaloтАЩyaс╣Г san─Бtanaс╕ерее (BG 2.24)
(He is Eternal, Omnipresent, Immovable, Firm, Ancient)
