[[Ch. 3 Yoga of OneтАЩs Own Dharma (Part 4) Source: prekshaa]]

Thus, one who leads life in the form of tapas, yaj├▒a, and d─Бna, does not have to hanker after mokс╣гa. It is readily available. By leading a life that is dedicated to the divine, he climbs above the duality caused by lust and anger. Gradually he will realize that there is something beyond worldly enjoyment and becomes eligible to see the abode of param─Бtm─Б. Then is freedom from karmic shackles.

yastv─Бtmaratir─Уva sy─Бd─Бtmatс╣Ыpta┼Ыca m─Бnavaс╕е ред
─Бtmany─Уva ca santuс╣гс╣нastasya k─Бryaс╣Е na vidyat─У рее BG 3.17

Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa says, тАЬsahayaj├▒─Бh praj─Бh srс╣гс╣нv─БтАЭ (It appears that there is a p─Бс╣нh─Бntara, тАЬsahayaj├▒aihтАЭ). It is probably necessary to make sense of this verse by explaining and understanding the inner meanings of expositions of the earlier ─Бc─Бryas.

  1. It should be noted that there is no mention of division on the basis of region, caste, or clan. By the words тАЬpraj─Бh srс╣гс╣нv─БтАЭ, it is clear that it refers to all humankind. Therefore, this instruction applie to all humans, irrespective of caste or position in life. 2. The temperament of yaj├▒a is inherent in the makeup of human nature. It has not entered man from outside. It is not created by someone elseтАЩs influence. The inclination towards yaj├▒a is one of the innate qualities of humanity. 3. Yaj├▒a is worship. An important part of worship is naivedya or oblation. It is also called ─Бhuti or havirbh─Бga; that itself is up─Бyana or gift. The common English translation of the word yaj├▒a is sacrifice. In essence, тАЩsacrificeтАЩ also means proper conduct of oneself towards something sacred тАУ that is, start with worship and make an offering. Giving up something that belongs to us for an object worthy of worship тАУ giving up oneтАЩs ownership with a sense of reverence is yaj├▒a. 4. Is not the purport of the earlier verse that Yaj├▒a is inborn in man? What does it mean? Does it not imply that giving up ownership is inborn and natural in him? Is it real, though? Our experience tells us otherwise. Man is by nature selfish. Giving up something selflessly is usually unnatural to him. (See #7 below). 5. Let us explore the experience in greater depth and breadth. In every human, there is surely some generosity in something. Even the most parsimonious man will show some affection and concern towards his wife and children тАУ at least sometimes. He might loosen up, at least to reach his own selfish ends. He might draw someone close to him and help him. The seed of selflessness is thus sown. D─Бna and yaj├▒a are the workings of sattva-guс╣Зa. There is no human without at least some goodness in him. Just as there cannot be a person who is completely s─Бttvika, there is no one completely devoid of goodness. In some people, the quality of sattva-guс╣Зa and the tendency towards yaj├▒a are quite minimal and feeble. By associating with the world, these feelings gradually grow and become more intense. Lust becomes love. Love transforms into attachment. Attachment moulds into fellowship. Fellowship trains one to give up selfishness, at least a little. This is the instruction of n─лti acquired by acquaintance with the world. This teaching is possible because there is at least an iota of sattva in all humans. The germination of this tiny seed of sattva is the initial manifestation of yaj├▒a. Matthew ArnoldтАЩs opinion is nearly the same тАУ тАЬ… the enduring Power, not ourselves, which makes for righteousness.тАЭ (Literature and Dogma). 6. Initially, natural selfishness itself expects othersтАЩ help. No one can lead a life in this world without at least some help from other people. Thinking thus objectively, a solitary life is not a full life. No man is completely independent. Everyone is dependent on others. As humans are necessary for one anotherтАЩs survival, they have established families, societies, and states. Plato the philosopher affirms the same. Thus, interdependence among humans is a natural state. 7. Even though the seed of yaj├▒a is naturally present within us, our difficulty is that it is dormant (See 5. above). As we will later see in the sixteenth chapter, daiv─л and ─Бsur─л qualities are both mixed in our nature. Selfishness and friendship with others co-exist. A sense of ownership exists alongside indifference. The object of dh─Бrmika rituals is to sift through this mixture, separate out the virtuous qualities and reinforce them. Among all dharmas, the first one is the intention to help others, the will to think of othersтАЩ welfare. Even if it is born out of a desire for oneтАЩs own welfare, it is not a flaw. It is enough if from within arises the realisation that there is someone other than oneself and that their companionship is valuable. This wisdom paves the way for further lessons in moral instruction. When man progresses from egotism to affection тАУ when ego expands from self-centredness into a sense of тАШmineтАЩ and тАШmy peopleтАЩ тАУ it can be said that the progress of n─лti has begun. The second step is moving from the sense of тАЬonly these are mineтАЭ to the feeling that тАЬall are mineтАЭ. Due to the organisation and mechanics of creation, natural self-love and self-regard themselves desire the company of others and help practise giving up selfishness. 8. тАЬparasparaс╣Г bh─Бvayantaс╕етАЭ: is the golden maxim of life in the world taught by Bhagav─Бn. That indeed is friendship with the world. It is a yaj├▒a where oneтАЩs selfishness is offered as an ─Бhuti. Bonding with family is its preliminary form. The husband has to give up something for the happiness of his wife. She, in turn, has to do the same for him. This mutual giving up for the otherтАЩs sake itself is yaj├▒a which leads to a rise in matrimonial bliss. In fact, love itself is preparation for giving up oneself. Without the yaj├▒a of the offering of oneтАЩs ego, there cannot be family or friendship or society, or any human relationship at all. 9. As the fluid of тАШmeтАЩ and тАШmineтАЩ gradually spreads from oneтАЩs home to the extended family, to society and then to the country, it goes deeper and becomes thinned and diluted. As ego thins out, the practice of likening oneself with the whole world increases. As the practice of ─Бtmaupamya (the feeling that the whole world is like us) increases, the universe is seen and experienced as an extension of oneself. When the sense of belonging breaks out of the embankments of worldly attachment and rushes into the sea of param─Бtm─Б, mokс╣гa or salvation is gained.

[[Ch. 3 Yoga of OneтАЩs Own Dharma (Part 5) Source: prekshaa]]

тАЬWhen devas are worshipped and satisfied, they give rain and good crops.тАЭ

It is easy to misconstrue this statement. Will rains cease, or will crops die because worship is stopped? Are rains and crops dependent on human effort? Then, does it not mean that man is more powerful than nature? This is a frivolous argument. If a father says to his scallywag of a son, тАЬIf you study well, I will buy you a wristwatch. If you listen to your mother she will give you tasty snacks,тАЭ what does it mean? Does he imply that he will not feed his son or throw him out of the house if he does not pass his exams? We are familiar with such behaviour of fathers and sons. Even if the son is a rogue and fails all his exams, his parents tell him to try, try, and try again. Bhagav─БnтАЩs promises of rains and crops and fulfilment of other wishes are not injunctions, but incentives and means of encouragement. It is an instruction to an individual. Mother Nature does not stop rains and crops that are due to the whole world, just because an individual or a thousand people stop their worship and yaj├▒as.

At this point, the symbiosis that is alluded to in тАЬparasparaс╣Г bh─Бvayantaс╕етАЭ seems like it should be between humans and the divine. However, we should understand that a similar relationship with the motive of mutual benefit should be present between humans and lesser animals as well. It is also clear that humans should also have similar conduct with one another.

The statute of symbiosis is applicable to the whole world. What is its fundamental tenet?

sarva-bh┼лtastham-─Бtm─Бnaс╣Г sarva-bh┼лt─Бni c─Бtmani ред
─лkс╣гate yoga-yukt─Бtm─Б sarvatra sama-dar┼Ыanaс╕е рее BG 6.29

The inspiration for such conductтАФa feeling of brotherhoodтАФis natural in all beings. Goodness is present in everyone to at least a small extent, but it is hidden deep inside. It has to be brought out and made to express itself. That is the intention of ┼Ы─Бstras and traditions.

Yaj├▒a is performed for the benefit of the entire world. It is a form of worship performed for the abnegation of oneтАЩs selfishness and the welfare of the world.

The universe thrives on the symbiosis between the devas and humans. Yaj├▒a is a means to establish that relationship. Such activity that cements the bond between the devas and humans is dharma. That is what the ┼Ыruti says тАУ

yaj├▒ena yaj├▒am-ayajanta dev─Бh ред t─Бni dharm─Бс╣Зi pratham─Бny-─Бsan рее (Puruс╣гa-s┼лkta, с╣Ъgveda 10.90.16)

At the beginning of creation, various devas employed the five primordial elements (pa├▒ca-mah─Б-bh┼лtas) in appropriate activities, and thus worshipped ─к┼Ыvara. That was the first yaj├▒a and the beginning of dharma. Dharma is the subservience of the forces of nature to the rule of the divine without transgressing it in any way. Dharma is performing acts that are ordained. This is what our great poets have praised. V─Бlm─лki and Vy─Бsa are of the same opinion. They do not consider the devas to be completely separate from humans, or that there is no connection between their world and ours. Devas, humans and other animals belong to the same world.

yatra vi┼Ыvam bhavatyekan─лс╕Нamрее (Mah─Бn─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa-Upaniс╣гad 1.14)

The entire universe is embedded in the nest of the Supreme Brahma. In the ┼Ъ─Бkuntala, K─Бlid─Бsa says,

tava bhavatu biс╕Нauj─Бс╕е pr─Бjyavс╣Ыс╣гс╣нiс╕е praj─Бsuред
tvamapi vitatayaj├▒o vajriс╣Зaс╣Г pr─лс╣Зayasva рее (Abhij├▒─Бna-┼Ы─Бkuntalam 7.34)

тАЬMay Indra send abundant rain for the benefit of your subjects; may you please him with many yaj├▒as.тАЭ

We have to grasp the meaning of these lines of the G─лt─Б (6-29) carefully. The universe is created by ─к┼Ыvara. Many energies come together in this great and continuous endeavour. By the ordinance of ─к┼Ыvara, man has the unique opportunity to collaborate with them, by becoming one of them. That is dharma. Satkarma is that which makes use of this opportunity.

Karma is like water, without its own form, taste or colour. Water takes the colour, taste, and form of the ground on which it flows. Similarly, depending on the person performing it, karma can be puс╣Зya or p─Бpa. Karma that is beyond these may be a mere sport of ─Бtm─Б. The nobler the karmi (doer) becomes, the purer the karma gets. Karma is, anyway, an integral part of the universe. When that is so, when it satisfies the governing deities of the universe, they grant good rain and bountiful crops in return. Living beings thus enjoy bliss and bounty.

There is a question here. What is the relation between yaj├▒a performed by humans and rains and crops? If men stopped performing yaj├▒a, would natureтАЩs work cease? Does it not rain, donтАЩt crops grow in countries where people do not even know the concept of yaj├▒a? Here are five points to ponder upon:

  1. All religions espouse the belief that there is a relationship between human merit and divine grace. Similarly, there is a relationship between human p─Бpa and the wrath of the deities. When they are angry, natural calamities such as drought, flood, earthquakes, and pandemics plague the earth. This belief can be observed in the texts of Islam as well as in Christian religion. 2. Similarly, we cannot accept that in countries outside India - countries that do not know the Vedas and ┼Ы─Бstras- rain and crops are obtained without yaj├▒a. Yaj├▒a is essentially the worship of the divine. In this broad sense, there is no community that does not perform yaj├▒a. Even the most primitive African tribe firmly believes in a supernatural power, fears its wrath, and craves for its blessing. Probably such faith is more entrenched in them than in modern city dwellers. There is no human without religion; and no religion without yaj├▒a. Therefore we cannot use the example of religions outside the umbrella of the Vedas to prove that there is no relationship between rain, crops, and yaj├▒a. 3. Just as it is difficult to prove that human karma and nature are related, it is difficult to prove that they are unrelated. Similar are the claims about the afterlife and the otherworld. If rebirth is possible and the afterworld exists, puс╣Зya and p─Бpa as well as drought and plenty are inter-related. тАЬAs in the physical world, so in the world of spirit, nothing ever goes without producing results тАУ results of one kind or of another kindтАЭ [A line DVG probably made in English.] We believe in karma; we believe in rebirth; we believe that the future is influenced by the past. Therefore, we also believe that human karma is definitely related to divine intervention. 4. If natureтАЩs working is not a result of human actions, what can be the rationale for it? Does natureтАШs activity proceed without any rules? Is it random? Is it mad exuberance? When we observe natural phenomena like the movements of the sun, moon, and earth, it does not seem so. We see order there. We have already seen that the warps of the thread of time find a place in the working of nature. Then, how do natural events sometimes occur without any apparent reason? Effect always has a cause. We reason that a part of those causes is human karma тАУ good or bad. Nature follows the dicta of ─к┼Ыvara. That karma should have appropriate consequences is *─к┼ЫvaraтАЩ*s law. 5. The universe is a glorious mega machine. Divine beings, humans, lesser animals, and inanimate objects are its gears, wheels, handles, ramrods, and ribbons. The machine works only if all these components are doing their allocated jobs. Suppose the screw on the mudguard of a car is loosened by coming into contact with a shaft, it should be repaired immediately. If it remains loose, it starts making a sound, the vibrations of which loosen other parts of the car. Gradually, the entire machinery of the car might fail. It is the same with the machinery of the universe. Transgression committed by a human today will touch the deities, the powers of nature and will anger them. Man is not isolated from the universal machine. Whatever happens to it, happens to him also. Whatever he does affects it as well. Thus, celestial beings and humans are parts of the same machine.

This has been explained in other places.

[[Ch. 3 Yoga of OneтАЩs Own Dharma (Part 6) Source: prekshaa]]

Who are devas? Various pictures of divine beings holding a trident, staff, rope, or discus might arise in our minds. These pictures are useful elsewhere; they can assist in meditation. When we are studying philosophy, devas are the powers of creation and nature тАУ great powers of various kinds. The relationship between humans and these superhuman deities may not be directly observable to us. But it cannot be said that they do not exist just because they are not seen. For most of us living in Bangalore, China is unseen. But does China not exist? We do not doubt its existence at all!

Bhagav─Бn has explained the symbiosis between the world of devas and the world of humans тАФ that one influences the other, and has presented a philosophy that is more expansive and munificent than todayтАЩs socialism and communism тАУ

tair-datt─Бn-aprad─Бyaibhyo yo bhuс╣Еkte stena eva saс╕ерее BG 3.12
тАЬOne who consumes alone, the bounty bestowed upon him by the divine overseers, is verily a thief.тАЭ

yajna-┼Ыiс╣гс╣н─Б┼Ыinaс╕е santo mucyante sarva-kilbiс╣гaiс╕еред
bhu├▒jate te tv-aghaс╣Г p─Бp─Б ye pacanty-─Бtma-k─Бraс╣З─Бtрее BG 3.13
тАЬYaj├▒a is giving a part of oneтАЩs earnings to others to please the divine. One who consumes the leftovers of this yaj├▒a considering it as pras─Бda from them is virtuous. Cooking only for oneself and partaking of it is a p─Бpa.тАЭ

Therefore, we have rituals like vai┼Ыvadeva, bali-haraс╣Зa, and bh┼лta-bali, where food is offered to the powers of the universe, performed since ancient times. Behind the rule that one should not partake of meals without guests is the same intent. That is why the Veda declares

тАЬkeval─Бgho bhavati keval─Бd─л.тАЭ (с╣Ъgveda-saс╣Гhit─Б 10.117.6)
тАЬOne who eats alone eats only p─Бpa.тАЭ

Naivedya offered to the divine and hospitality towards guests are also yaj├▒as. This is the principle of communal living. This is the path to the elevation of the j─лva.

saс╣Гsс╣Ыс╣гс╣нaс╣Г dhanamubhayam sam─Бkс╣Ыtamasmabhyamред (с╣Ъgveda-saс╣Гhit─Б 10.84.7)
“May Manyu and Varuс╣Зa provide us both kinds of wealth that is undivided.”

┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa merely taught Arjuna the technique to expand the nature of his ─Бtm─Б, something that has been expounded by с╣Ыс╣гis since the times of the с╣Ъgveda. The ─к┼Ыopani┼Ыat says тАУ

tena tyaktena bhu├▒j─лth─Бh (─к┼Ы─Бv─Бsya-upaniс╣гad 1)
All wealth belongs to ─к┼Ыvara. You enjoy the world thinking of it as his pras─Бda.

I would like to relate something heartwarming about a family I know well. The head of the family was quite well-to-do; he was a government servant, drawing a salary of about four hundred or five hundred rupees. His wife was the overseer of the house. She would sit for her meals after the whole family and the servants were also fed. When she sat down thus for her meals, she would serve herself whatever she wanted and keep back the remaining food. Then she would gather some food from her plate into her palms тАУ rice, curry, ghee, fried food, etc., and stand at the door of her house. Some beggars who knew the hour would come there and accept food from her hands. This was her daily practice. One day, her son asked her the meaning of this. She replied that this was her d─Бna. The boy asked, тАЬWhy is this d─Бna required? HasnтАЩt Father given you enough money? He performs d─Бna, doesnтАЩt he?тАЭ

She replied, тАЬYour father gives me money to run the entire family. D─Бna that he does is from his own earnings. My earning is only through my cooking. Earning my food through my own hard work, and giving away a part of that as charity is puс╣Зya for me. What is the use if I give d─Бna from your fatherтАЩs money and your money? That doesnтАЩt have my ty─Бga. D─Бna without ty─Бga is only in name.

Karma is necessary for everyone because of their relationship with the whole universe.

When we say тАШeveryoneтАЩ, is it implied that those who are already self-realised are included? Yes. Those who read тАЬtasya k─Бryam na vidyateтАЭ from the seventeenth verse and close the book might think that the self-realised do not have to perform karma. That is a delusion because the sentence that starts in that verse ends in the nineteenth verse тАУ

tasm─Бdasaktaс╕е satataс╣Г k─Бryaс╣Г karma sam─Бcara (BG 3.19)
тАЬTherefore without attachment, you should always perform action which should be doneтАЭ.

An ─Аtma-j├▒─Бni just does not have the desire to gain anything for himself. He willingly performs his duties for the benefit of the world without desiring any fruits of labour, not because of other stipulations. Everywhere, Bhagav─Бn says тАЬk─Бryaс╣Г karma,тАЭ тАЬniyataс╣Г karma.тАЭ тАЬDo your duty.тАЭ It is indeed said that one should perform d─Бna but it does not mean that one should take a loan for it. One should not steal in order to do charity. Duties such as taking care of oneтАЩs own family are to be performed by the returns earned by oneтАЩs own karma.

One who experiences the ─Бtm─Б will not have selfish desires or indigence. Karma performed by such a person is bereft of p─Бpa and is beneficial to the whole world as well. Such a man has the complete authority to perform karma for the sake of the universe. The one about whom it is said тАЬtasya k─Бryam na vidyateтАЭ, one who performs his duties without anyoneтАЩs obligation, without greed, with a feeling of being one with the universal soul тАУ his karma alone is beneficial to the world.

Purification of the soul and obtaining an object of desire are the two natural uses of karma. An ─Бtma-j├▒─Бni does not need either of these. He is already pure; he doesnтАЩt desire anything either. Then why does he still work? For the benefit of the worldтАФfor *loka-saс╣ЕgrahaтАФ*is Bhagav─БnтАЩs reply. The establishment and maintenance of the order of the universe is his responsibility. ┼Ъr─л Vidy─Бraс╣Зya says the same thing тАУ

j├▒─Бnin─Б carituс╣Г ┼Ыakyaс╣Г samyag-r─Бjy─Бdi-laukikam (Pa├▒cada┼Ы─л 9.114)
“It is possible for a j├▒─Бni to engage in polity and other worldly matters.”

PlatoтАЩs opinion is the same. Affairs of the state impact many; therefore one who wants to practise statecraft should not be selfish. Bh─лс╣гma too says the same thing in the Mah─Бbh─Бrata. тАЬYou are possibly not interested in the pleasures of svarga or kingship. Should you not, however, take the circumstances of the world into account? Perform your duty diligently to please the owner of the house in which you live.тАЭ

[[Ch. 3 Yoga of OneтАЩs Own Dharma (Part 7) Source: prekshaa]]

There is another thing to consider. Illustrious people such as Janaka, who are greater than you have all performed karma much before you.

karmaс╣Зaiva hi saс╣Гsiddhim ─Бsthit─Б janak─Бdayaс╕еред
loka-saс╣Еgraham-ev─Бpi saс╣Гpa┼Ыyan kartum-arhasi рее BG 3.20
тАЬJanaka and others attained fulfilment by karma only; You should also perform your duty keeping the welfare of the world in mindтАЭ.

Janaka was a great and elevated soul. Many с╣Ыс╣гis would send seekers desirous of initiation into brahma-vidy─Б to him. His story appears in many places тАУ in the Mah─Бbh─Бrata, Bh─Бgavata, Yoga-v─Бsiс╣гс╣нha, and above all in the Bс╣Ыhad─Бraс╣Зyakopaniс╣гad where it appears as a conversation between him and Y─Бj├▒avalkya. Janaka did not give up his kingship. The royal sage that he was, he ruled the kingdom constantly observing how people lived. O Arjuna, when such an exceptional man performed karma, why do you refuse? Just as Janaka was distinguished in his lifetime, so are you now. The ordinary imitate the eminent.

yadyad─Бcarati ┼Ыreс╣гс╣нhaс╕е tattadevetaro janaс╕е ред

тАЬLet us say that Janaka is not in front of us now. Am I not there? You have seen me since childhood. You know my basic nature. On many occasions such as the burning of Kh─Бс╣Зс╕Нava forest, you have seen my prowess. Why am I performing karma in this world? All that anyone might desire, is under my power; what else do I want? However, I still perform karma, for the welfare of the world. If I do not perform karma, anarchy will spread in the world and the society will degenerate. It is not just now, it has been so forever.тАЭ

yad─Б yad─Б hi dharmasya gl─Бnirbhavati bh─Бrata ред

“Whenever there is decline of dharma and rise of adharma, I manifest myself. For the protection of the virtuous, for the destruction of the wicked, and for the establishment of dharma, I am born in every yuga.”

paritr─Бс╣З─Бya s─Бdh┼лn─Бс╣Г vin─Б┼Ы─Бya ca duс╣гkс╣Ыt─Бс╣Г ред

How affectionate Bhagav─Бn is towards the universe! We should never forget this. We should diligently and devoutly discharge the duties that have been allotted to us by his divine arrangement. This is the advice most pertinent to us in this age and time. However, the thinkers among us give first preference to the subject of mokс╣гa (liberation) and second place to our duties in this world.

In the story of Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa in the Bh─Бgavata, the gopik─Бs ask him: тАЬIn this world, we see that some people love only those who love them. Some others love those who do not love them in return. Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa said, тАЬGiving love to someone who loves us is a commercial transaction. It is a great thing only when we show kindness towards those who do not like us.тАЭ

Bhagav─Бn praises selfless yaj├▒a performed just for the benefit of others. Even a j├▒─Бn─л cannot neglect worldly duties.

sakt─Бс╕е karmaс╣Зyavidv─Бс╣Гso yath─Б kurvanti bh─Бrata ред

This is the essence of karma yoga. It has to be always remembered by those who share their ideals with the Gokhale Institute.

Even though Karma is directly perceived, its root is hidden. When a manтАЩs inner tendencies flow out through his actions, it becomes karma.

yatpuruс╣гo manas─Бbhigacchatiред tadv─Бc─Б vadatiред tatkarmaс╣З─Б karotiред (Taittir─лya-─Бraс╣Зyaka Prap─Бс╣нhaka 1, Anuv─Бka 23, Mantra 1
тАЬWhat a man thinks, he speaks and performs as actionтАЭ.

Therefore, the place of origin of good and bad results of karma is the manas (mind). The mind is the kart─Б or doer. Karma follows the doer. If he is good, it is good. If he is bad, it is bad. If his intention is improper, it is not virtuous, even if the endeavour is worthy. If the intention is upright, he is worthy; regardless of the nature of his work, it is virtuous.

How does a j├▒─Бn─л differ from an aj├▒─Бn─л? Do not both of them work for the sake of the world? Having said that, there is a characteristic difference. The realised individual selflessly works for the order of the universe. The result of the work of the unrealised man could be either order or disorder. Disorder because ego reigns in him; he is desirous of the rewards of his labour. The worldly man measures everything with a view of what is in it for him. What the aj├▒─Бn─л performs with an eye for profit, the j├▒─Бn─л performs without any expectation. The function is the same. One establishes a satra to provide free food for the needy; the other starts a fancy restaurant. They perform the same karma. The wise man does it without anyone forcing him, with a view that he is one with all beings of the universe; the ignorant does it out of self-interest.

Even the j├▒─Бn─л might think that he is working for the betterment of the world. Is it not selfishness? Does not the seed of selfishness thrive in him to that extent? Bhagav─БnтАЩs response is thus: тАЬEven if a tiny bit of egotism is present in oneтАЩs mind, he cannot be called a j├▒─Бn─л. In a worldly sense he may be called a j├▒─Бn─л; he just does not have any realisation of the ─Бtm─Б. However, there is an interesting aspect to consider. Outwardly, one may seem to be egoistic in the matter of karma. Internally he may perform karma not out of his own volition but because his nature compels him. Genuine love for Bhagav─Бn could be the reason for his joy.

prakс╣Ыteс╕е kriyam─Бс╣З─Бni guс╣Зaiс╕е karm─Бс╣Зi sarva┼Ыaс╕е ред
ahaс╣Еk─Бravim┼лс╕Нh─Бtm─Б kart─Бhamiti manyate рее BG 3.27
тАЬActions are being done in every way by the guс╣Зas of prakс╣Ыti (nature). However, a man deluded by ego thinks that he is the doerтАЭ.

[[Ch. 3 Yoga of OneтАЩs Own Dharma (Part 8) Source: prekshaa]]

Human nature is composed of the triad of guс╣Зas тАУ sattva, rajas, and tamas. It is true of the universe also. A manтАЩs inner nature influences his outward behaviour and vice-versa. The essence of graha-atigraha mentioned in the Bс╣Ыhad─Бraс╣Зyaka-upaniс╣гad is this mutual impulse.

tattvavit-tu mah─Бb─Бho guс╣Зa-karma-vibh─Бgayoс╕е ред
guс╣З─Б guс╣Зeс╣гu vartanta iti mattv─Б na sajjate рее (BG 3.28)

One who knows the principle of distribution of natural temperaments (guс╣Зa) and actions (karma) understands that all the workings in the world are a dialogue between the guс╣Зa-triad internal to the j─лva and the guс╣Зa-triad of the universe. Also he understands that the ─Бtm─Б is unaffected by these transactions and remains an uninvolved outsider.

The j├▒─Бn─л knows that life in this world is a working of prakс╣Ыti and is not related to the j─лva тАУ like the sahс╣Ыdayas (connoisseurs) watching a play. Life in this world needs to be only seen from afar and enjoyed. Actors who come on stage perform different actions тАУ they laugh, cry out, and scream. The audience, without really being a part of the happenings, remain separate but see, experience, and enjoy the play.

The mental condition of the j├▒─Бn─л is thus тАУ

s─Бkс╣г─л cet─Б kevalo nirguс╣Зa┼Ы-ca (┼Ъvet─Б┼Ыvatara-upaniс╣гad 11)
тАЬWitnessing everything, isolated, devoid of all guс╣Зas.тАЭ

Prakс╣Ыti seems amuse herself through her manifold activities. That is the l─лl─Б of Bhagav─Бn and is beyond our control. A j├▒─Бn─л constantly keeps this in mind. Ordinary people do not differentiate ─Бtm─Б from the body and other up─Бdhis (attributes). They are of the illusion that the body is the j─лva and the ─Бtm─Б. Indeed, the body consists of three aspects тАУ 1. Sth┼лla {Gross, tangible form}, 2. S┼лkс╣гma {subtle form}, 3. Liс╣Еga or K─Бraс╣Зa {The subtle form that is unaffected by transmigration between bodies.} Until body, mind, and notions arising from memories of previous births captivate the j─лva, it remains just that тАУ a mere j─лva. Our mind mistakes j─лva to be the supreme ─Бtm─Б and vice versa because that is how it understands the nature of the body. But a j├▒─Бn─л is тАШkс╣ЫtsnavitтАЩ тАУ тАШone who knows everything.тАЩ He sees that ordinary people are deluded. But he does not thoughtlessly seek to liberate them from their path. Spiritual attainment is proportional to oneтАЩs intellectual capacity, skill and virtue. People should not be prevented from pursuing the s─Бdhan─Б that they deem fit. If we stop them from doing what is suitable for them, they will lose their s─Бdhan─Б; our instruction will be unsuitable for them and they will not be able to follow it and thus they will deteriorate. When learning to walk, it is not good if one forgets the gait of a crow but cannot learn the gait of a swan. The g─лt─Б therefore says,

na buddhibhedaс╣Г janayet aj├▒─Бn─Бс╣Г karmasaс╣Еgin─Бm (BG 3.26)

If people follow what is right for their stage, they will earn the ability to enter higher stages.

This is what our enthusiastic ved─Бntins should realise. Proclaiming the ultimate truth to lay people might be detrimental to them, rather than being helpful. If a father teaching his young child to walk well pulls him at his speed, the child might lose its motivation, energy or even his life. It is the same in spiritual pursuit. There must not be an undue hurry to make progress in the path of self-realisation.

The initial requirement for the study of Ved─Бnta is to keep the mind under control and to be honest in the work one is doing. We must pay more attention in nurturing this common worldly moral conduct. People are more engaged in disputesтАФof тАЬDvaitamu sukham─Б advaitamu sukham─БтАЭ [A famous kriti by Sri Ty─Бgar─Бja]тАФwhether dvaita is better or advaita is better. It is useless. All interpretations of Ved─Бnta expect purity of the j─лva and the six-fold qualities of ┼Ыama, dama, etc. [┼Ъam─Бdi-с╣гaс╣нka-saс╣Гpatti refers to ┼Ыama, dama, titikс╣г─Б, ┼Ыraddh─Б, uparati, and sam─Бdh─Бna.] We have to give more importance to that.

~

Bhagav─Бn has summarised the relationship between j├▒─Бna and karma. An ordinary man thinks that he is the one performing karma, from the point of view of the j─лva. The j├▒─Бn─л knows that he is not the doer but prakс╣Ыti is the doer. The distinction between the two of them is not in performing karma; it is common to both. For ordinary people, karma is preparation for j├▒─Бna. For realised j─лvas, karma is the result of j├▒─Бna. Bhagav─Бn thus set the boundaries of the pervasiveness of karma and said, тАЬArjuna, the result of your karma does not belong to you. Whatever be the result, understand that it belongs to me (that is, to the Param─Бtm─Б) and fight without desire or egotism.

mayi sarv─Бс╣Зi karm─Бс╣Зi saс╣Гnyasy─Бdhy─Бtmacetas─Б ред
nir─Б┼Ы─лrnirmamo bh┼лtv─Б yudhyasva vigatajvaraс╕ерее (BG 3:30)
тАЬDedicate all your actions to me with your mind intent on the supreme ─Бtm─Б. Break off from your affliction. Do not fear. Fight without anguish!тАЭ

Even a great j├▒─Бn─л follows the path paved by his own prakс╣Ыti. Then how is j├▒─Бna useful for him? What is the use of self-realisation when Prakс╣Ыti dictates everything? It is this: when a j├▒─Бn─л performs karma, his negative mental qualities like desire and hatred are kept in check. Of course, he does perform karma; but it is untainted by love or hate. An ordinary man, on the contrary, is afflicted by desire and hatred. He also works according to the dictum of his nature, but the difference is in the condition of their minds.

prakс╣Ыtiс╣Г y─Бnti bh┼лt─Бni nigrahaс╕е kiс╣Г kariс╣гyati (BG 3.33)

Nature is all-powerful in everything. Is it possible for someone born with a voice like that of a beast of burden to sing like the Gandharvas? Natural qualities are always present in their places, without fail. In any situation, nature rushes forth to show herself. This nature is different for different people. In the context of a j─лva, it is of the form of unconscious tendencies inherited from previous births. It is the result of past actions and conditioning. Therefore, nature works differently for different people. It then follows that dharma is also different for different people. Dharma follows Nature. The dharma of a being is based on the nature that it houses. That is svadharma. Karma has to be performed, it cannot be avoided. But what kind of karma should it be? The karma is in the form of oneтАЩs svadharma. While performing karma is inevitable, performing it as oneтАЩs svadharma is most excellent.

┼Ыrey─Бn-sva-dharmo viguс╣Зaс╕е para-dharm─Бt-sv-anuс╣гс╣нhit─Бt ред
sva-dharme nidhanaс╣Г ┼Ыreyaс╕е para-dharmo bhay─Бvahaс╕ерее (BG 3:35)

“Arjuna, you are a kс╣гatriya. Your dharma is to fight. Saс╣Гny─Бsa is dharma for br─Бhmaс╣Зas; indeed only for a few of them, for those in whose minds dispassion has arisen by itself. Indeed, ┼Ы─Бstras say that saс╣Гny─Бsa is to be avoided in the Kali-yuga. Only those who have been dispassionate and weary for a long time are eligible for saс╣Гny─Бsa. It is prescribed only for those who are genuinely disinterested in the pleasures of the world. Renouncing the world is to be done when one is truly disinterested in it. You, however, are a kс╣гatriya. Why are you trying to follow a specific dharma prescribed only for a few br─Бhmaс╣Зas? It is better to perform oneтАЩs own karma even if all its attributes are not palatable. Do not consider Vi┼Ыv─Бmitra as your role model. He obstinately persevered and won, and is worthy of our praises and prostrations. However, your nature is different. You have to fight. Fight!”

[[Ch. 3 Yoga of OneтАЩs Own Dharma (Part 9) Source: prekshaa]]

Why only Svadharma?

“OneтАЩs own karma performed diligently, even though it may not be the best thing, is better than othersтАЩ karma performed in a most satisfying manner”. What then is svadharma?

Certain qualities, powers, propensities, and enthusiasm come to some people naturally. Using such qualities, that mindset and those internal faculties for the benefit of the world is dharma.

Then, should he be tied to his natural talents? Why should he not adopt something that is superior? How is a seemingly deficient svadharma nobler than a тАШbetterтАЩ dharma that is, albeit, not oneтАЩs own? There are four reasons for this :

  1. Nature helps the doer in svadharma. Whatever she aids him in, is svadharma. Since she is supporting him, his work becomes easy. This ease is the first advantage of following svadharma. 2. When the duty becomes easy, it gets done faster too. The yield is greater too. Thus, the second reason is the plentitude of results. 3. The world will benefit greatly from this work тАФ as much as the doer can give, it can take and profit from it. Increased benefit to the world is the third reason. 4. When performing svadharma, at least some known qualities and abilities are solidly established and flourish in the character. If this dharma is given up and another chosen in its place, the existing abilities are weakened; there is no guarantee that new ones are gained. Therefore, the fourth reason is that there is an absolutely undiluted improvement of oneтАЩs skills.

The washerman in our town, Machayya, works till his bones break when there is a wedding in the local wealthy manтАЩs house. What is the use? The man who is seated on the velvet carpet and garlanded on the wedding day is the musician Rangappa. Machayya became sick and tired of this and made his son Marayya learn music. After learning music for ten years, the boy could sing bhajans on the roadside, but no more. The donkeys commented that the town lost a washerman, but did not gain a musician either.

The Practice of Sattva

Arjuna raised another question. Even if we try to perform an action with the best of intentions, we may accrue p─Бpa because of it. What should be done about that? Bhagav─Бn answered thus:

k─Бma eс╣гa krodha eс╣гa rajo-guс╣Зa-samudbhavaс╕е ред
mah─Б┼Ыano mah─Бp─Бpm─Б viddhyenamiha vairiс╣Зam рее (BG 3.37)

Bhagav─Бn has answered this vividly and clearly. K─Бma has to be subdued. Senses excite the mind. The manas agitates the buddhi. The agitated intellect loses its vision. Therefore, you have to carefully protect that which is above the intellect тАФ the true essence of the ─Бtm─Б. This will preserve the buddhi from being spoiled by external influences. The intellect works well when the senses are under control. Therefore, rouse the quality of sattva within you, hidden behind the veil of the intellect, and let that be your safeguard.

Attributes like k─Бma and krodha are hereditary. Family, in turn, is chosen based on previous karma and tendencies from past lives. Relatives and friends, society, and surroundings are also based on v─Бsanas - impressions from past lives. If thus, the qualities of a man depend upon countless lives, how can we hope to change them? The answer is that every j─лva has enough internal sattva that can be much stronger than the negative v─Бsanas accumulated from many births. But it is dormant, or it is shrunk within itself because of external r─Бjasic and t─Бmasic influences. We have to remember one characteristic of the j─лva here. The sattva of the j─лva is unlimited in its source. The Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зar─Бja-s─Бgar dam is a huge reservoir of water. The water that we get from there into our house in a tap is just a droplet from there. The pipes that carry water from the KRS to our house might be blocked by dirt and block the flow of water. However, we should remember that behind the dripping tap in our house, there is a vast reservoir. This reminiscence gives us courage. This reminiscence is the contemplation of Bhagav─Бn. He is backing us. If we remember that omniscient, omnipotent Bhagav─Бn is behind the strength that is exuded by our bodily organs – that there is an ocean of energy behind us – it becomes possible to subdue k─Бma and krodha, which are but forms of rajas and tamas. One should constantly practise meditating on the nature of the ─Бtm─Б and Brahma. We shall study this later.

The capability of the ─Бtm─Б appears dormant. An awakened man sharpens and hones the strength of the ─Бtm─Б. The intellect then remains conscious and corrects the mind when it errs. The awakened mind quells sensory excitement. When heat from the senses subsides, the viveka to discriminate between right and wrong becomes possible. This viveka decreases the tendency to err. Thus, the first step towards conquering sin is to defeat the foe that is desire.

This chapter is generally called the Karmayoga. In a copy of the ┼Ъ─Бnkarabh─Бс╣гya, it is called karma-pra┼Ыaс╣Гs─Б-yoga тАФ or the yoga (path) of praise for karma. Karma can be of many kinds. This chapter deals with karma that is of the form of day-to-day work, specifically karma in the form of oneтАЩs own dharma тАФ svadharma. Therefore, it has been called sva-dharma-yoga, so that the meaning is easily grasped.

The next chapter deals with the same topic. What was called karma in the form of yaj├▒a in this chapter, is said to be karma that will be an offering to the Supreme Brahma, or karma that is performed without getting attached.

[[Ch. 4 Yoga of Unattached Karma (Part 1) Source: prekshaa]]

Note

Summary

Similar to a peepal tree that has an old trunk and root along with young and tender shoots, there are stages in the history of man. The old should form the basis for the new; only then does the new acquire credibility and authority. Continuity of the new from the old is proof of a healthy society. In his instruction to Arjuna, ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa demonstrated this same continuity to him.

That which internally spurs one to search for goodness in whatever way possible is the door to dharma for that person. Dharma follows the condition of a j─лva - its fitness and eligibility. The svadharma of every j─лva is in turn determined by its unique characteristics. This means that the contemplation and practice of dharma is possible by viveka and not by blind faith.

Even though we work to fulfill our desires, if we work to serve Bhagav─Бn as a devotional yaj├▒a, our ego is subdued and our j─лva is purified. As it becomes purer, the j─лva becomes capable of grasping the true essence of the ─Бtm─Б. A man who does not perform karma as a yaj├▒a will not even obtain its fruits in this world. He alone is worthy whose life-river flows between two banks of ─к┼Ыvar─Бnugraha (whatever is obtained is ─к┼ЫvaraтАЩs blessing) and ─к┼Ыvar─Бrpaс╣Зa (whatever is given to others is an offering to ─к┼Ыvara).

Chapter 4 / Section 5

The Yoga (Path) of Unattached Karma (Nirlepa-karma-yoga) or J├▒─Бna-yoga

This chapter deals with the following seven main topics.

  1. The antiquity of the instruction about karma 2. The divine greatness of dharma 3. Distinction of guс╣Зa and karma for dharma 4. Akarma in Karma 5. Different karma-yaj├▒as 6. The relationship between karma and j├▒─Бna 7. The necessity to completely eliminate doubt

Let us recall what Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa said in the previous chapter. He said, “Arjuna, you say that you will not perform your duty. You say that you will not fight тАУ fighting that is karma enjoined upon you by virtue of your family and your basic nature. Is karma subordinate to you? No. Nature makes you perform karma. Your innate disposition exhorts you to engage in activities. If you try to repress your intrinsic activities, such repression is also karma. Karma is inescapable in any which way.

na hi ka┼Ыcit kс╣гaс╣Зam-api j─Бtu tiс╣гс╣нhaty-akarmakс╣Ыt ред
k─Бryate hy-ava┼Ыaс╕е karma sarvaс╕е prakс╣Ыtijair-guс╣Зaiс╕е рее (BG 3.5)

“No one in this world can remain aloof without performing any activity. Owing to the inevitability of karma, whatever freedom you enjoy is not to abandon karma; it is to deliberateтАФin a given circumstanceтАФwhether a task is good or bad, and to choose that which is aligned to dharma. Even this freedom to critically examine a task is also limited because the mind that is engaged in deliberation is itself largely influenced by past impressions (pr─Бc─лna-v─Бsan─Бs). The saс╣Гsk─Бras from past lives bind and cloud the mind and intellect. Even so, at an auspicious moment, because of some unseen force, the spark of sattva rises up from within. Real deliberation is then possible. Dharma has to be thought about then, especially svadharma:

┼Ыrey─Бn svadharmo viguс╣Зaс╕е paradharm─Бt svanuс╣гс╣нhit─Бtред (BG 3.35)

тАЬYou say you want to give up your svadharma; you say that you wish to become a saс╣Гny─Бsi; you want to follow para-dharma [the dharma of others]; you say that you do not want the kingdom. This is not appropriate. There is great merit in adhering to svadharma.

svadharme nidhanaс╣Г ┼Ыreyaс╕еред (BG 3.35)

тАЬEven if your sva-dharma causes your death, it is more desirable, because nature helps you in your endeavour. It has three advantages тАФ

  1. Your actions will become easier and faster 2. By actions aligned to svadharma, the world will benefit more than it will if you performed para-dharma. 3. Your innate qualities will grow and expand. As they grow and flourish, knowledge of the ─Бtm─Б will spring forth sooner and more easily. Your life will attain fulfilment sooner.

“Right now, your svadharma is to fight the war. Would you say that it involves cruel deeds like killing, and that it is p─Бpa? If you carry out your actions selflessly it does not become p─Бpa. When does p─Бpa happen then? When you are driven by self-benefit тАФ even if there is a little bit of selfishness in you тАФ it becomes p─Бpa. When you execute your tasks selflessly, then there is no p─Бpa. The situation of the world requires war right now. War is needed for the sake of justice. War is needed to sustain dharma in the universe. It is not for your sake. Carry it out as an offering to Bhagav─Бn. Perform that which secures the well-being of the world without any selfish desire for profit. Then the p─Бpa that is attached to the fight will not affect you. There is an inherent element of impurity attached in every worldly duty,. This is true of all the duties of all people, to at least a little extent. One cannot say no to life because of this. It is necessary to examine how to cleanse this impurity off. Karma is the process of life itself and therefore, it is impossible for it to be devoid of all dirt. How then can it be purified? By removing all traces of selfishness. If karma is performed without any desire for selfish benefit and as an offering to ─к┼Ыvara, it becomes a means for elevation rather than a degrading p─Бpa. Anything other than satkarma is duс╣гkarma. Whatever is not your dharma is adharma for you. All karma other than your sva-dharma is adharma for you!” Thus, in the fourth chapter, Bhagav─Бn develops what he had elucidated previously.

[[Ch. 4 Yoga of Unattached Karma (Part 2) Source: prekshaa]]

The Antiquity of Karma-vidy─Б

тАЬArjuna, what I am explaining to you now is not something new and contemporary. It is something that I had explained to the sun named Vivasv─Бn at the beginning of creation. He, in turn, taught this to Manu, the progenitor of the human race. Manu then gave the same upade┼Ыa to Ikс╣гv─Бku, the foremost among kings. Thus, this knowledge of karma has been passed on through many generations. Earlier, many king-sages like Janaka and others followed the tenets of this knowledge and became accomplished.”

Why did Bhagav─Бn thus speak of an unbroken guru-┼Ыiс╣гya tradition? Did he intend that since it was ancient, it had to be accepted? K─Бlid─Бsa says,

pur─Бс╣Зam-ity-eva na s─Бdhu sarvaс╣Г
na c─Бpi k─Бvyaс╣Г navam-ity-avadyamрее
santaс╕е par─лkс╣гy─Бnyatarad-bhajanteтАж (M─Бlavik─Бgnimitram Act 1)

All that is ancient is not great because of its antiquity; all that is new is not bad because of its newness. The guс╣Зa or doс╣гa of something can be determined only after careful reasoning. Nothing should be accepted with blind faith. Still, the fact that many people over hundreds of generations accepted it is proof enough of the probity of the knowledge of karma. We find similar testimony of widespread acceptance by people spanning aeons even with regard to the Vedas. Therefore, the fact that a great many people have accepted the principle of karma is evidence of its efficacy.

This is why Bhagav─Бn praised antiquity and tradition. The people of our times should study this principle carefully. Human history should, like the flow of a mighty river, be unbroken. Only then does it acquire prominence. Otherwise, if it is broken here and there, torn asunder by flaws, inconsistent and incoherent, and absurd, it becomes a meaningless travail. It becomes like the lok─Бyata refrain “aparaspara-saс╣Гbh┼лtam” (BG 16.8) (born and existing independent of one another). This is why all our social reformers have always averred that they are the followers of their elders. This is the tradition in all countries. If a reformer wants his work to be sustained in future, he always says that he is only reiterating and demonstrating what is already expressed in previous works. Jesus Christ also did the same. He did not claim that he founded a new religion, but that his was an ancient creed that disappeared over time and he was only resurrecting it. Scholars of commerce, law, and other subjects also say that they are only taking naturally established philosophies forward and not creating them anew. The seers of the Vedas said,

“iti ┼Ыu┼Ыruma dh─лr─Бс╣З─Бс╣Г ye nas-tad-vicacakс╣гire” тАФ “This we heard from the wise, who explained it to us.” (─к┼Ы─Бv─Бsya Upaniс╣гad 10)
“idam-─Бhur-an┼лc─Бn─Бс╕е” тАФ “thus said the ancients…” (Kum─Бrasambhava 6.15)
“tadeс╣г─Бbhyukt─Б” тАФ “this was declared…” (Taittir─лya-upaniс╣гad 2.1)
“atraite ┼Ыlok─Б bhavanti” тАФ “these are the verses here…” (Maitr─Бyaс╣Зy-upaniс╣гad)

etc., and remembered their ancient masters.

This is not just an act of courtesy. Those who strive for the progress of humankind follow the method of home builders. The very first layer is the foundation, then comes a line of bricks, and then a line above that and so on. A storey is built using the lower storey as support. Thus, it is important that all the levels from the foundation to the topmost floor are connected. A building that has stood strong for a long time itself is proof that it can withstand the impact of rain and sun and wind, and also the thumps and thwacks of people living in it. A religion or custom is venerated because it is time-tested. This is tradition. The plight of a civilisation without tradition is similar to that of a cotton strand that is flitting aimlessly as the wind takes it.

Tradition is not mindless parroting of customs and rules. тАШTraditionalтАЩ does not amount to mere repetition. Saying and doing the same thing over and over again is not progress. True progress blends older aspects of societal life with the new тАФ just as old trunk and roots of a peepal tree coexist with and nurture new branches and leaves. The same pattern of progress holds true for human history also. The old should form the basis for the new. Only then does newness gain acceptability and strength. Such continuity from old to new is the sign of a healthy society. ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa demonstrated that such continuity existed in his instruction and therefore it was worthy of following. It was accepted by many people across many generations, and therefore it was authoritative. He said, “My good man, this instruction is suited for all times. DonтАЩt think that you, Arjuna, are the first among the worldтАЩs intelligent people! There were many wise people before you who followed this path. I am only telling you what has been established firmly, by virtue of being accepted across generations by many people. Therefore it is fit to be accepted.”

Why did something that was well-established even in ancient times go missing?

evaс╣Г parampar─Б-pr─Бptam-imaс╣Г r─Бjarс╣гayo viduс╕еред
sa k─Бleneha mahat─Б yogo naс╣гс╣нaс╕е parantapaрее (BG 4.2)
(This science that was passed on in an uninterrupted manner, studied by sages among kings, was lost).
“As aeons passed, the conditions of the world changed and this knowledge was lost.тАЩтАЩ

Coming to think of it, it is not surprising at all. We see many streams of knowledge dying out in front of our eyes.

Divine Avat─Бras

Arjuna was surprised on hearing Bhagav─Бn praise long-lost ancestors. He said, “Wait a moment, my dear fellow! When was Vivasv─Бn born and when were you born? How were you, my contemporary, able to instruct someone who existed long, long ago?”

This question of ArjunaтАЩs gave an opportunity to Bhagav─Бn to demonstrate his firm attachment towards his dharma. He said, “Arjuna, you and I do not belong to this era alone; we have always existed. You and I differ in two aspects. Firstly, you have forgotten your previous births; I remember them. Secondly, your births were caused because of your deeds тАФ good and bad. My avat─Бras are for the protection of dharma.тАЭ

yad─Б yad─Б hi dharmasya gl─Бnirbhavati bh─Бrata
abhyutth─Бnam adharmasya tad─Бtm─Бnaс╣Г sс╣Ыj─Бmyaham ред
paritr─Бс╣З─Бya s─Бdh┼лn─Бс╣Г vin─Б┼Ы─Бya ca duс╣гkс╣Ыt─Бс╣Г
dharmasaс╣Г┼Ыth─Бpan─Бrth─Бya sambav─Бmi yuge yuge рее (BG 4.7, 4.8)
(Whenever dharma declines and adharma ascends, I manifest myself.
To protect the virtuous, to destroy the evil and to establish dharma, I am born in every age).

[[Ch. 4 Yoga of Unattached Karma (Part 3) Source: prekshaa]]

Why is Dharma Worthy of Worship?

Dharma is established and nurtured by the divine. Bhagav─Бn who needs to have no thought for anything else thinks of dharma alone and of his own volition. This should bring the greatness of dharma to our minds. Dharma is ─к┼ЫvaraтАЩs own property. Therefore, it is immensely worthy of our worship. We have to always remember that ─к┼Ыvara is watching us all the time. An American poet says thus:

Though the mills of God grind slowly,
And they grind exceeding small,
Though with patience He stands waiting
With exactness grinds He all.
тАФRetribution, Henry Wadsworth Longfellow

Not one human-grain can elude the mill of karma. Sooner or later, they are consumed by it. Those who follow dharma escape it.

svalpam-apy-asya dharmasya tr─Бyate mahato bhay─Бt (BG 2.40)
(Even following a little of this dharma protects from great fear)

The Need for Viveka

All this is fine, but what is the way to dharma? Whatever approach oneтАЩs heart spurs him to take in his search for goodness тАФ is the means of dharma for him. Dharma follows the condition of the j─лva, its distinct qualifications and its strengths and weaknesses. A тАШone size fits allтАЩ approach cannot be applied to dharma. The dharma of a j─лva is determined by its unique quality. This means that the acceptance of dharma is possible only by clear-headed deliberation and not by blind faith.

dharme pram─лyam─Бс╣Зe hi vedena karaс╣З─Бtman─Б
iti kartavyat─Б-bh─Бgam m─лm─Бс╣Гs─Б p┼лrayiс╣гyati
(When dharma is being comprehended through the Veda,
m─лm─Бс╣Гs─Б complements it by providing practical means.)
тАФT─Бrkika-rakс╣г─Б

M─лm─Бс╣Гs─Б means logic, or deliberation on cause and effect. This verse means that one should reflect carefully, to understand the true nature of dharma.

Thus dharma is fundamentally the same for everyone. Its practice differs according to the desires and capabilities of the doer. Just as food conforms to the health of the stomach and the desire of the palate; dharma also conforms to the state of the j─лva. It should consider the incapability of the j─лva also. Can fasting be prescribed to a person who cannot bear hunger? The dharma of a person is decided based on the natural proclivities of his j─лva.

Classification of Guna and Karma (Guna-karma-vibh─Бga)

People harbour different desires in their heart and to obtain them, they propitiate different deities. They are all travellers on the wide road that leads to Bhagav─Бn. As the innate qualities and propensities of humans are naturally different, they have been broadly classified into four categories to determine their respective dharmas. Bhagav─Бn said, “I incarnate myself in this world again and again to establish dharma, to systematize varс╣Зas and ─Б┼Ыramas, to codify appropriate fruits for actions. Thereby I am performing my dharma.тАЭ

c─Бtur-varс╣Зyaс╣Г may─Б sс╣Ыс╣гс╣нyaс╣Г guс╣Зa-karma-vibh─Бga┼Ыaс╕е (BG 4.13)

There is a peculiar attribute of the system of j─Бti that needs to be discussed here. The reformers of today argue that it is against the principles of equality and is therefore a blemish upon society. Even though the G─лt─Бch─БryaтАЩs advice espouses equality, the essential meaning is that this equality should be practical and ultimately result in wholesome benefit to the j─лva. The aim of the varс╣Зa system is that an individual should employ his qualifications by birth in the service of the collective. It is true that the elevation of the individual is important. But if it has to be a genuine ennoblement and not just a fa├зade, it should result in continuous, perpetual value to the collective. The basic premise of the varс╣Зa system is that by being of service to the collective, an individual can achieve his own betterment. The qualities, activities, and capabilities of an individual help him to thus be of service.

Bhagav─БnтАЩs words describe the existing situation and not the products of human imagination. As this four-fold division of human society is based on natural qualities, it is settled that it is applicable for all humans in all places at all times.

Bhagav─Бn himself has established the varс╣Зa system considering the various qualities distributed amongst different groups of people, and the several benefits that accrue to the world through them. He has established the dharma of various varс╣Зas and clans based on the naturally occurring proportions of sattva, rajas and tamas in each person.

The varс╣Зa system will be studied again in the appendix.

Akarma in Karma

Bhagav─Бn explains to Arjuna that even though he is engaged in karma, he is not tainted by it.

na me karma-phale spс╣Ыh─Б (BG 4.14)
тАЬArjuna, it is not wrong for you to fight to win a kingdom, or for glory and renown. It is also acceptable to perform your duty as an offering to Bhagav─Бn, with the sole purpose of dharma.тАЭ

evaс╣Г j├▒─Бtv─Б kс╣Ыtaс╣Г karma p┼лrvairapi mumukс╣гubhiс╕е
kuru karmaiva tasm─Бt tvaс╣Г p┼лrvaiс╕е p┼лrvataraс╣Г kс╣Ыtam(BG 4.15)

Kс╣Ы┼Ыna is not modernist, but traditionalist. He believes in practices that are established over time. That is the meaning of san─Бtana as in san─Бtana-dharma. Not only those who desired worldly wealth and pleasure, but even people desirous of mokс╣гa performed karma. Mokс╣гa is тАШreleaseтАЩ. Why did those desirous of emancipation shackle themselves in karma? Bhagav─Бn explains.

karmaс╣Зo hyapi boddhavyam boddhavyam ca vikarmaс╣Зaс╕е
akarmaс╣Зa┼Ыca boddhavyaс╣Г gahan─Б karmaс╣Зo gatiс╕е (BG 4.17)

The ways of karma are mysterious. Therefore, to understand its nature, we have to first understand the three types of karma тАФ karma, vikarma and akarma.

  1. vihita-karma тАФ oneтАЩs ordained duty, that which has to be performed without fail, which yields results 2. vikarma тАФ unfavourable, forbidden karma, that which should not be performed, 3. akarma тАФ there are three possible meanings to this word. Therefore the preceding and succeeding contexts have to be examined before the meaning is determined.

i. Giving up all karma, including those that are mandatory or required; doing absolutely nothing at all.

m─Б te saс╣Еgos-tv-akarmaс╣Зi (BG 2-47)

karma jy─Бyo hyakarmaс╣Зaс╕е
na prasiddhyedakarmaс╣Зaс╕е (BG 3.8)

ii. Performance of necessary duties, but not getting attached to its results. Perform action but be unconcerned and calm as though no action needs to be performed.

karmaс╣Зy-akarma yaс╕е pa┼Ыyet (BG 4.18)

karmaс╣Зy-abhipravс╣ЫttoтАЩpi naiva ki├▒cit karoti saс╕е (BG 4.20)

kurvannapi na lipyate (BG 5.7)

iii. It could also mean vikarma тАФ action that should be avoided, something that should not be done. Even though the G─лt─Б doesnтАЩt have this kind of meaning, it is seen elsewhere.

Thus, the meaning of akarma is to be inferred from the context.

[[Ch. 4 Yoga of Unattached Karma (Part 4) Source: prekshaa]]

Arjuna is hasty. Initially, he was eager to fight. Then, he was eager to give up fighting. Vikarma is the result of this haste. Therefore, the following is said about those who deduce the nature of dharma -

yukt─Б ─Бyukt─Бс╕е
al┼лkс╣г─Б dharmak─Бm─Бс╕е syuс╕е
yath─Б te tatra varteran
tath─Б tatra varteth─Бс╕е
Those who are skillful and experienced, not harsh, and practise dharma constantly, as they behave (during times of doubt), so too you shall.
тАФTaittir─лyopaniс╣гad, ┼Ъ─лkс╣г─Бvall─л, Anuv─Бka11

dharma-┼Ы─Бstr─Бnus─Бreс╣Зa
krodha-lobha-vivarjitaс╕е
(Who is devoid of anger and greed according to the precepts of dharma)
тАФY─Бj├▒avalkya-smс╣Ыti 2.1

What, then, is the way here?

karmaс╣Зyakarma yaс╕е pa┼Ыyet akarmaс╣Зi ca karma yaс╕е
sa buddhim─Бn manuс╣гyeс╣гu sa yuktaс╕е kс╣Ыtsnakarmakс╣Ыt (BG 4.18)
(One who sees action in inaction and inaction in action is wise among men, he is a yogi; he performs all actions)

Bhagav─Бn has captured the entire essence of karma in this verse. One who can achieve the detachment and calmness of a non-doer even while performing all actions, and can likewise find the benefit of karma while giving its fruits up, is wise. He is kс╣Ыtsnakarmakс╣Ыt тАФ one who is worthy of performing all karmas. Such a man performs all actions but is not influenced by their consequences. Jackfruit should be peeled, but the hands should not become dirty. The hands should therefore be lubricated with oil beforehand тАФ that is the trick. Bhagav─Бn says the same thing later through the example of a lotus-leaf in water -

padmapatram iv─Бmbhas─Б (BG 5.10)

A man should live in this world like a lotus leaf in water. He has to work hard outwardly. Internally, he should not be affected by it. The affliction and perturbation associated with karma should not hassle him while he performs it. The same thought is expressed in the old saying -

alepav─Бdam─Б┼Ыritya ┼Ыr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зajanak─Бvubhau (Unknown)
The doctrine of non-attachment was employed by both ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa and Janak─Б.

Asaс╣Еgakarma тАУ Karma without Attachment

Bhagav─Бn explains akarma further:

tyaktv─Б karmaphal─Бsaс╣Еgaс╣Г nityatс╣Ыpto nir─Б┼Ыrayaс╕е
karmaс╣Зyabhpravс╣ЫttoтАЩpi naiva ki├▒cit karoti saс╕е (BG 4.20)
(If one is engaged in karma but abandons the desire for fruits of action, is always content and not subject to the whims of anyone, then it is as though he is not doing anything at all)

How can he “naiva ki├▒cit karoti saс╕е " тАФ not do anything, even though he is actively engaged in karma? By being ever-content and completely disinterested.

tattvavit-tu mah─Бb─Бho guс╣Зakarmavibh─Бgayoс╕е
guс╣З─Б guс╣Зeс╣гu vartanta iti matv─Б na sajjate (BG 3.28)

There are some internal and some external qualities in human nature. They keep agitating one another. This agitation is not related to the ─Бtm─Б, but happens in the domain of prakс╣Ыti. It is not suitable to attach this agitation to the ─Бtm─Б.

A human has freedom only to determine karma, vikarma and akarma. This freedom to deliberate is also quite limited, because even the intellect is shackled by impressions from previous births. Individual discernment is present in everyone at least to some extent. At least an awareness that one is not a j├▒─Бn─л, or the wisdom that he should not proclaim it to the world if he does indeed think that he is one, or the awareness of the dangers of such self-praise тАФ these are all present in any person. A man should develop his discerning abilities using the wisdom he already possesses. As discernment (viveka) becomes a habit, detachment can be practised.

There is a phrase that is often used in R─Бm─Бyana and the Mah─Бbh─Бrata тАФ “r─Бmasya akliс╣гс╣нakarmaс╣Зaс╕е”, “r─Бmam akliс╣гс╣нakarm─Бс╣Зam”. The same is said about Yudhiс╣гс╣нhira. Those great people perform their duties, but do not become exhausted because of them. This is alepayoga тАФ the yoga of performing action without getting attached. This is the formula of tyaktv─Б karmaphal─Бsaс╣Еgam. Even if a person actively performs karma, if he does not desire its fruits for himself and is content always, and is not subject to othersтАЩ whims, that karma does not make any difference to him; to him, it is as good as doing nothing.

The epithet nityatс╣Ыpta is mentioned above. This is a very important quality. Likewise, nir─Бshraya. He should not be dependent on anything or anyone. Desiring the society of others is discouraged. The upright and beneficial qualities of a person emerge completely only when he becomes independent. Niс╕еspс╣Ыhasya tс╣Ыс╣Зaс╣Г jagat тАФ the universe is but a trifle for the unattached. A man who does not have any desire, even though he performs action, is naiva ki├▒cit-karoti тАФ does not do anything. He understands dharma. He does not deem praise or censure, fame or infamy as important. He does not experience mental strain; he does not attach his ─Бtm─Б to any labour. It is said in the second chapter itself -

nainaс╣Г chindanti ┼Ыastr─Бс╣Зi nainaс╣Г dahati p─Бvakaс╕е
na cainaс╣Г kledayanty─Бpo na ┼Ыoс╣гayati m─Бrutaс╕е (BG 2.23)

Responsibility of the J─лva-state

We said that a j├▒─Бn─л does not get fatigued and does not attach himself to any labour. Does it mean that he has no sense of responsibility?

There is only one fundamental thing - the ─Бtm─Б. It is now in the state of a j─лva. In this state, it has certain responsibilities. In its state as pure ─Бtm─Б, it is unstained. However, as a j─лva, it has its own responsibilities, puс╣Зya and p─Бpa, dharma and adharma. That is why Bhagav─Бn says that we should have the right judgement. It is difficult to know the path of karma. Knowing our rightful duty (vihitakarma) is difficult, as is performing it without exertion. One should neither be proud of oneтАЩs accomplishments nor feel distressed about not performing action. Wise is he who performs activity with the sole view that it is a duty. We can take the example of doctors. They have neither love nor hate for their patients, but work with the sole intention of bringing the bodies to their normal working state. They never worry if the patient is a criminal or a thief.

The principle is that there should be no desire for the fruit of a task. Our duties should be performed to please Bhagav─Бn and to sustain dharma. Even in the performance of good karma, there are two stages. The first stage is to act to please Bhagav─Бn, whereas the second stage is to act with self-knowledge. Self-knowledge is hard to obtain; it has to develop within us, by itself. For this to happen, the impurities that cover the mind have to be removed. These impurities can only be removed when dh─Бrmic duties are performed.

[[Ch. 4 Yoga of Unattached Karma (Part 5) Source: prekshaa]]

Selfless Karma

Who should follow the principle of not wanting results for oneтАЩs duties? Those who are seeking mokс╣гa. How many of us are wishing for mokс╣гa? Surely, the number of people wishing for material things vastly exceeds that. We all desire something or the other. They may all be noble desires. For instance, those indulging in wrongdoing must be destroyed; we as a country should grow our own food; we have to establish ourselves well in the world; attain glory and so on. We performтАФindeed we have to perform our duties to attain these desires. A man desirous of mokс╣гa can also carry out all these duties, but he does them independently. This is the meaning of nir─Б┼Ыrayaс╕е.

We work towards one or the other goal. Kс╣Ыpaс╣З─Бс╕е phalahetavaс╕е тАФ wretched are they who work only with the motive of results. What did our с╣Ъс╣гis pray for? Asmin de┼Ыe ┼Ы┼лro j─Бyat─Бmity─Бha тАФ “May brave people be born in this country, may strong horses be born; may youth capable of discussing in assemblies be born; may they discuss and argue in august assembliesтАЩтАЩ тАФ all this is selfishness from a certain perspective. It might be beneficial, but it is still selfishness. Bhagav─Бn assures Arjuna that p─Бpa will not attach to him if he performs his duties just for the sake of dharma, to sustain the world.

yadс╣Ыcch─Бl─Бbhasantuс╣гс╣нo dvandv─Бt─лto vimatsaraс╕е
samaс╕е siddh─Бvasiddhau ca kс╣Ыtv─Бpi na nibaddhyate (BG 4.22)
(He who is content with what comes to him unasked, transcending dualities, free of jealousy, who remains equanimous during attainment or nonattainment of the desired object, will remain free even when he performs worldly duties.)

Duties do not shackle a man who, without fatiguing oneself, is content with what he has, has a state of mind that has risen above worldly love and hate, shunning jealousy, is single-minded, and is of equanimous disposition towards success or failure. Yadс╣Ыcch─Б is something has come to us, as it is our lot; let it be. Dvandv─Бt─лtaс╕е тАФ p─Бpa and puс╣Зya also constitute duality тАФ but let us not go so far. The duality that we see commonly is that of love and hate. Vimatsaraс╕е тАФ without jealousy. Bhagav─Бn says this word again and again. By all accounts, practising it is very difficult; being free of jealousy тАФ anas┼лy─Б is hard in this world. Samaс╕е siddh─Бvasiddhau ca тАФ we should not give up activity because the results of our work were not what we expected. We have to try again and again to perform our dharma. He, who carries out his duties with such a mindset, is тАФ kс╣Ыtv─Бpi na nibaddhyate” тАФ not bound by karma.

Karma-yaj├▒a

gatasaс╣Еgasya muktasya j├▒─Бn─Бvasthita-cetasaс╕е
yaj├▒─Бy─Бcaritaс╣Г karma samagraс╣Г pravil─лyate (BG 4.23)
One who is unattached and is liberated, with his mind established in true knowledge, acts in the spirit of yaj├▒─Б. All his actions are indeed absolved.

The activity performed by a knower of truth, who is neither anxious for the results nor is excessively passionate, is no different from yaj├▒a. All karma, carried out with such a view does not influence the performer of the action in any way and dissolves away completely.

Each and every one of our duties must be carried out in the spirit of the yaj├▒a. This is the instruction of the ┼Ыruti as well тАФ to live with the spirit of yaj├▒a. Whenever the word yaj├▒a is mentioned, a picture of homa, the sacrificial fire, purohitas chanting mantras and ghee for the oblation comes to mind. That is not just it. All worship is yaj├▒a. Grammar dictates the same тАФ “yaj p┼лj─Бy─Бm” тАФ the root yaj is used in the context of worship. In practice, yaj├▒a usually refers to oblation through fire or an offering. Giving up something we love in order to please another is yaj├▒a.

It has been said earlier one should give up the desire for the fruit of an action. However, this feelingтАФgiving up something for a loved oneтАФis easier to grasp. The following verse is well-known.

brahm─Бrpaс╣Зaс╣Г brahma-haviс╕е brahm─Бgnau brahmaс╣З─Б-hutam
brahmaiva tena gantavyaс╣Г brahma-karma-sam─Бdhin─Б (BG 4.24)

All karma carried out by a j├▒─Бn─л is yaj├▒a. All parts of this yaj├▒a, all its instruments are manifestations of the Supreme Brahma. The very process of yaj├▒a is dedicated to It. The oblation that is poured into such a yaj├▒a is Brahma. The fire that accepts it is also Brahma. The person performing the yaj├▒a is also Brahma. Thus, the profit gained by a man who is engrossed in selfless, divine duties тАФ brahma-karma, is Brahma itself. The doer, the work and the object are all one with Brahma. All activities of life are, indeed, worship of Parabrahma. ┼Ъruti says the same -

tasyaiva viduс╣гo yaj├▒asy─Бtm─Б yajam─Бnaс╕е ┼Ыraddh─Б patn─л ┼Ыar─лramidhmam urovedirlom─Бni barhirveda┼Ы┼Ыikh─Б hс╣Ыdayaс╣Г y┼лpaс╕е k─Бma ─Бjyaс╣Г manyuс╕е pa┼Ыuс╕е тАж yanmaraс╣Зaс╣Г tadavabhс╣Ыthaс╕е тАФ Mah─Бn─Бr─Бyaс╣Зopaniс╣гad

The nature of the yaj├▒a of a j├▒─Бn─л is said to be thus тАФ the consciousness of the ─Бtm─Б is the yajam─Бna (the performer of the yaj├▒a). Only a man with a wife is entitled to perform yaj├▒a, therefore ┼Ыraddh─Б or devotion is the wife. The body is the fuel; the heart is the y┼лpa pillar. Desires are ghee, anger is the sacrificial animal тАФ yaj├▒apa┼Ыu. The ritual bath taken after the yaj├▒a is complete, is avabhс╣Ыtha. Avabhс╣Ыtha for a j├▒─Бn─л is death. He is not scared of death. Instead, just as a yajam─Бna feels satisfied after a yaj├▒a is completed, he feels gratified that his life is now offered to Brahma.

We saw the same idea in the third chapter as well.

yaj├▒─Бrth─Бt-karmaс╣ЗoтАЩnyatra lokoтАЩyaс╣Г karmabandhanaс╕е
tadarthaс╣Г karma kaunteya muktasaс╣Еgaс╕е sam─Бcara (BG 3.9)

yaj├▒a┼Ыiс╣гс╣н─Б┼Ыinaс╕е santo mucyante sarvakilbiс╣гaiс╕е (BG 3.13)

Our well-being and happiness are all favours granted by the Supreme. Though it was our hand that did the work, it was the hand of the divine that gave boons. If this much is in our minds, p─Бpa will not touch us.

Bhagav─Бn is instructing us about the way in which we can perform all karma and yet remain free from p─Бpa Experience all the pleasures of the world; but do not forget that it is a favour granted by ─к┼Ыvara. The essence of this instruction is to always remember Brahma.

smс╣Ыtim─Бtreс╣Зa yat puс╣Гs─Бс╣Г brahma tanma├▒galaс╣Г viduс╕е
тАФ Viс╣гс╣Зu-pur─Бс╣Зa
(Brahma is that which bestows blessings even on men who merely remember It)

yasya smaraс╣Зam─Бtreс╣Зa janma-saс╣Гs─Бrabandhan─Бt
vimucyate namastasmai viс╣гс╣Зave prabhaviс╣гс╣Зave
тАФ Viс╣гс╣Зu-Sahasran─Бma
(Salutations to him, whose mere remembrance liberates one from the shackles of birth and saс╣Гs─Бra.)

Even the mere remembrance of Brahma is highly beneficial to us. How is that? The Supreme Brahma is the greatest. If its thoughts fill our minds, p─Бpa does not enter them.

[[Ch. 4 Yoga of Unattached Karma (Part 6) Source: prekshaa]]

Once we say that it is not wrong but only fit and proper to experience pleasure, we have to make all arrangements to obtain it. Sustaining the family, earning a salary for their comfort, taking loans in case there are emergencies and repaying them, giving and taking help, struggling thus in many ways become the duty of a householder.

┼Ъr─л ┼Ъankar─Бc─БryaтАЩs instruction is thus тАУ

yogarato v─Б bhogarato v─Б saс╣Еgarato v─Б saс╣Еgavih─лnaс╕е
yasya brahmaс╣Зi ramate cittaс╣Г nandati nandati nandatyeva
тАФMohamudgara
(A man whose mind dwells blissfully in Brahma is always happy, whether he is engaged in tapas or worldly pleasure, whether he is in company or is alone).

If a driver is appointed to drive a car, it becomes his responsibility to check whether all the parts of the car are working properly and whether there is enough fuel in the car. The Supreme, in its infinite wisdom, has established dharma in this world. It is our responsibility to see that it is performed well.

┼Ъr─л Kanakad─Бsa has expressed the sentiment that every duty is sev─Б to the divine in one of his k─лrtanas, beautifully.

tanu ninnadu j─лvana ninnado raс╣Еga
enad─Бvudondan─л jagadoс╕╗u n─Б k─Бс╣Зe
anudinadali baha sukhaduс╕еkha ninadayya
(O Raс╣Еga, this body is yours, this life is also yours. In this universe, I donтАЩt see anything that is mine. The pleasure and pain that I experience daily are also yours).

This is the essence of all Ved─Бnta. Our entire life is a yaj├▒a. Bhagav─Бn says that yaj├▒a is of many types.

dravyayaj├▒─Бstapoyaj├▒─Бс╕е yogayaj├▒─Бstath─Бpare
sv─Бdhy─Бya-j├▒─Бna-yaj├▒─Б┼Ыca yatayaс╕е saс╣Г┼Ыitavrat─Бс╕е (BG 4.28)
(Ascetics accomplish various yaj├▒as such as dravyayaj├▒a (giving up wealth), tapoyaj├▒a (performing austerities), yogayaj├▒a (practice of aс╣гс╣н─Бс╣Еgayoga), sv─Бdhy─Бya-j├▒─Бnayaj├▒a (self-study, gaining and distribution of knowledge).

evaс╣Г bahuvidh─Б yaj├▒─Бс╕е vitat─Б brahmaс╣Зo mukhe
karmaj─Бn viddhi t─Бn sarv─Бn evaс╣Г j├▒─Бtv─Б vimokс╣гyase (BG 4.32)
In this way, many kinds of yaj├▒as are known from the Vedas. Know all of them to be derived from karma (all of them are different forms of karma). Thus, you will be liberated.

In the Presence of the Divine

Whatever one can think of, whatever oneтАЩs mind likes, whatever one is capable of doing, whatever one likes to do, - if one thinks, тАЬ┼Ъr─л Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa pras─лda (┼Ъr─л Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa*,* be pleased)тАЭ while doing any of this or praying for any of this - it becomes a yaj├▒a. Similarly, when experiencing any of this, if all of it is offered as ┼Ъr─лKс╣Ыс╣гс╣З─Бrpaс╣Зa (offered to ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa*)*, it becomes a yaj├▒a. However, it is not merely the tongue that must say this - but the mind. It should be embedded firmly in the heart. This famous verse also says the same -

─Бtm─Б tvaс╣Г girij─Б matiс╕е sahacar─Бс╕е pr─Бс╣З─Бс╕е ┼Ыar─лraс╣Г gс╣Ыhaс╣Г
p┼лj─Б te viс╣гayopabhogaracan─Б nidr─Б sam─Бdhisthitiс╕е
sa├▒c─Бraс╕е padayoс╕е pradakс╣гiс╣Зavidhiс╕е stotr─Бс╣Зi sarv─Б giraс╕е
yadyat karma karomi tattadakhilaс╣Г ┼Ъambho tav─Бr─Бdhanam
тАФ┼Ъiva-m─Бnasa-p┼лja

The essence of the earlier upaniс╣гat quote тАФ “tasyaivaс╣Г viduс╣гo yaj├▒asy─Бtm─Б yajam─Бnaс╕е” is also the same. “┼Ыar─лraс╣Г gс╣Ыhaс╣Г” тАФ the body is the house of Para┼Ыiva, and the enjoyment of worldly pleasures is “te p┼лj─Б” тАФ his worship. ┼Ъr─л Kanakad─Бsa says “eveyikkade noс╕Нuva noс╣нa ninnadayya” тАФ the sight that stares (at beautiful maidens) without blinking is yours, “с╣гaс╕Нurasadannakke nalid─Бс╕Нuva jihve ninnadu” тАФ the tongue that is gladdened by tasty food with all six flavours is yours. Life should be led in this manner, with a mind to yaj├▒a. “Yanmaraс╣Зaс╣Г tadavabhс╣Ыthaс╕е” тАФ death is also a part of the yaj├▒a of life. The word yaj├▒a has a wide range of meanings. By the word j├▒─Бna in j├▒─Бnayaj├▒a should be understood philosophy, biology or mathematics and all other branches of learning. Physics, biological and social sciences and all other scientific pursuits too are j├▒─Бna, which implies that even scientists are established in yaj├▒a. All studies, all art, and all knowledge are harmonised in the realm of self-welfare.

Our ancestors followed a meaningful vrata, “kavale kavale Govindaс╣Г” тАФ at mealtime, they would take Bhagav─БnтАЩs name with each morsel of food they partook instead of chatting with others. This is the same as reciting verses during meals. TodayтАЩs city life is not conducive for remembering the names of the divine often. Gandhiji tried to bring back this practice. Singing divine names is a kind of training for some minds. For people with such a mindset, even chanting divine names is a yaj├▒a. There are two kinds of results for all yaj├▒as тАФ obtaining what one wishes for, and gradual elevation of the j─лva.

We perform our activities with a desire to accomplish something. However, if we perform karma with a view that it is a yaj├▒a or that it is a service to the divine, our minds will gradually turn towards the Supreme; our ego will gradually diminish as the j─лva becomes purer. And as the j─лva becomes purer, it becomes capable of grasping the principle of reality.

People work according to their capabilities. What did Kucela have? A handful of rice! How did that become inexhaustible? Because he said Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣З─Бrpaс╣Зa. Everything should be seen as an offering to Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa. Whatever we obtain must always be seen as a boon from Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa. An elderly person in my family would recite a Telugu verse at mealtime тАФ “Not a grain of rice more, not a grain less; not a minute earlier, not a minute later; not a drop of water more, not a drop less. Bhag─Бvan, only the quantity that you determine will enter my stomach”. After chanting the pre-meal mantras, he would recite this verse and take ─Бpo┼Ыana(ritual drinking of a spoon of water before meals). The meaning of the mantras chanted by vaidikas at meals тАФ “┼Ыraddh─Бy─Бс╣Г pr─Бс╣Зe nivi┼Ыya тАж pr─Бс╣З─Бya sv─Бh─Б …” тАФ is the same, it is the constant remembrance of the presence of the divine. It is “practising the presence of the Supreme”. It is the feeling that we are always under the watch of the divine. The feeling of this proximity of the divine does not arise from a thousand campaka flowers or ten thousand jasmines. If the feeling first exists, only then does worship with this large heap of flowers carry any meaning. Maturity of mind is paramount. This is what Bhagav─Бn implies when he says “patraс╣Г puс╣гpaс╣Г phalaс╣Г toyaс╣Г”.

yaj├▒a-┼Ыiс╣гс╣н─Бmс╣Ыta-bhujo y─Бnti brahma san─Бtanam
n─Бyaс╣Г lokoтАЩsty-ayaj├▒asya kutoтАЩnyaс╕е kuru-sattama (BG 4.31)
O great scion of the Kurus! Those who partake of the amс╣Ыta that is the remnant of yaj├▒a attains the eternal abode of Brahma. One who does not perform yaj├▒a is not even fit for this world, what then to say of other, higher worlds?
