[[Ch. 4 Yoga of Unattached Karma (Part 7) Source: prekshaa]]

A person who carries out his duties without considering it an offering, will not even gain the good in this world. Then, how can he obtain a good state in other worlds? Mokс╣гa is the best among the four cardinal aims of human life. Karma helps achieve dharma, artha and k─Бma (dharma, wealth, and enjoyment). Even so, karma is the necessary first step for mokс╣гa. Mokс╣гa is liberation from the burden of the universe. Since we do not know the true nature of the ─Бtm─Б, m─Бy─Б (illusion of the world) and moha (attachment to the world) cover and shackle us, and make life miserable and burdensome. To get rid of the burden, we should know the true nature of j─лva, ─к┼Ыvara and Param─Бtm─Б. That is tattvaj├▒─Бna or the knowledge of reality. The way to this knowledge is training the mind by performing our duties.

┼Ыrey─Бn dravyamay─Бt yaj├▒─Бt j├▒─Бnayaj├▒aс╕е parantapa
sarvaс╣Г karm─Бkhilaс╣Г p─Бrtha j├▒─Бne parisam─Бpyate (BG 4.33)
(O scorcher of foes, J├▒─Бnayaj├▒a is better than yaj├▒a performed with physical objects. All karma culminates in j├▒─Бna. )

A man who feels that he is performing a yaj├▒a, will be content with what he obtains. What he gains is a blessing from ─к┼Ыvara, what he gives away is an offering to ─к┼Ыvara тАФ indeed, blessed is the man whose life-stream flows thus between the banks of blessings and offerings. He reaches the ocean of Brahma quickly. By constant recollection of ─к┼Ыvara, he will understand the nature of Bhagav─Бn тАФ “j├▒─Бne parisam─Бpyate” тАФ it culminates in j├▒─Бna.

The Benefit of Satkarma

Thus, there are four uses of performing satkarma тАФ

  1. Obtaining what one desires, like in the stories of Gajendra and Dhruva. 2. Practice of bhakti: the experience that there is something above us, the understanding that it deserves our love, worship, service, and obedience. This gives us serenity and courage. 3. Diminished ego: the illusion of “I”, the constant feeling that there is an ocean of energy behind us. 4. Preparing the mind to grasp the knowledge of reality.

The intellect can, probably to a certain extent, understand the nature of the ─Бtm─Б. To understand it fully, it has to be experienced. If it has to be experienced, all our internal faculties must work together as one. The severity and rigidity of the ego must be annihilated. All this priming will ready it for self-realisation. “buddhigr─Бhyamat─лndriyam” (BG 6.21) тАФ it can be grasped by the intellect, even though it is suprasensory. Belief should rise from inside. The mind, akin to a mirror, must become pure.

dh┼лmen-─Бvriyate vahnir-yath─Бdar┼Ыo malena ca (BG 3.38)
(Just as fire is enveloped by smoke, and a mirror by dirt).

Karma is that which wipes this mirror clean.

Obtaining J├▒─Бna

Well then, is knowledge gained by just performing our duties? That is not enough; there must be other effort too. What is that?

tadviddhi praс╣Зip─Бtena paripra┼Ыnena sevay─Б
upadekс╣гyanti te j├▒─Бnaс╣Г j├▒─Бnin─Бtattvadar┼Ыinaс╕е (BG 4.34)
(Learn that knowledge from those who have realized the truth. Approach them with a spirit of sincere enquiry and serve them with humility. They will impart that knowledge to you.)

Praс╣Зip─Бta is bowing down, a demonstration of humility. It is a sign that one is interested in learning something of value. It signifies earnestness and receptivity. Readiness to grasp is the first sign of a seeker of knowledge.

The second sign is paripra┼Ыna тАФ Analysing the same thing in various ways and asking pertinent questions, thereby clearing all doubts.

The third sign is sev─Б or service. Be with the elderly and knowledgeable always. The guru may expound the theory of the Supreme Brahma in words, but its practice must be learnt by observing his conduct. “kelavaс╣Г m─Бс╕╗pavarind─Х kaс╣Зс╕Нu” тАФ learn some things by observing those who are already doing them. One must wait, watch and observe how gurus deal with challenging and difficult circumstances when the mind is perturbed.

This is the essence of philosophy:

yad j├▒─Бtv─Б na punarmoham evaс╣Г y─Бsyasi p─Бс╣Зс╕Нava
yena bh┼лt─Бnya┼Ыeс╣гeс╣Зa drakс╣гasy─Бtmanyatho mayi (BG 4.35)

The supreme principle is that by knowing which the delusion that is clouding your mind will not arise again; after seeing which you will see all creatures of the world within yourself and me also. How can you incur p─Бpa after understanding this? Harming others is p─Бpa.

┼Ыlok─Бrdhena pravakс╣гy─Бmi yaduktaс╣Г granthakoс╣нibhiс╕е
paropak─Бraс╕е puс╣Зy─Бya p─Бp─Бya parap─лс╕Нanam
(In half a verse, I will convey what has been expounded at length by millions of books. It is puс╣Зya to help others, and p─Бpa to hurt others.)

Who is para тАФ other тАФ when there is nothing in the universe other than oneself? For an ─Аtmaj├▒─Бn─л, there is nothing or no one other than him in the universe. How, then, can he hurt anyone else? Or, how can he even help anyone else? It is just self-conceit to say that one has helped another. One who sees himself in everyone doesnтАЩt see “other”. Therefore, he is not even touched by puс╣Зya or p─Бpa.

ayaс╣Г nijaс╕е paro veti gaс╣Зan─Б laghucetas─Бс╣Г
ud─Бracarit─Бn─Бс╣Г tu vasudhaiva kuс╣нumbakam
тАФHitopade┼Ыa 1.71

Ordinary people have the feeling that one is his own, or that another is alien. Therefore he has the concepts of puс╣Зya or p─Бpa. But the generous man who has comprehended the Supreme principle considers the whole world is an extension of himself. Therefore, understanding the true nature of the Supreme will erase the differences in the world, their derivatives such as greed and delusion, and their derivatives such as hatred and jealousy.

j├▒─Бnaс╣Г labdhv─Б par─Бс╣Г ┼Ы─Бntim acireс╣З─Бdhigacchati (BG 4.39)
(Having obtained knowledge, he will quickly attain great peace).

[[Ch. 4 Yoga of Unattached Karma (Part 8) Source: prekshaa]]

The Necessity of Firm Decision

Arjuna, if we analyse from the perspective of the supreme principle, it becomes clear that your doubts are baseless. Be firm about the ─Бtm─Б. Do not entertain doubts in your mind.

aj├▒a┼Ыc─Б┼Ыraddhadh─Бna┼Ыca saс╣Г┼Ыay─Бtm─Б vina┼Ыyati
n─Бyaс╣Г lokoтАЩsti na paraс╣Г na sukhaс╣Г saс╣Г┼Ыay─Бtmanaс╕е (BG 4.40)
(One who does not know, doesnтАЩt have faith or is filled with doubts in his mind, perishes. A doubtful man can neither live in this world nor the otherworld. He is never happy.)

Do not keep swinging between karma, j├▒─Бna, dharma or sanny─Бsa. You will be ruined from all sides if you do that. Trust something completely. Only then will you attain a better state.

Let us suppose a man has been invited to a banquet at a big restaurant. We can imagine the conflict in a traditional manтАЩs mind if he comes to know that that day is an ek─Бda┼Ыi[eleventh day of the lunar fortnight; traditional Hindus fast on this day.] If he stays back at home, he will be thinking about the good time his friends are having. If he does go, he will be worrying that he is eating outside food on an ek─Бda┼Ыi. Both are doubtful тАФ saс╣Г┼Ыay─Бtm─Бs. One did not enjoy the banquet, the other did not think of Bhagav─Бn on ek─Бda┼Ыi.

We have to believe in one thing тАФ either karma or j├▒─Бna. Only then can we be peaceful. Belief is courage, and courage is happiness. There are thousands, even countless philosophies in todayтАЩs world. But it cannot be said that any one of them can really build faith. Many of them can, however, shake existing beliefs. The poverty of our times is that we do not have strong belief тАФ the belief тАШI am living for a specific purpose, I will be delivered from our sorrows from thisтАЩ. Amongst the various kinds of poverty that afflict us, lack of belief (┼Ыraddh─Бd─Бridrya) is the greatest.

тАЬArjuna, doubt born of ignorance is housed in your heart. Cut it with the power of the knowledge of the self, and establish yourself in the yoga of performing your duty for the Divine. Get up and fightтАЭ. This is ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣ЗaтАЩs instruction.

Nirlepa-yoga

This chapter seems to have got its name, j├▒─Бna-karma-saс╣Гny─Бsa-yoga, from the words тАЬyoga-saс╣Гnyasta karm─Бс╣Зaс╣ГтАЭ. This chapter is called brahma-yaj├▒a-pra┼Ыaс╣Гs─Б in the ┼Ъ─Бс╣Еkara-bh─Бс╣гya. The important takeaway here from the view of the common people is karmaс╣Зyakarma yah pa┼Ыyet. We should perform karma, but in such a way that its dirt does not stick to us. Therefore, it is quite apt if we name this chapter nirlepa-karma-yoga.

Alepa or nirlepa is a negative form. It means that something is not there, and not that something good is present instead. If something or some work has to be useful, there should be a positive тАЩasтАЩ (present) quality associated with it. Just because something bad went away, it does not mean that something good came by. Just because a banana leaf is cleaned well with water, it does not mean that the tongue tasted good food and the stomach became full. A banana leaf becomes useful if and only if there are various palatable eatables on it. Similarly, an unattached mind should attain yoga. Yoga means one thing joining another. When a j─лva joins the Supreme ─Бtm─Б, it becomes yoga. Nirlepa-karma-yoga is that by which an unattached mind or a purified mind that has washed off all attachments, performs its ordained duties and gradually merges the j─лva with param─Бtm─Б.

APPENDIX 1

*─к┼ЫvaraтАЩ*s Governance

yad─Б yad─Б hi dharmasya gl─Бnirbhavati bh─Бrata
abhyutth─Бnam adharmasya tad─Бtm─Бnaс╣Г sс╣Ыj─Бmyaham (BG 4.7)
(Whenever dharma decreases and adharma becomes more prominent, I take birth).

paritr─Бс╣З─Бya s─Бdh┼лn─Бс╣Г vin─Б┼Ы─Бya ca duс╣гkс╣Ыt─Бс╣Г
dharmasaс╣Г┼Ыth─Бpan─Бrth─Бya sambav─Бmi yuge yuge (BG 4.8)
(I am born again and again to protect the good, to destroy the evil and to establish dharma).

anany─Б┼Ыcintayanto m─Бс╣Г ye jan─Бс╕е paryup─Бsate
teс╣г─Бс╣Г nity─Бbhiyukt─Бn─Бс╣Г yogakс╣гemaс╣Г vah─Бmyahm (BG 9.22)
(I will take complete care of those who think of me always with no other thought and worship me, and are fully occupied in me).

Anything that exists (sat) can be thought of in four ways -

  1. Parabrahma тАФ this is shapeless, changeless, still, and not subject to expansion. 2. ─к┼Ыvara or Jagad─л┼Ыvara тАФ is an entity related to Brahma that has shape, can change and has activity. It is the energy that rules the universe. 3. Prakс╣Ыti тАФ this is the universe, with name, form and activity. It is under the control of ─к┼Ыvara. 4. J─лva тАФ this is of the form of many living beings of the universe, the individual element of the universe.

Of the above four, the first one does not have any activity. Therefore, we will examine the relationship among the other three.

It is already said that ─к┼Ыvara is related to the universe in the same way as a king is related to a subject in a constitutional monarchy, such as England. Constitutional monarchy is a system of governance where the king and all his subjects are subservient to a known set of rules and arrangements. In such a system, just as common people agree to abide by a set of rules (the constitution, for instance), the king is also bound by the same rules. The king here is not at complete liberty to do as he pleases. Though it does not tie up his hands fully, it sets a limit to his freedom. His official duties are carried out within this limit, and he accepts it.

[[Ch. 4 Yoga of Unattached Karma (Part 9) Source: prekshaa]]

When they ascend the throne, EnglandтАЩs Kings (or Queens) take an oath in front of their subjects that they will follow, preserve, and protect the traditional methods and rules of governance. In India, the President who is in place of the King, takes this oath while swearing in тАФ тАЬI will, to the best of my ability, preserve, protect and defend the Constitution and the law.тАЭ (Art. 60) Thus, even the highest official of the state is subject to the arrangement accepted by the common people.

In Ved─Бnta, ─к┼ЫvaraтАЩs sovereignty over the universe is similar. The system of governance accepted by the all the people is dharma. Dharma is the constitution of the kingdom. ─к┼Ыvara has taken the responsibility of sustaining and maintaining it. In the constitution of dharma, the important sentence is that ─к┼Ыvara is its protector. Thus, in the sustenance of dharma, he is not just an officer, but also the supreme authority. The constitution of dharma gives four responsibilities to ─к┼Ыvara.

  1. Protecting those who follow dharma 2. Punish those who harm dharma 3. Re-establishment of dharma, whenever the situation demands it 4. Protection of the distressed.

To perform the first two of the above tasks тАФ that is protection of dh─Бrmics and punishing the adh─Бrmics, ─к┼Ыvara has appointed other functionaries. They are deities such as Indra, Agni, Yama, Varuс╣Зa, and V─Бyu. The deities of different karmas, deities of different directions, planets and stars are such officers. Generally, they protect the dharma of the world. They protect and encourage the dh─Бrmics of the world, and punish adh─Бrmics appropriately. ─к┼Ыvara, the overlord of the universe, supervises their work. Thus, ─к┼Ыvara does not have to get into the daily activities of the world. For day-to-day activities, dharma-┼Ы─Бstra is the law. Various deities take the responsibility of maintaining law and order. ─к┼Ыvara is just the supervising head in relation to them. Ordinarily, ─к┼Ыvara himself is actionless.

Similarly, even in our current system of governance, the king is a neutral entity. Walter Bagehot, an English political scientist avers that the most excellent quality of an English king is his wise inaction. The fundamental concept here is that the King can do no wrong. This does not mean that there are no mistakes in polity. Mistakes may happen; their responsibility does not rest with the king but with the minister whose duty it is to advise the king on various political matters. That is, the minister becomes responsible for all political damage; this is the peculiarity of the English political setup. This is the meaning behind the phrase “responsible government”.

Thus, even though much of the day-to-day administration is the responsibility of the minister, the system leaves some special rights and offices тАФ prerogatives тАФ to the King. Inviting the parliament and dismissing it, taking up the reins of administration during conflict, pardoning those who have been condemned to severe punishment тАУ all these are the kingтАЩs prerogatives.

The same applies to the rule of ─к┼Ыvara. Among the above four dh─Бrmic duties of a king, punishing the evil and protecting the good generally fall under the umbrella of the duties of various other deities of the world. The other two тАФ re-establishing dharma and being compassionate towards the weak тАФ are the prerogatives of ─к┼Ыvara. In this world and the otherworld, various deities of the karmas mete out rewards and punishments to humans for their deeds тАУ meritorious or otherwise.

However, the good may become weak and evil may become all-powerful at certain times. When evil reigns, the powers of the lesser deities will not be enough to sustain the world. Such times call for the direct descent of ─к┼Ыvara himself. The below lines proclaim this.

yad─Б yad─Б hi dharmasya gl─Бnirbhavati bh─Бrata
abhyutth─Бnam adharmasya tad─Бtm─Бnaс╣Г sс╣Ыj─Бmyaham (BG 4.7)

Keeping this in mind, Arjuna praised Bhagav─Бn as “┼Ы─Б┼Ыvata-dharma-gopt─Б” (BG 11.18)

Terrible actions such as wars become necessary to re-establish san─Бtana dharma and to destroy evil in the world. ─к┼Ыvara arranges, harmonizes and arbitrates such occasions. Thus, protecting dharma by multifarious means falls in the field of the rightful duties of ─к┼Ыvara.

In the same way, giving succour to the distressed, showing affection to the miserable, the protection of those who are seeking it are all the charge of ─к┼Ыvara. In our world, in a political setup like that of England (even in India), it is the authority of the throne to discuss with ministers and grant amnesty if a citizen sentenced to harsh punishment repents and begs for it. In a similar way, it is ─к┼ЫvaraтАЩs duty to show compassion to the devotees who are begging for protection, so that there is no laxity in the rule of dharma, and in a way that encourages dharma. This mercy of the divine cannot be construed as partiality and criticised as haughtiness. The divine is not merciless and unjust. Instead, it has kindness and affection that fosters dharma. This is why Bhagav─Бn is

gatirbhart─Б prabhuс╕е s─Бkс╣г─л niv─Бsaс╕е ┼Ыaraс╣Зaс╣Г suhс╣Ыt (BG 9.18)
(The resource, provider, Lord, witness, abode, refuge and friend)

[[Ch. 4 Yoga of Unattached Karma (Part 10) Source: prekshaa]]

APPENDIX 2

Distinction between karma and akarma

karmaс╣Зo hy-api boddhavyam boddhavyam ca vikarmaс╣Зaс╕е
akarmaс╣Зa┼Ы-ca boddhavyaс╣Г gahan─Б karmaс╣Зo gatiс╕е (BG 4.17)

The discussion on karma and akarma is so deep that it baffles even the wise, says Bhagav─Бn. What does that imply? Simply that the responsibility of a man is great and that it should translate into sad-asad-viveka – discernment between right and wrong, truth and falsehood. Thus it becomes oneтАЩs duty to use his viveka and independently undertake due consideration. We have to keep this in mind carefully.

Akarma is that action which is not ordained for us. Karma that is beyond our capability and propriety is akarma for us. Bhagav─БnтАЩs opinion is that this should be examined carefully.

akarmaс╣Зa┼Ыca boddhavyaс╣Г

The inference is that we should also know the karma that we should not perform. This is the subtle precept in the theory of karma.

A particular karma may be highly valued in the world; it may be recommended to us by society and the learned. It is left for us to decide whether it is right for us to perform it.

Going on a pilgrimage to Kedarnath and Badrinath has been believed to be a great virtuous accomplishment for aeons. But eighty or ninety- year old men and women should decide whether it is karma or akarma for them. Deciding it for them is difficult for others.

Suppose the head of a family is suffering from a terrible disease. Someone then instructs his wife to observe certain austerities for two weeks in a far off pilgrim centre to propitiate the divine and to gain longevity for her husband. Whether it is karma for her to stay with her husband during this time or travel to a far-off place is something she has to decide for herself.

Thus, karma for Rama may become akarma for Bhima. And something that is akarma for Shyama may be karma for Soma. Here, it is impossible to have one rule that holds for all circumstances. Therefore, individual responsibility plays a major role. No one can escape responsibility by disregarding viveka and arguing, “I did it because he told me,” “I trusted Bhagav─Бn and did it,” and “I believed my guruтАЩs blessings and did it.” Devotees who follow the bhakti tradition should be careful about this. They usually say, “Bhagav─Бn will take care of everything; we do not have any responsibility”. These are not the words of those who have understood the distinction between karma and akarma.

Bhagav─Бn gives results. Humans put forth the effort. Is the effort right? Is it adequate? These are the questions that are in front of us. We should always have this sense of personal responsibility.

karmaс╣Зy-akarma yaс╕е pa┼Ыyet akarmaс╣Зi ca karma yaс╕е
sa buddhim─Бn manuс╣гyeс╣гu sa yuktaс╕е kс╣Ыtsna-karma-kс╣Ыt (BG 4.18)

This means that we have to see karma in akarma and akarma in karma, and that this is the mark of a wise man. What is akarma? Akarma may mean two things тАФ

  1. Not performing any activity implying karmalopa or delinquency in oneтАЩs duty 2. Performing activities but remaining aloof from it, as though no activity is being performed тАФ karma-phala-virakti тАФ disinterested in the fruits (results) of karma.

The second meaning is implied here, not the first. Bhagav─БnтАЩs opinion is never to give up karma. This is made clear in many other verses тАФ

m─Б te saс╣Еgos-tv-akarmaс╣Зi (BG 2.47)

yaj├▒a-d─Бna-tapaс╕е-karma na ty─Бjyaс╣Г k─Бryam-eva tat (BG 18.5)

Therefore, we have to read the meaning of this dictum as giving up the desire for the results of action, as given in (2). P─Бpa does not affect one who performs all his various ordained, rightful and dh─Бrmic duties, but does not worry about their results, as though he is not performing them at all. His karma does not shackle him.

j├▒─Бn─Бgniс╕е sarva-karm─Бс╣Зi bhasmas─Бt kurute tath─Б (BG 4.37)

─Бtmavantaс╣Г na karm─Бс╣Зi nibadhnanti dhana├▒jaya (BG 4.41)

karmaс╣Зy-akarma yaс╕е pa┼Ыyet akarmaс╣Зi ca karma yaс╕е (BG 4.18)

These are some of the greatest and most important words in the G─лt─Б. Akarma may mean two things, therefore we have to be careful in grasping the meaning.

In тАЬm─Б te saс╣Еgos-tv-akarmaс╣Зi,тАЭ akarma means giving up karma entirely. This is not right. Another akarma тАФ where desire for the fruit of the karma is given up тАФ is implied.

“karmaс╣Зy-akarma” means that one has to perform his duties, but remain aloof as though he is not doing anything, meaning that he should remain neutral towards the good or bad consequences of his actions. He should work hard, but not feel that he is tired, or that he did not get to taste the sweet fruit of his labour.

тАЬAkarmaс╣Зi ca karmaтАЭ means that one has to take a giving-up attitude towards the results of action. This is interesting. Doing oneтАЩs duties is karma, akarma namely giving up even the thought of its results is itself another karma.

Desire to perform karma, but disinterestedness in its results тАФ that, then, is the prescription. Akarma in the form of giving up the desire for results while performing ordained karma, karma in the form of disinterestedness while giving up the results of karma.

While performing karma, giving up the ownership and desire for the results becomes akarma. While giving up such desire (which is akarma), the act of giving up itself becomes karma. Thus, тАЬkarmaс╣Зy-akarmaтАЭ and тАЬakarmaс╣Зi ca karma.тАЭ

A cook in a hotel cooks food for customers, that is his karma. He does not worry about who is eating the food prepared by him. That is akarma. A customer who visits the hotel eats the food. That is his karma. It is akarma for him to inquire about the person who cooked the food. Thus, akarma within karma and karma within akarma тАФ perform duties diligently but be unconcerned about the results тАФ this is the principle.

APPENDIX 3

Rains, Crops and Deities

ann─Бd-bhavanti bh┼лt─Бni parjany─Бd-anna-sambhavaс╕е
yaj├▒─Бd-bhavati parjanyo yaj├▒aс╕е karma-samudbhavaс╕е (BG 3.14)

The divinities of the world do not provide rains and crops only to those who perform yaj├▒as. They are generous. If one propitiates them, they become helpful to the entire mankind. If there is even one virtuous man in the village, the entire village is benefited by the results of his good deeds.

The implication of this teaching is that one has to enjoy the benefit obtained by the performance of yaj├▒a by sharing it with everyone, even though he has earned it alone. What does it really mean? Even though a deity gives some bounty as a boon to someone who has performed various virtuous actions, even others have the right to partake of it. The performer of yaj├▒a is not the lone beneficiary of the received boon. Everyone who is with him would have helped him in some or the other way, however small or big. If not in a positive, encouraging way, they would at least have helped him negatively by not harming the venture, by not creating obstacles in his way! Therefore, they also have the right to enjoy the boon received in a yaj├▒a.

Thus, the specious argument whether a non-performer of a yaj├▒a obtains its benefits or not, falls flat. There must be at least some virtuous people. A part of the fruits of their virtuous actions are obtained by everyone тАФ this shows the greatness of virtuous deeds. The good performed by one brings welfare to everyone.

andu naraс╣Еg─Х yuddhamukhadoс╕╗ paratattvaс╣Г peс╕╗du lokak─Бс╣Г
bandap─Хnann─Хyoddhatara duс╣гс╣нara daс╣Зс╕Нisi s─Бdhuvс╣Ыndak─Б-
nandavanittu ┼Ы─Б┼Ыvatada dharmava saс╣Гsthitagaiven─Хс╣Гda go-
vindan─Х n─лnadaс╣Г mar─Хte-yenadaninnumadek─Х b─Бre b─лradiс╣Г?
O Govinda, once upon a time, at the commencement of a fight,
You instructed Nara on the Supreme Principle, and proclaimed
That you will appear in this world to punish the evil,
To gladden the good, and establish dharma.
Have you forgotten that promise?
Why do not you appear now with all your might?

The Essence

Having performed karma, the j├▒─Бn─л (the knower) gives up its result.

When might a planter of a coconut palm see its fruit? Whoever plants the tree is different from one who takes care of it. Yet another is he who enjoys its fruits. The planter plants the tree for the good of the people. Just as the seed of p─Бpa is in oneтАЩs nature, so is the seed of puс╣Зya. The G─лt─БтАЩs message is to amplify this virtuous aspect.

Internal equanimity and an external sense of distinction are the two parts of the maxim for world welfare. The care a mother provides at home depends on the age and health of her children. If she insists upon external equality and gives food meant for a sixteen-year old to a sixteen-month old, it would not cause well-being but quite the opposite of it. Those politicians who shout, тАЬEquality, EqualityтАЭ till their throats go hoarse would do well to remember that there is an appropriate place for the principle of distinction in our lives.

Chapter 5 / Section 6

Yoga of Harmony of Action and Wisdom (Karma-j├▒─Бna-s─Бmarasya-yoga) or Saс╣Гny─Бsa-yoga

This is a small chapter but distills the essence of the G─лt─Б. It deals mainly with the following five topics тАУ

  1. Synergy between steadfastness in action and steadfastness in knowledge 2. The state of mind needed for action 3. The inactivity of the Self 4. Practising the presence of the Self everywhere 5. A yogiтАЩs adherence to welfare of the world

Arjuna saw an inconsistency in Bhagav─БnтАЩs words in the fourth chapter. тАЬKс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa, you once extolled the renunciation of action. Then you praised the yoga of action. (This is an indication of mutual opposition between yoga and renunciation).

┼Ыrey─Бn dravya-may─Бd-yaj├▒─Бt-j├▒─Бna-yaj├▒aс╕е parantapa
sarvaс╣Г karm─Бkhilaс╣Г p─Бrtha j├▒─Бne parisam─Бpyate (BG 4.33)
(More excellent than the yaj├▒a of material objects is the yaj├▒a of knowledge. All this action, O P─Бrtha, finds fulfillment in knowledge)

You said on one occasion, тАЬAll action concludes in the knowledge of the Self. On another occasion, you said,

tasm─Бd-aj├▒─Бna-sambh┼лtaс╣Г hс╣Ыtsthaс╣Г j├▒─Бn─Бsin─Бtmanaс╕е
chittvainaс╣Г saс╣Г┼Ыayaс╣Г yogam-─Бtiс╣гс╣нhottiс╣гс╣нha bh─Бrata (BG 4.42)
(Therefore, having rent asunder the doubt arisen out of ignorance with the sword of knowledge, attain yoga, O Bh─Бrata)

This was said earlier тАУ тАЬBe steady in the yoga of action; arise for battle!тАЭ

Both of these are your own statements. What is your conclusion in this matter? If the knowledge of reality is the supreme benefit of action and actions have to be performed to attain this knowledge, is it not established that there is no need for action after attaining knowledge? In other words, renunciates do not have to perform any action, right? Saс╣Гny─Бsa or renunciation is without karma or action. Karma-yoga has karma in it. So which one is greater тАУ karma or saс╣Гny─Бsa?тАЭ This was the question to which the fifth chapter proceeded as an answer.

saс╣Гny─Бsaс╕е karma-yoga┼Ы-ca niс╕е┼Ыreyasakar─Бvubhau
tayostu karma-saс╣Гny─Бs─Бt-karma-yogo vi┼Ыiс╣гyate (BG 5.2)
(Both karma-yoga and saс╣Гny─Бsa yield supreme welfare. Of them, however, the yoga of action is superior to the renunciation of action)

This was Bhagav─БnтАЩs answer: тАЬBoth the yoga of renunciation and the yoga of action yield the best of benefits. However, the yoga of action is special.тАЭ

Saс╣Гny─Бsa is renunciation or giving up. Yoga is joining one object to another. What does it mean to give up action? What does the тАЬjoiningтАЭ or the тАЬyogaтАЭ of giving up mean? It is clear from the word-meanings that both do not refer to the same thing. Bhagav─Бn clarifies that saс╣Гny─Бsa is different from yoga not just by sound, but even by meaning тАУ тАЬkarma-yogo vi┼Ыiс╣гyateтАЭ. The uniqueness of karma-yoga is that it is a prerequisite to s─Бс╣Еkhya or the knowledge of reality, which is the ultimate goal of saс╣Гny─Бsa as well.

saс╣Гny─Бsas-tu mah─Бb─Бho duс╕еkham-─Бptum-ayogataс╕е
yoga-yukto munir-brahma na cireс╣З─Бdhigacchati (BG 5.6)

Here yoga refers to karma-yoga. Without karma-yoga, it is nigh impossible to attain renunciation. O strong-armed one! With karma-yoga, however, it will not take long for the seeker to attain the knowledge of Brahman.

Who is a Saс╣Гny─Бsin?

Are all those who wear saffron robes, shave their heads, and give up rituals saс╣Гny─Бsins? It has been said earlier (3.6) that it is not so. If one renounces out of haste, not only does one become ineligible to perform action but will also not automatically qualify for knowledge.

na karmaс╣З─Бm-an─Бrambh─Бn-naiс╣гkarmyaс╣Г puruс╣гoтАЩ┼Ыnute
na ca saс╣Гnyasan─Бd-eva siddhiс╣Г samadhigacchati (BG 3.4)

The same is repeated later as well.

тАж.saс╣Гny─Бs─лтАж.na niragnirna c─Бkriyaс╕е
(One does not become a saс╣Гny─Бs─л just by giving up agnihotra and other rituals).

The characteristic of a true saс╣Гny─Бs─л is this

j├▒eyaс╕е sa nitya-saс╣Гny─Бs─л yo na dveс╣гс╣нi na k─Б┼Иkс╣гati (BG 5.3)

тАЬHe, who neither hates nor desires, is known always as a saс╣Гny─Бs─лтАЭ. The feeling of indifference that is implied in the phrase тАУ тАЬna dveс╣гс╣нi na k─Б┼Иkс╣гatiтАЩтАЩ is not one of mere co-existence. Consider a couple of bus or train passengers who do not know each other. Their mutual co-existence is indicative of тАЬna dveс╣гс╣нi na k─Б┼Иkс╣гatiтАЭ тАУ a negative feeling. Bhagav─Бn shows how to add a positive dimension to it of the root form тАШas.тАЩ

labhante brahma-nirv─Бс╣Зam-с╣Ыс╣гayaс╕е kс╣г─лс╣Зa-kalmaс╣г─Бс╕е
chinna-dvaidh─Б yat─Бtm─Бnaс╕е sarva-bh┼лta-hite rat─Бс╕е (BG 5.25)

The с╣Ыс╣гis, being cleansed of all impurities, having extinguished all doubts, and endowed with definite knowledge, are engaged in the welfare of all beings.

The present series is a modern English translation of DVGтАЩs Kendra Sahitya Akademi Award-winning work, Bhagavad-g─лt─Б-t─Бtparya or J─лvana-dharma-yoga. The translators wish to express their thanks to ┼Ъat─Бvadh─Бni R Ganesh for his valuable feedback and to Hari Ravikumar for his astute edits.

[[Ch. 5 Yoga of Harmony of Karma and J├▒─Бna (Part 2) Source: prekshaa]]

The phrase hita-nirata (engaged in welfare) does not involve merely uttering homilies. It means those who internally resolve to act towards universal welfare and ensure that those resolutions are acted upon externally. It is thus not necessary for a saс╣Гny─Бsin to give up activity that yields in the well-being of the world. But such activities have to be performed with an extraordinary mindset. The activity referred to here is interacting with the world тАУ taking from the world and giving back to it. It is but natural for mental modifications such as desire and anger and greed and delusion to creep in during such activities. The one who performs activities free of these mental agitations is the true saс╣Гny─Бsin.

It is important to keenly examine the words used in this verse. Saс╣Гny─Бsins are chinna-dvaidh─Б, they whose dvaidh─Б or doubt is torn asunder. When asked, тАЬDoes the divine exist?тАЭ, a few answer in the words of a famous agnostic [Joseph Ernest Renan] тАУ тАЬO God, (if there is a God), save my soul (if I have a soul).тАЭ This is doubt. There is no desire to believe but no courage to give up belief as well. This dvaidh─лbh─Бva (feeling of doubt) is like a pendulum oscillating between belief and disbelief. Saс╣Гny─Бsins are devoid of these feelings of uncertainty. What answer did Ramakrishna Paramahamsa give Swami Vivekananda in his pre-monastic state when asked if God existed? тАЬYesтАЭ. When again asked, тАЬCan you show meтАЭ?, the Paramahamsa replied, тАЬYes, certainly!тАЭ Saс╣Гny─Бsins thus possess definite knowledge. Moreover, they are тАШyat─Бtm─Бnaс╕етАЩ - those who have their minds under control. Will not arrogance arise with definite knowledge? Saс╣Гny─Бsins do not just have control over themselves but are also sarvabh┼лtahite rat─Бс╕е (engaged in the welfare of all beings). They do not sit idle twiddling their thumbs but strive for the welfare of all. One should take note of the word hita (welfare) here. The word sukha (pleasure) could have been used, but it was not. All that is pleasing does not result in well-being. The purport is to engage in activities that ultimately result in well-being.

Sarva-bh┼лt─Бtma-bh┼лtatva (Being the Self of all Beings)

Saс╣Гny─Бsins engage in action for the welfare of the world. They are not bound by it because they are without ego and are indifferent to opposites such as pleasure and pain.

yogayukto vi┼Ыuddh─Бtm─Б vijit─Бtm─Б jitendriyaс╕е
sarvabh┼лt─Бtmabh┼лt─Бtm─Б kurvannapi na lipyate (BG 5.7)

His self is the Self of all beings. He considers the sorrow and happiness of all beings as his own. Such a j├▒─Бn─л desires for the rest of the world the same contentment that he pursues. The j─лva must be elevated. Remember the pleasure we get when we lazily stretch our limbs. That pleasure does not necessarily indicate hita (well-being). However, the sound sleep that we get after a dayтАЩs hard work is not just sukha (pleasure) but also indicates hita (well-being). The work of uplifting a j─лva is hita. The saс╣Гny─Бsin experiences the Self of all beings within himself. Who can be a rival or enemy to him who is all? The Self is uniform and is everywhere. Therefore there is no room for partiality, affection or for envy and infatuation. But how does this тАЬbeing the Self of all beingsтАЭ come to our mind? How can our intellect understand it? How can we experience it every moment? Experience is greater than knowledge. Our contemplation should be such that we should become one with the object of our contemplation. The eight siddhis[aс╣Зim─Б, laghim─Б, mahim─Б, garim─Б, pr─Бpti, pr─Бk─Бmya, ─л┼Ыitva, and va┼Ыitva] or attainments such as aс╣Зim─Б (the ability to become atomic in size) are achievable by means of haс╣нha-yoga. But this state of sarva-bh┼лt─Бtma-bh┼лt─Бtm─Б (being the Self of all beings) is beyond all such siddhis and is possible only through much refinement.

Asaс╣Еgakarma (Action without Attachment)

k─Бyena manas─Б buddhy─Б kevalairindriyairapi
yoginaс╕е karma kurvanti saс╣Еgaс╣Г tyaktv─Бtma┼Ыuddhaye (BG 5.11)

Yogis perform action through their body, mind, intellect, the sensory and motor organs. How? тАЬSaс╣Еgaс╣Г tyaktv─БтАЭ (by giving up attachment). Two points are important here тАУ

  1. If an action has to be performed well, the performer has to be a j├▒─Бn─л. 2. All the faculties of knowledge and action must unite during an action.

It is only then that the body becomes capable. Not even a single organ must slacken. All organs must be effective, attentive, and firm. It was therefore that ┼Ъr─л-Vidy─Бraс╣Зya said,

j├▒─Бnin─Б carituс╣Г ┼Ыakyaс╣Г samyagr─Бjy─Бdilaukikam
тАФPa├▒cada┼Ы─л 9.114
(It is possible for a j├▒─Бn─л to effectively discharge worldly actions such as administering a kingdom).

As the knower of the Self is not selfish, all the actions he performs are effective. Why do yogis act? тАЬ─Аtma┼ЫuddhayeтАЭ тАУ for the purification of the mind. The same idea is conveyed in the tenth verse.

brahmaс╣Зy─Бdh─Бya karm─Бс╣Зi saс╣Еgaс╣Г tyaktv─Б karoti yaс╕е
lipyate na sa p─Бpena padmapatramiv─Бmbhas─Б (BG 5.10)

Action must be performed, but should be offered to Brahma. There must be no expectations such as тАУ тАЬThis work will yield me profit or bring me fame.тАЭ Demerit will not bind him who has no such expectations and calculations during action. It might be asked, тАЬAny activity is naturally associated with selfishness. How could that not affect a j├▒─Бn─л?тАЭ The answer is тАЬpadmapatramiv─Бmbhas─БтАЭ (like a lotus leaf in water). A cloth gets wet when dipped in water. Even though a lotus leaf originates, sustains itself, and falls away in water, moisture never sticks to it. A j├▒─Бn─л lives in the world just like the lotus leaf in water. He participates in all of its pleasures and sorrows but is internally unchanged.

yoтАЩntaс╕еsukhoтАЩntar─Бr─Бmas-tath─Бntarjyotireva yaс╕е
sa yog─л brahmairv─Бс╣Зaс╣Г brahmabh┼лtoтАЩdhigacchati (BG 5.24)

A j├▒─Бn─л resolves thus тАУ тАЬPrakс╣Ыti causes everything. It does not affect me.тАЭ

The poet Lucretius observed тАУ тАЬThe bystander on the sea-shore is happy when he sees fishermen struggle to catch fish. On the one hand, he is entertained by witnessing their adventures. On the other, he is relieved that he is not undergoing that hardship.тАЭ The j├▒─Бn─л, much like this bystander, witnesses the actions of the world without any anxiety.

[[Ch. 5 Yoga of Harmony of Karma and J├▒─Бna (Part 3) Source: prekshaa]]

The Steadfastness in Yoga of a J├▒─Бn─л

yuktaс╕е karmaphalaс╣Г tyaktv─Б ┼Ы─Бntim─Бpnoti naiс╣гс╣нhik─лm
ayuktaс╕е k─Бmak─Бreс╣Зa phale sakto nibadhyate (BG 5.12)

The word тАЬyuktaтАЭ here means yoked or harnessed to yoga or being steadfast in yoga. A j├▒─Бn─л, having performed action, gives up its fruit. We realise quite soon that it is not easy to do so. But it is not that rare either. When can a planter of a coconut palm see its fruit? The planter of the tree is different from the caretaker who is again other than the enjoyer of the fruit. The planter plants the tree for the good of the people. Just as the seed of p─Бpa is in our nature, the seed of puс╣Зya too is within us. The intent of the G─лt─Б is in amplifying this tendency for good in us. The goodness within us must be expanded. The one who does that obtains peace from being steadfast (тАЬ┼Ы─Бntim─Бpnoti naiс╣гс╣нhik─лmтАЭ). тАЬNaiс╣гс╣нhik─лmтАЭ refers to that which results from niс╣гс╣нh─Б (being established in something). Just as it is said elsewhere тАУ

tanniс╣гс╣нhasya mokс╣гopade┼Ы─Бt
тАФBrahma-s┼лtra 1.1.7
(Mokс╣гa or final liberation is declared for one who is established in It).

Tranquillity results from being fully established in something. One has to be devoted or be established in at least one thing. Partial trust in ─Аyurveda, and believing a little in Unani or allopathy is how our belief is usually spread across different things. The one who is not established in yoga тАЬk─Бmak─Бreс╣Зa phale sakto nibadhyateтАЭ is bound because he is attached to the fruit of acting according to his desire. Such a person acts differently in every moment according to his whims. тАШK─Бmak─БraтАЩ (acting according to oneтАЩs whims) is the opposite of being established in yoga. That indeed is deviating from the right path. One who acts according to his caprices cannot attain tranquillity. His interest is only in the fruit of the moment. His тАШniс╣гс╣нh─БтАЩ or steadiness is in a flux and he thus attains no peace. He is then тАШnibadhyateтАЩ тАУ bound by his actions.

The Meaning of the Word Karma

The word тАШkarmaтАЩ has multiple meanings. There is no reason to single out sat-karma (good karma) here. The phrase тАЬbrahmaс╣Зy─Бdh─БyaтАЭ (surrendering in Brahma) is used here. There can be no тАЬduс╣гkarmaтАЭ (bad karma) during the remembrance of Brahma. Good karma can be of two kinds тАУ scriptural or ┼Ы─Бstr─лya works and worldly works. ┼Ъ─Бstr─лya works pertain to those rituals such as yaj├▒as and y─Бgas that are prescribed in the ┼Ыruti or smс╣Ыti. Both ┼Ы─Бstr─лya and worldly actions are referred to by the word karma. All of this karma has to be surrendered to Brahma. The remembrance of Brahma must pervade all these works. There must be no trace of personal desire. The one who does that - lipyate na sa p─Бpena - is not tainted by demerit. Demerit accrues in the presence of ego. Therefore тАЬsaс╣Еgaс╣Г tyaktv─БтАЭ (abandoning attachment) has been used to qualify the performance of action - specifically, abandoning attachment to тАШmeтАЩ and тАШmineтАЩ. Who then is responsible for the action? тАЬBrahmaс╣Зi ─Бdh─БyaтАЭ тАУ the j├▒─Бn─л delegates all responsibility to Brahm─Б.

The same is expressed in the statement тАУ тАЬyuktaс╕е karmaphalaс╣Г tyaktv─БтАЭ (the one in Yoga having given up the fruit of action). Here тАЬayuktaс╕етАЭ means the one who has not yoked his mind to Bhagav─Бn. тАШK─Бmak─Бreс╣ЗaтАЩ тАУ the one who acts capriciously. Such a person is phale saktaс╕е тАУ interested in the result. He is nibadhyate тАУ bound. What else but bondage can happen to such a person?

Internal Detachment

The thought continues here.

sarvakarm─Бс╣Зi manas─Б saс╣Гnyasy─Бste sukhaс╣Г va┼Ы─л
navadv─Бre pure deh─л naiva kurvanna k─Бrayan (BG 5.13)

By va┼Ы─л is meant one who has control over himself. Such a person is happy. Why? тАЬsarvakarm─Бс╣Зi manas─Б saс╣ГnyasyaтАЭ тАУ having mentally given up all actions. Works have to be performed externally but they have to be renounced internally. This indeed is the essence of the G─лt─Б. However, such renunciation should not result in any lapse in the performance of external action. The non-attachment referred to here is internal. Bhagav─Бn says that it is possible to renounce actions internally without any impact on external action.

We have experienced on occasion that while action happens externally there is no equivalent internal impact. The change of the yaj├▒opav─лta (sacred thread) is such an activity for many of us. During the commencement of a meal, activities such as pariс╣гecana (purifying food by sprinkling water around oneтАЩs food) are similar in nature. Though it is an external activity, it is quite rare for the mind to be involved in such activities. Cyclists routinely putting their feet to pedal is an external activity that, however, does not touch the mind. We should perform action without experiencing mental anguish. We have to practise internal detachment. T─Бс╣нhastya (detachment) refers to standing on the shore. The one on the shore does not get wet. Neither is he concerned with who is bathing or drowning in the waters. Even if he watches it, he has no selfish interest in those. Similarly, external actions do not impact a j├▒─Бn─л.

Man should divide himself into two тАУ the doer and the seer. He should think, тАЬI am the witness. The doer is someone else.тАЭ There are no mental disturbances then. Ego & selfish desires cause mental disturbances.

naiva kiс╣Гcitkarom─лti yukto manyeta tattvavit
pa┼Ыya├▒ ┼Ыruс╣Зvan spс╣Ы┼Ыa├▒-jighrann- a┼Ыnan-gacchan svapan ┼Ыvasan (BG 5.8)
pralapan-visс╣Ыjan-gс╣Ыhс╣Зann-unmiс╣гan-nimiс╣гannapi
indriy─Бс╣З─лndriy─Бrtheс╣гu vartanta iti dh─Бrayan (BG 5.9)

The knower of reality believes that he is not doing anything; but he watches; he listens; he touches various objects; smells different things; walks about, eats, sleeps; attends calls of nature, blinks his eyes and yet does not feel that he is doing anything. But all of these are not Vedic rituals! Are not all of these worldly activities? Indriy─Бс╣З─лndriy─Бrtheс╣гu тАУ sensory organs indulge in what they desire. His mind is not those sense organs. Thinking thus, he surrenders his actions to Brahma (brahmaс╣Зy─Бdh─Бya). He resolves in his mind that he does not do anything.

The Behaviour of the Guс╣Зas

But arenтАЩt all of these world activities happening? Who then is performing all these? We saw it in the third chapter.

tattvavittu mah─Бb─Бho guс╣Зakarmavibh─Бgayoс╕е
guс╣З─Б guс╣Зeс╣гu vartanta iti matv─Б na sajjate (BG 3.28)

The guс╣Зas of the organs engage in the guс╣Зas of the objects. The sensory organs engage in the objects of the external world. The same principle is stated more extensively in the Bс╣Ыhad─Бraс╣Зyakopaniс╣гad 14.6.2.

jihv─Б vai grahaс╕еред sa rasen─Бtigraheс╣Зa gс╣Ыh─лto jihvay─Б hi ras─Бnvij─Бn─Бti ред
v─Бgvai grahaс╕еред sa n─Бmn─БтАЩtigraheс╣Зa gс╣Ыh─лto v─Бc─Б hi n─Бm─Бnyabhivadati ред
cakс╣гurvai grahaс╕еред sa r┼лpeс╣З─Бtigraheс╣Зa gс╣Ыh─лta┼Ыcakс╣гuс╣г─Б hi r┼лp─Бс╣Зi pa┼Ыyati ред
┼Ыrotraс╣Г vai grahaс╕еред sa ┼Ыabden─Бtigraheс╣Зa gс╣Ыh─лtaс╕е ┼Ыrotreс╣Зa hi ┼Ыabd─Б├▒chс╣Ыс╣Зoti ред
mano vai grahaс╕еред sa k─Бmen─Бtigraheс╣Зa gс╣Ыh─лto manas─Б hi k─Бm─Бnk─Бmayate ред
hastau vai grahaс╕еред sa karmaс╣З─Бtigraheс╣Зa gс╣Ыh─лto hast─Бbhy─Бс╣Г hi karma karoti ред
tvagvai grahaс╕еред sa spar┼Ыen─Бtigraheс╣Зa gс╣Ыh─лtastvac─Б hi spar┼Ы─Бnvedayata ityaс╣гс╣нau grah─БтАЩaс╣гс╣н─Бvatigrah─Бс╕еред

The Vedic seers divided the world into grahas and atigrahas. Whatever grasps is known as a graha and whatever is grasped is known as an atigraha. The tongue is a graha; taste is an atigraha. The ear is a graha; sound, music etc. are atigrahas. The ear, eye, and even the mind that controls these are all classified as grahas. All of them captured by k─Бma (desire) that is an atigraha. All sense organs are grahas. The sensations of taste, smell etc., that attract these grahas are atigrahas. Thus the categories graha and atigraha naturally exist in the world, as the products of the primordial prakс╣Ыti. Prakс╣Ыti is ParabrahmaтАЩs power of action. Prakс╣Ыti cannot exist without Brahma. These categories of graha & atigraha are the products of prakс╣Ыti, the power of Brahma. These two engage as well as excite each other. This is our life. The lives of all beings can be summed up as harmony and disharmony between the graha and atigraha. This is our perennial struggle.

[[Ch. 5 Yoga of Harmony of Karma and J├▒─Бna (Part 4) Source: prekshaa]]

The Actionless─Аtm─Б

The whole of creation is thus created from BrahmaтАЩs power, BrahmaтАЩs l─лl─Б. It is enjoying ─Бnanda (bliss) causing all these actions. Why do we call it ─Бnanda? ─Аnanda is the nature of Brahma. Difficulty or pain is not in its nature. Even when we experience distress or sorrow, there is definitely an aspect of its l─лl─Б in them. To the divine, our laughter and tears are like the laughter and tears of children to adults. Therefore in the Rudr─Бdhy─Бya the Supreme is praised as тАЬnama ─Бkkhidate ca prakkhidate caтАЭ (Salutations to the one who causes minor as well as major troubles).

na kartс╣Ыtvaс╣Г na karm─Бс╣Зi lokasya sс╣Ыjati prabhuс╕е
na karmaphalasaс╣Гyogaс╣Г svabh─Бvastu pravartate (BG 5.14)

It cannot be said that since ─к┼Ыvara has created this world, it is better to let him experience it. None of these affect ─к┼Ыvara because he is ─к┼Ыvara (the supreme ruler). The engagements of the world do not affect the Self (─Бtm─Б) who is the indweller of the j─лva, as the former is an aspect of ─к┼Ыvara. However, they affect the j─лva which is the embodied Self. Even the j─лva is the same as the Self, but enveloped by a shroud. The j─лva cries out, тАЬMy shroud is heavy! ItтАЩs heavy!тАЭ When experiencing the тАШheavinessтАЩ of the shroud, the Self is known as the j─лva. But it becomes light when a knower casts off the covering shroud. This state of the j─лva is natural. However, the Self is beyond Nature. ─к┼Ыvara is neither the doer of worldly activities nor is he the one who established this system of causality. But all fundamental components and energies of these universal laws are but minor aspects of his limitless power. It is their actions that constitute worldly events. The relationship between action and their results does not belong to ─к┼Ыvara. Doership, enjoyership, creatorship, and cause тАУ are all in the realm of Prakс╣Ыti (Primordial Nature). It is prakс╣Ыti that makes j─лvas dependent upon her to perform their actions. The state of the j─лva is something that can be remedied; it is not permanent. Mokс╣гa is release from the state of the j─лva. When something that is not the Self envelops the Self, it becomes a j─лva. The non-Self is subject to destruction. It can be removed. We saw in the second chapter:

v─Бs─Бс╣Гsi j─лrс╣З─Бni yath─Б vih─Бya
nav─Бni gс╣Ыhс╣З─Бti naroтАЩpar─Бс╣Зi
tath─Б ┼Ыar─лr─Бс╣Зi vih─Бya j─лrс╣З─Бni
any─Бni saс╣Гy─Бti nav─Бni deh─л (BG 2.22)

Thus, the non-Self can be cast off. The Self, that is the internal sentience of the j─лva, has to be released from this shell of the non-Self. The true nature of the ─Бtm─Б is revealed when this shell is removed. It is thus that Bhagav─Бn said:

navadv─Бre pure deh─л naiva kurvanna k─Бrayan (BG 5.13)

The two eyes, two ears, two nostrils, the mouth, the two nether orifices - together constitute the nine gates (navadv─Бra). Our body is the city with these nine gates. The lord of the city is seated inside these gates. He does not do anything and is much like the constitutional monarch who has delegated all work to ministers and officials. They conduct all the activities under his rule.

The Extent of ArjunaтАЩs Question

We might think that the topic of this chapter is far removed from ArjunaтАЩs question. ArjunaтАЩs question was whether he should fight or not. In the guise of answering his question, Bhagav─Бn instructed him on various topics such as what Prakс╣Ыti is, what Brahma is, what it means to perform action, who the doer is and who the enjoyer is. We feel that this is a digression. When asked about war, Bhagav─Бn talked about the Self and non-Self. How are these even related? The reply is that this particular problem can only be dealt with in this way. There is no foundation other than the discernment between the Self and the non-Self to effectively determine what dharma and adharma are. ArjunaтАЩs question was this тАУ тАЬIs this dharma or adharma? I think this is adharma.тАЭ Krishna replied that this was dharma. On what basis could this question have been settled? What is the testimony? The discernment between the Self and the non-Self is the sole testimony. Arjuna somehow asked this question. But he did not realise the root of this query and how far it reached. His query came in the heat of the discussion. The knowledge of the Self is needed to decide what duty is and is not. We have to then accept the verdict of those who are able to discern between the Self and the non-Self.

The Cessation of Ignorance

J├▒─Бna or knowledge is not something extraneous to a j─лva but intrinsic to it. The nature of the Self is three-fold тАУ Existence, Knowledge, and Bliss (sat, cit, ─Бnanda respectively). This cit is the seed of knowledge. Cit is knowledge, the process of comprehension, and the action that is inspired. All of these are latent in the j─лva from time immemorial. Ignorance masks this knowledge like a wicker-basket (masks a lamp). Because of this, we see the wicker basket and not Brahma.

aj├▒─Бnen─Бvс╣Ыtaс╣Г j├▒─Бnaс╣Г tena muhyanti jantavaс╕е (BG 5.15)

When the cover of ignorance is removed, knowledge arises spontaneously. That is why Bhagav─Бn asks Arjuna to conquer Anger and Desire. The rest happens on its own.

dh┼лmen─Бvriyate vahnir-yath─Бdar┼Ыo malena ca
yatholben─Бvс╣Ыto garbhas-tath─Б tenedam─Бvс╣Ыtam (BG 3.38)

Just as smoke covers burning coal, just as dirt covers a mirror does the natural state of ignorance conceal knowledge. How can we get rid of this ignorance? By practising the presence of the Self (─Бtma-samakс╣гat─Б), which is also the same as practising the presence of the divine.

Samakс╣гat─Б refers to something in front of our eyes - presence. We have to experience the presence of the divine by practising it.

Those that have attained the practice of the presence of the Self have been described thus.

tadbuddhayas-tad─Бtm─Бnas-tanniс╣гс╣нh─Бs-tatpar─Бyaс╣З─Бс╕е
gacchanty-apunar─Бvс╣Ыttiс╣Г j├▒─Бnanirdh┼лtakalmaс╣г─Бс╕е (BG 5.17)

Have we experienced divine presence or not? We can find this out for ourselves. When someone derided as vile or cheap by society comes and sits next to us, what expression does our face take? What does our mind tell us when a person who has wronged us sits next to us? How do we behave when a person of power or fame moves near us? Our mind values all these external distinctions such as status, rank, and prestige. But on the other hand, if all of these persons тАУ who are non-different from the Self тАУ are viewed with the same measure of self-love, we would be practising equality.

All differences must be eschewed. The mind is full of such differences. Whoever realises the presence of the divine has no such differences.

vidy─Бvinayasaс╣Гpanne br─Бhmaс╣Зe gavi hastini
┼Ыuni caiva ┼Ыvap─Бke ca paс╣Зс╕Нit─Бс╕е samadar┼Ыinaс╕е (BG 5.18)
(The knowers of the Self view with equanimity a Brahmin endowed with learning and humility, a cow, an elephant, a dog and him who eats dog flesh.)

[[Ch. 5 Yoga of Harmony of Karma and J├▒─Бna (Part 5) Source: prekshaa]]

The Vision of Equality (Sama-dar┼Ыana)

This is a famous ┼Ыloka. What does тАУ sama-dar┼Ыana - the vision of equality mean? Does equality imply that both the elephant and the cow be offered the same food? The word тАЬequalтАЭ is one of the most misused words of our times. Politicians use this word ad nauseam. It is not uncommon for this word to be used without knowing its actual meaning or with an erroneous understanding. Equality is giving to each being what is best for it. A feast for a Brahmaa and grass for the cow тАУ showing the same love across beings is viewing all equally. Teachers might rebuke a student and reward another with a sweet. This too is equality from the perspective of the studentsтАЩ needs and abilities.

The vision of equality requires two things тАУ the seer and the seen. The well-being of the seen has to result from the seerтАЩs vision of equality. The vision of equality has to conclude in a consideration of the welfare of the seen. A uniform perspective of benefiting all is the vision of equality. This instruction pertains to the sameness of love for all. The same love for all beings finds different expressions based on the needs of its recipients.

What is the relation of equality to this instruction about knowledge? The mark of true knowledge is seeing all with equanimity. The chief characteristic of the seer of the Self is equanimity. He does not hate anybody and has the same love for all. He constantly thinks about the well-being of all, not just about the pleasure of a few. In spiritual matters, well-being is more important than pleasure. It is all fine to help others find pleasure as long as it is not in opposition to their eventual well-being. Pleasure and well-being need to be separated out.

Knowledge and humility together are described as the characteristics of a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa. Seldom are these fine qualities seen together. There are many knowledgeable people but not all of them are humble. Similarly, not all humble persons are scholars. It is rare for knowledge and humility to combine. Arrogance and egoism have to be rooted out from us. The first words of ┼Ъr─л ┼Ъaс╣ЕkaraтАЩs prayer are тАУ

avinayam apanaya viс╣гс╣Зo
тАФс╣вaс╣нpad─л-stotram
(O Viс╣гс╣Зu, take away arrogance)

Humility is тАЬam─Бnitvam-adambhitvamтАЭ (not being arrogant, not being deceitful). Humility is something of a rare quality in a democracy. A humble person gets nothing there. The one desirous of thriving in a democracy has to constantly be a rabble rouser. The squeaky wheel gets the grease. The one without a voice suits a ruined well. If one desirous of living a good life waits for recognition and an invitation from others, he might as well wait forever. Even when nobody wants to listen, hustlers rush forward to claim, тАЬHear me. DonтАЩt listen to others. IтАЩm the only one who can redeem the country; others will despoil it. IтАЩm your only confidante. All others are your enemies. IтАЩm the only truthful one; others are cheats,тАЭ and manage to get good positions. Where is the encouragement for humility in such an environment? The G─лt─Б quoted by politicians and R─Бvaс╣ЗaтАЩs renunciation are the same.

Equanimity is stated in another way.

ihaiva tairjitaс╕е sargo yeс╣г─Бс╣Г s─Бmye sthitaс╣Г manaс╕е
nirdoс╣гaс╣Г hi samaс╣Г brahma tasm─Бd brahmaс╣Зi te sthit─Бс╕е (BG 5.19)

They, whose minds are steadfast in the experience of Brahma that is uniform everywhere, obtain mokс╣гa (or liberation) ihaiva (in this world only). The statement that Brahma is uniform everywhere just means that it is impartial. Not that it appears the same to everybody. Just as the sky is uniform everywhere, Brahma is uniformly omnipresent. It does not have any inequality or cruelty. This is the purport of the statement тАЬ┼Ыuni caiva ┼Ыvap─Бke caтАЭ (in a dog and in a dog-eating caс╣Зс╕Н─Бla). The intent of a j├▒─Бn─л is to do whatever it takes to uplift any j─лva. The intent of upliftment is the same across all beings. What is equality from a judgeтАЩs viewpoint? To give everyone their just due according to the law. We need practice for such a temperament to reside in our minds. Our selfish desires and infatuation must go. As long as these exist within us, this practice of equanimity will not be possible.

┼Ыaknot─лhaiva yaс╕е soс╕Нhuс╣Г pr─Бkс╣гar─лravimokс╣гaс╣З─Бt
k─Бmakrodhodbhavaс╣Г vegaс╣Г sa yuktaс╕е sa sukh─л naraс╕е (BG 5.23)
(One must face the onslaught of Desire and Anger here, while alive. The one who can bear it and win over them is a yogi. He indeed is happy.)

In this chapter, yoga refers to karma-yoga. Yogis are sarvabh┼лtahiterat─Бс╕е (engaged in the welfare of all beings). They experience their own Self everywhere and thus everyone is non-different from their own Self. The practice of welfare for all is an expression of the love for the Self. The practice of omni-welfare is an action too. That action is performed to please Bhagav─Бn.

bhokt─Бraс╣Г yaj├▒atapas─Бс╣Г sarvalokamahe┼Ыvaram
suhс╣Ыdaс╣Г sarvabh┼лt─Бn─Бс╣Г j├▒─Бtv─Б m─Бс╣Г ┼Ы─Бntimс╣Ыcchati (BG 5.29)

This is one of the most beautiful statements that ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa has made about himself. тАЬI am the friend of all beings. I am the protector of all. Perform your duties knowing that I am thereтАЭ. Whom do all our yaj├▒as and other meritorious works and austerities reach? It reaches Bhagav─Бn. Whoever constantly experiences this divine greatness attains tranquility. This statement enables the contemplation of the divine Incarnation.

Reflection upon the Principle of Equality

The G─лt─Б has numerous mentions referring to equality тАУ sama, samat─Б, s─Бmya, sam─Бna, samadar┼Ыi тАУ which have been used in two kinds of meanings that are not opposed to each other but are closely related.

  1. The first meaning is seen in phrases such as тАЬsama-duс╕еkha-sukhaс╣Г dh─лramтАЭ and тАЬsamatvaс╣Г yoga ucyateтАЭ. In these situations, equality refers to an attitude of indifference to opposites such as profit-loss, like-dislike, and friends-enemies. 2. The second meaning can be seen in statements such as тАЬsamaс╣Г sarveс╣гu bh┼лteс╣гuтАЭ and тАЬpaс╣Зс╕Нit─Бс╕е samadar┼Ыinaс╕етАЭ. The purport here is that the Self uniformly exists in all beings.

Both of these meanings have to be considered according to the context.

TilakтАЩs Argument

As ┼Ъaс╣Еkar─Бc─Бrya had criticised the path of action, Bal Gangadhar Tilak endeavoured to establish the primacy of action. Tilak was not interested in re-establishing the a┼Ыvamedha and the v─Бjapeya rituals. He was more concerned with action in this world. ┼Ъaс╣Еkar─Бc─Бrya was not opposed to that either. In fact, ┼Ъaс╣Еkara was least interested in it. From his perspective, nothing needed to be said about worldly action as it was self-evident that everyday action was imperative. ManuтАЩs testimony, that was considered to be of prime importance by ┼Ъaс╣Еkara, is relevant here. ┼Ъaс╣Еkar─Бc─Бrya quotes profusely from Manu. тАЬс╣Ъс╣З─Бni tri─лс╣Зi ap─Бkс╣Ыtya mano mokс╣гe nive┼ЫayetтАЭ (Having paid the three-fold debt, the mind must be engaged in liberation), and others are relevant quotes here. BuddhaтАЩs chief instruction was about moral action. ┼Ъaс╣Еkar─Бc─Бrya insists on fulfilling all these moral prerequisites before holding a Ved─Бnta treatise in oneтАЩs hands. Only those endowed with the wealth of the ┼Ыama-sextet [ ┼Ыama, dama, uparati, ┼Ыraddh─Б, titikс╣г─Б, sam─Бdh─Бna] are qualified for the knowledge of Ved─Бnta . Only those are fit to even touch the G─лt─Б. Therefore ┼Ъaс╣Еkara implicitly agrees that worldly dharma is essential. His issue is only about the rituals of the ┼Ыruti and smс╣Ыti. For us in this era, due to the influence of the times, this is completely irrelevant. Our paс╣Зс╕Нitas repeatedly debate about тАШkarmaтАЩ. Due to this irrelevant debate, this already complicated matter becomes even more complicated. Neither ┼Ъaс╣Еkar─Бc─Бrya nor the other ─Бcharyas have any issue with the fact that worldly dharma has be performed. Even if ┼Ъaс╣Еkar─Бc─Бrya forbids them, those actions will not stop as Bhagav─Бn Krс╣гс╣Зa himself has extolled the performance of karma.

┼Ъaс╣Еkar─Бc─Бrya is chronologically the first amongst the ─Бc─Бryas of the three schools (Advaita, Dvaita and Vi┼Ыiс╣гс╣н─Бdvaita). When he could raise an issue, how could the teachers of the other schools remain quiet without having a say on it? Thus grew this literature of disputation. We can keep that aside.

What is relevant to us is not the question of ┼Ыrauta rituals but that of everyday worldly actions. There are dos and donтАЩts as well as dharma and adharma and virtue and vice in everyday life. Is the G─лt─Б relevant for the issues of everyday life that are out of the pale of Vedic eligibility? If not, the G─лt─Б is a work that stands to become irrelevant with the passage of time and is not worthy of our respect and submission.

[[Ch. 5 Yoga of Harmony of Karma and J├▒─Бna (Part 6) Source: prekshaa]]

The Three Maxims of the Yoga of Action

If we consider the instruction of the G─лt─Б as valuable in all places and at all times, the principles of karmayoga apply to all of us. Why? By karma here is meant not just scriptural and traditional rituals connected to devat─Бs but also all life related activity. Whatever needs to be done to sustain the family тАУ loans and receipts, searches for brides and grooms, squabbles with the in-laws, the good and bad of our neighbourhoods, national and international affairs тАУ all of these are actions as well as duties.

First of all, the decision of what to do and what not to do has to be decided from the vantage point of the inner Self. Secondly, auspicious action is that which leads to the j─лvaтАЩs progress. Thirdly, egoism and hankering after results must be given up in any activity and all actions must be performed as service to Bhagav─Бn. These three rules form the instruction of the fifth chapter.

We discussed the topics of knowledge and liberation. Activity or karma is needed as a prerequisite for j├▒─Бna. Karma persists after the dawn of knowledge, however, as the play of the Self. The jn─Бn─л sees his own Self or divine presence everywhere. Therefore he is able to effortlessly perform any action as a service to Bhagav─Бn. Thus action exists as a prerequisite prior to the dawn of knowledge. Action persists later too. The only difference is that while the former kind is mandatory and of the type of an injunction, the latter is a play and is effortless. Thus action exists both before and after the rise of knowledge.

Usually, faith in the efficacy of action as well as a curiosity for knowledge exist among ─Бstikas*. As knowledge ripens, action recedes. The milk we drink is mixed with water. Even milk directly from a cowтАЩs udder has water content in it. As the milk is heated, however, the proportion of water keeps decreasing while the proportion of milk solids keeps increasing. In khova and such milk products used for making sweets, water content is almost non-existent and milk solids comprise the entire substance. The interaction between karma and j├▒─Бna is similar. As the knowledge of reality matures, the craving for the results of the action reduces. Age and worldly experience could be the reason for this. A mental state where karma is seen solely as external activity might arise. Thus, the hankering after karma gradually reduces while j├▒─Бna, the inner essence of karma, becomes brighter. One fine day, action might be seen as completely unnecessary once knowledge has matured. Karma then automatically falls off. The jn─Бn─л does not voluntarily give up karma, but it leaves him by itself. We are reading a novel lying down. After sometime, sleep overtakes us and we close our eyes. The book in our hands falls off by itself.

suptahastasthapuс╣гpavat..
(Like a flower in the hands of a sleepy person)

What happened then? It is not that faith in karma was lost but that it became unnecessary. When do we need the book? Till we are able to memorize it. Once we know it by heart and are able to recite its contents on demand, what is the need for the book? The performance of karma is like the book. Karma is for the attainment of j├▒─Бna. The book is also for attaining knowledge. As more knowledge is acquired, the book and karma become irrelevant.

A note of caution, however. Have we really attained j├▒─Бna? Let us first ensure that. It is safer to perform karma assuming that we have not attained knowledge rather than renouncing it with the assumption that we have attained knowledge.

Gist

APPENDIX

Controversy with Schools of Philosophy

The following verses from the fifth chapter are worth remembering.

s─Бс╣Еkhyayogau pс╣Ыthagb─Бl─Бс╕е pravadanti na paс╣Зс╕Нit─Бс╕е
ekamapy─Бsthitaс╕е samyagubhayorvindate phalam (BG 5.4)
yats─Бс╣Еkhyaiс╕е pr─Бpyate sth─Бnaс╣Г tadyogairapi gamyate
ekaс╣Г s─Бс╣Еkhyaс╣Г ca yogaс╣Г ca yaс╕е pa┼Ыyati sa pa┼Ыyati (BG 5.5)

Bhagav─Бn opines that the distinction between the followers of s─Бс╣Еkhya and yoga is not worth consideration for a seeker.

тАЬOnly the childish think of s─Бс╣Еkhya and yoga as different. The knowers do not differentiate between them. Following either one well ensures that the fruit of both is attained.

тАЬWhatever position is attained by the s─Бс╣Еkhya is attained by the yogis as well. He who sees s─Бс╣Еkhya and yoga as one is the one who really sees reality.тАЭ

This point is crucial for our country in these times. The poisonous element in our society is inter-religious and sectarian strife. The above verses show that sectarianism is bad and harmful.

The above words are good advice not just for dvait─Бdvaita controversies but for conflicts between the votaries of ┼Ъiva, Viс╣гс╣Зu, ┼Ъakti and other deities as well.

Not just that. The rivalries seen between Hinduism, Christianity, Islam and other local and foreign religions can also be answered well by the above verses.

The destination is one but the paths are many. The wayfarer chooses his path according to his aptitude and strength.

The contention amongst Dvaita, Advaita and other schools of philosophy will be discussed in detail in the appendix of the book.

[[Ch. 6 The Practice of Dhy─Бna (Part 1) Source: prekshaa]]

Note

saс╣Гnyasipudu karmaphalavano karmavanoред
enaс╣Г karmadoс╕╖illaс╣Г

Saс╣Гny─Бsa makes one fit for knowledge
What should we give up, karma or its fruit?
Karma itself is pure, faultless.
It only becomes impure by the feeling of тАШIтАЩ.

sv─Бntada ┼Ыodhan├йyappudu

antanta┼Ы┼Ыodhitadai-

The mind is refined

By contemplating within,

Summary

Not having any desire for oneтАЩs own profit is Saс╣Гny─Бsa. Working in a righteous way for riches, wishing for pleasure and coveting success are all suitable for householders. Even if oneтАЩs duties are performed with intended personal benefit, they can eventually bring about selflessness. Whether this is a worldly karma or a religious one, whether it is selfish or not тАФ it turns the mind towards the divine if it does not violate dharma. Various experiences gained during the course of life because of constant contact with the world shake and jolt the j─лva, make it wander about, and exhaust it. Finally they bring about the realisation about the limited value of the world, the plight of pleasures, and the bounds of human effort.

The G─лt─Бc─Бrya does not prescribe severe austerities that affect bodily functions. He says that all activities should be within permissible limits. S─Бdhan─Б should not affect efficiency in action and peace of mind.

Dhy─Бna-yoga is fixing the mind upon the principle of the ─Бtm─Б. It is impossible to understand the Bhagavad-G─лt─Б without dhy─Бna. Knowledge gained from mere study of books is incomplete. Complete knowledge is gained from oneтАЩs own experience and the practice of ─Бtmaupamya.

Different births of a j─лva are just like chapters in a single novel. One who wants to study the progression of a j─лva should see the various accounts of different births as the uninterrupted flow of a river. Different streams join this river тАФ clear and pure streams as well as waters turbid with sewage. The river becomes cleaner and clearer as it progresses. Thus, the flow of small streams also becomes meaningful. Similarly, even a little effort in the right direction will not go waste.

Chapter 6. Dhy─Бna-yoga or Dhy─Бnabhy─Бsa-yoga

In the previous chapter was enunciated karma-j├▒─Бna-s─Бmarasya тАФ that karma and j├▒─Бna are harmonious n with each other. In this chapter will be described dhy─Бna, an activity that, with satkarma, helps in attaining j├▒─Бna.

There are ten important points discussed in this chapter:

  1. Relationship between saс╣Гny─Бsa and yoga 2. Importance of human self-effort 3. How j├▒─Бna (knowledge) and vij├▒─Бna (experiential wisdom) are essential to each other 4. The method of dhy─Бna 5. The proper limit for food and enjoyment 6. Tranquility 7. The practice of ─Аtmaupamya or considering the universe as an extension of oneтАЩs own self 8. Accomplishment by practice 9. Even a little practice does not go waste 10. The excellence of performing dhy─Бna

The Relationship between Saс╣Гny─Бsa and Yoga

We might remember that earlier we examined the question of the nature of a saс╣Гny─Бs─лn. The answer to that is now given with certainty.

an─Б┼Ыritaс╕е karma-phalaс╣Г k─Бryaс╣Г karma karoti yaс╕е
sa saс╣Гny─Бs─л ca yog─л ca na niragnir-na c─Бkriyaс╕е (BG 6.1)

Who is a saс╣Гny─Бs─л ? Not one who has given up yaj├▒a and other fire sacrifices^(^([1])) and other dh─Бrmic activities like d─Бna, but one who performs his duties without any desire for selfish benefit. He alone is a yogi.

Among the mah─Бv─Бkyas (great declarations) in the G─лt─Б, this is one of the most important. Yoga here could mean either karmayoga or j├▒─Бnayoga. Ultimately, saс╣Гny─Бsa and yoga are complementary to each other and are not mutually detrimental. Saс╣Гny─Бsa, s─Бс╣Гkhya and j├▒─Бna are all treated as synonyms in the G─лt─Б. Similarly, the words dharma, niyata karma and kartavya are all synonymous. The performance of karma yields citta┼Ыuddhi (purification of the mind) that is a prerequisite to attain j├▒─Бna. It is impossible to obtain j├▒─Бna without purifying the mind. The mind must be equanimous and composed to receive j├▒─Бna. Saс╣Гny─Бsa becomes a tool to calm and compose the mind. Thus, both karma and saс╣Гny─Бsa become one in j├▒─Бnayoga. They are complementary to each other. ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa makes this clear when he says,

─Бrurukс╣гor-muner-yogaс╣Г karma k─Бraс╣Зam-ucyate
yog─Бr┼лс╕Нhasya tasyaiva ┼Ыamaс╕е k─Бraс╣Зam-ucyate (BG 6.3)

The readiness for the practice of yoga is obtained by karma, before the actual practice of yoga is begun. Yoga then becomes complete by the practice of ┼Ыama (tranquillity).

The necessary first step is to perform oneтАЩs ordained duties and then give up the fruit of labour. This is the practice of egolessness. Love and hatred are thence transcended, thus achieving tranquillity of mind. This leads to the complete experience of the Self.

yaс╣Г saс╣Гny─Бsam-iti pr─Бhur-yogaс╣Г taс╣Г viddhi p─Бс╣Зс╕Нava
na hyasaс╣Гny─Бsta-saс╣Еkalpo yog─л bhavati ka┼Ыcana (BG 6.2)

The first step to prepare for yoga is to give up purpose (saс╣Еkalpa). In other words, desire and want. Thoughts about the outcome тАФ that something should result out of an action, or that something should take place in a specific way only and not in any other way тАФ are all saс╣Еkalpa. Saс╣Гny─Бsa is the absence of desire for personal fulfilment.

Giving up Desire for Selfish Ends

There is a question here. Should we not have many saс╣Еkalpas such as the upliftment of the nation and so forth? Saс╣Еkalpa is planning. Can there be development in the world without planning? Such questions may arise. Saс╣Еkalpa is the mark of human will; should human effort or will be given up? Has not Bhagav─Бn himself said тАЬpauruс╣гaс╣Г nс╣Ыс╣гuтАЭ тАФ тАЬI am agency or will in humansтАЭ? It has been amply said in the R─Бm─Бyaс╣Зa and the Mah─Бbh─Бrata that pauruс╣гa is required. Without saс╣Еkalpa, pauruс╣гa is impossible.

The answer to this question is thus: Firstly, the intent here is not to give up desire for the progress of the world but to give up selfish desires. The desire for profit, enjoyment, and fame should be given up. However, there is no harm in desires that please Bhagav─Бn. Secondly, selfish desires are prohibited for saс╣Гny─Бs─лs and people desirous of the knowledge of the ─Бtm─Б, not for everyone. Saс╣Гny─Бsa is for those who deem worldly pleasures as worthless. Giving up all desires is not expected of people whose minds are firmly and truly attached to the world. The saс╣Еkalpa of such people is тАЬcaturvidha-phala-puruс╣г─Бrtha-siddhyarthaс╣ГтАЭ тАФ to gain the four-fold achievements in life. Even a selfish desire can be acceptable as dharma. Are not karmas like agniс╣гс╣нoma and a┼Ыvamedha similar to this? Working for pleasure, riches, and success in a righteous manner is not proper for saс╣Гny─Бsa but is acceptable for the gс╣Ыhastha. This saс╣Еkalpa of a householder belongs to the millions of objects to be achieved by human beings, the foremost of which is dharma.

A student in a gurukula is prohibited from using perfume, flowers, and t─Бmb┼лla^(^([2])). However, these enjoyments are not forbidden for householders, and even encouraged. If we say that a man suffering from fever should not be served fatty foods, it doesnтАЩt mean that his guests should also be deprived of ghee. Let there be selfishness; but it should be subservient to dharma. However, when the highest spiritual knowledge is aspired for, this selfishness should go away.
