[[Ch. 6 The Practice of Dhy─Бna (Part 2) Source: prekshaa]]

The Advantage of Performing Karma

The idea that the mind becomes pure by performing karma should be examined before acceptance. Even if one is selfish while performing an ordained duty (vihita-karma), its performance by itself can gradually bring about selflessness. Whether it is a spiritual or worldly duty, even if it is done out of selfishness тАФ if it adheres to dharma, its results are two-fold. Firstly, it turns our minds towards the divine; the second is the fulfilment of our objective. Meditation upon the divine does not need any explanation. However, there is one thing to be said about obtaining desires. Performing satkarma is required for everything тАФ whether to procure something desirable or to get rid of something undesirable. More importantly, karma means being in contact with the world. Being in constant contact with the world trains the j─лva spiritually or changes it in some way. Even such changes can benefit the j─лva. Karmas, akarmas, haste, lack of judgment, profit, loss, passion, hatred, jealousy, obstinacy, separation, disease, and sorrow тАФ these various experiences shake and jolt the j─лva, make it drift about, tire it, and finally bring about the realisation of the meagre extent of the value of the world, of the plight of worldly enjoyment, and of human endeavour. We recall Bhartс╣ЫhariтАЩs words here тАФ

m─Бtar-medini t─Бta m─Бruta sakhe tejas-subaс╣Гdho jala
bhr─Бtar-vyoma nibaddha eva bhavat─Бm antyaс╕е praс╣З─Бm─Б├▒jaliс╕еред
yuс╣гmat-saс╣Гga-va┼Ыopaj─Бta-sukс╣Ыta-sph─Бra-sphuran-nirmala-
j├▒─Бn─Бp─Бsta-samasta-moha-mahim─Б l─лye para-brahmaс╣Зiрее
Vair─Бgya-┼Ыataka, 100

Bhartс╣Ыhari probably realised that his life on earth was coming to an end. He then folded his hands and prayed тАФ “O mother Earth, father Air, friend Fire, cousin Water, O Sky, who protects me like a brother, this is the last prostration to you from me”. Why? “Because of your association, I was able to gain puс╣Зya, and because of the puс╣Зya I was able to gain pure, vast and self-effulgent knowledge of the Self.тАЭ As we come more and more in contact with the world, our delusions and infatuations are removed. Contact with the world gives us a sense of the true value of different things. Thus, we become detached from our infatuations, one by one. This is the supreme benefit of experience of association with the world. Connection with the world is one of the exercises required for the j─лva. The purity of mind that is achieved by this relationship with the world is greater than that obtained by the sixteen saс╣Гsk─Бras. Therefore, karma is a vital instrument. Indeed, karma is synonymous with man.

Thus, a limit to selfishness is itself set by enjoying the fruit of oneтАЩs self-centered actions. Experiencing pleasure is required for the j─лva, as is experiencing sorrow. Therefore, the j─лva is ripened even by selfish satkarma, performed out of selfish desire. Remembering the divine and new refinement for the j─лva тАФ these are the auspicious results of satkarma. The j─лva gradually ascends to higher planes of existence through multiple lives by experiencing the fruits of its actions.

Aneka-janma-saс╣Гsiddhas-tato y─Бti par─Бс╣Г gatiс╣ГрееBG 6.45
тАЬThus perfected by many lives, he attains the supreme state.тАЭ

One cannot jump to the highest plane, it has to be ascended like a staircase.

Saс╣Гny─Бsa is not easy; giving up oneтАЩs interests is not easy; giving up saс╣Еkalpa is not easy either. Performing vihita-karma and enjoying worldly experiences through them тАФ this is how one can earn the capacity to experience the supreme reality.

Thus, not just ┼Ыrauta and sm─Бrta karmas, but all worldly duties, all transactions of life, all friendships and relationships, all physical and spiritual lending and borrowing are training for the j─лva. Therefore, we can say that karma itself is life.

Atha khalu kratumayaс╕е puruс╣гaс╕ерее
puruс╣гo v─БvayajтАЩaс╕ерее
krato smara kс╣Ыtaggс╣Г smara
Ch─Бndogyopaniс╣гad 3.14.1

The above sentences from the Upaniс╣гads also mean the same. The j─лva is karma itself. Karma gives spiritual training to the j─лva.

Who can Perform Karma?

Every human being has the freedom to choose the karma that has to be performed, according to his capability and circumstances.

uddhared-─Бtman─Бtm─Бnaс╣Г n─Бtm─Бnam-avas─Бdayetред
─Бtmaiva hy-─Бtmano bandhur-─Бtmaiva ripur-─Бtmanaс╕ерееBG 6.5

If man did not have the above freedom, this saying would have been meaningless. The j─лva has the freedom to elevate itself, and the freedom to choose whether or not to perform a certain karma.

Why is a person in this state now? Because he acted in a certain way in the past. One exists because of his karma, the karma that he performed in his past. The certainty that one is responsible for his future is embedded in the statement that one exists because of his karma. If a man deliberates today on what he has to do and not do, and performs only the beneficial duties prudently, his circumstances tomorrow will be excellent. In the eyes of westerners, karma is adс╣Ыс╣гс╣нa тАФ unseen тАФ some kind of predetermined fatalism about which one can do nothing. They opine that this is a drawback of Ved─Бnta. But we say that it is not a drawback, but a blessing. Who is the master of your life now? You тАФ that is, what you did yesterday. Who will be the master of your life tomorrow? You тАФ that is, what you do today. If yesterday is the master of today, today will be the master of tomorrow. Thus, past, present, and future are continuously and wholly woven together. Therefore, whatever you have to do today, do it right. This is the essence of the statement тАЬuddhared-─Бtman─Бtm─Бnaс╣ГтАЭ. A man is the master of his future. This is the main takeaway from this chapter.

Then can we not jump once and jump hard, and take control of our future? That is not possible. Why is this? This is because the burden from the past weighs the j─лva down. That burden should first be lightened. The future is endless. Just as the past does not have any beginning, the future does not have any end. The future that you desire will someday be yours. If you work towards being in the presence of the divine, that is also possible.

bah┼лn─Бс╣Г janman─Бm-ante j├▒─Бnav─Бn m─Бс╣Г prapadyateредBG 7.19

If we work towards something in each life, we will obtain true knowledge over time. The meaning is this тАФ the j─лva must be trained. We have to have that goal in mind and perform karma that trains the j─лva, in every life.

┼Ъama

Now we have agreed that karma is the path to spiritual progress. Is that enough? No.

yog─Бr┼лс╕Нhasya tasyaiva ┼Ыamaс╕е k─Бraс╣Зam-ucyateрееBG 6.3
тАЬ┼Ъama causes the seeker to be established in yoga.тАЭ

┼Ъama or tranquility should join karma. Tranquility is possible by meditating on the nature of the Supreme tattva. In a nutshell, karma can train the j─лva in a good way, but can also perturb it. The possibility of mental disturbance cannot be escaped even when one is engaged in worship. тАЬYou have brought only red flowers today!тАЭ, тАЬThere is not enough oil for the lampтАЭ, тАЬWhat have you prepared for the naivedya?тАЭ тАФ thus there are many agitations in the mind.

We agreed that karma is transacting with the world. The world does not listen to our words. In a family, a wife may not be able to adjust with the nature of her husband; the husband may not follow his wifeтАЩs whims; the children may not listen to both of them; the old men are irritated by everyone. The employer does not care about the difficulties of his employee; the employee does not worry about the employer. Patient colleagues may not be capable; capable colleagues may not be patient. A man who tries to perform karma in such a world faces anxiety and mental anguish at every step. How can we keep the mind content and resolute in such circumstances?

yogasthaс╕е kuru karm─Бс╣Зi saс╣Гgaс╣Г tyaktv─Б dhanaс╣Гjayaред
siddhya-siddhyoс╕е samo bh┼лtv─Б samatvaс╣Г yoga ucyateрееBG 2.48

How can equanimity be possible when the surroundings are chaotic? The means for that is meditation upon the divine. If the remembrance of the divine is etched firmly in the mind, mental anguish ceases; conflict vanishes; the work we do becomes meaningful. Therefore, the majesty and glory of the divine should always be meditated upon. Then any work done will be completed to perfection. Thus for spiritual upliftment, dhy─Бna is also as important a means as karma.

J├▒─Бna-vij├▒─Бna

j├▒─Бna-vij├▒─Бna-tс╣Ыpt─Бtm─Б k┼лс╣нastho vijitendriyaс╕еред
ukta ity-ucyate yog─л sama-loс╣гс╣н─Б┼Ыma-k─Б├▒canaс╕ерееBG 6.8

The mind needs two kinds of intellectual wealth to be content. One is j├▒─Бna, the other is vij├▒─Бna. J├▒─Бna here means the knowledge of the true nature of the ─Бtm─Б (tattva-j├▒─Бna). It is knowledge gained by persistent effort of the intellect тАФ knowledge obtained from reading books and listening to discourses. Vij├▒─Бna is experiencing the knowledge gained thus. Vij├▒─Бna is the experience of j├▒─Бna. One is theory тАФ intellectual pursuit, whereas the other is practice тАФ experiential pursuit. One has to obtain both of these and remain unperturbed by the senses. Such a man is тАЬtс╣Ыpt─Бtm─БтАЭ. One who is separate from every attribute of the j─лva except the ─Бtm─Б тАФ such as the body тАФ such a man is тАЬk┼лс╣нasthaс╕е vijitendriyaс╕етАЭ. тАЬk┼лс╣нasthaс╕етАЭ means existing separately, and changeless like the firm anvil of a blacksmith. As William Wordsworth said about John Milton тАФ

Thy soul was like a star and dwelt apart
London, 1802

The light should mingle with others like that of a star, but the person should stay aloof. As said previously, тАЬpadma-patram-iv─Бmbhas─БтАЭ тАФ one should be in the world, and yet not attached to it. That is being k┼лс╣нastha. Such a man is тАЬyuktaтАЭ тАФ he is established in yoga. Gold and stone mean the same to him

The Method of Dhy─Бna

A yogi brings his senses under his control, learns to distinguish between ─Аtma and an─Бtma and practises it in this world as much as possible, and is at peace.

yog─л yu├▒j─лta satatam ─Бtm─Бnaс╣Г rahasi sthitaс╕еред
ek─Бk─л yata-citt─Бtm─Б nir─Б┼Ы─лr-aparigrahaс╕ерееBG 6.10

тАЬHe always unites his mind with the ─Бtm─Б. He keeps his mind under control. He does not worry about earning or enjoying. He sits alone in a private place and immerses himself in dhy─Бna, thinking about the nature of the ─Бtm─БтАЭ.

tatraik─Бgraс╣Г manaс╕е kс╣Ыtv─Б yata-cittendriya-kriyaс╕еред
upavi┼Ыy─Бsane yu├▒jy─Бt yogam─Бtma-vi┼ЫuddhayeрееBG 6.12

Dhy─Бna should be performed in a clean place. The seat should be firm. It should neither be too high nor too low. The flow of light and wind should not agitate but be calming. Sitting in such a place, one should focus his mind.

It is said that yoga should be practised while sitting. Even the Brahmas┼лtra says тАФ “─Бs─лnas-sambhav─Бt” (Brahmas┼лtra 4.1.7). Why should it not be done while walking? Of course, it can be done while walking if it is possible, but it is not possible! When we are walking, we constantly think about where we step next. If we meditate while lying down, we might fall asleep. We should therefore sit calmly to perform dhy─Бna. “yatraik─Бgrat─Б tatr─Бvi┼Ыeс╣г─Бt” тАФ one should sit wherever the mind can concentrate. A place where the mind is calm and unlikely to wander is the right place for dhy─Бna.

[[Ch. 6 The Practice of Dhy─Бna (Part 3) Source: prekshaa]]

Limiting Pleasures

It is not required for a s─Бdhaka practising dhy─Бna to adhere to valiant restrictions on food and other diversions. His sitting posture should not hinder easy breathing and other bodily activities, and should not cause trouble to his limbs. There is a proper measure for eating, sleeping and j─Бgaraс╣Зa^(^([1])). A yogi is moderate in the above aspects. Here, moderation means just as much as is required for mental balance; neither more, nor less.

n─Бtya┼Ыnatas-tu yogoтАЩsti na caik─Бntam-ana┼Ыnataс╕е ред
na c─Бti-svapna-┼Ы─лlasya j─Бgrato naiva c─Бrjunaрее BG 6.16
yukt─Бh─Бra-vih─Бrasya yukta-ceс╣гс╣нasya karmasu ред
yukta-svapn─Бvabodhasya yogo bhavati duс╕еkhah─Б рее BG 6.17

A glutton cannot become a yogi, as also one who seldom eats. Excess sleep is not recommended, as is j─Бgaraс╣Зa or staying awake for too long. One should be tranquil; there should be no excess of pleasure.

Two Goals

There are two goals here:1) Efficiency in work 2) Peace of mind. When the yakс╣гa asked^(^([2])) what was the main characteristic of the practice of Dharma, Dharmar─Бja said, тАЬd─Бkс╣гyam-ekapadaс╣Г dharmyaс╣ГтАЭ (MBh. 3-314-72) тАФ тАЬEfficiency is one-quarter of dharmaтАЭ. Dharma is possible when one is efficient. J─Бgaraс╣Зa, oversleeping, starving, and stuffing oneтАЩs stomach with food тАФ all these affect the peace of mind.

Enjoyment of and attachment to pleasure should be present in such a way that progress towards the two aforementioned goals is not impeded. Just as тАШnot impedingтАЩ is important, it is also important that they be тАШpresentтАЩ. The body and the senses should be controlled, not killed. They become obedient only if they are humoured for some time. If we try to suppress in a strict manner, they might revolt and break the mind into pieces. Dhy─Бna then becomes impossible; worldly work becomes impossible. Viveka deserts the mind that is not peaceful.

Efficiency and peace of mind are required not only for a seeker of knowledge and not just for a yogi but are required qualities even for us, who are not quite so inclined in this direction. The plight of humans is like this because these qualities are not present in our day-to-day dealings. Dhy─Бna-yoga can be practised when the mind is healthy and content.

yatroparamate cittaс╣Г niruddhaс╣Г yoga-sevay─БBG 6.20
saс╣Еkalpa-prabhav─Бn k─Бm─Бn tyaktv─Б sarv─Бn-a┼Ыeс╣гataс╕еред
manasaivendriya-gr─Бmaс╣Г viniyamya samantataс╕ерее BG 6.24
┼Ыanaiс╕е ┼Ыanair-uparamet buddhy─Б dhс╣Ыti-gс╣Ыh─лtay─Бред
─Бtma-saс╣Гsthaс╣Г manaс╕е kс╣Ыtv─Б na ki├▒cidapi cintayetрееBG 6.25

The qualification for yoga is said to be acquired when the mind stops roving here and there, and can focus without getting agitated. Until then we do not qualify for yoga. Completely giving up all desires that are the root cause of various saс╣Еkalpas, controlling all senses and subjugating them, attaining tranquility little by little at a time with a steady mind, firmly establishing the mind in the ─Бtm─Б, one desiring to practise dhy─Бna should not think of anything else. This is param─Бtma-dhy─Бna-yoga or the yoga of meditating upon the Supreme.

Different Types of Dhy─Бna-yoga

For many among us, param─Бtm─Б is a distant thing. It is not easy for us to even imagine it. But we also possess a desire to understand its nature. Therefore, we also need a method of dhy─Бna that might gradually lead us on the path to true knowledge. In the statement

*─Бtma-saс╣Гsthaс╣Г manaс╕е kс╣Ыtv─Б…*BG 6.25

We can replace ─Аtma with a deity of our choice тАФ one that we love and can grasp. “Deva-saс╣Гsthaс╣Г manaс╕е kс╣Ыtv─Б”, “┼Ыambhu-saс╣Гsthaс╣Г manaс╕е kс╣Ыtv─Б”, “r─Бma-saс╣Гsthaс╣Г manaс╕е kс╣Ыtv─Б”, “v─Бс╣З─л-saс╣Гsthaс╣Г manaс╕е kс╣Ыtv─Б”, “kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa-saс╣Гsthaс╣Г manaс╕е kс╣Ыtv─Б”, “lakс╣гm─л-saс╣Гsthaс╣Г manaс╕е kс╣Ыtv─Б”, “gaur─л-saс╣Гsthaс╣Г manaс╕е kс╣Ыtv─Б”, etc тАФ thus fixing the mind upon our iс╣гс╣нadevat─Б. Usually, during all vratas like Vin─Бyaka-caturth─л, during all japas like that of the G─Бyatr─л-mantra, it is an established tradition to recite the dhy─Бna-shloka first. The intention is to bring the Divine image to mind тАФ and in the process, fix the mind on the greatness of the deity, its wonderful power and glory. “mukt─БvidrumaтАж” in g─Бyatr─л-dhy─Бna, “dhyeyaс╕е sad─Б savitс╣Ы-maс╣Зс╕Нala-madhyavartiс╕е”, etc.

This is the first lesson in dhy─Бnayoga.

The method of dhy─Бna has to be learnt from experienced people only. It is not possible to learn it by listening to speeches and explanations. The secret of dhy─Бna is the mechanism to temper the mind. This mechanism differs from j─лva to j─лva. Some children can be cajoled with candies; others might need to see a cane before they oblige. There is no single rule that works for all minds. If experienced people share their experiences, some guidance can be obtained from it. I am not experienced^(^([3])). I will just say a few words that I have merely heard from others.

Means for Dhy─Бna

As far as possible, those who want to practise dhy─Бna should decide on the following four first.

  1. A designated place 2. A specific time 3. The m┼лrti of a deity 4. A mantra or a mah─Бv─Бkya

Out of the twenty-four hours available in a day, at least fifteen minutes should be earmarked for this purpose. Early morning is the best time. If that is not possible, even night time is fine. It is of utmost importance that the mind should be at peace. If there is a specific time and place, the mind can easily take the requisite mood or attitude. It might be difficult to achieve the same in a different place or at a different time. One should sit there in silence, where there is no animated activity of others. One should sit with a clean mind and body in such a place, and fix the concentration on the icon of the iс╣гс╣нadaiva. Once should recall the stories, the wonderful qualities and splendour of the deity, and keep thinking about it. If he feels like it, he can perform p┼лj─Б, but the mind should not wander away in the hullabaloo of flowers and naivedya. Japa should not even be performed loudly, because sound pulls the mind outward towards the world. Among all dhy─Бnas, silent dhy─Бna is the best. That is why yogis are called maunis (those who are silent).

Then, are bhajanas and k─лrtanas wrong? No, they are also useful. However, their use is limited. Bhajanas and k─лrtanas bring elevated emotions to the mind. These emotions are fructified only by performing dhy─Бna solitarily.

I feel that the practice of dhy─Бna is possible at least to a certain extent for everyone тАФ including women^(^([4])). There is no one who is so busy that he or she is not free for a few minutes before sleeping at night, or in the early morningтАФjust beside the bedтАФbefore one sets out for their daily routine. If those five minutes are used for dhy─Бna, it will not only bring much-needed peace and calm during the entire day, but also firmly establishes a practice routine.

Yogis can engage themselves in deep dhy─Бna of their deity for a very long time. It is very difficult for us to achieve such deep concentration for a long time. It is a great fortune if our minds can fix themselves upon the divine even for a second. One of my elders would say тАФ “I can wash a buffalo with ease, washing a s─Бligr─Бma is difficult”. Another elder would say, “I can focus for hours on worldly matters; whereas my mind is not focused for half a minute in the half hour I spend for p┼лj─Б”. Worldly things excite our temper or desire, and trap us with them. There is no such outward attraction for devotion to the divine. It happens inside us. Our firm and persevering effort is required for it. “Uddhared-─Бtman─Бtm─Бnam”. That is why it is difficult. S─Бdhan─Б is when something difficult is achieved. What is great in achieving something that is easy?

Without such dhy─Бna, it is difficult for anyone to understand the Bhagavad-G─лt─Б. Experience is knowledge. Here, by experience, we mean our own experience. The knowledge obtained from books is incomplete. Bookish knowledge is only a poor imitation of the knowledge gained by experience, whereas experience gives complete knowledge. When such experience has to be gained, the mind has to ripen. Both karma and j├▒─Бna are ways to ripen the mind. Both of them are needed.

“y─Бvad-y─Бvat karmabhya uparamate t─Бvat t─Бvat nir─Бy─Бsasya jitendriyasya cittaс╣Г sam─Бdh─лyateред”
(As it recuses itself from activity, the mind of the one who is at ease and whose sense organs are controlled attains focus.)
┼Ъ─Бс╣Еkara-g─лt─Бbh─Бс╣гya 6.3

nait─Бdс╣Ы┼Ыaс╣Г br─Бhmaс╣Зasy─Бsti vittaс╣Г
yathaikat─Б samat─Б satyat─Б ca.
┼Ы─лlaс╣Г sthitirdaс╣Зс╕Нanidh─Бnam─Бrjavaс╣Г
tatastata┼Ыcoparamaс╕е kriy─Бbhyaс╕е
(There is no other wealth of a br─Бhmaс╣Зa
than unity, equanimity, truth,
character, firmness, the cessation of punishment, sincerity
and gradual cessation from activity)
Mah─Бbh─Бrata, 12.169.35^(^([5]))

They say that the mind should desist from sensual enjoyment; the meaning here is to get rid of the cares, scares and fuss of karma. Karma should be performed, but we should also extricate ourselves from it. Both are required тАФ there are different requirements for different situations.

Mark of an ─Аtma-j├▒─Бn─л

┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa describes the mark of a meditator who has successfully accomplished ─Аtmadhy─Бna.

sarva-bh┼лtastham-─Бtm─Бnaс╣Г sarvabh┼лt─Бni c─Бtmaniред
─лkс╣гate yoga-yukt─Бtm─Б sarvatra sama-dar┼Ыanaс╕ерееBG 6.29
yo m─Бс╣Г pa┼Ыyati sarvatra sarvaс╣Г ca mayi pa┼Ыyatiред
tasy─Бhaс╣Г na praс╣Зa┼Ыy─Бmi sa ca me na praс╣Зa┼ЫyatiрееBG 6.30
sarvath─Б vartam─БnoтАЩpi sa yog─л mayi vartateBG 6.31
─Бtmaupamyena sarvatra samaс╣Г pa┼Ыyati yoтАЩrjunaред
sukhaс╣Г v─Б yadi v─Б duс╕еkhaс╣Г sa yog─л paramo mataс╕ерееBG 6.32

All living beings are within the expanse of the ─Бtm─Б. A yogi internalises this experience and behaves in the same way towards everything and everyone. We have seen the meaning of samabh─Бva earlier: it means having clear distinction between proper and improper in external behavior and equal love for all internally. Everything is a manifestation of the divine, and the divine pervades everything uniformly. It cannot be said that it manifests densely in some and sparsely in others. The love that a yogi feels internally is equal and common for all. Wherever he is, whatever state he is in, he always interacts with the divine at all times. ─Аtmaupamya is characteristic of him. ─Аtmaupamya^(^([6])) means behaving towards someone else as though it was oneself. A great yogi is one who considers othersтАЩ happiness and sorrow as his own, at all times and in all places. He is part of all of the worldтАЩs experiences, be it joy or agony. This is what ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa says. He does not abandon the world; but he is engrossed in the welfare of all beings. Internally, he is not attached to worldly activities, but outwardly, he helps in those very activities. Internally, he is firmly established in the true knowledge of the ─Бtm─Б. Because of this тАФ because his knowledge of the true nature of the ─Бtm─Б is complete, he is able to conduct himself as though the whole world is an extension of himself. Just as it is the innate nature of jasmine to spread fragrance, the quality of ─Аtmaupamya is thus natural and effortless for a yogi. ─Аtmaupamya is prescribed dharma for a s─Бdhaka, and a natural development for a siddha (one who has attained it). Thus, its importance is in both ways. This philosophy of ─Аtmaupamya is the fundamental thread running through all our worldly morals and traditions. The ┼Ы─Бstras expound this in many ways -

─Бtmanaс╕е pratik┼лl─Бni pareс╣г─Бс╣Г na sam─Бcaretрее
(One must not do to others what one would find disagreeable)
MBh. 5.15.17, 18

m─Бtс╣Ыvat para-d─Бr─Бс╣Г┼Ыca para-dravy─Бс╣Зi loс╣гс╣нhavatред
─Бtmavat sarva-bh┼лt─Бni yaс╕е pa┼Ыyati sa pa┼Ыyatiрее
(One who sees othersтАЩ wives as his own mother,
othersтАЩ wealth as a lump of earth,
and all beings as one self, indeed sees.)
Hitopade┼Ыa 1.14

[[Ch. 6 The Practice of Dhy─Бna (Part 4) Source: prekshaa]]

Accomplishment through Practice

It looks as though this principle appealed to ArjunaтАЩs mind, in the course of teaching of the true nature of the ─Бtm─Б. However, he still had doubts regarding the practice.

cancalaс╣Г hi manaс╕е kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa pram─Бthi balavad-dс╣Ыс╕Нhamред
tasy─Бhaс╣Г nigrahaс╣Г manye v─Бyor-iva suduс╣гkaramрее BG 6.34

Arjuna says тАФ “Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa, is not the mind fickle? It can impede the path of the j─лva and shake it, can it not? Is it possible to bottle up wind?”. Bhagav─Бn says, “indeed, it is difficult; but not impossible”. How, then, is it possible?

asaс╣Г┼Ыayaс╣Г mah─Бb─Бho mano durnigrahaс╣Г calaс╣Гред
abhy─Бsena tu kaunteya vair─Бgyena ca gс╣ЫhyateрееBG 6.35

The mind can be taken into control with intelligent effort. Practice of dhy─Бna and indifference to worldly pleasures are the ways to accomplish that.

The word abhy─Бsa (practice) should be looked at in a little more detail here. Abhy─Бsa means doing something again and again. What does this imply? It means that when one sets out to achieve something, it cannot be done by the mental adrenaline rush of one moment, but requires persistent and consistent effort for a long time. A moment is just a point in a long line. Time is the straight line comprising these moments without any gap. Dots are right next to each other in a line, without any gap. Dhy─Бna and vair─Бgya too should thus be practised continuously, without any gap. How long should the practice last? Till the sattvaguс╣Зa of the j─лva breaks out of the shackles of rajas and tamas and rises above them, and becomes strong enough to put them down. The time required for sattva to become this strong is determined by how large the quanta of rajas and tamas are. Who can measure the quantity of the three guс╣Зas hidden in a j─лva? There can be no one outside the j─лva who can convey this to him. The workings of his innermost mind will not be visible to them. In fact, it is not even necessary for someone outside to convey it to him, because he can himself realise when his sattva becomes stronger. The development of sattvaguс╣Зa will happen for everyone at some time or the other тАФ however evil or uncultured he may be. There is no being without even an iota of sattva. His exact moment of favourable opportunity is when his sattva blooms. That is when he has to be watchful. This is the тАШinner voiceтАЩ that he has to heed. It is heard when bodily ears are closed and the inner ones are opened. If it has to become a habit, one has to listen to it carefully, grasp its intent and follow it thenceforth. The mind becomes strong with long-term practice of detachment and dhy─Бna. It becomes easier to pursue the true knowledge of the ─Бtm─Б when the mind firms up.

Arjuna says тАФ тАЬThis is fine, Krishna, I have ┼Ыraddh─Б. However, my attempt to control my mind might not complete and break down halfway. What will then become of me? What will happen if a small speck of cloud gets separated from its parent? Caught in the wind, it will be scattered without even a sign remaining of it. Is not my plight the same? What if the only outcome of running a race is fracturing oneтАЩs foot? I would not have completely left the practice of dhy─Бna, neither would I have achieved itтАЭ.

Even a little practice will not go waste

┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa replies to this question thus:

p─Бrtha naiveha n─Бmutra vin─Б┼Ыas-tasya vidyateред
na hi kaly─Бс╣Зa-kс╣Ыt ka┼Ыcit durgatiс╣Г t─Бta gacchatiрееBG 6.40

If you try and do not succeed, you will not suffer from it. One who tries to do good will never come to ruin.

A boy might be coaxed by the elders of the family to study for a difficult exam. They are convinced that he is intelligent and studious, and might pass the exam. He might not be so confident, and might ask тАЬWhat if I donтАЩt pass?тАЭ. The elders will then say, тАЬit is okay to not pass this time. What is the harm in studying for it? The preparation for this exam will help you next time, if not this nowтАЭ. ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣ЗaтАЩs answer is similar.

He had given a similar assurance to Arjuna earlier:

neh─Бbhikrama-n─Б┼ЫoтАЩsti pratyav─Бyo na vidyateред
svalpam-apyasya dharmasya tr─Бyate mahato bhay─БtрееBG 2.40

Even if this dharma is followed a little, it protects us from great fear.

Saс╣Гsk─Бra from many lives

The above statement is not just one of encouragement. The accomplishment of yoga is possible only through gradual steps. Our efforts might not bear fruit in a single birth. A j─лva attains a favourable state in the next birth because of the puс╣Зya of this birth. From the puс╣Зya of that birth, it attains an even better state in another birth. Thus, the qualification to be in the presence of the divine is accrued from the saс╣Гsk─Бra and effort of many lives.

pr─Бpya puс╣Зya-kс╣Ыt─Бn lok─Бn uс╣гitv─Б ┼Ы─Б┼Ыvat─лс╕е sam─Бс╕еред
┼Ыuc─лn─Бс╣Г ┼Ыr─лmat─Бс╣Г gehe yoga-bhraс╣гс╣нoтАЩbhij─БyateрееBG 6.41
athav─Б yogin─Бm-eva kule bhavati dh─лmat─Бс╣Гред
etaddhi durlabha-taraс╣Г loke janma yad-─лdс╣Ыс╣гamрее BG 6.42

A follower of the path of yoga will gain puс╣Зya and thus attain better stations even if his effort is not enough to take him to the intended final destination. His incomplete practice of yoga will not harm him in any way. Rather, he will then be born in a virtuous and wealthy family, and becomes capable of performing virtuous deeds again. Or, he might be born in a family of seers and yogis and gain true knowledge of the self. Is it not great fortune to be born in such a good family? It is indeed great puс╣Зya to be born in a good household.

tatra taс╣Г buddhi-saс╣Гyogaс╣Г labhate paurva-dehikaс╣Гред
yatate ca tato bh┼лyaс╕е saс╣Гsiddhau kuru-nandanaрееBG 6.43
p┼лrv─Бbhy─Бsena tenaiva hriyate hyava┼ЫoтАЩpi saс╕еред
jij├▒─Бsurapi yogasya ┼Ыabda-brahm-─БtivartateрееBG 6.44
prayatn─Бd-yatam─Бnastu yog─л saс╣Г┼Ыuddha-kilbiс╣гaс╕еред
aneka-janma-saс╣Гsiddhaс╕е tato y─Бti par─Бс╣Г gatimрееBG 6.45

One who practises dhy─Бna-yoga but leaves his body before his efforts fructify, will be born in a noble family in the next life. Because of the excellence in the place and circumstances of his birth, his mind will turn towards his practice of yoga, which he had left half-finished. Due to his previous practice, his mind will be ripe and ready for yoga. Maturity of the mind is because of the influence of his family. Thus, his practice of yoga resumes. Even if he faces obstacles during his practice this second time, he will be capable of overcoming them. Further, he deliberates upon the nature of reality. He gains knowledge and thus transcends all bookish knowledge. The material in his effort to gain knowledge is ┼Ыabda-brahma тАФ or the collection of Vedas and ┼Ы─Бstras. When we say that he transcends them, it is implied that he has full possession of the knowledge contained in them, and therefore they are no longer necessary to him. Thus, by repeated efforts he loses the impurities accumulated in him from the actions and desires of his previous births, and acquires true knowledge.

Three points have to be observed in the above discussion:

  1. Rebirth 2. The relationship between family and the eligibility to perform yoga 3. The necessity of continuous and long practice.

Influence of Family

Consideration of familial influence in the conduct of a person is a distinctive feature of san─Бtana-dharma. It is respectful to call ┼Ъr─лr─Бma as belonging to the family of Ikс╣гv─Бku, or the family of Raghu. So also, Paurava, Bh─Бrata, Y─Бdava are all names that denote great pride. с╣Ъс╣гi Kaс╣Зva indicated King Duс╣гyantaтАЩs exalted nature by saying тАЬuccaiс╕е kulaс╣Г catmanaс╕етАЭ (distinguished indeed is his clan). There is a term тАФ noblesse oblige тАФ which means that with wealth comes great responsibility. Arjuna himself talks about familial dharma in his extensive lament of abandonment. There is a saying in kannaс╕Нa тАФ тАЬkulavannu n─Бlag├й heс╕╗uttad├йтАЭ тАФ the tongue betrays the family. Thus, family and society are of great importance. It comes to a man by his actions in his previous births. When we say that a family is good, it means that they are good-natured and also have good saс╣Гsk─Бra. A s─Бttvika mind and innate spirituality run naturally in the family and comprise their ancestral wealth. Also, there is more opportunity for contact with good people and education in such a family. Thus, being born in such a family is the fruit of great puс╣Зya in itself. Similarly, being born in a base family is the result of p─Бpa.

Step-by-step improvement of the j─лva

Various accounts of different births and rebirths are not different stories but all births are different chapters of a single great story. One who wants to understand the progress of a j─лva should examine the different chapters of different births as one unbroken and uninterrupted flow, like that of a river. Streams of clear water join this river, as does village muck. As the river flows further, it loses its filth and becomes clearer and clearer. Thus, the inflow of small but clear streams also finds a favorable outcome. The story of our meagre but sincere effort is similar.

The progress of a j─лva happens gradually. Each birth is a step. The eligibility for mokс╣гa comes from many saс╣Гsk─Бras. For the j─лva to attain a good state (sadgati) various kinds of purification are required, just as various strokes with a hammer are required to create a sculpture out of stone, and various methods of mixing, boiling, and filtering are required to produce medicine out of herbs. Therefore, it is not right to be hasty about mokс╣гa. Only constant practice of yoga helps in the attainment of mokс╣гa.

The superiority of dhy─Бna-yoga

Yoga is when a human being employs his divine nature in the service of the world, and thereby unites his inner-self with the param─Бtm─Б. This means that he should perform the activities of the world without any desire for its fruit: тАЬYogaс╕е karmasu kau┼ЫalamтАЭ. Such yoga is superior to penance such as vratas and upav─Бsas, better than the knowledge of many ┼Ы─Бstras, and better even than yaj├▒as and y─Бgas. Therefore, O Arjuna, you practise this yoga and become a yogi.

yogin─Бm-api sarveс╣г─Бс╣Г madgaten─Б-ntar─Бtman─Бред
┼Ыraddh─Б-v─Бn bhajate yo m─Бс╣Г sa me yukta-tamo mataс╕ерееBG 6.47
тАЬI consider one who fixes his mind upon me and serves me with devotion, as the best among the yogis.
Let your mind be within me. Let your hand obey my instructionsтАЭ.

This is dhy─Бnabhy─Бsa-yoga тАФ the yoga of the practice of dhy─Бna.

[[Ch. 7 Yoga of Jagat-J─лva-─к┼Ыvara (Part 1) Source: prekshaa]]

Summary

Whatever is essential and uniquely great in this world is to be understood as a salient mark of BrahmaтАЩs power. Whatever quality endows a thing with usefulness and value belongs to the power of Brahma.

In addition to sattva, the guс╣Зas of rajas and tamas are also necessary for the functioning of the world. The agitation amongst these three guс╣Зas is vital for the constantly dynamic behaviour of the universe and therefore for its existence. Prakс╣Ыti has thrown man a competitive challenge a- “I have instituted this disparity among guс╣Зas. Let man overcome it if he can.”

M─Бy─Б is the appearance that manifests to our mind after concealing or distorting reality. It is the world-controlling power that causes the error due to avidy─Б that is seen by the mindтАЩs eye to appear real.

The one who is free of avidy─Б, whose influence spans multiple births, is not affected by m─Бy─Б. The cessation of avidy─Б is possible through the practice of the presence of ─к┼Ыvara - with renewed effort towards gaining the knowledge of reality.

He who experiences Bhagav─БnтАЩs presence everywhere considers all worldly relations, kith and kin as ─к┼ЫvaraтАЩs blessing. As that blessed feeling grows, infatuation and delusions recede. The j─лva is purified. The contemplation of reality becomes easier. The knower of reality understands what in his life is owed to the world and what is owed to his inner self. He then works towards the welfare of both and becomes free of worry. Such a state is tranquility.

Section 8 / Chapter 7

J├▒─Бn─Б-vij├▒─Бna-yoga

known as

The Yoga of Jagat, J─лva and ─к┼Ыvara

Though the seventh chapter has only thirty verses, its matter is complex and not easy to understand. The following nine main points are covered here:

  1. The world - insentient prakс╣Ыti 2. The world - sentient prakс╣Ыti 3. ─к┼Ыvara 4. The essence of Brahma in ─к┼Ыvara 5. The marks (signs) of Brahma 6. M─Бy─Б 7. Crossing over m─Бy─Б 8. The worship of ─к┼Ыvara 9. The cessation of infatuation

This chapter covers these nine great topics in its small compass. The last chapter discussed meditation. Karma resulting in the purification of the mind is a negative attainment^(^([1])). Dhy─Бna (meditation) on the other hand is a positive attainment. P─Бpa is destroyed by karma while new well-being is gained by dhy─Бna. This has already been stated in the sixth chapter. тАЬMental agitation is remedied by means such as “yukt─Бh─Бravih─Бrasya” (of the one with propriety in food and enjoyment). A state of calm is then reached, one should sit in a clean place and meditate” - and such is stated there.

Now, the object to be meditated upon has to be ascertained. Dhy─Бna (meditation) has three aspects - dhy─Бna (the act of meditation), dhy─Бtс╣Ы (the meditator), and dhyeya (the object of meditation). Knowledge, similarly has three aspects - j├▒─Бna (knowledge), j├▒─Бtс╣Ы (the knower), and j├▒eya (the known). All those desirous of knowing reality are dhy─Бtс╣Ы. Bhagav─Бn now tells us what the dhyeya should be.

asaс╣Г┼Ыayaс╣Г samagraс╣Г m─Бс╣Г yath─Б j├▒─Бsyasi tacchс╣Ыс╣Зu
BG 7.1

It is not sufficient to understand the nature of Brahma a little here and a little there. Brahma has to be understood samagram (completely) - from the beginning to the end.

Before proceeding to the next part of the work, it is important to understand a few words and their meanings. It appears that terminology used in this chapter was well known among people during Vy─БsaтАЩs time. The same words have been used in the Mokс╣гa-dharma-parva and the Sanatsuj─Бt─лya. People probably understood terms such as Brahma without any explanation. But all these are new words for us.

The Meaning of the Word Sat

The Supreme Brahma is of the nature of sat (pure existence). Sat originally referred to existence. The meaning “good” came to sat only later. What exists for a long time is sat. The word sat stems from the root тИЪas = bhuvi (in existence). Words such as satya, asti, come from the same тИЪas. Whatever exists is sat. Existence here is existing as-is. Whatever exists unbothered and untainted by the past, present, or future, is unchanged at any time, and is of the same form throughout, is known as sat. That is satya (Truth). Sat is that which is unmodified by the distinctions of time, place, season, limitation, or external actions. We saw this at the beginning of the work itself.

acchedyoтАЩyamad─БhyoтАЩyamakledyoтАЩ┼Ыoс╣гya eva ca,
nityaс╕е sarvagataс╕е sth─Бс╣ЗuracaloтАЩyaс╣Г san─Бtanaс╕е.
BG 2.24

The substance of sat is great, very great; greater than anything we can imagine as the greatest; Infinite; Limitless. That is why we call It Omnipresent or Brahma (that stems from the root тИЪbс╣Ыhi - vс╣Ыddhau (increase). Brahma is sat. This is all we can say about It - It exists. That is the only thing possible. It is foolhardy to venture to say anything beyond it. Our ancestors have added two other characteristics to sat - cit (consciousness) and ─Бnanda (bliss). Both of these are considered taс╣нastha-lakс╣гaс╣Зa^(^([2])) rather than svar┼лpa-lakс╣гaс╣Зa^(^([3])). Cit and ─Аnanda - the liс╣Еgas (markers) of Brahma - are like those characteristics of a swimmer visible to one who is standing on the shore (taс╣нastha). The liс╣Еga is a symbol or a marker used to denote the principle behind it. We notice a bit of both cit and ─Бnanda in practice. But sat is something that is devoid of any markers and is without activity and thus unnoticeable in practice. That can only be experienced - buddhigr─Бhyam at─лndriyam. It is not possible to establish its existence through reasoning. It is pure being and pure existence, known in Greek and Latin as ousia and esse respectively. In Saс╣Гskс╣Ыta, it is known as satt─Б.

The Two States of Sat

We can contemplate upon two states of Brahma - 1. Vyakta (manifest). This is prakс╣Ыti. This is k─Бrya-brahma (Brahma as effect) 2. Avyakta (unmanifest) that is also known as k─Бraс╣Зa-braс╕еma (Brahma as cause). The latter is also known as Pure existence or Parabrahma. The manifest is known as vyakta and the unmanifest is known as avyakta in the eighth chapter of the G─лt─Б.

avyakt─Бd vyaktayaс╕е sarv─Бс╕е prabhavanty-ahar─Бgame
r─Бtry-─Бgame pral─лyante tatraiv-─Бvyakta-saс╣Гj├▒ake
BG 8.18

paras-tasm─Бttu bh─БvoтАЩnyoтАЩvyaktoтАЩvyakt─Бt-san─Бtanaс╕е
yaс╕е sa sarveс╣гu bh┼лteс╣гu na┼Ыyatsu na vina┼Ыyati
BG 8.20

When does pure existence become manifest? When it becomes visible in the form of the world. The manifest aspect of Brahma is known as jagat (the world). What is the cause of the world? Supreme Brahma. Statements such as “janm─Бdyasya yataс╕е”^(^([4])), “yato v─Б im─Бni bh┼лt─Бni j─Бyante”^(^([5])), “sarvam khalvidam brahma tajjal─Бnityup─Бs─лta”^(^([6])) convey the same purport. The world is subservient to Brahma and exists on the foundation of Brahma. Prakс╣Ыti is created from the cit aspect of Brahma.

Prakс╣Ыti is prakarс╣г─Б kс╣Ыtiс╕е - an excellent and vast creation. Whose work is it? The limitless energies that are in Brahma are the matter under consideration now. How limitless is the consciousness of Brahma - Its cicchakti! It is beyond thought! What exists in it and does not exist in it cannot be said. Its capability exceeds imagination. Its expression itself is Prakс╣Ыti - a great action that is the entire Universe! Whatever can be experienced by our eyes, ears and other sense organs, whatever can be imagined or inferred by our intellect - all that is Prakс╣Ыti. All our systems of knowledge, thought, reasoning, and distinction belong to the realm of Prakс╣Ыti. The arena of our everyday life is pervaded by Prakс╣Ыti. The world is the place where we demonstrate the energies of our mind, intellect, and talent. This manifest world then is permeated by тАЬunmanifest existenceтАЭ within and without.

An iceberg floats in the great ocean of the unmanifest. The iceberg is water too; but with the form of an iceberg. The ocean is the unmanifest; the iceberg is the manifest. The manifest is something that can be recognised. This recognisable universe floats in the ocean of the unrecognisable unmanifest. The unmanifest aspect of Brahma is like air sustaining a floating balloon within and without. Is not that in which something floats greater than the thing itself? This is also what the ┼Ыruti says - “p─БdoтАЩsya vi┼Ыv─Б bh┼лt─Бni ред trip─Бdasy─Бmс╣Ыtaс╣Г divi”. P─Бda refers to a quarter. The solar orb, the lunar orb, the earth, the visible universe - all together comprise just a quarter of Brahma. Thrice or many times as big as the manifest world is the unmanifest or the invisible.

Thus Brahma has two aspects - the manifest and unmanifest - or visible and invisible. That is why our ancients said - vyakt─Бvyakta-svar┼лp─Бya (of the nature of the manifest and unmanifest) whenever they remembered Brahma. In all things movable and immovable, whatever is seen and felt by us, whatever has movement, is all pervaded by Brahma. It is in this way that It is omnipresent and omniscient. That is the reason for It to be known as Viс╣гс╣Зu which means all-pervading. As it exists in everybody as their own ─Бtm─Б (self), It is known as param─Бtm─Б.

idaс╣Г sarvamasс╣Ыjata ред^(^([7]))

tatsс╣Ыс╣гс╣нv─Б tadev─Бnupr─Бvi┼Ыat рее^(^([8]))

Having created the entire universe, the Supreme Brahma entered it. This was expressed by the Vedic seers as a story.

After being created, the creature required food and other things for sustenance. How is it possible to manage all this without an overseer? It was thus that Brahma became ─к┼Ыvara - the controller. The aspect of omnipresence is referenced by the term param─Бtm─Б whereas parame┼Ыvara refers to the aspect of the omnipotent ruler of the universe. The same principle thus appears in two forms to our words and thoughts.

What is the ─Бtm─Б?

Whatever a being refers to when he says тАШIтАЩ, тАШmeтАЩ, is the ─Бtm─Б (Self)^(^([9])). (See the second chapter) The object referenced by the word aham (I) is the self. The self is consciousness in its essential state. When this consciousness assumes the body and other instruments of karma, it becomes known as the j─лva or j─лv─Бtm─Б. Sometimes, the complete collection of the body, sense organs, mind, and other instruments is referred to as the ─Бtm─Б. This is the normal practice of common people. Even the mind is referred to by the word ─Бtm─Б. The j─лva other than the mind and body is also known as the ─Бtm─Б. An old saying goes:

yacc─Бpnoti yad─Бdatte yacc─Бtti viс╣гay─Бniha
yacc─Бsya santato bh─Бvaс╕е tasm─Бd─Бtmeti kathyate
Liс╣Еgapur─Бс╣Зa 1.70.96

тАЬWhatever obtains (what comes), whatever takes (what it wants), whatever experiences the objects of the universe, whatever endures without a gap, is known as the ─Бtm─Б.тАЭ

The j─лva is the gross form or at the centre of the individual in the happenings of the world. The inner seed of the j─лva is the ─Бtm─Б.

The State of the J─лva

When an up─Бdhi (limiting adjunct) is applied to the ─Бtm─Б, it becomes known as the j─лva. An up─Бdhi is something - ─Бdhi - that can be said to be externally added. External events like suffering (vy─Бdhi) and disease are also up─Бdhis. The word up─Бdhi is also used in the sense of a title or a designation. If a pink rose is kept next to a transparent glass marble, the marble appears pink in colour. The colour pink is an up─Бdhi for the marble. A garland of flowers is strung using a thread. The fragrance of the flowers becomes an up─Бdhi for the thread that is, the thread acquires a quality that did not belong to it. An aspect that does not belong to a thing but is attached to it externally is an up─Бdhi. Once the universe is created, it has to be administered and hence the contact with the universe. Therefore, the Supreme Brahma assumes a few up─Бdhis. When the ─Бtm─Б appears with these up─Бdhis, it is known as the j─лva. When the actionless ─Бtm─Б is seen as an effect, it becomes known as a j─лva.

Let us clarify the meanings of a few repeatedly used terms such as j─лv─Бtm─Б, param─Бtm─Б and ─к┼Ыvara.

We see growth and decline in every living being. Ingestion of food and its egestion are seen in all animals. All living beings - including plants - take in food and extrude something else. Growth comes from intake and decline comes when intake reduces. This is something that the j─лva does. It fattens the body for its first twenty years and wears out the body for the rest of its life. Insentient objects work due to human contact. To humans, they are mere implements. Objects that cannot act by themselves and need something else for their movement are termed jaс╕Нa (insentient). The G─лt─Б refers to such objects as apar─Б. It is an inferior grade of creation.

The j─лva holds its inner consciousness and external insentient objects together. The ─Бtm─Б assumes various forms to accomplish a variety of tasks. Those forms are up─Бdhis.

The world exists because of the j─лva. It is because of the existence of the j─лva that the mind and other organs are functional. We should understand that man comprises two parts - the j─лva and the non-j─лva. The insentient part is the non-j─лva. But it should not be despised as inferior. We are familiar only with the inferior part while the superior part is beyond our senses. We can see the superior aspect only via the inferior part. We must strive to understand the unfamiliar through the familiar.

The seed of consciousness within a j─лva is the ─Бtm─Б or the j─лv─Бtm─Б. The layer outside it is the body. The j─лva is a combination of the inner ─Бtm─Б and the external body. Worldly actions are dependent on external appearances. When a person known to us is dressed in a khaki uniform with ribbons and wears red headgear, he is known as a soldier. If the same person appears to us with his head shaved and donning saffron robes, he is known as a saс╣Гny─Бsin. Similarly, the ─Бtm─Б along with the organs of action and the organs of knowledge such as the body is known variously as a j─лva, animal, being, and a living thing.

J─лv─Бtm─Б-Param─Бtm─Б

In the innumerable mass of living beings in this world, when each being is considered separately, that unique being is known as vyaс╣гс╣нi. When the entire set of j─лvas is considered together, that group is referred to as samaс╣гс╣нi according to ┼Ы─Бstric terminology. A hundred-rupee note is samaс╣гс╣нi. When each rupee coin is counted individually and separately, it is known as vyaс╣гс╣нi.

[[Ch. 7 Yoga of Jagat-J─лva-─к┼Ыvara (Part 2) Source: prekshaa]]

The State of ─к┼Ыvara

From the perspective of the visible world, the invisible and divisionless part of the universe, Supreme Brahman is known as ─к┼Ыvara or Parame┼Ыvara. When the pure, formless, and actionless Brahman assumes the position of the universal controller, it is known as Parame┼Ыvara. There are no differences such as the ruler and ruled in the transcendental state of Brahman. When that consciousness exists as part of the world and is seen as the ruler of the universe, it is known as ─к┼Ыvara.

This cursory explanation is a necessary introduction to the following topic. Our subsequent inquiry will become easy if we know at least the broad meaning of terms such as j─лva, jagat, ─к┼Ыvara, ─Бtm─Б and Brahman. Let us now return to the treatise.

Insentient Prakс╣Ыti

The thing we know directly is the world. That indeed is Prakс╣Ыti. ┼Ъ─Бstric deliberation begins with this. Prakс╣Ыti is of two kinds - apar─Б or inferior and par─Б or superior. The former (and visible aspect) is better known to us. It has eight parts to it.

bh┼лmir─БpoтАЩnalo v─Бyuс╕е khaс╣Г mano buddhireva ca
ahaс╣Гk─Бra it─лyaс╣Г me bhinn─Б prakс╣Ыtiraс╣гс╣нadh─Б
BG 7.4

Earth, water, fire, air, and the sky are the five primordial elements. Their respective qualities - smell, taste, light, touch and sound are experienced by the mind, the intellect and ego - which constitute the antaс╕еkaraс╣Зa. Thus these eight (five sense organs and three mental components) are the components of Prakс╣Ыti which form the functional implements of the power of the Supreme Brahman.

The first five of these elements combine and work with external facing sensory organs - the nose, tongue, eyes, skin and the ear. The mind (manas), intellect (buddhi) and ego (ahaс╣Зk─Бra) are antaс╕еkaraс╣Зa.

There is a school of thought that there are four antaс╕еkaraс╣Зa. This school includes citta (thought, intention) as the fourth organ. But if we were to add something like this, we should add many more components such as memory. Such issues are best dealt with by considering all such components as parts of the manas.

The function of the manas is to know the objects of the world. The buddhi processes the information given by the manas and decides what is suitable or not. Ahaс╣Зk─Бra assigns an objective to the buddhi. Whenever an object is perceived, it is natural to consider the question, “What of it to me?” This natural practice of extending the personal тАШIтАЩ during the perception of every object with is ahaс╣Зk─Бra. (There is a separate appendix that deals with the topic of ahaс╣Зk─Бra).

Thus the universe comprises the five primordial elements, five organs of sensory perception and the three antaс╕еkaraс╣Зa. Adding the five organs of action (speech, hands, legs and the two nether orifices) to the mentioned makes up the eighteen important parts of human life. This world is thus the arena of action of these eight or eighteen parts.

K─Бlid─Бsa describes the eight bodies of the supreme ┼Ъiva by replacing manas, buddhi and ahaс╣Зk─Бra with the sun, moon and the yajam─Бna (the performer of a yaj├▒a). ┼Ъaс╣Еkar─Бc─Бrya, like K─Бlid─Бsa, praises Lord Dakс╣гiс╣З─Бm┼лrti in the following verse.

bh┼лrambh─БsyanaloтАЩniloтАЩmbaramaharn─Бtho him─Бс╣Г┼Ыuс╕е pum─Бn
ity─Бbh─Бti car─Бcar─Бtmakamidaс╣Г yasyaiva m┼лrtyaс╣гс╣нakam

Amarasimha, the creator of the Amarakosha, accepts the primacy of the eight-fold form of the Supreme ┼Ъiva.

aс╣гс╣нam┼лrtyahirbudhnyo mah─Бk─Бlo mah─Бnaс╣нaс╕е

Sentient Prakс╣Ыti

The previous section dealt with the eight parts of the apar─Б or inferior prakс╣Ыti that is deemed inferior as it is insentient and not independent. Manas, buddhi and ahaс╣Зk─Бra are also insentient as they are incapable of doing anything without contact with the j─лva. They act only when the j─лva-consciousness enters them. This is why the j─лva is regarded as belonging to the par─Б category or superior prakс╣Ыti.

apareyam-itas-tvany─Бс╣Г prakс╣Ыtiс╣Г viddhi me par─Бm
j─лvabh┼лt─Бс╣Г mah─Бb─Бho yayedaс╣Г dh─Бryate jagat
BG 7.5

The world is of the j─лva and for the j─лva. The world does not exist without the j─лva. There is no reason for the world to exist without the j─лva. The world consists of the implements needed to satisfy the reason for a j─лvaтАЩs existence. The world is the arena of opportunity for the j─лva. The j─лva lacks fulfillment without the world. Thus the world and the j─лva are symbiotically related. They constitute the top and the bottom of the body of prakс╣Ыti.

The j─лva is a subject in the empire of prakс╣Ыti. The five primordial elements and others constitute its officials. Who is its king? Parame┼Ыvara - the Supreme controller - the aspect of Supreme Brahman that controls - whose functional forms are Brahm─Б, Viс╣гс╣Зu and ┼Ъiva.

ahaс╣Г kс╣Ыtsnasya jagataс╕е prabhavaс╕е pralayastath─Б
BG 7.6

Both the world and the j─лva are endowed with form. Hence they undergo various modifications such as birth and death. ─к┼Ыvara is not subject to birth and death. While he himself is without birth or death, ─к┼Ыvara is the reason behind the modifications of the world and the j─лva such as birth and death. Thus Supreme Brahman is of the form of the trinity of Brahm─Б (the creator), Viс╣гс╣Зu (the preserver) and ┼Ъiva (the destroyer).

The Marks of Brahman

How is one to recognise the existence of ─к┼Ыvara? The characteristics of the presence of ─к┼Ыvara are described in the four verses beginning from “rasoтАЩhamapsu” to “dharm─Бviruddho bh┼лteс╣гu”.

rasoтАЩham apsu kaunteya prabh─Бsmi ┼Ыa┼Ыi-s┼лryayoс╕е
praс╣Зavaс╕е sarva-vedeс╣гu ┼Ыabdaс╕е khe pauruс╣гaс╣Г nс╣Ыс╣гu
puс╣Зyo gandhaс╕е pс╣Ыithivy─Бс╣Г ca teja┼Ы-c─Бsmi vibh─Бvasau
j─лvanaс╣Г sarva-bh┼лteс╣гu tapa┼Ы-c─Бsmi tapasviс╣гu
b─лjaс╣Г m─Бс╣Г sarva-bh┼лt─Бn─Бс╣Г viddhi p─Бrtha san─Бtanam
buddhir-buddhi-mat─Бm asmi tejas tejasvin─Бm-aham
balaс╣Г balavat─Бс╣Г c─Бhaс╣Г k─Бma-r─Бga-vivarjitam
dharm─Бviruddho bh┼лteс╣гu k─БmoтАЩsmi bharata-rс╣гabha
BG 7.8-10

The taste in food and drink, the light in the sun and the moon, enterprise in humankind, effulgence in fire, life in organisms, the austerity among the austere, the intelligence of the intelligent, the strength of the strong that is devoid of selfishness, the desire of those who do not perform adharma - all of these show the power of Brahman. Whatever is excellent in the world are all marks of the greatness of Brahman.

Thus, sv─Бm─л here has mentioned only those qualities that are essentially the best because he wants to enumerate the salient signs and not everything. Even though all, including greed and the inclination for evil, is Brahman, Bhagav─Бn here talks only about the important marks. Adh─Бrmic works come under the purview of Brahman but do not constitute its main markers. “Dharma + aviruddho bh┼лtesu” (that which is not against dharma). The same expression is seen in the tenth chapter as well.

yad-yad-vibh┼лtimat sattvam╠Б ┼Ыr─лmad-┼лrjitam eva v─Б
tat-tad-ev─Бvagaccha tvam╠Б mama tejoтАЩm╠Б┼Ыa-sambhavam
BG 10.41

Whatever in this world is glorious, auspicious, and brilliant is to be known as a mark of Brahman. There is a certain value associated with every single thing in this world. Whatever quality endows a thing with usefulness and value belongs to the power of Brahman. The Veda describes the same as follows.

ya evaс╣Г veda

Whatever is tranquility in speech, whatever is acquiring and preservation in the incoming and outgoing of breath, whatever is the ability to do things with the hands, whatever is the power of movement in the legs, whatever is the power of satiation in rain, the energy in lightning (electricity) that is capable of many things, the handsome appearance in domestic animals, light in the stars - all these manifest Parabrahman. They are to be worshipped considering that Brahman is in them.

The Element of Asat in the World

As we just saw, the divine manifests in both human and superhuman activities. Just as what is considered useful has a place in our lives, even that which we consider useless has a place in our lifeтАЩs arena. Even those seemingly devoid of value are divine in nature.

nilayanaс╣Г c─Бnilayanaс╣Г ca
vij├▒─Бnaс╣Г c─Бvij├▒─Бnaс╣Г ca
satyaс╣Г c─Бnс╣Ыtaс╣Г ca
- Taittir─лyopaniс╣гat

He became the well-founded and that without a foundation, the intelligent and the non-intelligent, the true and the untrue.

The above ┼Ъruti text has the same gist.

ye caiva s─Бttvik─Б bh─Бv─Б r─Бjas─Бs t─Бmas─Б┼Ы ca ye
matta eveti t─Бn viddhi na tvahaс╣Г teс╣гu te mayi
BG 7.12

Whatever is endowed with the qualities of sattva, rajas, or tamas, have all emanated from Brahman. But Brahman is not in those guс╣Зas and their modifications. The guс╣Зas, however, are in Brahman.

The ocean has water-bubbles and foam in it. But the foam does not contain the ocean in it. The sky contains clouds that are formed of water droplets; but the sky is not in the cloud. The body contains so many substances that are not really parts of the body. Hair and nails arise from the body, but are not necessary for the maintenance of life. Similarly, in prakс╣Ыti - the body of Brahman - many things occur such as the imbalances of the guс╣Зas such as exuberances in rajas and tamas. But those are not characteristics of Brahman. Brahman is not тАШpresentтАЩ in them.

The Necessity for the Imbalance of the Guс╣Зas

The quality of asat - that which is not s─Бttvika - which refers to r─Бjasa and t─Бmasa are needed for the functioning of the world. Just sattva by itself is insufficient. The ┼Ы─Бstras have mentioned these three guс╣Зas at every step.

Why three guс╣Зas? Why not just two? Or four for that matter? Conflict in this world becomes possible because of an “odd” number. No conflict is possible with only one. If there are two, one can defeat the other. A third is needed to separate the two. This imbalance has to exist constantly. The world cannot exist without this imbalance. For the worldтАЩs existence, that is, for the worldтАЩs activities to take place, a conflict amongst these three guс╣Зas is fundamentally necessary. Prakс╣Ыti has established this in her creation. “O Human, I have set up this conflict amongst these three guс╣Зas. Overcome them if you can”, is a challenge that prakс╣Ыti has thrown at us.

[[Ch. 7 Yoga of Jagat-J─лva-─к┼Ыvara (Part 3) Source: prekshaa]]

M─Бy─Б

Why does this discernment of thought not exist normally in people? Bhagav─Бn answers:

m─Бy─Бy─БтАЩpahс╣Ыtaj├▒─Бn─Бс╕е

M─Бy─Б has taken away the discerning ability of people.

M─Бy─Б is a special mechanism in the operation of prakс╣Ыti. It is an error or mistake that arises during an inconsistency during the comprehension of other objects by the mind. Consistency here refers to compatibility; not just a lack of opposition but also positive agreement. It is important that there be agreement between these two aspects to see an object properly.

1. The seerтАЩs vision has to be fit.
2. Adequate light should fall on the object of sight.

A deficiency in even one of these hampers the knowledge of the object. A lacuna in either the seerтАЩs visual acuity or in how the object is viewed will lead to false or incomplete knowledge. Nothing else needs to be said for defects in both. Tradition terms the lacuna in the seerтАЩs vision as avidy─Б and the change in the seen (say, the shine of silver mistakenly seen in nacre) is known as m─Бy─Б. Avidy─Б that has the j─лva as its locus and the world-deluding M─Бy─Б are counterparts that mutually reinforce each other.

The world dances; the eye throbs. The resultant vision is that of m─Бy─Б.

A man is travelling to a town at dusk when darkness falls. He sees an object on the way. It appears to sway from side to side. He thinks it to be a snake and runs away afraid. He shivers and sweats. Another approaches him and inquires about the reason for his fear. When told that it was because of a snake, the latter laughs and tells him that it was not a snake but a piece of rope. M─Бy─Б is that which made a rope to appear as a snake in dim light. That which made the man unable to see through that fiction is his own avidy─Б.

M─Бy─Б is not falsehood. Neither is it true. The rope elicited all those reactions such as fear and sweating that a real snake would. The тАШsnakeтАЩ he saw appeared to be a snake, even though it was not. The memory of a snake seen elsewhere superimposed on the substratum of the rope caused the delusion of the snake. Thus M─Бy─Б is that unique set of circumstances that makes one thing appear as another. M─Бy─Б is not entirely a lie; but is definitely not the truth either. In the preceding story, the delusion would not have occurred had either the piece of rope or the memory of the snake not been there. That which caused fear and suffering in the person even before he could analyse the situation is avidy─Б.

When we travel in the hot sun in automobiles or trains, we sometimes see тАШlakesтАЩ shimmering far away. Those are not lakes in reality but heat haze. Due to the variation in temperature from the air near the hot ground to the cooler air above it, air density gradually decreases with increasing temperature, thereby varying the refractive index of the air. This produces a shimmering effect that the seer considers water. This is M─Бy─Б. The play of air and temperature outside and the thirst within.

When we lift our heads, it appears as if a blue clothed canopy has been pitched above us. But there is no tent or fabric or plank in the sky; it is space; empty space. The blue colour of the sky is an illusion. Due to the scattering of blue light by the earthтАЩs atmosphere, the sky appears blue. Whatever the reason might be, this misapprehension in our vision is well known. That error stems from m─Бy─Б.

Let us look at one more example. Assume we are travelling from Bengaluru to Maisuru. When our train reaches Maddur station, suppose that we see the train from Maisuru start for Bengaluru through the window. Though our train is stationary, it appears as if it is our train that is moving and not the train from Maisuru. The masked or changed appearance of the actual situation presented to our minds is m─Бy─Б. A thing appearing as something else is m─Бy─Б. Also, the non-appearance of an existing thing is also m─Бy─Б.

The Twofold Nature of M─Бy─Б

M─Бy─Б acts in two ways.

1. Showing a thing as something else. This power of m─Бy─Б is known as vikс╣гepa. A waterless desert in the afternoon sun shining appears as a reservoir of water from afar. That is a mirage. That is an example of m─Бy─БтАЩs vikс╣гepa.
2. Masking an existing thing and showing it as non-existent is ─Аvaraс╣Зa. A big tree makes its generating seed invisible. When a plant grows into a big tree, we get the impression that the tree had existed in the same state forever. It makes us forget that a seed was its cause. M─Бy─БтАЩs power of concealing the truth is known as ─Аvaraс╣Зa. The outer beauty of the body conceals urine, stools, and pus from bothering our mind. This is the power of ─Аvaraс╣Зa.

It is not possible to elucidate this two-fold m─Бy─Б further because m─Бy─Б can be considered existent via one perspective and non-existent via another. It is present if we consider it to be there and absent if we consider it as not there. M─Бy─Б is something that is impossible to exactly delineate.

sann─Бpyasann─Бpyubhay─Бtmik─Б no bhinn─Бpyabhinn─Бpyubhay─Бtmik─Б no
s─Бс╣Еg─Бpyanaс╣Еg─Бpyubhay─Бtmik─Б no mah─Бdbhut─Бnirvacan─лyar┼лp─Б
Vivekac┼лс╕Н─Бmaс╣Зi 111

Neither being nor non-being; not simultaneously being and non-being; Not different; Not non-different; not simultaneously different and non-different. Not endowed with parts; not unendowed with parts; not simultaneously both. It is a great wonder and is beyond verbal description - such as тАЬThis its origin; thus its existenceтАЭ and so on.

The person who overcomes beginningless avidy─Б that is propagated through the succession of births is unaffected by m─Бy─Б.

In conclusion, whatever false appearance we call a delusion or an error or mistaken perception is caused by m─Бy─Б. We can see more of it in other places.

The Dominance of M─Бy─Б

The reason for this long discussion on m─Бy─Б is the impact it has on our lives. M─Бy─Б is the universal power that brings the error of avidy─Б in the perceiverтАЩs intellect to fruition. Because of that film on our perception, we are unable to see the ever present association between jagat and ─к┼Ыvara or the essential relationship between the j─лva and param─Бtm─Б. M─Бy─Б causes the j─лva to view its normally perceived world as ever permanent. It is also the cause of the j─лvaтАЩs ego-centric delusions such as, тАЬI am the ruler, I am the enjoyerтАЭ. Mighty indeed is m─Бy─Б. It is impossible for us to comprehend the reality of the relationship between jagat and ─к┼Ыvara or that between j─лva and ─к┼Ыvara without overcoming m─Бy─Б. As m─Бy─Б is the greatest impediment towards the knowledge of reality, we had to have this lengthy discourse on it.

The Limitations of the Intellect

Just as fog envelops the bodyтАЩs eye, the mindтАЩs eye, so to speak, is also covered by a fog. The mindтАЩs rays of attention are scattered on the one hand by the latent impressions of previous births (v─Бsanas), and on the other hand by the tastes, glitter, and glamour of the world. Similarly, while there are long standing habits and unexamined beliefs on one side, new thought processes and new developments in the world seem to fly in their face. Our intellectual faculties are scattered between the two. While manтАЩs intellectual capacity is essentially limited, it is also paralysed by latent v─Бsanas and old beliefs. With these limits, the mindтАЩs deficiencies double. One side of the mind is fogged and the world it sees changes every moment, escaping any kind of comprehension and analysis. How therefore can one glimpse reality with partial vision on one side and constant change on the other? With that, even tin will be valued like silver. The crow will be welcomed as a koel. The foam of water bubbles will be mistaken for a white rocky mountain. A lake stagnant with moss and hyacinth appears like a lush meadow. Thus does universal m─Бy─Б trick the mind and intellect out of comprehending reality.

tribhir guс╣Зa-m─Бy─Бir bh─Бvair ebhiс╕е sarvam idaс╣Г jagat
mohitaс╣Г n─Бbhij─Бn─Бti m─Бmebhyaс╕е param avyayam рее
daiv─л hyeс╣г─Б guс╣Зa-may─л mama m─Бy─Б duratyay─Б
m─Бm eva ye prapadyante m─Бy─Бm et─Бс╣Г taranti te рее
BG 7.13, 7.14

The three guс╣Зas:sattva, rajas and tamas present in prakс╣Ыti have enveloped the world in delusion. As Brahma is beyond those three guс╣Зas, the world cannot understand that Brahma is ever unchanging. M─Бy─Б comprising these three guс╣Зas is of divine origin and is hence difficult to overcome.

The principle of jagat, j─лva, and ─к┼Ыvara eludes us because the veil of m─Бy─Б shrouds us. With that veil cast off, the Supreme Truth can be attained. Has not Bhagav─Бn himself declared that his m─Бy─Б is inscrutable? Bhagav─Бn himself shows the way by declaring that only those who take refuge in him are able to cross m─Бy─Б and attain the Supreme reality.

Crossing M─Бy─Б

M─Бy─Б with the guс╣Зa triad is of divine origin. We should not complain that this m─Бy─Б - this delusion - is cheating us because its place of creation is Brahma. Those who bear the thought of the Supreme Brahma in their minds are able to subdue m─Бy─Б. M─Бy─Б is one of the inferior activities of prakс╣Ыti. How is it possible to get rid of something inferior? By encouraging the superior. To get rid of malodour, one uses perfumes. M─Бy─Б, similarly, can be overcome through the practice of divine presence - by encouraging the knowledge of reality. As our conviction in the existence of the divine becomes firmer, the grip of m─Бy─Б loosens.

The Worship of Bhagav─Бn

It is thus established that the worship of Bhagav─Бn is essential for the knowledge of reality. A couple of words now, on the method of worship

chatur-vidh─Б bhajante m─Бс╣Г jan─Бс╕е sukс╣Ыitino’rjuna ред
─Бrto jij├▒─Бsur arth─Бrth─л j├▒─Бn─л cha bharatarс╣гabha рее
BG 7.16

Those who take refuge in Bhagav─Бn are of four kinds.

  1. ─Аrta (The distressed) - Those who resort to the divine only when they encounter difficulties in life personifying the adage - тАШsaс╣Гkaс╣нa baс╣Гd─Бga v─Хс╣Гkaс╣нaramaс╣ЗaтАЩ - тАШVenkataramana is resorted to only when there is distressтАЩ. 2. Jij├▒─Бsu (those desirous of knowing) - Those who are curious about the knowledge of the Supreme; students of the ┼Ы─Бstras. 3. Arth─Бrthi (those seeking material things) - Those who keep vows to attain specific material objectives. 4. J├▒─Бn─л (the knower) - those that have realised the knowledge of reality experientially.

All these four are sukс╣Ыtis which means that they possess the puс╣Зya from their good deeds. All the four are noble. The j├▒─Бn─л among them is one who has attained the object of his intention.

j├▒─Бn─л tv─Бtmaiva me matam

The j├▒─Бn─л is a keval─Бtm─Б: one who has attained union with ┼Ъr─л Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa.

bah┼лn─Бс╣Г janman─Бm ante j├▒─Бnav─Бn m─Бс╣Г prapadyate
v─Бsudevaс╕е sarvam iti sa mah─Бtm─Б su-durlabhaс╕е
BG 7.19

тАЬOthers, over several lives, gradually attain to the Supreme Abode through meditation upon the principle that V─Бsudeva is everything. Such great personages are rare to findтАЭ.

The way of overcoming m─Бy─Б is through the practice of ─к┼ЫvaraтАЩs presence. None need be disheartened that such a practice is impossible for them. One must practice with patience and without haste. The thing to remember is that this practice takes time. Let as much time be taken as required. As time is infinite, there is no need to hurry. But it is important that the practice being undertaken is done thoroughly. Be it a man or a woman, devotion to Bhagav─Бn can be practised according to oneтАЩs birth, oneтАЩs bent of mind, and as possible by oneтАЩs intellect. Let any method of worship be followed.

yo yo y─Бс╣Г y─Бс╣Г tanuс╣Г bhaktaс╕е ┼Ыraddhay─Бrchitum ichchhati

BG 7.21 to 7.23

тАЬWhoever worships whatever divine form with ┼Ыraddh─Б, I will firm up the ┼Ыraddh─Б for him in that form. If he has worshipped the form with ┼Ыraddh─Б, his desires will be fulfilled. I have established this arrangementтАЭ.

When these words are recalled by us, it becomes clear how our religious animosities are nothing but insubordination (to the divine) and a lack of humility. Not just Hindus but Muslims and Christians too should pay attention to this principle. It is not important whether the Supreme Being is with or without form. But the devotion and ┼Ыraddh─Б of the devotee is all important. Also important are the devoteeтАЩs mental attitude and the keenness of his yearning for the divine.

Keeping oneтАЩs mind in the divine is the same as not keeping oneтАЩs mind on things non-divine - which translates to releasing oneтАЩs mind from the non-divine. What then about oneтАЩs spouse and children? Are those relationships not boons from the divine? The one practising divine presence everywhere sees all relationships as ─к┼ЫvaraтАЩs blessing. Such a person regards his or her family duties as devotional service to Bhagav─Бn. There is nothing for such a person that is not Bhagav─Бn.

ichchh─Б-dveс╣гa-samutthena dvandva-mohena bh─Бrata
sarva-bh┼лt─Бni sammohaс╣Г sarge y─Бnti parantapa рее
yeс╣г─Бс╣Г tvanta-gataс╣Г p─Бpaс╣Г jan─Бn─Бс╣Г puс╣Зya-karmaс╣З─Бm
te dvandva-moha-nirmukt─Б bhajante m─Бс╣Г dс╣Ыс╕Нha-vrat─Бс╕е рее
BG 7.27, 7.28

тАЬAll beings at the time of their birth lose their ability for discernment when they are subservient to desires, hatred, ego, envy, and other pairs of opposites. Those whose p─Бpa has come to an end and those who have performed puс╣Зya become free of this pair of opposites and take refuge in ─к┼ЫvaraтАЭ.

This is the gist. Devotion to the divine means giving up selfishness and infatuation. As the thought that oneтАЩs family, kith and kin are blessings from the divine grows, selfishness and infatuation wane. As they wane, the j─лva becomes purer. As the j─лva becomes purer, contemplation of reality becomes easier. The one with the knowledge of reality understands what in oneтАЩs life is owed to the world and what is owed to oneтАЩs own inner self. Such a person, acting for the good of both, becomes free of worry. This is tranquillity.

The Upaniс╣гad uses the example of the spider (┼кrс╣Зan─Бbhi) to explain creation. The spider uses the sticky substance within itself to make a thread and weaves a web with it. It creates its own web-kingdom with the material created out of its own body and rules it as its king. During the creation of the web, it forgets that it is the creator. One who sings for oneтАЩs own happiness forgets oneself in the sweetness of oneтАЩs own voice. One enjoys it as if listening to someone elseтАЩs voice. The spider can similarly feel that its web creation was anotherтАЩs creation that it had conquered for itself. Thus a creator of something can be deluded into thinking that he is different from his creation after seeing the wonderful things of his own creation. In reality, the creator, the instrument, and the creation are fundamentally one. The sentience of Brahma is the doer, prakс╣Ыti is the instrument and the world is the creation. M─Бy─Б is the strange and wonderful play of the world. The indivisible unity of the root cause of the universe is veiled by the illusion of m─Бy─Б. ┼Ъ─Бstra shows us the concealing curtain and asks us to tear it and cast it away. As our ┼Ыraddh─Б in the Supreme Cause grows, the effect of m─Бy─Б on us weakens.
