Summary

The sv─Бm─л instructs Arjuna on the greatness of meditating upon the letter Om in the eighth chapter. Om is the essence, the representation of everything. The practice of meditation is predominantly emotional. The fundamental principle explained here is that such an emotional state can be reached with regular practice.

Chapter 8.Akс╣гarabrahmayoga orPraс╣Зav─Бrthayoga

(The Yoga of the meaning of Om)

In the previous chapters was discussed the practice of karma as an external means of s─Бdhan─Б. From the second to the sixth chapter, karma is important. Bhakti and j├▒─Бna are only incidentally mentioned. Chapters nine to eighteen discuss the internal s─Бdhan─Б of bhakti and j├▒─Бna. The eighth chapter is like a bridge between these two stages. The previous chapters have demonstrated the principle of ─Бtm─Б and the greatness of Bhagav─Бn. To realise this principle, the practice of an inward-looking s─Бdhan─Б becomes necessary. This s─Бdhan─Б is dhy─Бna. Sw─Бm─л is now ready to show the way to bring the form of the divine in the mind, by meditating upon profound symbols such as the praс╣Зava. It is only fit that this chapter has been called тАШBrahm─Бkс╣гaranirde┼ЫaтАЩ by ancient philosophers because praс╣Зava is verily the letter that denotes Brahma.

The important topics discussed in this chapter are -

  1. Some terminology 2. Importance of the moment of death 3. Up─Бsan─Б of the letter denoting the Brahma 4. Adherence to karma with constant remembrance of Brahma 5. The two ways open for the j─лva

It appears that Arjuna had not clearly understood the full meaning of some technical terms used by Bhagav─Бn ┼Ъr─л Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa earlier. Sometimes, our understanding of a word might be enough for us to roughly recognise the meaning but might fall short of the rigour required to explain it to someone else. We all use the word тАШmanтАЩ. If someone asks us the meaning of this word, we will find it difficult to explain. It is not enough to say, тАЬman is a kind of animalтАЭ. Similarly, when asked what rice is, it is not enough to answer that rice is a kind of grain. A proper, scientific answer can be provided for these questions by the dictionary. When this is the case with ordinary words, the terms used in advanced ┼Ы─Бstras must be much more difficult. However, continuing with the study of ┼Ы─Бstras without fully understanding these terms is meaningless. Such terms used in ┼Ы─Бstras are collectively known as paribh─Бс╣г─Б. The common meaning of karma is work тАФ any work. The ┼Ы─Бstric meaning of the word is тАЬspecific action that is ordained by ┼Ъruti and Smс╣Ыti, and results in gaining better worldsтАЭ.

ArjunaтАЩs questions about the meanings of the technical terms are in the first two verses. Commentators have counted them variously as seven and eight, though there is no real difference between the two groups. Let us look at these questions, one by one.

1. Question: Kiс╣Г tad-brahma? тАФ What is that Brahma?

In this question, тАШthatтАЩ тАФ тАШTatтАЩ implies an earlier reference. Arjuna is asking the meaning of тАЬbrahm─Бkс╣гara-samudbhavamтАЭ in the third chapter, and тАЬbrahm─Бrpaс╣Зaс╣Г braс╕еmahaviс╕етАЭ in the fourth chapter.

Answer: Akс╣гaraс╣Г brahma paramaс╣Г ред

Brahma is that which cannot be destroyed and is most supreme.

The word тАШakс╣гaraс╣ГтАЩ means both eternal and omnipresent. тАШKс╣гaraтАЩ is destruction. Akс╣гara means indestructible with respect to time and also with respect to place. тАШParamaс╣ГтАЩ means the basis of all that is desired by man, and yet above it it all. тАЬAс╣Зoraс╣З─лy─Бn mahato mah─лy─Бn редтАЭ, тАЬavyaktoтАЩyamacintyoтАЩyaс╣Г редтАЭ, тАЬacaloтАЩyaс╣Г san─Бtanaс╕етАЭ.

2. Question: Kim adhy─Бtmaс╣Г?

What is adhy─Бtma?

Answer: Svabh─БvoтАЩdhy─Бtmam-ucyate

тАЬHuman nature тАУ its entire structure - is called adhy─БtmaтАЭ

A human being is the sum total of his body, senses, mind, intellect, ego, j─лva, and ─Бtm─Б. This is collectively known as adhy─Бtma. The collection of the means and channels through which a j─лva can connect with the world and is able to conduct its activities is adhy─Бtma.

It is said in the bh─Бс╣гya of ┼Ъr─л ┼Ъaс╣Еkar─Бc─Бrya тАФ тАЬparasya brahmaс╣Зaс╕е pratidehaс╣Г pratyag─Бtma-bh─Бvaс╕е svabh─Бvaс╕е ред тАж ─Бtm─Бnaс╣Г dehamadhikс╣Ыtya pratyag─Бtmatay─Б pravс╣Ыttaс╣Г param─Бrtha-brahm─Бvas─Бnaс╣Г vastuтАЭ.

тАЬThe nature of Brahma is to exist in every body as the indwelling self. The thing that is the indwelling self of the body which is ultimately the same as the Supreme Brahma is adhy─Бtma.тАЭ

a. The ─Бtm─Б that is in the state of the j─лva is adhy─Бtma. The j─лva includes attributes like the body, mind, etc.
b.The state where ─Бtm─Б takes the form of the j─лva is adhy─Бtma. All relationships created by a man for himself are adhy─Бtma.

3. Question: kiс╣Г karma? тАЬWhat is karma?тАЭ

Answer: bh┼лtabh─Бvodbhavakaro visargaс╕е karmasaс╣Гj├▒itaс╕е ред

тАЬKarma is the agglomeration of all the ways in which all beings use their energies and wealth in tasks that result in their rebirthтАЭ.

Our transaction with the world is in the form of giving and taking. In every moment, through his body, speech, and mind, man constantly releases parts of himself into the world around him. This constant giving is karma. Since a part of him spreads itself out in the world, its results and reactions come back to him in different forms, as the fruit of his karma. He is reborn again and again to reap these fruits тАФ to discharge his debts and to experience the impressions of his past. Thus, karma is the collective name for all dealings with the world that cause rebirth. In short puс╣Зya and p─Бpa constitute karma.

4. Question: Adhibh┼лtaс╣Г ca kiс╣Г? тАЬWhat is adhibh┼лta?тАЭ

Answer: Adhibh┼лtaс╣Г kс╣гaro bh─Бvaс╕е ред

тАЬAll destructible things in this world are adhibh┼лta.тАЭ

тАЬKс╣гaro bh─Бvaс╕етАЭ means destructibility or the characteristic of destruction. тАШBh┼лtaтАЩ refers to something that has become or has happened. Here, we should pay attention to the difference between the words тАШbeingтАЩ and тАШbecomingтАЩ. Whatever becomes or happens, goes. Therefore it is kс╣гara. Thus, kс╣гara is something that lives for a short while and perishes later.

5. Question: Adhidaivaс╣Г kimucyate? тАЬWhat is called adhi-daiva?тАЭ

Answer: тАЬPuruс╣гa┼Ы-c─Бdhi-daivatamредтАЭ тАЬ(The vir─Бс╣н) puruс╣гa is adhidaivataтАЭ

BrahmaтАЩs energy is present in every being, causing it to engage in various activities. The aggregated energy of all those beings in its most exalted state (the state of Brahma) is the Vir─Бс╣н Puruс╣гa. This form has been described in the Puruс╣гas┼лkta of the Vedas and in the eleventh chapter of the Bhagavadg─лt─Б. Puruс╣гa is the Brahma in the form of the world. That is adhidaiva. This meaning has to be connected with

тАЬdaivaс╣Г caiv─Бtra pa├▒camaс╣Г редтАЭ (BG 18.14)

Adhidaiva is the fundamental energy that is the basis of all actions in the universe. It is the energy of Brahma, the universal consciousness, that creates the universe and controls it. Brahma in action is adhidaiva. That indeed is ─к┼Ыvara.

6. Question: тАЬ─Бdhiyaj├▒aс╕е kathaс╣Г?тАЭ тАЬWhat is the nature of adhiyaj├▒a?тАЭ

Answer: тАЬadhiyaj├▒oтАЩhamevaтАЭ тАЬThat to which the yaj├▒a is addressed is adhiyaj├▒a. I am that (Bhagav─Бn= ─к┼Ыvara).тАЭ

Yaj├▒a is worship. There should be an object for worship. Different types of yaj├▒as are expounded in the fourth chapter. Yaj├▒as can have different objects of worship such as Indra, Varuс╣Зa, Soma, or Agni. Thus, when there are different devat─Бs, are the presiding deities different and yaj├▒as different or are they all one and the same? The answer is that even though the names of the devat─Бs are different, it is only Brahma that is worshipped.

тАЬekaс╣Г sad vipr─Б bahudh─Б vadanti, indraс╣Г yamaс╣Г m─Бtari┼Ыv─Бnam─Бhuс╕е редтАЭ
тАЬsarvadeva-namask─Бraс╕е keahavaс╣Г pratigacchati редтАЭ

7. Question: тАЬkoтАЩtra deheтАЩsmin?тАЭ тАЬWho is in this body?тАЭ

Answer: тАЬAhamev─Бtra deheредтАЭ тАЬI (the divine) am the one in this bodyтАЭ.

The body comprises five sheaths. These sheaths are like a Russian doll - one inside another, yet another inside it and so on. Well-dressed men in the early twentieth century would wear five or six layers of clothes on them тАФ an overcoat, a short coat within it, a waistcoat inside that, and then a shirt and a vest inside, and further a jubba also. Similarly, the human body has five layers. The first is annamaya kosha. This is made of flesh, blood, skin, and bone. Within that is the pr─Бс╣Зamaya ko┼Ыa, comprising pr─Бс╣Зa, ap─Бna and other vital airs. The third is manomaya, consisting of experiences such as pleasure and pain. The fifth is vij├▒─Бnamaya, comprising the intellect and decision making abilities. The fifth is ─Бnandamaya, which comprises bliss. Within this resides the ─Бtm─Б, the basis and origin of all layers. The five ko┼Ыas are only its attributes. Param─Бtm─Б is that consciousness which resides within these five ko┼Ыas.

тАЬt─Бsm─Бt sarvagataс╣Г brahmaтАЭ (Therefore is Brahma all-pervading) (BG 3.15)
тАЬ─к┼Ыvaraс╕е sarvabh┼лt─Бn─Бс╣Г hс╣Ыdde┼ЫeтАЭ, (─к┼Ыvara is situated in the heart of all beings) (BG 18.61)
тАЬeko devaс╕е sarvabh┼лteс╣гu g┼лс╕Нhaс╕е sarvavy─Бp─л sarvabh┼лt─Бntar─Бtm─БтАЭ (There is one deva concealed in all beings who is omnipresent and is the inner self of all beings) (┼Ъvet─Б┼Ыvataropaniс╣гad 6.11)

It has to be noted that the object of worship in the sixth question is the same as the worshipper in the seventh question, the only difference between them being their state.

8. Question тАЬpray─Бс╣Зak─Бle ca kathaс╣Г j├▒eyoтАЩsi?тАЭ тАЬHow is a man to know you at the time of the final journey?тАЭ

тАЬAt that time of departure, how should one meditate upon you? You have countless forms; your l─лl─Бs are infinite. Which of them should we remember when our end is nigh?тАЭ

A: тАЬantak─Бle ca m─Бmeva smaran тАж madbh─Бvaс╣Г y─БtiтАЭ

тАЬIn those last moments, it is enough to meditate upon me in any form. My real nature will be understood.тАЭ.

Meditating upon any form among the infinite forms, any l─лl─Б among the infinite l─лl─Бs of the divine can show us the presence of the divine.

The sixth verse of this chapter has to be contemplated upon here.

yaс╣Г yaс╣Г v─Бpi smaran bh─Бvaс╣Г tyajatyante kalevaraс╣Г ред
taс╣Г tamevaiti kaunteya sad─Б tadbh─Бvabh─Бvitaс╕е рее (BG 8.6)
тАЬWhichever form the devotee is meditating upon at the time of his end,
Bhagav─Бn shows himself to his devotee in the same formтАЭ.

This is the reason for our practice of naming children after devat─Бs or Gurus. It is natural for humans to think of their loved ones at the time of death. Our ancients thought that divine names would be called out and the greatness of the divine would come to mind at least under this pretext.

Who knows when the end is going to arrive? Death does not give us prior notice to make an appointment with us. It can come without any warning. Therefore, a wise man is always prepared for it. Constant contemplation of the divine is the preparation.

тАЬtasm─Бt sarveс╣гu k─Бleс╣гu m─Бmanusmara yuddhya caтАЭ (BG 8.7)
тАЬRemember me at all times; Fight as you remember me.тАЭ

The Object of Dhy─Бna

Ordinary people require a symbol or a form for dhy─Бna. However, the supreme Brahma-tattva is тАШacintyar┼лpamтАЩ (beyond description) and тАШanirde┼Ыyavapuс╕етАЩ (with a form that cannot be pointed out). Even so, Bhagav─Бn has pointed out two characteristics -

sarvasya dh─Бt─Бram-acintyar┼лpam ─Бdityavarс╣Зaс╣Г tamasaс╕е parast─Бt рее (BG 8.9)

  1. Sarvasya dh─Бt─Бram тАФ One who rules over everything and protects everyone. 2. ─Аdityavarс╣Зaс╣Г тАФ Bright like the Sun.

These are the main characteristics. The marks of Brahma have been discussed extensively earlier; such as тАЬrasoтАЩham apsuтАЭ and тАЬprabh─Бsmi ┼Ыa┼Ыi-s┼лryayoс╕етАЭ. We can bring to mind any of these features: тАЬyaс╣Г yaс╣Г v─Бpi smaran bh─Бvaс╣ГтАЭ. It is important to concentrate the mind.

The praс╣Зava has to be meditated upon during dhy─Бna. Praс╣Зava means тАЬprakс╣Ыс╣гс╣н─Б nutiс╕етАЭ [Most excellent praise] (from the root с╣Зu stutau) тАУ the praise of Parabrahma.

Omityek─Бkс╣гaraс╣Г brahma vy─Бharan m─Бmanusmaran ред (BG 8.13)
The japa of Om has to be performed while meditating upon Bhagav─Бn.

Omityek─Бkс╣гaraс╣Г brahma ред (Om the letter denotes Brahma) (G─Бyatr─л-mantra)

Omiti brahma ред Omit─лdagm sarvam (Taittir─лyopaniс╣гad1.8)
тАЬOm itself is Parabrahma. Om is all this (the entire universe)тАЭ

Thus, Upaniс╣гads like Kaс╣нha, M─Бс╣Зс╕Н┼лkya, Ch─Бndogya and Bс╣Ыhad─Бraс╣Зyaka extol the greatness of the Praс╣Зava.

There are three letters in Om тАФ a, u and m. These three letters denote the following, respectively -

  1. a тАФ Sat (existence), the gross universe, the earthly plane, the male animal, the waking state, sattvaguс╣Зa, Bhagav─Бn Brahm─Б [Not to be confused with Brahman] 2. u тАФ Cit (consciousness), j─лva, the subtle universe, the atmosphere, the female animal, the dream state, rajoguс╣Зa, Bhagav─Бn Viс╣гс╣Зu 3. m тАФ ─Аnanda (bliss), ─к┼Ыvara, the causal universe (k─Бraс╣Зa-prapa├▒ca), the sky, an animal of the neuter gender, the state of deep sleep, tamoguс╣Зa, Bhagav─Бn Rudra. 4. Om тАФ (the union of all of the above) = Peaceful, Param─Бtm─Б, the unmanifested, genderless, the universe, the infinite prakс╣Ыti, vir─Бс╣н-puruс╣гa, transcending the three guс╣Зas, Parabrahma.

Thus, the letter om is a symbol that denotes everything. It denotes all existence, all knowledge and all powers and energies. The hidden meaning of this great mantra should be learnt from experienced people. I am not one.

The mantras that have been passed to us through tradition тАФ like Om Namah ┼Ъiv─Бya, Om Namo N─Бr─Бyaс╣З─Бya тАФ show us one of the infinite forms of Bhagav─Бn. It is difficult to visualise the infinite. Visualising an image of R─Бma, Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa, Some┼Ыvara, Gaс╣Зapati or ─А├▒janeya is not that difficult. M┼лrtis and pictures help with that. Therefore, ordinary people hold on to dhy─Бna-mantras of a specific deity and engage themselves in its worship. However, the Praс╣Зava is not specific to any form; contemplation is its mainstay. It includes both manifest and unmanifest, single and manifold. The three worlds, the three guс╣Зas, the three states (j─Бgrat, svapna and suс╣гupti), the three deities тАФ the essence of the universe is thus evinced in threes as the separate letters a, u and m тАФ and brings to mind one group among the three. Then, the combined letter Om establishes in the mind тАФ that the union of these three is greater than the sum of its parts. Initially, such contemplation seems impossible. It becomes possible gradually - little by little - with continuous effort and practice.

[[Ch. 8 Yoga of the Meaning of Om (Part 2) Source: prekshaa]]

The Importance of Feeling

During dhy─Бna, it is not syllables that are important, neither are sound or meaning. Feeling is paramount. The syllable is a means to bring the right feeling to the mind. M┼лrtis and pictures of deities, worship with incense sticks and lamps are also the means to bring to mind the emotion associated with the divine. Therefore, the mind should be made to focus on the meaning of the syllable тАФ the feeling associated with the icon. This is dhy─Бna-yoga.

Is it not easier for dhy─Бna if the syllable of a mantra has only one meaning, rather than a multitude of them? We saw earlier that praс╣Зava can have many meanings; will not the mind get scattered here and there by that? The answer is thus: a mantra that has a single meaning is suitable in the beginning. However, should not the meaning expand gradually? Initially, let it be “Om Namaс╕е ┼Ъiv─Бya” or “Om Namo N─Бr─Бyaс╣З─Бya”. Steadily, let the focus increasingly move towards Om. It is fine if any one among the various meanings of the praс╣Зava strikes the mind. It could be the triad of Brahma, Viс╣гс╣Зu and Mahe┼Ыvara тАФ or Earth, space and sky тАФ or sattva, rajas and tamas тАФ or energy, water and food тАФ whichever triad of these strikes the mind first, it gradually expands and covers all other triads, and transcends them all. This is the power of practice. As already conveyed, the secret has to be learnt from adepts; I am not one. Let us now move to the next topic.

ananyacet─Бс╕е satataс╣Г yo m─Бс╣Г bhajati nitya┼Ыaс╕е ред
tasy─Бhaс╣Г sulabhaс╕е p─Бrtha nityayuktasya yoginaс╕е рее (BG 8.14)

тАЬA yogi is one who does not let his mind wander, but follows me always. I (Bhagav─Бn) am easily obtained by him, who is always one with meтАЭ

─Бbrahma-bhuvan─Бl-lok─Бс╕е punar-─БvartinoтАЩrjuna ред
m─Бmupetya tu kaunteya punarjanma na vidyate рее (BG 8.16)

The entire universe тАФ starting from the world of Brahm─Б is born again and again, and perishes each time. “Punarapi jananaс╣Г punarapi maraс╣Зam” is true for everything and everyone, until the j─лvatma becomes one with Parabrahma. The liberated, pure ─Бtm─Б always abides in the presence of the Supreme Brahma тАФ that is, in the best of lokas. The Sv─Бmi now explains this exalted state.

In the previous chapter, it is said that Brahma exists in two states тАФ vyakta or manifest and avyakta or unimanifest. Vyakta is the visible or tangible universe. Avyakta is invisible or something that transcends the visible universe. The single fundamental substratum for both of these is san─Бtana (eternal); that is Brahma. Mokс╣гa is the constant experience of Brahma. Achieving Mokс╣гa is the fulfillment of Yoga.

parastasm─Бttu bh─БvoтАЩnyoтАЩvyaktoтАЩvyakt─Бt san─Бtanaс╕е ред
yaс╕е sa sarveс╣гu bh┼лteс╣гu na┼Ыyatsu na vina┼Ыyati рее (BG 8.20)
тАЬParabrahma is that which is beyond the manifest and unmanifest. It is the eternal element in transient bodiesтАЭ.

avyaktoтАЩkс╣гara ityuktastam─Бhuс╕е param─Бс╣Г gatiс╣Г ред
yaс╣Г pr─Бpya na nivartante taddh─Бma paramaс╣Г mama рее (BG 8.21)

After reaching the abode of Brahma which is beyond the universe, intangible and imperishable, there is no returning. That is the supreme abode, the presence of the divine. That is the state of mokс╣гa. A s─Бdhaka might achieve it in his lifetime on earth, in this world. Such mokс╣гa is j─лvanmukti. Our ┼Ыrutis and pur─Бс╣Зas mention that с╣Ыс╣гis like ┼Ъuka and V─Бmadeva were j─лvanmuktas.

Even if that does not happen, if a s─Бdhaka is free of k─Бma and krodha and is engrossed only in Brahma, he may attain mokс╣гa when he departs from his body and leaves this world. That is videhamukti. Thus, mokс╣гa is of two types.

There is no calculation of tithi, v─Бra and nakс╣гatra required for the attainment of mokс╣гa. It happens by itself. No outward force can speed it up or slow it down. It is an experience that happens deep within oneтАЩs heart. It does not have external dos and donтАЩts.

The liberation that is achieved by a j─лva after experiencing the fruits of its past actions and finally giving up his body is of two kinds тАФ sadyomukti and kramamukti.

Sadyomukti is that which is achieved when a s─Бdhaka leaves this world and becomes one with Brahma without stopping at any intervening stations. This path is called Devay─Бna. When a j─лva on the way to mukti pauses at other, gradually better lokas, it is kramamukti or pitс╣Ыy─Бna. The Sv─Бmi describes it thus тАФ

agnirjyotirahaс╕е ┼Ыuklaс╕е с╣гaс╣Зm─Бs─Б uttar─Бyaс╣Зam ред (BG 8.24)

The characteristics of the path to the Brahma are fire, light, day, purity, and the half of the year that is called uttar─Бyaс╣Зa.

dh┼лmo r─Бtristath─Б kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зaс╕е с╣гaс╣Зm─Бs─Б dakс╣гiс╣З─Бyanaс╣Г рее (BG 8.25)

The characteristics of the path to the other puс╣Зyalokas are smoke, night, darkness, the six months of the year that are known as dakс╣гiс╣З─Бyana.

┼Ыuklakс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зe gat─л hyete jagataс╕е ┼Ы─Б┼Ыvate mate ред
ekay─Б y─Бtyan─Бvс╣Ыttim anyay─БтАЩтАЩavartate punaс╕е рее (BG 8.26)

Through devay─Бna is achieved the state of Brahma and the cessation of births. Through pitс╣Ыy─Бna, one goes through multiple births тАФ gains puс╣Зya again and again, spends it, and gains it again тАФ thus continues the circle of births.

Pitс╣Ыy─Бna is the way of gradually better lives тАФ good family, justly acquired wealth, good karma, good children, good pastimes тАФ these are indicative of puс╣Зya. Even if a man established in Brahma is not able to achieve mokс╣гa immediately, even if he has to take a few more births because of various reasons, he sometimes attains better worlds and is again born on the earth in suitable families and leads a life established in Brahma.

pr─Бpya puс╣Зyakс╣Ыt─Бn lok─Бn uс╣гitv─Б ┼Ы─Б┼Ыvat─лс╕е sam─Бс╕е ред
┼Ыuc─лn─Бс╣Г ┼Ыr─лmat─Бс╣Г gehe yogabhraс╣гс╣нoтАЩbhij─Бyate рее (BG 6.41)

Thus, he ascends in steps. This is the mukti of Pitс╣Ыy─Бna. It is not to be understood as inferior or fearsome. Good progeny and good family are gained by the blessings of Pitс╣Ыdevatas; it is training to the j─лva. Should we be scared of training and tests? One who refuses such training is not eligible to experience Brahma.

The belief that death during the uttar─Бyaс╣Зa brings mokс╣гa and death during the dakс╣гiс╣З─Бyana brings about rebirth is older than the time of ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa. It is in the Vedas [Ya evaс╣Г vidv─Бnudagayane pram─лyate dev─Бn─Бmeva mahim─Бnaс╣Г gatv─Б’‘dityasya s─Бyujyaс╣Г gacchatyatha yo dakс╣гiс╣Зe pram─лyate pitс╣Ыс╣З─Бmeva mahim─Бnaс╣Г gatv─Б candramasass─Бyujyaс╣Г salokat─Бm─Бpnoti (Taittir─лyopaniс╣гad 4)].Bh─лс╣гma would have believed in it тАФ which is why he bore the severe pain of lying on a bed of arrows and waited for the arrival of uttar─Бyaс╣Зa.

Should we now believe in it or not? This belief is not troublesome; there is no reason to stop believing it. Just lack of direct evidence is not enough to erase this ancient belief. There should be a concrete reason to disbelieve in it. In any case, what do we lose by believing in it?

We can have three kinds of attitudes towards any concept тАФ 1. Belief 2. Disbelief 3. Suspension of belief.

All of us believe in our own existence. We say that eight elephants carrying the world is reality but is a mere story. But in the matter of pa├▒c─Бс╣Еga and j─Бtaka, we do not argue. If someone condemns it as untrue, we cannot prove it to be true. If someone obstinately argues that it is true, we cannot argue and prove him wrong. When many people have been believing in something for a very long time and it is not really troubling to us, it is better to follow it as much as possible. If someone says that the attack by China [in 1962] was because of the confluence of eight planets, we cannot say that it was not so. If someone says that the two are not related, we cannot argue with them either. Our consideration should only be this тАФ on the pretext of the aс╣гс╣нagrahas, the minds of at least a few people turned towards the divine. Even that is beneficial. Some people found courage and satisfaction because of those p┼лjas and homas. That is beneficial too.

The concept of uttar─Бyaс╣Зa-devay─Бna and dakс╣гiс╣З─Бyana-pitс╣Ыy─Бna should be viewed similarly. It is about something that happens after death тАФ something that cannot be seen by us here with our physical eyes. Actually, ordinary people like us cannot clearly discern the difference between uttar─Бyaс╣Зa and dakс╣гiс╣З─Бyana. Physicists or meteorologists may explain the physical difference to us. However, who can explain the passage of a j─лva?

The matter in the minds of those who harbour questions about this topic is actually a doubt about the superiority of devay─Бna and the inferiority of pitс╣Ыy─Бna. At the bottom of this is the question тАФ why should we say that those who die in dakс╣гiс╣З─Бyana are inferior? They fear that their end might arrive in dakс╣гiс╣З─Бyana. There are two things here.

  1. Pitс╣Ыy─Бna is not base or vile. If someone thinks that they are eligible for more, they are deluded. That sense of entitlement itself shows their ineligibility. 2. Pitс╣Ыy─Бna paves the way to obtain worldly wealth, pleasure, prosperity and progeny. How many of us can say no to these?

Those with the firmness and greatness of Bh─лс╣гma do not have to raise this question at all. He was a svecch─Бmaraс╣Зi тАФ he could give up his body whenever he wanted. There is no remedy for the delusion that that just dying in uttar─Бyaс╣Зa can bestow mukti. The goal of this chapter is mainly to inculcate ennobling emotion in people. It is certainly not the supreme truth. Like in other places, this is an instructive means of drawing attention to differences in the eligibility of aspirants to achieve mukti. The most important principle to take away from this chapter is -

tasm─Бt sarveс╣гu k─Бleс╣гu m─Бmanusmara yuddhya ca рее (BG 8.7)
(Therefore, at all times, fight while remembering me)

Summary

pathaveraс╕Нu paradi sukс╣Ыtige
sita-sauraс╣Г deva-y─Бnam-adu mokс╣г─Бrthaс╣Г ред
pitс╣Ыy─Бnaс╣Г satkula-saс╣Г-

Two ways there are to reach the divine for the righteous.
Bright and sunny is Devay─Бna, the way to mokс╣гa.
Pitс╣Ыy─Бna, the way to a better birth and training
To the j─лva, and brings about gradual progress.

Summary

The objects of the world function because of Brahma. Because of this, we confuse those objects for Brahma. We worship the glamour of the world while in fact, it is Brahma that should be worshipped. This is a mistake indeed. One should always remember that the world is a modification of Brahma-consciousness and that Brahma is beyond all the objects of the world.

Bhagav─Бn assures us that he will take up the responsibility of the entire well-being of whoever is completely dependent on him. What more assurance does one need?

Bhagav─Бn has affirmed that all devotion with ┼Ыraddh─Б reaches him and that he is propitious to those devoted to him. If all worldly actions such as taking in food and giving d─Бna are performed as offerings to ┼Ъr─лKс╣Ыsс╣Зa, the j─лva attains the Supreme Goal. We see the heart of the G─лt─Б-teaching in this chapter.

Chapter 9R─Бja-vidy─Б-r─Бja-guhya-yogaor Brahma-jagat-sambandha-yoga

(The Yoga of the Relationship between Brahman and the World)

In the previous chapter, after considering seven or eight questions such as тАЬkiс╣Г tadbrahmaтАЭ (What is Brahman?), тАЬadhibh┼лtam kim?тАЭ (What is adhibh┼лta) and what a pr─Бс╣З─л (being) is, Bhagav─Бn taught that OM (praс╣Зava), which denotes the entire collection of Jagat (world), J─лva and I┼Ыvara, has to be mentally meditated upon. Now will be elucidated the relationship between Brahma and Prakс╣Ыti - which is also the relationship between ─к┼Ыvara and the world.

This chapter covers the following topics:

  1. The omnipresence of Brahma 2. The subservience of the world to Prakс╣Ыti 3. The two-fold nature of Prakс╣Ыti 4. The attainability of I┼Ыvara 5. The worldly aspect of Dharma 6. Surrender to Bhagav─Бn

idaс╣Б tu te guhyatamaс╣Б pravakс╣гy─Бmy-anas┼лyave ред
j├▒─Бnaс╣Б vij├▒─Бna-sahitaс╣Б yaj-j├▒─Бtv─Б mokс╣гyaseтАЩ┼Ыubh─Бt рее
BG 9.1

The chapter begins with the above verse. The topic that Bhagav─Бn is about to tell us is the greatest secret! A mystery! What is that secret? A marketing trick or a profit-minded manoeuvre or a scheme for greater fame? This strategy is not for any worldly attainment but pertains only to the ─Бtm─Б. Therefore, only the eligible will be instructed here. If the ineligible are instructed in this matter, there is a chance of misunderstanding or misuse or trivialisation - all of which is harmful to the world. This verse thus is an exhortation to share this secret only after considering the studentтАЩs worthiness.

Don’t think of this secret as Br─Бhmaс╣Зa obscurantism. It is well known that our government limits the sales of drugs that are mixed with mercury, sulphur, lead or mandate a prescription for those medicines that can have significant side-effects upon accidental consumption. Such medicines or prescription drugs carry labels with warnings like тАШpoisonтАЩ or тАШfor prescription use onlyтАЩ or тАШoverdose can cause injury.тАЩ On the other hand, home remedies such as ginger, pepper, and cumin can be used as medicine by almost anyone. Even a healthy person is not adversely affected by their consumption. However, those medicines explicitly labelled are meant only for patients and not for general consumption. It is dangerous for others to consume such drugs. Therefore the pharmacist is legally bound to sell such drugs only when accompanied by a prescription and only to those for whom the drug has been prescribed.

Similar is the rule regarding the teaching of the Vedas, ┼Ы─Бstras, and the G─лt─Б. They have to be imparted only after due discernment about the fitness of the taught. These are not like commercial goods that are sold to the general public. These words of Matthew Arnold are worth remembering here тАУ

Some secrets may the poet tell,
For the world loves new ways;
To tell too deep ones is not wellтАФ
It knows not what he says.

Moreover, this is тАЬj├▒─Бnaс╣Б vij├▒─БnasahitamтАЭ (knowledge with realisation) тАУ which is essentially experiential and not bookish learning. The theoretical understanding gained through external sources of knowledge such as teachers and ┼Ы─Бstras is denoted as j├▒─Бna. To this should be added vij├▒─Бna тАУ the experiential realisation of j├▒─Бna through vich─Бra. Vich─Бra is the analysis of experience; a practical application of theory. Bhagav─Бn is now all set to teach the principle that is in agreement with both theory and experience.

This instruction is deemed тАШR─Бja-vidy─БтАЩ (the Royal Science) which means that it is the king of all vidy─Бs. Just as the KingтАЩs power enables all his subjects employed in different posts to enjoy proportionate benefits during the discharge of their duties, this r─Бja-vidy─Б enables assignment of the right values and positions of other vidy─Бs. Thus this knowledge of reality ought to be at the head of all other vidy─Бs.

r─Бja-vidy─Б r─Бja-guhyaс╣Б pavitram-idam-uttamam ред
pratyakс╣г─Бvagamaс╣Б dharmyaс╣Б susukhaс╣Б kartum-avyayam рее
BG 9.2

R─Бja-vidy─Б is also fittingly called R─Бja-yoga as it can be known through direct experience, is consistent with dharma, is easily performed, does not cause harm, is imperishable, and is easy to perform. Haс╣нha-yoga has opposite characteristics to R─Бja-yoga. While Haс╣нha-yoga is a teacher that brings the fear of punishment to students, R─Бja-yoga is a gentle and tactful teacher.

What then is the gist of this charming vidy─Б?

may─Б tatam-idaс╣Б sarvaс╣Б jagad-avyakta-m┼лrtin─Б ред
mat-sth─Бni sarva-bh┼лt─Бni na c─Бhaс╣Б teс╣гv-avasthitaс╕е рее
BG 9.4
na ca mat-sth─Бni bh┼лt─Бni pa┼Ыya me yogam-ai┼Ыvaram ред
bh┼лtabhс╣Ыn-na ca bh┼лtastho mam─Бtm─Б bh┼лta-bh─Бvanaс╕е рее
BG 9.5

(May─Б) By me (Brahma), (avyaktam┼лrtin─Б) who has no external characteristics such as form and quality, (jagat idam sarvam) all this world (tatam) is pervaded.
(Through one perspective) all beings reside in me, I am not in them.
(Another perspective) The worldтАЩs beings really do not reside in me. See my (BrahmaтАЩs) divine and wondrous yoga in the aspect of ─к┼Ыvara. It is Brahma-consciousness that is the origin and sustenance of this multitude of beings. But Brahma itself is not in them.

This is a complicated statement. It needs to be patiently reflected upon.

The inquiry here is about existence. In Samskс╣Ыtam, existence is known as astitva. The same is sat + t─Б (satt─Б) or sattva. The subject of existence, termed ontology, is an important aspect of Western philosophy. What are some questions about existence?

  1. A certain thing might exist and still not be perceived by anyone. 2. Even if it is perceived, it might be perceived as something else. 3. Even if it exists, it might be attached to something else like a shadow. 4. It might be something that only the mind perceives but not the eye. 5. It might exist during one moment and not exist in the next.

Many doubts can thus arise about existence. Does our world really exist? Or is it merely an appearance? Is not appearance a level of existence? Should not an appearance have some kind of substratum? What might that be? Such are the questions.

Independent existence (svatantra-satt─Б) is something that exists without requiring anything else to exist as a substratum or for protection. It existed before, exists now, and will continue to exist later. It cannot be repudiated, modified, or destroyed in any place or time. Such is the existence of Brahma; completely independent.

When a thingтАЩs existence requires something else to be present, the thing is said to have a dependent existence (adh─лna-satt─Б). The reflection in a mirror is an example. An object’s reflection is seen as long as the object stays in front of the mirror and disappears when the object is moved. We have already come across the illustration of the glass and the red rose. As long as the rose is near the glass, the glass appears red. No red glass without the red rose. Shadows too are in this category. They require another solid body for them to be seen. The shadow is a projection of the object. Brahma is existence itself, while the world is an appearance. The shadow is seen as long as the object is present. Once the object is gone, the shadow goes as well. But the object itself is not a shadow. It has an independent existence while the shadow has a dependent existence. Brahma has an independent existence; the world is like its shadow and hence has a dependent existence. Let us return to the treatise keeping this in mind.

The present series is a modern English translation of DVGтАЩs Kendra Sahitya Akademi Award-winning work, Bhagavad-g─лt─Б-t─Бtparya or J─лvana-dharma-yoga. The translators wish to express their thanks to ┼Ъat─Бvadh─Бni R Ganesh for his valuable feedback and to Hari Ravikumar for his astute edits.

[[Ch. 9 Yoga of the Relationship between Brahman and the World (Part 2) Source: prekshaa]]

The two ┼Ыlokas beginning with тАЬMay─Б tatamidaс╣БтАЭ have the following seven points.

  1. May─Б tatam-idam (All of this is pervaded or extended by me) 2. Mat-sth─Бni sarva-bh┼лt─Бni (All beings exist in me) 3. Na c─Бhaс╣Б teс╣гv-avasthitaс╕е (I am not in them) 4. Na ca mat-sth─Бni bh┼лt─Бni (The beings are not in me) 5. Bh┼лta-bhс╣Ыt (The sustainer of beings) 6. Na ca bh┼лta-sthaс╕е (Not in these beings) 7. Mam─Бtm─Б bh┼лta-bh─Бvanaс╕е (My Self constitutes the existence of beings)

There seems to be an inconsistency in these. How do we reconcile тАШmat-sth─БniтАЩ and тАШna ca mat-sth─БniтАЩ? Can a consistent meaning be gleaned from these seven statements? Let us see.

1. May─Б tatam-idam тАУ This entire universe is extended from Brahma. The word tatam (extended) implies an extending energy as well as a material that is extended. A cloth is the extension of yarn; the yarn is an extension of cotton. Only when cotton as the raw material is present can the skills and energies of the yarn-maker and the weaver come into play. A vessel is an extension of metal. Only in the presence of the metallic raw material can the blacksmithтАЩs hammer and anvil go to work. Similarly, the fundamental energy needed for the creation of the universe is that of Brahma. What about the material for creation? The answer again, is Brahma.

Our experience in the world is that anything that is born or created has two causes тАУ a mother and a father. One is the b─лja (seed) and the other the kс╣гetra (field). Take a look at some man-made creations. For a pot, the kс╣гetra is clay and the b─лja is the potterтАЩs pot-making ability. In ┼Ы─Бstric terminology, the clay is known as the up─Бd─Бna-k─Бraс╣Зa (material cause) and the potterтАЩs felicity is known as the nimitta-k─Бraс╣Зa (efficient cause).

However, Brahma is not a created object like a pot or a cloth; it is self-existent. Brahma is by itself the field or material cause as well as the seed or the efficient cause.

A thingтАЩs efficient cause is active only during its creation. An objectтАЩs material cause always lies latent in the object just like clay that exists in a pot. The clay is the potтАЩs material cause. The potterтАЩs fashioning of the pot ends just after the pot is made and is therefore the efficient cause.

So far so good. We just said that Brahma is itself both the material and efficient cause. Is there an example for that in the world? Yes, there is. We saw that at the end of our discussion of the seventh chapter.

yathorс╣Зa-n─Бbhiс╕е sс╣Ыjate gс╣Ыhс╣Зate ca рее
Muс╣Зс╕Нakopaniс╣гat 1.1.7

For a spider-web, the efficient cause is the spiderтАЩs ability to weave a web whereas the material cause is the web fluid. Both of these are within the spider. Similarly, Brahma can assume two forms as well as possess two capabilities. Much like our Upanishadic spider, Brahma can make its own web fluid and weave those fantastic webs. It appears to us that Brahma prepares its own colours and costumes, assumes roles and disguises by itself and plays the world-drama.

Another instance is found in the Bh─Бgavata where ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa himself became the cows, calves, and cowherds, in an exhibition of his divine m─Бy─Б (Note:This example was added by the translator in lieu of DVGтАЩs untranslatable example.).

svayam ─Бtm─Бtma-govats─Бn prativ─Бry─Бtma-vatsapaiс╕е ред
kr─лс╕Нann-─Бtma-vih─Бrai┼Ы-ca sarv─Бtm─Б pr─Бvi┼Ыad-vrajam рее
Bh─Бgavata-pur─Бс╣Зa 10.13.20
(The Self of all entered Vraja enjoying himself with his own play тАУ becoming the cows and calves himself as well as the cowherds.)

The conclusion is this: Creation is an independent l─лl─Б (pastime) of Brahma that is not ordered or inspired or impelled by another. Brahma does not need material or help from anyone else.

2. Now to the second point тАУ “mat-sth─Бni sarva-bh┼лt─Бni” (all beings exist in me). Brahma is the substratum of all that exists. Brahma pervades all that exists. There is nothing that exists apart or outside of Brahma тАУ there will not be anything else. This is the essence of the first statement of the ─к┼Ы─Бv─Бsyopaniс╣гat тАУ ─л┼Ы─Бv─Бsyam-idam sarvс║бm (All this is the dwelling of ─к┼Ыvara). The word тАШexistenceтАЩ includes whatever we see, experience, or infer. It is not possible to even talk about something as separate from Brahma. There is no existence for anything other than Brahma. The verb asti (is) can be used without qualification only with respect to a specific subject тАУ Brahma. There is no absolute existence for anything other than Brahman. Whatever exists тАУ as much as it exists тАУ exists within Brahma, enclosed in its greatness like the shards of clouds in the atmosphere. It is Brahma that wholly and continuously pervades everything within and without, above and below, and all around. That is indicated by тАШmat-sth─Бni sarva-bh┼лt─БniтАЩ.

3. The third point is “na c─Бhaс╣Г teс╣гu”. Just because beings exist in Brahma and are able to act only because of BrahmaтАЩs support, they cannot be equated with Brahma. Doing so would be in error. In reality, Brahma is not limited either by forms and functions of things or by their shapes and modifications. It is beyond all these.

The world is a modification of Brahma-consciousness. A modification cannot alter the fundamental nature of the causal consciousness. A pot is an altered form of clay. This alteration cannot change the nature of clay. Modification is temporary; the causal substance is eternal.

A human being has nails and hair; but a human is not in those hair and nails. Shaving and cutting hair or nails does not affect the person. The sea has foam and bubbles; but there is no sea in foam and bubbles. The sea is undiminished even in the absence of foam and bubbles. Just as hair and nails are for the body and foam and bubbles are for the ocean, the things of the world are adventitious and momentary for Brahma. Though they appear real, they lack essence. The essence of Brahma lies not in the objects of the world. Even though husk might have come from paddy, it is not paddy by itself. Though an aspect of paddy might be seen in the husk, the husk is not the essence of the paddy.

Let us look at it in another way. Right now we have two things on our minds - Brahma and the world. Consider that they are opposite shores of a river and that the j─лva is the river in between. When we see the world-shore from the Brahma-shore, it appears to us as not a rocky solid shore but a sandy one. It pleases the eye with its lush green appearance, but hides the marsh beneath it. It feels better than a coarse boulder. But when we stand in the world-shore, we feel that it is not solid and that it might collapse anytime. The opposite shore seems safer. Both the rock and sand are earth. But the earth’s quality of stability manifests itself not in the sand but in the rocky shore. Similarly, Brahma’s essence lies in the Supreme Pure Brahma that is beyond the visible world. But the world does not completely reflect Brahma’s essence. The same is conveyed by the twelfth verse of the seventh chapter.

matta eveti t─Бn viddhi na tvahaс╣Б teс╣гu te mayi
“I (Brahma) am not present in the three qualities of Sattva, Rajas and Tamas. But they are in me (Brahma).”

Sleep and mumblings exist in a human being; but there is no human being in sleep and mumblings.

It is delusion to consider that the essence of Brahma is the world, an extension of Brahma. But the world has no substratum other than Brahman.

[[Ch. 9 Yoga of the Relationship between Brahman and the World (Part 3) Source: prekshaa]]

4. Now on to “na matsth─Бni bh┼лt─Бni”. Was it not said earlier that matsth─Бni bh┼лt─Бni (all objects are in me)? But when we analyse reality, the objects do not exist in me; but only appear to be in me. Brahma is the substratum for that appearance. A traveller sees flowing water at a distance. But it is nothing other than a mirage. It is only a phenomenon; not an actual stream. That false appearance is created by a combination of sand, sunlight, and distance. The world, similarly, is a strange phantom that is indicated by Bhagav─Бn as “pashya me yogamai┼Ыvaram”. The world-causing m─Бy─Б is the effect of ─к┼Ыvara’s Yoga. In the second canto of the Bh─Бgavatam, ┼Ъuka says this to King Par─лkс╣гita.

─Бtma-m─Бy─Бm с╣Ыte r─Бjan parasy─Бnubhav─Бtmanaс╕е ред
na ghaс╣нet─Бrtha-sambandhaс╕е svapna-draс╣гс╣нur iv─Б├▒jas─Б рее
Bh─Бgavatam - 2.9.1
bahu-r┼лpa iv─Бbh─Бti m─Бyay─Б bahu-r┼лpay─Б ред
ramam─Бс╣Зo guс╣Зeс╣гv-asy─Б mam─Бham iti manyate рее
Bh─Бgavatam - 2.9.2

The objects seen in a dream do not really belong to the dreamer. The relationship between them is only because of the dream. Similarly, the world and man are related only because of m─Бy─Б. Without m─Бy─Б, the relationship does not exist. This m─Бy─Б is multifarious and due to it, even the world appears so. Man relishes the tastes and refinements offered by m─Бy─Б with the feelings of тАШmeтАЩ and тАШmineтАЩ. M─Бy─Б is that which shows unreal things as real and vice versa. In this three-fold world of the seer, seen and sight, m─Бy─Б takes the form of natural movement. The seeing eye shudders; the illuminating light flickers; the object to be seen shakes. Sight is thus affected. This imbalance in sight is m─Бy─БтАЩs effect. It is m─Бy─Б that attracts and traps our attention thereby making Brahma imperceptible. We are reminded every moment of the worldтАЩs existence but forget Brahma that is the basis of it all. We offer to the glamour of the world that which should be offered to Brahma. This is a mistake. Knowledge or j├▒─Бna lies in understanding that the world is different from Brahma and that Brahma is not to be confused with the world.

yath─Б mah─Бnti bh┼лt─Бni bh┼лteс╣г┼лcc─Бvaceс╣гv-anu ред
praviс╣гс╣н─Бny-apraviс╣гс╣н─Бni tath─Б teс╣гu na teс╣гv-aham рее
Bh─Бgavatam 2.9.35

These are Bhagav─Бn’s words in the Bh─Бgavatam: “Just as Earth and other primordial elements simultaneously enter beings big and small and do not enter them, I am in them as well as outside of them.”

A mango tree grows due to the combination of earth, water, heat, and other elements. But none recognise the elements of Earth, Water or Light while eating a mango. The five great elements are praviс╣гс╣н─Бny-apraviс╣гс╣н─Бni - that is - have entered the mango and have not entered the mango. Similar is Brahma with the objects of the world - It is in them and not in them.

The p─Бrij─Бta tree is born and grows because of contact with these five great elements. Even then, we do not think of the p─Бrij─Бta flower as belonging to any single element. The five great elements are praviс╣гс╣н─Бny-apraviс╣гс╣н─Бni - they have entered the p─Бrij─Бta and have not entered it. Brahma has also simultaneously entered and not entered the beings of the world - “tath─Б teс╣гu na teс╣гu”. BrahmaтАЩs relationship with these flora is similar. In a certain perspective, they are related and unrelated from another perspective.

Brahma’s relationship with all beings from microorganisms and insects all the way to Hiraс╣Зyagarbha (the divine creator) is to be viewed similarly.
Brahma exists in the world from the Absolute or Transcendental viewpoint. Not in the transactional or relative viewpoint.
The world exists in Brahman from a transactional viewpoint. Not the transcendental one.

The pampered child cries for an elephant. The grandfather buys her a toy elephant from the market. The satisfied child proudly exults in showing her elephant to everyone. The elephant is made of either wood or mud. But will anybody call it тАШmudтАЩ? If someone asks for some mud to scrub vessels, will the toy elephant be given to them? The toy appears outwardly as an elephant. But in reality, it is made of mud. Internally, it is earth but externally an elephant.

Let us look at another example of the great drama personality Varadacharya who strode the stage dressed as Hiraс╣Зyaka┼Ыipu, the asura. The audience waiting with bated breath would watch it without batting an eyelid. Was that Hiraс╣Зyaka┼Ыipu? No. It was Varadacharya. Was that Varadacharya? No, Hiraс╣Зyaka┼Ыipu. Varadacharya was mild-mannered and of a gentle disposition. He who appeared to be a heartless r─Бkс╣гasa to the audience was actually a compassionate soul to his friends and dependents. Varadacharya ("praviс╣гс╣н─Бny apraviс╣гс╣н─Бni”) entered but did not enter Hiraс╣Зyaka┼Ыipu, S─Бraс╣Еgadhara, Duс╣гyanta and other characters.

A thing or a person might have multiple qualities. None of those qualities by themselves can be the person or the thing. Likewise, Brahma-consciousness has an infinite variety of forms. None of those forms or behaviours by themselves, is Brahma. Form, behaviour, and state are apart from Brahma. They belong to m─Бy─Б.

The same opinion is succinctly expressed by this verse.

All these you are, and each is partly you,
And none is false, and none is wholly true.
Stephen Vincent Ben├йt

Is m─Бy─Б different from Brahma? In one view, it is different and non-different from another view. An object is different from its shadow. But since the shadow cannot exist without the object, they are non-different. Is a wave different from the ocean? It is different in one aspect and in another, it is the same. The leaves of a tree flutter with the wind, but the trunk itself is unshaken. A still picture cannot capture the motion of the leaves, but it captures the trunk easily. Is the tree fluttering? Not from the view of the trunk. Is the tree immobile from the leafтАЩs perspective? No, because the leaf is shaking. Thus Brahma, that is one without a second, assumes a form like its shadow, its wave or like a leaf on the top of a tree. That form is m─Бy─Б. M─Бy─Б is not Brahma, but it cannot exist without It. Hence m─Бy─Б that does not fit the definitions of existence and non-existence, or truth and falsehood and cannot be known definitely in any way is traditionally designated anirvacan─лya (indescribable). The world is different from Brahma to the eye shrouded by m─Бy─Б. When the shroud is removed, however, the world is non-different from Brahma.

5. тАЬ(Mam─Бtm─Б) bh┼лtabhс╣ЫtтАЭ - Brahma-consciousness bears or supports all beings; It nourishes and protects the world. All the powers of the Universe belong to Brahma. Man does not possess those in the least.

6. тАЬ(Mam─Бtm─Б) na ca bh┼лtasthahтАЭ - Brahma-consciousness does not reside in beings. It is not possible to point at a specific being and say, “This is Brahma” as Brahma is omnipresent and all pervading. It cannot be mixed piecemeal with anything.

These above six sentences seem to indicate that Brahma is different from a being, where a тАШbeingтАЩ could refer to an animal, insect, anything with a body, or a j─лva. During our time, the word j─лva is more in use than the word bh┼лta or being. Let us use that for now.

Our next question is about the relationship between j─лva and Brahma. The j─лva is something that all of us have experienced to a limited extent. Brahma is something that has not been experienced but something whose name has been just heard. How are they mutually related? Let us look at the seventh item in our list before trying to answer that.

[[Ch. 9 Yoga of the Relationship between Brahman and the World (Part 4) Source: prekshaa]]

7. “Mam─Бtm─Б bh┼лtabh─Бvanaс╕е” : Brahma-consciousness is the cause of a j─лva’s rise and fall. The term bh─Бvanaс╕е can variously mean birth, existence, sustenance, or control. Brahma has embedded the seed of с╣Ъta (Cosmic order) and dharma in human nature. с╣Ъta is the law in creation. “Deeds beget appropriate rewards and a j─лva has to experience them” is the cosmic law of с╣Ыta. The practical application of с╣Ыta in life is dharma. Dharma and adharma result in puс╣Зya and p─Бpa respectively and therefore in svarga and naraka. “A j─лva follows dharma or adharma to experience elevation or degradation” - is the decree of Brahma. Brahma-consciousness becomes bh┼лtabh─Бvana by virtue of this universal decree which controls the j─лva’s birth and life. Hence it is Brahma that is responsible for the journey of the j─лva.

It might be helpful to use an allegory to clarify the combined meaning of these three statements.

  1. Mam─Бtm─Б bh┼лtabhс╣Ыt 2. Mam─Бtm─Б na ca bh┼лtasthaс╕е and 3. Mam─Бtm─Б bh┼лtabh─Бvanaс╕е

Consider a traditional joint family (common fifty years ago) in India with the head of the family, his wife, their four or five children, and six or eight grandchildren making it fifteen to twenty members in the family.

  1. Apart from himself and his wife, the head of the family is either the father or grandfather to most of the family members and is bh┼лtabhс╣Ыt (as their head) to them. He guides them, educates them, establishes them in a suitable vocation, and bears responsibility for their welfare. He is bh┼лtabhс╣Ыt for all of them as their nourisher. 2. Even so, he does not enter their personal lives much. He allows them their freedom according to their age and circumstance. He wishes for the general welfare and happiness of his daughters-in-law and grandchildren. He leaves them to their own devices thinking, “Let them live according to their discretion. They don’t have to live for me. Let them lead their lives for their own well-being.” He takes care of them, but does not impose his wishes upon them. Such a person - na ca bh┼лtasthah - if asked for their share of property by any of his children wishing to lead separate lives, justly gives to them what they deserve and asks them to lead lives wisely. He lives with his younger children as long as they want him to. When they do not need him anymore he separates from them, allowing them their independence. His disposition thus is one of detachment and thus is “na ca bh┼лtasthah”. 3. He educates his children, corrects their ways, and trains them to be prudent. The know-how of what is good and what is not that he imparts to his children will keep them in good stead. They will fail miserably if they reject his teachings. On the other hand, they will benefit from suitably applying his instruction. In this way, he is bh┼лtabh─Бvana (the giver of welfare) for his family.

This is the gist.

  1. The world is a family of j─лvas created by ─к┼Ыvara (Brahma). 2. Family hassles, however, do not affect ─к┼Ыvara. 3. ─к┼Ыvara has supplied j─лvas with necessary means of sustenance. 4. ─к┼Ыvara demonstrates rules and guidance through the mechanisms of prakс╣Ыti to help j─лvas lead a better life. This set of rules is dharma. 5. He also provides them with the requisite intellect to understand and discern the good and bad of those dharmas. 6. The j─лva attains welfare or otherwise depending on how well it maintains dharma. 7. ─к┼Ыvara is aloof from the world. Nothing of the world affects him. 8. It is the j─лva who needs the world to refine himself and achieve purification. 9. The j─лva benefits by getting closer to his source, Brahma. 10. M─Бy─Б clouds the j─лva’s understanding and keeps him away from Brahma. M─Бy─Б is that deluding power found in Prakс╣Ыti.

We have now briefly discussed the relationship between Brahma and the world, the Brahma-j─лva relationship, and the relationship between the world and the j─лva. This is requisite preparation for the next chapter. It is useful to understand their background as these topics appear repeatedly.

It has been stated above that the world exists in Brahma just like the clouds in the atmosphere. Bhagav─Бn relates the same through another comparison.

yath─Бk─Б┼Ыa-sthito nityaс╣Б v─Бyuс╕е sarvatra-go mah─Бn ред
tath─Б sarv─Бс╣Зi bh┼лt─Бni mat-sth─Бn─лtyupadh─Бraya рее
BG 9.6

Brahma is like the sky. The world is like the wind in it.

Good. Brahma is independent; the world is not. Who created this dependent-independent relationship? Brahma anyway is self-existent, uncreated, and unborn. But is the same thing with the world? Or, if it is created, who created it? The answer again is Brahma.

prakс╣Ыtiс╣Б sv─Бmavaс╣гс╣нabhya visс╣Ыj─Бmi punaс╕е punaс╕е рее
- BG 9.8
may─Бdhyakс╣гeс╣Зa prakс╣Ыtiс╕е s┼лyate sacar─Бcaram рее
- BG 9.10

Brahma assumes the aspect of ─к┼Ыvara and creates the world again and again through Its power of Prakс╣Ыti. Prakс╣Ыti gives birth to this animate and inanimate world with Brahma as the adhyakс╣гa (the presiding entity).

In a regular assembly or gathering, the word тАШpresidentтАЩ denotes a position that performs a set of specific activities. Neither does the president of an assembly give a speech nor does he proffer any opinion. The president listens to othersтАЩ speeches and observes the proceedings. The position by itself ensures dignity in the assemblyтАЩs proceedings. The president is a witness who is present during an assembly, not one who does anything. The presidentтАЩs presence ensures propriety in proceedings. Thus the word тАШpresidencyтАЩ is apt in our discussion.

Brahma does not do anything by Itself. It is тАШpresidentтАЩ because it observes prakс╣ЫtiтАЩs activities. Prakс╣Ыti is but one aspect of the limitless power of Brahma. It has been earlier said that Brahma is the master of the world-family. The mistress of this family is prakс╣Ыti. Or prakс╣Ыti can be likened to the Prime Minister of a well-ruled country. All the administrative duties are discharged by the Prime Minister. It has already been mentioned that Brahma is like the Constitutional Monarch who does not have the strain of administration, which is the domain of prakс╣Ыti. A thief stole; a policeman arrested him and the judge sentenced the thief to six months of imprisonment. The thief was handcuffed. What did the king have to do here? All the activities were done as part of the rule of law. Similarly, j─лvas obtain their rewards or punishment for their activities as determined by the rule of dharma. Brahma is an unattached witness. It witnesses goings on тАЬfrom aboveтАЭ. Hence тАЬadhi + akс╣гaтАЭ - adhyakс╣гa.

tap─Бmyahamahaс╣Б varс╣гaс╣Б nigс╣Ыс╣Зh─Бmyutsс╣Ыj─Бmi ca ред
amс╣Ыtaс╣Б caiva mс╣Ыtyu┼Ыca sadasacc─Бhamarjuna рее
BG 9.19
тАЬI heat the waters, gather them upwards into clouds and rain the waters down. I am Immortality as well as Death. I am Being as well as Non-being.тАЭ

The above ┼Ыloka as well as these from the third chapter are also worth reflecting upon.

iс╣гс╣н─Бn bhog─Бn hi vo dev─Б d─Бsyante yaj├▒abh─Бvit─Бс╕е ред (3.12)
ann─Бdbhavanti bh┼лt─Бni parjany─Бdannasaс╣Бbhavaс╕е рее (3.14)

Just as the Supreme ─к┼Ыvara is the inner controller of the j─лva, he is its sustainer as well. ─к┼Ыvara is the one who provides all the means necessary for life and is the basis for everything.

Not just that; he is Death as well. The Kaс╣нhopaniс╣гad outlines this gory truth.

yasya brahma ca kс╣гatraс╣Г ca ubhe bhavata odanaс╕е ред
mс╣Ыtyuryasyopasecanaс╣Г рее
тАЬFor Brahma, both the wise and brave are morsels of rice. And Death is a tasty pickle.тАЭ

Who rules the world? It is prakс╣Ыti who controls the world. She is of two forms - daiv─л and ─Бsur─л. The ones who take refuge in the daiv─л form become Bhagav─БnтАЩs devotees.

[[Ch. 9 Yoga of the Relationship between Brahman and the World (Part 5) Source: prekshaa]]

Those who follow the ─Бsur─л form of prakс╣Ыti delude and waste themselves.

mogh─Б┼Ы─Б moghakarm─Бс╣Зo moghaj├▒─Бn─Б vicetasaс╕е
BG9.12

The r─Бkс╣гasas are cruel and unscrupulous. For them, their bodies are their self and bodily pleasures are the greatest happiness. Naraka and repeated births in lowly creatures are their fate.

Bhagav─Бn expounds upon this dual nature of prakс╣Ыti later in the sixteenth chapter.

How can man be liberated if he is being pulled hither and thither by prakс╣Ыti? Sv─Бm─л now instructs us about how blessed the devotees are. He is for everyone -

gatirbhart─Б prabhuс╕е s─Бkс╣г─л niv─Бsaс╕е ┼Ыaraс╣Зaс╣Б suhс╣Ыt ред
prabhavaс╕е pralayaс╕е sth─Бnaс╣Б nidh─Бnaс╣Б b─лjamavyayam рее

тАЬBrahma is the way, the nourisher, the residence, the refuge, the friend, the origin, the dissolution, the sustainer, the final destination, and the indestructible seed of all existence.тАЭ

By performing vaidika activities such as yaj├▒as, those worshipping Bhagav─Бn reach svarga and other worlds, and after experiencing pleasures there -

kс╣г─лс╣Зe puс╣Зye martyalokaс╣Г vi┼Ыanti рее

(Once puс╣Зya is spent, they return to the world of men)

Thus the fruit of puс╣Зya is bound to end someday.

evaс╣Б tray─лdharmam-anuprapann─Б
gat─Бgataс╣Б k─Бmak─Бm─Б labhante рее
BG 9.21
(Those following the dharma of the three Vedas and are desirous of multiple desires attain the cycle of birth and death)

The same was indicated in 2.45 - traiguс╣Зyaviс╣гay─Б ved─Б nistraiguс╣Зyo bhav─Бrjuna (Vedas deal with the three guс╣Зas. O Arjuna, go beyond the guс╣Зa-triad!). Whether Arjuna was able to achieve freedom from the guс╣Зa-triad or not, it seems impossible for us. My submission is for us not to be indifferent to the good acts within the perimeter of the three guс╣Зas. Bhagav─Бn shows us that there is a way out even for weak and afflicted beings like us.

anany─Б┼Ыcintayanto m─Бс╣Б ye jan─Бс╕е paryup─Бsate ред
teс╣г─Бс╣Б nity─Бbhiyukt─Бn─Бс╣Б yogakс╣гemaс╣Б vah─Бmyaham рее
BG 9.22
тАЬI (Bhagav─Бn) am responsible for the yogakс╣гema (welfare) of those who worship me without thinking of anyone or anything else and are always absorbed in me.тАЭ

Yoga is the attainment of the desired welfare. Kс╣гema is pleasure resulting from welfare - a happiness with contentment and no agitation. That indeed is relaxation. Are not all of our huffs and puffs for profit and enjoyment? But Sv─Бm─л says - тАЬLeave all those burdensome thoughts of your welfare, wealth, and pleasure to me. I will take care of themтАЭ. What else can be a bigger assurance?

ye’pyanyadevat─Бbhakt─Б yajante ┼Ыraddhay─Бnvit─Бс╕е ред
te’pi m─Бmeva kaunteya yajantyavidhip┼лrvakam рее
BG 9.23

The words of the D─Бsa-saints of Karnataka - тАЬhariya karuс╣Зadoс╕╗─Бda bh─Бgyava hari samarpaс╣Зe m─Бс╕Нi badukiroтАЭ (Surrender unto Hari all that fortune that came to us from HariтАЩs compassion), тАЬanudinadali baha sukha-duс╕еkha ninnadayyaтАЭ (Those everyday pleasures and pains are yours!), and тАЬkereya n─лranu kerege celli varava paс╕Нedavaraс╣Гte k─Бс╣ЗiroтАЭ (Pour the water of the pond into the pond, and consider yourself blessed) - all convey the same emotion.

Surrendering everything is the hallmark of Saс╣Гny─Бsa (renunciation); it is giving up what one considers oneтАЩs own to Bhagav─Бn.

┼Ыubh─Б┼Ыubhaphalairevaс╣Б mokс╣гyase karmabandhanaiс╕е ред BG 9.28
(You will thus be liberated from the auspicious and inauspicious fruits and all fetters of karma).

Bhagav─Бn takes no sides; he neither hates anyone nor does he long for anyone. He is the same for everyone. He gives in to Bhakti.

ye bhajanti tu m─Бс╣Б bhakty─Б mayi te teс╣гu c─Бpyaham ред
BG 9.29
тАЬI am in him who is devoted to meтАЭ.

There is no delay after Bhakti for divine grace to follow - just as there is no gap between oneтАЩs standing in front of a mirror and the appearance of oneтАЩs reflection in it. Just after breathing out is breathing in. If the Bhakta takes refuge in Bhagav─Бn, Bhagav─Бn too responds immediately to the Bhakta.

api cetsudur─Бc─Бro bhajate m─Бmananyabh─Бk ред
s─Бdhureva sa mantavyaс╕е samyagvyavasito hi saс╕е рее
BG 9.30

Improper or immoral deeds might have been performed. There could have been a bad motive. It could have been a bad circumstance. Whatever it may be, once single-minded devotion to Bhagav─Бn is established, he will set everything right. A person who resolves thus is a s─Бdhu (virtuous).

What is the distance between earth and Vaikuс╣Зс╣нha (Bhagav─БnтАЩs supreme abode)? The D─Бsa-saints answer that it is just one palm-length! It is bhakti that takes us through the journey of the palm-length!

kс╣гipraс╣Б bhavati dharm─Бtm─Б ┼Ыa┼Ыvacch─Бntiс╣Б nigacchati ред
kaunteya pratij─Бn─лhi na me bhaktaс╕е praс╣Зa┼Ыyati рее
BG 9.31
тАЬWhatever might have happened in the past, p─Бpa is destroyed once bhakti arises. That person becomes a votary of dharma and gets permanent repose. Arjuna, this is my vow. My devotee will never come to harm!тАЭ
m─Бс╣Б hi p─Бrtha vyap─Б┼Ыritya ye’pi syuс╕е p─Бpayonayaс╕е ред
striyo vai┼Ыy─Бstath─Б ┼Ы┼лdr─Бste’pi y─Бnti par─Бс╣Б gatim рее
BG 9.32
(Even those born of sinful origins such as women, vai┼Ыy─Бs and ┼Ы┼лdras will attain the Supreme Goal by taking refuge in me.)

A controversy might arise here. Are women, vai┼Ыy─Бs and ┼Ы┼лdras considered to be of sinful origin? Bhagav─Бn has already said тАЬsamo’hamтАЭ (I am equal everywhere). By using the word тАЬapiтАЭ (also), why is he showing step-motherly treatment towards women, vai┼Ыy─Бs and ┼Ы┼лdras? Is this not taking sides? Is this not discrimination?

We have pondered over this nitty-gritty aspect of dharma in the past chapter. The practice of internal equality finds fulfillment only in the external practice of hierarchy. Equal love towards all, and circumstantial awareness is the operative principle here. Let\ us look at it from this perspective.

The practice of bhakti and ┼Ыraddh─Б come to a br─Бhmaс╣Зa through his lineage as well as societal influence. Bodily penance and mental concentration are easier for him than for the others. Therefore, the path of divine contemplation might not be that hard for him.

Similar is the case for a Kс╣гatriya. If the Br─Бhmaс╣ЗaтАЩs penance is through the practice of knowledge, a Kс╣гatriyaтАЩs penance is through practice of weaponry and physical exercise. Bhakti and focus may not be difficult for him due to the refinement of the body and mind.

A woman, however, because of her bodyтАЩs natural structure, has a few physical limitations and differences in mental perspective. Her menstrual and postpartum conditions impede her physical practice of tapas and agitate her mind. More importantly, prakс╣Ыti fills a womanтАЩs heart more with motherly love and affection than a manтАЩs heart. This is prakс╣Ыti’s strategy for sustaining the world. Whatever might be the fatherтАЩs disposition, is it not the motherтАЩs love that ensures a child its future? However a husband is, it is only the love and commitment of the lady of the house that makes a family. Thus, the female heart is the first instrument of prakс╣ЫtiтАЩs duty of protecting the world. This indeed is the strength of the feminine. There is however, an associated side-effect - non-concentration of the mind. The top of a coconut palm is single-pointed, whereas a mango tree has many ends owing to its many branches. A woman needs her husband, her children as well as ─к┼Ыvara. She cannot give up on anyone. She needs ─к┼Ыvara for her husband and children. Thus one-pointed devotion is harder for a woman than for a man. Even so, if she is devoted even for a moment, the same benefits that accrue to others accrue to her as well. This is the significance of тАШapiтАЩ - that there is a path even for those who are incapable of intense devotion and penance.

One-pointed concentration is hard even for vai┼Ыyas (businesspeople). A vai┼Ыya needs to maintain his business with hundreds of individuals to successfully run his business to make a profit. The thought of profit and loss in business cleaves his mind into two. His worldly associations are complex. He has to give a part of his devotion to the world. Difficult are his circumstances. In spite of all that, if he takes refuge in Bhagav─Бn even momentarily, divine grace visits him as well. This too is signified by тАШapiтАЩ.

After these two explanations, we see that not much else needs to be said in relation to the ┼Ы┼лdras. A person known as a ┼Ы┼лdra (by definition) lacks in knowledge and the company of the refined. He is not invested with much responsibility and only needs to do what is asked of him. Where is the time or the requisite tranquillity for Bhagav─БnтАЩs worship for one who is constantly engaged in the service of other people? But in the middle of all his duties, if he takes refuge in ─к┼Ыvara for even a brief period of time, he too gets to partake of Bhagav─БnтАЩs munificence. Even here, the words тАЬte apiтАЭ (they too) are not meant to reject a ┼Ы┼лdra for his inferiority but to denote compassion for the effort he undertakes.

Sv─Бm─л has taught us that he will look after the welfare of those who are constantly engaged in divine contemplation. Whatever the method of worship, or whoever the worshipped might be, all adorations performed with ┼Ыraddh─Б reach ─к┼Ыvara who is the one controller of the Universe. This instruction applies to everyone - be they wise or wealthy or strong or even world-weary or unlettered. Bhagav─Бn is easily accessible to all. This is a life-maxim for us.

manman─Б bhava madbhakto mady─Бj─л m─Бс╣Б namaskuru ред
m─Бmevaiс╣гyasi yuktvaivam─Бtm─Бnaс╣Б matpar─Бyaс╣Зaс╕е рее

Engaged thus in me constantly, you will reach me alone.

тАЬArjuna, only the physical world is visible to your eyes. But circumstances agitate you. Observe with your inner-eye. You will see Infinite Consciousness behind the world and as its basis. Surrender to that Supreme Being. You might feel that It is far away from you now. Turn towards It, believe in It, prostrate to It and proceed in Its path. You will reach Its abode. Dh─Бrmic life is nothing other than life turned towards the divine; that indeed is a blessed life. This is the essence of the G─лt─Б.

─к┼Ыvara, the birthless, imperishable,
immeasurable, unattached,
pervader of all the three worlds, and powerful,
describes his own glory and
shows how he can be praised and loved.

Summary

Our freedom to discern must be used to gain the knowledge of Bhagav─БnтАЩs nature, his non-attachment and omnipotence. Bhagav─Бn directs us to guiding lights and flagstaffs along the path to that knowledge. It becomes possible to achieve the blessings of Bhagav─Бn by revering and worshipping all glorious things in the world as the marks of the Divine.

Section 11 / Chapter 10. Vibh┼лti-yoga or─к┼Ыvara-vaibhava-yoga

(The Yoga of ─к┼ЫvaraтАЩs Glory)

In the preceding chapters, we have outlined the following important topics with their subtopics.

  1. Brahma-consciousness or ─к┼Ыvara that is the origin of the universe. 2. ─к┼Ыvara as the basis for everything and as the inner controller of the j─лvas. 3. The j─лvaтАЩs position as an enjoyer of different world objects 4. The m─Бy─Б of Prakс╣Ыti that prevents the j─лva from experiencing the Divine

In this chapter we discuss the expressions of Divine glory.

These are the main topics discussed in this chapter тАУ

  1. Bhagav─Бn is beginningless and non-attached 2. Prakс╣ЫtiтАЩs artifice of opposites 3. Buddhi-yoga (the Yoga of intellectual understanding) that results from bhakti 4. Guiding lights for the seeker of Bhagav─БnтАЩs abode

LetтАЩs remember one of the puzzling items from previous chapters. ─к┼Ыvara is seen in three different ways from the vantage of the world тАУ

  1. ─к┼Ыvara is the inner controller of the world.
    тАЬsarva-bh┼лt─Бtma-bh┼лt─Бtm─БтАЭ (BG 5.7) 2. But ─к┼Ыvara is unmodified by the world.
    тАЬna ca mat-sth─Бni bh┼лt─БniтАЭ (BG 9.5) 3. Though everything resides in ─к┼Ыvara, he is unattached to anything. тАЬna tvahaс╣Г teс╣гuтАж te mayiтАЭ (BG 7.12)

The world is the abode of the j─лva. The basis of the existence and the activity of the j─лva is Brahma-consciousness. Even so, the deeds of the j─лva do not attach to Brahma. The j─лvas are responsible for their own actions.
Brahma-caitanya or the consciousness of Brahma is like a money-lending bank. The j─лva is like a customer of the bank. When a customer of the bank takes out a loan, it is the customerтАЩs responsibility to ensure that the loan amount is profitably utilised rather than squandering the money and going to jail as a loan defaulter. The customerтАЩs lack of judiciousness does not concern the bank. The principle here is that the j─лva is responsible for his own action and that ─к┼Ыvara is unattached. The j─лva is an appointed employee of the enterprise of world-activity тАУ representing the vyaс╣гс╣нi (individual) aspect. The chief executive officer of this enterprise is ─к┼Ыvara тАУ the samaс╣гс╣нi (collective) aspect of Brahma-consciousness. Thus it is essential for the j─лva to understand the nature and omnipotence of ─к┼Ыvara. Bhagav─Бn Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa now bestows this teaching upon us.

aham-─Бdir-hi dev─Бn─Бс╣Г maharс╣г─лс╣З─Бс╣Г ca sarva┼Ыaс╕е рее
BG 10.2
bhavanti bh─Бv─Б bh┼лt─Бn─Бс╣Г matta eva pс╣Ыthag-vidh─Бс╕е рее
BG 10.5
sukhaс╣Г duс╕еkhaс╣Г bhavoтАЩbh─Бvo bhayaс╣Г c─Бbhayam-eva ca рее
BG 10.4
тАЬArjuna, I (─к┼Ыvara) am indeed the origin of all the Devas and the great с╣Ъс╣гis.тАЭ (─к┼Ыvara has no other origin. He is the origin of everything. He is not someone who was born in a remote moment of time. He is present everywhere at all times.) тАЬThese different mental states in all these beings stem from me. Pleasure, pain, birth, death, being, going, meeting, separating, fear, fearlessness тАУ all of these arise from my power.тАЭ

ahaс╣Г sarvasya prabhavo mattaс╕е sarvaс╣Г pravartate рее
BG 10.8
тАЬI, the Supreme ─к┼Ыvara, am the origin of all creation. All of this proceeds from me (the Supreme ─к┼Ыvara).тАЭ

The words тАЩsarvasyaтАЩ and тАЩsarvaс╣ГтАЩ include both what we consider good and bad.

Opposites are a part of this creation. Rights and wrongs are mixed up in it as well as things desirable and despicable, wholesome and unwholesome, as well as facts and falsehoods. The Taittir─лyopaniс╣гad states the same:

so.k─Бmayata ред bahu sy─Бm praj─Бyeyeti ред…idam sarvamasс╣Ыjataред ..sacca tyacc─Бbhavatред nirukta├▒-c─Бnirukta├▒ caред nilayana├▒-c─Бnilayana├▒-caред vij├▒─Бna├▒-c─Бvij├▒─Бna├▒-caред satya├▒-c─Бnс╣Ыtaс╣Г ca ред satyamabhavat ред yadidaс╣Г ki├▒ca ред tatsatyamity─Бcakс╣гateрее
Taittir─лyopaniс╣гad 2.6.1

How then can we get out of this tight spot? By the practice of remembering ─к┼Ыvara-samakс╣гat─Б (the presence of ─к┼Ыvara).

mac-citt─Б mad-gata-pr─Бс╣З─Бс╕е bodhayantaс╕е parasparam ред
kathayanta┼Ы-ca m─Бс╣Г nityaс╣Г tuс╣гyanti ca ramanti ca рее
BG 10.9
teс╣г─Бс╣Г satata-yukt─Бn─Бс╣Г bhajat─Бс╣Г pr─лti-p┼лrvakam ред
dad─Бmi buddhi-yogaс╣Г taс╣Г yena m─Бm-upay─Бnti te рее
BG 10.10
тАЬThey whose minds and breaths are engaged in me, who talk with each other about me, who always remember me and are happily engaged in me, to them of continuous devotion, I give buddhi-yoga (Yoga of the Intellect) through which they attain meтАЭ.

Buddhi-yoga referenced here is what was described in the previous chapter (9.1) as тАЬj├▒─Бnaс╣Г vij├▒─Бna-sahitamтАЭ тАУ an amalgam of knowledge and experience.

The take-away nugget here is about the benefit of Buddhi-yoga. Bhagav─Бn gives the strength of Buddhi-yoga, the path of knowledge, to those to whom he wishes to reveal his true form. We have an age-old bickering. Is bhakti the result of j├▒─Бna? Or is it j├▒─Бna that results from bhakti? Sometimes we feel that this controversy is just hair-splitting. In reality though, the more the knowledge of an object, the greater is the love towards it. The reverse is true as well тАУ the greater the love towards an object, the more one learns about it. Suppose that j├▒─Бna stems from bhakti. Will bhakti deteriorate or increase after the dawn of j├▒─Бna? Or if bhakti stems from j├▒─Бna, will j├▒─Бna be washed away in the flood of bhakti? Both of these views are extreme. It is possible for both j├▒─Бna and bhakti to co-exist and this is the common situation. Buddhi-yoga is a fruit of bhakti тАУ in other words, the result of the bhaktaтАЩs own efforts. Once bhakti permeates the instrument-triad of the bhakta тАУ his body, speech and thought, and is wholesome and pure, it becomes worthy of Bhagav─БnтАЩs appreciation. Such an appreciation is not partiality but an acceptance of the bhaktaтАЩs eligibility or the recognition of the bhaktaтАЩs ability. This indeed is the Divine protection of the devotees and an indicator of Bhagav─БnтАЩs love of dharma.

Given the nature of bhakti and j├▒─Бna, it would be incongruous to hold that they are mutually exclusive. Both perform the same activity just as both our eyes unite to see the same object.

Verses 9.12,13 informed us that Prakс╣Ыti has instituted two mutually opposite paths for the j─лva тАУ the daiv─л (Divine) and the ─Бsur─л (Demonic). As the previous chapter has taught us that the daiv─л path is conducive to welfare, it can be inferred that the j─лvas have the freedom to distinguish between the daiv─л and ─Бsur─л paths and can choose to follow the former. This ability to discern between wholesome and unwholesome things is the crest-jewel of human free will. In the sixth chapter, the verse fragment

uddhared-─Бtman─Бtm─Бnam…
BG 6.5
(One must better oneself through oneself)

conveys the same message. All right. Everyone has freedom of discernment. But do they put it into use? Many are those who forget it and lose it. The powers of the ─Бsur─л path tempt and delude the j─лva to forget himself in a stupor. The stupefied j─лva loses attention. His free will becomes of no use and can actually bring disaster. Freedom is for the attentive тАУ to distinguish between the good and otherwise.

[[Ch. 10 Yoga of ─к┼ЫvaraтАЩs Glory (part 2) Source: prekshaa]]

ArjunaтАЩs mind is gaining maturity. DidnтАЩt Bhagav─Бn say тАУ

dad─Бmi buddhi-yogam…
BG 10.10

What is buddhi-yoga? Buddhi is a faculty of the antaс╕еkaraс╣Зa. Manas (mind), saс╣Еkalpa (will), j├▒─Бpaka (recall) and other mental faculties hanker after so many external objects, collecting sensory information about them. The buddhi (intellect) gathers all these pieces of information under its purview, analyses them, classifies them, assesses their qualities and strengths, and ascertains their usefulness. This is the work of the buddhi.

buddhir-vivecan─Б r┼лp─Б s─Б j├▒─Бna-janan─л ┼Ыrutau рее
Brahma-vaivarta, Khaс╣Зс╕Нa 2 Chapter 23

It is the buddhi that gathers the true knowledge of a certain object. Buddhi-yoga is a mechanism to unite the buddhi with the para-tattva тАУ Supreme Principle. This mechanism is a boon that Bhagav─Бn bestows upon the eligible j─лva. There is no summum bonum without this boon.

Buddhi-yoga is not a set of subtle intellectual acrobatics. Mathematicians, scientific researchers, lawyers, and logicians perform many intellectual feats. Their life lies in performing these cerebral adventures. But that does not constitute buddhi-yoga. Normally, the scholarly exercises of the ┼Ы─Бstrik scholars do not beseech the Divine for boons тАУ those proceed independently. However, when the intellect tries to attain the Supreme, the illumination for its path has to come from the destination. That blessing of the light has been variously referred to as either inspiration or revelation or a vision. Thus attaining the Supreme is impossible without Divine blessing. The Upaniс╣гads convey the same message.

yamevaiс╣гa vс╣Ыс╣Зute tena labhyaс╕е рее
Kaс╣нhopaniс╣гad 2.23, Muс╣Зс╕Нakopaniс╣гad 3.2.3
dh─Бtuс╕е pras─Бd─Бn-mahim─Бnam-─Бtmanaс╕е рее

What then is the path to Divine favour? The answer is bhakti, worship and surrender.

тАЬArjuna, I am the Supreme ─Бtman who resides in the hearts of all beings (as consciousness). I am the first of all beings, their middle as well as the end.тАЭ

Thus narrating the Divine glories in a nutshell, Bhagav─Бn then goes on to enumerate the chief symbols of that greatness. He has already stated some of these qualities in the seventh chapter beginning with тАЬrasoтАЩham-apsuтАЭ (I am the taste in the waters), тАЬj─лvanaс╣Г sarvabh┼лteс╣гuтАЭ (life in all beings), and on to radiance, intellect, strength, and the desire permitted by dharma. Now instead of qualities, Bhagav─Бn uses glorious objects as the symbols of Divine opulence thus тАУ Viс╣гс╣Зu among the twelve ─Бdityas; the moon among celestial objects; the mind among the instruments of perception; Meru among the mountains; Skanda (Subrahmaс╣Зya) among the commanders-in-chief; japa among the yaj├▒as; the sacred a┼Ыvattha (Ficus religiosa) among the trees; K─Бmadeva among the generators of the clan; the letter тАЬaтАЭ (рдЕ) in the alphabet; the knowledge of the ─Бtmanamong all vidy─Бs; the enthusiasm to be praised, lustre, and attractive speech among women; betting in gamblers; strategy among those desirous of winning; silence among those maintaining a secret; and knowledge of the knowledgeable. In this way, Bhagav─Бn denoted whatever is most excellent in human understanding as a symbol of Divine grandeur and made it easy for Arjuna to practise the presence of the Divine.

There is a certain matter here that we should bring to our attention. Did the Sv─Бmin not state earlier that both daiv─л and ─Бsur─л elements co-exist in creation? He also told us that there are two paths shown by Prakс╣Ыti. But when he showed his Divine glories, Bhagav─Бn used only the daiv─л elements to make his point but not the ─Бsur─л elements. Let us try to understand why. This is an important concept that we need to bring to our minds.

с╣Зa tvahaс╣Г teс╣гu te mayi
тАЬI am not in them. They are in me.тАЭ

Our body contains blood and flesh as well as urine and faeces. But life-consciousness is established in blood and flesh. Urine and faeces тАУ fit to be egested or excreted out of the body тАУ are not the stations of consciousness. Similarly the Divine body has sublime aspects to it as well as vile ones. The vile aspects of the Divine body are temporary; not long-lasting. Therefore those wishing to experience Divine glories must worship the pure and auspicious aspects of the world. Whatever be the object on which bhagavat-prak─Б┼Ыa - Divine illumination falls, it becomes excellent. Conversely, the worldly object on which Divine illumination does not fall is not auspicious but a mere shadow of the excellent, and is therefore not worthy of adoration. Therefore Bhagav─Бn makes only those excellent aspects of Prakс╣Ыti his symbols to make it possible for devotees to easily recognise the Divine aspects.
