Summary

Arjuna, to strengthen his spiritual steadfastness, implores Bhagav─Бn to show him a direct vision of the universal form. ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa, after giving Arjuna eyesight with special faculty to witness and withstand such a vision, shows him his immensely wondrous cosmic form. The immediate vision and experience of Bhagav─БnтАЩs universal form has a profound impact on Arjuna - an impact that mere theoretical understanding of the divine had hitherto not achieved. Arjuna then extols the divine majesty.

Section 12 / Chapter 11Vi┼Ыva-r┼лpa-sandar┼Ыana-yoga

(The Yoga of the Vision of the Cosmic Form)

The G─лt─Б declares in the third chapter that the Supreme Principle is beyond the reach of buddhi (intellect).

yo buddheс╕е paratas tu saс╕е ред
BG 3-42

If a principle is out of reach of the buddhi, how can the latter grasp it?
It was said in the sixth chapter that the bliss of Brahma-experience can be grasped by the buddhi.

buddhi-gr─Бhyam at─лndriyam ред
BG 6-21

The apparent inconsistency in these two statements can be resolved through some reflection.
The buddhi functions by cooperating with the manas which in turn works in conjunction with the sense organs. Thus, the buddhi is usually influenced by the actions of the sense-organs. That the Supreme Principle - paravastu is beyond such an imperfect and wavering buddhi is the gist of the statement - yo buddheс╕е parataс╕е. Therefore, the instruction in the third chapter is to тАФ

jahi ┼Ыatruс╣Г mah─Б-b─Бho k─Бma-r┼лpaс╣Г dur─Бsadam ред
BG 3-43
(O Strong-Armed one! Destroy this enemyтАФdesireтАФthat is difficult to overcome)

In the phrase buddhi-gr─Бhyam from 6-21, buddhi refers to the intellect unsullied by the actions of the sense-organs - a purified intellect. Anything that is imagined or thought of by such a buddhi is an intellectual concept.

Another question arises now. Can everything тАЬunderstoodтАЭ by the intellect be truly experienced?

School children are normally posed with problems like the following in arithmetic. Ten workers work for eight hours a day and build a house in a month. How many days will it take to build the same house if ten thousand workers were to work similarly for 8 hours a day? The arithmetical answer can be intellectually understood, but it cannot be realised in experience. Can ten thousand workers even stand in the same space that ten workers work?

Scholars say that zero in a number has a certain value. How can ordinary people experience the value of zero?

Buddhi is generally known to have two aspects. On the one hand, it is tainted by sense organs that connect to it through the manas. On the other hand, it is weakened due to sense experience. Though the buddhi can grasp whatever is inaccessible to the eye, ear and other sense organs through inference and imagination, it is but a fraction of knowledge; surely incomplete. Complete knowledge can arise only from experience.

Not everything grasped by the buddhican be experienced. The principle independently understood by buddhi must first permeate into the mind. From the mind it should descend to the physical realm of bodily sense organs to become experience. Experience is complete knowledge. That which is only understood by the buddhi is not complete knowledge.

The difference between buddhi-gr─Бhyam (grasped by the buddhi) and buddhi-m─Бtra-gr─Бhyam (grasped only by the buddhi) should be borne in mind. So must the distinction between buddhi-gс╣Ыh─лta-m─Бtram (understood only by the buddhi) and anubhava-siddham (born of experience). Attainment through experience is higher than attainment via buddhi. Answers to some mathematical problems are attained at the intellectual level only and cannot be experienced.
The heart is the site of experience. The fruit of the activity of the manas and buddhi is experienced in the heart. This is vouchsafed for by several statements from the ┼Ыruti and the smс╣Ыti.

─к┼Ыvaraс╕е sarvabh┼лt─Бtm─Б hс╣Ыddeshe ред (─к┼Ыvara, the self of all beings, in the heart)
Bhidyate hс╣Ыdyagranthiс╕е ред (The heart-knot is rent asunder)
Agnirme v─Бci ┼Ыritaс╕е ред v─Бgghс╣Ыdaye ред hс╣Ыdayam mayi ред (Agni is in my speech; the speech in my heart; the heart in me.)

The heart is the arena of experience. It is the heart that touches the truth. The heart is larger than the manas and buddhi for it encompasses both.

The knowledge of the Supreme Principle is predominantly experiential. Intellectual comprehension is imperative for experience. Other instruments are also necessary. ManтАЩs external organs bahiс╣гkaraс╣Зa must be subservient to his antaс╕еkaraс╣Зa, which in turn must cooperate with one of them - the buddhi. Experience of the supreme principle is possible only when all these instruments unite in harmony. The eleventh chapter of the G─лt─Б - dealing with the cosmic form - illustrates this concept.

The concepts of j├▒─Бnaс╣Г vij├▒─Бna-sahitam and buddhi-yoga were expanded upon in the ninth and tenth chapters. The theoretical knowledge of the principle (j├▒─Бna) was enumerated with ┼Ы─Бstric basis as well as logical reasoning. The practical aspect (vij├▒─Бna) was expounded with illustrations of well-known personages and well-known phenomena. With this, ArjunaтАЩs confusions and fears were put to rest. It appears, however, that a few doubts continued to bother him. The first - тАЬWill my acquired belief endure firmly?тАЭ The second - тАЬHow eligible am I to attain spiritual knowledge?тАЭ Arjuna felt that only personal experiential testimony could resolve these niggling questions. He therefore implored Bhagav─Бn for such a vision who then bestowed it upon him. This is the gist of this chapter.
Though the entire matter of the chapter can be conveyed in a small number of words, this chapterтАЩs greatness cannot be overstated. It is an established practice to recite this chapter of the vi┼Ыva-r┼лpa while the monastic name is given to the ordained renunciate during the rite of accepting saс╣Гny─Бsa (renunciation).
At the beginning of this chapter, Arjuna clearly states that his mind was purified.

yat tvayoktaс╣Г vachas tena mohoтАЩyaс╣Г vigato mama
BG 11-1

Questions such as тАЬWho is the j─лva? What is the world? Who is ─к┼Ыvara? What is the path towards good? What is dharma?тАЭ - all received appropriate answers. There was no doubt left uncleared. But was it not ArjunaтАЩs desire to attain the state of a sthitapraj├▒a (one of steady wisdom)? Bhagav─Бn had indicated this to Arjuna in the beginning -

┼Ыruti-vipratipann─Б te yad─Б sth─Бsyati ni┼Ыchal─Б ред

тАЬYour mind has lost its equipoise by listening to the words of all and sundry. When your mind is concentrated at one point without being scattered hither and thither, your mind will attain yoga.тАЭ

Arjuna then inquired about the characteristics of a sthita-praj├▒a. He wanted to be a sthita-praj├▒a (one of steady wisdom) rather than a chala-praj├▒a (whose wisdom is unsteady). The wisdom obtained from ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гnaтАЩs words could slip away due to anotherтАЩs words - like old water pushed away by new flowing water or a lamp getting extinguished by the wind. Arjuna wanted to ensure that this knowledge learnt from Bhagav─Бn remained firm and did not flow away. This was ArjunaтАЩs intent.

[[Ch. 11 Yoga of the Vision of the Cosmic Form (part 2) Source: prekshaa]]

Here, by тАЬdivine eyesтАЭ we do not need to imagine a pair of extra-physical eyes with their own eyeballs and eyelids. It is enough to think that Bhagav─Бn endowed the eye with the ability to behold divine effulgence. This is what we have to understand - when we pray to ─к┼Ыvara for a boon, we need to ask for the requisite strength to bear and control the blessing. Our desires know no limits and make us forget what is suitable and what is not. If Bhagav─Бn gives us what we deserve, weтАЩre dissatisfied. However, if he grants us whatever we ask of him, it is akin to committing suicide. Gastric issues are guaranteed if one forgets oneтАЩs digestive ability and indulges in a feast. When we pray for a meal, we need to ask for medicine for indigestion as well. When taking up a vow in a deityтАЩs honour for progeny, one must not forget to ask for means of sustenance. When asking for a kingdom, we must not forget to ask for a treasury and an army too. When asking for a boon, we need to also ask for the ability to use the blessing well.

┼Ъr─л Kс╣Ыс╣гna had a lot of love for Arjuna. Therefore he first gave him the faculty for divine vision and only then showed him his divine form. Sa├▒jaya describes that magnificent form thus:

He was flabbergasted; he trembled; his hairs stood on end; he folded his hands and began praising Bhagav─Бn.

BG 11.31
тАЬO Ferocious one! Who are you? Tell me, O best among gods! I bow to you, be appeased! I know not your nature. I would like to understand you - who existed before everything.тАЭ

Did you understand the impact of direct experience? What a difference in effect between j├▒─Бna (intellectual understanding) gleaned by the intellect and vij├▒─Бna (experiential wisdom) seen by the eyes and felt by the manas! When he asked for the vision of the cosmic form, Arjuna never even for a bit thought that the experience would be this terrorising! He thought that witnessing the vision with his eyes would be as easy as arguing with his words. What happened during the vision, though? Fear, trembling, distress! This shows that ArjunaтАЩs understanding of the truth was not complete. He had only seen the pleasant side of Bhagav─Бn but not the terrible aspect. Suppose a person knows only one face of a two-faced thing, how can we say that he has complete knowledge of it? The seeker of truth must know as many facets of the truth as there are. It is not enough to just have heard of something. One should have seen the thing with oneтАЩs own eyes. It is not just enough to have seen and heard the thing, but the thing must be grasped by the buddhi as well. And not just intellectually grasped by the buddhi, but should have been experienced by the manas and the seeker should become one with the sought. Becoming one with the sought тАФ becoming it тАФ is complete experience. Similar was ArjunaтАЩs state now after experiencing the vision of the Universal form. When the ┼Ыruti says - тАЬcakс╣гurvai satyamтАЭ (the eye is the truth), it does not mean that whatever is seen by the eye is the truth but that the eye is one of the instruments for reaching the truth. Even theoretical knowledge strengthened by intellectual inference and logical strengthening is insufficient. The truth is experienced only when the theory is confirmed by visual validation. Arjuna needed such a direct confirmation and he got it now.

Even though Bhagav─Бn had bestowed divine vision upon Arjuna, the latterтАЩs human frailty had remained. The strength of his manas had not increased. Hence the fear. Even after what he sought after appeared in front of him, he experienced fear. Those who think that Brahma-experience is nice and pleasant must repeatedly recollect this episode. Brahma is not a grocery item to be bought from a store. If we make Brahma-experience cheap, it is us who suffer, not Brahma. Hence it is better to limit idle talking and casual listening about Brahma and mokс╣гa.

Did Arjuna not already accept that ─к┼Ыvara is the тАЬsarva-dharma-gopt─БтАЭ (the eternal protector of dharma) in the eighteenth verse? The responsibility of protecting dharma is that of ─к┼Ыvara, not of Arjuna and not of Bh─лс╣гma or the others. Whatever was needed to establish dharma had already been planned and set in motion. That plan would not have stopped even if Arjuna had demurred. Such is divine rule. The same is referred to by Bhagav─Бn later as тАЬdaivaс╣Г caiv─Бtra pancamamтАЭ (18-14) (Divine providence is the fifth factor that determines the outcome of any action). Be it in an individualтАЩs life or the history of civilisations - divine providence is the final arbiter. Not acknowledging the divine is being egoistic. Arjuna understood this.
A war had become inevitable for the survival of the world. Without it, essential and eternal dharma would not have held out amidst mortals. This was not a war just for one Arjuna or five P─Бс╣Зс╕Нavas. ArjunaтАЩs role in it was not as a cause, but as an instrument. Any conflict needs two sides. One side was ready and the other was wavering. It was necessary for the protector of eternal dharma to firm up the fickle side.
The secret of the universe that had eluded Arjuna in the lectures on s─Бс╣Еkhya, karma and j├▒─Бna became evident to him now. Bhagav─Бn is the controller of the world. He has assigned us a dh─Бrmic duty only to benefit us. If we do not perform that duty, it is not dharma that will be affected but our own progress. Bhagav─Бn can use others if we disregard our duty. But we are the ones who will be left without a resort. When such a beneficial opportunity arises, it becomes a dh─Бrmic obligation for us. Arjuna finally understood this and expressed remorse for having protracted this investigation thus far.

[[Ch. 11 Yoga of the Vision of the Cosmic Form (part 3) Source: prekshaa]]

Bhagav─Бn was pacified and assumed his human form. Arjuna said –

Bhagav─Бn now said - тАЬArjuna, you have witnessed a special form that cannot be attained by the merits gained from the Vedas, Yaj├▒as, charity and other penances. The only path towards an experience of the divine being is bhakti - single-minded Bhakti.

mat-karma-kс╣Ыin mat-paramo mad-bhaktaс╕е saс╣Еga-varjitaс╕е ред
nirvairaс╕е sarva-bh┼лteс╣гu yaс╕е sa m─Бm eti p─Бс╣Зс╕Нava рее
BG 11.55
тАЬO P─Бс╣Зс╕Нava, He who performs my (Bhagav─БnтАЩs) works and thinks of me as the Supreme, that bhakta, who gives up association with non-bhaktas and is not opposed to any living being, he will attain me.тАЭ

The vision of the universal form enabled a great inner experience in Arjuna. But it should not be forgotten that behind that universal form exists a supra-universal principle that is the basis of even the universal form. Both the universe and the supra-universe have to be borne in mind. They are not really two - but one. The universe has form and so can be seen. The supra-universe is formless and therefore cannot be seen.

A form is marked by a well-established boundary тАФ a defining line, a perimeter that limits an area. Any form therefore, is finite. But pure existence is infinite, limitless. How does one bring form to it? An appearance of a finite form makes infinity disappear. Thus the supra-universe cannot be grasped by sense organs such as the eyes and the ears. How does one experience it then? It can be seen when the manas and buddhi meditate upon it. The tapas of the manas and buddhi is Bhakti. However, that tapas needs an easily attainable focus. A form or a m┼лrti facilitates this. Just as the pradakс╣гiс╣Зa of a temple has a m┼лrti of the divine as its centre, the manas and buddhi of normal people have the vi┼Ыva-m┼лrti (Bhagav─Бn in the form of the universe) as their object. The service of this visible universe, considering it as a form of Bhagav─Бn, is dharma. The service of the supra-universal principle is adhi-dharma. The one who lives a тАЬuniversal lifeтАЭ is able to experience the supra-universal as well. The universe is the bridge that takes the j─лva to the supra-universal.

Vi┼Ыv─Бk─Бr─Бnubhavad─Х
Vi┼Ыv─Бt─лt─Бnubh┼лti samanikumadariс╣Г ред
Vi┼Ыv─Бsavс╣Ыddhige naraс╣Г-
g─л┼Ыvaranugr─Бdbhut─Бkс╣Ыtiya k─Бс╣Зisidaс╣Г рее
The experience of the universal form
leads to the experience of the supra-universal.
And therefore to nourish the bhakti of Arjuna,
─к┼Ыvara showed him the terrific and wondrous form!

At the beginning of our study, we had asked a question - тАЬIsnтАЩt the G─лt─Б a ┼Ы─Бstra? How did it become a song?тАЭ We have seen an answer to that question to some extent in this chapter. G─лt─Б or a song is a literary category. The arrangement of words accompanied by music, that causes waves of feeling to rise in the listenerтАЩs psyche and causes satisfaction, is a song. The song has to cause a uniquely pleasurable experience that calms our minds. By the vision of the vi┼Ыva-r┼лpa, Arjuna lost his grief and worry; and attained happiness and a definite understanding with the exit of fear and doubt. Suppose a lone traveller on his way to a distant land gets caught in a murky jungle and loses his sense of direction. He is distressed, tired and is almost resigned to the fate that a wild animal will end his existence. What if a friend brings light to him and gets him to his destination on an easily traversable path? The feeling that our poor traveler might have experienced upon reaching the destination is similar to what Arjuna felt now. This emotional experience is conveyed to our minds by the masterful words of Vy─Бsa. ┼Ъ─Бnta (tranquillity or peace) is the key rasa in this episode. It is nourished by the sub-emotions of karuс╣Зa and adbhuta. There is a lingering debate on the question whether ┼Ы─Бnta is indeed a rasa. This, however, is not a place for that discussion. ArjunaтАЩs words and behaviour show us that ┼Ы─Бnta is not just a rasa, but that it is the parama-rasa or adhi-rasa тАФ Supreme rasa or a supra-rasa. The rasa ┼Ы─Бnta is uniquely different from all other rasas in an aspect. It is not a rasa that can be achieved by all like ┼Ыс╣Ыng─Бra and other rasas. Only those tormented by a┼Ы─Бnti (disturbance, anxiety) can appreciate the nature of the ┼Ы─Бnta-rasa. CanтАЩt feelings such as separation or loss of money be considered a┼Ы─Бnti? Yes - but those are fleeting and limited feelings that can be neutralised by trivial profits and dalliances. The a┼Ы─Бnti that afflicted Arjuna was unlike this - it shook the very foundations of his existence. This a┼Ы─Бnti was not based on the desire for some object, but about the fundamental meaning of life. The G─лt─Б gives tranquillity to those tormented by questions such as - тАЬWhat is the essence of life? What is its goal? How does one attain fulfillment?тАЭ The raison dтАЩ├кtre for the ┼Ы─Бnti that the G─лt─Б bestows upon its votaries is not based on scriptural exegesis or debates that are solely intellectual. It is an all-encompassing unique inner experience. The buddhi is merely the gateway to the inner world. When the teaching entered the heart through the buddhi, it became a ┼Ы─Бstra. When that instruction took over all the sense organs and the instruments of knowledge such as the manas and buddhi and established the entire inner-kingdom in that Great Vision, it became poetry. The supreme effect of poetry is this achievement of engrossment. The same will be explored in a future chapter.

The main topic of this chapter is the vir─Бс╣н (the visible all-encompassing) form of Brahma. This description of the vir─Бс╣н is found in several places in the Veda. We indicate two of the important portions here. The first one is the Puruс╣гa-s┼лkta.

Summary

Giving up the fruit of our actions means that we experience the world with the notion that all felicity and happiness we experience is a favour from ─к┼Ыvara, and that adversities are training to the j─лva. This needs the j─лva to make mindful choices of karma to be performed, unwavering devotion to dharma, equanimity in the experience of the fruit of karma, and finally complete surrender to ─к┼Ыvara. Here, ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa instructs Arjuna on how to gradually diminish oneтАЩs affinity with ego and experience first hand the relationship with Divine.

Section 13 /Chapter 12Bhakti-yoga/Bhakti-sop─Бna-yoga

(The Yoga of the steps of Bhakti)

At the end of the eleventh chapter, we analysed a significant concept. The supreme reality or sadvastu is of two kinds: One is vi┼Ыvar┼лpa тАФ the form that encompasses the entire universe, and the other supra-universal. Vi┼Ыvar┼лpa is tangible reality and it is evident. That is ─к┼Ыvara-yoga. The supra-universal is intangible truth and has to be inferred indirectly. That is Parabrahma. Arjuna asks which of these two he has to meditate upon. The Sv─Бm─л answers his question in this chapter. There are four important points here.

  1. The difficulties in meditating upon the formless - nirguс╣Зop─Бsana. 2. Ease of worshipping the divine that has a form - saguс╣Зop─Бsana 3. Stepwise worship of the divine 4. The wealth of qualities that has to be earned by the worshipper.

Arjuna asked: тАЬO Great one, what should I believe? You say тАЩmat-karma-kс╣Ыt mat-paramaс╕етАЩ тАФ one who does the work ordained by me and engrossed in me тАФ Who is тАЩmeтАЩ here? Should I seek you and your form that is visibly manifest in the universe, or the invisible, unmanifest and intangible, pure and Supreme Brahma? You have instructed me in the worship of both of these. Which of them is better?”

“teс╣г─Бс╣Г ke yoga-vit-tam─Бс╕е”
BG 12.1

Sv─Бm─лтАЩs answer is thus: “O Arjuna, when there are many ways to reach a destination, shouldnтАЩt a traveller choose one that is right for his body and mind? One road might be uneven and bumpy, and additionally difficult to traverse because of sharp stones and thorns. It might, however, be shorter. A strong man in a hurry might choose this path because it is short. Another, weaker man would say that it is more important to not fatigue himself. With time on his side, the circuitous route would be better for him though it takes more time, because it does not harm his body. The journey that a j─лva undertakes towards better worlds is similar. The worship of the intangible Brahma is more suited for those who are stronger and can sustain strain. The worship of the manifest form is more suited for weaker people. Both will attain the same supreme state тАФ one directly and the other gradually.

mayy─Бve┼Ыya mano ye m─Бс╣Г nitya-yukt─Б up─Бsate ред
┼Ыraddhay─Б parayo-pet─Бs-te me yukta-tam─Б mat─Бс╕е рее
BG 12.2
тАЬThose who rest their minds upon any one form of ─к┼Ыvara, and continuously meditate upon the Brahma with a form (s─Бk─Бra-brahma) are closest to himтАЭ.
Ye tvakс╣гaram-anirde┼Ыyam avyaktaс╣Г paryup─Бsate ред
с╣нe pr─Бpnuvanti m─Бmeva sarva-bh┼лta-hite rat─Бс╕е рее
BG 12.3
тАЬThose who are friendly towards the whole world, who meditate upon the indestructible, indescribable, intangible and formless Brahma, reach ─к┼Ыvara HimselfтАЭ.

The followers of both paths attain the same end; there is a slight difference only in the speed with which it is attained. The quicker way is more difficult; the other way is circuitous but easier. Why should we not choose the faster one?

kle┼ЫoтАЩdhikataras-teс╣г─Бm avyakt─Б-sakta-cetas─Бс╣Г ред
avyakt─Б hi gatir-duс╕еkhaс╣Г dehavadbhir-av─Бpyate рее
BG 12.4

The journey towards better worlds is anyway difficult. Both paths require the practice of self-control and giving up carnal pleasures. Till we reside in a body that consumes salt and spices, it is difficult to subdue our senses. Therefore, it is a given that it is difficult to indulge in worshiping Bhagav─Бn. Further, worshipping the unmanifest and formless Brahma is much more difficult than worshipping the tangible Brahma with a form. The difficulties are of two kinds. The first is that of intellectual capability. Ordinary intellect cannot grasp the indescribable and unthinkable. The supreme tattva is described thus in the Vedas -

Yato v─Бco nivartante ред apr─Бpya manas─Б saha рее
Tai.U, Brahm─Бnandavall─л
yanmanas─Б na manute yen─Бhurmano matam рее
Kenopaniс╣гaс╕Н 5

Brahma is described as that very mysterious thing тАФ тАЬ from where speech and mind return without being able to grasp it; that which cannot be held by the mind, but causes the mind to understandтАЭ. The intellect has to put great effort to understand this concept clearly. Even if we think that the intellect is able to grasp this, there is a second difficulty тАФ that of experience. Brahma should be experienced. It becomes truthful knowledge only then. тАЬsaс╣Гniyamyendriya-gr─БmamтАЭ тАФ тАЩSubduing the collective influence of the sensesтАЩ, тАЬsarvatra sama-buddhayaс╕етАЭ тАФ тАЩdisplaying equanimity everywhereтАЩ, тАЬsarva-bh┼лta-hite rat─БhтАЭ тАФ indulging in the well-being of all creationтАЩ. To whom is this easy? Each second, the body has to grapple with arising desire, love and infatuation. The enchanting beauty and glamour of Nature captivates our eyes and deviates our minds from the thought of true knowledge. If a man who has not yet escaped the clutches of m─Бy─Б thinks that he is as capable as the people who have, his plight will be similar to that of a lame person trying to climb a hill. Therefore, the humility of worshipping Brahma with a form is safer than the strenuous exercise of meditating upon the formless Brahma.

ye tu sarv─Бс╣Зi karm─Бс╣Зi mayi saс╣Гnyasya matpar─Бс╕е ред
ananyena-eva yogena m─Бс╣Г dhy─Бyanta up─Бsate рее
BG 12.6
teс╣г─Бm ahaс╣Г samuddhart─Б mс╣Ыtyu-saс╣Гs─Бra-s─Бgar─Бt ред
bhav─Бmi na cir─Бt p─Бrtha mayy-─Бve┼Ыita-cetas─Бm рее
BG 12.7
тАЬBhagav─Бn quickly holds and draws towards him those who give up the fruit of all their actions in him, seek his direction in everything, not indulging in anything else other than meditating upon him and rest their minds firmly in himтАЭ.

Is this method of up─Бsan─Б easy for everyone? ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa did not think so.

─Бtha cittaс╣Г sam─Бdh─Бtuс╣Г na ┼Ыaknoс╣гi mayi sthiraс╣Г ред
abhy─Бsa-yogena tato m─Бm-icch─Бptuс╣Г dhana├▒jaya рее
BG 12.9
тАЬIf you cannot establish your mind in ─к┼Ыvara firmly and constantly, do it as much as you can, whenever you can. With practice comes focusтАЭ.

Is practice easy, though? In our houses, those who wear maс╕Нi and sit for worship know that it is an arduous practice. It is difficult to focus for long on something that cannot respond to us, something that does not react to our actions. Young people can concentrate on their loved ones for a little time. The reason for that is born from the natural reaction of the limbs. There is an echo to a sound, a sign in answer to another. Is Bhagav─Бn so wondrous and attractive? Blessed are they whom he attracts of his own accord. We are not talking about them. Let us look at the plight of those who are not so lucky. They have to go in search of Bhagav─Бn of their own volition. It is true that our mind does turn towards the Divine when worldly adversities arise. But the very next second, it turns back from there and focuses on something else. How can we discipline something that is so fickle? One way is to engage it in karma тАФ some good work. When the body and hands are engaged in a work, the mind is engrossed in it and does not flit here and there. The minds of carpenters, engineers, masons, and farmers are settled and rested in their work. Therefore, Arjuna, тАЬmatkarma-paramo bhavaтАЭ тАФ тАЬperform karma as service toBhagav─БnтАЭ. Perform karma with the view that you are only doing it for the love of Bhagav─Бn.

с╣Гadartham-api karm─Бс╣Зi kurvan siddhim av─Бpsyasi рее
BG 12.10
тАЬPerform laukika and vaidika karmas as an offering to ─к┼Ыvara. You will then achieve the supreme state”.

The world is a carpenterтАЩs shop. You are a carpenter working there. Do your work diligently, to please the owner. From such work you will earn for life in this world, and blessing for the afterlife. This is the training of karma, the biggest and best of all trainings.

[[Ch. 12 Yoga of the steps of Bhakti (part 2) Source: prekshaa]]

Well, then, is this path тАФ performing oneтАЩs duties with the sole purpose of pleasing Bhagav─Бn тАФ an easy journey? ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa himself was uncertain about it. Bhagav─Бn is not in front of our eyes; dharma is not in front of our eyes either. Performing our duties only for the sake of Bhagav─Бn or for dharma тАФ single-minded devotion to our duty without even an iota of selfishness тАФ is difficult. It is not easy to be a devoted servant who does his duties conscientiously even in the absence of the master who distributes the wages. Many people perform karma with the desire to obtain something or the other in return. Let them do so, but let them perform it with the notion that the fruits of the karma (or the lack thereof) belong to ─к┼Ыvara. If they obtain what they desire, let them think that it is the blessing of ─к┼Ыvara and not their earning. If their effort doesnтАЩt bear fruit, let them bear it with the reasoning that it is punishment meted out to them, and that this will erode their defects. Thus, one has to live in the belief that good or bad results both belong to ─к┼Ыvara and not to us, and remember him always.

sarva-karma-phala-ty─Бgaс╣Г tataс╕е kuru yat─Бtma-v─Бn рее
BG 12.11
тАЬWith effort, suppress the ego that says that you are the doer, or that you achieved this. Accept the results of your action as given by Bhagav─Бn, and not as your own. Seek refuge in him, in happiness and in adversitiesтАЭ.

What does тАЬgiving up the fruits of karmaтАЭ mean? We have to understand this for ourselves.

tyaktv─Б karma-phal─Б-saс╣Гgam рее
BG 4.20
yuktaс╕е karma-phalaс╣Г tyaktv─Б рее
BG 5.12
m─Б phaleс╣гu kad─Бcana ред m─Б karma-phala-hetur-bh┼лс╕е рее
BG 2.47
An─Б┼Ыritaс╕е karma-phalam рее
BG 6.1

As we note above, this instruction is seen many times in the G─лt─Б. What does тАЬgiving up the fruit of karmaтАЭ mean? Does it mean that one should cook food and throw it out without eating? Or plant a garden, and when it yields fruits and flowers, throw them in the gutter? No, it isnтАЩt like that. Instead of eating cooked food by oneself, it should be shared with others. Surely, thereтАЩs no harm in the cook smelling the aroma of the food he cooked? Or should he crumple his face saying that the p─Бyasam is bitter or spicy, just because he prepared it? Should he not experience pleasure? Even if he experiences pleasure, should he not express his experience of pleasure? Is dharma only in calling a flower disgusting? Is karma-phala-ty─Бga only about calling a steaming bowl of rice as plain mud?
We should try and deliberate upon what constitutes karma-phala-ty─Бga. There are four aspects in this s─Бdhan─Б. If we are not clear about them, karma-phala-ty─Бga becomes just a word тАФ an imposing sound that hits the eardrums. Let us look at these aspects.

1.Karma means kartavya-karma. Kartavya is that work, failing to perform which amounts to dereliction. The three main deciding factors for this karma are three -

The first is the felicitous inspiration that arises in us. It is a feeling that if this work is done, it is good for everyone.
The second is the capability and means to do the work, something that we already possess.
The third is an understanding of the necessities of the world around us тАФ to our family, society and country.

Kartavya is work done using our energy and wealth to better the lives of others. We might make mistakes when we try to undertake certain activities. We might try to take on more than we can handle; or display our worldly benevolence where it is not required. Thus, we might start performing something that is not our kartavya; and also forget our kartavya. Taking unnecessary karma upon oneself might create problems. Karma entails coming in contact with the world; coming in contact with the world means that we are stepping into the lives of others. Thus in our haste to perform a duty that we think we have to do, we get embroiled in the pains and pleasures of others. To perform a p┼лja with a hundred thousand jasmine flowers, one may have to enter the gardens of unknown people and jostle among them to obtain the flowers. To feed a thousand people, he may have to fall at the feet of unworthy people. Thus, even an activity done with the objective of puс╣Зya might cause us to come in contact with p─Бpa during its course. Therefore, one must be careful when deciding what is kartavya and what is not. Kartavya should not be given up, a work that is not kartavya should not be taken up.

2. Secondly, once a kartavya is decided upon, we should not procrastinate, thinking whether this activity will be beneficial or not. Regardless of whether it results in victory or defeat, a kartavya in accordance with dharma should be performed. If our conscience proclaims something as dharma, we should consider it divine ordinance and do it, even if a hundred people are against it or a hundred obstacles are in its way. Just because it faces defeat, a dharmic kartavya does not become adharmic. Whether a kartavya is indeed a kartavya or not, whether dharma is indeed dharmic or not does not depend on its result тАФ profitable or detrimental. Dharma is dependent on Universal Truth and existence; Therefore, kartavya is performed as an offering to Bhagav─Бn. тАЬParameshvara pr─лtyarthaс╣ГтАЭ, тАЬ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣З─Бrpaс╣ЗamastuтАЭ тАФ this is the method of kartavya.

  1. Thirdly, one should not worry about the fruit of karma that has been performed. The fruit of karma or the lack thereof, is decided by daiva. Who knows our karmas in the past, or the eligibility of others related to our karma? There is no one who can figure out the cause and effect-relationship among various entities in this world thoroughly. The fruit of karma is accorded to each j─лva, based on their ability accrued for many lives from past karmas. The important philosophy here is to not to be mentally stirred by this change. Whatever comes, due to Bhagav─БnтАЩs will, and therefore it has to be surrendered to. If we are impatient, we will become defiant towards the Divine. Therefore, we should always be indifferent towards the fruits of our karma, and not let our mind be disturbed by it.

Sukha-duс╕еkhe same kс╣Ыtv─Б l─Бbh─Бl─Бbhau jay─Бjayau ред
samaс╕е siddh─Б-vasiddhau ca kс╣Ыtv─БтАЩpi na nibadhyate рее
BG 2.38

  1. Fourthly, we should accept what comes to us, as the pras─Бda from ─к┼Ыvara.

Tena tyaktena bhu├▒j─лth─Бс╕е рее
─к┼Ыopaniс╣гad - 1

The above statement does not mean that one should not experience pleasure. One should experience pleasure, but with the feeling that it is a pras─Бda obtained in a temple.

[[Ch. 12 Yoga of the steps of Bhakti (part 3) Source: prekshaa]]

┼Ъr─л Kanakad─Бsa, the great mystic, said this -

с╣вaс╕Нurasadannak├и nalid─Бс╕Нuva jihv├и ред kaс╕Нurucigoс╣Гbuva ruciguс╣Зa ninadayya рее
(Yours is the tongue that enjoys food with six rasas;
yours is the nature that deeply relishes all tastes)

The beauty, the very essence of the things that are present in the universe, the senses that experience them, and their capability to discern and enjoy belong to Bhagav─Бn.

annaс╣Г ca brahma ред bhokt─Б ca brahma рее
(Food is Brahma, the eater is Brahma).

Therefore,

brahm─Бrpaс╣Зaс╣Г brahma-haviс╕е brahm─Бgnau brahmaс╣З─Б hutam рее
BG 4.24

Therefore, one should experience pleasure with the feeling that the thing that is giving happiness, and oneтАЩs own energy that is experiencing pleasure are both the boons of Bhagav─Бn. Bhagav─Бn is the owner of everything, and I am a mere beggar тАФ this is the common meaning of some of our traditional statements. Hindus first offer the food that is cooked, fruits and even flowers that are to be worn, to the divine. Only after that do they consume it themselves as pras─Бda. Muslims have this tradition (Bismillah) too; Christians also have Grace. Objects of pleasure are not oneтАЩs own, nor are they of oneтАЩs own earning. They belong to the Divine, who has given it to us as a boon. A man who enjoys worldly pleasures in this manner will never need to have apprehensions about his karma accruing p─Бpa. Even if the fruit of the karma is obtained from his karma тАФ his own effort, he should not try to own it, that is karma-phala-ty─Бga. Thus, removing the connection of ego from the result and connecting ─к┼Ыvara with it instead, is karma-phala-ty─Бga.

Thus, karma-phala-ty─Бga has four aspects : (1) Discernment about kartavya (2) equanimity about good or bad results (3) giving up the results to Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa (the mindset of Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣З─Бrpaс╣Зa) (4) acceptance of pras─Бda.

The summary of this discussion is to remember Bhagav─Бn in times of happiness and think of it as his boon, and remember him in times of adversities and look upon them as training for the j─лva.

Thus, the instruction is step-by-step. At its most advanced, it is worshipping the abstract. The second step is resorting to the worship of ─к┼Ыvara with form. The third step is the practice of the remembrance of ─к┼Ыvara and the fourth is the practice of performing oneтАЩs duties for the love of ─к┼Ыvara. The fifth is understanding ─к┼ЫvaraтАЩs will.

J├▒─Бna is at a higher level than practice; dhy─Бna is higher than j├▒─Бna; karma-phala-ty─Бga is better than dhy─Бna; from this renunciation of the fruit of karma results peace; peace itself is the ultimate fruit.

Abhy─Бsa is to believe an instruction that is received, and to follow it without independent questioning or reasoning. J├▒─Бna is internalizing the instruction by deliberating upon and analyzing it. Dhy─Бna is having this guiding philosophy constantly in oneтАЩs sight. When the mind is fixed upon this principle, selfishness vanishes. Thus, when ego and attachment gradually lessen and the j─лva offers itself completely to param─Бtma, peace is then readily obtained.

Bhakti has many outcomes тАФ worldly pleasures, wealth, fame, long life, children, accomplishment of all desires, getting rid of hardships and misfortunes, waning of sins, obtaining svarga тАФ thus there are many benefits. Above all, is ─Аtma-┼Ы─Бnti тАФ peace for the ─Бtma. In the eight verses from тАЬadveс╣гс╣н─Б sarvabh┼лt─Бn─Бс╣ГтАЭ to тАЬteтАЩt─лva me priy─Бс╕етАЭ, sv─Бm─л enunciates the qualities of devotees who perform bhakti for peace of mind, so that we keep them in mind.

When he was tired of worldly affairs, when he suffered from anguish whether his work would continue or not, when people became furious with him for no reason at all, when his friends were depressed or when he felt agitated for whatever reason, Sri.Sastry would recall these verses. If you permit me to say so, Sri.Srinivasa Sastry had followed this ideal to the last letter.

Who can say to what extent we can practise the qualities of adveс╣гс╣н─Б, maitra, etc? I believe that if we recall these qualities again and again and try to follow them, ─к┼Ыvara might bless us with compassion.

[[Ch. 13 Yoga of Nature and the Primeval being (part 1) Source: prekshaa]]

Introduction

ekam-ev─Бdvayam-ar┼лpaс╣Г brahmam-avyayam-akriyaс╣Г

lokaj─лvana-s─лс╣Гdhu-v─лciyoс╕╗ ─Бtmad─л с╕Нolotsavaс╣Г рее

Brahma is the One, without a second, formless, changeless and without action

Summary

Bhagav─Бn ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣ЗaтАЩs instruction is chiefly about the method of gaining knowledge; about the greatest philosophy that is the object of gaining knowledge, and the discernment to distinguish between dharma and adharma that results from knowledge. All the works of the universe are due to the interaction between prakс╣Ыti (Nature) and puruс╣гa (the sentient being). Since these transactions are infinite, the variety and uniqueness we find in various forms of life and other things in the universe are also infinite. The method of realizing the single entity that is inside all this variety, the basis of everything, is explained in the G─лt─Б.
Prakс╣Ыti is the field where the plant of saс╣Гs─Бra grows. ─Аtm─Б is the farmer. The energy of the ─Бtm─Б is of the form of true knowledge, and is always equanimous. Because it is equanimous, the knower of the field (lit. kс╣гetraj├▒a) perceives his field and also other fields and farmers. Param─Бtm─Б is the energy, the thread that binds and holds together the various aspects of the universe. Bhagav─Бn describes kс╣гetra as a constituent of prakс╣Ыti, and explains qualities such as humility and straightforwardness that have to be practised by those who want to realize the principle of the ─Бtm─Б (─Бtmatattva).
Some realize the nature of m─Бy─Б with their intellect and make their lives fruitful. Some others practise dhy─Бna and realize param─Бtm─Б from that. Yet others learn the splendour that is the ─Бtm─Б from others, worship that and obtain fulfilment. Worship is of paramount importance тАФ as it grows, divine experience comes along.
M─Бy─Б is the wall raised by prakс╣Ыti between j─лva and param─Бtm─Б. It comprises bricks that are the guс╣Зa-triad. For those who want to understand the nature of the ─Бtm─Б, it is necessary to understand the three guс╣Зas.

Section 14 / Chapter 13Kс╣гetra-Kс╣гetraj├▒a-Yoga /Prakс╣Ыti-Puruс╣гa-Yoga

(The Yoga of Nature and the Primeval being)

Exposition of knowledge starts in this chapter of the G─лt─Б. The eighteen chapters of the G─лt─Б can be divided as three с╣гaс╣нkas тАФ Karmaс╣гaс╣нka, Bhaktiс╣гaс╣нka and J├▒─Бnaс╣гaс╣нka respectively. A с╣гaс╣нka is an aggregate of six chapters тАФ a hexade. In a hexade, the respective topic is the principal topic, whereas an allusion to the other two is incidental. Looking at this in its entirety, karma, bhakti and j├▒─Бna are like the three stones of a stove, all of them to be used together. Even though they appear as three separate entities, they work together in unison. The three can be considered separately only for the sake of intellectual understanding, not for practice and experience. Thus, the portion of the G─лt─Б from the thirteenth to the eighteenth chapter helps in understanding the true nature of Brahma.

The principal topic of the present chapter is j├▒─Бna or knowledge. What is j├▒─Бna? It is a work of the intellect. If an animal recognizes another animal or thing that is different from it, that is j├▒─Бna. There are two important strengths within us тАФ one is the manas and the other is the buddhi. The manas experiences deficiency or desire or pain, just as feeling happiness, pleasure, love and hatred is its job. Based on the reports submitted by the eyes, ears and other sense organs, the manas experiences want and insufficiency, and satisfaction and happiness. The buddhi then evaluates and informs about the nature and worth of the information thus gathered thus by the manas through the sense organs and its memory. The manas and buddhi are not completely different. They are like the two different sides of a single sheet of paper. It is merely shastric terminology to recognize the action of one side as feeling and classify it as that of the manas, and recognize that on the other side as that of the buddhi and call it j├▒─Бna. Even though feeling and knowledge are one and the same at the etymological level, their common usage is slightly different.

It is the work of manas when a baby cries of hunger. It is the work of the buddhi when it stops crying on seeing its mother approaching, thinking that she might be bringing milk. It is the work of the manas when a mother grieves over her childтАЩs illness. Then it is the work of the buddhi that sends the father to the doctor and gets medicine. The manas made Du┼Ыyanta fall hopelessly in love with ┼Ъakuntal─Б and wail to no end. Later, when she complained that a bee from the garden was trying to hurt her, it was his buddhi that made him rush forward on this pretext, bragging thus about his heroism тАФ тАЬwho can trouble the poor girl when I am here?тАЭ

Buddhi arranges information gathered by the manas about things and provides them for action. During this process, it deliberates upon their nature and inherent disposition, and what they can be used for. The result of this deliberation is j├▒─Бna.

Bhakti is mainly a work of the manas. J├▒─Бna is mainly a work of the buddhi. Karma is a bodily work that is directed by both manas and buddhi.
Let us now go to the text. In the beginning of the G─лt─Б itself, Bhagav─Бn has noted the following тАФ

deh─л nityam avadhyoтАЩyaс╣Г dehe sarvasya bh─Бrata
BG 2.20
There is a body (deha), and there is a deh─л (the ─Бtm─Б that resides in the body) that rules over it and is separate from it. The body undergoes change and eventual destruction, but the deh─л тАФ ─Бtm─Б is unchangeable and eternal.

Since Parabrahma is extremely subtle and cannot be described by mere words, Bhagav─Бn has placed pointers to its nature within seemingly contradictory sentences. Only by examining the sentences again and again can we discern the underlying meaning hidden between these lines.

an─Бdimat paraс╣Г brahma na sat tan-n─Бsad-ucyate рее
BG 13.13
тАЬParabrahma is without beginning, and is said to be both existing and not existingтАЭ.

Here, the first part an─Бdimat paraс╣Г brahma can also be split as тАЬan─Бdi+matparaс╣Г+brahmaтАЭ. Then, we can read the meaning as тАЬBrahma is that which is without beginning, and which is above my present birth of Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣З─Бvat─Бra, which has a beginningтАЭ.

The second part is more difficult to understand. It has the following words тАФ

na + sat + tat + na + asat (ucyate). The meaning is as below:
tat = that Brahma
na sat = appears as though it does not exist тАФ that is, it is not directly perceptible but has to be inferred. It lies hidden under the blanket woven by prakс╣Ыti, that is the universe. This blanket that we see undergoes change and destruction. Therefore it is asat. The тАШsadvastuтАЩ Brahma lies hidden in the тАШasatтАЩ universe, and imparts a feeling that it is not there. Therefore, тАЬna satтАЭ.
тАЬNa asatтАЭ = In reality, it is not something that does not exist. It is present at all times in all places. Even if it is not seen, it is not something that does not exist.
In тАЬna sat tatтАЭ , тАШsatтАЩ is something that can be discerned by the senses.
Brahma does not exist from the point of view of the sense organs. The same opinion is espoused by the ┼Ыruti also тАФ

asadv─Б idam agra ─Бs─лt ред tato vai sat aj─Бyata рее
Tait. Up. 7.1
тАЬIndeed, didnтАЩt asat verily exist in the beginning? Sat was born from itтАЭ

From the verb тАЬ─Бs─лtтАЭ, it is clear that there was something. But it was not possible to be known or understood. It was without a form, gender and other physical properties. What existed in the beginning was not vacuum, but something that was not perceptible by eyes and ears. Since it could not be seen physically, it was called asat. Asat means imperceptible. Something that exists but does not show itself, is avyakta. That is asat. Here, тАЬasatтАЭ does not mean complete nonexistence, but nonexistence from the point of view of perceptibility. It is the nonexistence that is inferred about the beginning of time, from the point of view of after the universe came into existence.

[[Ch. 13 Yoga of Nature and the Primeval being (part 2) Source: prekshaa]]

How is Brahma?

sarvataс╕е p─Бс╣Зip─Бdaс╣Г tat sarvatokс╣гi-┼Ыiro-mukham ред
sarvataс╕е ┼Ыrutimalloke sarvam ─Бvс╣Ыtya tiс╣гс╣нhati рее
BG 13.14
тАЬIts limbs are everywhere, as are its eyes and heads. It тАЩsarvam ─Бvс╣Ыtya tiс╣гс╣нhatiтАЩ тАФ pervades everythingтАЭ. Here, we are reminded of the line тАЬsahasra┼Ы─лrс╣г─Б puruс╣гaс╕етАЭ from the Puruс╣гas┼лkta and the eleventh chapter of the G─лt─Б.
sarvendriya-guс╣З─Бbh─Бsaс╣Г sarvendriya-vivarjitam ред
asaktaс╣Г sarvabhс╣Ыt-caiva nirguс╣Зaс╣Г guс╣Зa-bhoktс╣Ы ca рее
BG 13.15
тАЬIt shines in all works of the senses. But it does not have sense organs. It is not attached to anything, but still sustains everything. It is without any qualities, but experiences them.
avibhaktaс╣Г ca bh┼лteс╣гu vibhaktam iva ca sthitam ред
bh┼лta-bhartс╣Ы ca tat j├▒eyaс╣Г grasiс╣гс╣Зu prabhaviс╣гс╣Зu ca рее
BG 13.17
тАЬIt is whole, but seems as though it is divided among all creatures. It bears all creation and nurtures them. It consumes them and gives birth to them againтАЭ.
jyotiс╣г─Бmapi tat jyotiс╕е tamasaс╕е param (ucyate) рее
BG 13.18
тАЬIt is the light of all lights. It is farther and beyond all darknessтАЭ.

This is what we have set out to understand тАФ something that cannot be defined, something that is not accessible to description. Which student of poetry can claim that the above lines are not poetry?
What is the source of knowledge? What is the one that reveals everything? What is that energy that reveals everything to everyone?

yath─Б prak─Б┼Ыayatyekaс╕е kс╣Ыtsnaс╣Г lokamimaс╣Г raviс╕е ред
kс╣гetraс╣Г kс╣гetr─л tath─Б kс╣Ыtsnaс╣Г prak─Б┼Ыayati bh─Бrata рее
BG 13.34
тАЬJust as one Sun lights up the whole world, the kс╣гetr─л (one who is the lord of the kс╣гetra, that is ─Бtm─Б) lights up the whole fieldтАЭ.

тАЬHow do we see one another? We think it is because of our eyes. However, mere eyes are not enough. On the night of Am─Бv─Бsy─Б, when there is no external light, we cannot see one another. If our eyes have to work, they need a common agent such as the Sun or a lamp that can communicate between the eyes and the object to be seen. The brightness of the eyes mingles with the light from the Sun or the lamp and impacts the mind. How does the mind attain the capability to sense and perceive this impact? From the param─Бtm─Б who is inside. Therefore the ─Бtm─Б that dwells inside a body is called para├▒jyoti. In the Bс╣Ыhad─Бraс╣Зyaka, this concept is established thus тАФ

atr─Бyaс╣Г puruс╣гaс╕е svayaс╣Г jyotirbhavati рее
Bс╣Ыhad─Бraс╣Зyaka 4.1.3.9

In a small verse of this chapter called jyotir-br─Бhmaс╣Зa in the same upaniс╣гad, this theory is crystallized:

kiс╣Г jyotis-tava bh─Бnu-m─Бn ahani me r─Бtrau prad─лp─Б-dikam ред
sy─Бd-evaс╣Г ravi-d─лpa-dar┼Ыana-vidhau kiс╣Г jyotir-─Бkhyahi me рее
cakс╣гus-tasya nim─лlana-─Бdi samaye kiс╣Г dh─лr-dhiyo dar┼Ыane ред
kiс╣Г tatr─Б-ham ato bhav─Бn paramakaс╣Г jyotis-tad-asmi prabho рее
Eka┼Ыlok─л
The guru asks his disciple:
Q: With the help of which light do you view objects?
A: With the help of the Sun
Q: In the night?
A: Lamp, fire, etc
Q: That is right, but with which light do you view the Sun and the lamp?
A: With the eyes.
Q: When you have closed your eyes, how do you recognize objects?
A: With my buddhi.
Q: How do you recognize the buddhi?
Q: With the light of the ─Бtm─Б within me.
Q: Then you are para├▒jyoti тАФ supreme light, are you not?
A: Yes. I am para├▒jyoti.

A slightly changed version of the above verse can be found in the ┼Ыata┼Ыlok─л, ascribed to ┼Ъaс╣Еkar─Бch─Бrya.

The G─лt─Бc─Бrya says the following about this Supreme being :

j├▒─Бnaс╣Г j├▒eyaс╣Г j├▒─Бnagamyaс╣Г hс╣Ыdi sarvasya viс╣гс╣нhitam рее
BG 13.18
Knowledge (j├▒─Бna), that which has to be known (j├▒eya) and j├▒─Бnagamya (attainable by knowledge) are present in the hearts of everyone.

This concept has to be examined a little carefully.
J├▒─Бna is the means or technique to obtain true knowledge. These means are elucidated as principles such as тАЬam─Бnitvaс╣ГтАЭ, adambhitvaс╣ГтАЭ, etc. Personal practices like ┼Ыama, dama and societal ones like yaj├▒a, d─Бna and tapas are meant here. Therefore, j├▒─Бna here means the self-discipline required for gaining true knowledge.
J├▒eya : This is the object of knowledge.

J├▒eyaс╣Г yat tat pravakс╣гy─Бmi yad j├▒─Бtv─БтАЩmс╣Ыtam a┼Ыnute ред
an─Бdimat paraс╣Г brahma na sat tann─Бsaducyate рее
BG 13.13
The supreme tattva is that, on understanding which all our questions will be answered. That is j├▒eya.
kasminnu bhagavo vij├▒─Бte sarvamidaс╣Г vij├▒─Бtaс╣Г bhavati рее
Muс╣Зс╕Нakopaniс╣гat 1.3
yen─Б┼Ыrutaс╣Г ┼Ыrutaс╣Г bhavaty-amataс╣Г matam avij├▒─Бtaс╣Г vij├▒─Бtam рее
Ch─Бndogyopaniс╣гat 6.1.3
─Бtmano dar┼Ыanena ┼Ыravaс╣Зena maty─Б vij├▒─Бnenedaс╣Г sarvaс╣Г viditam рее
Bс╣Ыhad─Бraс╣Зyaka-upaniс╣гat 2.4.5

тАЬSarvaс╣ГтАЭ here means all that which we understand to be existing, not excluding even the tiniest, most insignificant bit. When we understand the nature of the ─Бtm─Б completely, we can understand the nature of other things from that. That ─Бtm─Б is Parabrahma. That itself is j├▒eya. It is the basis of all satt─Б or existence. When its nature is understood, the form of all things, the actions of all j─лvas can be understood really and wholly. That fundamental knowledge is j├▒eya. It is Parabrahma.
3.j├▒─Бna-gamyam: What is the use of understanding the ─Бtm─Б? If the nature of that which is the basis and the raw material of all life is understood, the righteous or wrong way of leading a life will also be understood; the understanding of making life productive will also be understood. The discernment of dharma, adharma and adhidharma is the prime use of studying philosophy.

Thus, it is necessary to understand the following three things тАФ

  1. Readiness for knowledge 2. The supreme principle, which is the object of knowledge 3. dharma, adharma and adhidharma тАФ which are the result of knowledge.

At the beginning of this chapter, we used the words kс╣гetra and kс╣гetraj├▒a. We have seen the use of some of their synonyms. Let us recall these technical terms once.

| | | | | |—–|—————–|————————–|—————| | | I | II | III | | 1 | kс╣гetra | kс╣гetraj├▒a, kс╣гetri | j─лv─Бtma | | 2 | deha (body) | embodied j─лva (deh─л) | j─лv─Бtma | | 3 | ┼Ыar─лra (body) | embodied j─лva (┼Ыar─лr─л) | j─лv─Бtma | | 4 | jagat | s┼лtr─Бtma | ─кshvara | | 5 | prakс╣Ыti | puruс╣гa | puruс╣гottama |

We have seen in the upaniс╣гads that Brahma is understood by us in two forms.

etatsarvaс╣Г yanm┼лrtaс╣Г c─Бm┼лrtam рее (Pra┼Ыnopaniс╣гat)
с╕Нve v─Бva brahmaс╣Зo r┼лpe ред m┼лrtaс╣Г caiv─Бm┼лrtaс╣Г ca рее
(Bс╣Ыhad─Бraс╣Зyakopaniс╣гat)

We have seen that the same has been reiterated in the 12th verse of this chapter, asтАФ

na sat tat ред na asat рее

Prakс╣Ыti is alluded to in тАЬna satтАЭ and puruс╣гa (j─лv─Бtma) in тАЬna asatтАЭ. The same deliberation continues now.

prakс╣Ыtiс╣Г puruс╣гaс╣Г caiva viddhyan─Бd─л ubh─Бvapi ред
vik─Бr─Бс╣Г┼Ыca guс╣З─Бс╣Г┼Ыcaiva viddhi prakс╣Ыti-saс╣Гbhav─Бn рее
BG 13.20
тАЬJust as the parabrahma which is the basis of all universe is without beginning, its manifestations тАФ prakс╣Ыti and puruс╣гa also do not have a beginning. Understand that all changes in the universe, all its qualities and influences are from prakс╣ЫtiтАЭ.

An─Бdi means that without beginning тАФ therefore it is not affected by the vagaries of time.
When is the birthday of prakс╣Ыti or the universe? They are not born at all; they exist тАФ svata eva тАФ by themselves.
If they are not born, will they not die either? No, they do not die, but their death is as true and as real as their birth. This means that birth and death are small alterations but not the real form of the parabrahma.
To the eyes of someone who has understood parabrahma, creation and destruction are the momentary magnificent manifestations of prakс╣Ыti, which is the formidable strength of Parabrahma. That is m─Бy─Б. At once, exists and does not exist тАФ it depends on the knower. We have seen this idea earlier.
What is the greatness of prakс╣Ыti?

k─Бrya-k─Бraс╣Зa-kartс╣Ыtve hetuс╕е prakс╣Ыtir-ucyate рее
BG 13.21

All the qualitative and and operational attributes of the universe belong to the jurisdiction of prakс╣Ыti. The action of the strength of parabrahma is fundamental for all instruments and all doings.

Then what is j─лva? It is described thusтАФ

puruс╣гaс╕е sukha-duс╕еkh─Бn─Бс╣Г bhoktс╣Ыtve hetur-ucyate рее
BG 13.21

J─лva is the one that experiences joy and sorrow. Prakс╣Ыti inspires and excites. With this inspiration and excitement, a human acts with or without discernment and acquires joy or sorrow accordingly.

puruс╣гaс╕е prakс╣Ыtistho hi bhuс╣Еkte prakс╣Ыtij─Бn guс╣З─Бn ред
karaс╣Зaс╣Г guс╣Зasaс╣ЕgoтАЩsya sad-asad-yonijanmasu рее
BG 13.22
тАЬWhen a man is enamoured by prakс╣Ыti, he experiences the qualities of prakс╣Ыti. The form that he chooses to take in this world and the family where he chooses to be born show what qualities of prakс╣Ыti he chooses to acceptтАЭ.

Thus the future of puruс╣гa тАФ or j─лva тАФ depends on his discernment and discrimination of right and wrong, and his ability to critically examine virtues and vices.
We have seen the inspiration of prakс╣Ыti and the responsibility of the j─лva. That is our life. We have to next examine the ─к┼Ыvara-tattva or the Puruс╣гottama-tattva.

upadraс╣гс╣н─БтАЩnumant─Б ca bhart─Б bhokt─Б mahe┼Ыvaraс╕еред
param─Бtmeti c─Бpyukto deheтАЩsmin puruс╣гaс╕е paraс╕е рее
BG 13.23

The supervising agency тАФ the one who ensures that the fruit of an action reaches the doer тАФ is Mahe┼Ыvara. He does not need anything for himself. He does not say no to anything either. Therefore, he is тАЬAnumant─БтАЭ, meaning that he remains aloof and approves of everything. He says тАЬDo whatever you want, and partake of the fruit of what you have doneтАЭ. He looks as though he is incarnating as a j─лva, performs actions in this world and experiences the results of his actions. Still, he is the master of all; he is not subordinate to anything. That Mahe┼Ыvara himself is the supreme being that is in the body. This is unaffected by the state of the body. We call him the Param─Бtm─Б.

[[Ch. 13 Yoga of Nature and the Primeval being (part 3) Source: prekshaa]]

Thus, the Parabrahma is conducting the activities of the universe in three forms тАФ prakс╣Ыti, j─лva and ─к┼Ыvara.

y─Бvatsaс╣Гj─Бyate ki├▒cit sattvaс╣Г sth─Бvarajaс╣Еgamam рее
kс╣гetra-kс╣гetraj├▒a-saс╣Гyog─Бt (tad-viddhi bharatarс╣гabha) рее
BG 13.27

Whatever is born in this world тАФ whether it is a living being or an inanimate object тАФ the instrument of its birth is the union of kс╣гetra and kс╣гetraj├▒a, prakс╣Ыti and puruс╣гa, or the universe and j─лva. They are both equally responsible for the activities of the universe.
IsnтАЩt the universe of innumerable forms? Therefore, the types of unions of prakс╣Ыti and j─лva are also innumerable. There is no limit to the forms, hustle and bustle of prakс╣Ыti. As a result, there is no limit to the complementing forms and activities of the j─лva as well. Hence, there are innumerable animals of extraordinary variety. These myriad objects and organisms appear as though they are different from one another, as though they originate from different sources. Because of this seeming diversity, we see dualities such as us and them, loved and hated. From this arise love and hatred, puс╣Зya and p─Бpa. Thus was born, the ocean of sams─Бra. Amidst the beating waves of this ocean, where is peace for the j─лva?

yad─Б bh┼лta-pс╣Ыthag-bh─Бvaс╣Г ekastham anu-pa┼Ыyati ред
tata eva ca vist─Бraс╣Г brahma sampadyate tad─Б рее
BG 13.31
тАЬWhen man sees the innumerable and diverse forms of animate beings as the manifestations of the same, single supreme energy тАФ as though they are different waves and vortices of the same ocean тАФ then he will see and experience the vast expanse of BrahmaтАЭ.

That is unity in diversity.

samaс╣Г sarveс╣гu bh┼лteс╣гu tiс╣гс╣нhantaс╣Г parame┼Ыvaram ред
vina┼ЫyatsvтАФavina┼Ыyantaс╣Г yaс╕е pa┼Ыyati sa pa┼Ыyati рее
BG 13.28
тАЬThe ─Бtm─Б who is the master is present in all beings equally. Inside the body that undergoes changes and destruction, it does not change in any way and remains the same. One who sees that, understands the true tattvaтАЭ.
samaс╣Г pa┼Ыyan hi sarvatra sam-avasthitam ─л┼Ыvaram ред
с╣Зa hinasty─Бtman─БтАЩтАЩtmanaс╣Г tato y─Бti par─Бс╣Г gatim рее
BG 13.29
тАЬOne who sees ─к┼Ыvara everywhere, equally тАФ one who experiences nearness with ─к┼Ыvara everywhere in the same way тАФ cannot harm anyone. This is because he sees and experiences all j─лvas that appear different, as the manifestations of the same Brahma. That is the way to the best stateтАЭ.

We saw above that all the motions of the universe every day and every second, birth, death and other changes, the interactions between various animate and inanimate beings in the universe are the result of the united working of prakс╣Ыti and puruс╣гa, the universe and j─лvas and the body and the embodied j─лva. What is the role of the Param─Бtm─Б in this constant flurry of activities? Indeed, the ─Бtm─Б does not have any role. It is without any attachment, and is aloof.

an─Бditv─Бt nirguс╣Зatv─Бt param─Бtm─БтАЩyam avyayaс╕е ред
┼Ыar─лrasthoтАЩpi kaunteya na karoti na lipyate рее
BG 13.32
тАЬThe param─Бtm─Б is without beginning, middle or end. He is without alities or alterations. Even if he is present in the body amidst its various attributes, he does not perform anything. Nothing attaches to himтАЭ.

The interactions between kс╣гetra and kс╣гetraj├▒a, etc. described above, are for prakс╣Ыti and j─лva only. Param─Бtm─Б is separate from these both.
In the seventh chapter, we saw that the sadvastu is understood in three ways тАФ

  1. Apar─Б-prakс╣Ыti or the inanimate universe 2. Par─Б-prakс╣Ыti or the animate energy 3. Parabrahma, which is the shelter for both the prakс╣Ыtis, and is yet different from both of them.

Let us recall those sentences again.

Bh┼лmir-─БpoтАЩnalo v─Бyuс╕е khaс╣Г mano buddhir-eva caред
Ahaс╣Еk─Бra it─лyaс╣Г me bhinn─Б prakс╣Ыtir-aс╣гс╣нadh─Б рее
BG 7.4

apareyam рее

This is the physical nature. It is inanimate. ─Аtm─Б or energy is separate from this.

Itastvany─Бс╣Г prakс╣Ыtiс╣Г viddhi me par─Бс╣Г ред
j─лvabh┼лt─Бс╣Г (mah─Бb─Бho) yayedaс╣Г dh─Бryate jagat рее
BG 7.5

This is the part of Bhagav─БnтАЩs prakс╣Ыti that is animate.

Ahaс╣Г kс╣Ыtsnasya jagataс╕е prabhavaс╕е pralayas-tath─Б ред
mayi sarvam idaс╣Г protaс╣Г s┼лtre maс╣Зigaс╣З─Б iva рее
BG 7.6

This is the nature of param─Бtm─Б, the thread that holds all these together.

Thus the supreme being is understood as тАФ

  1. The universe made of five elements 2. J─лv─Бtm─Б 3. Param─Бtm─Б.

Thus, we think that the real or sadvastu is one or many. How do we get this understanding? Where is the source of this j├▒─Бna?
When we set out to learn a subtle and deep matter, it is easier if we start from a direct and perceptible concept and then move towards more subtle and abstract thoughts. Therefore, the Sv─Бm─л starts with the following тАФ

  1. idaс╣Г ┼Ыar─лraс╣Г kaunteya kс╣гetram ityabhidh─лyate рее - BG 13.2 2. etad yo vetti taс╣Г pr─Бhuс╕е kс╣гetraj├▒a iti tad-vidaс╕е рее - BG 13.2 3. kс╣гetraj├▒aс╣Г c─Бpi m─Бс╣Г viddhi sarva-kс╣гetreс╣гu bh─Бrata ред - BG 13.3

As we saw above, the subject here is of the body, the embodied j─лva, and param─Бtm─Б. We shall look at these from the point of view of acquiring knowledge. Initially, тАЬidaс╣Г ┼Ыar─лraс╣ГтАЭ тАФ this body тАФ is kс╣гetra, fundamental, base, field. All growth and prosperity starts from there. There is no j─лva without the body. The instrument that is the body has three sheaths тАФ sth┼лla, s┼лkс╣гma and laiс╣Еga. The ─Бtm─Б resides inside these as j─лva. Thus, the most fundamental object that is necessary for the sustenance of all animate objects is the body. That is prakс╣Ыti. The apar─Б-prakс╣Ыti is the womb and param─Бtm─Б is the seed.

etad-yon─лni bh┼лt─Бni рее (BG 7.6)
b─лjaс╣Г m─Бс╣Г sarva-bh┼лt─Бn─Бm рее (BG 7.10)

Prakс╣Ыti is the womb; param─Бtm─Б is the seed. Prakс╣Ыti is the field where the plant of sams─Бra grows; param─Бtm─Б is the kс╣гetraj├▒a or the farmer.
The j─лv─Бtm─Б was called the deh─л, or the one who resides in the body. Now the word kс╣гetraj├▒a is used. What is the difference? The difference is in the suffix тАЬj├▒aтАЭ (*j├▒a - avabodhane,*to know, comprehend, understand). In the word тАЬdeh─лтАЭ, the action of knowing is not stated. тАЬJ├▒aтАЭ means one who knows. One who thinks that тАЬthis field is mine; I rule over it; this is how it has to be ruledтАЭ, is kс╣гetraj├▒a тАФ the ─Бtm─Б who is present inside the j─лva.

  1. kс╣гetraj├▒aс╣Г c─Бpi m─Бс╣Г viddhi sarva-kс╣гetreс╣гu bh─Бrata рее (13.2)

Here kс╣гetra is the first object and kс╣гetraj├▒a is the second. Knowledge is only possible when there are two objects. The activity of knowing needs two objects тАФ the knower and the known. The knower is j├▒─Бtс╣Ы, the known is j├▒eya. If we stick to the words j├▒─Бt─Б and j├▒eya, we can discuss the subject quickly without the strain of too many words.

How does the j├▒─Бt─Б understand the j├▒eya? This is an important topic. IsnтАЩt j├▒─Бna the relationship that is established between two objects through the activity of the mind and the intellect? What is the instrument that establishes this relationship? Now suppose I sit in the building of the Gokhale institute and talk to someone who is sitting in the Akashavani building. The relationship between us is established by the telephone wire between us. Let us call this instrument that transmits sound from me to him and back from him to me as the communicator. The communicator makes something known. The wire is attached to both sides and is equally related to both. In our present discussion, the body is the kс╣гetra and the ─Бtm─Б is the kс╣гetraj├▒a. If the ─Бtm─Б has to understand the body, there should be a communicating cord between them. Which is that? The communicator should belong to both sides, should be equanimous towards both and should engulf both. What is this between the body and the j─лva? That is the param─Бtm─Б.

Let us see another example. I am speaking now. You are all listening kindly. What is the communicator between us? тАЬSoundтАЭ is not enough. If I speak Greek or Latin, only meaningless sounds will reach you. Then, the sound starting from my lips will reach your ears, but cannot reach your minds. My purpose will not be fulfilled if there is no communicator between my mind and yours. Kannada is that communicator. Kannada is the equal instrument for us both. Therefore it can establish a relationship between two minds. Therefore, common language is our communicator.

Similarly, what is the communicator between the kс╣гetra and the kс╣гetraj├▒a, that is equally disposed towards both of them? That is the energy of the ─Бtm─Б. Since this energy - the ─Бtmacaitanya is equally disposed towards both sides, a kс╣гetraj├▒a can know his kс╣гetra and also other kс╣гetras and kс╣гetraj├▒as. This is the meaning of the following line from the seventh chapter тАФ

с╣Гayi sarvamidaс╣Г protaс╣Г s┼лtre maс╣Зigaс╣З─Б iva рее (BG 7.7)

A thread strings beads of various shapes and colors and creates a necklace out of them. If the thread breaks, the beads will be strewn every which way. The various aspects of the universe are similarly arranged. The thread that strings them is param─Бtm─Б, and is the communicator that establishes the relationship of knowledge between them. Therefore, the ┼Ы─Бstras call it the тАЬs┼лtr─БtamaтАЭ.
There are three concepts to keep in mind here.

  1. kс╣гetra тАФ which is the prakс╣Ыti of the universe 2. kс╣гetraj├▒a тАФ which is the j─лvatma 3. param─Бtma, The thread that extends equally amongst all kс╣гetras and kс╣гetraj├▒as

Bhagav─Бn has given the description of all the above. Let us first look at prakс╣Ыti.

Mah─Б-bh┼лt─Бny-ahaс╣Еk─Бro buddhir-avyaktam-eva ca ред
indriy─Бс╣Зi da┼Ыaikaс╣Г ca paс╣Гca cendriya-gocar─Бс╕е рее
BG 13.6

These are twenty four objects together тАФ
The five elements тАФ (1) Earth, (2) Water, (3) Fire, (4) Air and (5) ─Бk─Б┼Ыa
(6) ahaс╣Зk─Бra (the concept of I, ego)
(7) buddhi
(8) avyakta (prakс╣Ыti that is in reserve тАФ the creative energy that is hidden and beyond our imagination)
The five sense organs тАФ (9) eyes (10) ears (11) Nose (12) tongue (13) skin
The five organs of action тАФ (14) speech (15) hands (16) legs (17) anus (18) The gonads
(19) The manas, which is beyond senses
The five senses (20) sound (21) touch (22) sight (23) taste and (24) smell.

Here, Bhagav─Бn lists the constituents of the type of prakс╣Ыti that is kс╣гetra. Among them, avyakta is one. Of the others, some тАФ like the five elements, are perceptible by everyone, whereas some тАФ like love and hatred тАФ are understood only by experience. тАЬAvyaktaтАЭ belongs to neither category. What is it?
Avyakta is something that is not manifest. It is reality that is not clear. It is the hidden energy that is invisible in spite of existing, that exists in spite of being invisible. We can call that as the hidden treasure, the reserve of the energy of the Brahma. Let us see a couple of examples. We all see water daily. We have seen lakes and wells. But when we stand in front of the Jog falls or look at the ocean, we experience an extraordinary feeling that is not felt when a lake or a well is seen. The capability to bring about such a reaction in us exists in the waters of lakes and wells, but is avyakta. It becomes perceptible when it is seen amassed in the waters of rivers and seas.

[[Ch. 13 Yoga of Nature and the Primeval being (part 4) Source: prekshaa]]

The object that is water, is HтВВO for a chemist, and ambrosia for a thirsty man. The satiating and refreshing potential imperceptible in hydrogen and oxygen was perceived by the mind of a thirsty man when they together touched his tongue.
Beauty is also the perceived state of тАЬavyaktaтАЭ. Eyes, ears, mouth, nose, cheeks and hair тАФ these are present for all faces. All bodies are equally made of skin, blood vessels and bones to a surgeon. A chemist does not see the difference in the physical makeup of one person from that of another. Can a connoisseur of beauty accept this? A face is beautiful if it has a quality that transcends that of organs, something that cannot be obtained by the analysis of a mere surgeon or a chemist; otherwise it is ugly. That quality might be a kind of brightness, movement, or expression. A frowning face might become gracious and pleasant on seeing someone. A plain face may appear beautiful to someone; it is the good fortune of the seer! The beauty that was hitherto imperceptible becomes known to the inner workings of the beholderтАЩs mind.
This, then, is avyakta. It remains hidden always and shows itself and influences us from time to time. It is the innermost motion of prakс╣Ыti.
To the innumerable avyaktas we see in the world, we can add the results of the development of human intellect. Steam power, petroleum energy, electricity were not known тАФ were avyakta тАФ a couple of hundred years ago. As human intellect developed and spread, scientific research was accelerated, it discovered and honed the тАЬavyaktaтАЭ energies and made them clearly perceptible. Train, ship, car, aeroplane, the Sputnik тАФ all these are examples of avyakta manifesting in front of us.
Sweetness is avyakta in a raw mango. As time goes by, sweetness gradually expresses itself. Taste and digestibility are avyakta in freshly harvested rice. The same rice becomes tasty and easily digestible in a few months.
Thus, avyakta is that quality of prakс╣Ыti that is hidden in the beginning and shows itself as time goes by. We can call it the rootтАФprakс╣Ыti, or the embryoтАФstate of prakс╣Ыti.

avyakt─Бd-vyaktayaс╕е sarv─Бс╕ерее
BG 8.18

Avyakta is the immense, unfathomable energy of prakс╣Ыti that lays hidden. The world is forever new because of it. It can also be described as the energy of prakс╣Ыti that rejuvenates the universe.
There are other inner workings and experiences that should be added to the twenty four concepts listed above.

icch─Б dveс╣гaс╕е sukhaс╣Г duс╕еkhaс╣Г saс╣Еgh─Бta┼Ы-cetan─Б dhс╣Ыtiс╕е рее
BG 13.7

Saс╣Зgh─Бta means a collection or a cluster, the various functions that happen along with the body. Cetan─Б is the energy that courses through the limbs. Dhс╣Ыti means steadfastness towards a motive.

etat kс╣гetraс╣Г sam─Бsena savik─Бram (ud─Бhс╣Ыtam) рее
BG 13.7

Thus, after the forms and attributes of the body are described тАФ before the characteristics of the param─Бtm─Б who gives the j─лv─Бtm─Б the ability to know him are described тАФ Bhagav─Бn elucidates the preparation required for such knowledge. This is because the knowledge of ─Бtm─Б and Brahma will remain mere phrases for someone who does not undergo spiritual instruction and internal purification; they can never be an experienced truth to him.
Among the preparations, some are dos and some are donтАЩts. Some are thus тАФ

am─Бnitvam adambhitvam ahiс╣Гs─Б kс╣г─Бntir-─Бrjavaс╣Г ред
─Бc─Бryop─Бsanaс╣Г ┼Ыaucaс╣Г sthairyam ─Бtma-vinigrahaс╕е рее
BG 13.8

Am─Бnitva: Pride means to think of oneself as the best, and gives rise to arrogance. Am─Бnitva is giving it up. That is humility, and willingness to be led.
Adambhitva: the desire to show off oneтАЩs own qualities and possessions that are deemed valuable by others is dambha. This should be given up.
Ahiс╣Гs─Б, kс╣гam─Бguс╣Зa, ─Бrjava тАФ mean that oneтАЩs conduct is not crooked, but is simple and straightforward. Performing service to the Guru, maintaining purity of body and mind, steadfastness, giving up impulsiveness and never being distracted and inattentive, not hankering after carnal pleasures and not thinking only of oneself all the time, not being captivated by wives and children or land and wealth, not swaying according to oneтАЩs own whims тАФ these are some donтАЩts.
Dos are as follows тАФ

Mayi c─Бnanya-yogena bhaktir-avyabhic─Бriс╣З─л ред
BG 13.11

Devotion to nothing else but Bhagav─Бn, being away from worldly flurry and tumult, practising silence and solitude.

adhy─Бtma-j├▒─Бna-nityatvaс╣Г tattva-j├▒─Бnartha-dar┼Ыanam ред
etad-j├▒─Бnam iti proktam aj├▒─Бnaс╣Г yad-atoтАЩnyath─Б рее
BG 13.12

Here, тАЬj├▒─БnamтАЭ is the means to knowledge, the device through which knowledge is obtained. What is meant by тАЬtattva-j├▒─Бn─Бrtha-dar┼ЫanamтАЭ? The meaning of j├▒─Бna-nityatva (or niс╣гс╣нhatva) may be understood as firmly rooted in knowledge or proficiency in learning. What does тАЬartha-dar┼ЫanamтАЭ mean? It means the direct experience of the meaning of the subject being learnt, bringing the concepts learnt by the buddhi into daily life and practising it. Reciting verses and explaining their meaning is not experiencing it. It is not enough if Philosophy is outwards, it should make one look inwards.
If someone asks us to prove philosophical concepts and to show evidence about the existence of Brahma, we should show the above list and ask them what qualities among them they have practised. If they have not passed the above exam, let them prepare themselves first. Of what use are spectacles to someone whose eyes are bandaged because of disease?

locan─Бbhy─Бс╣Г vih─лnasya darpaс╣Зaс╕е kiс╣Г kariс╣гyati?
[To a blind man what use would a mirror serve?]
(Hitopade┼Ыa)

The qualities of am─Бnitva, adambhitva and ─Бrjava are not easy to follow. We miss our steps because of transgressions that might appear small and insignificant. A man who commits a colossal offence might attain sadgati sooner. Ravana and Hiraс╣Зyaka┼Ыipu were released quickly of their mortal coils. We are scared of committing big crimes, but overlook small snafus. We easily lie in small matters, and think that they will not affect anyone. Small corruptions deform the j─лva and crumple it. The j─лva is like a string. It can be easily bent, but cannot be straightened again with the same ease. The j─лva is like paper; it is easy to fold it, but it is difficult to get rid of the creases. Those who want to experience param─Бtm─Б should first lose their crookedness and deformities. The donтАЩts in the above list demand long and careful practice. If we want to understand the supreme tattva, we should first make our j─лva get rid of its bad habits. Therefore, the first step to philosophy is self-examination and self-inquiry.
After explaining the devices to obtain knowledge comes the description of that which has to be known тАФ j├▒eya. What is that? It is the basis of all knowledge that principle which is known as param─Бtm─Б. Sv─Бm─л now alludes to it. It is only an allusion, not description. It is so subtle that description and explanation are impossible тАФ

s┼лkс╣гmatv─Бt tad-avij├▒eyam рее
BG 13.16

We saw in the chapter of karmayoga тАФ

prakс╣Ыteс╕е kriyam─Бс╣З─Бni karm─Бс╣Зi рее
(BG 3.27)
guс╣З─Б guс╣Зeс╣гu vartante рее
(BG 3.28)

On the one hand are the qualities of prakс╣Ыti, visible externally. On the other hand are past notions and perceptions, and inclinations internal to oneself. Life in the universe is constant engagement and skirmish between these two. The ─Бtm─Б is an impartial witness.

yath─Б sarvagataс╣Г saukс╣гmy─Бt ─Бk─Б┼Ыaс╣Г nopalipyate ред
sarvatr─Б-vasthito dehe tath─БтАЩтАЩtm─Б nopalipyate рее
BG 13.33
─Аk─Б┼Ыa, even though it subtly pervades everything everywhere, is not touched by anything. In the same way, even when ─Бtm─Б is present in all bodies, it is not affected by any aspect or activity of any part of the body.
yath─Б prak─Б┼Ыayaty-ekaс╕е kс╣Ыtsnaс╣Г lokam imaс╣Г raviс╕е ред
kс╣гetraс╣Г kс╣гetr─л tath─Б kс╣Ыtsnaс╣Г prak─Б┼Ыayati bh─Бrata рее
BG 13.34
тАЬJust as one Sun lights up the whole world (even if he touches it, it cannot touch him), the kс╣гetr─л (─Бtm─Б) lights up everything by virtue of its energy; still it is not affected by itтАЭ.

Let us summarize and recall the points in our discussion so far. They are four.

  1. Prakс╣Ыti: The material of the universe that is made of the five elements, it shelters other aspects; the body and its attributes; by itself it is inanimate. 2. J─лva: It is the animate aspect that lives in the inanimate universe, and consumes the fruit of its actions, and it is directed by the guс╣Зa-triad. 3. ─кshvara: It is present in all inanimate energies and is also present externally as an authoritative factor, and rules over the universe and the j─лva. It is the thread on which the universe and j─лvas are strung together. This is called k─Бrya-brahma or the ┼Ыabala-brahma. 4. Parabrahma: It is that, whose tiniest part of energy is the cause of all the activities of the universe, from whose immeasurable sunlight one single ray sustains life in all universe тАФ that eternal and fundamental energy. This is also called k─Бraс╣Зa-brahma or ┼Ыuddha-brahma.

Thus, there are four aspects to the para-tattva. These four do not have any beginning. The former among them pales in front of the latter. From the first three arises saс╣Гs─Бra which deviates from Brahma. When the j─лva meets Brahma, that saс╣Гs─Бra ceases to be experienced. A person who knows Brahma looks at saс╣Гs─Бra as a playful sport rather than a laborious task that has been imposed upon him. That is, even though all the above four are without any beginning, the attachment of the first three to saс╣Гs─Бra is not eternal. The dominance of the first three is ended by the fourth.

ya evaс╣Г vetti puruс╣гaс╣Г prakс╣Ыtiс╣Г ca guс╣Зaiс╕е saha ред
sarvath─Б vartam─БnoтАЩpi na sa bh┼лyoтАЩbhij─Бyate рее

тАЬOne who has understood the nature of the j─лva (puruс╣гa), and the qualities of prakс╣Ыti, is not born again whatever condition he may be in; that is, he is selfless and without ego and therefore he is free of worldly bondageтАЭ.
dhy─Бnen─Бtmani pa┼Ыyanti kecid-─Бtmanam ─Бtman─Б ред

тАЬSome comprehend the param─Бtm─Б by practising dhy─Бna; some through their manas; yet others by applying their buddhi to analyse the universe and other such exercises of s─Бс╣Зkhya-yoga, and others by practising karma-yogaтАЭ.

тАЬEven if those who are not capable of gaining the knowledge of ─Бtm─Б by meditation or intellect or karma listen and learn from others (say, from gurus or friends) of its greatness and splendour, they will also cross this mortal universeтАЭ.

Devoted practice is more important than anything else. The meaning of the Saс╣Гskс╣Ыta word тАЬup─БsanaтАЭ is to be near. We saw the word тАЬsamakс╣гat─Бbhy─БsaтАЭ earlier тАФ that is up─Бsan─Б. When the mind always dwells near the object of love and devotion, that is up─Бsan─Б. тАЬH─Бjar bh─Бс╣гiтАЭ тАФ practice of the presence of God тАФ that is up─Бsan─Б.
As devotion towards Bhagav─Бn grows, the yearning for worldly experiences lessens and the experience of Brahma floods our being.

[[Ch. 14 Yoga of Attention towards the Mechanism of the Three Guс╣Зas (part 1) Source: prekshaa]]

Introduction

vaс╣Г┼Ы─л-vibh┼лс╣гita-kar─Бn-navan─лrad─Бbh─Бt

He whose hand is adorned by the flute, with the hue of a new dark cloud,
He whoтАЩs dressed in a yellow garment, with ruddy lips resembling the bimba fruit,
With an innocent moon-like handsome face, the lotus-eyed,
Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa тАУ beyond him, I do not know of any other reality.

Note

pitta kapha v─Бta dh─Бtu

agitate all the j─лvas all the time.
The body and manas are animated by that.
