Summary

The reason for the rampant violence and instability everywhere can be traced to the imbalance of the three guс╣Зas that constitute the world тАУ sattva, rajas and tamas. This should be borne in mind by politicians who seek world peace and universal upliftment and organise summits and seminars on the same. If there is focus towards elevation sattva-guс╣Зa, peace becomes readily available. The itch of scabies, caused by an infection, cannot be cured by applying civet oil.

Section 15 /Chapter 14 /Guс╣Зa-traya-vibh─Бga-yoga /Triguс╣Зa-tantra-j─Бgar┼лka-yoga

(The yoga of attention towards the mechanism of the three guс╣Зas)

This chapter deals with the effects of the three guс╣Зas of prakс╣Ыti that have been expounded upon by Bhagav─Бn right from the beginning of the G─лt─Б. In the third chapter, Bhagav─Бn says

k─Бryate hy-ava┼Ыaс╕е karma sarvaс╕е prakс╣Ыtijair-guс╣Зaiс╕е рее
(BG 3.5)
тАЬEveryone performs their activities under the influence of prakс╣Ыti. None is really free of her.тАЭ

In the same chapter, he again says тАУ

prakс╣Ыteс╕е kriyam─Бс╣З─Бni guс╣Зaiс╕е karm─Бс╣Зi sarva┼Ыaс╕е рее
(BG 3.27)
тАЬAll works are caused by the guс╣Зas of prakс╣Ыti.тАЭ
guс╣З─Б guс╣Зeс╣гu vartanta iti matv─Б na sajjate рее
(BG 3.28)
тАЬThe guс╣Зas of manтАЩs inner and outer nature act with and react to one another resulting in activity. The seer knows that these works do not attach to the Self.тАЭ

Thus the sv─Бm─л repeatedly separates out the j─лvaтАЩs ─Бtm─Б and the instruments of his work.

In the seventh chapter, he instructs again тАУ

tribhir-guс╣Зa-mayair bh─Бvair-ebhiс╕е sarvam-idaс╣Г jagat
mohitaс╣Г n─Бbhij─Бn─Бti m─Бmebhyaс╕е param avyayam рее
(BG 7.13)
daiv─л hy-eс╣г─Б guс╣Зa-may─л mama m─Бy─Б duratyay─Б
m─Бm-eva ye prapadyante m─Бy─Бm et─Бс╣Г taranti te рее
(BG 7.14)
тАЬThe myriad effects of these three guс╣Зas have deluded the entire world causing the j─лva to not know his own Self. M─Бy─Б is the power of these three guс╣Зas.It is hard to cross her, but not impossible. Those who take refuge entirely in Bhagav─Бn can cross this ocean of M─Бy─Б.тАЭ

What does this mean? The wall standing between the j─лv─Бtm─Б and the param─Бtm─Б was built by prakс╣Ыti. The three guс╣Зas are the bricks that make up this wall. Those desirous of experiencing param─Бtm─Б have to exert themselves in scaling this wall. This wall of m─Бy─Б is the main topic of the fourteenth chapter.

This chapter is small without much scope for debate or polemics and hence, not much is said about this chapter in our commentarial tradition. That is not a reason, however, to consider this chapter unimportant. In my opinion, the description of the three guс╣Зas is key to our analysis of reality. Plato, the Greek philosopher par excellence, has opined that human nature is tri-fold. Those interested can study this in his Republic. It is these natural guс╣Зas that form and influence human life. These three guс╣Зas are the source of all the actions and behaviours of this world. Without understanding the character of these three guс╣Зas well it is impossible to understand the j─лvaтАЩs nature. Without knowing the nature of the j─лva, it is not possible to bring harmony to the world and the nature of our ─Бtm─Б will remain distant from us. It is therefore that the sv─Бm─л tells us -

yajj├▒─Бtv─Б munayaс╕е sarve par─Бс╣Г siddhim ito gat─Бс╕е рее
(BG 14.1)
idaс╣Г j├▒─Бnam up─Б┼Ыritya mama s─Бdharmyam ─Бgat─Бс╕е рее
(BG 14.2)

By realising the nuances of these guс╣Зas, all the great sages attained great siddhis and became
similar in nature to Bhagav─Бn.

Guс╣Зa here does not refer to specific human qualities transmitted from person to person or those imbibed by oneтАЩs own experience or via imitation of others or something non-existent that was gained via gradual practice. This chapterтАЩs exposition is about the innate guс╣Зas that are natural to us and accompany us from our birth.

We analysed two parts of the world in the previous chapter тАУ kс╣гetra and kс╣гetraj├▒a. It is now pertinent for us to understand the amount of influence that the kс╣гetra (prakс╣Ыti) has on the daily life of the kс╣гetraj├▒a (j─лva). The three guс╣Зas are the power of the kс╣гetra. The sv─Бm─л now tells us about the main aspects of the kс╣гetra, which is none other than Universal prakс╣Ыti - the vi┼Ыvaprakс╣Ыti, the stuff of which the universe is made. The first evolved state of prakс╣Ыti is mahat. Just as clay is used by a potter to make his wares, mahat is used by ─к┼Ыvara to create the world.

mama yonir-mahad brahma tasmin garbhaс╣Г dadh─Бmy-aham ред
sambhavaс╕е sarva-bh┼лt─Бn─Бс╣Г tato bhavati bh─Бrata рее
(BG 14.3)
тАЬMahat тАУ the primordial form of Prakс╣Ыti тАУ is the generative organ in which I, Brahma, plant the seed. Then happens the birth of all beings.тАЭ

In words such as mahad-brahma and mahad-yoni, mahat refers to the primordial prakс╣Ыti. All accounts of creation are intellectual concepts created by great sages for the instruction of common folk. It should not be thought that the act of creation happened on a specific day at a specific time or that there was nothing created before that moment. Creation is without beginning, it has been there forever, undergoing constant modification. It is just for the convenience of stating an account that we fix a time for creation. If we were to narrate the account of creation as a story тАУ in the beginning of creation existed pure Brahma тАУ which is the k─Бraс╣Зa-brahma or the cause. K─Бrya-brahma or Brahma that is an effect is a later modification of Pure Brahma. It is at that stage that Brahma тАЩdecidesтАЩ to create. Brahma that is associated with a will to create is known as ┼Ыabala-brahma or Brahma with variety. Its power or energy is the Unmanifest or the avyakta.

avyakt─Бd-vyaktayaс╕е sarv─Бс╕е рее
(BG 8-18)

From avyakta comes mahat тАУ an undifferentiated, amorphous mass. From mahat comes ahaс╣Еk─Бra (ego); from it come the five tanm─Бtras (the subtle substrata of the five elements); from it the five primordial elements and from them comes the world.

This is the order in which creation occurs.

mahataс╕е param-avyaktam рее
(Kaс╣нhopaniс╣гad)

From mahat proceeds avyakta тАУ

pr─Бkс╣Ыtam-annam tri-guс╣Зa-bheda-pariс╣З─Бmatv─Бt mahad-─Бdyam ред
(Maitr─Бyaс╣Зyupaniс╣гad)
The mass of prakс╣Ыti because of the differentiated three guс╣Зas becomes mahat.

Back to this chapter.

sarva-yoniс╣гu kaunteya m┼лrtayaс╕е sambhavanti y─Бс╕е
t─Бs─Бс╣Г brahma mahad-yonir-ahaс╣Г b─лja-pradaс╕е pit─Б рее
(BG 14.4)
Wherever, whatever is born тАУ whatever be its shape or action тАУ its first mother is Prakс╣Ыti, just as ─к┼Ыvara or Puruс╣гa is its first father.

They are the ─Бdi-dampati (the primordial couple) as well as the an─Бdi-dampati (the beginningless couple). All the couples of this universe are Prakс╣Ыti and ─к┼Ыvara. The world calls them variously as Brahm─Б-Sarasvat─л, Viс╣гс╣Зu-Lakс╣гm─л or as ┼Ъiva-Gaur─л.
Is this couple made of separate constituents? Or is it just one principle that manifests itself as two? This is a monumental question that we will deal with later. Let us now consider one of the two тАУ prakс╣Ыti that is the kс╣гetra or the field for the birth of the world.

sattvaс╣Г rajas tama iti guс╣З─Бс╕е prakс╣Ыiti-sambhav─Бс╕е
nibadhnanti mah─Б-b─Бho dehe dehinam avyayam рее
(BG 14.5)
тАЬSattva, Rajas, and Tamas, the three guс╣Зas born of prakс╣Ыti, bind the embodied ─Бtm─Б to the body, though the ─Бtm─Б is changeless. Thus, the changeless appears changed. Bringing the appearance of change to the changeless is the power of the tri-fold guс╣Зas of prakс╣Ыti.тАЭ

This is a principle we need to bear in mind. It is more important to remember that the bond of the world is made of the guс╣Зa-triad than remembering that the world is made of five elements.

The present series is a modern English translation of DVGтАЩs Kendra Sahitya Akademi Award-winning work, Bhagavad-g─лt─Б-t─Бtparya or J─лvana-dharma-yoga. The translators wish to express their thanks to ┼Ъat─Бvadh─Бni R Ganesh for his valuable feedback and to Hari Ravikumar for his astute edits.

[[Ch. 14 Yoga of Attention towards the Mechanism of the Three Guс╣Зas (part 2) Source: prekshaa]]

What is a guс╣Зa? A certain innate characteristic or natural power of a thing that causes affinity or otherwise with another thing is its guс╣Зa. Thus the guс╣Зa is an intrinsic power of a thing that attracts or repels another. It requires a counterpart just as love requires a suitable recipient; beauty requires a connoisseur; valour a competitor; scholarship a disciple; magnanimity requires one who seeks; pomp and show require an audience; the taste of a dainty dish requires a diner; darkness requires light; sorrow requires one who can take it away; pleasure requires one to renew it; infamy requires fame, and so on. Inviting or repelling another thing is the effect of a guс╣Зa. Hence guс╣Зa is something that requires something else to be with it. The graha-pratigraha^(^([1])) section of the Bс╣Ыhad─Бraс╣Зyakopaniс╣гad 3.2 deals with the importance of guс╣Зa. The relationship between Brahma and guс╣Зa has two sides. While Brahma does not require anything else, guс╣Зa is that which requires another for its existence. From guс╣Зa rise the world and this life. The world exists as long as the guс╣Зa exists. He who transcends the guс╣Зas goes beyond the world.

In our current discussion, the guс╣Зa is a natural disposition, tendency or impulse that manifests itself in manтАЩs antaс╕е-karaс╣Зa^(^([2])). One could call guс╣Зa an inner impulse. Guс╣Зa is normally translated into English as тАЩquality,тАЩ but a translation as тАЩimpulseтАЩ or тАЩpropensityтАЩ is better. A guс╣Зa manifests itself externally тАУ up from the depths of man. There are two effects stemming from this propensity тАУ

  1. Eroding of the past 2. Seeding the future.

The guс╣Зa expresses a j─лvaтАЩs saс╣Гsk─Бras from past lives and rarefies them. Saс╣Гsk─Бra here refers to a j─лvaтАЩs learning from its trials and tribulations as well as persistent experience and practice. Every j─лva carries a bundle of saс╣Гsk─Бras from its lives from its beginningless past and its repeated contact with the world in each of its lives. Such residual impressions in a j─лva are termed v─Бsanas. The natural guс╣Зas expend each of these v─Бsanas from previous lives by expressing them. When a j─лva contacts the world in its present life, its guс╣Зas from previous lives are used to interact with other j─лvas who in response express their own guс╣Зas. This response from the world and other j─лvas gives more saс╣Гsk─Бras to our j─лva. These new saс╣Гsk─Бras seed the j─лvaтАЩs future. In this way, our latent propensities or innate guс╣Зas are the results of our previous saс╣Гsk─Бras as well as seeds for future lives.

A guс╣Зa is usually defined as an internal quality of a thing that causes a distinct and definite effect. Examples are fragrance in sandalwood or coolness in water. A guс╣Зa could also mean a rope or thread. Binding is a ropeтАЩs function. Therefore the statement тАЬguс╣З─Б nibadhnantiтАЭ (guс╣Зas bind) is apt even in this way.

It is by philosophical convention that guс╣Зas are three in number. In reality, there is no guс╣Зa that exists purely by itself without an admixture of other guс╣Зas. Is there just air in a cityтАЩs atmosphere? Especially on a busy public road with buses travelling on it? There are several substances mixed in it тАУ rattling noise from the busтАЩs engine, dust arising at its tyres, diesel fumes from its exhaust pipes, its pungent odour, and so on. These substances are always mixed in a busy roadтАЩs air. Similarly, the three guс╣Зas coexist, and found always mixed with one another. The proportions of the guс╣Зa mixture vary with each individual j─лva. Each j─лva has a unique ratio of the guс╣Зa-combination. Infinite j─лvas imply infinite ratios in which guс╣Зas are combined.

When only one of the three guс╣Зas exists, activity cannot take place in the world as even when they are in equal proportion. This is an important concept. If the world has to be the world that is, in constant movement, two circumstances are necessary тАУ

  1. The guс╣Зas have to be intermixed. 2. The guс╣Зas should not be mixed in equal proportion.

For the world to be dynamic, the guс╣Зas have to be mixed in unequal proportions.

What should one with viveka do then? He knows that sattva is conducive towards wellness and that he cannot escape from rajas and tamas. With the inevitable presence of all the three guс╣Зas and only one of them preferred, the best help oneтАЩs discernment could give is towards the elevation of oneтАЩs sattva-guс╣Зa. One should strive to increase oneтАЩs level of sattva and maintain a higher proportion of rajas than tamas as much as possible. This is the only freedom one has.

Pure sattva, by itself, cannot accomplish anything in this world. It needs rajas for it to act. But even when much rajas is accumulated, it must be subservient to sattva. Rajas should not lord over sattva. This combination is referred to as brahma-kс╣гatram in the Bс╣Ыhad─Бraс╣Зyakopaniс╣гad (1.4).

brahma v─Б idam-agra ─Бs─лtka ekam-eva ред
tad-ekaс╣Г sanna vyabhavat ред
tacchreyo-r┼лpam atyasс╣Ыjata ред
kс╣гatram ред
y─Бnyet─Бni devatr─Б kс╣гatr─Бс╣Зi ред
dharmaс╣Г tad-etat kс╣гatrasya kс╣гatram ред
yad-dharmaс╕е…. tad-etat brahma-kс╣гatram ред…
тАЬBrahma existed first. Only it existed. It created an excellent form. That is kс╣гatra. Those qualities that can protect even devat─Бs are kс╣гatra. Dharma can be established through kс╣гatra and not just through br─Бhmaс╣Зya, which is pure sattva. If dharma, of the form of obedience of men to devat─Бs, has to be established in this world, the guс╣Зa of br─Бhmaс╣Зya - sattva, should unite with rajas тАУ the guс╣Зa of kс╣гatra. Pure sattva is insufficient for this worldтАЩs work.тАЭ

Let us now look at the characteristics and differences across the three guс╣Зas in this table. This has been described in twelve verses. A summary is given below.

| Guс╣Зa | Nature | Indication | Activity | Effect | Path to | Conclusion | |———-|——————|—————————-|——————–|————————|————————–|———————| | Sattva | Purity | Illumination | Knowledge | Bliss | Higher worlds - svarga | Peace | | Rajas | Desire and anger | Being excessive, agitation | Action orientation | Craving, Anxiety | Middle world - earth | Repetitive movement | | Tamas | Delusion | Inaction | Ignorance | Error, Laziness, Sleep | Lower world - naraka | Sorrow |

We have already discussed that these three guс╣Зas are always found combined in unequal proportions.

rajas tama┼Ы-c─Бbhibh┼лya sattvaс╣Г bhavati bh─Бrata
rajaс╕е sattvaс╣Г tama┼Ы-caiva tamaс╕е sattvaс╣Г rajas tath─Б рее
(BG 14.10)

тАЬSattva pushes Rajas and Tamas down; Rajas in turn tries to dominate Sattva and Tamas; Tamas also tries to overpower Sattva and Rajas. This contest between these guс╣Зas results in world activity.тАЭ

If these guс╣Зas were to settle down in equal proportions, world activity will come to a standstill. ┼Ъr─л ┼Ъaс╣Еkara and ┼Ъr─л R─Бmanuja have indicated the same in their commentary on the following Brahma-s┼лtra.

aс╣Еgitv─Бnupapatte┼Ыca ред (2.2.8)

The bh─Бс╣гya of ┼Ъr─л R─Бmanuja is as follows тАУ

guс╣З─Бn─Бm-utkarс╣гa-nikarс╣гa-nibandhan-─Бс╣Еg─Бс╣Еgi-bh─Бv─Бddhi jagatpravс╣Ыttiс╕е ред

People who ardently aspire thus тАУ тАЬWars should stop on this earth. Peace should be established. There should be universal upliftmentтАЭ тАУ should remember this. When there is infection in the gut, pus in the blood, and lice in the hair, there is no point in distributing face powder as the means towards happiness. The situation is similar to aspiring for world peace while their interiors are filled with rajas and tamas. Of what good is nuclear disarmament when the insides are boiling with poison?

DonтАЩt ask if peace isnтАЩt needed. Who doesnтАЩt want peace? There is no wealth greater than peace for those belonging to Vaidika-dharma. There is no happiness greater than peace.

The above is the daily prayer of Vaidika-с╣Ыс╣гis. However, such a prayer does not yield fruit with no efforts on our part. They have shown us the path to attain that peace.

This path is difficult. Peace can definitely be attained by those who accept this path and walk on it. This path, however, is not for politicians who desire their own victory and the defeat of their enemies which they confuse for peace. Will a person affected by scabies be cured by constant instructions of тАЬDo not scratch!тАЭ? Only when the person consumes medicine that purifies the blood and destroys disease-causing micro-organisms will the itch be resolved. The path for those who desire world peace is similar. They have to first cross the three guс╣Зas and bring those with a preponderance of rajas and tamas to the path of sattva. Who are those that can accomplish this? Do such people exist?

[[Ch. 14 Yoga of Attention towards the Mechanism of the Three Guс╣Зas (part 3) Source: prekshaa]]

A relevant matter here needs discussion. Bhagav─Бn says that the three guс╣Зas have to be transcended or sublimated. Good. But even to transcend those guс╣Зas, a guс╣Зa or means is needed. Is that way a guс╣Зa? What guс╣Зa is that?

That guс╣Зa is sattva, a preponderance of sattva to be precise. There is a state to be attained by elevating the proportion of sattva. What is the guс╣Зa of that state? Even that is sattva. Sattva is obtained by enhancing sattva. What does it mean?

Sattva is of two kinds. One that is attached to rajas and tamas. The other is beyond even the contact of rajas and tamas and exists by itself. The former is combined sattva or sattva pertaining to Prakс╣Ыti. The latter is pure sattva or sattva pertaining to Brahma. When combined sattva is purified of other guс╣Зas and strengthened it becomes fit to attain Br─Бhm─л-state.

The words тАУ тАЬexceededтАЭ, тАЬsublimatedтАЭ, тАЬgo beyondтАЭ тАУ do not just refer to rajas and tamas but also to that sattva that is blended with them. For experiencing Brahma, only the element of pure sattva is needed. The nature of pure sattva is described in the seventeenth chapter, thus:

sadbh─Бve s─Бdhubh─Бve ca sadityetprayujyate рее
(BG 17.26)

Next in the fourteenth chapter.

guс╣З─Бn et─Бn at─лtya tr─лn deh─л deha-samudbhav─Бn
janma-mс╣Ыityu-jar─Б-duс╕еkhair vimuktoтАЩmс╣Ыitam a┼Ыnute рее
(BG 14.20)

тАЬThe three guс╣Зas are born in the body. When the embodied ─Бtm─Б goes beyond those guс╣Зas, he becomes free of birth, death, old age and sorrow and attains immortality.тАЭ

Arjuna then asked тАУ тАЬSv─Бmin, what are the markers of one who has transcended the guс╣Зas? How does he behave?

Now Bhagav─Бn shows us a method to win over the three guс╣Зas and transcend them:

prak─Б┼Ыaс╣Г cha pravс╣Ыittiс╣Г cha moham eva cha p─Бс╣Зс╕Нava
na dveс╣гс╣нi sampravс╣Ыtt─Бni na nivс╣Ыtt─Бni k─Бс╣Еkс╣гati рее
(BG 14.22)
тАЬIllumination is sattva; action is rajas and delusion is tamas. The knower does not hate any of these guс╣Зas when they operate around him. He does not seek out any of them when they are absent.тАЭ

ud─Бs─лna-vad ─Бs─лno guс╣Зair yo na vich─Бlyate
guс╣З─Б vartanta ity-evaс╣Г yoтАЩvatiс╣гс╣нhati neс╣Еgate рее
(BG 14.23)

He appears ud─Бs─лnavat (like an indifferent person). However, he is not really indifferent. The vat suffix after ud─Бs─лna shows similarity, not identity. Being indifferent would mean lacking innate compassion for the world, and without any interest in dharma. It should not be so. If a knower were to be really indifferent, it would conflict with Bhagav─БnтАЩs teaching about duty from the previous chapters. Can an indifferent person тАУ one that does not accept any duty тАУ have any ordained duty? Duties must be performed with sincerity and interest but with no desire for their fruit. This is the meaning from the suffix vat in ud─Бs─лna-vat. The seekerтАЩs mental constitution should not alter. Just as the manas of an indifferent person is unattached, the one who is unattached to the results of an action is a knower. The manas of a knower is not agitated by the play of the guс╣Зa-triad. He is not shaken up like common people who become slaves to the changes in their guс╣Зas.

Peals of laughter, exclamations, cries, bawls, brawls and songs of inmates are all heard in a mental institution. When a person тАУ mentally sound or one who considers himself sound тАУ visits the mental institution, he considers all those displays of emotion as symptoms of mental illness. Similarly the one who has transcended the guс╣Зas sees the agitations and celebrations of worldly people and considers them as a play of the natural guс╣Зas, an illness caused by them. He himself is unaffected by them.

How does one reach this elevated state? Through constant remembrance of Brahma and practice of BrahmaтАЩs presence.

brahmaс╣Зo hi pratiс╣гс╣нh─Бham amс╣Ыitasy─Бvyayasya cha
┼Ы─Б┼Ыvatasya cha dharmasya sukhasyaik─Бntikasya cha рее
(BG 14.27)
тАЬ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa is the direct form of Supreme Brahma. He is the greatest sattva without any modification or loss; he is the origin of eternal dharma; he is the fountainhead of unbroken bliss.тАЭ

The one who constantly reflects upon this sees all the guс╣Зas, the desires and the agitations they cause, and the activity they inspire as things other than the ─Бtm─Б. His focus is on dharma alone. By gradual practice of self-control, pure sattva preponderates in him and through that he experiences param─Бtm─Б.

Just as the cure for a disease becomes possible only after knowing its defining characteristics, it becomes easier to treat the j─лva after knowing about the method of the three guс╣Зas. This seems to have been Bhagav─БnтАЩs intent in this chapter. Let us transcend the three guс╣Зas through the blessings of Bhagav─Бn.

Summary

We act according to our whims and desires, forgetting that it is us who have created our own life circumstances, and that it is our present behaviour that forms our future. Bhagav─Бn instructs us through a profound allegory that this world has its origin in Brahma. We are the ones who defile this saс╣Гs─Бra that is born out of Brahma. It is possible to extricate ourselves from this relationship through a practice of detachment. The one who is detached is not weighed down by the world. The world becomes a place of entertainment for him.

Section 16 /Chapter 15 /Puruс╣гottama-yoga /─А┼Ыvattha-m┼лlop─Бsana-yoga

(The Yoga of meditation on the root of the a┼Ыvattha)

At the end of the previous chapter, Bhagav─Бn showed us an excellent strategy of the escape from the web of the three guс╣Зas and stated that it was him - the Supreme Self - that was the origin of dharma.

┼Ы─Б┼Ыvatasya ca dharmasya sukhasyaik─Бntikasya ca рее
BG 14.27

The first of the Puruс╣г─Бrthas (the four primary human values) is dharma and the last is Mokс╣гa - both of which reside in Brahma.

brahmaс╣Зo hi pratiс╣гс╣нh─Бham рее
ibid

(I am the support of ─к┼Ыvara)
The above statement tells us that it is Brahma that appears as dharma in this world system. How is Brahma the same as dharma? The Sv─Бm─л now explains.
Dharma is an arrangement of relationships. For any relationship, there have to be two things. There is no talk of a relationship in the case of a story like Robinson CrusoeтАЩs who is all by himself. There is a relationship only when there are at least two objects. Even Crusoe who lived on an uninhabited island considered himself as many and had to think - тАЬMy body is dirty. I must wash itтАЭ, тАЬMy stomach is feeling hungry. I must look for some food for itтАЭ - thereby considering his own bodily organs as different from him. At those moments, the relationship between him and his body is through the tactile sense; the relationship between him and his stomach is through the affliction of hunger. When that relationship - that can exist between two or more objects - is as good it can be, it is called dharma. In the relationship of dharma, the j─лva is one side while the jagat (the world) is on the other. Dharma sustains both of them.
Bhagav─Бn uses a beautiful metaphor to drive home this teaching. A metaphor (r┼лpaka) is a figure of speech (an alaс╣Зk─Бra). The function of an alaс╣Зk─Бra is to compare a well-known object to a little-known or unknown object to better inform the reader about the nature of the latter. In such an alaс╣Зk─Бra, if the object of comparison and the standard of comparison are treated as one without any distinction between them, it is called a metaphor. Consider the following example from a Kannada classic.

┼Ыr─лvadhuvinaс╣Гbakacakorakaс╣ГтАж
devapura-lakс╣гm─л-ramaс╣Зan─Бsyacaс╣Гdran ─Бnaс╣Гdamaс╣Г namag─лyali редред
-Jaimini Bh─Бrata 1.1

(Sought after by cakora-bird-eyes of ┼Ыr─л, may the moon-face of the deity of Devapura - Lakс╣гm─л-ramaс╣Зa - bestow bliss upon us.)

This is a r┼лpaka (metaphor) in which all the features of the moon are shown established in the face of Lakс╣гm─л-ramaс╣Зa.

There are different r┼лpakas such as abheda (non-difference) and t─Бdr┼лpya (having the same form). Let us not dwell upon the intricacies of alaс╣Зk─Бra-┼Ы─Бstra (aesthetics) right now. What is relevant to us now is this - r┼лpaka is a figure of speech that gives a better understanding of something we donтАЩt know. The j─лva, the world, Brahma - are all things that are not directly perceived. Bhagav─Бn uses the metaphor of the directly perceived a┼Ыvattha tree to help us visualise the nature of the relationship between the j─лva, the world, and Brahma.

┼лrdhva-m┼лlam adhah╠г-┼Ы─Бkham a┼Ыvattham╠Б pr─Бhur-avyayam ред
chand─Бm╠Бsi yasya parn╠г─Бni yas tam╠Б veda sa veda-vit рее
BG 15.1
тАЬThere is an indestructible Peepal tree. But its roots are above and its shoots are towards the bottom. Its leaves are the Vedas. Whoever knows is the knower of the Veda.тАЭ

This is a topsy-turvy, root-over-head tree! Look at its speciality! Its roots are up somewhere - unseen by our eyes, unreachable by our hands while its branches point downwards where we can reach them. This means that the branches and twigs of this tree form the entire material of the world. This tree is - avyayam pr─Бhuс╕е - said to be unmodifiable; that can never be destroyed; always of one form. The Vedas are the leaves of this tree. He who knows the secret of this tree knows everything.

adha┼Ы cordhvaс╣Г prasr╠гt─Бs-tasya ┼Ы─Бkh─Б
gun╠гa-pravr╠гddh─Б vis╠гaya-prav─Бl─Бh╠г ред
adha┼Ы ca m┼лl─Бny-anusantat─Бni
karm─Бnubandh─лni manus╠гya-loke рее
BG 15.2
тАЬThe treeтАЩs branches extend both upward and downward. The three guс╣Зas of sattva, rajas and tamas are the fertiliser that nourish the tree. The objects of desire are its tender shoots. Its props and roots sprawl across the human world, binding j─лvas with karma.тАЭ

As long as the three guс╣Зas of sattva, rajas and tamas are operating, this tree stands well-nourished. The shoots of this tree - vis╠гaya-prav─Бl─Бh╠г - are objects of desire that are ever fresh; making us think тАЬI need this, I desire thatтАЭ and have myriad cravings. This treeтАЩs props and roots are anusantat─Бni - which continuously follow, and are karm─Бnubandh─лni as well - they bind us with our own karmas. Manus╠гya-loke is mentioned here as humans are endowed with more awareness and responsibility than animals and birds. The world of humans lies between the upper heavens of the devas and the nether regions. The human j─лva can go up or down.
The origin of the world-a┼Ыvattha cannot be comprehended by the human mind. It is not possible for humans to newly extend the tree. It is Prakс╣Ыti that has sustained the growth of the tree from time immemorial using her three guс╣Зas. It is only the treeтАЩs fruit that is for manтАЩs consumption.
Let us look at the many interesting features of this saс╣Гs─Бra-tree. Saс╣Гs─Бra is not to be construed just as family and children. It is the river of life of the form of birth and death. Whatever we meet in our life journey - all of it constitutes saс╣Гs─Бra while being - karm─Бnubandh─лni - binding us with karma.
Any tree could have been used as the object of this metaphor. Why was the A┼Ыvattha or the holy Peepal tree chosen? The use of this tree as a metaphor is as ancient as the Vedas. Why did the great sages choose this tree? What is the secret behind their choice of the A┼Ыvattha? The features of the A┼Ыvattha tally well with the circumstances of saс╣Гs─Бra. This great tree has four special characteristics that are the same as saс╣Гs─Бra.

  1. Longevity: The A┼Ыvattha has a long lifespan. While one of its sides wilts away another side blossoms.Saс╣Гs─Бra is similar - non-existent on one side while growing on the other. Through the succession of offspring, it is long-lived as well. 2. Widespread: The branches, the roots and props of the A┼Ыvattha extend in all directions for a long distance. The branches of saс╣Гs─Бra too extend afar from hither to thither. 3. Many knotted: The props and the branches of the A┼Ыvattha are knotted and braided haphazardly. Saс╣Гs─Бra similarly is knotty in its numerous narrow and arduous circumstances that arise due to the push and pull of relationships. 4. Nourishes many: The A┼Ыvattha gives refuge to many insects and birds and protects them. Saс╣Гs─Бra too protects and nourishes many relatives, friends, guests, strangers, and those who come in contact with us through their professions and trades.

Thus the comparison is quite apt. This is an ancient metaphor described in the Yajur─Бraс╣Зyaka as follows.

┼лrdhvam┼лlamav─Бk┼Ы─Бkham ред vс╣Ыkс╣гaс╣Г yo veda samprati ред na sa j─Бtu janaс╕е ┼Ыraddadhy─Бt ред mс╣Ыtyurm─Б m─Бray─Бditiс╕е ред
-Taittir─лy─Бraс╣Зyaka 1.11.5
тАЬThe one who knows the secret of the tree with its roots at the top and branches at the bottom will not be afraid that death might strike him. This is because he knows that the treeтАЩs roots lie in eternal Brahma-consciousness.тАЭ

Bhagav─БnтАЩs statement echoes the same. The one who knows that the world originates in Brahma does not need to fear death. There is no need to fear for the treeтАЩs existence just because a branch dries and falls off. Likewise, there is no danger to the primordial consciousness because of one manтАЩs death. A j├▒─Бn─л thus has realised the eternality of the ─Бtm─Б. This indeed is the essence of statements from the second chapter such as тАЬnainaс╣Г chindanti ┼Ыastr─Бс╣ЗiтАЭ, тАЬacchedyoтАЩyamad─БhyoтАЩyam.тАЭ The same is taught in the Upaniс╣гads as well. The Kaс╣нhopaniс╣гad is clear about this.

┼лrdhvam┼лloтАЩv─Бk┼Ы─Бkha eс╣гoтАЩ┼Ыvatthaс╕е san─Бtanaс╕е ред
tadeva ┼Ыukraс╣Г tad brahma tadev─Бmс╣Ыtamucyate рее
tasmiс╣Гllok─Бс╕е ┼Ыrit─Бс╕е sarve tadu n─Бtyeti ka┼Ыcana рее
Kaс╣нhopaniс╣гad 2.3.1
тАЬThe roots are above and the shoots below. This a┼Ыvattha is eternal. That is the light. That indeed is Brahma. That indeed is immortal. All the worlds are dependent on it. There is nothing beyond it.тАЭ

[[Ch. 15 Yoga of meditation on the root of the a┼Ыvattha (part 2) Source: prekshaa]]

What is the reason behind the name a┼Ыvattha for a tree thus extolled in the Veda? ┼Ъvaс╕е in Saс╣Гskс╣Ыt means tomorrow. ┼Ъvastha is something that will exist tomorrow just as it exists today. A┼Ыvattha then refers to something that will not be the same tomorrow as it is today. It is something that changes every instant - something constantly changing or fickle.

na ┼ЫvoтАЩpi sth─Бt─Б iti a┼Ыvatthaс╕е taс╣Г kс╣гaс╣Зapradhvaс╣Гsinam a┼Ыvattham
(As it will not exist tomorrow, as it is changing every instant, it is known as a┼Ыvattha)
-┼Ъr─л ┼Ъaс╣ЕkaraтАЩs commentary on Bhagavadg─лt─Б 15.1

The word jagat means the same as well - something that is moving, revolving, and changing.
The same Brahman that is firm, uniform, and immutable in its absolute aspect, is dynamic, of myriad forms and ever-changing in its active form. Whatever appears to our eyes as something born, dying, laughing, suffering, adventuring, emaciated, defeated, victorious or in one of those innumerable states is originally birthless, deathless, indefatigable, free from worldly limitations, of one form, and tranquil.
It is to bring that primordial origin to our notice that Bhagav─Бn mentions ┼лrdhvam┼лlam.
A question here. ┼кrdhva - means the direction above our heads or pointing to the sky. What is uniquely great about that? Does not Brahman exist in the direction below? Does Brahman discriminate between upward and downward directions? Aren’t all directions the same for it? The answer is as follows - тАЬBrahman is omnipresent and has no directional differences. In fact it is beyond the distinctions of space. The notions of “above” and “below” are for us - humans. Whatever we consider good or better, we denote by words such as тАЬhighтАЭ, тАЬheadтАЭ or тАЬtopтАЭ. Just placing an object worthy of reverence in a high position brings us satisfaction. In reality, there is no тАЬaboveтАЭ or тАЬbelowтАЭ for Brahman which is omnipresent. We attribute to it an тАЬexaltedтАЭ or тАЬhighтАЭ position to satisfy our devotional attitudes. The Taittir─лya Upaniс╣гad states -

satyaс╣Г j├▒─Бnamanantaс╣Г brahma ред yo veda nihitaс╣Г guh─Бy─Бс╣Г parame vyoman ред
soтАЩ┼Ыnute sarv─Бn k─Бm─Бn рее
(Brahman is truth, knowledge and without end. He who knows the supreme space in oneтАЩs heart, he attains all desires.)
Taittir─лya Up. 2.1.1

Brahman is the greatest mystery - beyond even the reach of speech and mind. If such a mystery has to be indicated, a most excellent position needs to be pointed to. Such a reference in the previous Upaniс╣гadic statement is - guh─Бy─Бс╣Г parame vyoman. The thrust behind ┼лrdhvam┼лlam is similar.
The author of the Bh─Бgavata expands upon the description of the saс╣Гs─Бra-tree in the G─лt─Б with poetic flair. When ┼Ъr─л Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa was in the womb of Devak─л, the four-faced Brahm─Б and other Devas extolled him thus - тАЬO Bhagav─Бn! You are the seed of this saс╣Гs─Бra-tree which is non-different from the world.тАЭ What is the nature of that tree?

ek─БyanoтАЩsau dviphalas-trim┼лla┼Ы-cat┼лrasaс╕е pa├▒ca┼Ыiphaс╕е с╣гaс╕Н─Бtm─Б ред
saptvag-aс╣гс╣н─Бviс╣нapo nav─Бkс╣гo da┼Ыacchado dvikhago hyaadivс╣Ыkс╣гaс╕е рее
-Bh─Бgavatam 10.22.27
Ek─Бyanaс╕е тАФ There is one but one basis for it which is the primordial prakс╣Ыti.
Dviphalaс╕е тАФ It has two fruits - of pleasure and pain.
Trim┼лlaс╕е тАФ Three roots of the three guс╣Зas - sattva, rajas and tamas. Whoever rends asunder these roots will no longer be bound by the world.
Chat┼лrasaс╕е тАФ Four tastes тАФ dharma, artha, k─Бma and mokс╣гa.
Pa├▒cashiphaс╕е тАФ Five prop roots of our five sense organs.
с╣вaс╕Н─Бtm─Б тАФ Six characteristic qualities - hunger, thirst, fatigue, delusion, old age and death.
Saptatvak тАФ Seven types of bark тАФ skin, blood, flesh, fat, bones, nerves and seminal fluid
Aс╣гс╣н─Бviс╣нapaс╕е тАФ Eight branches тАФ The five primordial elements - earth, water, sky, fire, air, the manas, buddhi and ahaс╣Еk─Бra.
Nav─Бkс╣гaс╕е тАФ Nine hollows or orifices тАФ two eyes, two ears, two nostrils, the two nether orifices and one mouth.
Da┼Ыacchadaс╕е тАФ Ten leaves тАФ The five principal pr─Бс╣Зas - pr─Бс╣Зa, ap─Бna, vy─Бna, ud─Бna and sam─Бna - and the five subsidiary pr─Бс╣Зas тАФ n─Бga, k┼лrma, kс╣Ыkala, devadatta and dhana├▒jaya.
Dvikhagaс╕е тАФ Two birds тАФ The j─лvatm─Б and the Param─Бtm─Б.
With these two birds is created this huge saс╣Гs─Бra-world. This is the primordial world-tree that has been created by you, O Bhagav─БnтАЭ - thus did Brahm─Б and other Devas praise ┼Ъr─л Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa.

tvameka ev─Бsya sataс╕е pras┼лtistvaс╣Г sannidh─Бnaс╣Г tvamanugraha┼Ыca ред
tvanm─Бyay─Б saс╣Гvс╣Ыtacetasastv─Бс╣Г pa┼Ыyanti n─Бn─Б na vipa┼Ыcito ye рее
-Bh─Бgavatam 10.22.28
тАЬYou alone are the worldтАЩs origin! You alone are its residence! You are its caretaker! Those deluded by your M─Бy─Б see world-objects as different from one another. Those with knowledge are not deluded and see you as the undifferentiated one everywhere!тАЭ

There are many more pur─Бс╣Зic descriptions of this saс╣Гs─Бra-tree metaphor. ┼Ъr─л ┼Ъaс╣Еkar─Бc─Бrya quotes a few of them. ┼Ъr─л Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa himself states this in the tenth chapter.

a┼Ыvatthaс╕е sarvavс╣Ыkс╣г─Бс╣З─Бm ред
-BG 10.26

He praises the greatness of the a┼Ыvattha which is a visible symbol of the invisible Brahman. It is with this feeling and belief that all Hindus consider it sacred and worship it by p┼лj─Бs and pradakс╣гiс╣Зas - even while being mocked at by foreigners for тАЬworshipping trees, sticks and stones.тАЭ Even some of us who consider the words of those foreigners as great testimony join them in deriding ourselves. So be it. This too is the effect of the a┼Ыvattha whose nature it is to wither on one side while flowering on the other.
We need to bring our attention to two points about this tree.

1. Chand─Бс╣Гsi yatra parс╣З─Бni тАФ тАЬThe Vedas are the leaves of this tree!тАЭ What does this mean? The leaf performs a vital function in the life of a tree. The leaf protects the tree. The leaf absorbs various nutrients from the environment and nourishes the tree. If all the leaves are plucked off, a tree becomes akin to a skinless man and perishes. How are the Vedas the protectors of the saс╣Гs─Бra-tree? It is dharma that nourishes our lives and dharma in turn is known through the Vedas.

vedoтАЩkhilaс╣Г dharmam┼лlam ред
-Manusmс╣Ыti 2.6

Therefore the Vedas protect the saс╣Гs─Бra-tree. From the Vedas proceeds dharma and through dharma is the sustenance of the world-system. Brahman that is the cause of the saс╣Гs─Бra-tree is thus also the cause of dharma and the ┼Ы─Бstras that teach dharma. It is because of dharma that saс╣Гs─Бra stands. It is through the Vedas that there is a social system. Without the structure of a social arrangement, society would get pulled apart in all directions. We see a similar statement in the Upaniс╣гads as well. When Bhagav─Бn as the Vir─Бс╣н-puruс╣гa created the universe, the created beings began consuming one another. Bhagav─Бn saw this anarchy and he thought to himself, “Having done so much, I forgot to appoint a policeman here.” Thinking thus, he created dharma. This allegory is narrated in the Bс╣Ыhad─Бraс╣Зyakopaniс╣гad. It is dharma alone that can protect people. That is the reason for Bhagav─Бn comparing the Vedas to the leaves of the saс╣Гs─Бra-tree тАФ chand─Бс╣Гsi yatra parс╣З─Бni.
Despite the greatness of this tree, a violent statement has been made about destroying it.

asaс╣Еga┼Ыastreс╣Зa dс╣Ыс╕Нhena chitv─Б рее
-BG 15.3

This seems to imply on the surface that the saс╣Гs─Бra-tree is insignificant, and befits destruction. That, however, is not the intended purport. How can we destroy the tree created by Bhagav─Бn, for the protection of which he established a system in the form of the Vedas and ┼Ы─Бstras? As saс╣Гs─Бra has Brahman for its origin, it is worthy of our worship. Its origin is the excellence of excellence. We, the j─лvas, manage to desecrate it, that is all. How do we escape this impure relationship is the question. The answer for this question is тАФ “asaс╣Еga┼Ыastreс╣Зa dс╣Ыс╕Нhena chitv─Б”. Detachment is the mechanism to be followed in saс╣Гs─Бra.
2. There is another point worthy of our special attention - “karm─Бnubandh─лni manuс╣гyaloke”. All the bonds that bind us - be they friendly relationships or barbed wires of rivalry - are results of our former karmas. Old actions, old debts, and old tendencies result in impediments, irritations and complexity in our lives. We experience pleasure and suffering in our lives thinking that these are accidental, seemingly absolving us of any responsibility towards them. We forget that all of our experiences are due to our previous actions. In reality, whatever we experience is the result of our old karma. The responsibility is ours.
Why do the learned say that this saс╣Гs─Бra is beginningless and endless? Because this saс╣Гs─Бra is the creation of Brahman. What, then, about us who are enmeshed in it? Should we be stuck in it eternally? Is there any release from it? They reply - “Yes. There is release from it.” Those who earnestly seek release from saс╣Гs─Бra have a chance at it. However, for those who say - тАЬWhy release? We like it here!тАЭ, Bhagav─Бn says, тАЬSo be it. Stay here itself!тАЭ. How does release happen for those who seek it? Will the world vanish once there is release? The world does not go anywhere. We are no longer deluded by it, that is all. The power that created the world will continue to protect it. It is not possible for us to destroy it. Why should we even try to destroy it? It is enough to destroy the web of misunderstanding that we have about the world. It is enough if there is no suffering from the world for us. We donтАЩt have to desire the destruction of the world. It is enough if the reason behind our view of the world as burdensome or evil is resolved once and for all. Mokс╣гa is also the same. For one who does not consider the world a hard place, the world becomes a place of enjoyment and entertainment. Such a person could not possibly desire for the world to be destroyed.

[[Ch. 15 Yoga of meditation on the root of the a┼Ыvattha (part 3) Source: prekshaa]]

We saw in the previous Bh─Бgavata ┼Ыloka a mention of two birds in the primordial tree - dvikhago hy─Бdivс╣Ыkс╣гaс╕е. When there is a tree, there is usually a bird in it. The metaphor of the two birds comes to us again from the Veda. The Muс╣Зс╕Нakopaniс╣гad describes the two birds of the saс╣Гs─Бra tree thus.

dv─Б suparс╣З─Б sayuj─Б sakh─Бy─Б sam─Бnaс╣Г vс╣Ыkс╣гaс╣Г pariс╣гasvaj─Бte рее
Muс╣Зс╕Нakopaniс╣гad 3.1.1

The mention of these two birds is seen elsewhere in the Vedas as well. Two birds; from afar they appear identical. However, their inner characteristics are entirely different. Their external looks are the same. Sayuj─Б (appearing similar). Who are those two birds? Bhagav─Бn says that here.

dv─Бv imau puruс╣гau loke kс╣гara┼Ыc─Бkс╣гara eva ca
kс╣гaraс╕е sarv─Бс╣Зi bh┼лt─Бni k┼лс╣нasthoтАЩkс╣гara ucyate рее
uttamaс╕е puruс╣гastvanyaс╕е param─Бtmetyud─Бhс╣Ыtaс╕е
yo loka-trayam-─Бvi┼Ыya bibhartyavyaya ─л┼Ыvaraс╕е рее
BG 15.16-17

  1. Kс╣гara refers to the j─лva. It means something that is perishable. Bearing a body that is perishable, performing works good and bad, enjoying their desirable and undesirable results, lamenting frequently, crying with joy, adventuring exuberantly - the j─лva is a fragment of the Universal consciousness. It is kс╣гara - something that can be eroded and exhausted. Though it exists momentarily, it is eventually cast off. The ─Бtm─Б that exists in this temporary changing state is the j─лvatm─Б. It is a sentience that has entered the insentient. The j─лva-consciousness that permeates and animates the bodyтАЩs limbs, sense organs, manas, buddhi and ahaс╣Еk─Бra is known as kс╣гara. 2. Akс╣гara is the unattached state of the same universal consciousness. It is the indestructible consciousness latent in the destructible body and is therefore known as k┼лс╣нastha (unchangeable). The kс╣гara can act only because of the presence of the akс╣гara. As the basis of the kс╣гara, the akс╣гara is beyond the kс╣гara-j─лvaтАЩs experiences of puс╣Зya and p─Бpa and is a changeless witness known as the s┼лtr─Бtm─Б (the Self that is the common thread in all j─лvas). It is also known as the k┼лс╣н─Бtm─Б (the chief Self). The self that is embodied in the body and is the kс╣гetraj├▒a (knower of the field/body) in the kс╣бetra (field/body) is akс╣гara which is in turn “used” by the kс╣гara-j─лva. The function of an electric power company is to just supply power. The power company or outlet does not restrict the use of power to specified uses only. Electricity could be used for good or bad. The use of electricity is the responsibility of the user. The power company is not concerned with that. Similar is akс╣гara. Both the j─лvatm─Б and the k┼лс╣н─Бtm─Б are vyaс╣гс╣нi (individual) experiences - considerations that are necessary when viewing each being separately. 3. The Param─Бtm─Б is the samaс╣гс╣нi (collective aggregate) of all separate sentiences of the j─лv─Бtm─Бs. When a rupee is counted separately as each paisa, each paisa is considered individually - as vyaс╣гс╣нi. The combined value of a hundred such paisas is samaс╣гс╣нi. When all the characteristics that are unique to a j─лva are separated and discarded, a remainder is left. When all such remainders are viewed as an aggregate, it is considered Param─Бtm─Б.We should understand that the characteristics of the vyaс╣гс╣нi and the samaс╣гс╣нi are quite different.

The features of a hundred separate single paisa coins are completely different from that of a single rupee note. However, the purchasing value of both is the same. As the saying in English goes, тАЬTwelve of the one and a dozen of the other”, both are the same in a marketplace. However, a hundred paisas are different from a single rupee in these cases - timewise - when we have to count each of those coins out; weightwise - when we have to carry a hundred coins around; and in terms of satisfaction when we present dakс╣гiс╣З─Б to br─Бhmaс╣Зas. Similarly, Param─Бtm─Б and kс╣гara-akс╣гara are quite different in transactional or relative reality. But from the perspective of the Absolute, they are all the same. The one who exists changelessly as a whole during all times and circumstances is the one beyond both kс╣гara and akс╣гara - known as puruс╣гottama (best among puruс╣гas). The best among puruс╣гas is Param─Бtm─Б. He permeates, sustains, and protects all the three worlds.
To use an analogy from physics, Param─Бtm─Б can be likened to potential energy and the j─лv─Бtm─Б to kinetic energy. While the former is like the ocean, the latter is like the wave. The substance is the same but forms are different.
Bhagav─Бn has clarified that the j─лva is a part of Brahma-consciousness.

mamaiv─Бс╣Г┼Ыo j─лva-loke j─лva-bh┼лtaс╕е san─Бtanaс╕е ред
manaс╕е-с╣гaс╣гс╣нh─Бn─лndriy─Бс╣Зi prakс╣Ыtisth─Бni karс╣гati рее
BG 15.7
тАЬIt is my (BrahmaтАЩs) aspect that exists in the world of beings as the eternal j─лva. That rules over the five sense organs and the sixth instrument of manas that reside in prakс╣Ыti.тАЭ

It is the caitanya (sentience) of the j─лva that animates all bodily and mental organs. This caitanya of the j─лva belongs to param─Бtm─Б. When the primordial Brahma-consciousness expresses itself by flowing through transient bodily instruments, it becomes known as kс╣гara.

Why does Brahma have to become the j─лva? Does Brahma have any goal? Because it is impelled by another? Or because of fear? Or a desire? No. Without Brahma, it is impossible for anything to even exist. All of what is - is Brahma. When there is nobody else anywhere, why should there be fear? When one is all-powerful, what is the reason for desire? What could the reason for world creation be? The Bс╣Ыhad─Бraс╣Зyakopaniс╣гad informs us.

sa vai naiva remeред ek─Бk─л na ramateред
sa dvit─лyamaicchatрее
-Bс╣Ыhad─Бraс╣Зyaka 1.4.3
тАЬ(When Brahma was all by itself) It was not happy. There is no happiness for one who is lonely. Therefore It sought another as a companion.тАЭ

Thus the world is a companion that Brahma created by itself. The Taittir─лyopaniс╣гad states -

soтАЩk─Бmayata ред bahu sy─Бс╣Г praj─Бyeyeti тАж. tad─Бtm─Бnaс╣Г svayamakuruta ред

Taittir─лya 2.6.1
тАЬBrahma was all alone. It desired thus - тАЬMay I be manyтАЭ. Then it created itself manifold as the world. The seers say that it did well thusтАЭ.
devasyaiс╣гa svabh─БvoтАЩyam рее

тАЬThat is Bhagav─БnтАЩs self-expression. Though he neither has any lacunae nor fear, though he is not impelled by any otherтАЩs desire or need, he creates the world and plays the drama of a j─лva as a sportтАЭ.
lokavattu l─лl─Бkaivalyam рее
Brahmas┼лtra 2.1.33
Just as the people of the world engage in sport for amusement, ─к┼Ыvara does not have any other motive and has created the entire world as his l─лl─Б (sport/pastime).

The baby in the cradle enjoys itself by laughing and kicking its limbs in sheer joy. For whom is this activity? A healthy and strong baby, unaware of anotherтАЩs existence, does it for its own happiness. L─лl─Б is an activity done for oneтАЩs own joy without any thought about others.
A beautiful damsel when alone sees herself in the mirror. When we are alone, we enjoy ourselves by singing a verse or tune in our own ordinary voices. The rich man, while his family members are asleep, closes the door of his room to relish the sight of his valuables. Parents delight in lovingly gazing at their children asleep. Thus, contemplating oneтАЩs own beauty, valuables and accomplishments without any need for another or without other desire, for oneтАЩs own joy is something we observe in human behaviour. The Supreme Brahma too sports in l─лl─Б in seeing the majesty of its own potency. What is l─лl─Б? It is an activity done for oneтАЩs own joy without involving others, without asking for external help, and without any extraneous goal. In this way, the universe is *BrahmaтАЩ*s l─лl─Б. The consciousness expressed in this l─лl─Б can be thought of in three aspects. 1. The j─лvatm─Б that animates bodily organs. 2. The K┼лс╣н─Бtm─Б or the internal witness-self. 3. Param─Бtm─Б or the Supreme ─Аtm─Б. Of these three, the contact with saс╣Гs─Бra and therefore the world is only for the j─лva.

[[Ch. 15 Yoga of meditation on the root of the a┼Ыvattha (part 4) Source: prekshaa]]

Let us now conclude this topic. The j─лva has come in contact with the saс╣Гs─Бra-tree. The root of that tree is in the supreme position (тАЬparame vyomanтАЭ). In its lower part are branches and twigs in the form of the world. The higher the j─лva goes - towards the root - the farther he gets from the bitterness, all the bothersome pests and filthy odours of the tree. That is mokс╣гa. The upward journey towards the origin is fueled by the effort of discernment. How, though, can that be done? It is dark; the tree is knotty in places and is many-branched. The j─лva has lost his way in it. When he sees fruit, he greedily consumes more than what he can take, and suffers indigestion and other maladies of the gut. тАЬThis world is filthy,тАЭ he reflects. тАЬI should not entangle myself in it. I should go beyond this. I should go to the root of the tree where these twigs and props will stop bothering me. How do I attain that state?тАЭ

a┼Ыvattham enaс╣Г su-vir┼лс╕Нha-m┼лlam
asaс╣Еga-┼Ыastreс╣Зa dс╣Ыс╕Нhena chhittv─Б ред
tataс╕е padaс╣Г tat parim─Бrgitavyaс╣Г
yasmin gat─Б na nivartanti bh┼лyaс╕е рее
BG 15.3
тАЬHow does one cut this deep-rooted a┼Ыvattha? By the axe of asaс╣Еga (detachment) - the consideration that тАЬthis is not mineтАЭ that translates to giving up pride and attachment. He needs to hack through the thicket of branches with this weapon thereby marking a way out for Brahma-experience.тАЭ

Asaс╣Еga is the consideration that the world is not mine. Who created this world? The Supreme Brahma. Therefore it is not mine. I have to look for a way out of this world. But what do I do about the leaves - Chand─Бс╣Гsi (the Vedas)? One must use the Vedas and dharma to reach the source. Our attention, however, has to be on the top - the root of the tree. тАЬThis tree is not mine. It has come from elsewhere for whatever reason and belongs to someone else. It is not my property.тАЭ This is how the Vedas can be used. As the ─к┼Ы─Бv─Бsyopaniс╣гad asks

kasyasvit dhanam?
─к┼Ыa Up. 1
тАЬWhose indeed is wealth?тАЭ

I did not create it! It belongs to ─к┼Ыvara. My duty is that of service only. My job is to build a bench for the root of the a┼Ыvattha tree, to water it, rid it of dirt. But for whose joy? For the joy of this treeтАЩs creator. That is how the tree is nourished. When it grows thus, its shade and fresh air benefits many j─лvas. My responsibility is to just do what has been said. There is dharma to which I should be subservient. A gardener in a mango grove cannot ask questions like, тАЬMaster, why did you not plant the grafted mango?тАЭ or тАЬWill you eat this fruit yourself or sell it at the market?тАЭ
When dharma is followed, the branches and props do impede us but on the contrary, they actually help us. It is with their help that we are able to get to the root. It is through dharma that we get a vision of Param─Бtm─Б. The Supreme dharma is that of detachment.
Another Upaniс╣гad states -

с╣Гameti badhyate jantuс╕е
с╣Зa mameti vimucyate рее ┼Ъiva Up. 7.114
(Saying тАЬmine, mineтАЭ, the creature is trapped. Saying тАЬnot mineтАЭ releases it)

What becomes a binding rope when we say тАШmamaтАЩ (mine) becomes a garland of flowers when we say тАЬna mamaтАЭ (not mine). Mokс╣гa is a perspective of the manas. When the manas is of one kind, it is binding; when it is of another kind, it is emancipating. The blossoms of the saс╣Гs─Бra-tree are sweet, lovely, desirable, and worthy of praise. They infatuate us at every step making us feel, “Ah! Such a beautiful world! How can I renounce it? On the other hand, I should make it my own! It should all be for me!”

Many of us feel proud thinking thoughts like - “My husband is so smart!”, “How lovely is my wife!”, “My son is amazing!” We have to be cautious at such moments. Whose is this wealth? Who created these relationships? Where did my sonтАЩs intelligence and daughterтАЩs beauty come from? None of these is mine. I did not earn any of it. All of this is the blessing of ─к┼Ыvara, due to his will. This must be the kind of asaс╣Еga (detachment) that we practise.

The word parim─Бrgitavyam has been used here. It means that one should search again and again. The supreme goal is not easy to attain. We have to return to where saс╣Гs─Бra stems from by climbing up the path. The j─лva has to think thus about the tree he inhabits - “This is not mine. This is not for my enjoyment. Let me be trained and cleansed instead by it.” This is the path towards Brahma.

After this, Bhagav─Бn describes his own nature.

Food is converted to energy through the process of digestion, which in turn takes place because of the heat energy that is characteristic of the digestive system. This digestive fire is ─к┼ЫvaraтАЩs creation.

Summary

Man is a mixture of daiv─л and ─Бsur─л qualities. The human world is the place where he can examine and filter his qualities and train him for better things. Prakс╣Ыti influences him with the guс╣Зa-triad and makes him move forward because of the influence of his daiv─л aspects, or regress because of his ─Бsur─л aspects. Man has freedom to discerningly choose to progress or regress.
The path of dharma, which has two main qualities тАФ acceptance of ─к┼Ыvara and submission to him тАФ becomes visible by the contemplation and examination of daiv─л and ─Бsur─л qualities. Because Vedas and ┼Ъ─Бstras are disregarded, the consciousness of puс╣Зya and p─Бpa has vanished. Here can be seen the seed of various kinds of misery and agony the world is currently experiencing. At least now, will human attention veer towards the Vedas which are the sole means of gaining true knowledge, or towards ┼Ы─Бstras that teach how the manas and buddhi should prepare themselves for understanding philosophy?

Whichever way we see, it is irrefutable that the effort of the buddhi is necessary. However, if buddhi has to understand the principle that is beyond the grasp of the senses, it has to work within the precincts of acceptance of the authority of the Vedas. The moral strength obtained by the study of ┼Ыastras nurtures buddhiтАЩs ability for philosophical deliberation, and accelerates the process of understanding. Human intellect is paramount in the sensual world. In the realm of other-worldly knowledge, Vedas and ┼Ы─Бstras are paramount. The effort of the buddhiin understanding the supreme tattva, in accordance with the supreme tattva is always desirable.

Section 17 /Chapter 16 /Daiv─Бsura-sampad-vibh─Бga-yoga /Daiv─Бsura-viveka-yoga

(The Yoga of Distinction Between ─Бsur─л and daiv─л qualities)

In verses 10-13 of chapter 9, we have seen prakс╣Ыti express itself in two ways. One is “─Бsur─лс╣Г r─Бkс╣гas─лс╣Г caiva” тАФ ─Бsur─л or demonic and the other is “daiv─лс╣Г” тАФ divine. Both of these are the expressions of prakс╣Ыti. The past karmas of the j─лva are the reason they appear together or separately in a man. Birth is taken according to karma; puс╣Зya results in better lives; p─Бpa results in poorer lives.
This is the intention behind the following line тАФ

┼Ыuc─лn─Бс╣Г ┼Ыr─лmat─Бс╣Г gehe ред
BG 6.41

HasnтАЩt even good karma performed with great devotion and good intentions gone in vain some times? The truth is that even though there are no tangible results of that karma, they are always there. The result of puс╣Зya often expresses itself in rebirths, as being born in good and wealthy families that practise purity.
The sixteenth chapter deals with the cause and effect relationship between various lives. Firstly, the characteristics of divine beings are listed тАФ

abhayaс╣Г sattva-saс╣Г┼Ыuddhiс╕е j├▒─Бna-yoga-vyavasthitiс╕е ред
d─Бnaс╣Г dama┼Ыca yaj├▒a┼Ыca sv─Бdhy─Бyas-tapa ─Бrjavam рее
BG 16.1

“Abhaya” means there is no fear in saying the truth or in performing dh─Бrmic duties. Truth hesitates when there is fear. Fearlessness is the primary requirement for truth and justice. Many people fear the consequences of telling the truth. Fear of what others may think and a crafty mindset that gives a convenient, if dishonest answer to all questions тАФ these are very common in todayтАЩs world. That should give way to the trust that one should be faithful to Bhagav─Бn, and he will protect us always. This trust gives rise to fearlessness. We can see this fearlessness in Gandhi. This is the mark of a person who believes in Bhagav─Бn.

abhayaс╣Г vai brahma ред
Bс╣Ыhad─Бraс╣Зyaka

“Abhaya” is not audacity or haughtiness; it is humble fearlessness; it is the courage of truth.
“Sattva-saс╣Г┼Ыuddhiс╕е” : keeping the manas pure, limpid and wakeful тАФ take care so that it is unselfish and guileless and always pleasant. It should be as gracious and clear as a stream flowing from a mountaintop. That is serenity. The manas should not entertain doubts and crookedness.
“J├▒─Бna-yoga-vyavasthitiс╕е” is constant devotion to deliberating about the Brahma and bringing it into daily practice. тАЬI have to understand this tattva, I will perform whatever s─Бdhan─Б to that end, I will definitely attain this tattvaтАЭ - such intense diligence and effort should be there.
тАЬD─БnaтАЭ: Freely giving up something belonging to oneself for the use of others. This is also an attribute of daiv─л nature. We have seen in the Bс╣Ыhad─Бraс╣Зyaka тАФ тАЬd─Бmyata datta dayadhvaс╣ГтАЭ. Dama is the instruction given to the Devas; d─Бna is the instruction to humans; and day─Б is to the r─Бkс╣гasas. Thus, the daiv─л quality that humans have to practise is d─Бna. Only if it is there, it is confirmed that our hearts have melted, and that we sympathise and empathise with other beings.
D─Бna is a quality that is becoming significantly scarce in present times. We call Paurohitya as тАЬpriest-craftтАЭ тАФ and accuse them that the purohitas want money and therefore raise such brouhaha. An English philosopher called T.H.Green says that there are many amongst us with good intentions; but they just end in words and do not get expressed as work. It is said that there is a Japanese story about a man who spent his life in tall talks. When he went to the afterworld, he was pushed into a room that was full of people wagging their mouths and tongues. Wherever he looked, he saw tongue wagging in mouths; whichever way he turned, there were open lips and shaking tongues. When he asked why this was so, he was told тАЬDear fellow, isnтАЩt this all you did on the Earth?тАЭ. Green says that we should not speak too much about great things. As talk increases, morality decreases.
Our ancestors have greatly praised the quality of d─Бna, especially of the secret variety. An old woman in the house would not sit down for lunch, till everyone else in the family was fed, and give up some morsels from her portion of food to beggars or stray animals that needed to eat. That is bh┼лtabali.
тАЬDamaс╕етАЭ: Keep oneтАЩs senses under control.
тАЬYaj├▒aс╕етАЭ: Worship of ─к┼Ыvara. The word sacrifice is used in English. That means ─Бhuti or bali offered to a deity; it means that the feelings of тАЬmeтАЭ and тАЬmineтАЭ тАФ ego and attachment тАФ are offered as sacrifice.
тАЬSv─Бdhy─Бyaс╕етАЭ: Studying texts and treatises related to oneтАЩs profession тАФ humility that there is a lot to know - these help cultivating the buddhi . тАЬSvaтАЭ here means the study of something related to oneself. For a br─Бhmaс╣Зa, this could be studying oneтАЩs own ┼Ы─Бkh─Б. Engineers might want to study engineering texts, and doctors might want to study Ayurveda. Our culture considers worldly sciences such as dhanurveda, sculpting, Ayurveda as upavedas.
тАЬTapaс╕етАЭ: Steadfast devotion that does not allow the thought of anything other than the object of devotion. Just as one has to practice giving up what he has earned, he should also practise reducing his desires and wants, and strive day and night to achieve his objective. Tapas is constant mindfulness about oneтАЩs goal.
тАЬ─АrjavaтАЭ: Straightforward conduct that is not crooked or deceitful, and practises what the conscience preaches.
In addition to the qualities that have been described above,

ahiс╣Гs─Б satyam-akrodhaс╕е ty─Бgaс╕е ┼Ы─Бntir-apai┼Ыunam ред
day─Б bh┼лteс╣гvaloluptvaс╣Г m─Бrdavaс╣Г hr─лr-ac─Бpalam рее
BG 16.2

тАЬApai┼Ыunaс╣ГтАЭ means the absence of calumny. Aloluptva means not being licentious or forget oneself in worldly pleasures. This does not mean that one should not experience pleasure. It just means that one should not lose oneself in sensual pleasures. тАЬHr─лс╕етАЭ means modesty. This is a great quality. It is a natural boon given to humans by Bhagav─Бn. It is a limiting boundary drawn because of concern that someone may think ill of us. If there is even a tiny bit of good manners left in this world it is due to this quality of тАЬhr─лтАЭ. It is the fundamental quality that gives rise to all other forms of propriety. That is why it is specially extolled in the Vedas.

tejaс╕е kс╣гam─Б dhс╣Ыtiс╕е ┼Ыaucam adroho n─Бti-m─Бnit─Б ред
bhavanti saс╣Гpadaс╣Г daiv─лm abhij─Бtasya bh─Бrata рее
BG 16.3

Lustre, patience, courage, purity, not being treacherous, тАЬna atim─Бnit─БтАЭ means not swelling our affections and pride. Some level of self-respect and affection is unavoidable; but it should not increase much. If there is no self-respect and love at all, there might not even be affection between a parent and child! However, self-conceit and haughtiness are not acceptable.

[[Ch. 16 Yoga of Distinction Between ─Бsur─л and daiv─л qualities (Part 2) Source: prekshaa]]

All the above are s─Бttvika qualities. тАЬAbhij─БtaтАЭ means one who is born after performing puс╣Зya. Such a person is blessed with daiv─л qualities. Whoever thinks he is born in a good family and acts accordingly тАФ one who has earned the qualification to worship the Divine тАФ he will be blessed with the wealth of these above qualities. It releases the j─лva from bondage. All this is divine wealth.
The qualities opposite to the above are ─Бsur─л qualities.

dambho darpoтАЩtim─Бna┼Ыca krodhaс╕е p─Бruс╣гyam eva ca ред
aj├▒─Бnaс╣Г c─Бbhij─Бtasya p─Бrtha saс╣Гpadam ─Бsur─лm рее
BG 16.4

Dambha is the display of pride, and conceit that one possesses something that others do not. Darpa is vanity, hardness of the manas. It is the feeling that others are inferior to oneself. Excessive infatuation, malice, cruelty, lack of knowledge, lack of discernment тАФ all these are t─Бmasic qualities. They are the result of p─Бpas committed in past lives. They tighten the bonds of the j─лva.
Sv─Бm─л now elucidates the results of these two kinds of qualities.

daiv─л saс╣Гpad-vimokс╣г─Бya nibandh─Бy─Бsur─л mat─Б ред
m─Б ┼Ыucaс╕е saс╣Гpadaс╣Г daiv─лm abhij─БtoтАЩsi p─Бс╣Зс╕Нava рее
BG 16.5
тАЬDaiv─л qualities are those that help in attaining mokс╣гa. ─Аsur─л qualities are those that cause bondage. Arjuna, do not grieve thinking whether you are qualified to strive for mokс╣гa. You are born with daiv─л qualities. You are eligible to tread the path towards mokс╣гaтАЭ.

There is one thought here. Bhagav─Бn listed daiv─л qualities; he listed ─Бsur─л qualities as well; he will describe them further. Why did he not mention human qualities? Are there no such qualities as human qualities? The purport here is that all the above qualities are human only. There is no human trait that does not fall into either daiv─л or ─Бsur─л category. Humans are a mix of divine and demonic aspects. This is what the Vedas say:

puс╣Зyena puс╣Зyaс╣Г lokaс╣Г nayati ред p─Бpena p─Бpam ред ubh─Бbhy─Бm eva manuс╣гyalokam рее
Pra┼Ыnopaniс╣гat

When both kinds of traits commingle, he comes to the mortal world. This is an opportunity for him; he can either ascend to better states, or plummet to viler states. In his management of this universe, Bhagav─Бn has given this freedom to humans. The Bс╣Ыhad─Бraс╣Зyaka says the following -

sa v─Б тАж k─БmamayoтАЩk─Бma-mayaс╕е krodhamayoтАЩkrodhamayo dharmamayoтАЩdharmamayaс╕е sarvamayas-tadyad-etat-idaс╣ГmayoтАЩdomaya iti yath─Бk─Бr─л yath─Бc─Бr─л tath─Б bhavati рее

Since we cannot give a finite list of human traits, the upaniс╣гat says тАЬidammayaс╕е adomayaс╕етАЭ. A j─лva is full of all necessary and unnecessary qualities. He becomes what he does and how he conducts himself.
Since a human is thus a mix of both good and bad qualities, he cannot be steady where he is, and should continuously move up or down every second.
Plato gives the same instruction:

тАЬIn the human soul, there is a better and also a worse principle; and when the better has the worse under control, then a man is said to be master of himself (which is a term of praise); but when, owing to evil education or association, the better principle, which is also the smaller, is overwhelmed by the greater mass of the worse тАФ in this case he is blamed and is called the slave of self and unprincipled.тАЭ
(The Republic, Book IV)

The same feeling is echoed in the poem тАЬA Death in the DesertтАЭ by Browning.

Man is not God, but hath GodтАЩs end to serve тАФ
A master to obey, a course to take, тАФ
Somewhat to cast off, somewhat to become.
Grant this, that man must pass from old to new,
From vain to real, from mistake to fact,
From what once seemed good to what now proves best.
How could man have progression otherwise?
Progress, manтАЩs distinctive mark alone,
Not GodтАЩs and not the beastsтАЩ; God is, they are;
Man partly is and wholly hopes to be.

What the G─лta calls тАШ─БsuraтАЩ, Browning calls beastly or animalistic. Every second, daiv─л aspects keep pulling man upward, or ─Бsur─л aspects keep pulling him down. There is progress if he ascends; if he descends, he will deteriorate. He cannot keep quiet even for a second and say that he wants neither progress nor deterioration. He cannot remain where he is. Indeed, prakс╣Ыti does not leave him alone! She keeps poking him with the trident that is the three guс╣Зas and troubles him constantly. Daiv─л and asur─л are both the energies of prakrti.

dvau bh┼лtasargau lokeтАЩsmin daiva ─Бsura eva ca рее
BG 16.6

Prakс╣Ыti has placed man on a greasy pole. He cannot embrace it and remain where he is. He should fold his hands in front of it and keep moving upwards with fortitude. Even if he forgets himself for a moment, he will slide down. Our daily life is this dangerous game.
Divine beings do not face this instability. They reside perpetually in the higher worlds. They do not get down from there. If they do climb down, the balance of the universe will go haywire. The sun, moon, clouds and lightning, air and water should perform their assigned tasks constantly, without fail. That is what prakс╣Ыti has decreed. They cannot make mistakes there. They do not slip down.
On the other hand, Asuras do not have even an iota of an idea of progress. They do not understand the difference between high and low, honorable and contemptible. They do not even worry that they are inferior and that they might fall further. Such is ─Бsur─л delusion or beastly confusion. They are born again and again in low forms and thus spend their accumulated p─Бpa. They might be born as humans at some point of time and then they might qualify to discern the difference between progress and regress. It is an uncertain future.
Humans have the freedom to examine progress and retreat wilfully and with full volition and use of oneтАЩs buddhi . It is not required for divine beings; and not possible for ─Бsur─л beings. In this creation, the opportunity to progress towards better states is possible only for humans.
After suggesting this principle, Bhagav─Бn explains the grimness of ─Бsur─л qualities тАФ we might choose to think that it is to create dread and alarm in common people and awaken them. Bhagav─Бn did not need to create fear in Arjuna. He had not displayed ─Бsur─л qualities. There was absolutely no doubt that he was rich with the wealth of daiv─л qualities. DidnтАЩt ┼Ъrikс╣Ыс╣гna himself say this? Love for truth, devotion to dharma, sympathy towards all beings тАФ all these are clearly manifest in Arjuna. Therefore it is possible that this instruction is for other common people of this world. I feel that ┼Ъrikс╣Ыс╣гna had the people of 1963 CE (or 2023 CE perhaps) in his mind when he spoke this. I believe you would think the same if you see these sentences from the Gita.

asatyam- apratiс╣гс╣нhaс╣Г te jagad-─Бhur-an─л┼Ыvaram ред
aparaspara-sambh┼лtaс╣Г kimanyat-k─Бma-haitukam рее
BG 16.8

тАЬWhat is Truth? There is nothing called Truth. If there is Truth, who has seen it? Where is the ─к┼Ыvara who rules the universe? This is anarchy. It is haphazardly placed (apratiс╣гс╣нhaс╣Г); the establishment of dharma is fake. All things in the universe are born out of randomness; there is no relationship between them тАФ they are not related to one another in accordance with precepts like тАЬ─Аk─Б┼Ы─Бd-v─БyuhтАЭ, etc., or from other lives. If you say there are so many life-forms, they are all the results of lust between male and femaleтАЭ тАФ this is what asuras say. That is atheism. That is the theory of c─Бrv─Бkas.
They do not agree that j─лvas are born out of interaction between various karmas, by set rules, and obligations between j─лvas and that they are thus related to one another. They do not agree that the rope of karma binds the whole universe within a single sack.
тАЬaparaspara-saс╣Гbh┼лtaс╣ГтАЭ can mean two things. First meaning is тАЬfrom the union of male and femaleтАЭ: тАЬaparaс╕е+ca+paraс╕е+caтАЭ тАФ when one joins another. Since there is тАЬk─БmahaitukamтАЭ next to this word, we can understand it as a union between male and female. Another meaning could be the union of two completely unrelated things that have randomly and arbitrarily somehow come together.
In ancient Greece, there were philosophers called Atomists. They had not accepted the existence of ─к┼Ыvara. They believed that interactions between atoms was the reason for the birth, death, and rebirth of the universe. They believed that the nature of these atoms drove them to behave in this way. The energy that makes them move or stops them from movement does not come from the external environment. They unite with other atoms and divide from them, of their own volition. They do not have an authority that makes them do this.
We see that many animate and inanimate things constantly collude together and disperse from one another. What is the reason for this? The atheist says that it is by chance, and that it does not have a reason. The theist says that it is because of impressions from the past. From the point of view of a theist, nothing happens without reason.
