[[Ch. 16 Yoga of Distinction Between ─Бsur─л and daiv─л qualities (Part 3) Source: prekshaa]]

In the R─Бm─Бyaс╣Зa, after Da┼Ыaratha left to the heavenly abode, when Bharata begged R─Бma to return to Ayodhy─Б and become the king, Srir─Бma says the following -

yath─Б k─Бс╣гс╣нhaс╣Г ca k─Бс╣гс╣нhaс╣Г ca samey─Бt─Бс╣Г mah─Бrс╣Зave ред
sametya ca vyapey─Бt─Бс╣Г k─Бlam─Бs─Бdya ka├▒cana рее
evaс╣Г bh─Бry─Б┼Ыca putr─Б┼Ыca j├▒─Бtaya┼Ыca dhan─Бni ca рее
(2.105.26, 27)
Sr─лr─БmaтАЩs opinion is тАФ тАЬJust as two logs coming from different places travel together for some time and then disperse in a vast ocean, similarly wives, children, relatives and wealth are with us for some time and leave us. This union and parting are characteristics of saс╣Гs─Бra. Nothing is permanent in this world, except dharmaтАЭ.

In the analogy of logs of wood above, the energy that makes the logs move is the current of water. Each river pushed a log into the ocean. Remnants of debts from past lives and the obligations of puс╣Зya and p─Бpa of the beings of the world have caused them to come together in various ways. Vaidika dharma believes that all friendships and other relationships and all hatred and distress happen for a reason. Materialists (Those who believe in the absolute independence of the physical world) aver that there is no such reason. They say that life is just whatever we directly perceive.

Materialists say that the universe is just a collaboration of atoms; they say that death and pralaya are the dispersal of atoms. Combination and dissolution happen solely because of the nature of atoms and nothing else. The bonding ability and valency of atoms make them behave thus. Who created them in this way? Nobody knows who it is. The universe is a result of their attractive and repulsive forces. Likewise, a man and his manas are the result of the play of atomic forces. After playing for a long time like this, atoms might lose their energy and become still. That is death. Till that comes, whatever a man finds pleasure in, is good for him. Puс╣Зya, p─Бpa and rebirth are cock-and-bull stories. There is nothing after death.

This is a summary of the atomic theory. It is ┼Ы┼лnyav─Бda тАФ or the theory of voidness; because there was vacuum before the birth of the universe and after its death. It is an atheistic theory, because it does not accept the existence of the ─Бtmavastu that is different from temporary and fleeting atoms. That is materialism. In todayтАЩs world, it is a known fact that communists are the materialists, opposing religious beliefs and upholding the supremacy of the material world.

This is the answer the Veda gives to atheists and materialists тАФ

asanneva sa bhavati ред asad-brahmeti veda cet ред asti brahmeti ced-veda ред santamenaс╣Г tato viduс╕е рее Taittir─лya-upaniс╣гad
тАЬOne who thinks that there is no Brahma, becomes naught himself. One who believes in it will qualify to understand its full nature of the mysterious sadvastu that is the BrahmaтАЭ.

The universe and man are a small part of the Brahma which is the basis of everything. From where can a part originate, if not from the whole? If that does not exist, this does not either. It is obtained by those who believe in it, not those who disbelieve and dismiss it. Those who say that they donтАЩt believe in a supreme being only regard self-importance and their own pleasure. Those people, who are established in themselves тАФ their own bodies and their pleasure тАФ are asuras. Let us see which peoples answer to the characteristics of asuras, as described by Bhagav─Бn.

k─Бmam─Б┼Ыritya duс╣гp┼лraс╣Г dambha-m─Бna-mad─Бnvit─Бс╕е рее
(BG 16.10)
cint─Бm-aparimey─Бс╣Г ca pralay─Бnt─Бm-up─Б┼Ыrit─Бс╕е ред
k─Бmopabhoga-param─Б et─Бvaditi ni┼Ыcit─Бс╕е рее
(BG 16.11)
─лhante k─Бmabhog─Бrthaс╣Г any─Бyen─Бrtha-sa├▒cay─Бn рее (BG 16.12)
тАЬTheir desire is never satisfied. There is no beginning or end to their pride and haughtiness. They are so sure of themselves that they have plans till the end of the world. They have decided that pleasure is their highest human goal, and strive towards earning the means required for thatтАЭ.

Is this not the description of many countries among us now? When we say India has to compete with Europe and America, is it not in this competition of acquiring more and more pleasure objects? (This was written in the 1960s. By now we can safely say that we are effortlessly competing with western nations in consumerism and what Sr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa succinctly puts as тАЬkamopabhogapar─БmyaтАЭ.)
What is the nature of their pride?

asau may─Б hataс╕е ┼Ыatruс╕е haniс╣гye c─Бpar─Бnapi ред
─л┼Ыvaroham ahaс╣Г bhog─л siddhoтАЩhaс╣Г balav─Бn sukh─л рее
(BG 16.14)
─Бс╕НhyoтАЩbhijanav─Бn asmi koтАЩnyoтАЩsti sadс╣Ы┼Ыo may─Б ред
yakс╣гye d─Бsy─Бmi modiс╣гya ityaj├▒─Бna-vimohit─Бс╕е рее (BG 16.15)
тАЬI destroyed this enemy, now I will hit this other enemy. (I gobbled Tibet and am now nibbling at India). I am the master. I am the master of pleasures. I am the winner. I am the strongest. I was born to experience pleasure only. I am the most affluent. I was born in the best family. Who in the world can be equal to me? I perform all the yaj├▒as I desire to. I give all the d─Бnas I want to. I enjoy all the wealth I wantтАЭтАФ The ignorance and delusion of an asura makes him talk like this.

Asuras do worship now and then. DidnтАЩt R─Бvaс╣Зa and other r─Бkс╣гasas perform penance and other austerities and gain boons from that? But what kind of worship was that?

moh─Бd-gс╣Ыh─лtv─БтАЩsadgr─Бh─Бn pravartanteтАЩ┼Ыuci-vrat─Бс╕е ред
yajante n─Бmayaj├▒ais-te dambhen─Бvidhi-p┼лrvakam рее
(BG 16.10, 16.11)
тАЬAsuras fancy and perform unclean vratas (like worshipping bh┼лtas and pretas) that are forbidden by the virtuous. For praise by the world, they perform yaj├▒as disregarding ┼Ы─Бstra and samprad─Бya. It is yaj├▒a for namesake only; in reality it is mere pageantryтАЭ.

What is the use of many pots of water for a sandhy─Бvandanam without mantras? There is no food for the hungry; but electric lights in the wedding pandal are bright enough to hurt the eyes. Was this happening in Sr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣ЗaтАЩs time? Probably not. Bhagavan knows the past, present and future. He might have seen our times through his divine vision and said this.

mam─Бtma-paradeheс╣гu pradviс╣гantoтАЩbhyas┼лyak─Бс╕е рее
(BG 16.18)
тАЬThey abhor and despise param─Бtm─Б which is within them and others alsoтАЭ.

This is the main trait of materialists. They do not respect the existence of the supreme energy that is param─Бtm─Б within them or within others, and behave with intolerance and hatred towards Bhagav─Бn, like Hiraс╣Зyaka┼Ыipu. Doom is reserved for them.

─Бsur─лс╣Г yonim─Бpann─Б m┼лс╕Нh─Б janmani janmani ред
m─Бmupr─Бpyaiva kaunteya tato y─Бnty-adham─Бс╣Г gatim рее
(BG 16.19)
Such people cannot attain the param─Бtm─Б. They are born in low life-forms again and again and sink downwards.

By deliberating upon and understanding life in the universe and by critically examining the qualities of daiva and asura, the principles of accepting Bhagav─Бn and treading the path towards him can be understood. We should first completely accept in our minds that param─Бtm─Б pervades everywhere, is the cause of everything and is the master of everything. Secondly, as we have accepted Bhagav─Бn, we should submit to his rule wholeheartedly.

The following three human qualities come in the way of such acceptance :

trividhaс╣Г narakasyedaс╣Г dv─Бraс╣Г n─Б┼Ыanam─Бtmanaс╕е ред
k─Бmaс╕е krodhas-tath─Б lobhaс╕е tasm─Бd-etat-trayaс╣Г tyajet рее
(BG 16.21)
тАЬThere are three doors to naraka тАФ k─Бma (desire), krodha (anger) and lobha(covetousness). These harm the ─Бtm─Б. Therefore they should be given upтАЭ.

K─Бma is the desire for pleasure. It is the fancy for seeking, seeing and experiencing delight and pleasure everywhere, come what may. If that is not satisfied, it results in prolonged frustration, which is nothing but krodha. Lobha is the intense greed for possessing whatever, whoever one wants, wherever it/he/she is. R─Бvana is the ideal for all the three qualities. K─Бma is the predominant quality of K─лcaka; krodha of Kaс╣Гsa and lobha of Duryodhana.
Along with kama, krodha and lobha, moha (impulsiveness due to delusion/or without discretion), mada (forgetting oneself out of pride) and m─Бtsarya (jealousy) are added and called the ariс╣гaс╕Нvarga тАФ or the six enemies. These six are thieves that hide within every man and steal his daiv─л wealth when he is not paying attention. One should be careful about these thieves who are within him. Well-being of the ─Бtm─Б will then follow.
By giving up k─Бma and others, the ─Бtm─Б is filtered clean of its impurities. That is a negative action. After this, there has to be a positive action of s─Бdhan─Б. The way for that should be understood from ┼Ы─Бstras.

tasm─Бc-ch─Бstraс╣Г pram─Бс╣Зaс╣Г te k─Бry─Бk─Бrya-vyavasthitau ред
j├▒─Бtv─Б ┼Ы─Бstra-vidh─Бnoktaс╣Г karma kartum-ih─Бrhasi рее
BG 16.24
тАЬArjuna, ┼Ы─Бstra is the teacher that tells you what you have to do and what you should not. Perform your karma according to itтАЭ.

Washing a vessel is meaningful if good food is cooked in it. If good food has to be cooked, one should know the art and science of cooking тАФ from watching others cook, reading cookbooks, and by oneтАЩs own experience. Similarly, if our life has to become better, we have to know what makes it more beautiful and what distorts it.

Here, ┼Ы─Бstra is the collective term for four instructors:

vedaс╕е smс╣Ыtiс╕е sad─Бc─Бraс╕е svasya ca priyam-─Бtmanaс╕е ред
etac-caturvidhaс╣Г pr─Бhuс╕е s─Бkс╣г─Бd-dharmasya lakс╣гaс╣Зam рее
Manusmс╣Ыti
1.Vedas 2. Smс╣Ыtis 3. Traditions followed by the good and learned. 4. OneтАЩs own discernment of what is beneficial and what is not for him тАФ dharma can be ascertained when the above four are together.

[[Ch. 16 Yoga of Distinction Between ─Бsur─л and daiv─л qualities (Part 4) Source: prekshaa]]

It is not possible for ordinary people to know the path of dharma by their own judgment, without the guidance of ┼Ъruti and Smс╣Ыti. Their knowledge is limited; the capability of their buddhi is sparse; their nature is fallible, owing to k─Бma, krodha and lobha; therefore instruction and guidance from ancestors and traditions followed by older and experienced people becomes the basis for performing dharma. They show us the highway of dharma. Any path other than this is fraught with dangers and is not safe.

yaс╕е ┼Ы─Бstra-vidhim-utsс╣Ыjya vartate k─Бmak─Бrataс╕е ред
na sa siddhim-av─Бpnoti na sukhaс╣Г na par─Бс╣Г gatim рее
BG 16.23
тАЬOne who transgresses the decree of ┼Ы─Бstra and follows wherever his manas takes him will not be able to obtain the tattva. He will not experience bliss and will not attain higher worldsтАЭ.

Because the world venerates ┼Ы─Бstra, it protects the world. The end of our peace of mind began when our people started asking тАЬWhat is in ┼Ы─Бstra?тАЭ and denounced it as a superstition. When respect for puс╣Зya and fear of p─Бpa vanished from our minds, they started becoming the abode of restlessness. When educated and respectable people started sloganeering such as тАЬWhat is svarga? It is a mere toy. What is naraka? A mere scarecrowтАЭ, the foundation of traditional lifestyle was hit. What shifted then is now sprinting in all directions without any control. This is the result of giving up ┼Ы─Бstra. It is seen in every street in every village. Dharma vanished and law took its place.

From the point of view of the state of the present world, there is no other book as important as this chapter of the G─лt─Б. If life in this world for us has to become tolerable, the first thing that is necessary is the distinction between puс╣Зya and p─Бpa. Scientific advancement has encouraged the hankering for carnal pleasures. It is on the agenda of the social and political institutions of those countries also. TodayтАЩs hue and cry is about increasing the standard of living. Thus, when indulging in pleasure-mongering itself becomes the most important goal of life, earning the objects that propel us towards this goal feels like our foremost duty. From this arises and propagates the delusion that adharma is indeed our dharma. If the society has to be rescued from this great misconception, at least some people should understand the difference between daiv─л and ─Бsur─л qualities and should try to influence people to accept more and more daiv─л qualities and get rid of ─Бsur─л qualities. The daily samkalpa of с╣Ъс╣гis is -

anс╣Ыt─Бt-satyam-upaimi ред m─Бnuс╣г─Бd-daivam-upaimi рее
(Taittir─лya-br─Бhmaс╣Зa)
тАЬI will go from falsity to truth; I will attain divinity from humanityтАЭ.

Anс╣Ыta or falsity is that which is artificial and not in our nature. Blind imitation of others is anс╣Ыta. Truth is whatever that is agreeable to our true nature. Hankering for worldly pleasures and traversing blindly in the path trod by others to attain them, without proper understanding of our svadharma is anс╣Ыta and adharma. The wonderful and deceptive splendour of the universe might pull us towards adharma. The с╣Ъс╣гis pray that they never go to the side of adharma and that they be established in svadharma.
Similarly, human desires and bonds might drag us to the path of asuras. The с╣Ъс╣гis pray to the Devas that they may never stray from the daiv─л path.

There is one sentence that needs to be explored in a little more detail. That is тАЬtasm─Бcch─Бstraс╣Г pram─Бс╣Зaс╣Г te редтАЭ.

Authority of ┼Ъ─Бstra

What does our buddhi have to do if ┼Ы─Бstra itself is the supreme authority? Should there be no freedom for independent working of the buddhi ? These questions have been answered earlier. Let us briefly recall them.
Sense objects are required for human buddhi to do its work. Where there are no senses, the buddhicannot do anything. The manas provides material to the buddhi. Senses provide material to the manas. If the senses do not collect information, the field of the manas is empty. If the manas is unemployed, the buddhihas to be quiet too. Thus, the field where the buddhican work is bounded. Concepts such as j─лva, ─Бtm─Б, ─к┼Ыvara, many lives and many worlds тАФ are far from it. Senses cannot touch those mysteries. How can the manas enter where senses do not? Thus, the supreme principle cannot be grasped by the buddhi.

Not only that, senses can trap the buddhi. They can distract the manas with pleasure and its attainment, and make it forget that there is a supreme principle beyond them that is worth striving for in our lives. Even here, the buddhi becomes weak because of its slavery to the senses. Therefore Sv─Бmi instructs us again and again to control our senses.

It is not possible for mere buddhito comprehend param─Бtm─Б, the most mysterious principle in life. Vedas are the only means to know the nature of something that is beyond senses. The Vedas are the words of those who have directly seen and experienced the paravastu. Without understanding that, we cannot obtain true knowledge. But is the buddhi not required there? It is certainly required. The Vedas do not carry any meaning to someone whose buddhi is not purified. It is the job of the buddhi to understand the hidden meaning in the Vedas correctly and make them his own.

┼Ъ─Бstras help in two ways.
They explain the subtleties of philosophy
They teach us the preparations required for bringing philosophy into our daily lives. Our understanding of philosophy is according to the preparation of our buddhi and morality. Any teaching is imparted according to the ability of the receiver. This is the scheme to be followed to grasp ┼Ы─Бstra. The two objectives of ┼Ы─Бstra are to develop the right aptitude and propriety of instruction.

The buddhi works in two ways
Understanding the Vedas
Using reasoning and past experiences, critically examine what has been understood and establish the concept firmly.
Our mindset towards ┼Ы─Бstra should have two aspects. The first is ┼Ыraddh─Б and the second is viveka. ┼Ъraddh─Б is belief. Just as we trust food served by our mother and the medicine given by a good doctor, we should trust and understand the instructions given by ┼Ы─Бstra. After that, just as we would remember the food or medicine and their effect on us, we should critically re-examine our understanding by pondering upon the cause-and-effect relationship, and changing тАФ updating our understanding of ┼Ы─Бstra if necessary, again and again. This has to be performed by the buddhi. Thus, it does not mean тАЬ*buddhir-apram─Бс╣Зam (*Meaning that the buddhi is not a pram─Бс╣Зa.)тАЭ just because тАЬ┼Ы─Бstram pram─Бс╣ЗamтАЭ was said. It just means that mere buddhi is not enough. The buddhi is certainly required, but it is not sufficient by itself. The raw material for the working of the buddhi-machinery should come from ┼Ы─Бstra тАФ that is the essence of this discussion. Only buddhi can explain what has been said in the ┼Ы─Бstra.

[[Ch. 16 Yoga of Distinction Between ─Бsur─л and daiv─л qualities (Part 5) Source: prekshaa]]

Therefore, it does not mean that belief in ┼Ы─Бstra means that the buddhi is going to stop working. In the sixth chapter, Bhagav─Бn himself has explained how important the buddhi is.

buddhi-gr─Бhyam at─лndriyam рее

The nature of the ─Бtm─Б is beyond the senses and the manas. The Upaniс╣гat says тАФ

yanmanas─Б na manute yen─Бhur-mano matam рее

Thus, the inability of the senses and manas are shown. The buddhi can grasp more subtleties than the manas.

Manastu par─Б buddhir-yo buddheс╕е paratastu saс╕е ред
(BG 3.42)

Among the human means to obtain knowledge, the one closest to the paratattva is the buddhi. If that does not work properly, it is as if there is no loop in the rope used to draw water from a well. The tattva is not obtained without the effort of the buddhi. What do we mean when we say that the buddhi should work? It should face the supreme tattva тАФ work with the firm purpose of understanding it. That is ┼Ыraddh─Б. If that is not done тАФ if it turns its back to the tattva, the buddhi might harm us instead of helping. The crux here is that the buddhi should work in accordance with the essence of ┼Ы─Бstra. The main principle of ┼Ы─Бstra is beyond the senses and beyond the world. We do not have any resort other than ┼Ы─Бstra if we are to understand the basic, fundamental principles. Therefore, it is imperative that we understand what ┼Ы─Бstra says. However, understanding ┼Ы─Бstra is impossible without the effort of the buddhi. Maharс╣гi Manu says -

pratyakс╣гaс╣Г c─Бnum─Бnaс╣Г ca ┼Ы─Бstraс╣Г ca vividh─Бgamam ред
trayaс╣Г suviditaс╣Г k─Бryaс╣Г dharma┼Ыuddhim abh─лpsat─Б рее
─Бrс╣гaс╣Г dharmopade┼Ыaс╣Г ca veda-┼Ы─Бstr─Бvirodhin─Б ред
yastarkeс╣Зanu-sandhatte sa dharmaс╣Г veda netaraс╕е рее Manusmс╣Ыti
тАЬ1. The knowledge of the world that is seen and experienced directly (pratyakс╣гa) 2. The aspects that are understood when these are examined (anum─Бna) 3. Religious texts that help in the understanding of the Vedas, such as smс╣Ыtis and pur─Бс╣Зas тАФ those who desire to obtain pure dh─Бrmic knowledge should depend on all the above threeтАЭ.
тАЬOnly the one who uses his buddhi to logically establish the instruction of с╣Ыс╣гis without misconstruing its fundamental concepts will understand dharma, not othersтАЭ.

Thus, the necessity of the buddhi is clearly demonstrated. The pram─Бс╣Зas outlined above тАФ pratyakс╣гa, anum─Бna and ─Бgama are all the works of the buddhi.
If a surgeon is asked to perform surgery without cutting away the neck of the patient, does it mean that we are hampering his freedom to treat his patients? If we ask a teacher to correct a student without harming him physically, are we taking away his freedom to teach? If we ask someone to donate money without borrowing from others or begging, does it mean that we are preventing him from exercising his freedom to perform d─Бna? Similarly, if one is asked to be careful to not hit at the roots of the tree of dharma it does not mean that the dirt and rot in its branches should not be cleaned^(^([1])). The purport of this discussion is that the buddhi should follow ┼Ы─Бstras in its deliberations. The same is said in a verse, supposedly written by Sr─л ┼Ъankar─Бc─Бrya.

dustark─Бt suviramyat─Бс╣Г ┼Ыrutimatas-tarkoтАЩnusandh─лyat─Бm рее
s─Бdhan─Б-pa├▒cakam

It is not possible for even the greatest buddhi to independently perceive the parabrahma that is beyond senses and all understanding. It has to be understood only through the help of the Vedas. Barring this one restriction, the buddhi is free to work unconstrained. Not only that, it is required to work.

Along with the material for deliberation, the buddhi also acquires eligibility to work тАФ only because of ┼Ы─Бstra. The saс╣Гsk─Бras, etc that are ordained by ┼Ы─Бstras such as smс╣Ыti purify the manas. Worldly desires, greed, infatuation and hatred are eroded and sensual impulses are reduced. As ─Бsur─л nature in the senses reduces, daiv─л nature takes its place in the manas. When the manas starts paying attention to the divine, the buddhi becomes capable of understanding the philosophy of the parabrahma. Thus, the buddhiderives even the capability to perceive the Brahma through ┼Ы─Бstra, along with the material for reflection.

The buddhi and ┼Ы─Бstra are both needed by each other. One needs the help of the other to be meaningful. ┼Ъ─Бstra cannot be understood without the help of the buddhi. When there is no ┼Ы─Бstra there is no material for the buddhi to ponder about. The object that has to be understood here is beyond the realm of understanding of this world, beyond the senses. If this has to be explained to the world, at least some basic instructions should be there as a basis. Just as foundation is to a building, the Vedas are to the study of the parabrahma. However, the foundation is not the house itself. The explanations and elucidations that come out of manтАЩs buddhi are like the house. Let us change this simile a little. If we think of the Vedas as the Earth, which is the basis of all life, we can say that various religions and philosophies are the buildings that stand on this basic premise that is the Earth. There is no house without the Earth. There is no fulfilment for the earth without houses. Thus, the words of the ┼Ы─Бstra and human discernment are symbiotic.
A cautionary word seems to be in place here. One should not consider anything and sundry written in the Saс╣Гskс╣Ыta language as ┼Ы─Бstra. Only that which has traditionally been passed down from generations as the word of learned sages is ┼Ы─Бstra. Others cannot be given the respectful place of pram─Бс╣Зa. It is true that one should be subservient to the words of ┼Ы─Бstra. However, one should also be able to distinguish between real ┼Ы─Бstra and mere pleasant words. It is possible to see that some parts of the Veda are more authoritative and authentic than others. Therefore, even within the Vedas, it is necessary to understand the subtle differences between various expressions and examine the other pram─Бс╣Зas from the basis of the greatest pram─Бс╣Зa one can find. Therefore, even subservience to ┼Ы─Бstra requires the effort of the buddhi. This is why the commentators on smrtis say -

─лti-kartavyat─Б-bh─Бgaс╣Г m─лm─Бс╣Гs─Б p┼лrayiс╣гyati рее
(Bh─Бvaprak─Б┼Ыik─Б)

Thereby agreeing that the buddhi has a role to play in the search for the supreme truth.

Let this be our constant prayer.

[[Ch 17 Yoga of the Discernment of tri-fold ┼Ъraddh─Б (Part 1) Source: prekshaa]]

Note

arising from the guс╣Зa-triad born of prakс╣Ыti.
When buddhi is completely restrained by

Summary

Food, yaj├▒a and d─Бna are three-fold according to the three components of prakс╣Ыti - sattva, r─Бjas and t─Бmas. During all of our life activities, our focus must be on encouraging an exuberance of sattva.

Section 18 /Chapter 17 /┼Ъraddh─Б-traya-vibh─Бga-yoga /┼Ъraddh─Б-traya-viveka-yoga

(The Yoga of the Discernment of tri-fold ┼Ъraddh─Б)

The subject of this chapter is ┼Ыraddh─Б that is of three kinds.

┼Ъraddh─Б can be defined as trust or what is referred to in English as faith or belief. It is implicit trust placed in something - prior to reasoning, and without any examination or analysis. Such faith is seen even among Christians and Muslims. When an object is believed to exist and function even in the absence of any immediate or inferential testimony for its existence, such a belief is known as ┼Ыraddh─Б.

In that case, isnтАЩt ┼Ыraddh─Б the same as blind belief or superstition? Does it not appear to be against the buddhiтАЩs logical reasoning?

Well, yes and no. While the buddhi has already been accepted in earlier chapters as the most important instrument to obtain j├▒─Бna, we have also seen that there is a limit to the buddhiтАЩs capabilities. There are many areas where the buddhi cannot venture into independently. J─лva, ─Аtm─Б, ─к┼Ыvara, puс╣Зya, p─Бpa, transmigration, different lokas - are all matters that the buddhi cannot address by itself. This is because such matters are beyond the grasp of the sense organs as well as the touch of the manas. The buddhi too, therefore, is away from such subjects. If the buddhi has to enter such areas, it has to be led there by entities that are knowledgeable in them. Vedas, ┼Ы─Бstras, guru, and ┼Ыiс╣гс╣нa (learned, wise) traditions are such trustworthy and knowledgeable guides for the buddhi. If we say no to these trusty and wise guides in matters that are beyond the buddhi, we are essentially saying no to an offer of light while we scramble in pitch darkness. In such matters, where worldly wisdom counsels us -

n─Бnyaс╕е panth─Б vidyateтАЩyan─Бya
“There is no other way towards that abode.”
-┼Ъvet─Б┼Ыvatara Upaniс╣гad (3.8)

only the ┼Ы─Бstras and gurus can be our guides. The mental readiness to trust them is ┼Ыraddh─Б. Upade┼Ыa (instruction) to one without ┼Ыraddh─Б is like planting a seed on a boulder. The instruction to Arjuna would be fruitful only if he had ┼Ыraddh─Б in it. So, in order to ascertain whether Arjuna really had ┼Ыraddh─Б in his teaching, Bhagav─Бn now - towards the end of the G─лt─Б - bestows upon us this instruction on tri-fold ┼Ыraddh─Б, using Arjuna as a pretext.

When there is agreement between ┼Ы─Бstric teaching and conclusions based on independent reasoning, there is no reason for concern. However, in present circumstances, agreement between worldly thought and the ┼Ы─Бstras is dwindling. The ┼Ы─Бstras prohibit travel overseas for a br─Бhmaс╣Зa; but the buddhi says that it is necessary. The ┼Ы─Бstras are in favour of the system of varс╣З─Б┼Ыrama; the buddhi considers it unsuitable. The ┼Ы─Бstras mandate a ┼Ыikh─Б (tuft of hair) for males, but the buddhi likes cropped hair. The ┼Ы─Бstra necessitates black beads for married women (in the maс╣Еgalas┼лtra), but the buddhi considers it a primitive practice. The ┼Ы─Бstras say that the bond of marriage is unbreakable; but the buddhi says that the institution of marriage is optional. We can quote a thousand such examples. In such dilemmas, what is the path to welfare? The ┼Ы─Бstra or oneтАЩs own buddhi?

There is scope for both ┼Ы─Бstra and buddhi in our lives. In that case, should both of them function in the same spheres of life? Or do both have mutually exclusive areas of operation? This has to be discussed.

When it comes to the operation of the buddhi, it must be borne in mind that the buddhi needs raw material to work with. An expert potter cannot function without clay or a carpenter cannot carve without wood. Similarly, a farmer needs land to cultivate, a merchant needs wares to trade with, and a doctor needs medicine in treating her patients. In short, any function needs some input material to refine or work with. Likewise, the buddhi needs raw material which is supplied by the manas. Sense organs such as the eyes and ears gather information about the world and convey it to the manas, which in turn is conveyed to the buddhi. At the same time, the manas informs the buddhi of its likes and dislikes. In addition to the manas, old memories also influence the buddhi. Thus, the buddhi gets its input raw material from the sense organs, manas, and memory. This implies that as long as the sense organs and the manas cannot function, the buddhi cannot either. We have now thus established the limits for the buddhiтАЩs functioning.

We have seen before that satya (truth) is of two kinds. One is truth that is seen and the other is truth that cannot be seen. The seen truth is accessible via the sense organs and corresponds to the world that we directly perceive. The unseen world is not accessible through the sense organs. It is a secret consciousness that is beyond the world. We cannot perceive it but can only witness its power and effects in our world and lives.

Some of our life activities pertain to the directly perceived world and can be attained by our buddhi. Others are beyond this world and thus imperceptible by our sense organs. The buddhi cannot operate by itself there.

Through this distinction we can ascertain their respective spheres of influence. In areas of activity perceived by our sense organs, thus permitting its operation, human buddhi assumes primacy and the ┼Ы─Бstras become secondary. Where sense organs cannot operate and the buddhi does not get material to work with, the Vedas and ┼Ы─Бstras become paramount making human buddhi secondary.

J─лva, ─к┼Ыvara, p─Бpa, puс╣Зya, svarga, naraka - all of these are concepts or objects that cannot be directly perceived by our sense organs. The buddhi therefore cannot operate independently here. Sputniks and spacecraft that go beyond our solar system cannot touch the world of adhy─Бtma (pertaining to the Self). It is impossible for them to even know of its existence. In that secret kingdom of adhy─Бtma, the buddhiтАЩs activity is restricted to understanding the statements of the ┼Ы─Бstra. In that kingdom, the buddhi lacks the authority to formulate new theories and impose them. If the buddhi independently surmises the origin and progress of a j─лva and arrives at a conclusion about satya and dharma through conjecture and logic, such a conclusion will be found lacking in testimony, thereby becoming doubtful.

Human buddhi suffers from two natural defects. First - the incompleteness of its raw material. Second - the imperfection of sense perception.
The buddhiтАЩs main functions are the analysis of objects and the estimation of their worth. Analysis requires objective material to analyse. The buddhi cannot create such material through its independent imagination, because it is not in direct contact with the world. The objects for the buddhiтАЩs analyses have to be supplied by the manas or memory. The manas or memory, in turn, fetch the material from sense organs. Thus the sense organs are the messengers that supply information to the buddhi. The faculties of the sense organs are severely limited and are tainted by pleasure and desires. Our eye can see only one side of an object at a given moment. It cannot see all sides of an object simultaneously. Sight can extend only up to a limited distance, say for ten or a hundred metres, and no further. Thus the ability of an eye is one-sided and limited by distance. The abilities of other human sense organs too are similarly one-sided and limited. Therefore any information collected by such instruments is likewise one-sided and limited. Such incomplete information cannot convey the complete nature of an object. Hence the inevitable deficiency in the buddhiтАЩs raw material.

Moreover, the sense organs desire pleasure, thereby subjecting them to the defects of partiality and infatuation while collecting information.

Also, is the buddhi so capable that it can reach the end of any inquiry? No. Just like the body, the buddhi too can become languid or dull. In its partial and piecemeal examination of an object, the buddhi can become lazy, forgetful, and prejudiced, leading to errors in judgement.

The present series is a modern English translation of DVGтАЩs Kendra Sahitya Akademi Award-winning work, Bhagavad-g─лt─Б-t─Бtparya or J─лvana-dharma-yoga. The translators wish to express their thanks to ┼Ъat─Бvadh─Бni R Ganesh for his valuable feedback and to Hari Ravikumar for his astute edits.

[[Ch 17 Yoga of the Discernment of tri-fold ┼Ъraddh─Б (Part 2) Source: prekshaa]]

There are four kinds of activities of the buddhi. The first is analysis which means separating the object of inquiry into its constituent elements. The second is classification which is grouping the various components and properties of the object of inquiry. The third is causality which is identifying the cause-effect relationship as well as the estimation of the amount of a certain substance needed to achieve a specific effect. The fourth kind of activity is deciding whether to perform an activity or not. After considering its current circumstances, the buddhi helps decide whether a specific action will have its intended consequences, how much of the result would be beneficial, as well whether such an action is suitable to perform. Such activities can together be termed value judgement. But all four of these activities are possible only after the buddhi has found the input material for its work. The buddhi can only analyse material made available to it through the sense organs and the manas. The objects of our world are perceivable by our sense organs. Our buddhi can reason and hypothesise only after grasping these sense-objects. But it cannot proceed with objects that are beyond the ken of the sense organs and the manas. The buddhi has no purview over objects that are beyond sensory perception. Many ─Бdhy─Бtmic (spiritual) elements are beyond the senses. Neither can our eyes, ears, and hands nor can the manas touch ─Бdhy─Бtmic principles. The manas might indicate that something is ─Бdhy─Бtmic. The buddhi can accept it as such but it cannot be claimed that the spiritual is under its sway.
The principles of ─Бtm─Б, ─л┼Ыvara, and the j─лvaтАЩs progress or regress cannot be perceived by the sense organs. However, the sense organs are able to experience the effects of such elements. With this experience as the basis, the buddhi can guess and grasp at the nature of the origin of these principles. Spiritual principles are thus accessible to the buddhi but not subordinate to it. Also, spiritual principles become accessible only after the buddhi accepts the ─Бstika ┼Ы─Бstras. It is not that the n─Бstikas lack the faculty of buddhi. But since they lack ┼Ыraddh─Б in the ┼Ы─Бstras, they cannot grasp ─Бdhy─Бtma. If they had been able to grasp it, they would not have been n─Бstika. The ─Бdhy─Бtmic principles can be realised only after acceptance of the ┼Ы─Бstras. There is no external testimony for the existence of the ─Бtm─Б other than the statements of the ┼Ы─Бstra. Can something like the j─лva be pointed at with our fingers and physically be transferred from oneтАЩs arms to another? How can the existence of svarga and naraka be shown in the external world? Where are the records to show transmigration? The pur─Бс╣Зas tell us that Prahl─Бda proved Bhagav─БnтАЩs existence by making him appear in a pillar. Where are those who can make Bhagav─Бn appear in front of us? All these ideas - j─лva, daiva, ─Бtm─Б, brahma, puс╣Зya, p─Бpa, svarga, naraka - are part of the knowledge that has come to us from the Veda. These cannot be established by human buddhi. Thus, even for those who would like to inquire after the Supreme Principle as well as those desirous of leading a principled life, the Veda becomes the fundamental testimony. It is after considering all the defects of human buddhi such as doubt and error that Bhagav─Бn Vy─Бsa declared

tark─Бpratiс╣гс╣нh─Бn─Бt рее
тАЬAs logic has no foundationтАЭ
-Brahma S┼лtra 2.1.11

in his s┼лtras and has clarified that mere human reasoning is insufficient to reach the supreme tattva. ┼Ъr─л ┼Ъaс╣ЕkaraтАЩs commentary on the above is as follows.

puruс╣гotprekс╣г─Б-m─Бtra-nibandhan─Бstark─Б apratiс╣гс╣нhit─Б bhavanti, utprekс╣г─Бy─Б niraс╣Еku┼Ыatv─Бt ред… puruс╣гa-mati-vair┼лpy─Бt ред …kapila-kaс╣Зabhuk-prabhс╣Ыt─лn─Бс╣Г paraspara-vipratipatti-dar┼Ыan─Бt ред tark─Бс╣З─Бm-apratiс╣гс╣нhitatvaс╣Г tarkeс╣Зaiva pratiс╣гс╣нh─Бpyate ред sarva-tark─Б-pratiс╣гс╣нh─Бy─Бс╣Г ca loka-vyavah─Бroccheda-prasaс╣Еgaс╕е ред
“The chain of tarka (reasoning) comes from human conjectures and their extensions. As these conjectures are unchecked, tarka lacks a sound basis. Human buddhi assumes different forms which is why Maharс╣гi Kaс╣З─Бda could not accept Maharс╣гi KapilaтАЩs arguments. Hence, tarka, which is an effect of human buddhi, is incapable of establishing the supreme principle by itself. This can be established by the conventions of tarka itself. If tarka is not established anywhere, even worldly activities become impossible.”

Thus tarka, a product of the buddhi, is necessary in a few areas and inconclusive in others. In such a dilemma, the Veda is our only refuge.
Suprasensory knowledge can be attained only through the Veda.

pratyakс╣гeс╣З─Бnumity─Б v─Б yast┼лp─Бyo na buddhyate ред
enaс╣Г vidanti vedena tasm─Бdvedasya vedat─Б рее
-S─Бyaс╣Зa in Taittir─лya-saс╣Гhit─Б-bh─Бс╣гya-bh┼лmik─Б
тАЬThe suprasensory knowledge that cannot be obtained by an analysis of the perceived world or be inferred from sense perceived objects - the path to the supreme that cannot be gained by tarka alone - can be ascertained by the Veda. Thence is the Veda-hood of the Veda.тАЭ

This is the conclusion. In suprasensory matters, the Veda is the sole authority. In other words, the VedaтАЩs primary authority is in matters pertaining to adhy─Бtma. However, in those areas that are not ─Бdhy─Бtmic and pertain only to this world (secular investigations), the faculty of discernment from human buddhi plays the chief role.
Does it mean that buddhi cannot help those who rely on the Vedas and ┼Ы─Бstras? No. Buddhi is required in all areas. But the buddhi has to restrict itself within the boundary of the Veda. Can a calf not ramble about in a meadow? It can and it should. But it cannot cross the fence. If it crosses the fence, it can fall prey to tigers and leopards. Cattle are free within the limits of the meadow. The buddhi is free within the enclosure of the Veda. Freedom here is relative to what is to be achieved. If human buddhi cannot act unfettered, the meaning of the Veda will not become apparent.

─Бrс╣гaс╣Г dharmopade┼Ыaс╣Г ca veda┼Ы─Бstr─Бvirodhin─Б ред
yastarkeс╣З─Бnusandhatte sa dharmaс╣Г veda netaraс╕е рее
тАЬOnly he who reflects upon the sage advice of dharma with tarka that is unopposed to the Veda will understand dharma; none other.тАЭ
-Manu Smс╣Ыti 12.106

In the commentary to the above words of Manu, Kull┼лkabhaс╣нс╣нa references the following opinion of Kum─Бrila Bhaс╣нс╣нa from his v─Бrttika.

dharme pram─лyam─Бс╣Зe hi vedena karaс╣З─Бtman─Б ред
itikartavyat─Бbh─Бgaс╣Г m─лm─Бс╣Гs─Б p┼лrayiс╣гyati рее
тАЬOnly the Veda is the means to understand dharma. The practical aspects of this understanding are ascertained by the buddhi in the form of m─лm─Бс╣Гs─Б.тАЭ

The conclusion is this: In ─Бdhy─Бtmic matters wherein concepts such as j─лva, ─л┼Ыvara, puс╣Зya, p─Бpa, svarga, naraka, transmigration and mokс╣гa assume importance, ┼Ыraddh─Б in Veda assumes primacy. Human buddhi acts as its helper. In areas where the j─лvaтАЩs welfare is not directly addressed and the worldly arithmetic of profits and losses holds sway, the buddhiтАЩs independent skill assumes priority. In a few areas of our life, therefore, ┼Ыraddh─Б in the ┼Ы─Бstras is the main actor with the buddhi in a supporting role. In other areas, the faculty of discernment from the buddhi has to be strong and capable to help lead a life that is aligned to the Vedas and ┼Ы─Бstras. Thus both ┼Ыraddh─Б and buddhi; and hence the vaidika and worldly ways, can be mutually reconciled.
Let us now go back to Arjuna. From the perspective of ┼Ыraddh─Б in the vedas and ┼Ы─Бstras, Arjuna had to follow his Kс╣гatriya-dharma. The instruction of the Veda-┼Ы─Бstra is as follows - тАЬthe ─Бtm─Б cannot be destroyed; it is eternal; its complete realisation is the greatest attainment of life; for such an attainment, the j─лva has to be rid of its impurities and imperfections; for such a complete purification of the j─лva, performing dharma is imperative; by performance of dharma is implied oneтАЩs own dharmaтАЭ. This is not merely an intellectual theory but one of ┼Ыraddh─Б in the ┼Ы─Бstras. Arjuna getting battle ready is manifesting ┼Ыraddh─Б in the ┼Ы─Бstras.
With his battle-readiness come issues such as the design of army formations, the selection of a commander-in-chief, specific choices of weapons, and decisions of what missile to employ in response to a specific enemy missile. They can be solved only through the ability of oneтАЩs own buddhi.
In short: ┼Ы─Бstra is needed for the knowledge of the Supreme Principle whereas buddhi is for its application in the world.
This is evident even in the activities of common people like us. To celebrate a wedding, for instance, the matching of the bride and groom is a matter for the ┼Ы─Бstra and so is the selection of the auspicious muh┼лrta. Charming the families of the bride or the groom; choosing the right menu for the feasts; the list of invitees; the venue of the wedding - should it be the neighbourhood temple or oneтАЩs own house? Should money be borrowed or should just the wedding groceries be bought on credit? Should the interest rate be 10 percent or 12? - are all problems that are in the domain of worldly buddhi. It is sufficient if there are no lies or cheating in it. Thus both the ┼Ы─Бstra and our buddhi have a place in our lives. Both of these, perhaps, have to coexist everywhere. ┼Ъ─Бstra and the discernment from buddhi do not have to contradict each other. In fact, both are complementary to each other. We had to say so much about this matter now because our society is vacillating without any certainty. What is right - the ┼Ы─Бstra or the mundane way of the world? Should we trust it, or analyse it independently? Veda or science? The contentment of the past? Or the glitz and glamour of today? This is the dilemma that haunts us. If we have to resolve this, we need to clarify to ourselves what the respective domains of veda┼Ы─Бstras and human buddhi are.

[[Ch 17 Yoga of the Discernment of tri-fold ┼Ъraddh─Б (Part 3) Source: prekshaa]]

Arjuna now asks

ye ┼Ы─Бstravidhimutsс╣Ыjya yajante ┼Ыraddh─Бy─Бnvit─Бh ред
teс╣г─Бс╣Г niс╣гс╣нh─Б tu k─Б kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa sattvam─Бho r─Бjastamah рее
BG 17.1
Some people in the world possess ┼Ыraddh─Б, but not in the rules of the ┼Ы─Бstra but in something else imagined by themselves. What happens to them?

We often see such people around us. There are new gurus everyday teaching their newer meditative practices. The Sv─Бm─л with the perfumed beard, the sv─Бm─л who sat for eight days with his feet bound in chains, the sv─Бm─л who showers his instructions like an incessant drizzle, the yakс╣гiс╣З─л sv─Бm─л with his yantras and mantras, the mighty and miraculous sv─Бm─л - are all adept at attracting the world.

The seer of Sringeri, ┼Ъr─л ┼Ъiv─Бbhinava Nс╣Ыsiс╣Гhabh─Бrat─л prayed thus:

k─Б┼Ы─Бyavastreс╣Зa kar─Бttadaс╣Зс╕Нa-
kamaс╣Зс╕Нalubhy─Бс╣Г japam─Бlay─Б ca
vibhr─Бmayantaс╣Г gс╣Ыhiс╣З─Бс╣Г kadambaс╣Г
m─Бс╣Г p─Бhi pс╣Ыthv─лdharar─Бjaputri !
“O Devi P─Бrvat─л! What am I doing? Decked in saffron garments, holding a kamaс╣Зс╕Нalu in my hands, along with a japa-m─Бl─Б, and the staff of saс╣Гny─Бsa - I delude the householders. It is you who should protect such a person”.

Those words that came from him as an expression of ego-effacement are literally true in the case of many others who, unfortunately, are gaining fame by proclaiming themselves as the redeemers of the world. At such a time, it is our duty to be alert. ┼Ъraddh─Б has a hierarchy of worthy and unworthy recipients. In worthy recipients, ┼Ыraddh─Б elevates the j─лva while it causes the j─лvaтАЩs downfall when invested in the unworthy.

┼Ыraddh─БmayoтАЩyaс╣Г puruс╣гaс╕е ред yo yacchraddhaс╕е sa eva saс╕е рее
BG 17.3
A man is the ┼Ыraddh─Б he keeps.

A manтАЩs progress is influenced by the object he values most and believes to be of utmost importance. A manтАЩs final state depends on whatever he believes in. Every man is defined by the ┼Ыraddh─Б he professes. Therefore there must be intellectual caution even in the object of his ┼Ыraddh─Б.
┼Ъraddh─Б is of three types - s─Бttvika, r─Бjasa, and t─Бmasa. Thus, those who worship the devat─Бs are s─Бttvika; those worshipping groups of yakс╣гas and rakс╣гas are said to be r─Бjasa while those propitiating the bh┼лtas and pretas are deemed t─Бmasa. Those performing extreme rituals, horrific balis, and intemperate penances are all t─Бmasa, not s─Бttvika. Such acts are ─Бsur─л, impelled by desire, fuelled by ego, and result in p─Бpa.
Just as in worship, there are differences even in food and behaviour. The well-being of the body and the mind is according to the food consumed.

rasy─Бс╕е snigdh─Бс╕е sthir─Б hс╣Ыdy─Б ─Бh─Бr─Бс╕е s─Бttvikapriy─Бс╕е рее
BG 17.8
Foods that are delicious, soft, can be easily absorbed into the blood and muscles, and give strength to the heart are s─Бttvika.

If one is desirous of longevity, activity, strength, pleasure and happiness, then one must partake of s─Бttvika foods.

This ideal of food must not be forgotten by the students of the G─лt─Б. Praising the greatness of the s─Бttvika ideal while gorging on t─Бmasa food is meaningless. The quality, strength and nature of man are all influenced by what he eats. Whatever be the disease, right food is the first medicine.

annaс╣Г hi bh┼лt─Бn─Бс╣Г jyeс╣гс╣нham ред
tasm─Бt sarvauс╣гadhamucyate ред
-Taittir─лyopaniс╣гad 2.2.1

Even modern doctors hold that the traditional food habits of our people are best. Rice obtained from threshing paddy at home, flour from grinding stones, a substance (now rarely found!) known as ghee, gingelly oil from wooden oil presses - are all s─Бttvika foods. D─Бl/huс╕╖i made of pulses, s─Бru/rasam, obbaс╣нс╣нu/p┼лraс╣З poс╕╖i, and salads are considered healthy. Doctors say that these old style traditional food preparations constitute a тАШbalanced diet.тАЩ These have unfortunately been replaced by biscuits, ice creams, candies and other foods with unpronounceable names in our ultra-modern age. Preparing foods of yore requires patience in our minds, strength in our arms, and respect towards cooking as an important duty. How can we expect that grand old ladyтАЩs qualities in this era of superficially shiny and dainty appearances?

If one wants anxiety, flaring tempers, and fatigue, one can consume sour, salty, pungent, hot and hard foods.
Stale, spoiled, and dry items, and remnants of food eaten by another are the foods of t─Бmasas.

There are three kinds in yaj├▒a and d─Бna as well.

aphal─Б-k─Бс╣Еkс╣гibhir-yaj├▒o vidhidс╣Ыс╣гс╣нo ya ijyate ред
yaс╣гс╣нavyam-eveti manaс╕е sam─Бdh─Бya sa s─Бttvikaс╕е редред
BG 17.11
A yaj├▒a carried out with no expectation of reward, a firm faith that performing the rituals prescribed in the ┼Ы─Бstra is an obligatory duty, and a calm mind are deemed to be of s─Бttvika-┼Ыraddh─Б.

The yaj├▒a performed with the expectation of a reward, or for oneтАЩs own vanity or to get praise from the world is considered r─Бjasa.
That activity bereft of mantras or dakс╣гiс╣З─Б (remuneration offered to the officiators in a yaj├▒a) or purity, not following a prescribed set of rules, and is wantonly done is called t─Бmasa.

Tapas (penance) also is of three kinds.

anudvegakaram v─Бkyaс╣Г satyam priyahitaс╣Г ca yat
sv─Бdhy─Бy─Бbhyasanaс╣Г caiva v─Бс╣Еmayaс╣Г tapa ucyate
BG 17.15
Restraining oneself in oneтАЩs mental, verbal and bodily activities, thereby not causing any anxiety, and keeping oneтАЩs mind clear is tapas that is s─Бttvika.

Tapas performed with the objectives of felicitation, honour, or reverence from others is r─Бjasa.
The activity performed with obstinacy and an intent to harm others is t─Бmasa. ─Аsur─л activity is such.

D─Бna (charity) too is of three types.

d─Бtavyam-iti yad-d─Бnaс╣Г d─лyateтАЩnupak─Бriс╣Зe ред
de┼Ыe k─Бle ca p─Бtre ca tadd─Бnaс╣Г s─Бttvikaс╣Г smс╣Ыtam рее
BG 17.20
The d─Бna that is made to a person incapable of returning the favour after ascertaining his circumstances and his worthiness and done as an obligatory duty is termed s─Бttvika.

The d─Бnas given with the expectation of a favour in return or carelessly or without regard for who is receiving the d─Бna are deemed r─Бjasa and t─Бmasa.

After expounding upon how the three-fold ┼Ыraddh─Б is expressed with regard to the recipients and methods of worship and yaj├▒a, d─Бna and tapas with relevant illustrations, Bhagav─Бn now shows us the path of worship of the supreme j├▒─Бn─л who is beyond the three guс╣Зas.

Om tatsaditi nirde┼Ыo brahmaс╣Зas-trividhaс╕е smс╣Ыtaс╕е ред
br─Бhmaс╣Зas-tena ved─Б┼Ыca yaj├▒─Б┼Ыca vihit─Бс╕е pur─Б рее
BG 17.23
Designating the Supreme Brahma through the three symbols is an ancient practice. 1. Om 2. Tat. 3. Sat - are those three sound symbols. Through that designation by Brahma were ordained - at the time of creation - br─Бhmaс╣Зas (those who instruct Brahmavidy─Б), the Vedas (the repositories of Brahmavidy─Б), and the yaj├▒as (the acts that worship Brahma).

The above means that all those words, treatises, and activities that are for the worship of Brahma - whatever is worthy of worship and is holy - all of that is indicated by тАЬOm tat satтАЭ. Whatever is directed by Brahma and whatever is offered to Brahma - all of it is covered under тАЬOm tat satтАЭ.

[[Ch 17 Yoga of the Discernment of tri-fold ┼Ъraddh─Б (Part 4) Source: prekshaa]]

Let us now reflect a little upon its meaning.

1.Om

tasm─Бdomityud─Бhс╣Ыtya yaj├▒ad─Бnatapaс╕еkriy─Бс╕е ред
pravartante vidh─Бnokt─Бс╕е satatam brahmav─Бdin─Бm рее
BG 17.24
“The votaries of Brahma perform yaj├▒a, d─Бna and tapas after uttering Om”.

We have discussed the meaning of Om in the eighth chapter under “Omityek─Бkс╣гaraс╣Г Brahma.” Om has three constituent units of a + u + m. When considered separately, they can be construed as representing either the trinity of Brahma-Viс╣гс╣Зu-Mahe┼Ыvara or the triad of sattva-r─Бjas-t─Бmas or the waking-dream-sleep states or earth-atmosphere-sky or svarga-martya-p─Бt─Бla or energy-water-food or masculine-feminine-neuter genders or day-night-twilight, thereby bringing to mind all the aspects and qualities of the universe organised into triads. With Om - that is the culmination of the three units - we can not only bring the world to mind but also that which is beyond the world. Thus Om is a complete and all-encompassing symbol of the worldly and supra-worldly, the expressed and unexpressed energies, as well as the visible and invisible aspects of truth.

2. Tat

tadity-anabhisandh─Бya phalaс╣Г yaj├▒a-tapaс╕е-kriy─Бс╕е ред
d─Бna-kriy─Б┼Ыca vividh─Бс╕е kriyante mokс╣гa-k─Бс╣Еkс╣гibhiс╕е рее
BG 17.25
“After uttering the syllable tat, those desirous of mokс╣гa perform yaj├▒a, d─Бna and tapas without wanting anything else.”

Tat refers to “that” or “it” in English. We use “it” and “that” to refer to something familiar. For example - “That man” or “at that time”. Though Brahma is well-known, it is not directly perceived. Hence, the use of the word tat is appropriate here. There is yet another interesting reason. Any object that has no established name or whose nature is unexplainable by human language is also referred to by “that”. In traditional families, a wife did not address her husband by name, choosing instead to address him by words such as avaru. The husband too would not call his wife by name and would use the words - “she” or “her”. Similarly, it is an established tradition that the knowers of Brahma use the word tat to refer to Brahma.
Tattva can be resolved as tat+tva - “a thing being itself.” The state of an object devoid of all its external attributes like its form or colours, its activities - as just itself - unrelated to anything other than itself, without any other adjuncts is tat+tva. Brahma is such.

3. Sat

sadbh─Бve s─Бdhubh─Бve ca sat+ityetat prayujyate
pra┼Ыaste karmaс╣Зi tath─Б sat+┼Ыabdaс╕е p─Бrtha yujyateрз╖рз╖
yaj├▒e tapasi d─Бne ca sthitiс╕е sat+iti cocyate.
karma caiva tadarth─лyaс╣Гsat+ityev─Бbhidh─лyateрз╖
BG 17.26,27

The word sat has two meanings.

  1. Sat is that something that has eternal existence. Sat is existence - in one state for all time. That indeed is the truth. Supreme Brahma is the supreme truth - satyasya satyam - the truth of the truth.
  2. Whatever is fit or good is also denoted by sat. For example, sat+jana, sat+karma etc.,. This second meaning comes from the first. It is the truth that is good. Untruth cannot be good. Only whatever is eternal is good; not transient objects. Param─Бtm─Б is the truth, and eternal. Hence any action or object or event related to him is good and is the most excellent. Whatever takes us towards the truth, whatever gets us divine grace is sat. That is the absolute good. All auspiciousness and good come to us from that truth. Brahma is the repository of all auspiciousness, it is the source of all that is good. Therefore, the worship of Brahma is sat+karma.

The word sat thus indicates eternal existence as well as something that is good and right. Any worthy endeavour deserves the prefix sat as well. Therefore all actions of yajna, d─Бna and tapas offered to Bhagav─Бn befit the prefix sat.
It is instructive to examine the similarities between the Saс╣Гskс╣Ыta word sat and the Kannada word uс╕╗. In Kannada, the word uс╕╗ refers to something тАЬthat isтАЭ, from which is derived the word uс╣Зс╣нu (present). The Kannada word for good - oс╕╗с╕╗eyadu - also comes from the root uс╕╗. Whatever is related to or can take us closer to the ever present (uс╣Зс╣нu), is also good (oс╕╗, oс╕╗с╕╗eyadu).

Thus the word “Om tat sat” is worthy of reverence from all perspectives. It designates the entire universe, all the devat─Бs, all the j─лvas, and in fact everything! Therefore these three words are used to reference any devat─Б or dharma. The meaning of this word-triad declares that it is a happy obligation for anyone devoted to truth to have ┼Ыraddh─Б in it. ┼Ъraddh─Б in such a great mantra is life-redeeming.
Placing ┼Ыraddh─Б in any one object ensures an easier path towards progress. Whatever is done without ┼Ыraddh─Б is waste, for without it, there is neither worldly nor other worldly achievement.

Summary

The concluding chapter of the G─лt─Б - a veritable lamp showing us the path to a fulfilling life - gives great courage and fortitude to people who are immersed in worldly karma. Here, Bhagav─Бn explains the necessity of karma that is devoid of desire for results and is performed only as a service to ─кsvara. He propounds the principle that it is not the renouncing of karma that elevates the j─лva, but giving up the results of karma. Karma provides the j─лva an opportunity to get rid of its selfishness. The j─лva is blessed with many innate capabilities and qualities. The practice of using these natural abilities for the benefit of the world increases sattva in the j─лva. Through that, it also makes life meaningful.

The natural differences that are present in the composition of the universe itself are the basis for the system of varс╣Зa. The objective of this system is to benefit society from the constructive aspects of the nature of each person. The two goals of dh─Бrmic karma are тАФ the prosperity of the individual j─лva and the sustenance of the world. Following oneтАЩs own svadharma that is in accordance with oneтАЩs nature is the way to elevate oneself. The instruction of svadharma that is the crown-jewel of the G─лt─Б-┼Ы─Бstra is especially necessary in our times - when incompetence and complexity are prevalent in all fields of work. This teaching is indeed most suitable to be practised by all.

Bhagav─Бn enumerates the steps on the ladder of the j─лvaтАЩs progress such as being immersed in oneтАЩs own duties, fortitude (dhс╣Ыti), self-control (saс╣Гyama), selflessness (nirahaс╣Еk─Бra), and non-covetousness (aparigraha). He delineates the qualities of a Brahma-realised-person such as equanimity and devotion only towards Parabrahma. Further, he declares there is no opposition between the performance of karma and dharma and the knowledge of the highest truth. He explains that it is futile to oppose karma that is impelled by prakс╣Ыti. As part of this instruction is an exposition of the mechanism of the machinery of the universe which is worthy of constant contemplation.
Karma should be performed before the dawn of Brahma-knowledge, and after that as well. While karma is an instrument when a man is a seeker of knowledge, it becomes his second nature once the knowledge is attained. Being free of infatuation and hatred (r─Бga and dveс╣гa), and keeping the mind composed and clear are all duties for a seeker, and are attainable only with effort. For a j├▒─Бni, however, freedom from infatuation and a clear mind are natural and effortless, joyful and playful. The view of a seeker is admixed with ego; but that of the j├▒─Бni is with a view that everything is Brahma, and is for the happiness and well-being of all.

Section 19 /Chapter 18 /Mokс╣гa-saс╣Гny─Бsa-yoga /Tadeka-┼Ыaraс╣Зat─Б-yoga

(The yoga of single-pointed surrender)

This is the last chapter of the G─лt─Б. Here, Sv─Бm─л summarises the instructions from all the previous chapters, and in conclusion teaches an great method that can be adopted by one and all. In one word, it is тАЬtad-eka-┼Ыaraс╣Зat─БтАЭ тАФ taking refuge in him alone.
The following topics are dealt with in this chapter :

  1. The difference between saс╣Гny─Бsa and ty─Бga 2. The necessity of karma 3. The part of the divine in karma 4. Kartс╣Ыtva is characteristic of j─лva. 5. The following triads similar to the guс╣Зa-triad -
    1. J├▒─Бna-triad
    2. Karma-triad
    3. Kartс╣Ы-triad
    4. Buddhi-triad
    5. Dhс╣Ыti-triad
    6. Sukha-triad 6. Mutual dependence among men тАФ the system of varс╣Зa that facilitates it. 7. The greatness of svadharma 8. Karma as a service to Bhagav─Бn 9. The inevitability of war for Arjuna 10. The nature of the M─Бy─Б of ─к┼Ыvara 11. Seeking refuge from ─к┼Ыvara alone 12. The results obtained by studying the G─лt─Б.

There is a warning for us all in the way this chapter begins. In the previous chapters, Arjuna had said a few times that his doubts were cleared and that he was satisfied.

mohoтАЩyaс╣Г vigato mama рее
BG 11.1
id─Бn─лm asmi saс╣Гvс╣Ыttaс╕е рее
BG 11.51

In spite of that, his doubts were not ending. Even in this last chapter, he asks тАФ

saс╣Гny─Бsasya tattvamicch─Бmi vedituс╣Г ty─Бgasya ca рее
BG 18.1
What is the principle of saс╣Гny─Бsa? What is the principle of ty─Бga?

If Arjuna, who thought he was satisfied with Bhagav─БnтАЩs instruction was riddled thus again and again with new doubts, what to say of us, ordinary mortals? We might feel for a moment that we have understood everything and there are no doubts remaining. That is a deluding satisfaction; there will be a new doubt in the very next moment; we forget what was said earlier, or some aspect might not be clear to our minds. In this way, there will be uncertainty and doubt at every step. This topic is deep and very complex; our belief will not become firm unless each and every aspect is clearly understood. To get that clarity, it is not enough to listen to a lecture once or read the text twice. It should be repeated again and again in the mind. The text should be recalled again and again (The word used in the original is ─Бloс╕Нan├и). The mind should be stirred with the meaning of the text and the text should be deeply researched with the mind. Only if the text is examined and deliberated upon again and again in this way can this topic be understood, and certainly not just by superficially familiarising oneself with the letters and the verses.

The question asked now by Arjuna had already been answered many times. It was the main subject of the fifth chapter.

saс╣Гny─Бsaс╕е karmayoga┼Ыca niс╕е┼Ыreyasa-kar─Бv-ubhau ред
с╣нayostu karma-saс╣Гny─Бs─Бt karma-yogo vi┼Ыiс╣гyate рее
BG 5.2
тАЬBoth karma-saс╣Гny─Бsa and karma-yoga can help in attaining mokс╣гa. Among those two, karma-yoga is better than karma-saс╣Гny─Бsa.

Sv─Бmi makes it clearer now тАФ

k─Бmy─Бn─Бс╣Г karmaс╣З─Бс╣Г ny─Бsaс╣Г saс╣Гny─Бsaс╣Г kavayo viduс╕е ред
sarva-karma-phala-ty─Бgaс╣Г pr─Бhus-ty─Бgaс╣Г vicakс╣гaс╣З─Бс╕е рее
BG 18.2
тАЬSaс╣Гny─Бsa is renunciation of karmas motivated by desire. Ty─Бga is giving up all results of karma.тАЭ

Thus, Bhagav─Бn shows a subtle difference between saс╣Гny─Бsa and ty─Бga. These two words are often used interchangeably. Speaking at a gross level, they both do mean the same; however, there is a subtle difference between them, which Sv─Бm─л explains.

We have seen earlier that karma is of many kinds. There are three main types:

  1. Laukika karma : This is of the form of oneтАЩs profession, interaction with others, friendship and other relationships, neighbourly actions, duties towards oneтАЩs country and so on. It is a training to the j─лva on oneтАЩs obligations to society. 2. Vaidika nitya-karma: This is karma of the form of worshipping the divine, depending on oneтАЩs varс╣Зa and ─Б┼Ыrama, on oneтАЩs religion and tradition. The main objective of these karmas is training to the j─лva тАФ introspection and teaching the manas. 3. Vaidika k─Бmya-karma: This is also worship of the divine. However, it has a selfish objective, lower than that of saс╣Гsk─Бra to the j─лva. Various vratas, d─лkс╣гas and p┼лjas performed to obtain health, wealth, children and status belong to this category. Yaj├▒as like agniс╣гс╣нoma and a┼Ыvamedha are also k─Бmya-karmas.

Saс╣Гny─Бsa is giving up k─Бmya-karmas. A Saс╣Гny─Бsindoes not have to perform varalaksm─л-vrata, n─Бga-pratiс╣гс╣нha or circumambulate the a┼Ыvattha tree. A saс╣Гny─Бsin need not perform any karma with a view of worldly benefit. However, he has to perform nitya-karmas such as japa and sn─Бna.

k─Бmy─Бn─Бс╣Г karmaс╣З─Бс╣Г ny─Бsam рее
BG 18.2

In this context, тАЬny─БsaтАЭ means giving up. To etymologically derive тАЬsaс╣Гny─БsaтАЭ, the word тАЬny─БsaтАЭ is useful.

What, then, is ty─Бga?

sarva-karma-phala-tyagaс╣Г pr─Бhus-ty─Бgam рее
BG 18.2
Renunciation of the results of all karmas is ty─Бga.

The concept here is not giving up karma, but giving up the results of karma. A saс╣Гny─Бsin gives up only k─Бmya-karmas. A tattvaj├▒a gives up the results of all his karmas. Karma is inevitable for all of us who are still embodied. Even a j├▒─Бni performs laukika-karmas. Why is that? He performs those karmas without any desire тАФ for his own conditioning, for the love of the Bhagav─Бn and to help the world. A ty─Бg─л тАФ whether he wears ochre robes signifying saс╣Гny─Бsa or not тАФ gives up the results of all karmas for the love of Param─Бtm─Б.

[[Ch 18 Yoga of Single-pointed Surrender (Part 2) Source: prekshaa]]

A gс╣Ыhastha performs karmas out of desire тАФ for the wellbeing of his wife and children and for the sake of his friends and relatives. Worldly life becomes possible only if householders have those desires. His dharma is to take care of his family. Therefore, he performs certain karmas to support his dharma. If he thinks that he is performing all the karmas as itтАЩs dharma and not for his own pleasure and satiation, it is as good as ty─Бga. This feeling should be within him. In spiritual matters, oneтАЩs own conscience is the judge, it need not be explained to others. The ┼Ы─Бstras say that the works of puс╣Зya should not be advertised to the world. Those who trumpet their works of puс╣Зya are called тАЬdharma-dhvajaтАЭs by Manu. D─Бna and dharma should be done in secret. Even Christians follow the same precept. If this is the case of ordinary works of puс╣Зya, what to speak of the ─Бtm─Б тАФ does it behove of anyone to proclaim that he is a j├▒─Бni and a ty─Бgi?

A ty─Бgi performs all his prescribed karmas. His mind is not attached to the good or bad results of any of them. One who thinks тАЬAll karma is worship of the divine; good or bad that results from it does not belong to me. The karma that I performed is for the love of Bhagav─Бn; May he do as he pleasesтАЭ is a ty─Бgi. His love for Bhagav─Бn makes him do his karmas.

The question of karma appears in the G─лt─Б again and again. Even in this eighteenth chapter, a large part deals with karma. Therefore, it is established that the G─лtopade┼Ыa is for ordinary saс╣Гs─Бris like us. Karma is for saс╣Гs─Бris. Saс╣Гs─Бra itself is karma.
Our Trimat─Бc─Бryas were yatis тАФ ascetics тАФ they had accepted saс╣Гny─Бsa. Mokс╣гa was their immediate goal. Therefore, the G─лt─Б became a mokс╣гa-┼Ы─Бstra for them. Though it cannot be said that gс╣Ыhastha-dharma was not in their purview, it was a puruс╣г─Бrtha that was far from and beneath mokс╣гa. Theirs was the way of nivс╣Ыtti тАФ the way where they tried to unshackle themselves from the fetters of karma. Ours is the way of pravс╣Ыtti тАФ where we compulsorily have to perform karma. Dharma-karma is near to us; mokс╣гa is far off. Therefore, the important instruction for us in the G─лt─Б is the instruction of karma. In this last chapter, Bhagav─Бn, for a large part, expounds the principle of karma. This gives courage and encouragement to people like us. If the nature of karma is understood with right judgement and performed as it should be, mokс╣гa will come to us when it has to. We do not have to think urgently about mokс╣гa now.

Any karma is fraught with faults. Therefore, some say that all karma should be given up.

ty─Бjyaс╣Г doс╣гavad-ityeke рее
BG 18.3

Some others say that the three-fold karmas such as yaj├▒a, d─Бna and tapas should not be given up at any cost. Bhagav─Бn also opines that yaj├▒a, d─Бna and tapas should never be given up and compulsorily performed.

yajna-d─Бna-tapaс╕е-karma na ty─Бjyaс╣Г k─Бryam-eva tat рее
BG 18.5

These are nitya-karmas that are prescribed according to oneтАЩs circumstances. They may be laukika-karmas or vaidika-karmas. They are not performed out of desire for their fruit, and train the j─лva. They are prescribed for everyone.
What is the reason for such an abundance of dialectic literature about the relationship between karma and j├▒─Бna, and that between karma and mokс╣гa in our ┼Ы─Бstras? As far as I know, this question is not so pervasive in the texts of other religions like Islam and Christianity. Whereas, in Hinduism, the discussion about karma and akarma is an integral part of ─Аtma┼Ы─Бstra, and has grown to be equally important. In his works, ┼Ъr─л ┼Ъankar─Бc─Бrya has devoted much space to deliberation about karma. This is because he had to answer the p┼лrvam─лm─Бс╣Гsakas. The p┼лrvam─лm─Бс╣Гsakas argued that there is no j├▒─Бna without karma, and that karma itself is j├▒─Бna. ┼Ъaс╣Еkar─Бc─БryaтАЩs bh─Бс╣гyas were their counterargument. Thus, this ┼Ы─Бstra grew abundantly.
However, it appears that this dispute has been there for a very long time. The ─к┼Ы─Бv─Бsya-upaniс╣гad says the following:

saс╣Гbh┼лtiс╣Г ca vin─Б┼Ыaс╣Г ca yastadveda ubhayagс╣Г saha ред
vin─Б┼Ыena mс╣Ыtyuс╣Г t─лrtv─Б saс╣Гbh┼лty─БтАЩmс╣Ыtam-a┼Ыnute рее
─к┼Ы─Бv─Бsya-upaniс╣гad 10
vidy─Бс╣Г ca avidy─Бс╣Г ca yastad-veda ubhayagс╣Г saha ред
avidyay─Б mс╣Ыtyuс╣Г t─лrtv─Б vidyay─БтАЩmс╣Ыtam-a┼Ыnute рее
─к┼Ы─Бv─Бsya-upaniс╣гad 11

The same concept is explained in the Kaс╣нhopaniс╣гad as well. Why has dialectical literature about karma grown so much? We have to ponder carefully about this.
Karma is worldly action тАФ take something from the world and give something back to it. This is our daily life. There is no karma in our life that is not of the form of giving or taking. Even while breathing we take in air and bestow it back upon the world. All the works done in the world are thus in the form of accepting and remitting, and either further oneтАЩs selfishness or erode it. Karmas done for our own pleasure, our own happiness, our own benefit, our own prosperity and prestige nurture selfishness. When those objects fructify, our selfishness is encouraged. As selfishness increases, we take more and more from the world and give back less and less. Thus, our debt to the world increases and the thread of saс╣Гs─Бra lengthens. As worldly transactions with selfish motives increase, the possibility of p─Бpa increases. As the fruits of puс╣Зya multiply, the attraction towards p─Бpa also increases. This is the danger in karma. This is present even in satkarma, because selfish desires are at the heart of our devotion to the divine, like opium that is dissolved in p─Бyasam. What is the story of Hiranyaka┼Ыipu, R─Бvaс╣Зa, B─Бс╣З─Бsura, Bhasm─Бsura and otherr─Бkс╣гasas? It is a story of descending to the world of p─Бpa through the doors of puс╣Зya. They performed rigorous penances and worshipped Brahma, Viс╣гс╣Зu and ┼Ъiva. The boons they acquired as a result of their puс╣Зya instigated them to perform p─Бpa. Tamasic devotion resulted in delusion and infatuation, and therefore they attained naraka.

Therefore, some people argue that they do not want to have anything to do with karma.

ty─Бjyaс╣Г doс╣гavad-ityeke рее
BG 18.3

So, then, is there no fault at all if we give up karma entirely? That is not true. This is because by giving up karma entirely, the j─лva loses opportunities to eradicate its selfishness. Selfishness is attached to the j─лva тАФ just like some people have cold all the time. If selfishness has to wear away, constant interaction with the world is necessary. Friction with the world loosens the strings of the heart and strengthens the manas as well. The three kinds of afflictions тАФ adhibhautika, adhidaivika and adhyatmika тАФ melt the j─лva. The great poet Bhartrhari explains the same to us in these charming words тАФ

m─Бtarmedini t─Бta m─Бruta sakhe tejaс╕е subandho jala ред
bhr─Бtar-vyoma nibaddha eva bhavat─Бm antyaс╕е praс╣З─Бm─Б├▒jaliс╕е рее
yuс╣гmat-saс╣Еga-va┼Ыopaj─Бta-sukс╣Ыta-sph─Бra-sphuran-nirmala-
j├▒─Бn─Бp─Бsta-samasta-moha-mahim─Б l─лye para-brahmaс╣Зi рее
Vair─Бgya-┼Ыataka 100

This is the great benefit of karma. When Bhartс╣Ыhari realized that his end was near, he folded his palms and beseeched thus тАЬO Mother Earth, Father Wind, Friend Sun, dear Water, brother Sky, here is my last obeisance to you. (I have benefitted from you). My selfishness and delusion are removed because of my purifying contact with you. As a result, I have obtained the pure, vast and limpid light of understanding of the self. Because of that, I am now able to become one with Param─Бtm─Б.
For a j├▒─Бni, saс╣Гs─Бra is akin to tapas. The house is a smithery. Just as a smith heats metal and makes it pliable, the heat of saс╣Гs─Бra softens human nature. Just as a smith would pat and hit the iron when it is hot, the blows delivered by the world correct human nature and temper it, thus making it useful to the world.
A vacana by Basavaс╣Зс╣Зa goes thus тАФ

martyalokavembudu kart─Бrana kammaс╣нavayyaред Illi salluvavaru alliy┼л salluvarayy─Бред
(This world is a smithery of the creator. Those who thrive here will thrive there also).

Heat from a kiln and blows of a hammer make a coin of a piece of metal. A good coin is valuable both in this world and the other. The pressures of oneтАЩs spouses and children, run-ins with relatives, skirmishes with shopkeepers, brawls at banks, wrangles at the workplace тАФ all these activities squeeze the tight knots of the j─лva and soften them; they straighten its crookedness and firm up the feeble parts; they dilute its self-centeredness; and they expand the boundary of affection and attachment. Thus, karma can subdue selfishness. For this reason,

Na ty─Бjyam-iti c─Бpare рее
BG 18.3

Should we perform karma, or give it up? Should we have a nose, or should we cut it off? If there is a nose, there might be the possibility of catching a cold also. However, there is no breath without the nose! Performing karma encourages selfishness. But if it is not performed, it does not mean that the existing selfishness goes away. Both of these are dangerous. The tactic here is to prevent selfishness that can enter karma. That is the principle.

yaj├▒a-d─Бna-tapaс╕е-karma na ty─Бjyaс╣Г k─Бryam-eva tat рее
BG 18. 5

Yaj├▒a is worshipping the divine. D─Бna is making the world happy. Tapas is self-control. Daiva, the world and the j─лva тАФ these three are an integral part of human life. Service to them is a must тАФ they should never ever be given up. Yaj├▒a, d─Бna and tapas are the means of purification for an intelligent person. When these karmas are performed with full knowledge of their meaning and with viveka, they can purge the faults of selfishness and purify the j─лva.
