[[Ch 18 Yoga of Single-pointed Surrender (Part 3) Source: prekshaa]]

Managing the family is a vrata. Marriage is a dharmic ritual. The transactions with the world that is done for these are opportunities for performing dharma. Household chores that are performed with this feeling are akin to tapas. It can also be thought of asyaj├▒a. We have already seen that the Vedas extol the entire life and all the worldly transactions of a j├▒─Бni as a great yaj├▒a.

tasyaivaс╣Г viduс╣гo yaj├▒asy─Бtm─Б yajam─Бnaс╕е ред
Mah─Бn─Бr─Бyaс╣Зa-upaniс╣гad 80

and so on.

et─Бnyapi tu karm─Бс╣Зi saс╣Еgaс╣Г tyaktv─Б phal─Бni ca ред
kartavy─Бn─лti me p─Бrtha ni┼Ыcitaс╣Г matam-uttamam рее
BG 18.6
тАЬThe best way is to perform yaj├▒a, d─Бna and tapas as they are oneтАЩs duties. However, there is a rule : They should not be tainted by ego and there should not be any desire for the resultтАЭ.

In the word тАЬkartavy─БniтАЭ, we can see that the suffix тАЬtavyatтАЭ is used. It means that it has to be compulsorily performed. The only condition is that the feeling тАЬI am doing it, I will enjoy the results of itтАЭ should not be there. The skill that has to be present in karma-yoga is the resigning of ego and any attachment to the rewards of an action. That is the desired skill. That itself is тАФ

yogaс╕е karmasu kau┼Ыalam рее
BG 2-50

┼Ъraddh─Б and enthusiasm while performing an action; indifference and disregard for its fruit.
As in all other fields in the worldly realm, karma is also affected by sattva, rajas and tamas.

niyatasya tu saс╣Гny─Бsaс╕е karmaс╣Зo nopa-padyate рее
BG 18.7

No one should ever stop performing niyata-karmas. This applies not only to karmas such as sandhy─Бvandana that are ascribed based on oneтАЩs varс╣Зa and ─Б┼Ыrama, but also to worldly duties such as oneтАЩs profession and socially beneficial activities. The karma of svadharma is compulsory for everyone, always. If that is given up as mere ritual, or as unimportant, it is tamasic renunciation.

moh─Бttasya parity─Бgaс╕е t─Бmasaс╕е parik─лrtitaс╕е ред
BG 18.7

Of late, we are becoming more and more abstemious towards satkarmas such as visiting temples, traveling on pilgrimages, etc. It is tamasic; and it is a work of delusion and stupidity.
Not just content with that, we give up rituals such as purificatory baths, concerned about weariness and fatigue. This is rajasic renunciation. We can see that often in our elites.

duс╕еkham-ityeva yat-karma k─Бya-kle┼Ыa-bhay─Бt tyajet рее
BG 18.8

A s─Бс╣гс╣н─Бс╣Еga-namask─Бra is tiring. If there is devotion within, can we not just fold our palms and express it? Why expend even that effort? IsnтАЩt a hand-signal enough? Why a hand-signal? IsnтАЩt a grin enough ? IsnтАЩt curling the lips enough? Or even raising oneтАЩs eyebrows is enough? Bhagav─Бn is omniscient, he knows everything about us. Why does he need our namask─Бras and hand-signs? Such is the mindset of our times. Seize svarga as easily as possible. As they say in Telugu, тАЬs┼лkс╣гmaс╣Гlo mokс╣гamтАЭ - earn mokс╣гa with as little effort as possible.

Bhagav─Бn, it appears, does not agree to this!

k─Бryam-ityeva yat-karma niyataс╣Г kriyateтАЩrjuna ред
saс╣Гgaс╣Г tyaktv─Б phalaс╣Г caiva sa ty─Бgaс╕е s─Бttviko mataс╕е рее
BG 18.9
Na dveс╣гс╣нy-aku┼Ыalaс╣Г karma ku┼Ыale n─Бnuс╣гajjate ред
ty─Бg─л sattva-sam─Бviс╣гс╣нo medh─Бv─л chinna-saс╣Г┼Ыayaс╕е рее
BG 18.10
тАЬS─Бttvic renunciation is that, where oneтАЩs ego and the desire for reward are given up while performing duties that are necessary to be performed because they are oneтАЩs prescribed karma, or circumstances demand that they be performed. Such a s─Бttvic renunciate does not hate the karma prescribed to him because it is difficult or disgusting, nor does he get attached to it because it is pleasing. He neither wanes on Ek─Бda┼Ыi nor waxes on Dv─Бda┼Ыi. He does not fear duties at a hospital, or jump with joy at the duties at a drama company. He neither runs away from the duty of carrying a corpse nor does he stand at the front of a wedding procession. He is equanimous towards auspicious and inauspicious тАФ that is, he is far from the consequences of dualities, and is impartial. He is free of all doubts and is established in objectivity.

Our belief that the G─лt─Б is a book of dharmic life will be firmly established if we see the importance given to karma performed with s─Бttvic renunciation in this chapter and the previous chapters. Karma is inevitable to some extent for all human beings.

с╣Зa hi dehabhс╣Ыt─Б ┼Ыakyaс╣Г tyaktuс╣Г karm─Бс╣Зy-a┼Ыeс╣гataс╕е рее
BG 18.11

Karma is indeed inevitable for everyone. Then how can we escape the possibility of p─Бpa while performing it? By renouncing only the fruit of the karma. Let us finish doing what we have to do. We are not concerned with its use. We are mere servants following instructions on how to perform actions. We only do what we are told. In the satra of Bhagav─Бn, there is a feast being served everyday. If the supervisor says тАЬHey you, clean the dirty platesтАЭ, it is not our place to ask тАЬHow many people ate?тАЭ.

Let us apply this instruction to the political duties of our age. Suppose it is election day. It is t─Бmasic ty─Бga to think that it is a holiday and spend the day sleeping or playing cards and completely forget about the election. It is r─Бjasic ty─Бga to think тАЬWho will go that far in the sun and suffer in the queueтАЭ and not go to the election and give up oneтАЩs duty out of fear of exertion. S─Бttvic ty─Бga is to go to the election booth, choose a candidate who is agreeable to oneтАЩs conscience and vote for him and not worry about the results of the elections тАФ whether his candidate wins or loses. This is the ty─Бga where one is not anxious about the result. He is established in objectivity.

Let us come to the filth and pollution in our city. It is t─Бmasic ty─Бga to give up any action to correct it and shrug it off saying тАЬWho can do anything about it? I couldnтАЩt care lessтАЭ. It is r─Бjasic ty─Бga to stand in the city squares and grumble against the municipality and leave it at that. Their nationalistic fervour ends there. There is another class of gentlemen. Their s─Бttvic ty─Бga is seen when they give up fear of exertion and fear of rubbing officials on the wrong side, when they write well-researched and detailed reports, publish them and poke to wake up the concerned officers.

Whatever karma we perform, there is definitely a result associated with it. But who is it for? It is for those who are attached to it; not for the ones who give it up.

aniс╣гс╣нamiс╣гс╣нaс╣Г mi┼Ыraс╣Г ca trividhaс╣Г karmaс╣Зaс╕е phalaс╣Г ред
bhavaty-aty─Бgin─Бс╣Г pretya na tu saс╣Гny─Бsin─Бс╣Г kvacit рее
BG 18.12
Thus sorrow, happiness and a mixture of the two are always present for a human if he performs karma with an eye for its rewards, whether it is in this world or others. For a ty─Бgi тАФ a saс╣Гny─Бsi тАФ it is not there.

This is because they have given up their desires and anxiousness for the result of their karma. What they have declined is not allotted to them.
Are we so courageous? No. Bhagav─БnтАЩs instruction is required for worldly people like us. We are concerned about the result of our actions. Therefore, we have to understand the structure of karma and its results. Who is responsible for karma? Who or what are responsible for the consequences of karma? The doer? The influencer? The regent? The one who approves? Those who help? The method of work? We need an explanation for results тАФ good or bad. Any karma cannot be performed by a man alone, without the help of anyone else. It happens only with the help of other people and othersтАЩ wealth. Whether it is big, easy, small, difficult or whatever else, there are many people who are deserving of the rewards of karma. They can be divided into five groups.

adhiс╣гс╣нh─Бnaс╣Г tath─Б kart─Б karaс╣Зaс╣Г ca pс╣Ыthag-vidhaс╣Г ред
vividh─Б┼Ыca pс╣Ыthak-ceс╣гс╣н─Б daivaс╣Г caiv─Бtra paс╣Гcamam рее
BG 18.14

To understand this verse, I feel that we have to tread a slightly different path from the explanations offered by earlier commentators. This is because of the difference in our views. In the eyes of the gurus of yore, mokс╣гa was the most important attainment and karma in daily life was unimportant. In our case, karmas in our daily lives are of paramount importance and for now, mokс╣гa is irrelevant. Before climbing the stairs, we have to first take firm steps on the ground. Can those who cannot climb to the loft jump to the sky? Mokс╣гa is near and karma is far for religious gurus. Whereas, for us, karma is near and mokс╣гa is far off. What applies to them might not apply to us. The immediate objective of saс╣Гny─Бsis is giving up karma and that of saс╣Гs─Бris is in performing satkarma. Saс╣Гs─Бra is itself just karma тАФ a bundle of many vaidika and laukika karmas.

[[Ch 18 Yoga of Single-pointed Surrender (Part 4) Source: prekshaa]]

Since saс╣Гs─Бris are thus different from saс╣Гny─Бsis, the interest and regard of saс╣Гs─Бris towards karma is different from that of saс╣Гny─Бsis. However,the meaning that we derive from the above ┼Ыloka from the point of view of saс╣Гs─Бra is not conflicting with or incongruous with that derived from the point of view of saс╣Гny─Бsa. This new path will set a context for people in the present age and time.

Let us see the individual words of the above verse, one by one.

  1. Adhiс╣гс╣нh─Бnam : Our ancients have called this the body. However, there is not much appeal in interpreting it as body, because in the next verse, the phrase тАЬ┼Ыar─лra-vaс╣Е-manobhihтАЭ is explicitly called out. There is no necessity here for reiteration. Therefore, it is more proper to interpret тАЬadhiс╣гс╣нh─БnamтАЭ as situations that influence a person to act in a certain way - circumstance or situation. A manтАЩs karma is influenced by the circumstance. тАЬAdhiс╣гс╣нh─БnamтАЭ is a collective name for situations that become the basis for performing a karma, the circumstances due to which karma is performed. 2. Kart─Б : The ancients and us do not differ in the interpretation of this word. Kart─Б is one who does, the man who performs the karma.He consumes the fruit of good or bad deeds that he performs. When we say kart─Б, we should remember that it is the sum total of the qualities of the j─лva, the remnants of puс╣Зya and p─Бpa from his past lives, associations due to past obligations, the impressions on the manas because of them, the combinations of the three guс╣Зas and so on. Kart─Б is not the pure ─Бtm─Б, but a j─лva that is shackled by the impressions of karma. Hence the responsibility of consuming their good or bad result. The pure ─Бtm─Б neither performs karma nor consumes its fruit.The j─лva along with collected past impressions and obligations is тАЬkart─БтАЭ. 3. karaс╣Зaс╣Г ca pс╣Ыthag-vidhaс╣Г : Different means used to perform karmas. Earlier commentators have interpreted тАЬkaraс╣ЗaтАЭ as indriyas. However, as we saw above, indriyas are alluded to in тАЬ┼Ыar─лra-v─Бс╣Е-manobhiс╕етАЭ . Therefore, there is the possibility of a different interpretation here. The people and instruments that assist in performing an activity are collectively called upakaraс╣Зa. They are the wealth that aid in performing karma.
  2. vividh─Б┼Ыca pс╣Ыthak-ceс╣гс╣н─Бс╕е : Earlier commentators interpret this as the changes that air causes in our body тАФ such as inhalation,exhalation,yawning, sneezing, etc. It makes more sense to interpret this differently тАФ as it seems difficult for us to believe that the results of a karma are dependent on yawns and dozing. The effects of the five pr─Бс╣Зas are seen in one of the next words, тАЬsar─лrav─БkтАЭ. It is proper to interpret ceс╣гt─Б as the manner in which a task is carried out. It is apt to understand it as a plan of action, programme, policy, strategy, tactic etc. It is like the skill displayed by a pawn in a game of chess. тАЬvividh─Б┼Ыca pс╣Ыthak-ceс╣гс╣н─Бс╕етАЭ therefore means the four strategies тАФ s─Бma, d─Бna, bheda, daс╣Зс╕Нa, and many other means of performing a task, the manner in which it is performed. 5. Daivam : Earlier commentators have construed this as the ruling deities of sense-organs тАФ such as the Sun and the Moon, or the energy that is internally present in the j─лva. It is not possible to demonstrate any special property of karma by just this much. There is no doubt that divine powers such as the Sun and the Moon and the internal energy exist. It is also well-known that they are also party to the performance of a karma. By saying тАЬthe body, speech and mindтАЭ, we do not mean a dead body, but a living and thriving one. When there is a j─лva, there are senses and the deities ruling those senses and the ─Бtm─Б that is present inside it. There is another thing that has to be explained apart from these. That is Fate. That itself is daiva.

The Yoga-v─Бsiс╣гс╣нha says :

pr─Бktanaс╣Г pauruс╣гaс╣Г tad-vai daiva-┼Ыabdena kathyate рее
Yoga-v─Бsiс╣гс╣нha 6.35

Daiva is that which has the power to allocate good or bad outcomes to people who take part in a karma and who have to consume its result, according to what they have earned in the past. That is fate. That is the controlling agent of the universe. In the eleventh chapter, Bhagav─Бn said -

mayaivete nihat─Бс╕е p┼лrvameva рее
BG 11.33

Daiva is that supreme authority who had already decided the outcome of the war that was yet to be fought and said тАЬIf you do not fight, the battle will not stop; do not think that if you exit the war, those who are supposed to be killed by you will remain alive; they have all been slayed alreadyтАЭ. Daiva is that omnipotent entity that has been praised by the Vedas as

y─Бth─БtathyatoтАЩrth─Бn vyadadh─Бt ┼Ы─Б┼Ыvat─лbhyaс╕е sam─Бbhyaс╕е ред
─к┼Ы─Бv─Бsya Upaniс╣гad, 8 тАЬhe allotted different tasks to the yearsтАЭ.

And,

dh─Бt─Б yath─Бp┼лrvam-akalpayat рее
с╣Ъgveda, 10.190.3
тАЬIn the beginning, Dh─Бtс╣Ы createdтАЭ.

We call it adс╣Ыс╣гс╣нa, vidhi, pr─Бcina, pr─Бpti, niyati, yoga, fate, past karma, etc. Daiva is the controlling force, the ruling authority of the universe. In other words, it is destiny, providence. That is daiva.

Though there are different interpretations of the word тАЬDaivaтАЭ, they all converge towards the meaning тАЬFateтАЭ. The performance of karma and the blessing of the divine are both two forms of fate. Both are not directly perceptible. The following verse from the ─Аdiparva of the Mah─Бbh─Бrata should be recalled here:

daive puruс╣гak─Бre ca lokoтАЩyaс╣Г saс╣Гpratiс╣гс╣нhitaс╕е ред
с╣нatra daivaс╣Г tu vidhin─Б k─Бlayuktena labhyate рее
Mah─Бbh─Бrata ─Аdiparva 122.21

The time taken to obtain results from our past karmas or divine blessings cannot be gauged by us. Their fruition might happen at some time. It is not meant to be understood by us. It works independently according to its timetable.
Let us apply the above five principles to an example. In the Kurukс╣гetra war,

  • Adhiс╣гс╣нh─Бna: The dispute between P─Бс╣Зс╕Нavas and the Kauravas about dharma. The just claim of the P─Бс╣Зс╕Нavas for the kingdom, and the enmity of the Kauravas that didnтАЩt allow them to part with it. This situation of dharmic conflict is the adhiс╣гс╣нh─Бna for the war. - Kart─Б : Dharmar─Бya - Karaс╣Зa : Bh─лma and Arjuna, Drupada and other warriors who helped them, Kaurava warriors such as Bh─лс╣гma and Drona are all numerous karaс╣Зas. - Ceс╣гс╣нa, up─Бya : Yudhiс╣гс╣нhira requesting Bh─лс╣гmaтАЩs blessings, letting Drona know of A┼Ыvatth─БmaтАЩs slaying, different vy┼лhas of the armies, the deliverance of various ┼Ыastras (weapons without mantras) and astras (weapons with mantras), Arjuna acquiring weapons like P─Б┼Ыupata тАФ all such deeds are тАЬpс╣Ыthak-ceс╣гс╣нahтАЭ. - Daiva : ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣ЗaтАЩs attempts at bringing peace, Mah─Бdeva bestowing the p─Б┼Ыupata weapon on Arjuna and appearing as Bhairavarudra on the battlefield тАФ this is daiva. Both ┼Ъr─лkс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa and Mah─Бdeva are not concerned with the results of the war. They only came for the sake of protecting dharma. They came only with the noble objective to establish dharma in the world. The work of daiva is in accordance with that of dharma.

What is the meaning of the above? It means that all thoughts and plans of man are subject to the rule of a superhuman rubric; it means that the human work is under the authority of the superhuman.

Let us apply the theory of five organs of karma to a wedding. A girl being of marriageable age and the father being prepared to perform the ritual of a marriage тАФ these are the adhiс╣гс╣нh─Бna. The father is the kart─Б. The bridegroom is the karaс╣Зa. The marriage brokers and mutual friends and relatives are the other karaс╣Зas. The various acts of service and civility тАФ such as perfume, feasts, the honorarium given to the bridegroom are the ceс╣гс╣н─Бs. Then comes the daiva. It is daivaтАЩs blessing if the wedding happens without the bride or the bridegroom falling sick at the time of the lagna or no obstacles in the form of bad news are encountered.

Let us look at a meal from the same perspective. The hunger of the stomach and the desire of the palate are the adhiс╣гс╣нh─Бnas. Kart─Б is the hungry man. Cooks and vessels are the karaс╣Зas. Struggling in shops to buy the items on credit and exhorting the workers and cooks are up─Бya-ceс╣гс╣н─Бs. It is the blessing of daiva to be able to finish the meal without stomach ache, or without hearing appetite-killing bad news or to be harangued by time-eating visitors.

There are more examples of the wrath of daiva than its blessings in the experience of people.

[[Ch 18 Yoga of Single-pointed Surrender (Part 5) Source: prekshaa]]

The summary is this. Daiva is hidden, a secret. It comes suddenly and unexpectedly, and cannot be grasped by the logic of causality. The word in Saс╣Гskс╣Ыta is тАЬ─БkasmikaтАЭ тАФ kasm─Бt means from where тАФ тАЬakasm─БtтАЭ means that one doesnтАЩt know from where it came. It is not possible to determine the causes and effects of such an occurrence. Since daiva is not directly perceptible, we forget it. The blow of despondency, if it hits us, becomes tolerable if we keep daiva in our minds while performing karma. The sorrow of efforts gone futile becomes hard to bear if daiva is forgotten while performing a karma.

┼Ыar─лra-v─Бс╣Е-manobhir-yat karma pr─Бrabhate naraс╕е ред
ny─Бyyaс╣Г v─Б vipar─лtaс╣Г v─Б pa├▒caite tasya hetavaс╕е рее
BG 18.15
тАЬWhether the work started by a man is that of the body or that of the mind тАФ whether it just or otherwise тАФ the reason for its success or failure has to be looked for in the above five organsтАЭ.

Adhiс╣гс╣нh─Бna : Circumstance тАФ we probably have made a mistake in gauging the pressure or the lack thereof, of a situation. Then the effort will go in vain.
Kartс╣Ы : His enthusiasm and belief might wane. Arjuna is a great example.
Karaс╣Зa : Friends and helpers might change. Duryodhana had believed in ┼Ъalya. ┼Ъalya forsook him when he became the charioteer for Karс╣Зa. Karс╣Зa had a divine weapon, but it did not come to him at the right time.
Up─Бya-ceс╣гс╣н─Б : In MacbethтАЩs story, the footsoldiers of the army cut trees down and hid themselves while walking to the enemy castle. The enemies mistook the forest to be moving and ran away. In the history of Mysore, there is a story of a king who tied torches to the horns of oxen. The enemies mistook them for light-ghosts and ran away, scared. These are pс╣Ыthak-ceс╣гс╣н─Бh.

The above four belong to human power. Even if all of them are okay, everything will be futile if daiva does not cooperate.

sarvaс╣Г niс╣гphalitaс╣Г tadeva vidhin─Б daive bale durbale рее

Why does daiva become adverse? The past karmas of all individuals who are engaged in the present karma might individually or collectively be adverse. Therefore, karma is perhaps not for one person alone. It follows that even the results of karma are not for an individual alone.

In a great karma, the fates of a thousand people might come together. In our tradition, it is customary for people who perform propitious karmas like going on pilgrimages or building temples to first collect alms from a few houses. Why is this? Among the people who give alms, there might be at least a few with puс╣Зya in their account; the idea is that the work may finish without encountering any obstacles. There may be one kart─Б, and a thousand helpers and approvers. Even they have a share in the results of the karma. Thus, daiva is the result of collective karma.

kart─Б k─Бrayit─Б caiva preraka-┼Ыca-anumodakaс╕е ред
sukс╣Ыte duс╣гkс╣Ыte caiva catv─Бraс╕е sama-bh─Бginaс╕е рее
(subh─Бс╣гita)

To protect the order and dharma of the universe, daiva might modify the results of the individual karmas тАФ whether they are good or bad. Let us set daiva aside for a moment; it is not available for our examination and inquiry. Let us see the four parties that are in control of man. For a karma to be successful, all four of them should be favourable.

  1. Adhiс╣гс╣нh─Бna or the circumstance might be favorable in the beginning, but may become adverse later. 2. The kart─Б himself may experience change of thought, or his energy might wane 3. His karaс╣Зas тАФ or the ingredients/instruments may be spoiled 4. Even if the above three are alright, there may be a mistake in his method.

Thus, the kartс╣Ы is not the only reason for an effort to succeed or fail or yield adverse results. The other three companions of his тАФ or one or two of the above parties may be the reason. Even if daiva is helpful, an effort may go in vain because of human errors.

tatraivaс╣Г sati kart─Бram ─Бtm─Бnaс╣Г kevalaс╣Г tu yaс╕е ред
pa┼Ыyaty-akс╣Ыta-buddhitv─Бt na sa pa┼Ыyati durmatiс╕е рее
BG 18.16
тАЬWhen the actual responsibility thus rests with so many people, one who thinks that he alone тАФ the j─лv─Бtm─Б in him alone тАФ is the kartс╣Ы, is devoid of intellect. Such a fool cannot know the truthтАЭ.

Here there are two concepts :

  1. The kart─Б is not alone. There are other claimants along with him. 2. тАЬIтАЭ is also an aspect of a j─лva and not just ─Бtm─Б.

The ─Бtm─Б that is present within a j─лva is the same ─Бtm─Б that is present in all j─лvas. The energy of the ─Бtm─Б is whole, never-changing and indivisible. One who has understood the omnipresence of the ─Бtm─Б realises that the relationship between the kart─Б and karma is unimportant and only circumstantial, and therefore it is transcendental and impermanent.

Indeed, didnтАЩt this topic appear in our discussion because of the question of dharma? If Duryodhana were dh─Бrmic and had said тАЬI will give whatever is entitled to you. You please take it and be happyтАЭ and acted accordingly, we would have completely missed the story of the Mahabharata. We would not have obtained the BhagavadG─лt─Б either. Therefore we have to praise Bhagav─Бn for giving Duryodhana his evilery and scheming mind ! DuryodhanaтАЩs evil mind became the pretext in the scheme of daiva.
A j├▒─Бnin understands that the state of j─лva that has been obtained by the ─Бtm─Б is not permanent and that the doership of the j─лvi is not permanent.

yasya n─Бhaс╣Гkс╣Ыto bh─Бvo buddhir-yasya na lipyate ред
hatv─БтАЩpi sa im─Бn lok─Бn na hanti na nibadhyate рее
BG 18.17
тАЬOne who is not tainted by ego and does not think of himself as the doer, one whose intellect is not stained with concern for the results of a karma тАФ even if such a man destroys all the worlds, he will not be a killer. It will not shackle himтАЭ.

This is the mark of a man who has progressed beyond dharma. We will see this adhidharma тАФ going beyond dharma тАФ later.

It is a crime when one person slays another. The same slaying done by a j├▒─Бnin is not a crime. This is because other people act out of ego and selfishness. A j├▒─Бnin does not have them. The objective of a j├▒─Бnin is for all j─лvas to obtain better states. Is it necessary to wipe out whole worlds to move all j─лvas to a better state? Bhagav─Бn is not saying that. To illustrate a principle, a figure of speech called utprekс╣г─Б is used. Idiomatic language cannot be understood by making sense of mere words. Only the intent should be grasped here.
It is impossible for a person who has understood the true nature of the ─Бtm─Б to be a sinner. This is because he is not acting out of selfish desires or hatred for others. Even if he does something that is characteristic of an egoistic and mean person, that work will inherently not carry any evilery. Instead, it will be for the welfare and prosperity of the world only. The only desire that such a person carries is the welfare of all beings. Therefore, there is no possibility of p─Бpa in his dealings.

That is fine. While describing the five components of karma, it is said тАФ

daivaс╣Г caiv─Бtra pa├▒camam рее
BG 18.14

Daiva is mentioned here separately. Does not this special component called daiva have authority over the other four? Cannot daiva fix or make favourable the adverse factors, if any, among adhiс╣гс╣нh─Бna, kart─Б, karaс╣Зa, tantras─Бdhana тАФ or make them adverse if they are favourable? Is daiva not omnipotent? The answer to that is below :

Daiva cannot rule over all human aspects of karma. A part of human endeavour does depend on divine blessings, but all of it does not. If all aspects of human effort are dependent on daiva, what is left for humans? How can he earn puс╣Зya or p─Бpa? The responsibility of the doer comes to a naught in that case! A human has puс╣Зya and p─Бpa. Once we say that he has puс╣Зya and p─Бpa in his account, it is clear that he will have responsibilities and freedom as well. He has the authority to discern and act accordingly. A man will be concerned with puс╣Зya and p─Бpa only if human effort is of importance in a karma. Thus, the kartс╣Ы has some amount of freedom when it comes to dos and donтАЩts. There are authoritative statements in the Brahma-sutras, etc., that declare that man has freedom to examine his progress or decline through his intellect and work towards what he wants.

kart─Б ┼Ы─Бstr─Бrthavattv─Бt рее
Brahmas┼лtra 2-3-33

What does ┼Ы─Бstra say? It says that there is puс╣Зya and there is p─Бpa; it says that there are good and bad results; it says that pleasure and pain are in accordance with dharma or adharma. Therefore, if the instruction about dharma and adharma has to be meaningful, man should have freedom and authority to understand both of them and rationally distinguish between them based on the situation. If that freedom is not given to man, he will not be responsible for dharma or adharma that happens through him.

Let us look at ┼Ъr─л R─Бm─Бnuj─Бc─БryaтАЩs commentary for the above s┼лtra. The interpretations of the three schools of Vedanta differ from one another only in parts where it is not possible to give proof to anyone. Where it is possible to provide proof, they have no objections.

┼Ы─Бsan─Бcca ┼Ы─Бstram ред ┼Ы─Бsanaс╣Г ca pravartanam ред ┼Ы─Бstrasya ca pravartakatvaс╣Г bodha-janana-dv─Бreс╣Зa ред acetanaс╣Г ca pradh─Бnaс╣Г na bodhayituс╣Г ┼Ыakyam ataс╕е ┼Ы─Бstr─Бс╣З─Бm arthavattvaс╣Г bhoktu┼Ы-cetanasyaiva kartс╣Ыtve bhavet рее
─Бtmanaс╕е akrtс╣Ыtve тАЬkury─БtтАЭ, тАЬna kury─БtтАЭ iti ┼Ы─Бstr─Бnarthakyaс╣Г sy─Бt рее
svarg─Бpavarga-s─Бdhan─Бnuс╣гс╣нh─Бna-vidh─Бna-┼Ы─Бstr─Бс╣З─Бm arthavattv─Бya, kartaiv─Бtm─Б ред boddhyureva hi ┼Ы─Бsanam рее

┼Ъ─Бsana means ruling. Since ┼Ы─Бstra rules us it is given that name. Pravartana is to instruct to act in such and such a way. How does ┼Ы─Бstra instruct? тАЬBodha-janana-dv─БrenaтАЭ тАФ by producing knowledge within us. ┼Ъ─Бstra provides knowledge and impels us to act or not act in a certain way. What is the use of tutoring a benumbed body that does not have any freedom? тАЬacetanaс╣Г ca pradh─Бnaс╣Г na bodhayituс╣Г ┼ЫakyamтАЭ тАФ there is no use in teaching someone who does not have power that he can use freely. тАЬataс╕е ┼Ы─Бstr─Бс╣З─Бm arthavattvaс╣Г bhoktu┼Ы-cetanasyaiva bhavetтАЭ : ┼Ы─Бstras become meaningful when the doer himself consumes the fruit of his actions. If a man has freedom to do or not do a certain karma, then it makes sense to tell him to do or not do it, since he is anyway free to accept or disregard it. If he wants to do it, he does it out of his own volition, just as he disregards it out of his volition as well. Therefore the puс╣Зya or p─Бpa accrued from his performing or not performing a karma will get attached to him. тАЬ─Бtmanaс╕е akartс╣Ыtve kury─Бt iti ┼Ы─Бstr─Бnarthakyaс╣Г sy─БtтАЭ тАФ if a man does not have freedom in doership, is it not meaningless to instruct him to do it or not do it in a specific way? The person to whom this is being told тАФ if he is not free to either do or not do something, all dharma┼Ы─Бstra of the form of dos and donтАЩts will become useless. тАЬBoddhyureva hi ┼Ы─БsanamтАЭ : ┼Ы─Бstra is only for the one who is eligible for instruction. If he is not eligible for it, the education given to him is akin to educating a rock or a wall. ┼Ъ─Бstra should be taught only to the one who has the freedom to follow or transgress it. He will accrue p─Бpa if he disregards it; he will accrue puс╣Зya if he complies with it. Who then obtains p─Бpa or puс╣Зya? The one who is free to perform тАФ or in other words, has kriy─Б-sv─Бtantrya. Here, kriy─Б means the ability to distinguish between dos and donтАЩts; between dharma and adharma. ┼Ъ─Бstra and its dos and donтАЩts can only be taught to one who has this ability to differentiate. Dharma-┼Ы─Бstras and rules are necessary only because this freedom exists. It is true that the freedom of man is limited. Why is that? It is because of daiva. However, the little freedom he has should be used for differentiating between dos and donтАЩts.

There are three stages in the lifecycle of any karma тАФ beginning, execution and consequence. Among these three, the last one тАФ consequence тАФ is mostly under the authority of daiva. The other two тАФ beginning and execution тАФ are mainly dependent on human effort. What is the nature of these two stages? The beginning is related to the internal working of the human mind тАФ it belongs to the realm of knowledge. Execution is external тАФ it happens in the domain of doing. Therefore Sv─Бm─л expounds upon the realms of j├▒─Бna and kriy─Б now.

j├▒─Бnaс╣Г j├▒eyaс╣Г parij├▒─Бt─Б trividh─Б karma-codan─Б рее
BG 18.18

The inspiration for karma happens because of the confluence of three aspects : knowledge, the object to be known and knower. This can also be said тАЬjn─Бtс╣Ы-j├▒eyaс╣Г parij├▒─БnamтАЭ. Let us take an example. Suppose there are some eatables in a covered vessel placed in a suspended basket. This is j├▒eya, or the thing to be known. A boy comes to know this. He is the knower or jn─Бtс╣Ы. He comes to know this because of the savoury smell. The knowledge of the smell that started from the eatable reached his nose and tempted him. By the commingling of food, nose and mind, there is an urge to steal the laddus from the basket. This urge happens within. Then comes the external work.

karaс╣Зaс╣Г karma karteti trividhaс╕е karma-saс╣Гgrahaс╕е рее
BG 18.18

A ladder and other means to reach the basket are karaс╣Зa; karma is putting oneтАЩs hand into the box and stuffing the laddu into the mouth; the one who later smacks his lips is the kart─Б. Thus, there are three parts to a karma.
Inspiration for a karma comes from the triad of jn─Бtс╣Ы, j├▒─Бna and j├▒eya which are internal, the execution of a karma is through the triad of kart─Б, karaс╣Зa and karma. First, a j─лva obtains j├▒─Бna. After that, the execution of a karma happens through that j├▒─Бna.

j├▒─Бnaс╣Г karma ca kart─Б ca tridhaiva guс╣Зabhedataс╕е рее
BG 18.19

Here, guс╣Зa means the guс╣Зa-triad of sattva, rajas and tamas. All our transactions are according to the differences between them. Therefore, the difference in the qualities of the three aspects of karma - j├▒─Бna, karma and kart─Б are explained now.

Let us first look at the three types of j├▒─Бna.

sarvabhuteс╣гu yenaikaс╣Г bh─Бvam-avyayam-─лkс╣гate ред
avibhaktaс╣Г vibhakteс╣гu taj-j├▒─Бnaс╣Г viddhi s─Бttvikam рее
BG 18.20
тАЬThe knowledge of one who has seen that the same energy of the ─Бtm─Б pervades all beings, and resides fully in different bodies and is s─БttvicтАЭ.

This is the complete experience of the supreme tattva.

A man who does not understand this all-pervading principle and thinks that all beings are different from one another, is said to have rajasic knowledge.

One who disregards the complete principle and confines the innumerable and multifarious manifestations of the supreme principle seen in the universe to one form is said to have tamasic knowledge.

The s─Бttvic form of knowledge keeps in view the complete and vast expanse of the supreme tattva.

Now let us look at the three kinds of karma. S─Бttvic karma is that which is performed without passion or hatred, ascertained from the ┼Ы─Бstras and tradition and oneтАЩs own judgement, without a touch of egoism and without any desire for its reward.

niyataс╣Г saс╣Еga-rahitam ar─Бga-dveс╣гataс╕е kс╣Ыtam ред
apala-prepsun─Б karma yat-tat-s─Бtvikam-ucyate рее
BG 18.23

This verse is the essence of all principles of karma-yoga.
Karma performed with an objective, performed with great difficulty and egoism is r─Бjasic.
T─Бmasic karma is that which is performed obstinately and foolishly, without thinking about the pros and cons of the karma, expenditure, or the difficulty to be undergone by others, or an understanding of oneтАЩs own capabilities and their limitations.
Thus, the mark of s─Бttvic karma is to intelligently distinguish between proper and improper and act accordingly.

Now let us look at the three kinds of kart─Бs.
A s─Бttvic kart─Б is one who performs karma without attachment or delusion, is not selfish, is stable and enthusiastic and is not altered by victory or defeat.
A r─Бjasic kart─Б is one who performs karma with a desire for its result, is deluded and passionate, does not mind resorting to violence and other base means, and one who is overjoyed by victory and cowed down by defeat.
A t─Бmasic kart─Б is one who is careless, egoistic and hypocritical, forgets propriety and is lazy, wails all the time and procrastinates.

In the context of karma, j├▒─Бna, karma and kart─Б are important. Next, we shall look at the three-fold classification of buddhi (intellect) and dhс╣Ыti (constancy) that are important in the execution of karma.

pravс╣Ыttiс╣Г ca nivс╣Ыttiс╣Г ca k─Бry─Бk─Бrye bhay─Бbhaye ред
bandhaс╣Г mokс╣гaс╣Г ca yo vetti buddhiс╕е s─Б p─Бrtha s─Бttvik─л рее
BG 18.30

The buddhi that knows when and how much to enter into what worldly transaction, and when and how to stop, which work has to be done and which should not, when should one be fearless and when to be fearful, what might bind the ─Бtm─Б and what can release it тАФ is s─Бttvic. A hasty intellect that does not examine dharma and adharma, dos and donтАЩts according to philosophy and misunderstands them is r─Бjasic.
A t─Бmasic intellect mistakes adharma for dharma and and in its stupor makes sense of everything in a perverted way.
In the beginning, Arjuna had r─Бjasic intellect. The mark of s─Бttvic intellect is to understand subtle differences between dharma and adharma. Arjuna had to learn this quality of discernment.
Dhс╣Ыti is the ability to hold. Both courage and steadiness are consolidated in this word.
S─Бttvic dhс╣Ыti is the firmness of the mind that keeps the manas, senses and pr─Бс╣Зas in control through continuous practice.
R─Бjasic dhс╣Ыti is that which keeps only the immediate goal in view while performing works of dharma, k─Бma and artha. The activism that we all showed when Gandhiji was alive is an example of that. It is only concerned with the immediate result.
T─Бmasic dhс╣Ыti is that which is not ready to give up sleep, groaning, dreaming, wailing or conceit.

[[Ch 18 Yoga of Single-pointed Surrender (Part 7) Source: prekshaa]]

There are three types of pleasure as well.

yat-tadagre viс╣гamiva pariс╣З─БmeтАЩmс╣Ыtopamam ред
tat-sukhaс╣Г s─Бttvikaс╣Г proktam ─Бtma-buddhi-pras─Бdajam рее
BG 18.37

  1. S─Бttvic sukha is that in which the mind rests and finds that its sorrows cease, that which appears distasteful in the beginning but then results in amс╣Ыta-like sweetness. It is due to the purity and pleasantry of oneself. This is the sukha experienced when the intellect completely understands the principle of the ─Бtm─Б and the mind is fully rid of impurity, delusion, and confusion, and there is peace and tranquillity. 2. R─Бjasic sukha is pleasure derived from worldly pursuits. It is sweet at first but gradually becomes bitter like poison. 3. T─Бmasic sukha is pleasure that is experienced out of sleep, laziness and carelessness. It creates confusion and delusion in the j─лva.

Selfishness тАФ a note : A friend has asked this question. IsnтАЩt at least a little selfishness required to be present in a man? How can worldly life progress without that? The answer to that can be answered in three aspects.

  1. Firstly, selfishness is natural. One does not have to put any effort into becoming selfish. It comes naturally by birth. The j─лva experiences both profit and loss due to it. The objective of dharma is to correct it so that there is more profit and less loss to the j─лva. Dharma does not say that selfishness should be completely eradicated. тАЬasm─Бkaс╣Г saha-kuс╣нumb─Бn─Бс╣Г kс╣гema-sthairya-v─лrya-vijaya-─Бrogya-saubh─БgyaтАжтАЭ isnтАЩt this the saс╣Гkalpa for any dharmic karma? 2. Secondly, why should we live? Is life just for living or with any objective? Plants and trees, snakes and lizards live just for the sake of living. If another objective is not included in such lives, who will be at loss? If we say that a man has to live for the sake of an objective, it is necessary that this objective be above selfish wants.Then the objective of life becomes great; selfishness only becomes a tool to achieve the real object of life. 3. Thirdly, even selfishness is three-fold, like sukha, dhс╣Ыti etc.
    1. T─Бmasic selfishness is that which thinks only of its palate, its comfort, its decoration and prestige, and thinks of the rest of the universe as something that exists to satisfy its need for pleasure. It takes whatever it needs from the world, and does not give anything in return. It does not repay its debt to the world. It does not even have an iota of feeling that it has benefitted from the world.
    2. R─Бjasic selfishness is that which expands to include oneтАЩs family, community, town and country, is part of their happiness and sorrow and shares a part of life with a part of the world. It is better than t─Бmasic selfishness. It feels that these people are oneтАЩs own, they should be part of oneтАЩs happiness and sorrow тАФ thus it includes others, loved ones, closely related ones in its circle of me and mine; it expands to that extent. It takes whatever it wants from the world, and gives back whatever it deems possible.
    3. The ─Бtm─Б within oneself is the ─Бtm─Б of the universe; the universe is the body where Bhagav─Бn sports; one has to experience oneself within this universe and become all-containing тАФ the desire to experience Brahma thus is s─Бttvic selfishness. It realises that it owns nothing and offers everything to Bhagav─Бn and feels happy, or thinks that everything belongs to itself and there is nothing against it; and feels its own ─Бtm─Б pervading the entire universe.

This verse in praise of mamat─Б by Appayya Dikс╣гita is fit to be recalled here.

tyaktavyo mamak─Бraс╕е tyaktuс╣Г yadi ┼Ыakyate n─Бsau ред
kartavyo mamak─Бraс╕е kiс╣Г tu sa sarvatra kartavyaс╕е рее
Vair─Бgya-┼Ыataka-77
тАЬIt is only right to give up self-interest and selfishness. If it cannot be given up, it becomes a duty to be self-interested; but that self-interest should be exercised everywhereтАЭ. All beings should be included in the realm of self-interest. S─Бttvic selfishness is that where тАЬsvaтАЭ includes the entire universe.

Thus, Bhagav─Бn explains the form of sattva in j├▒─Бna, karma, kartс╣Ыtva, buddhi, dhс╣Ыti and sukha and establishes its supremacy. Then he shows that sattva is not easily found or easy to be followed in the world.

We saw that unless the impurities attached to the j─лva in the form of the guс╣Зa-triad are washed away clean, the nature of the ─Бtm─Б cannot be seen. This cleaning-up does not happen easily or quickly, because the dirt of the guс╣Зa-triad comes from crores of past lives. It takes long and constant effort to erode them, and there should be a proper method in that effort. That method is svadharma.

We have already seen the nature of dharma. Let us recall it now. Dharma is the mutually beneficial relationship between the j─лva and the universe. Every personтАЩs j─лva comes with some capabilities, some tastes and predispositions attached to it naturally. These capabilities, tastes and predispositions are made of the three guс╣Зas. In the exercise of using them for the benefit and welfare of the world, the dirt in them diminishes and sattva becomes dominant. This is the main principle of dharma. On one side we have an individual person тАФ his alities and capabilities, his likes and dislikes, his remnant p─Бpas; on the other side we have the universe тАФ its attractions and conflicts and its difficulties. The energy of the ─Бtm─Б pervades these two spaces, within both of them equally. On both sides, it is hidden by the veil of prakс╣Ыti and cannot be seen. That ─Бtm─Б is what has to be known. Mokс╣гa is bringing it to oneтАЩs own constant experience. However, the veil of prakс╣Ыti is impregnable. The trickery of nature shows itself in layers and in colours тАФ it appears as flowers, fruits, man, woman, wealth and song in front of the j─лva and calls to him тАЬSee how beautiful I am, what pleasures I can give you ! Will you leave me and go? Come to me, my childтАЭ. This is why when we begin the study of Vedanta, we first recite ┼Ы─Бnti-mantras such as тАФ

bhadraс╣Г karс╣Зebhiс╕е ┼Ыruс╣Зuy─Бma dev─Бс╕е рее
┼Ыaс╣Г no mitraс╕е ┼Ыaс╣Г varuс╣Зaс╕е рее

Why do we prostrate to inferior deities when we are trying to experience the Supreme Brahman? ArenтАЩt we desirous of seeing the parabrahman? The answer is this. Before seeing and experiencing the parabrahman, the necessary thing is peace of mind. Before peace of mind, the necessary thing is peace of the body. Stability of the world is required for the stability of the body. Thus, the worship of param─Бtm─Б and worldly life are not mutually exclusive, they are always together. Therefore, the ┼Ы─Бnti-mantras at the beginning of the upaniс╣гads pray to Indra, S┼лrya, Varuс╣Зa and other deities to remove their obstacles and approve of their effort. ArenтАЩt those deities different manifest forms of prakс╣Ыti herself in the world? Hence, the devotee prays thus. тАЬO divine beings, do not stop the progress of my ─Бtm─Б thinking that I might forget you if I experience the Supreme Brahman. Till I am alive I will offer you what I have to. Be favourable towards my worldly well-being and show me the way for my future progressтАЭ. This is the intent.
Prakс╣Ыti should be favourable to us. We should not be subservient to her. Worldly life should continue well. But one should not stop there, thinking that that is the be-all and end-all. One should always progress. That is the meaning of the above words. When we visit temples at places like Belur, it is possible that we are marvelled by the beauty of the sculpture of the outside walls and forget the inner sanctum itself. Such are the caresses of prakс╣Ыti. How do we go beyond it? There is already a scheme for that. That scheme is dharma. Dharma is the means and tactics of dealing with prakс╣Ыti so as to escape from the web of infatuation with which she is trapping us. Dharma is the set of rules and methods that help in the elevation of the ─Бtm─Б, and is equally beneficial to both j─лva and the universe in their relationship.

The dirt of the guс╣Зa-triad attached to the j─лva should erode, the s─Бttvic capabilities of the j─лva should grow and help in the welfare of the world. Tamas should decrease and rajas should increase; rajas should decrease and sattva should increase. Both tamas and rajas should decrease further and sattva should reign supreme among the three. This is the manner of ascendance of the j─лva. The opportunity to erode rajas and tamas and to encourage sattva is given by interactions with the world. It is not easy to grind down the dirt of the guс╣Зas. ShouldnтАЩt a piece of sandalwood be rubbed on a grinding stone for it to wear down? Similarly, our past impressions should be ground on the stones of the world. When our temperaments are ground thus, they wear down and become sharp too. When a sword or knife is rubbed on a whetstone it wears down and becomes sharp. Thus, it becomes more capable in performing its work. Similarly, when an ─Бtm─Б performs worldly karmas in the prescribed way, its rajas and tamas reduce and sattva increases. Its capabilities increase. It is trained. Along with these two advantages, there is a third тАФ it is the worldly welfare that was made possible because we used our ability in the right way. Sattva thus increases; the mind expands; The ability of the ─Бtm─Б to be of use to the world increases. Impurities decrease; that is itself the decrease of evil. тАЬmama up─Бtta samasta-durita-kс╣гaya-dv─Бr─Б ┼Ыr─л-parame┼Ыvara-pr─лtyarthamтАЭ.

The present series is a modern English translation of DVGтАЩs Kendra Sahitya Akademi Award-winning work, Bhagavad-g─лt─Б-t─Бtparya or J─лvana-dharma-yoga. The translators wish to express their thanks to ┼Ъat─Бvadh─Бni R Ganesh for his valuable feedback and to Hari Ravikumar for his astute edits.

[[Ch 18 Yoga of Single-pointed Surrender (Part 8) Source: prekshaa]]

Impurities comprise impressions carried over from many lives, or natural temperaments тАФ different tastes, wavering wants and infatuations, etc. Thus, the unconscious tastes and impressions from past lives are the impurities. Some of them are to be suppressed and purged. Others are to be experienced fully and then only can they be done away with. Purifying the sattva means eradicating the past impressions. This happens when they are indulged and used up in dealings with the world.

Thus, in the system of human relationship with the world, there should be a strategy to destroy tamas, control the rajas and encourage sattva. This strategy should be according to the natural capabilities of the j─лva. The system of varс╣Зas is a scheme of relationship between the j─лva and the universe that makes sure the capabilities of a j─лva are used to further the welfare of the world, pares its tamas and rajas, and develops the inner nature of the ─Бtm─Б. The basis of this system is prakс╣Ыti тАФ unimpeded prakс╣Ыti. Bhagav─Бn says that the system of four varс╣Зas is based on the differences seen in the structure of the universe.

c─Бturvarс╣Зyaс╣Г may─Б sс╣Ыс╣гс╣нaс╣Г guс╣Зa-karma-vibh─Бga┼Ыaс╕е ред
BG 4-13

Dharma is realist, not “fancyist”. There are different kinds of guс╣Зas and karmas in this creation. On one side, we have people with different kinds of abilities and energies. On another side, we have the world with different needs and objectives. Therefore, diversity and differences are present in the basic nature of the universe itself.

It is a fact of prakс╣Ыti that among beings, there are differences in capabilities and qualities. It is an exaggeration to say that everyone is equal. Indeed, donтАЩt some idealistic seekers of excellence argue that everyone should be treated equally? If that comes into practice, we will suffer more than we do now. If all fingers of a hand become equal in length and thickness, can we hold a vessel or mix rice with them? When we say we want everyone to be equal, our only intention is that we should be treated on par with someone above us, and not that we want someone below us to be treated on par with us. This is the secret of the sloganeering about equality that is going on in the world now. Equality is only an external cover for self-prestige.

Dharma does not act according to such fancies. Short people are indeed short. Tall people are tall. Thin people are thin and fat people are fat. Dharma understands this reality. Treating a short man as a six-footer or a six-footer as a short person and acting accordingly is not dharma. One man might be brilliant, this other man might be dull. One person might have special abilities, another might be ordinary. Dharma is decided based on the differences between people. Satya or truth is factual. Dharma is that which does not follow anything but the actual fact. Giving a puс╕╗с╕╗angayi (Puс╕╗с╕╗angai unс╕Нe is a sweet ball that is hard as a rock) ball to someone without teeth and tambiс╣нс╣нu(Tambiс╣нс╣нu is a traditional soft, sweet ball) to someone with strong teeth is not dharma. All dealings in the universe are a mishmash of things that are inherently different from one another. It will be necessary to adjust short with long, strong with weak. This is how different aspects are teamed together. A dull ox is yoked with a sharp one when oxen are yoked to a cart. One cart should not get only dull oxen; neither should another cart get only sharp ones. The idea is that we should take what help we can from the enchantments from the hands of prakс╣Ыti. A man who has a good voice can learn music easily. It may not be easy for him to learn Mathematics or wrestling. Therefore, it is fit for those who set up a system in the world to consider the needs of the world, and estimate who is naturally more capable of contributing what it needs to the world.

The various types and extents of qualities and capabilities seen in human nature mainly fall into four categories. They are the four j─Бtis.

br─Бhmaс╣Зa-kс╣гatriya-vi┼Ы─Бс╣Г ┼Ы┼лdr─Бс╣З─Бс╣Г ca parantapa ред
karm─Бс╣Зi pravibhakt─Бni svabh─Бva-prabhavair-guс╣Зaiс╕е рее
BG 18.41

The duties of people are prescribed based on which qualities are naturally predominant in them. None of human capabilities is useless; no man is unfit тАФ these are the fundamental principles with which all scholars of dharma-┼Ы─Бstras agree.
There is no one in the world who is completely useless. The challenge is to evaluate the potential and harness it. Vai┼Ыyas are those who are more attentive towards money than others. A courageous and strong person can be a kс╣гatriya. Thus, dharma-┼Ы─Бstras evaluate the predispositions of people and decide their duties accordingly.
One should not think that this applies only to Hindu society. It is seen in all countries and all human societies. From the works of historians like Toynbee, we see that it was present in ancient Greece, Egypt and other countries. Just as there were some societal changes in India in the past two hundred years, there have been similar changes in England and other parts of Europe in the past three centuries. Distribution of wealth changed its course because of the industrial revolution. Since the distribution of wealth changed, the class and status of people also changed. In ShakespeareтАЩs drama тАЬTroilus and CressidaтАЭ, there is lamentation that class etiquette is eroding. It seems class differences existed in all societies. Westerners have not acknowledged it openly and have not named it as caste. The aspect exists, but it has not been evaluated philosophically. The varс╣Зa differentiation described in the G─лt─Б is natural in all human societies. Our ancients noticed this natural contrast and gave it a name. Western ancients did not notice it as we did, and do not call it by name. We see that many things and feelings around us do not have names. There is no difficulty in inferring that names such as Smith, Mason, Cook, etc., probably came from the professions of individuals. Now, they are all mixed up in their societies. Our society has still not become so heterogeneous.

We said that the varс╣Зa differentiation outlined in the G─лt─Б is naturally seen in all societies. We shall see the characteristics of Br─Бhmaс╣Зas.

┼Ыamo-damas-tapaс╕е ┼Ыaucaс╣Г kс╣г─Бntir-─Бrjavam-eva ca ред
j├▒─Бnaс╣Г vij├▒─Бnam-─Бstikyaс╣Г brahma-karma-svabh─Бvajam рее
BG 18.42
тАЬ┼Ъama, dama, tapas, ┼Ыauca, day─Б, ─Бrjava, knowledge of Brahma, knowledge of the world and belief in the divine тАФ one whose nature has these qualities is a Br─Бhmaс╣ЗaтАЭ.

We have talked about these qualities many times earlier. J├▒─Бna means the knowledge of the ─Бtm─Б, the knowledge of Brahma. Vij├▒─Бna is worldly knowledge тАФ ┼Ы─Бstras like engineering, medicine, etc. It is said тАЬvij├▒─Бnaс╣Г ┼Ыilpa-┼Ы─Бstrayoс╕етАЭ - (Amarako┼Ыa 1.5.329) vij├▒─Бna is the knowledge of sculpture and science One should develop oneтАЩs knowledge that helps worldly life, and it should be propagated тАФ this is a Br─Бhmaс╣ЗaтАЩs natural propensity. He is a teacher. He should first gain knowledge and then distribute it among others.

sv─Бdhy─Бya-pravacane eveti n─Бko maudgalyaс╕е ред taddhi tapas-tadd-hi tapaс╕е рее
Tai. U. ┼Ъ─лkс╣г─Бvall─л

Vyasa himself talks about the qualities of Br─Бhmaс╣Зas elsewhere :

nait─Бdс╣Ы┼Ыaс╣Г br─Бhmaс╣Зasy─Бsti vittaс╣Г yathaikat─Б samat─Б satyat─Б ca ред
┼Ы─лlaс╣Г sthitirdaс╣Зс╕Нanid─Бnam-─Бrjavaс╣Г tatas-tatas-coparatiс╕е kriy─Бbhyaс╕е рее
MBh, 12.169.35.1

Apparently, a Br─Бhmaс╣Зa does not have any wealth greater than this one thing. What is that? Ekat─Б or consistency тАФ to be steady and self-restrained; being one in mind, speech and behaviour, without any conflict. Samat─Б means that the mind is unchanged by dualities. Satyat─Б means established in truth. Sh─лla means good conduct. Sthiti means that if he believes in something, he constantly works towards it. Daс╣Зс╕Нanid─Бna means that he does not forget to correct himself in speech, mind and body. ─Аrjava is being straightforward. There is one last quality that has been listed : тАЬtatas-tata┼Ы-coparatiс╕е kriy─Бbhyaс╕етАЭ. This is specific to Br─Бhmaс╣Зas. He should perform karma. Now and then, he should step back and give it a rest. A Br─Бhmaс╣ЗaтАЩs special quality is to not get attached to karma. It is detachment or withdrawal. Bhagav─Бn says тАЬsaс╣Еgaс╣Г tyaktv─БтАЭ in the same sense. тАЬThis duty is not mine. I performed it because Bhagav─Бn ordered it. I have performed the karma as required. Now I have to step backтАЭ тАФ a br─Бhmaс╣ЗaтАЩs mindset should thus allow him to rest from work.

Continuous work without rest is rajasic. It is the quality ofkс╣гatriyasand vai┼Ыyas. A br─Бhmaс╣Зa is only established in karma when it is his duty; when there is no need for karma, he is established in the dhy─Бna of Bhagav─Бn.

Very well. If we say that these qualities are that of a br─Бhmaс╣Зa, does a man born in a brahmin family become a brahmin just because of his birth? We cannot escape this question; it has to be faced. Do we decide whether one is a brahmin from birth or from qualities? There is no doubt that quality is the ultimate characteristic that decides whether one is a br─Бhmaс╣Зa. That birth influences quality, however, is a factor to be considered. Biologists now agree that familial qualities are passed on from generation to generation. It is an irrelevant question if we ask if the seed or field are different. Keeping this possibility aside, if we agree that there is an unbroken, straight lineage, we can conclude without a doubt that the above qualities of a br─Бhmaс╣Зa have been transmitted from generation to generation from ancient times to the present times, even if ever so slightly.

[[Ch 18 Yoga of Single-pointed Surrender (Part 9) Source: prekshaa]]

In our times, the question of why is a br─Бhmaс╣Зa given more importance has become more and more vociferous. The answer to that is in the description of the above qualities. A br─Бhmaс╣Зa is devout and truthful; he regards that knowledge is of paramount importance and is always peaceful. All people of all countries respect such a person. Respect for those qualities are not out of drum-beating or force or even encouragement. It is born by itself from within the breast. These qualities are considered respectable by universal humanity that transcends caste, religion and other worldly attributes. If someone says that he does not respect those qualities, we do not fight with him. A br─Бhmaс╣Зa is calm and merciful. He does not have any strife with anyone. That these qualities are respected by people is itself a praise of human nature. Even a person who is not truthful respects those who always speak truth. What does this show? It shows that even though a man lies because of some reason best known to himself, he respects truth. Even if he lies to others, he wishes that everyone should tell him the truth and not lies. The respect and faith a liar has about truth and truthful people gradually turns into love for truth itself. Similarly, the br─Бhmaс╣Зic qualities that one respects will eventually be morally beneficial to himself.

A br─Бhmaс╣Зa does not beg for respect. His venerability is because of his qualities and not because he asked for it. One who says тАЬI am a brahmin, respect meтАЭ, shows his unworthiness by this mere statement. Manu says that one who expects reward is not a br─Бhmaс╣Зa. He says that a br─Бhmaс╣Зa should crave for contempt instead:

saс╣Гm─Бn─Бd-br─Бhmaс╣Зo nityam udvijeta viс╣г─Бdiva ред
amс╣Ыtasyeva c─Бk─Бс╣Еkс╣гet avam─Бnasya sarvad─Б рее
Manusmс╣Ыti 2-162

The next aspect to be considered after giving up prestige and conceit is that of money. The greatest assault on our people due to British rule was caused by the revolutionary attack on our moral philosophy. Acquaintance with the British inflamed the desire of the elites or our society, for material wealth. It was natural that the English needed Indian help to establish communication between us and them, and also to keep accounts. It became an opportunity for Brahmins. They had been immersing themselves in education for generations. It thus became easy for them to learn new languages and sciences. Added to the natural proclivity towards knowledge, there was additional encouragement from monetary incentives. They forgot the wealth that Vy─Бsa prescribed; and sought the wealth that had the queenтАЩs seal on it. Their qualities began slipping from them little by little. Brahminism became merely dynastic. They forgot ancient teachings and used their education, intellect and training to earn money. If they had at least remembered the old тАЬrichesтАЭ, their plight would not be as sorry as it is now. Because the Br─Бhmaс╣Зa forgot his true nature and the true wealth of his glorious lineage, it gave an opportunity for others to say тАЬthis fellow is the same as others; he is just one among a thousand others. What is so great about him?тАЭ. If he had not forgotten his own wealth, he would not have been censured by others. A little br─Бhmaс╣Зya would still remain in him. When others complain that many official posts are occupied by this caste called brahmins, a real br─Бhmaс╣Зa should introspect about it with poignancy, and not argue that a br─Бhmaс╣Зa is just more capable of earning. A br─Бhmaс╣Зa may be capable and successful in worldly work; but the question is whether he has preserved his dispassion, calmness, penance and friendliness for the whole world. The story of the Brahmin community in the past one hundred and fifty years is testimony to the fact that there is a high possibility of p─Бpa in worldly transactions.

Valour, courage, power, strength, ability to work, steadfastness in war тАФ these are the characteristics of a kс╣гatriya. A kс╣гatriya is one in whom these qualities are inborn. The world needs him to dexterously rule over the state. Just as we cannot include a money-minded brahmin in a group of br─Бhmaс╣Зas, we cannot consider an incapable man as a kс╣гatriya.

Similarly, a person skilful in agriculture, commerce and wealth management is a vai┼Ыya.

A ┼Ыudra is one who is not capable of owning any work, but can perform tasks that are given to him by people more capable than him. It is easier for him to exert himself physically rather than intellectually; and to follow rather than think freely.
There are four services that are absolutely necessary for the wellbeing of any human society: 1. Education 2. Protection 3. Wealth and prosperity 4. Labour. If even one of these malfunctions, there will be deficiencies in the well-being of the society. They are all equally important. The skills required for them are respectively 1. Intellectual labour and self-restraint 2. Courage and strength 3. Mechanisms and strategies for making profit 4. Taking care of oneтАЩs bodily health and ability to follow rules. These four qualities are not present in any one man in equal proportion. It is even difficult to find two or three in one person. It is common to see one quality being dominant and that the other qualities are present in small amounts. The karma of a person is decided based on the quality that is predominant, varс╣Зa is decided according to the karma. This is the secret of the system of varс╣Зas. The fundamental concept here is that everyone is not equally capable of doing all work. Therefore, people should introspect about their strengths and qualities and choose a profession accordingly.

This is opposite to the theory of universal equality that is being propounded in recent times. The mainstay of this argument is тАФ тАЬwhat man has done, man can doтАЭ. It can only be a feeling in the mind but not practically feasible. V─Бsudev─Бc─Бrya was a musician (a v─Бggeyakara of the twentieth century, in the court of Mysore Wodeyars.) . Can we all sing like him? Yes, we might тАФ if we practice for a hundred lives. But my throat that sings then is not my throat of today; not that of the present life. A man who is skillful in handling machines should not be asked to become a schoolteacher. A mechanic shows skill with machines. A school teacher has oratory skills that can show the universe on his palm. Society will benefit if people are engaged in tasks that they are skillful at, tasks that they have natural inclination for. That is the right economy тАФ the ability to reap more out of less investment. A pin that is used to pierce paper to set them together is made by some man. I am also a man. Can I make a pin? Yes, it is possible, if I am given a boundless amount of material and infinite time. But a man who has received training for this job can make a thousand pins in a minute. There are some musicians amongst us. Bhagav─Бn Brahma has forgotten to give them a good voice. For some reason, they think that they know music; they struggle to fix their voice. We listen to their struggle; however, we still havenтАЩt had the good fortune to listen to and enjoy any meaningful outcome of the struggle. Thus, our efforts that disregard our natural strengths and weaknesses are not economical.

The vast diversity of human qualities, strengths, propensities and inclinations of humans has great use in the order of the universe. Because there is inequality, one man is curious about, and respects another. Because there is inequality, a man requires anotherтАЩs help. Because there is diversity and inequality there is opportunity for friendship. We have seen that the Greek philosopher Plato has expressed the same opinion. If everyone becomes a musician, who will listen? If everyone becomes a doctor, who will get treated? If everyone becomes a teacher, who will learn? We need what we lack, from others. This is how we become friends with others. Because of inequality, one person feels friendly and respectful towards others. Because of diversity, we need one another.

In the present times, we are profusely misusing words like unity, equality, freedom, etc. It does not mean that these words do not have any meaning; they indeed have a beautiful meaning. People are merely uttering these words without understanding their true meaning, and with nary a thought to propriety or circumstance. It is similar to tying up the G─лt─Б in a cloth (Texts with powerful mantras are to be tied in silk cloth and kept safe from prying eyes and hands), noting that Bhagav─Бn said тАФ

idaс╣Г te n─Бtapask─Бya n─Бbhakt─Бya kad─Бcana рее
BG 18.67

This is a great sentence, pregnant with meaning. The word тАЬequalityтАЭ is like that. It is easy to misunderstand it. One must therefore be careful. Diversity and inequality are the arrangement of prakс╣Ыti. Because of them, people need one another, through which friendship and respect grows among people. Swami alludes to this wonderful principle in the chapter about karmayoga:

parasparaс╣Г bh─Бvayantaс╕е ┼Ыreyaс╕е param av─Бpsyatha рее
BG 3.11

Some disparity is seen in the system of varс╣Зas and karma. Descriptions such as тАФ br─Бhmaс╣Зa is the mouth, kс╣гatriyas are the shoulders, vai┼Ыyas are the thighs and ┼Ыudras are the feet тАФ have become cause for objection. The objection is born of unthinking folly. From the point of view of the society, all karmas are equally required. What is the objective here? Firstly, the impurity of the three guс╣Зas in an individual should erode. Secondly, his capability and strengths should flourish; thirdly, the workplace for these two objectives is to transact with the world. Fourthly, the world should benefit from the expression of his qualities and strengths. Thus, the objectives of a dharmic karma are individual elevation and the well-being of the whole world. From this perspective, an individualтАЩs wealth, prestige, and authority are not very important. Service to the whole world is important; service to the divine is important; oneтАЩs own profit and prestige are not. The path of our karma is what agrees with our nature.

[[Ch 18 Yoga of Single-pointed Surrender (Part 10) Source: prekshaa]]

While bringing up a baby, is one who feeds milk superior and one who cleans the cradle is inferior? Is the person who rocks the cradle superior to the one who takes the baby to the toilet? Due to the love a mother has for the baby, she is equi-poised towards all activities that have to be done to keep him healthy and happy. There is no evaluation of the work as superior or inferior. Even in the service of Bhagav─Бn, it is similar; there is no superior or inferior. ─А├▒janeya carried the mountain; the squirrel carried a little sand^(^([1])).

There was a lady in our town. She had lost her family at a very young age. She was one of the living saints I had seen. She would wake up at four in the morning. Among the temples in the town, there were two or three which were very big; there were four to six smaller temples in one temple. The previous evening, she would visit all places that had cows and collect dung. Before sunrise, she would wake up, mix that dung with water she had carried from the village tank (in those times, there were no taps) in a big vessel. Then she would go to the temple, sweep, mop and clean it with this water, while singing devaran─Бmas^(^([2])). Then she would decorate the premises with rangoli^(^([3])). In this way, all seven days of the week she had a menial job without salary. She had some fields that provided enough to eat once a day. Think about this life. Whose devotion is more тАФ devotion of those who perform sahasra-bilv─Бrcana and lakс╣гa-mallige arcana^(^([4]))? Or that of this lady? Can anyone say that the service a br─Бhmaс╣Зa performs to Bhagav─Бn is superior to that performed by others?

The same is expressed by Browning in his verse drama тАЬPippa PassesтАЭ. Pippa was a worker girl in a silk factory in Italy. She was an orphan. She had only one holiday in the whole year, the day of the new year. Once the day of the new year arrived. She thought тАЬI should be very happy todayтАЭ, and singing thus with a pure and light heart, went about the town :

GodтАЩs in His Heaven,
AllтАЩs right with the world.

This song was heard by some people who were engaged in some wrongdoing, and they all felt a little remorseful. She did not have any intention of elevating them. She didnтАЩt even know that such people existed. She thought everyone was good, and had no notion of bad. Her song influenced many people for the better. Another part of the song is this:

All service ranks the same with God ;
If now, as formerly, He trod
Paradise, His presence fills
Our earth. Each only as God wills
Can work тАФ GodтАЩs puppets, best and worst
Are we. There is no last nor first.

We are all toys in the hands of the divine тАФ all of us. Who is first, and who is last? All services rank equally in divine calculation. Whatever karma one performs, it culminates according to his divine will. This is the essence of тАЬtena vin─Б tс╣Ыс╣Зamapi na calatiтАЭ. This is the idea of the story in Kenopaniс╣гad. Bhagav─Бn might order some people to sweep the floor. He might ask some others to carry and bring water. He might say to some others to roll the carpet. The others might be asked to sit quiet and answer when someone walks in. We are all toys in his hands. We act according to the movement of his string, There is nothing in this world that is too insignificant. Nor is there anything that suprasses everything else in importance. From the point of view of service, everything is equal. This is the perspective of the poet Browning. This is seen in the R─Бm─Бyaс╣Зa also.─А├▒janeyacarried a hill, whereas the squirrel carried a little sand. There was a difference in capabilities; but there was equality in the mindset.

The poet Milton became blind. He prayed thus тАЬGod, you took away my eyes and deprived me of my daylight. Now my life is perpetually night. What service can I perform? But I have one satisfaction:

тАж. God doth not need
Either manтАЩs work or his own gifts. Who best
Bear his mild yoke, they serve Him best. His state
Is kingly : thousands at His bidding speed
And post oтАЩer land and ocean without rest;
They also serve who only stand and wait.
On his blindness

тАЬBhagav─Бn does not need manтАЩs service. He does not need the naivedyas and offerings given to him. The benefit is anyway to the person who performed it. Bhagav─Бn imposes a tax of duty upon man. Those who accept it without protest are his servants. Bhagav─Бn is an emperor. Thousands of people run about on land and sea to do his bidding. They are all his servants. If he orders some of them to not walk about and stay put in one place as sentries, doing that is also a service to him. The divine gave me blindness and asked me to stay in one place. This is also a service to him. I do this service happily.

The opinion of both Browning and Milton is about following instructions without fail. Our chance to elevate ourselves is the position, profession, worldly karma that has fallen to our lot by divine design. The G─лt─Б instructs us to use it like that. The teaching embedded in the story of Dharmavy─Бdha in the Mah─Бbh─Бrata is also the same.

In the present age, our world has become a toy in the hands of the greed-fiend. Various sciences, machinery and other technologies are finding their culmination in creating wealth. Food, clothes, vehicles and ostentation are the ultimate life-goals for everyone. Countries compete with one another, as do humans. Brothers compete with one another. In this mad marathon, the differentiating lines between different family professions has been erased. The job of a br─Бhmaс╣Зa is not encouraged. There is no opportunity for a kс╣гatriya at all. Where is he now? TodayтАЩs soldier just deploys bombs. TodayтАЩs ruler is a representative of all people. So a kс╣гatriya is jobless. No one likes to be called a ┼Ы┼лdra now. IsnтАЩt it todayтАЩs slogan that everyone is equal to everyone else in all ways? Who in the world is ready to serve someone else? Therefore the only profession that is left in todayтАЩs world is that of vai┼Ыyas. Earning money itself is the dharma for everyone now. Those who call themselves brahmins are at the forefront in this path. It cannot be said that engineering, medicine and law are brahminical professions. A clerkтАЩs job is also not special to a brahmin. No one can argue that government service is for a brahmin. When the British stepped into India, they had to take the help of Indians for their service and help. Then, brahmins who were rooted traditionally in jobs of the intellect rushed to learn English and gained offices and government posts. Other varс╣Зas followed them. With this joined the attraction of other professions born out of the influence of the industrial revolution in Europe. The old system of occupations collapsed. Thus, the world is wearing a different facade in various ways. Thought for earning a livelihood has increased, and that for looking into oneself has decreased. The stomach is itself divine, tasty food is heaven. This is the plight of todayтАЩs br─Бhmaс╣Зya :

yuge yuge tu ye dharm─Бs-tatra tatra ca ye dvij─Бс╕е ред
teс╣г─Бс╣Г nind─Б na kartavy─Б yugar┼лp─Б hi te dvij─Бс╕е рее
Par─Б┼Ыara smс╣Ыti 1.33

These are the words of Par─Б┼Ыara. A br─Бhmaс╣Зa has not transcended time. Then, does he not have to do anything to preserve the dharma of his lineage? Should he follow the wind, thinking that time is against him? That is not dharma.

sarvan─Б┼Ыe samutpanne hyardhaс╣Г tyajati paс╣Зс╕Нitaс╕е рее Subh─Бс╣гita-ratna-samuccaya
(When there is a possibility of complete loss, a wise man gives up half of it).

Dharma is to try to preserve as much br─Бhmaс╣Зa-dharma as possible тАФ the more the better тАФ even during adverse times. Brahmanism can be seen from two perspectives: 1. Satya 2. ┼Ъama 3. ┼Ъauca 4. Lokamaitri^(^([5])) 5. J─лva-saс╣Гsk─Бra^(^([6])) 6. J├▒─Бna-vij├▒─Бna-s─Бdhana^(^([7])) 7. Worshipping the divine 8. Virakti (dispassion). These eight are the qualities of the ─Бtm─Б тАФ qualities of the mentality. Even if the external conditions become atrociously wicked, these qualities of the manas do not need to change. The mark of a br─Бhmaс╣Зa is to keep oneтАЩs mind under strict control, not giving worldly changes any authority over his ─Бtm─Б, and not letting his mentality change under any circumstance. This is the first duty of abr─Бhmaс╣Зa. The second duty is to choose a profession that does not come in the way of practising the first. One should always look for a profession which does not merely profit monetarily, but does not prevent the practice of satya and ┼Ыauca as much as possible. Once such a job is found, he must excel at it and must be content. It is not wrong to desire to profit from oneтАЩs profession; but there is always the danger that it might prod him in the wrong direction. One should be careful about such dangers, and should be skilful in his job. This is the second duty of the br─Бhmaс╣Зa. There is a third duty too. He should eke out some free time from his worldly duties and spend it in the study of the vedas and ┼Ы─Бstras, instead of wasting it in frivolous activities. There is no one who does not have one day a week or one day a fortnight free. TodayтАЩs labour laws urge that labourers should receive holiday at least for some time in a week. Dedicating an hour or two on such days to the R─Бm─Бyaс╣Зa or the Mah─Бbh─Бrata is not difficult even for the busiest br─Бhmaс╣Зa. Where there is a will, there is a way. If those who call themselves br─Бhmaс╣Зas observe their own words, it is not difficult to realise those words in action, even in these adverse times.
