[[Ch 18 Yoga of Single-pointed Surrender (Part 11) Source: prekshaa]]

Qualities like truth and purity are not the special property of brahmins. They are to be practised by others as well. Why did we specially mention them as brahmaс╣Зic qualities? The real meaning is that an excellent, exemplary br─Бhmaс╣Зa behaves thus, and these qualities are easily practised by him; therefore other varс╣Зas should also try to emulate him and earn those qualities тАФ this is the real meaning.

с╣гve sve karmaс╣Зyabhirataс╕е saс╣Гsiddhiс╣Г labhate narah ред
svakarma-nirataс╕е siddhiс╣Г yath─Б vindati tacchruс╣Зu рее
BG 18.45

Everyone should be engaged in their natural duties. A manтАЩs capability is not decided based on whether the work he has secured is big or small; however insignificant his job is тАФ even if it is only to sweep the road тАФ the quality of his work, the devotion he shows towards his job, his enthusiasm and skill тАФ decide his worth.

During this discussion, it is worthwhile to remember this piece of advice that Sir M Visvesvaraya, the celebrated engineer and the administrator par excellence, gave to young engineers.

тАЬThe bulk of the work in the districts is of a very ordinary character, but it is not on that account to be despised. Many a young engineer may find no higher work to design or construct than a road-culvert or a tank-sluice. A dispensary or a dak bungalow may be his dream in architecture. But whatever the work, if the designs are to be proper and economical, a close study of local conditions and a correct knowledge of how similar work is best done elsewhere are very necessary. The young engineer may lay to heart the advice which Mr. Moberly Bell of the London Times gave on similar occasion. тАЬIf your business,тАЭ said he, тАЬis only to sweep a crossing, remember that it is your duty to make that crossing the best swept in the world.тАЭ
(14th November 1910)

The performance of oneтАЩs dharma through the performance of oneтАЩs own duties is indeed the worship of the divine. He who is engaged in the performance of svadharma attains siddhi.
That it is possible to attain siddhi through the performance of oneтАЩs dharma is one of the cardinal teachings of the G─лt─Б.

yataс╕е pravс╣Ыttir bh┼лt─Бn─Бс╣Г yena sarvam idaс╣Г tatam ред
sva-karmaс╣З─Б tam abhyarchya siddhiс╣Г vindati m─Бnavaс╕е рее
BG 18.46
тАЬThe energy and direction for all actions of every being arise from that root consciousness that has brought forth the entire universe from within itself and pervades it inside out. He, having worshipped the supreme consciousness through the performance of duties that are natural and obligatory to him, attains the greatest siddhi.тАЭ

This ┼Ыloka is pregnant with much meaning. There is likely no better or more apt description of Brahman than this. Neither is there a more concise elucidation of the method to worship Brahman. All-pervading Brahman is the source of every beingтАЩs inner urge that prompts it to perform an action or not. When the impurities of a j─лva - its guс╣Зas and tendencies accumulated through a beginningless succession of lives - are cleansed, the j─лva attains the true experience of his own Self. The mechanism to cleanse oneself of such impurities is dharma in the form of purifying works prescribed via oneтАЩs varс╣Зa or family or stem from oneтАЩs own innate character. Thus, the path towards self-knowledge proceeds through the performance of works that 1. are prescribed by the ┼Ы─Бstras, 2. are useful to the world, and 3. purify the j─лva. Whatever action has to be performed should be performed dexterously and efficiently.

┼Ыrey─Бn sva-dharmo viguс╣Зaс╕е para-dharm─Бt svanuс╣гс╣нhit─Бt
svabh─Бva-niyataс╣Г karma kurvan n─Бpnoti kilbiс╣гam
BG 18.47
тАЬThough not much virtue might be seen in svadharma, it is more beneficial than anotherтАЩs dharma that appears to be more virtuous. One does not incur p─Бpa by performing karma attuned to oneтАЩs own nature.тАЭ

Trading in meat, even if more profitable than the profession of teaching, is not the dharma of a br─Бhmaс╣Зa. Though a butcher might prefer acting in plays or in cinemas over his own profession that he does not like so much, his own family business is his dharma. If one does not perform oneтАЩs dharma, he is subject to p─Бpa. This is the principle explained in the tale of Dharmavy─Бdha^(^([1])).

sahajaс╣Г karma kaunteya sa-doс╣гam api na tyajet
sarv─Бrambh─Б hi doс╣гeс╣Зa dh┼лmen─Бgnir iv─Бvс╣Ыt─Бс╕е
BG 18.48
тАЬOne should not give up duties that are part of oneтАЩs nature and are established through oneтАЩs own community, even though they might seem to be faulty from othersтАЩ perspectives. Every profession in this world is fraught with one defect or the other - just as fire is always enveloped in smoke.тАЭ

Hari┼Ыchandra, due to circumstances of time and duty, had to stay guard at a funeral-ground. Was that a joyous duty? It does not seem so to us. When fate brought him to that place, he had to fulfil his duties as they had to be fulfilled. Thus, even when his wife Candramat─л carried the corpse of their son Lohit─Б┼Ыva, he insisted, тАЬThe fee due here must be paidтАЭ. There is no place for likes and dislikes during the performance of oneтАЩs duty.

All the smс╣Ыtis accept the opinion stated above. Manu has clarified the same. The following ┼Ыlokas from the atri-saс╣Гhit─Б state the same succinctly with no scope for doubt.

sv─Бni karm─Бс╣Зi kurv─Бс╣З─Б d┼лre santoтАЩpi m─Бnav─Бс╕е ред
priy─Б bhavanti lokasya sve sve karmaс╣Зyavasthit─Бс╕е рее
Atri saс╣Гhit─Б 8.41
Those men immersed in their own duties, even if they are afar, are liked by the world.

ye vyapet─Бс╕е svadharmebhyaс╕е paradharme vyavasthit─Бс╕е ред
teс╣г─Бс╣Г ┼Ы─Бstikaro r─Бj─Б svargaloke mah─лyate рее
That king, who chastises those established in othersтАЩ duties while neglecting their own, reigns in svarga.

─Бtm─лye saс╣Гsthito dharme ┼Ы┼лdroтАЩpi svargama┼Ыnute ред
paradharmo bhavet ty─Бjyaс╕е sur┼лpa-parad─Бravat рее Even a ┼Ы┼лdra established in his own dharma attains svarga. Thus anotherтАЩs dharma is to be discarded like anotherтАЩs wife, beautiful though she might be.

Plato, the pre-eminent Greek philosopher and considered the foremost among truth-seekers from all over the world, has again and again elucidated the concept of svadharma in his Republic - bolstering it with arguments and examples.

тАЬJustice is the having and doing of what is a manтАЩs own and belongs to himтАЭ
Republic. Book IV.

Can an activity that has no touch of p─Бpa even exist? Though every activity has the possibility of association with p─Бpa, it should not become an excuse for us to stay away from action. Activity has to be performed. The question is whether it attaches to us or not. If the activity in question comes to us naturally as an obligation, there is no attachment. There are several situations in which we may have to do something that we either do not like or is not considered proper by society at large. Bhagav─Бn refers to activities as - тАЬaniс╣гс╣нamiс╣гс╣нaс╣Г mi┼Ыraс╣Г caтАЭ - those that we like, those that we do not like and those that we like partially. Whatever may be the obligatory duty, there is no defect in its performance as long as there is no tinge of selfishness. That indeed is phalaty─Бga (giving up the fruit of actions) and the essence of saс╣Гny─Бsa (renunciation). When we perform karma in that manner, our impurities in the form of the three guс╣Зas are eroded. Our v─Бsanas (latent tendencies) are weakened. Qualities, virtues, and strengths that are hidden in our psyche are brought to light. This is conducive to goodness in the world. Erosion of the j─лvaтАЩs debts and impurities and an expression of the j─лvaтАЩs sattva make it easier to attain param─Бtm─Б.

However, in the twelfth chapter, Bhagav─Бn instructs us to give up all endeavours!

sarv─Бrambhaparity─Бg─л yo madbhaktaс╕е sa me priyaс╕е ред
BG 12.16

Whatever may be the endeavour, it is not free of one defect or the other. This is the instruction from the twelfth.
But in this chapter, Bhagav─Бn mandates us to perform suitable activity without worrying about accompanying defects, for no action is truly defect-free. Thus on the surface, there seems to be some disagreement between these two teachings. There is another verse that resolves this inconsistency.

yasya sarve sam─Бrambh─Бс╕е k─Бma-saс╣Еkalpa-varjit─Бс╕е ред
j├▒─Бn─Бgni-dagdha-karm─Бс╣Зaс╣Г tam─Бhuс╕е paс╣Зс╕Нitaс╣Г budh─Бс╕е рее
BG 4.19

There is the possibility of an iota of p─Бpa in all human activity. Even so, there is a strategy to completely negate even this sliver of p─Бpa from our activities. The strategy is an attitude of desirelessness. тАЬIt is not me who acts. This action is not for me. Whatever is done is being done in subservience to Bhagav─Бn. The guс╣Зas of prakс╣Ыti make us act. Results of those actions accrue to us via the laws of karma. I am ready for any kind of result. The decision to perform karma is not to be made from the perspective of my benefit, enjoyment, or prestige. By virtue of prior karma, I have attained a certain position and a specific set of opportunities in the world. It is from this understanding that I can decide upon dharma. My karma follows suit.тАЭ An action performed with the sole sense of duty after exercising such discernment does not result in p─Бpa, for there is no ego in it but obedience towards Bhagav─Бn. This is the essence of the principle of karma.

[[Ch 18 Yoga of Single-pointed Surrender (Part 12) Source: prekshaa]]

asaktabuddhiс╕е sarvatra jit─Бtm─Б vigataspс╣Ыhaс╕е ред
naiс╣гkarmyasiddhiс╣Г param─Бс╣Г saс╣Гny─Бsen─Бdhigacchati рее
BG 18.49

The word naiс╣гkarmya is used repeatedly in the ┼Ы─Бstras. It refers to a state of absence of p─Бpa when there is no activity being performed - a state without anxiety, a state of pure knowledge. For those in this state, karma is not a bondage. It is not that they do not perform karma; but that karma does not bind them anymore. Such people can perform karma - but of their own happy volition. They freely perform action for the welfare of the world, while considering it as their own self. Yaj├▒as such as the agniс╣гс╣нoma and the v─Бjapeya described in In our ┼Ы─Бstras, building food donation houses, performing vratas, charity, and others are considered to be karma. We have seen that life in its entirety can be considered a yaj├▒a in the extended sense of the term. Therefore, by the word karma can be understood both vaidika rites - daily, occasional and desired, and laukika activities. Man has an abundance of sense organs and motor instruments. All these tools have to be used in performing karma as the worship of ─к┼Ыvara : тАЬsvakarmaс╣З─Б tamabhyarchyaтАЭ (having worshipped him by oneтАЩs karma). The fruit of oneтАЩs karma is the ripening of the manas. It is commonly (and erroneously) thought that the knowledge of the ─Бtm─Б is a result of ┼Ы─Бstric study, intellectual sleights, and feats of logic; and that the knowledge of Brahma arises from scholarship and cerebral gymnastics. For this to happen, however, the mind must mature. Some lentils do not cook easily. One might have to use soda and other agents to hasten the process. The manas, likewise, might have become hard or soft. It is a problem even if it is as hard as a rock or all soft and gloppy. The rock has to be melted and softened while the glop has to be dried and hardened. This is possible only with worldly experience. There is contact with the world during the course of an activity. During such contact, friction amongst j─лvas is inevitable. It is this friction amongst the j─лvas that chastens it. The impurities within and without a j─лva - anger, desire and other mental imperfections - come out during conflict and inter-j─лva friction. The one suffering from indigestion is administered purges by doctors through prescribed medicines. For bodily impurities to leave the body, the alimentary canal must come in contact with medicines and other herbal preparations. Similarly, to purge the impurities of a j─лva such as rajas and tamas, there must be friction among j─лvas. Through the friction with the world induced through karma, hidden self─л┼Ыness and prejudice are uprooted. It is through such friction that a mind is perfected. The manas is the bridge between the j─лva and the ─Бtm─Б. It has therefore been said -

тАЬmana eva manuс╣гy─Бс╣З─Бm k─Бraс╣Зaс╣Г bandha-mokс╣гayoс╕етАЭ
Brahmabind┼лpaniс╣гad 2

It is the manas through which mokс╣гa becomes possible; it is the mind that binds. One can proceed in either direction on a bridge. If one goes from this side to the other - it is mokс╣гa. However, if one comes to this side from the other, it is bondage. The bridge is one - the manas. The manas has to be ripened through the performance of many kinds of activities. Karma therefore should be performed for the purification of the j─лva. ┼Ъr─л Purandarad─Бsa has sung:

тАЬmanava shodhisabeku nicca ред
dinadinavu m─Бс╕Нuva p─Бpa-puс╣Зyada vecca редтАЭ
(The mind must be examined every day.
P─Бpa and puс╣Зya spent every day must be appraised)

We are usually given to think that we perform activity to attain puruс╣г─Бrtha (the primary goals of life). Why should we act? To earn a living. Why again do we act? With an expectation that Bhagav─Бn might grant us a little more if whatever we have earned is not enough. There are thus several reasons for our work. It is Bhagav─БnтАЩs instruction to perform any work as a worship of ─к┼Ыvara. Such a performance of duty is the path to the knowledge of the ─Бtm─Б.
The perfection of the j─лva does not happen in a vacuum. Karma is performed on the stage of the world and not in an uninhabited place. The impetus for karma comes from interaction with the world. Therefore the j─лva has to be ground - much like sandalwood - against the grinding stone of worldly interaction. The chunk of sandalwood yields fragrance when ground well on a moistened grinding stone, giving it fulfilment. The j─лva likewise must grind its capabilities against the grindstone of the world wetted with the water of bhakti towards Bhagav─Бn. By grinding thus, the j─лva loses its impurities and becomes fit to experience param─Бtm─Б. Attaining the ─Бtm─Б is possible with such effort.

buddhy─Б vi┼Ыuddhay─Б yukto dhс╣Ыty─Бtm─Бnaс╣Г niyamya ca
┼Ыabd─Бd─лn viс╣гay─Бns tyaktv─Б r─Бga-dveс╣гau vyudasya ca
vivikta-sev─л laghv-─Б┼Ы─л yata-v─Бk-k─Бya-m─Бnasaс╕е
dhy─Бna-yoga-paro nityaс╣Г vair─Бgyaс╣Г samup─Б┼Ыritaс╕е
ahank─Бraс╣Г balaс╣Г darpaс╣Г k─Бmaс╣Г krodhaс╣Г parigraham
vimuchya nirmamaс╕е ┼Ы─Бnto brahma-bh┼лy─Бya kalpate BG 18.51 - 53

First is тАЬvi┼Ыuddhay─Б buddhy─БтАЭ - a purified intellect, which here refers to a clear understanding of the following -
That the world is a mixture of the Self and non-Self,
The Self and non-Self in the world
The eternal and the transient in the world
in the buddhi.

Then comes - тАЬdhс╣Ыty─Бtm─Бnaс╣Г niyamyaтАЭ - the manas has to be firmly restrained. The refinement achieved by the intellect (buddhi) should not instantaneously evaporate. The attraction from sound, sight and other sense-objects should be resisted to help restrain the mind. One must not fall into the trap of sense organs. The word dhс╣Ыti has two meanings - firmness and courage. Both meanings are applicable here. The instruction of the BhagavadG─лt─Б is for those who are ready and willing to restrain themselves. For those who think – тАЬLet our manas, our likes and dislikes, prejudices and passions wander freely. We want complete independenceтАЭ - the G─лt─Б is not for them. Then comes r─Бga-dveс╣гau vyudasya. Vyud─Бsa refers to discarding something. Karma refers to a relationship with the world. Such a relationship should not involve pride and partiality. How can equanimity result without discarding desires and dislikes? Therefore one must give up both infatuation and enmity in human relationships. R─Бga refers to thoughtless infatuation. Whatever mental state is referred to as vy─Бmoha (infatuation) for unworthy objects is referred to as bhakti (devotion) when the objects involved are worthy.

тАЬvivikta-sev─лтАЭ . Vivikta refers to being away from commotion - living in solitude. One must reflect with and within oneself for the rise of discernment. The same is referred to in a verse attributed to ┼Ъr─л ┼Ъaс╣Еkara - тАЬek─Бnte sukham─Бsyat─БmтАЭ (find joy in solitude). The intent here is to prevent others from distracting the mind. Just as j├▒─Бna needs world experience and a desire to understand for its growth, it also needs solitude. We have seen Bhagav─Бn Vy─БsaтАЩs words -

тАЬtatastata┼Ыcoparatiс╕е kriy─Бbhyaс╕етАЭ
Mokс╣гadharmaparva, Mah─Бbh─Бrata
(Gradual abstinence from activities)

We have already seen the following in the G─лt─Б.

┼Ыanaiс╕е ┼Ыanair uparamed buddhy─Б dhс╣Ыti-gс╣Ыih─лtay─Б
BG 6.25

The mind has to be often withdrawn from performing activities. This withdrawal has two benefits. The first is the practice of detachment - тАЬThis work is not attached to meтАЭ. Second, it provides us with an opportunity to reflect upon the good, the bad, and the erroneous in our works. A card player broods after his game, тАЬI should not have played that card, but played the other one insteadтАЭ. The author, after reading his just published work, analyses - тАЬAh! I should have written this segment in that way. It would have been better had this paragraph come before that.тАЭ Thus, withdrawal from activity helps purify the mind. Constant practice of solitude or withdrawal from activity has two benefits - 1. The practice of detachment 2. An opportunity to analyse the mind.

тАЬlaghv─Б┼Ы─лтАЭ : The one intent on meditation should keep his food and sleep light. The brain nods off when the stomach becomes heavy. For the buddhi to be attentive, one must neither be a glutton nor abstain completely from eating; but a moderate eater. The same desired behaviour was earlier referred to as yukt─Бharavih─Бrasya. Similarly, body, mind and speech have to be kept in check. Speaking extroverts the mind, which is then dragged hither and thither by the noise and commotion, scattering its attention to bits. The same situation is caused by dwelling upon conundrums and complications encountered during the study of ┼Ы─Бstra. External contact must be shunned and the feeling that one does not need anything must be practised. This indeed is vair─Бgya (renunciation).
The body requires a few bare necessities. Such facilities, however, should be used as helpers towards gaining ─л┼Ыvara-experience, as mere instruments. Not more. If the mind has to be restrained, unwanted desires and thoughts unrelated to Self-reflection must be given up. With the rise of renunciation, the ego and other mind-games subside.

Parigraha refers to accepting something from others or accumulating something for a rainy day. This is against the spirit of renunciation. As long as there is parigraha, a relationship persists with the world - a feeling of тАЬIтАЭ and тАЬmineтАЭ. The tranquil one who is without anxiety and feelings of тАЬIтАЭ or тАЬmineтАЭ becomes fit for the experience of Brahma. What is the need for external security for one who has full faith in Bhagav─Бn? тАЬAs ─к┼Ыvara wills itтАЭ, is renunciation. But he who thinks, тАЬLet us exercise caution lest Bhagav─Бn forgetsтАЭ practises parigraha. тАЬWhen I am pensioned, my income will be halved. Let me make up for it by accepting bribesтАЭ - is parigraha. Thoughts such as, тАЬLet me lead a life with an income earned through just means. If it is not enough for my ghee^(^([1])), I do not want gheeтАЭ, indicate vair─Бgya.

[[Ch 18 Yoga of Single-pointed Surrender (Part 13) Source: prekshaa]]

The nature of aparigraha (non-acceptance of superfluous material wealth) is well described in the story of Uс╣гasti in the Ch─Бndogyopaniс╣гad.

Uс╣гasti was a br─Бhmaс╣Зa living in the land of Kuru-p─Б├▒c─Бla. Hailstorms destroyed all the crops in the land causing a drought. People began to head out of their homes in search of food. So did Uс╣гasti and his wife. Uс╣гasti could not bear the pangs of hunger. His wife had become inured to hunger; she was emaciated and her body had become a bag of bones. Uс╣гasti felt that he could not live any longer without some food. By then both of them had reached a village of mahouts (ibhya). A mahout was eating beans. Uс╣гasti implored, тАЬDear man, I am feeling very hungry. Can you give me something to eat?тАЭ. The mahout gave him some of the same boiled beans he had been eating - leftovers usually considered impure. Though Uс╣гasti was a br─Бhmaс╣Зa, he accepted the leftover beans so that he could sustain his life. The mahout then offered him some water to drink. But Uс╣гasti refused. The surprised mahout asked, тАЬYou consumed those beans. Why not this water?тАЭ. Uс╣гasti replied - тАЬDrinking water is indeed necessary. But that is available elsewhere. The drought is for food, not water. You gave me food that sustained my life. For water, I will go to the pond or the lake outside the village. I cannot accept from you what I can get elsewhere.тАЭ Such is aparigraha.
Uс╣гasti then offered some of the same boiled beans to his wife. She refused. Uс╣гasti asked - тАЬI have eaten whatever is needed to sustain life; but some beans are leftover.тАЭ She preserved the leftover beans for the next day. They felt hungry when they proceeded further. He ate the previous dayтАЩs leftover beans his wife gave him.

One can take from others only that which is essential to sustain life. One should not accept non-essential things from others. This is the essence of aparigraha.

We have seen earlier that life is a set of give-and-take transactions with the world. Every moment, we take something from the world; and give the world something else in return. This can be seen in our breathing. The essence of aparigraha is in minimising what we take from the world while maximising what we give back to it.

The means for Brahma-experience is not intellectual ability but moral self-discipline. HereтАЩs where we lose the plot. We look for Brahma in grammar, nighaс╣Зс╣нu (Vedic lexicon), feats of logical manipulation, series of arguments, indicated in the Vivekac┼лс╕Н─Бmaс╣Зi as “v─Бgvaikhar─л ┼Ыabdajhar─л ┼Ы─Бstravy─Бkhy─Бnakau┼Ыalam” (ornate speech, flow of words, dexterity in interpreting the ┼Ы─Бstras). We memorise verses and commentaries and quote them when an opportunity arises. We casually utter words such as Brahma, m─Бy─Б, ─Бtm─Б, j─лva, j├▒─Бna, karma, prakс╣Ыti, and pr─Бrabdha without any thought. Has the principle of reality been experienced by us? The characteristics of one who has experienced reality is described thus:

brahmabh┼лtaс╕е prasann─Бtm─Б na ┼Ыocati na k─Бс╣Еkс╣гati.
samaс╕е sarveс╣гu bh┼лteс╣гu madbhaktiс╣Г labhate par─Бm
BG 18.54
“Always gracious, he has no sorrow or desire. He has the same love towards all beings. He has supreme devotion towards param─Бtm─Б.”

Every activity of such a brahm─Бnubhav─л stems from his love of the Supreme Brahma.

Prasanna refers to love or grace. A gracious thing gives pleasure to those who see it. The mind gets disturbed when it sees certain objects or scenes. It can become angry or lose itself in joy. Being prasanna is not something that intoxicates. The state of prasannat─Б is one wherein the mind is neither agitated nor fickle. We find prayers such as “Lakс╣гm─л Venkate┼Ыvara Prasanna” at the head of traditional wedding invitations. The intent here is for Bhagav─Бn to be pleased towards us without any doubts or peeves. Words such as pras─лda or pras─Бda have the same import. One who has experienced Brahma will have a similar nature of being ever pleased or gracious.

A brahm─Бnubhav─л does not wish to possess anything; neither does he grieve when something is lost. He regards everyone - sama (equally). We have earlier discussed the word - sama - one of those words that is easily prone to misinterpretation. Love is equal; but its practice changes with circumstance.

madbhaktiс╣Г labhate par─Бm рее
BG 18.54

Here, bhakti is referred to as something that a person labhate (obtains) - which makes us ask - was there no bhakti till now? The answer is that the bhakti till now was one that was either fickle or divided among many objects. But the one who has experienced Brahma attains par─Б-bhakti - undivided devotion only towards Supreme Brahma. Through such bhakti -

bhakty─Б m─Бm abhij─Бn─Бti y─Бv─Бn ya┼Ы-c─Бsmi tattvataс╕е
tato m─Бс╣Г tattvato j├▒─Бtv─Б vi┼Ыate tad-anantaram

Possessed with one-pointed devotion towards Supreme Brahma, he sees everything as a symbol of Brahma and experiences Brahma in its totality. He realises the true nature of Brahma vis-a-vis faux appearances of Brahma. He also understands what m─Бy─Б is, why the world was created, and what those things are that constitute the world. He gains a true understanding of Brahma as well as that of the world.

Does a knower of Brahma renounce the world and its concomitant dharma and karma? Certainly not.

sarva-karm─Бс╣Зy-api sad─Б kurv─Бс╣Зo mad-vyap─Б┼Ыrayaс╕е

тАЬThe true bhakta constantly performs every ordained activity with the realisation that whatever worldly belongings he considers his own have been bestowed upon him by Bhagav─Бn. Hence he surely obtains the blessings of Bhagav─Бn. He then attains Bhagav─БnтАЩs eternal abode.тАЭ

It is now clear that there is no inconsistency between the knowledge of Brahma and the performance of karma. The activities of the Brahma-knower are but an external expression of his Brahma-experience. With this instruction, ArjunaтАЩs course of action is clear. Even if he were only after mokс╣гa without any desire for power or kingdom or fame, he would still need to perform his duty. Such is dh─Бrmic activity which, through activities prescribed in the ┼Ы─Бstras - such as worship of Bhagav─Бn - causes the welfare of the world and consequently concludes in the welfare of the individual.

With the conclusion being established, Bhagav─Бn now summarizes the instruction.

cetas─Б sarva-karm─Бс╣Зi mayi sannyasya mat-paraс╕е

If, however, you do not accept this and consider yourself as the sole cause and doer, you will be ruined.

yadahaс╣Еk─Бram─Б┼Ыritya na yotsya iti manyase.

тАЬIf you, however, delude yourself into thinking that you are all-competent; and vow to stop fighting, your vow will sooner or later come to nought. The kс╣гatriya-nature latent in you will impel you and propel you into action.тАЭ

You might at first sit with crossed arms resisting battle. However, others will surely start the war. The war trumpet will be blown. Elephants and horses will rush in. Armies will strike each other with weapons. Cries of pain and horror will ensue. When those shrieks reach your ears, when your eyes see that river of blood, your true nature that is well-hidden inside you will get provoked. What then will happen? Instead of fighting with a suffusion of sattva as an offering to Brahma, you will fight with an exuberance of rajas without remembering Brahma, while being controlled by prakс╣Ыti.

svabh─Бvajena kaunteya nibaddhaс╕е svena karmaс╣З─Б. ред

Now Bhagav─Бn enunciates the gears and wheels of the world-machine in a mah─Бv─Бkya^(^([1])).

The work of ─л┼Ыvara is said to be two-fold here. First - тАЬ─л┼Ыvara is at the heart-centre of all beingsтАЭ. [[Ch 18 Yoga of Single-pointed Surrender (Part 14) Source: prekshaa]]

In the phrase, ─л┼Ыvaraс╕е sarvabh┼лt─Бn─Бm, ─л┼Ыvara is not to be taken as the same as the absolute aspect of Parabrahma. ─к┼Ыvaratva is an aspect or a state of ParabrahmaтАЩs l─лl─Б. It is normally referred to as k─Бrya-Brahma (Brahma as an effect). Supreme Brahma is without activity. When it appears to be active in the world, it is known as k─Бrya-Brahma or ─л┼Ыvara. Whenever we consider either activity or the world, an element of m─Бy─Б is involved. Volition, activity and such transactions have m─Бy─Б as their origin. Therefore ─л┼Ыvara is the state of Brahma when conjoined with m─Бy─Б. It is because of this that ─л┼Ыvara becomes the cause of m─Бy─Б.

─к┼Ыvaraс╕е…bhr─Бm─Бy─Бn sarvabh┼лt─Бni…m─Бyay─Б рее

M─Бy─Б is the set of attractions and repulsions in the world. Where is the origin of these attractions and repulsions? In the objects of the world? Or in the j─лva who is in contact with those objects through his sense-organs? The answer is - in both. Just as humans have two feet, m─Бy─Б too has two parts - one established in the structure of the world and another in the perceiver of world-objects. M─Бy─Б can show her influence when she is firmly standing on both her feet. What are those effects? M─Бy─БтАЩs influence is in concealing an objectтАЩs true nature while projecting another objectтАЩs form. A cataract-afflicted person walking in a moonlit night mistakes an approaching saс╣Гny─Бsi for his householdтАЩs lady cook. Such is the effect of m─Бy─Б.

A man is walking through the woods at dusk. His eyes perceive a swirling snake. He scampers away. Another passerby hits that object with his stick. It becomes clear that the object was not a snake but a rope. This is known as the fallacy of the rope and the snake. There are two effects involved here. The first is the concealment of the objectтАЩs innate rope-ness. The second is the projected snake-ness of the object. Concealing an objectтАЩs true form is the ─Бvaraс╣Зa power of m─Бy─Б. Projecting the appearance of another object is *m─Бy─БтАЩ*s power of vikс╣гepa. M─Бy─Б has this effect of not showing things that exist and projecting things that do not exist. This is similar to an artifice described by lawyers - тАЬsuppressio veri, suggestio falsiтАЭ (suppressing truth, suggesting untruth). M─Бy─БтАЩs effect is such. A man is walking on the sea shore in the afternoon. He sees a shiny trinket at a distance. Thinking it to be a jewel, he rushes toward it. But all he sees is a piece of glass. The smooth surface of glass surrounded by the sandy expanse, the rays of the sun from above, and a limitation of the perceiving eye - all combine to create this illusion. It was m─Бy─Б that concealed the objectтАЩs glass-ness that was present and projected a jewel-ness that was non-existent.

Several such examples can be given. A stainless steel dinner plate used by a man perceived to be wealthy can be mistaken to be made of silver! The power of circumstance is such that it can project a different metal than there actually is.
We feel happy whenever we stand in Lalbagh and look around. The lush greenery, the creepers undulating in the breeze, the dancing blossoms and the flowers - all seem to be calling out to us, talking to us, showering their affection on us, and playing with us. But in reality, what we have there are just bark, fibre, resin, twigs, leaves, and dirt! It is m─Бy─Б that shows us soft loveliness in this gross material.

LetтАЩs look now at the allure of anatomy. Skin, flesh, blood, and bones are the same in all bodies. What then is the basis of our saying that one face is more attractive than the other? It cannot just be physiological as all bodily material is similar in all humans. It is a positional arrangement of facial components which might appeal to the eyes of some, not to everybody. It is just an appearance. For those who think that this arrangement is beautiful, it is m─Бy─Б. For those unaffected by it, it is the usual modification of flesh and skin.

mukhaс╣Г ┼Ыleс╣гm─Бg─Бraс╣Г tadapi ca ┼Ыa┼Ы─Бс╣Еkena tulitam
stanau m─Бс╣Гsagranth─л kanakakala┼Ы─Бvityupamitau^(^([1])) рее
Vair─Бgya┼Ыatakam, Bhartс╣Ыhari

Such is the effect of m─Бy─Б. The author of the Bh─Бgavata defines m─Бy─Б thus:

с╣ЫteтАЩrthaс╣Г yatprat─лyeta na prat─лyeta c─Бtmani ред
tadvidy─Бd ─Бtmano m─Бy─БmтАж. рее
Bh─Бgavata 2.9.33

The word artha in the above refers to yath─Бrtha or reality - the nature of a thing as it actually exists. Prat─лti refers to its appearance to our mind in whatever form. Artha is its true form; independent of our perception. Prat─лti is the apparent form that is dependent on our mind and sense-organs.

тАЬInstead of a thingтАЩs true form, another object might appear to us. Upon investigation, however, if the other object that appeared is not perceived or validated in the self, the experience of the appeared object is considered m─Бy─Б.тАЭ
What can be concluded from this? That it is impossible to exactly delineate m─Бy─Б.

Is m─Бy─Б false? Not entirely. It is not without basis and not without effect.

Is m─Бy─Б true then? Again, not entirely. When we focus on the basis of m─Бy─Б, it melts away. The edifice of its effect collapses when we touch it.

The world, its creation, its sustenance, as well as its destruction - are all appearances due to m─Бy─Б. The world itself is m─Бy─Б because it does not have an independent existence. The worldтАЩs form itself is not firm. The world exults, undulates, roams around, dries up, evaporates, or appears manifold. Its form does not endure even for a single moment. The world is thus momentary. But we cannot deny its existence. Neither can we say with certainty that it exists. If we deny its existence, several objects including our body stage a protest - тАЬArenтАЩt we here? Look, we will eat you up. We will beat you up. We will bite youтАЭ - and come fight with us. This is something that is obvious to us during every moment. How can we deny its existence? It is not possible!

Can we then believe that the world exists? It slips away the moment we extend our hands to grasp it. Physicists have realised the difficulty in perceiving the exact nature of the universe. Suppose we attempt to estimate the distance to the moon while standing on planet earth. At that instance, we adjust the telescope to point to the moon at position A. But, in that time, the moon moves to position B. In the time we try to fix the telescope to point to B, the moon would have moved to C. Thus, attempts to measure the physical world become slippery. Its nature changes before we can ascertain its characteristics. The same water does not touch a person standing in a river for more than a moment. The world is thus constantly changing. How can one truly grasp it?

Just as it is impossible to prove that the world does not exist, it is equally impossible to prove that it exists. Leave alone the physical perspective. Even from an ─Бdhy─Бtmic perspective, the world does not endure. What is it that is eternal in the world? Youth? Health? Wealth? Power? Pleasure? Love? All of these thrive for a while and on one fine day, give up their places for their opposites to occupy. How can we then establish that the world exists?

The world is neither existent nor non-existent. The world exists if it is considered existent. It does not exist if itтАЩs not considered to be existent. For one who considers it existent, it eventually becomes void. For one who considers the world a void, it immediately looms large and challenges him.

Whatever does not display complete existence or complete non-existence is m─Бy─Б. M─Бy─Б cannot be considered absolute non-existence or completely false - like a hareтАЩs horns. It has a partial reality that is vy─Бvah─Бrika (transactional). As long as we are embodied, we are in the transactional world at least with reference to our bodies. dharma is created for such a transactional personality. If one transacts in the world with an understanding of dharma, lifeтАЩs burden becomes light. The world will not be a load of logs but a garland of flowers. The burden becomes a garland of blossoms for a j├▒─Бn─л or a yog─л. Such a person would have transcended m─Бy─Б. Having lived a life following the transactional dharma of the world, he crosses the bounds of the world and ascends higher. Until such a crossing, however, the world - and dharma - exist. dharma too is included under the ambit of m─Бy─Б. For one who is beyond m─Бy─Б, there is neither the world nor the limits of dharma. Such a person is an adhidharmi, an avadh┼лta^(^([2])), nothing other than the Self, the seer only of Brahma, and a j─лvanmukta (liberated while still living).

The life of m─Бy─Б is of a moment. But if we forget ourselves in that moment, m─Бy─Б becomes all-powerful and engulfs us. If, however, we are cautious, it will not show itself and moves away by itself.

bh┼лya┼Ыc─Бnte vi┼Ыvam─Бy─Бnivс╣Ыttiс╕е
(In the end is the cessation of the universal m─Бy─Б)
┼Ъvet─Б┼Ыvatara Up.

It is if you think it isnтАЩt and isnтАЩt if you think it is - such is the strange nature of m─Бy─Б. Therefore it is designated anirvacan─лya - which means that it is beyond definitions such as - тАЬit is thusтАЭ - something whose nature cannot be described exactly.

[[Ch 18 Yoga of Single-pointed Surrender (Part 15) Source: prekshaa]]

Let us now look at a story.

A story

There was a wedding in our village in the house of the landlord Shamarao. Shamarao was wealthy and generous. His kin by marriage Bhimarao was also a rich landlord and no less flamboyant. Fifteen cartloads of his people showed up for the wedding. So there were a hundred people from the groomтАЩs side and a similar number from the brideтАЩs side as well. With them were the two or three hundred villagers who participated in the wedding - making it quite the spectacle. The sounds from the wedding orchestra echoed in all directions. Arrangements had been made for the varap┼лj─Б^(^([1])) at the village R─Бma temple. There were several folks bedecked in all their finery, with zari (gold or silver thread) turbans and silk-bordered upper garments, roaming here and there with fulsome smiles under their plush moustaches. All of them are gaily conversing among themselves showering love and enthusiasm. Let us mark one of them - Gundurao, who too is of impressive demeanour with a well-groomed moustache, a gracious smile - who is shaking hands with everyone else and engaged in easy conversation. All those who see him think of him as a well-established member of society. After the varap┼лj─Б rituals were completed, even Gundurao, of his own accord, helps in distributing sandal fragrance, flowers, and betel. Following that was dinner. Gundurao continues his participation there as well - wishing bon appetit to one and all and ordering the food servers around. He makes everyone chant the prayer before eating food and ensures that all the guests get their customary t─Бmb┼лla (a fruit or a coconut with betel leaves) after their meal.

The wedding was celebrated for four days. Gundurao gains confidence from the groomтАЩs side as one on the brideтАЩs side and as belonging to the groomтАЩs side from those on the side of the bride. Both parties praise Gundurao - тАЬIt was because of Gundurao that our work became light! What a helpful person!тАЭ

On the fifth day, all the relatives begin to depart for their places. Then, an uproar ensues. Gold and silver ornaments gifted to the groom have disappeared! Finery and jewellery kept aside for the bride have vanished! There is much mayhem on both the brideтАЩs and groomтАЩs sides. All of them insist - тАЬCall that Gundrao. He can find out what happenedтАЭ. But where is Rao now? No one knows. Bhimarao asked Shamaro, тАЬWhere sir, is your Mr. Rao?тАЭ Shamarao questions him back - тАЬWhich Mr. Rao, sir?тАЭ to which the answer is - тАЬThe same person - Mr. Gundurao!тАЭ. Shamarao replies - shocked - тАЬAyyo! IsnтАЩt he from your side? I thought he was from your side!тАЭ

To ShamaraoтАЩs eyes, Gundurao belonged to BhimaraoтАЩs side whereas Bhimaro thought that Gundurao was on ShamaraoтАЩs side. But in reality, he belonged to neither side. He came from an unknown place, played his tricks, and left for some other place. In the days he was there, he attracted them, made both sides trust him, and finally cheated them. That is m─Бy─Б.

The matter does not end by cursing Gundurao. Who was it that facilitated and encouraged his sleight of hand? Shamarao was dumbstruck while Bhimarao was stupefied. That is avidy─Б. Avidy─Б is not the lack of formal education. It is a deficiency in perception. If the buddhi that had to climb ten stairs collapses on the sixth stair, it is avidy─Б that is the cause. The situation wherein the knowledge-power of the j─лva is burdened and weakened by latent tendencies of endless lives is denoted in the ┼Ы─Бstras as avidy─Б. It is a deficiency in knowledge, the incapability of the buddhi.

The teeth in our mouth have fallen off because of prakс╣ЫtiтАЩs law of ageing. Pretending to favour us, she force feeds us a banana with a chunk of opium hidden in it. As we do not have teeth, we cannot chew and so the opium slips into our throat without our knowledge. As our tongue tasted the fruit, we relished it. Now, we open our mouths for more. As the opium gets into our stomach, the drug induced high gets to our head. Our lack of teeth is avidy─Б. The fruit with opium is m─Бy─Б. Avidy─Б and m─Бy─Б thus combine to agitate our buddhis. While m─Бy─Б is a world phenomenon, avidy─Б resides in the j─лva.

M─Бy─Б is the charm in the world. Nobody would want to live in the world if m─Бy─Б did not do her job. WasnтАЩt there a jester next to the king in some of our dramas of yore? That jester would encourage all the pleasure cravings of the king and teach him devious ways to attain them. Whenever the king started on any adventure, the jester would prod him on saying - тАЬYes, that is the right thing to do!тАЭ. Finally when the king lost his teeth and got his moustache ripped, the same jester would then pretend to give advice to the king - тАЬO friend, did I not warn you back then?тАЭ and berate him, while laughing inwardly. Such are the noble qualities of a jester. M─Бy─Б plays the role of such a jester in our lives. After we have lived as tenants in a rented house for a while, she makes us argue that it is we who own the house and that the owner is actually an outsider! She makes us think that we own the world, making us forget that the world has another master. It is because of m─Бy─Б that we are attached to the world.

When m─Бy─Б embraces us, we feel pleasure and forget ourselves. Then from her soft, smooth, and lovely limbs exude prickly thorns, making us cry out - тАЬOhhh haaa!тАЭ in agony. When m─Бy─Б retracts those thorns, we are content once again. We choose the deep embrace again and forget ourselves. The hair-thorns and needle-like nails come out again, causing us pain. Her lullaby lulls us yet again into a stupor.

punarapi hasitam punarapi ruditam
punarapi m─Бy─Бsaudhanivasitam рее
(Again the laughter, again the cry,
Again the living in the palace of m─Бy─Б)

******

In trying to understand the extent of Bhagav─БnтАЩs instruction about the structure of the world-machine, the topic of m─Бy─Б was cursorily discussed.

─л┼Ыvaraс╕е sarvabh┼лt─Бn─Бс╣Г hс╣Ыdde┼Ыe.rjuna tiс╣гс╣нhati.
bhr─Бm─Бy─Бnsarvabh┼лt─Бni yantr─Бr┼лс╕Нh─Бni m─Бyay─Б
BG 18.61

The above ┼Ыloka is worthy of much repeated reflection. The more we think of it, many more flashes of meaning become evident to our minds. This ┼Ыloka is verily a mah─Бv─Бkya^(^([2])) .

The yantra referenced here seems to be like the merry-go-round that we see in our fairs and parks. A hemispherical roof blankets a tall pole from which ten or twenty rods descend. Attached to the ends of the rods are swing seats, cradles, and toy animals such as horses, elephants, or peacocks with seats on them. Children then choose to sit on their favourite mounts. The controller of the contraption turns a lever with which the roof starts whirling. The toy animals and cradles, along with their riders, also start whirling with the roof. We do not know if such a machine existed during the age of the Mah─Бbh─Бrata. But this simile suits the world-machine quite nicely.

  1. The merry-go-round is fitted with colourful flags, toys, and buntings and is attractive to the eyes. The world too is attractive to the sense organs. 2. The child sitting on one of the revolving toy horses forgets that it is a toy and imagines it to be a real horse. We too forget that our body is insentient and behave as if life is only a sequence of bodily activities. We also think that this life is eternal. 3. The rider thinks that he is the master of the toy horse and flails about his hands and legs exclaiming, тАЬhup, hup, go!тАЭ, as if he is urging on the horse. He forgets that the operator of the machine is someone else. We too think that we are masters of our lives, and that all our adventures and achievements are of our own doing. We presume that the world is because of us, forgetting the divine master who is the primordial origin of it all. 4. The speed of the rotation overwhelms the rider. In that overwhelmed feeling, he forgets where he is headed and why - showing a lack of discernment. That is delusion. It is the same for us too. The heady euphoria of worldly pleasure overwhelms us. We lose the caution and wisdom to ask ourselves - тАЬWhat is the goal of life? How can we make it fulfilling?тАЭ. This too is delusion. The whirling of the contraption makes the boy forget himself. Engaged in worldly running around, we forget ourselves too. The whirling machineтАЩs form, colour, and speed are attractive for children; wordly form, colour and the pace of activity attract us too. The children surrender to that transient attraction without further thought. So do we. While revolving in the machine, children forget reality and a fantasy takes them over. In worldly m─Бy─Б, we forget our true Self and are wonderstruck by the world.

[[Ch 18 Yoga of Single-pointed Surrender (Part 16) Source: prekshaa]]

There is a set of rules for the riders on the merry-go-round. The rider should proceed in his path and not collide with those ahead of him and those who follow him. Dharma is such a set of rules. If any of those rules is violated - say, the front rider does not leave way for the rider behind him or if a following rider drags the one ahead of him down - it is a sign that the rider has forgotten about the machine operator and that he has to be reminded of it. The behaviour of not troubling others is dharma. It is a kind of conduct. The G─лt─Б itself has told us - тАЬdhruv─Б n─лtiс╕етАЭ. Those who forget right conduct have to be reminded of it. The speed of the machine is maddening. Our body is inert, much like that wooden horse! It is param─Бtm─Б who causes the machine on which the j─лvas are riding to whirl around. How? Through m─Бy─Б.

When we visit the famous Channakeshava temple in Belur, we are so smitten by the exquisite sculptures of the stone-damsels around the temple that we return with no time to have dar┼Ыana of the deity inside the garbha-gс╣Ыha. That is the m─Бy─Б of the external beauty, and of erotic sentiment.

There seem to be two activities in Bhagav─БnтАЩs l─лl─Б.

  1. Maddening us. 2. Curing us of that madness.

He has maddened us by himself; he will cure us of it if we ask him to. Of what kind is that madness? It is the journey of the colourful merry-go-round. Prakс╣Ыti is that merry-go-round that has vividly colourful and brilliant elephants, horses, peacocks and swans. We forget that it is a game that we are playing. What started as a game becomes a violent passion. Just as Bhagav─Бn instructed us before:

─л┼ЫvaroтАЩhamahaс╣Г bhog─л siddhoтАЩhaс╣Г balav─Бn sukh─л
(I am the lord, I am the enjoyer.
I am accomplished, strong and happy!)

Thus are we deluded. We saw earlier that m─Бy─Б is a playful endeavour of prakс╣Ыti. It would be unfair to her if we said that this was the extent of her work. As much as prakс╣Ыti can delude us through m─Бy─Б, she is still truthful. One of her hands shows the manifest truth while the other shows us untruth.

sacca tyacc─Бbhavat ред
Taittir─лya Upaniс╣гat. 2.6.1

While one eye indicates treachery, the other points us to the truth. Trickery in one; cosmic truth in the other. The plant that sprouts according to the seed sown, offspring that resembles its parents, the arrangement of the five great elements according to their effects, the periodic cycle of seasons, the laws of motion of celestial objects, the hand that cooks food while the mouth consumes it - all these are the laws of с╣Ыta^(^([1])) .

ann─Бdbhavanti bh┼лt─Бni parjany─Бdannasambhavaс╕е ред
evaс╣Г pravartitaс╣Г cakram ред
BG 3.14

All these are effects of prakс╣ЫtiтАЩs с╣Ыta.

с╣Ыtaс╣Г satyaс╣Г paraс╣Г brahma
Mah─Бn─Бr─Бyaс╣Зopaniс╣гad

The source of prakс╣Ыti is Brahma that is beyond it. One can transcend prakс╣Ыti by obeying the laws of с╣Ыta and satya that form the beneficial aspect of prakс╣Ыti. Sv─Бmi has said this already:

m─Бmeva ye prapadyante m─Бy─Бmet─Бс╣Г taranti te ред
BG 7.14

It is Bhagav─Бn who has created m─Бy─Б. Therefore to cross m─Бy─Б, one must surrender to Bhagav─Бn while appealing to him - тАЬPlease withdraw your weapon of delusionтАЭ. He restates the same here:

tameva ┼Ыaraс╣Зam gaccha sarvabh─Бvena bh─Бrata ред
tatpras─Бd─Бtpar─Бm ┼Ы─Бntim sth─Бnam pr─Бpsyasi ┼Ы─Б┼Ыvatam рее
BG 18.62
тАЬTake refuge in that ─к┼Ыvara. Keep all of your mind in him and surrender to him. With his grace, you can join his eternal abode and attain lasting peace.тАЭ

With this, Bhagav─Бn gave all the intellectual instruction that Arjuna needed. It is Arjuna who has to make a decision now. The path he chooses should not be at the behest of others; neither should it be a forced obligation. ArjunaтАЩs position at the beginning of the G─лt─Б was one of compassion, with ┼Ыraddh─Б towards dharma, with concern towards world-welfare. But that position arose due to a natural lack of reflection, not borne out of his own discernment. It was not a firm decision established through rigorous intellectual analysis. Whatever activity a person might perform - even with the best of intentions - should be accepted by oneтАЩs own intellect if it has to be fulfilling. Therefore Bhagav─Бn concludes his teaching not with an order or ultimatum to Arjuna, but with a choice. He leaves the final decision to Arjuna -

iti te j├▒─Бnam─Бkhy─Бtam guhy─Бdguhyataram may─Б
vimс╣Ы┼Ыyaitada┼Ыeс╣гeс╣Зa yathecchasi tath─Б kuru
BG 18.63
тАЬArjuna, I have clarified all of your doubts and uncertainties with instructive answers. I have placed wisdom that is the secret of secrets in front of you. Analyse this instruction threadbare, reflect upon the right course of action, and do what you see fit.тАЭ

We have shown that this world is like a merry-go-round and that man is riding in it for enjoyment. Among those riders, it has been shown that there are virtuous ones as well as cheats and rogues. It has been shown that if we forget ourselves in the flow of pleasure, the intoxication gets to our head. It has been shown that the enjoyment in the machine is in its speed of movement. We have shown that when intoxicated, the rider forgets the original maker and operator of the machine and thinks that he is the owner. Once the maker was forgotten, riders could start fighting each other over who was the most important. In such a situation, it became the riderтАЩs duty then, to remember the original creatorтАЩs importance and after punishing the errant riders, instruct them too about the truth of the existence of the contraptionтАЩs maker. It has been shown that the judicious and orderly use of the machine constituted dharma and that the first treatment for the intoxication was to remember the existence of the owner of the merry-go-round. Both the origin of m─Бy─Б and the method to uproot it have been shown. There is nothing else left for instruction. What remains now is oneтАЩs own reasoned reflection.

In order to bring his remembrance to our minds, Bhagav─Бn causes obstacles and setbacks in our lives. Therefore the ┼Ы─Бstras praise hardships in many ways. Bhagav─Бn instructs us in the Bh─Бgavata :

yasy─Бham anugс╣Ыhс╣З─Бmi hariс╣гye tad-dhanaс╣Г ┼Ыanaiс╕е ред
tato тАЩdhanaс╣Г tyajanty asya svajan─Б duс╕еkha-duс╕еkhitam рее
sa yad─Б vitathodyogo nirviс╣Зс╣Зaс╕е sy─Бd dhanehay─Б
mat-paraiс╕е kс╣Ыta-maitrasya kariс╣гye mad-anugraham рее
Bh─Бgavata 10.88-89
тАЬWhen I decide to bestow my grace upon him, I take his money away from him without him knowing. Once he becomes poor, his people leave him. He becomes sorrowful and distressed without wealth and appropriate activity. If he then takes recourse to me (Bhagav─Бn) and surrenders to me, I will bestow my grace upon him.тАЭ

When a man possesses wealth and other comforts of life, man believes that his life is only because of them and forgets Bhagav─Бn. When he has his house, business, farms and livestock to satisfy him, why would he need Bhagav─Бn? His possessions give him what he desires. When they are lost, however, he remembers Bhagav─Бn. There is a famous saying in Kannada - saс╣Еkaс╣нa band─Бga veс╣Еkaс╣нaramaс╣Зa (Veс╣Еkaс╣нaramaс╣Зa is remembered when hardship arises). Bhagav─Бn is then given importance. That is the time for the elevation of the j─лva. We have seen this in the G─лt─Б -

caturvidh─Б bhajante m─Бс╣Г jan─Бс╕е sukс╣Ыtino’rjunaред
─Бrto jij├▒─Бsurarth─Бrth─л j├▒─Бn─л ca bharatarс╣гabhaред
BG 7.16

The first among the devotees is the afflicted.

Why did Bhagav─Бn make the merry-go-round of this world-m─Бy─Б? Why did he ensnare us in it and make us forget him? And then make us lament that we have forgotten him? Why console us who are wailing and then show us the path toward him? Why does he hide himself? Why does he make us desperate to look for him?

Such a question is yet again a distortion of our experience of m─Бy─Б. We dream when we are asleep. We mumble something by ourselves. When others surrounding us listen to it, they ask us after we have woken up - тАЬWhat were you mumbling during your sleep? Whom did you see? What happened?тАЭ Can we give them a satisfactory and consistent answer? The understanding within a dream is meaningless after we have woken up. Similar is our question after the cause of world-creation.

Parame┼Ыvara is all-powerful and all-independent. It is in the nature of power to constantly keep doing something. Power is characterised by movement. The world is created because of such a movement. Questions such as - тАЬWhat is Bhagav─БnтАЩs objective here? What might be his reason for creation?тАЭ do not arise for those who have understood the true nature of Bhagav─Бn. For those who have not, such questions exceed their mental and intellectual comprehension.

What does Bhagav─Бn need from the world? He has everything within him. He is the origin of everything. Why should he do anything?

na me p─Бrth─Бsti kartavyam triс╣гu lokeс╣гu ki├▒cana
n─Бnav─Бptamav─Бptavyam varta eva ca karmaс╣Зi
BG 3.22

Even then, Bhagav─Бn uses his power for the world and for its sustenance. Enjoying his own infinite power within himself is Bhagav─БnтАЩs l─лl─Б.

There was a rich man I knew. When all members of his household were asleep, he would enter his room with a small lantern, open his iron safe, noiselessly remove the bundles of currency notes and jewellery one by one from it, caress them fondly, count them again and again, exult at owning all of it, put all of it back again into the safe, lock it, and tie the key to his yaj├▒opav─лta^(^([1])). He experienced happiness in looking upon his wealth by himself.

It appears that Bhagav─БnтАЩs behaviour is similar. There is nothing that he needs. There is nothing new that he needs to acquire. He must have created the world when he desired to see and enjoy his own infinite powers for himself. Gauс╕Нap─Бd─Бc─Бrya says:

devasyaiс╣гa svabh─БvoтАЩyam ─Бptak─Бmasya k─Б spс╣Ыh─Б
M─Бс╣Зс╕Н┼лkya-k─Бrik─Б 1.9

The experience of oneтАЩs own power is playing with oneтАЩs Self and loving oneтАЩs Self. The same is indicated by Bhagav─Бn Vy─Бsa in his Brahmas┼лtra.

lokavattu l─лl─Бkaivalyam
Brahmas┼лtra 2.1.3

Just as people in the world do many things for their amusement, Bhagav─Бn has created the entire universe for his enjoyment. There are innumerable ways for enjoyment. Can there be a fixed method for that? Bhagav─Бn R─Бm─Бnuja in his commentary on the above s┼лtra says:

yath─Б lokeтАж.mah─Бr─Бjasya kevalal─лlaikaprayojan─Бс╕е kantuk─Бdy─Бrambh─Б dс╣Ы┼Ыyante ред tathaiva parasy─Бpi brahmaс╣Зaс╕е svasaс╣Еkalpam─Бtra-avaklс╣Ыpta-jagaj-janma-sthiti-dhvaс╣Гs─Бdi-l─лlaiva prayojanamiti niravadyam рее
тАЬJust as in the world, we see a great king engaging in a ball game just for amusement, there is no objection to the consideration that Supreme Brahma engages in creation, sustenance, destruction of the universe and other activities with no motive other than amusement.тАЭ

The babe in the cradle rolls its eyes around, shakes its arms and legs, and laughs. What might be its motive? To make us smile? To get a certificate from us? Nothing of that sort. It cannot have such selfish thoughts in its infancy. Its play is an expression of its health, a blossoming of its inner happiness, and a flow of the nectar of its bliss.

Another thing: Who is it that asks ─л┼Ыvara the question- тАЬWhy did you make the world?тАЭ Obedient servants do not pose questions such as - тАЬWhy have you left your feet dangling?тАЭ, тАЬWhy are you sitting cross-legged?тАЭ, тАЬWhy have you twisted your hand thus?тАЭ - to their comfortably seated masters. Disobedient servants do not have to be answered.

Who is it that questions ─л┼Ыvara? His servants? Or his dependents? Those who have taken refuge in him? There is a different, more important question to be answered. Whatever might be ─л┼ЫvaraтАЩs objective, what is it to you? The answer is - idle curiosity. Whatever might be ─л┼ЫvaraтАЩs objective, we are in no position to change it; neither can we escape from it. Such questions might be applicable if we had powers to reform ─л┼Ыvara or if we could promulgate a тАЬno confidenceтАЭ motion against him. Since that is not the case, the question does not arise. There is no democracy in the world of adhy─Бtma! When we cannot escape from m─Бy─Б that is a creation of ─л┼Ыvara, how can we escape from ─л┼Ыvara himself?

What is it then that we can do? Accepting our situation and trying to better it is the only strategy. The final answer to such questions is this:

kuto j─Бteyamiti te r─Бma m─Бstu vic─Бraс╣З─Б ред
im─Бс╣Г kathamahaс╣Г hanm─лtyeс╣г─Б teтАЩstu vic─Бraс╣З─Б рее
Yoga V─Бsiс╣гс╣нha 4.41

тАЬWe do not need to analyse why the world exists or what the objective for its existence is. Whatever might be the reason, we need to think about how to be liberated from this situation.тАЭ Should an ensnared bird indulge in thoughts like - тАЬLetтАЩs see. Is this net made of silk? Or cotton? Or fibre or nylon? Was it made in Bengaluru or Mumbai or Manchester?тАЭ - or should it think about how to escape from the trap?

Arjuna was directly aware of the true nature of his guru. He had seen with his own eyes that his guru was- тАЬsarvasya dh─Бt─Бramacintyar┼лpamтАЭ (the sustainer of everything, whose nature is unimaginable). He had realised with his being that his guru was тАЬ┼Ы─Б┼Ыvatadharmagopt─БтАЭ (the protector of eternal dharma). Therefore Arjuna did not ask any question about creation. If we remember these three phrases - тАЬsarvasya dh─Бt─БramтАЭ, тАЬacintyar┼лpamтАЭ, and тАЬ┼Ы─Б┼Ыvatadharmagopt─БтАЭ, several of our doubts will get resolved.

Bhagav─Бn ┼Ыr─л Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa fully understood the nature of the human psyche. This is one of the unique greatnesses of the Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣З─Бvat─Бra. He knew exactly the kinds of doubts, the hardships, the questions, and the desires that could possibly be found in the human heart. That is why the Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣З─Бvat─Бra is referred to as a complete avat─Бra. What can we gather from ArjunaтАЩs behaviour? We see that he was a doubter - one with genuine doubts, not a cavalier - but nevertheless a doubter. Certainty in knowledge is not easy to come by. Bhagav─Бn now utters the concluding statement to dispel any doubts lingering in ArjunaтАЩs mind. This is the same instruction from before.

manman─Б bhava madbhakto mady─Бj─л m─Бn-namaskuru
m─Бmevaiс╣гyasi satyan-te pratij─Бne priyo.si me рее
sarvadharm─Бnparityajya m─Бmekam ┼Ыaraс╣Зam vraja

тАЬFix your mind in me; be my devotee; worship me; bow to me. If you do this, you will attain me. You are dear to me. Therefore I promise you this. This is true.тАЭ
тАЬAbandon all the other dharmas and take refuge solely in me. I will release you from all p─Бpas and sorrows. Do not grieve.тАЭ

These uplifting and consoling words are filled with words like aham (I) and m─Бm (me). Such usages of the first person are seen in several other instructions too. Who is the subject of the first person in those mentions? Is it some man known by the name of Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa? Or an avat─Бra of Bhagav─Бn bearing that famous name? Or does that тАЬIтАЭ refer to the origin of that great caitanya whose symbol is the personality of ┼Ыr─л Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa? Wherever the first person is encountered in the G─лt─Б - such as aham, mama, m─Бm, mat, me, mayi - the subject referred to is not to be construed as human but as an expression of Parame┼Ыvara himself.

Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa, in the divine song,
refers to the all-pervading Brahma; not human,
Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa is the world-sustainer.
The name Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa is the music of worldтАЩs bosom-flute.

Bhakti is renouncing the ego

тАЬmanman─Б bhava madbhaktahтАЭ - тАЬBe my bhaktaтАЭ. The G─лt─Бch─Бrya has taught us bhakti in every chapter and verse. What is bhakti? All of us commonly consider ourselves to be bhaktas of a deity. We visit temples; chant divine names; when nothing else is possible, we say - тАЬ─л┼Ыvara is the only wayтАЭ; we spend money to perform p┼лj─Б. All of these are indicators of bhakti. But is that bhakti pure? It is bhakti that is our supreme savior. It is hence necessary to understand its nature through reflection.
Bhakti is love - love towards Bhagav─Бn that is complete and pure.

s─Б tvasmin parama-prema-r┼лp─Бред
N─Бrada-bhakti-s┼лtra

Parama here refers to love that is complete by itself and unalloyed with anything else. There is always a bit of selfishness hidden inside our bhakti. тАЬWe should trust Bhagav─Бn. Even so, we should be on our guardтАЭ - is our usual attitude. тАЬHas not ─л┼Ыvara given us an intellect? Should it not do its work? Do we not have any responsibility? Is it fine to overload Bhagav─Бn with our worries?тАЭ - such are our considerations. Discernment is definitely a part of our duty as is self-effort. So is being cautious. But the duty beyond all these is to accept the will of ─л┼Ыvara. All our discernments, adventures, and ideas yield results only because of Bhagav─БnтАЩs grace. Whether our efforts bear fruit or not is decided by providence. тАЬdaivaс╣Г caiv─Бtra pancamamтАЭ - refers to the fruits or results of our efforts. Bhakti in Bhagav─Бn is to accept the results of our efforts, though they may be against us. Faith in the divine that is oblivious to тАЬIтАЭ and does not ask - тАЬWhat happened to me? What of my effortтАЭ - is true and complete bhakti.

Bhakti and ego are mutually exclusive. They cannot co-exist. Ego cannot stand in front of bhakti. A bhaktaтАЩs ego is merely a servant of bhakti. Similarly bhakti does not enter where the ego reigns. Whatever little bhakti is displayed by an egotistical person is but a servant to his ego. Even a modicum of ego cannot be found in the mind, behaviour, and speech of someone whose bhakti is pure and complete. тАЬIt is Bhagav─Бn who is the cause of everything. Nothing happens without his order. Compared to Bhagav─БnтАЩs command, my desires and dislikes amount to arrogant overreaching. Whether I like what I get or not, it is ─л┼ЫvaraтАЩs pras─Бda that I have to calmly acceptтАЭ - such are the thoughts of a bhakta. A father is a father whether or not he gives us candies or tough love. A doctor cares for our welfare regardless of whether he gives us honey or ginger with pepper. Such is a bhaktaтАЩs trust in Bhagav─Бn; trust from which selfishness has been completely effaced. Bhakti is the destruction of I-ness. When worries such as, тАЬI, mine, what of me? Who will look after me?тАЭ are all erased without a chance for regeneration; when the mind is full of faith in Bhagav─Бn, then such a state is called bhakti - egoless bhakti.

[[Ch 18 Yoga of Single-pointed Surrender (Part 18) Source: prekshaa]]

A doubt here. “sarvadharm─Бn parityajya” (having given up all dharmas), “m─Бmekaс╣Г ┼Ыaraс╣Зaс╣Г vraja” (surrender unto Bhagav─Бn alone) - is the instruction. Fine. What is the intent behind - тАЬsurrender after having given up all dharmasтАЭ? IsnтАЩt surrender a dharma too? Or is surrender an adharma? If the verse had “anya-dharm─Бn” (giving up other dharmas) instead of “sarva-dharm─Бn” (giving up all dharmas), this doubt would not have arisen.
Retaining the verse as is, if “sarvadharm─Бn” and “┼Ыaraс╣Зaс╣Г vraja” have to be reconciled, the former has to be interpreted as “leaving all the controversial dharmas of the world aside” and the latter as “take refuge in a a special path, a dharma beyond worldly dharmas, an adhidharma.”

jagamirpannaс╣Г dharmaс╣Г
jaga ninagiradandu sarvam─Бtmaikamay─Бm рее
тАЬDharma exists for as long as the world exists.
Once the world ceases to exist for you, the oneness of the Self is all there is.тАЭ

Arjuna was not like ordinary men in two aspects. 1. In doubting. 2. In renunciation. In the first aspect, he had more doubts than usual. He repeatedly asked questions in every chapter. He would trust the answer that Bhagav─Бn gave at that instant. But the same trust would disappear when encountering another topic. Doubts and questions again and again. For such a person, ┼Ы─Бstric testimony, reasoning, and arguments would not be sufficient. The first help he needed was the strengthening of his faith. He had more trust in his love for Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa than in the ┼Ы─Бstras and reasoning. ┼Ъr─л Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa himself had witnessed this. It was hence the sv─БmiтАЩs desire to transform ArjunaтАЩs trust that had arisen as an effect of friendship and affection into divine faith. Therefore, he said, “Arjuna, you do not need the various exertions of inquiring into karmayoga, s─Бс╣Еkhyayoga, dhy─Бnayoga, sanny─Бsayoga, the dharma of different varс╣Зas, the duty of your clan, the duty of your social station, or worshipping the saguс╣Зa and nirguс╣Зa aspects of Brahma. These confusions will not give you peace of mind. Do you not have faith in me? Do as I ask you. Let things be the way they are. You do not need the hardships of reasoning. Act with faith in me; I will take on the burden of protecting you from harm. Set aside your anxiety about the statements of the ┼Ы─Бstras and the actions of society. Your welfare is my responsibility. “m─Бmekaс╣Г ┼Ыaraс╣Зaс╣Г vraja”. If devotion in the divine is total and firm, it will satisfy all shortcomings, remove any defects and bring to the devotee all possible well-being. This is above anything else. Therefore it is above all ordinary dharmas and is adhidharma - the crown of all dharmas. It is composed of pure faith and nothing else. It does not require external testimonials or inquiries or reasoning. ┼Ъaraс╣З─Бgati or surrender is unquestioned and complete faith in Kс╣Ыс╣гс╣Зa. There is no further analysis needed.

anyath─Б ┼Ыaraс╣Зaс╣Г n─Бsti tvameva ┼Ыaraс╣Зaс╣Г mama ред

This emotional ecstasy of bhakti has a few levels. Self-surrender or self-dedication is the peak of the edifice of bhakti. It is also known as prapatti (total surrender) or ┼Ыaraс╣З─Бgati.

In such bhakti, notions of “I”, “my rights”, “my share”, “my fate”, “my power”, or “my will” should be completely erased. The mental mode of “I” should have completely gone. Needless to say, it is quite difficult to ascend to such a state.

A particle of ego always lingers around in our bhakti. We reason - “Bhagav─Бn might bestow his boon on us; he might not too!”, “Bhagav─Бn is known to give us what we do not want in addition to what we asked for” - and dilute our bhakti. This is not complete self-surrender. As our bhakti towards Bhagav─Бn is mixed, so too are the boons we receive. Rice mixed with stones might be boiled in milk, but the resultant kheer will continue to have stones in it.

If our happiness has to be complete, the first prerequisite is the effacement of the ego. When we study poetry, we need to lose ourselves in the poetтАЩs creation. This is total immersion. If, however, our sceptical mind pops up every moment with - тАЬletтАЩs see how the poet has written thisтАЭ, enjoyment of the poem - be it of whatever level - will be incomplete. The same goes for music experience. If we keep watching out for where the singer misses a note, where he stumbles in his pitch or where he misses a beat - even if the quality of singing is worth a rupee, our enjoyment will only be of a paisaтАЩs worth. Such a situation is not right for either the artist or the audience. To experience a work of art completely - be it poetry or music or a sculpture - we must first surrender completely to it by losing our ego.

When ego effacement is necessary for even art experience, is there any doubt in considering it imperative for Brahma-experience?

Numerous examples in the pur─Бс╣Зas - the liberation of Gajendra, the taking away of the GopisтАЩ garments - emphasise that our self-surrender to Bhagav─Бn has to be complete and not half-hearted. All selfish feelings must be emptied out in the presence of Bhagav─Бn. Not even an iota of bashfulness, arrogance, obstinacy, or pride should be present. Much like a baby lying in its motherтАЩs lap, the bhakta should surrender to Bhagav─Бn; a disciple to his guru; and a reader to the poem - for only then is the gain complete.

Does human agency have no value then? There definitely is value in it during human effort - discernment on how exactly to apply effort and how much energy to expend on it. However, the result is in the domain of daiva. The pinnacle of human effort is in the acceptance of divine will. The apex of human discernment is in giving up anxiety about results.

No great experience is possible for one who does not know how to give oneself up completely. Surrender through unthinking faith is a kind of adhi-dharma that is fit for one racked with doubt.

There is another kind of adhi-dharma that befits one full of j├▒─Бna.

As difficult as it was for ArjunaтАЩs intellect to come to a conclusion, renunciation came easily to his mind. Was that not the subject of the entire first chapter? He had no desire for anything then. All his existing desires had dissolved into nothingness. He had nothing to do with any dharma. dharma is needed for the following benefits for its performer:

  1. To remove sorrow 2. To gain pleasure 3. To purify oneself

These three benefits do not apply in the least to one who has no feeling of тАЬIтАЭ or тАЬmeтАЭ. Arjuna had said - тАЬna k─Бс╣Еkс╣гe vijayaс╣Г kс╣Ыс╣гс╣ЗaтАЭ, тАЬkiс╣Г bhogair-j─лvitena v─БтАЭ. He had no desires. He had no fear other than that of p─Бpa. For such a person, the befitting instruction is that of the Self in all. A person with such knowledge can act anywhere while experiencing his own Self. At the beginning of the teaching, we see in the second chapter:

trai-guс╣Зya-viс╣гay─Б ved─Б nis-traiguс╣Зyo bhav─Бrjuna ред
nirdvandvo nitya-sattva-stho niryoga-kс╣гema ─Бtmav─Бn рее
BG 2.45
тАЬThe Vedas are for those who are controlled by the three guс╣Зas. The Vedas are of the form of dh─Бrmic rules and injunctions. Those who are controlled by sattva, rajas and tamas have to perform vaidika activities to rid themselves of the impurity of the guс╣Зa-triad. Arjuna, go beyond the three guс╣Зas. Then, the Vedas and external vaidika activities become unnecessary for you. Go beyond the opposites of worldly life; be an epitome of sattva (good qualities). This indeed is adhi-dharma. General dharma is virtue or good qualities formed through the adherence to external instructions and injunctions of the Vedas and ┼Ы─Бstras. Adhi-dharma, however, is virtue or goodness that flows and spreads by itself without any need for external instructions or actions.

тАЬGive up all dharmas and take refuge in me alone.тАЭ

Is not this instruction for taking refuge a kind of dharma? Is it adharma? Is not the dharma of surrender one of the dharmas that have to be given up?

Taking refuge in Bhagav─Бn is neither dharma nor adharma. It is beyond both of those; it is adhidharma.

The same actions and behaviours that are considered dharma while being obedient to the dicta of the Veda, become adhidharma when they happen by themselves without the need for any external rules or injunctions.

In the above G─лt─Б verse, we have m─Бm + ekam + ┼Ыaraс╣Зam + vraja.

[[Ch 18 Yoga of Single-pointed Surrender (Part 19) Source: prekshaa]]

How can there be adharma for one established in the origin of dharma? For such a person, there is no other object or being than Brahma. Whence p─Бpa for him? The ocean wipes out the many colours, tastes, and characteristics of the waters of the rivers that meet it - merging them all together into an indivisible oneness. The ocean of Brahma similarly extinguishes the individual characteristics of those who take refuge in it, transforming them into an indivisible unity.
The rasa of Brahma is an adhi-rasa (a rasa beyond worldly rasas) that harmonises every rasa, anti-rasa or non-rasa. It transforms stone to sugar; and iron to gold. The defects of the one absorbed in Brahma are already dissolved.

j├▒─Бn─Бgniс╕е sarvakarm─Бс╣Зi bhasmas─Бtkurute tath─Б рее
BG 4.37

The ┼Ыruti counsels the same. The Taittir─лya Upaniс╣гad says this.

He who has experienced the bliss of Brahma fears nothing. He does not fret - тАЬAlas! I did not perform any good deeds!тАЭ or тАЬAlas! I performed this evil deed!тАЭ - anxiously. He who knows the nature of Brahma keeps himself in good cheer. Entrusting both puс╣Зya and p─Бpa to Brahma, the origin of all the j─лvas, he enjoys self-contentment.
This is the state of one in adhi-dharma. Whatever he does - even if considered as a p─Бpa from the view of the world or the ┼Ы─Бstras - is not truly a p─Бpa for him, for he who is established in Brahma has neither the seed of p─Бpa nor selfish thoughts and desires in him. He sees the Universal Self everywhere and therefore his acts are directed towards general welfare, not otherwise.

The dh─Бrmic person, subject to vaidika rules or his guruтАЩs orders, societal traditions or other external factors, walks the path of the good either out of fear or desire.
However, the one established in adhi-dharma follows the path of the good without any such fears or restrictions or expectation of rewards because of the practice of seeing his own Self everywhere. He works for the welfare of the world without the need of a prescription or proscription.
The knower of the Self is mentioned in the third chapter on Karma Yoga.

yastv─Бtmaratireva sy─Бd-─Бtma-tс╣Ыpta┼Ыca m─Бnavaс╕е.
─Бtmanyeva ca santuс╣гс╣нas-tasya k─Бryam na vidyateрз╖рз╖

Here, k─Бrya refers to obligatory activity - something that has to be done because of external restrictions. тАЬk─Бryam na vidyateтАЭ - refers to some activity that has become imperative either because it has been mandated by someone else or because of a fear of punishment, or due to an expectation of benefit. As the knower of the Self is a personification of benevolence and has no ego, whatever he does is independent activity that results in nothing other than universal well-being. He is free to do something or not to do it. Whatever he does or does not do is not from an egoistic perspective but from that of the Universal Self.

Such a person is described by the ┼Ы─Бstras as an aty─Б┼Ыrami (one who is beyond all the ─Б┼Ыramas) or an avadh┼лta (one who has cast off everything).

(The yogi who has gone beyond the ─Б┼Ыramas and varс╣Зas and is established in his Self, is known as an ati-varс╣З─Б┼Ыram─л and an avadh┼лta)

Another verse is as follows.

tyaja dharmamadharmaс╣Г ca tyaja saty─Бnс╣Ыte ubhe ред

тАЬGive up dharma - of the form of external rules and injunctions - that is mandated by the ┼Ы─Бstras; give up adharma too. Give up the practice of speaking truth as well as untruth. Consider these opposites as mere modifications of name and form in creation and escape from them. Go beyond opposites by the constant remembrance of the l─лl─Бs of Brahma. Finally, renounce the notion of тАЬIтАЭ through which you renounced all this.тАЭ

Renunciation is also an activity. Any activity has a doer. It is the notion of doership that is ego. Even that should be dissolved! The тАЬIтАЭ should cease to exist.

j├▒─Бn─Бmс╣Ыtena tс╣Ыptasya kс╣Ыtakс╣Ыtyasya yoginaс╕е ред
naiv─Бsti ki├▒cit-kartavyam asti cenna sa tattvavit рее

(There is no obligatory duty for the Yogi satisfied with the nectar of knowledge, who has accomplished what needs to be done. If he thinks that he has obligatory duty, he does not know the truth)

All restrictions of dharma are prerequisites to the knowledge of Brahma. What was an obligation before the dawn of Brahma-knowledge becomes a joyous pastime after it.

vyavah─Бro laukiko v─Б ┼Ы─Бstr─лyo v─БтАЩnyath─Бpi v─Бред

(For me, who is not the doer and who is unattached,

An ancient stotra known as the ┼Ыuk─Бс╣гс╣нakam enumerates these marks of an avadh┼лta:

bhed─Бbhedau sapadi galitau puс╣Зyap─Бpe vi┼Ы─лrс╣Зe

┼Ыabd─Бt─лtaс╣Г triguс╣Зarahitaс╣Г pr─Бpya tattv─Бvabodhaс╣Г
